TRAVEL

--------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1867-08-18
Title: 1867 August 18 and 20, Newport, to Father

Newport, 8th mo., 18th. 1867.

Dear Father
I   thought I would write to thee this afternoon, in case I   should not get a chance before the steamer leaves.  Not that   I’m so very busy, but since I lie down every noon when I get   home from bathing in time, and in the evenings we have Mary   Williams’ lamp incased in the same little plain bonnet so   that we have no chance either to write or read after dark,   unless we take a lamp and go up stairs.  
On 6th day we   ordered the boat, but were not able to go out, on account of   the rain.  In the morning Alfred had the pleasure of   witnessing a little sail boat upset, the man who was in it   managed to get on the bottom untill a sail boat came to his   assistance.  In the afternoon the rain slackened some and we   made up quite a large party and hired the omnibus to go to   the south Shore and see if the horn spouted, we had George   and thecarriage beside.  When we got there the horn did not spout   at all, but the waves were very fine, and towards the latter   part of the time, when the sun came out, very beautiful the   sun shone on the spray making nearly half of a rainbow.  We   staid till quite late stopping on the way home at the   boathouse, the sea there was not nearly so fine though.  On   seventh day morning we made up a small fishing expedition,   consisting of Alf, Hazen, Tom Longstreth, George and myself.   We went about a mile above the poor house anchoring in a   little cove near the rail-road.  We had quite good luck, and   caught about 24 fish, including 2 star fish, several   Chaucksus, and one very fat eel, which I had the   gratification of catching.  Since we have been here we have   seen two very curious fish, one called an “old maid,” which   is about 1 foot long and white underneath; the other is a   “swell fish,” and looks very much like other fish, except   when you turn it over and rub it gentlyit becomes inflated and is puffed out like a small   air-baloon, it is about 6 inches long.  The fishermen on the   point have had a reading room and small library established   for their benefit in a back room looking out on the bay at   “Godderds,” (I don[t] know whether I have spelt it right or   not, but if thee pronounces it the way its spelt thee will   know where I mean) by a Miss or Mrs. Gibbs.  They take the   daily and some of the illustrated papers, and I noticed a   number of the “British Gardiner” I think it was on the   table.  Well to come to the point at once; uncle Harry was   invited to deliver a sort of a lecture to them on last 6th   day evening.  George Merrit seemed very desirous that the   ladies would come up and hear the discourse, which some of   them did.  The speech was very grand the subject being   “Water,” I dont know whether the fishermen properly   appreciated it, since I heard one remark afterwards that,   “it wouldtake a purty smart man to follow him.”  I believe uncle   Harry proposes to deliver some more during this week on   Light and Air.  20th 3rd day.  Yesterday we took a sail over   to the Dumplings and landed those that wanted to, the rest   of us going on down, towards Bever Tail.  This morning we   proposed sailing around Canonicut, recruits came in slowly   since they had been all finished by the expedition to the   Light ship, however as it turned out there was not enough   wind and we had to defer it untill tomorrow, and go bathing   instead.  This afternoon mother contemplates going sailing   if George thinks we are not going to have a squall; at   present it looks very much like rain.  I suppose Mother has   told thee all about the storm they have been having at home.   I hope we’ll not have it here.  And now since I have used up   my sheet I will stop.  affecty thy son
T.P. Cope Jr


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Rachel Drinker
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865

Title: [1805-1809?] to Henry Cope, Weston

Dear Henry

I have been writing or rather Scrawling to   William and Caroline, & thought I would Stain a little more   paper, how is our dear Francis He has had an afficting   trying time, I hope it will be the last, and thee has had   thy Share in simpathising with him, and attending on him   which I hope will have its use thee sertainly will have thy   reward for thy kind attention to an afficted brother, give   my best love to him I want much to see you, I expect to see   the in a few weeks I hope I Shan’t be disapointed we are all   faver’d with Health, the Rebeckah is come and I expect has   made a good voige I dont know of any thing new to tell you,   with Desires for your wellfare I remain your Affectinate   grangmother

Rachel DrinkerFor
Henry Cope
Weston

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Caroline Mary Cope Lewis:  1865-1953
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1911-04-02
Title: 1911 April 2, Awbury, to Lilly

Awbury –
April 2.nd.

Dearest Lilly –
I don’t   know what thee has thought of me for not thanking thee   before for thy Most generous Contribution to our Collection   for the Colored Summer Home –  it came on the day of the   evening when Jonnie was stricken. & I forgot about it   entirely until the following Tuesday, the day of our   Collection, & I should have sat downright then & written. but Anna was writing to thee & I sent   a message. & thought I would wait until I had more time to   write a longer letter.  but that time has scarce seemed to   come until now!  We have just finished dining at Mother’s –   & while Mother is engaged in her usual occupation with the   dishes in the pantry. I had sat down in the library with Tom   & Will who are both reading. to write to thee.  Anna was so   long ingetting her letter off to thee.  I imagine the Contents told   everything up to within a day or two –  Chellie is very   wonderful,– perfectly calm & like herself –  but she looks   badly – & I fear as the days go on & she realizes more &   more what has happened. that she will show it even more –   but she is blessed with four devoted Sons who are looking   after her in every way –  Miss Richardson of Course, as thee   knows is with them – & they kept theNurse, whom they had for Jonnie, until yesterday.  Anna too   keeps well. & so far is entirely natural – but Miss   Richardson watches her like a hawk. & never lets her be   alone long – they want her to go away.– but she does not   want to.– & Miss R. told me yesterday that they would not   insist upon it – which I am glad of – for I think we cannot   always judge what is best for others at these   times.
Mother, I am thankfulto say, is very well – & with Anna & my being here   alternately she has gotten along very well with the new maid   whom Anna got for her – but of course she is not a Companion   – or a trained nurse – and I think we are going to be able   to get Susan Stewart out next week for a few weeks until she   (Susan) goes to the Hospital –  We may be able to keep her   until Mother goes to North East, but thatI Cannot say –  Chellie was in hopes that Mother would   [heed] this nurse who has been with her this week.  & if she   liked her to have her go to Northeast with her.  but Mother   was strongly opposed to it –  I think largely because she   was a stranger – now we had proposed Miss Moses’ name.  &   she wants her –  So I expect she will be gotten –  I had had   a talk with her. & she is entirely willing to undertake it   if she is wanted. & both Mother & Tomseem to want it – tho’ Tom says he wants nothing except what   Mother wants –  The trouble is about Miss Moses she will   have to [leave] Mother to be home by the first of October –    I am quite sure she will be a very devoted nurse – and I   think it will be very hard for Mother to let her go –  I   only wish we could get a permanency –  Before Jonnie died   Miss R. had told Mother that she would come back to her in   the fall. & I think Mother ishoping for that –  but I feel that is not to be counted   upon.
Please forgive such a lenghty epistle –  Mother has   now returned from the pantry – the men have departed & I   must say goodbye to thee –
Please give my love to Ellie &   much for thyself –
from thy loving sister
[Care]

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1867-08-26
Title: 1867 August 26, Newport, to father

Newport 8th. mo. 26th. 1867.

Dear father
I rec’d   thy letter 5th day morning.  Thy accounts quite make me wish   to see England some time although I dont know that that time   will ever come.  On 4th day we sailed round Canonicut, and   since Lilly says she has given thee a condensed account of   our trip, I will copy our log by way of variety.  The   officers were: Capt. Geo. F Merritt, 1st mate T.P. Cope Jr   2nd mate A Cope Jr; Seaman T.K. Longstreth, Cabin boy F.H.   Cope.  Steward M. C Collins.  Cook V. Hartshorne and 6   passengers, A Newhall, M Newhall, M Farnum, H Carter, M.   Collins, & E.S. Cope.
Log of the Canonicut Party – Yacht   “TCope [Deferred]”
(Rations limited)
Started from the   pier at 8 1/2, A.M., arrived at the lighthouse at 8.40.   there met M.C. Cope and party in a row boat, who wished us   joy,and desired us to report all new discoveries; soon after we   commenced telling fortunes.  2 m. of 9 o’clock saw a   porpoise on the starboard side.  9.22. off fort Adams,   weather, calm, thin canopy of clouds, at this moment it was   proposed to “put more steam on.”  Three persons forward of   the “Lobster Box.”  progress, “slow but awfully sure.”  10.   o’clock, interesting information concerning the compass, by   Capt. Merritt.  surf seen at Bever Tail, fears entertained   for the health of the party.  Some excitement caused by the   appearance of two fish, which produced restlessness on the   part of the cabin boy –  10.11. opposite the Dumplings.  11   o’clock opposite Castle Hill the game of quintettes played   with interest by the 1st mate, cook, and several of the   passengers; the steward seiged with headache – at this time   doubts were expressed by the captain as to the probability   of the winds changing before 6 P.M. weather still calm.  [8]   m after 11. met a sailing vessel commanded by captain Henry   Merritt, rowed by the capt. and sculled by Henry Merritt jr   who hailed us, and threw a small lobster into the boat one   of the passengers was badly bitten which caused great   excitement untill she was rescued from the jaws of the   carnivorous creature.  11 1/2 A.M. Slight windthe South and visible, stood off to welcome it.  Party   regaled themselves with rations. 12. M. South wind   continues.  candy handed.  Met a schooner and were saluted   by a dog on board.  Long swells, health good.  12.10.   conversation on the weather prohibited– a number of the   passengers retired to rest – Cabin boy reclining on a   passenger–  cook on the dinner basket–  1st mate absorbed in   a book.  12.45. Point Judith lighthouse in sight.  After   serious consideration it was decided to pursue our journey   on which account three cheers were given.  12.50. Passing   Bever Tail.  three more cheers – passengers happy – saluted   by the horn and a towel was waved to us, which compliment   was returned passengers waving handkerchiefs.  2. P.M.   Dinner – great dispute on the subject of ringing the   triangle.  2.45. from “Lobster Box” end–  dinner   accomplished satisfactorily leaving the voyagers in a   quiescent state of mind–  dinner consisted of 9 courses   closed with sour-drops–  opposite M. Williams’- Bay   comparatively speaking very rough!  Fast passing Wickford –   Slight excitement Fortunes being told again aft. The 1st   mate has just restored the cabin to order, after dinner.    Aft becoming very impudent.  Bow hair dressing.  1st matesweeping and thereby discomboberating all – 2.55. Patience   in sight.  sentiment in the bow, 3.12. Approaching the end   of Canonicut Greenwich off the larboard bow.  Patience and   Rocky Pt. ahead.  the breeze delightful, and all of the   party very comfortable, some reading, some working zephyr   work.  3.20. Rounding the north end of Canonicut.  Three   cheers given by all the party.  3.35. P.M. Rounding   Canonicut.  Newport in view – on our homeward trip – breeze   good.  some of the party wishing to land we are going to (we   did’nt) 3.38. Met the Providence steamboat- Needless anxiety   on the part of the passengers.  Now dashing gaily towards   Newport.  3.55 Proceeding fondly – just played games of   authors and consequences.  3 m. of 5.P.M. off the   Lighthouse. health good.  Fine breeze- Band tuning up for a   song before we reach the pier.  Arrived at the pier at   5.P.M.  On first day evening we took a walk to Tammany Hill.   we started after a 6 o’clock tea but were not able to get   there untill dark or dusk.  It is the first time I was ever   there.  We saw the lights at Point Judith, the Light Ship,   Bever Tail and the Break water.  Yesterday was splendidlyclear.  In the morning we took a short float, I cant call it   a sail there wasn’t any wind, after which we went bathing.    In the afternoon I made up a small sailing party consisting   of Alice Carter, Abby Newhall, Tom Longstreth and Alfred, we   went out to the Dumplings and landed, & afterwards came back   to take Caroline Mary her first sail.  She could’nt have had   a more pleasant evening it neither too cold nor too warm, &   there was a splendid breeze.  We went around Rose Island and   got back in good season.  though not strictly obeying her   mothers instructions about being home at half past 6.  This   morning we went bathing as usual and also engaged the boat,   Alfred preferring to go to Coddingtons Cove to bathing.    Thee will observe that I’ve been getting about as much good   out of boating as possible this season.  Since we arrived   Alf has become a staunch friend of Geo. Merritt’s and Hazen   of Geo. Barlow’s. Its quite remarkable how devoted Alf is,   he spends the big parts of his time at the reading room with   George.  This morning I got a new key fitted, formy valise, having lost the other since my arrival.  We were   not able to mail these letters in time to go by the [La---]   so they will have to take their chance by going via New   York.  There are 24 folks going to Philadelphia the night we   go, which will make a pretty effectual change in Mary   Williams’ boarders, and there will be no one left but Tom   Longstreth to do the honors of the occasion.  We are rather   puzzled as to what to do if we were left by the 7 o’clock   train from New York, since the 10 o’clock train has been   taken off the line.  We will have to run the risk, I   suppose, of getting the 8.40, Washington train, stopped at   Frankford.  Having run out of news and since mother is also   writing I will stop.
affecty thy son
T.P. Cope Jr.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Rachel Drinker

Date: 1806-02-08
Title: 1806 February 8 to Henry Cope, Westown, PA

Philada 2nd mo 8th [1806]

Dear Henry

I receivd   thy letter, and am Pleasd to hear that there is a day set   apart for letter writing as I hope we shall hear oftener   from you, as writing is next to seing and talking with you,   to tell you (for I include Frances) that I love you, and   long to see you, would be like a tale twice told,   

your Cousin H D wrote from New Castle the 5th of the   2d moth that he was just setting of and expected to be at   sea in 48 hours, was much pleasd with the Captain, they were   detaind 2 weeks by the Ice, He seemd to go of in pretty good   sperits, as he went with the approbation of his Friends, I   have the pleasure to inform the that he appeard to be in an   improving way, I hope he will be preferred and kept in the   road that leads to peace

I am glad to hear that the   is contented, and willing to stay and get all the   instruction the can, I hope thee will get through all the   branches so as to come home next Summerthe river is froze over and I saw a number of people on it   as I return[e]d from Meeting this morning

Arther has   not got into any Buiseness yet, & is Desir[ou]s of paying   you a viset If he can get a Horse.

your Father &   mother is well, Caroline & allfred very lively, mother is   well of for help—Cousin Lydia is with me still and Sends her   love to the and Francis as does [Catherine] except of a   large Portion From your loveing grandmother

Rachel   Drinker

mary’s Father and Mother & Brother have been   commited to jail on suspion of Murder how it will go with   them we can’t tell now I think I have told you all the news   good and badHenry Cope
Westown
give my love to Friend 
Sharpless

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Julia K. Reeve
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1858-08-04
Title: 1858 August 4, to Ruth Anna Cope


Awbury 8 mo 4th [1858]
Fourth day night

Dear   Nanny,

Its frightfully late, and if I say so--thee   may be sure it is late; my eyelids have told me so sometime   since, and bed, over yonder, looks wonderous inviting--but   remembering Uncle's last injunction to write-- I begin forth   with, though thee must'nt expect much from sleepy folks--I   only am going to deliver Uncles message, which I have tried   to remember and transcribe exactly in his words-- "We only   desired thy return with Edward Biddle, thinking thee might   not have another opportunity for some time, if thee chooses   to run the risk of another escort do so--" I have just been   repeating this to Cousin Frank & he says, oh tell Anna there   will be some way of her getting home and to stay longer, if   she wishes it--We
do not want thee at home till thee gets better--and get   along pretty well without thee, I don't suppose Aunt Rachel   fares quite so well as if thee were here--but I do try to do   my best--Cousin Elizbt's letter of last eving told thee she   was'nt quite well--she is some better to-day--and I hope   tomorrow will be better still--(Oh my! There--I've actually   fallen asleep over my letter--thee wont feel much   complimented I'm afraid) Tell Clemmy we got her first   letter--and think we are very remiss not to have   ex[patiated] on its sweetness for [-]
Wellm [--rsis]   Mother is on--some of us have called upon her yet--somebody   must tomorrow, as she returns home Seventh day.
George   sends his love--and I expect the folks generally would,
I forgot to ask them--
Farewell--I'm so dreadfully   sleepy--thine Julie--

Oh my! I must wake up and tell   thee we got letters this afternoon--Cos Thos expected to   start in a sailing vessel from Havre on the 24 or 26th--So   he's on the ocean now--tossing about--Poor fellow! Frank was   travelling about in Scotland when last heard from, and   cousin Thos has advised him to return in a steamer thinking   he could not reach Havre time enough to sail with   him--Is'ent this too bad--to come home this way,   piece-meal--Cos Thos seems real blue--but rejoicing at the   thoughts of home. he cannot be here before 30 days, Uncle   says,
what a long time to wait--Is'ent it-- The [----] of love to   Clemmy and Aunt Susan--and all the rest--tell the two former   I hope they are attending to their [-obes]--the 29th is most   here--and they're both going to have written   invitations--they're names are down on the list--but the   invitations are not written yet--
Anna thee must come   home prepared to be very bright, and help me to remember my   friends those to whom I must send cards--Cousin John thinks   he cannot have his children now--tho he would like to go up   for thee very well, if they [---] well--They are very   restless at nights--We expect Uncle Edward 6th or 7th   day.--


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1867-07-28
Title: 1867 July 28, Laurel House, to Father

Laurel House
7th mo. 28th. 1867.

Dear Father
Lilly and Chelly having been keeping up such an active correspondence by the last two steamers, I thought I would reserve my efforts untill they had got through. 
We received a letter from uncle Tom inclosing a letter from thee informing us of the loss of thy masticators, it      would have been remarkably unfortunate if thee had not had      an extra set with thee.  I hope by this time thee is      enjoying thyself on terra firma, but since the difference of      time between where thee is and where we are is so great, we      find it hard to guess what thee is about.  We received letters from home last night, dated the 25th., saying they   were all well and preparing to leave for Newport on 5th day.   Mother had also received a letter from thee mailed at   Halifax
On last 6th day we rode to Stony Clove, an   entirely new place to me, about 10 miles distant.  The road   is quite rough, and runs between two mountains, one of which   rises almost perpendicularly about 1000 ft, as near as we   could judge, and on each side there are large rocks under   which we found ice: they say the sun never gets there and   the ice under the rocks never melts during the summer.  On   approaching this place the air becomes perceptably cooler   and on leaving it becomes warm again.  We took dinner at a   little farm house and although it was plain weenjoyed it very much.  After dinner we had to leave right   away for home.  Going back we had a splendid view of those   distant mountains you see on your way to the Plauterkill   Clove.
Yesterday morning we, that is Tom Stokes, Harry,   some other gentlemen and myself, walked down to Bastion   Falls to take a bath, thee remembers what a fine basin there   is at the foot of the falls, well it was there we went in;   the water was pretty cool on first going in but after we had   been in a little while, and had kicked around a good bit we   got quite warm and all in a glow.  We went under the fall   where it hit the rocks for a second time, but even there the   water stung like hail-stones, and I preferredthe pool to getting such a warming as that.  In the      afternoon we walked over to the Mountain House to see the      view, on starting it was beautifully clear but when we had      gone about half way, two clouds, very considerately, came      rolling down upon us, one from North and one from South      mountain, and by the time we got to the precipice both the      view and ourselves were completely mistified; we accordingly      went into the House and got weighed, and since thee will not      object to hearing how much some of the members of thy      immediate family weigh, I will give thee part of the      table:
R.R.C.  125 lbs.   E.S.C.  98 lbs.   T.P.C.  90      lbs.     Rachel has gained 7 lbs. since last sum- mer, and its becoming quite dreadful; I'm afraid, if she      goes on gaining, we will be obliged to have her put up in a      barrel and roll her home from Newport.  Tom Stokes, Ellie,      Madjie, and Walter are going home tomorrow morning: the rest      of us expect to leave here fourth day and go to Albany, we      will stay there that night, and go to Boston the next day;      leaving Boston 6th. day afternoon we will arrive at Newport      in time for tea.  I suppose mother has told thee that she      succeeded in engaging both the Georges during our stay      there.  The weather here has been very warm and showery; to      day it is very pleasant but it has been so very showery we      were afraid to try going to walk. Aunt Lizzie received two letters from the Adirondacks to      day one from cousin Clemmy and one from aunt Annie, giving      an account of a trip which they had taken to lake Placid by      the way of John Brown's grave; aunt Annie said the grave was      very plain, there was a tombstone with some engraving on it      and on a boulder nearby was the plain inscription "John      Brown - 1859."  She also said cousin Clemmy was a good deal      stronger and was able to bear fatigue as well as the rest of      them  They were both very much surprised to hear of thy      sudden leaving for England.  Lilly and Chelly send their      love.  We are all well and have had a most splendid time      considering that our "pa" is on the other side of the Atlantic and now having given thee   all the news I can remember I will   stop.
affectionately
thy son Thos P. Cope Jr


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Rachel Drinker
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1806-06-19
Title: 1806 June 19 to Henry and Francis, Weston

6th mo 19th 1806.
Dear Henry & Francis
I have been to   meeting, cald at your house, after it broke up your dear   mother handed me a letter from Francis,  she was so kind as   to send me Henrys last letter, where I was affection[ate]ly   rememberd and expressing a desire that I should not forget   you no be asurd I never Shall while I retain my sences, I   have Had a great deal of trouble since I saw you  I have   seen a dear loving Daughter go before me,.  to enjoy the   fruits of a well Spent life, I Continue with poor Uncle and   Johnny, thay request me not to leave them, we have had   pleasent accounts of the Conduct of of your & Cousins, and   are in dayly expectation of seeing them, poor lads they will   be much affected when thay come, they will not be likely to   hear of the chang that has taken place since they left us   till they arive.  I want very much to see you, I hope you   will come and pay us a visit, I am still Favoured with   Health, and that you may enjoy that Blessing is the Desire   of your affectinate Grandmother
Rachel DrinkerDear Cousins

Our dear Grandmother is Kind enough to   permit me to add a few lines to her letter–  I wish it was   in my power to communicate to you something that would   afford pleasure.  But alas!  I have lived to see the   melancholy period that death has seperated from me one of   the best of mothers, whose affection I believe I possessed;   and that I loved her with sincere affection, affords me no   small share of consolation–  She suffered much during her   illness, but such was her Christian fortitude that she never   discovered the least impatience, and constantly maintained   her usual cheerful serenity of mind, which was her   characteristic through a life of trials.  It was painful to   see her suffer so much bodily pain, but infinitly more so to   see her breath her last, a[l]though she suffered not the   pangs of death, but passed from this terrestrial world to   one where peace, happiness and pleasure reign triumphantly;   and where she now enjoys the blissful harvest of a spotless   and well spent life–  Such has been the immutable decree of   heaven to deprive me of an affectionate Mother and you an   affectionate Aunt– We are still blest with having our dear   Grandmother to cheer us–  She enjoysher usual health, which I hope she may enjoy for years to   come–
The last letter we received from Arthur states that   he and Cousin Henry are both well, and expect to leave the   West Indies very shortly; we of course expect them   daily–
Uncle is at present in good health, and I hope   will long continue so; here I must close this short epistle   and hope that I will see you before long –  I remain your   affectionate
cousin
John D Thomas6 mo. 19th 1806
Henry Cope
Weston6th mo 19th 1806.
Dear Henry & Francis
I have been to   meeting, cald at your house, after it broke up your dear   mother handed me a letter from Francis,  she was so kind as   to send me Henrys last letter, where I was affection[ate]ly   rememberd and expressing a desire that I should not forget   you no be asurd I never Shall while I retain my sences, I   have Had a great deal of trouble since I saw you  I have   seen a dear loving Daughter go before me,.  to enjoy the   fruits of a well Spent life, I Continue with poor Uncle and   Johnny, thay request me not to leave them, we have had   pleasent accounts of the Conduct of of your & Cousins, and   are in dayly expectation of seeing them, poor lads they will   be much affected when thay come, they will not be likely to   hear of the chang that has taken place since they left us   till they arive.  I want very much to see you, I hope you   will come and pay us a visit, I am still Favoured with   Health, and that you may enjoy that Blessing is the Desire   of your affectinate Grandmother
Rachel DrinkerDear Cousins

Our dear Grandmother is Kind enough to   permit me to add a few lines to her letter–  I wish it was   in my power to communicate to you something that would   afford pleasure.  But alas!  I have lived to see the   melancholy period that death has seperated from me one of   the best of mothers, whose affection I believe I possessed;   and that I loved her with sincere affection, affords me no   small share of consolation–  She suffered much during her   illness, but such was her Christian fortitude that she never   discovered the least impatience, and constantly maintained   her usual cheerful serenity of mind, which was her   characteristic through a life of trials.  It was painful to   see her suffer so much bodily pain, but infinitly more so to   see her breath her last, a[l]though she suffered not the   pangs of death, but passed from this terrestrial world to   one where peace, happiness and pleasure reign triumphantly;   and where she now enjoys the blissful harvest of a spotless   and well spent life–  Such has been the immutable decree of   heaven to deprive me of an affectionate Mother and you an   affectionate Aunt– We are still blest with having our dear   Grandmother to cheer us–  She enjoysher usual health, which I hope she may enjoy for years to   come–
The last letter we received from Arthur states that   he and Cousin Henry are both well, and expect to leave the   West Indies very shortly; we of course expect them   daily–
Uncle is at present in good health, and I hope   will long continue so; here I must close this short epistle   and hope that I will see you before long –  I remain your   affectionate
cousin
John D Thomas6 mo. 19th 1806
Henry Cope
Weston

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  John D.  Thomas
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1806-06-19
Title: 1806 June 19 to Henry and Francis, Weston

6th mo 19th 1806.
Dear Henry & Francis
I have been to   meeting, cald at your house, after it broke up your dear   mother handed me a letter from Francis,  she was so kind as   to send me Henrys last letter, where I was affection[ate]ly   rememberd and expressing a desire that I should not forget   you no be asurd I never Shall while I retain my sences, I   have Had a great deal of trouble since I saw you  I have   seen a dear loving Daughter go before me,.  to enjoy the   fruits of a well Spent life, I Continue with poor Uncle and   Johnny, thay request me not to leave them, we have had   pleasent accounts of the Conduct of of your & Cousins, and   are in dayly expectation of seeing them, poor lads they will   be much affected when thay come, they will not be likely to   hear of the chang that has taken place since they left us   till they arive.  I want very much to see you, I hope you   will come and pay us a visit, I am still Favoured with   Health, and that you may enjoy that Blessing is the Desire   of your affectinate Grandmother
Rachel DrinkerDear Cousins

Our dear Grandmother is Kind enough to   permit me to add a few lines to her letter–  I wish it was   in my power to communicate to you something that would   afford pleasure.  But alas!  I have lived to see the   melancholy period that death has seperated from me one of   the best of mothers, whose affection I believe I possessed;   and that I loved her with sincere affection, affords me no   small share of consolation–  She suffered much during her   illness, but such was her Christian fortitude that she never   discovered the least impatience, and constantly maintained   her usual cheerful serenity of mind, which was her   characteristic through a life of trials.  It was painful to   see her suffer so much bodily pain, but infinitly more so to   see her breath her last, a[l]though she suffered not the   pangs of death, but passed from this terrestrial world to   one where peace, happiness and pleasure reign triumphantly;   and where she now enjoys the blissful harvest of a spotless   and well spent life–  Such has been the immutable decree of   heaven to deprive me of an affectionate Mother and you an   affectionate Aunt– We are still blest with having our dear   Grandmother to cheer us–  She enjoysher usual health, which I hope she may enjoy for years to   come–
The last letter we received from Arthur states that   he and Cousin Henry are both well, and expect to leave the   West Indies very shortly; we of course expect them   daily–
Uncle is at present in good health, and I hope   will long continue so; here I must close this short epistle   and hope that I will see you before long –  I remain your   affectionate
cousin
John D Thomas6 mo. 19th 1806
Henry Cope
Weston6th mo 19th 1806.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Joe (Joseph Paul) Morris:  1879-1919
Recipient:  Francis Algernon Evans:  1878-1946
Date: 1911-10-28
Title: 1911 October 28, Str. “Dalmatia”, to Alg

Str. “Dalmatia”, Oct. 28, 1911.

Dear Alg,

I   meant or wanted to write to thee sooner, but thought I would   wait until we were really touching Palestine. I have my map   at hand in the case which thee presented me, and I think it   is going to be fine. So far nothing is blocking our plans –   neithercholera nor fanaticism aroused by war – and we are due at   Beirut tomorrow to go on to Damascus and take a two or three   weeks’ trip across country to Hermon, Galilee, and Samaria,   and so down to Jerusalem. To-day we have been looking, from   our ship, up at nothing less than Mount Carmel. Haifa as   thee knows is built at its foot and is of course very   picturesque. Part of the mountain’s sides is bare and brown,   rather, but part is covered with small trees, carob and oak,   I believe, which isa very pretty sight. Six or seven miles up the coast we can   see Acre with all its crusading associations. And as we have   been thinking of some of the associations of Mount Carmel it   is of course intensely interesting. I have a fine pair of   number eight binoculars which add to our enjoyment   greatly.

Nat Groton and I get along very well. He is   very patient with me; my awkwardness and unnecessary anxiety   in giving fees must be a great source of trial tohim, but he bears it well. With all these fellows coming   after you and towards you and around you for “bakshish” all   the time, it is very trying sometimes. Yesterday I had my   first – and I hope my last, as it is not pleasant –   experience of being cursed up and down and out and out by   one of the fellows who brought us out again to the Steamer   from Jaffa, for giving too little bakshish.

We went   ashore forpart of the day yesterday at Jaffa, or Joppa, which was   our first contact with Palestine. It was not calculated to   be sentimental. The disembarking is not easy, for there is   no harbor, and the rowboats are hard to get into from the   steamer. As I stepped down, the boat happened to sink in the   trough of a wave and I had the queer feeling of stepping   down into space.We were rowed in in a pelting rain, too, which made the   little streets of Joppa literally inches deep with – not   mud, but filth. The old tomb of Tabitha was only discovered   recently, but is old. The “house of Simon the tanner” may   well have been in a different place from the one which is   shown you. But after you think it over, these things make no   difference. It is Joppa. And the tanner’s house was just the   sort of one which is shown, and hisbusiness was a tannery, I suppose to make leather bottles   for water and wine. His house no doubt opened out on unclean   courts, and he was contaminated in Jewish eyes by touching   dead animals, swine at that. So where was a better place   than such a little house, with its unclean factory in the   midst and its flat roof looking out to sea and its host none   the less hospitable for any of these things, for Peter to be   prepared for his wonderful vision? And in this needy, little   town Tabitha did live. And thesame intensely interesting, picturesque life goes on its   crooked, little streets and alleys to-day. We saw a man   sitting, grinding meal between an upper and a lower   mill-stone, small ones, the upper of which he turned by   hand. We squeezed by long strings of camels, and walked   through swarms of turbaned Arabs. There are lots of other   interesting things in Joppa which stay with you in spite of   the filth through which  you wade, and the variegated odors   which assail your nostrils, but I must stop now. Please give   my love to thy mother, and Anna, and Harold, and my kind   remembrances to Miss Richardson, and if I may still trouble   thee, much love to Jac and Ed, and thyself

from Joe.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Rachel Drinker
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1806-06-09
Title: 1806 June 9 to Henry and Francis, Weston School

9th moth 9th 1806
My Dear Henry & Francis,

I   address yo both, as I have not paper for 2 letters, I am   indetted to your Brother William for this [s]crap,  I   receiv’d your letters and am glad to find by the contents   that you are well and content, we are all in perty good   health – your uncle Jasper and wife din’d at your house   yesterday and i understand intends to return home in a day   or two –  Auther expects to sail the Begining of next week,   for Saint Thomas is, Henry seems content to stay at home,  I   receiv’d a very affectinate letter from Lydia Cope she says   I was allways dear to her, and absence has increast her love   and affection for me,  now I hope it wont have the Contrarya   affect on you, I hope that time nor absence, will not lessen   the love I feel for you, and you for me.
I handed your   love as directed which was receiv’d pleasure your Cousins   Seem very throng one going to sea the other going in the   Contry [i] beleive will not have time to write, perhaps John   may  If he dont you must be content with this poor scrowl   from your Loveing Grandmother

Rachel Drinker
Dear Cousins,

By the permission of grandmother, I   take this opportunity of indulging myself in writing a few   line to you, which I should have done previous to this and   in a more particular manner, but my time has been pretty   generally occupied; and as my health has not for this some   time past been as good as formerly, I have not given so much   attention to my promise of writing to you as I otherwise   should have done –  The City in general is unusually   healthy, which I hope is not a presage to any malignant   fever: The weather is not at present very favourable after   so much rain, it is too warm–
Arthur I expect will sail   in a few days for St Thomas’s, where he intends selling   vessel and cargo, the sale of the former will depend upon   the price she will bring –  The voyage will be attended with   less danger than the former one to Cape Francois; they will   be liable it is true, to be taken by the English and French,   by the former because the port is a French one, by the   latter because they had been to the Cape; however if they   are careful to avoid all vessels in due time and conceal the   name of the sloop and her having been to Hayti they will   escapebeing captured–  The Sloop sails very fast [and] will in all   probability reach the port without any accident from man;   the fast sailing of the vessel will not quell a storm: then   thay must use their skill, do what lies in their power and   not be dismayed–
One would almost be induced to suppose   that nothing new or strange can take place, that every thing   that is extraordinary has past, and that the mine of wonder   is exhausted, for there is nothing but a series of old   occurrences revolving upon the face of the inhabitable and   navigable world–  Here I must resign my pen, and close this   uninteresting scrawl, with wishing you the blessing of   health and happiness –
I remain your affectionate   cousin
John D Thomas

N.B  If you cannot read my   writing (as I call it) when you come to Philadelphia I will   read it for you, with remark and improvements –6 mo 9th 1806
Henry Cope

Title: 1877 November 20, Gemantown, to Clementine Cope, Steamer Pennsylvania

Dear friend,
Clementine Cope--
Please find enclosed a   note of introduction to Walter Robson, who [-----es]   cheerful wishes to contribute to thy comfort on your voyage   in any way needed. Margaret unites with me in wishing thee a   prosperous and successful journey, and a safe return.--The   Lord is in every place, and I trust thee will both find Him   ever near, and keep near to Him, who is so loving and able   to preserve us--

very truly thy friend,
James E   Rhoads

Germantown 11.20.77


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1863-08-30
Title: 1863 August 30, Catskill, to My dear Mother

1863
Catskill Aug. 30th 
1st day eve

My dear   Mother

I had to leave off writing very suddenly last   time, as thee must have seen by the letter having no   direction.  We got to writing in bed at West Point as we   woke up early, & were not going to take breakfast till 8   1/2; but we had to go at 9 1/2, & as we were very pokey we   did not get down to breakfast till 9 o’clock-hence my great   hurry.  We left West P. in the boat, the rest of the way up   the Hudson was not however nearly so interesting, we soon   got out of the Highlands & then it seemed very tame.  This   is the most magnificent place we were ever, or are likely   ever, to be in; The view from the front of the house is very   extencive & beautifulfrom one place we can see the top of Mount Washington with   the opera glass.  The house is quite a large one tho’ mostly   old fashioned except the parlor wh. is up stairs, & has I   think most probably been altered the passages are the most   intricate I ever was in, & sometimes I feel completely lost.   We are on the very top of the mountain with dreadful   prespicise’s all around us, & it is the most dreadful place   to get up to that ever was, thee knows its a twelve miles   drive up the mountain from the landing, & how long does thee   ’spose we were getting up? 5 1/2 hours- just think of it the   horses walked nearly all the way, & stoped ever few   minut[e]s to rest; after we got fairly to the foot of the   mountain within about three miles from the house father &   Tom got out to walk, “& the consequence was” they got here   an hour & a quarter before us.the last part of the way poor Rach, was dreadfully sick, the   boat & stage together were too much for her, & as soon as we   got there I helped her get right to bed, she slept pretty   well however after she once did get to sleep tho’ she   suffered dreadfully poor child, thee knows her headaches are   so hard to bear, but don’t worry she’s quite well to day.    This morning they had service in the parlor to wh. Cous.   Clem, Chell & I went with papa’s leave. the sermon was   pretty good & I must confess I think it much better that   poking round all 1st day & going no where, if you can’t go   to meeting go to church – “thems my sentiments.”  After   service we all went out to take a ramble & after a good deal   of hunting round for paths & scrambling up them when found,   we at last arrivedat the top of South Mountain It was a beautiful walk   although it seemed to scare poor aunt Annie terribly to see   us so near the edge of these awful prespicise’s wh. surround   us every where; the rocks covered with ferns, mosses,   litgens are really beautiful.  We passed through what they   call “[Pudding]–stone Hall” a large cleft in the rocks   formed of pudding–stone & also through the lemon-squeezers   another crevise.  We are altogether enjoying ourselves very   much I think & propose staying here till 3rd day afternoon   when we will probably leave for Saratog[a], & thence to Lake   George.  at least those are present prospects but as we have   changed our plans several times to day I wont say certainly,   if we p[u]rsue the plan now proposed wewill stop at Belloes Falls on our way to Boston & spend   next 1st day at Nahant if we can.  We have rather a funny   time altogether about our meals & sleeping apartments here   things are not extremely clean, & it is so crowded we have   to come to the second table & therefore have to take our   breakfast at ten & dinner at four & now about 6 the supper   bell has rung, but I ‘spose we’ll come second class there   to.  We are quite glad of our thick dresses Mother, & have   worn nothing else hardly since we left home.  its right cold   to night, & we have to wear shawls & things all the time to   keep warm.  It is getting almost to dark for me towrite any more dear Mother so I think the[e] must let me   close.  I hope we shall hear from home tomorrow we want to   hear very much how you all are.  I shall try to write soon   again if we get to a stopping place  we have been going so   steadily that there has been hardly any time to do any   thing, but see the sights  Please excuse all defects – &   with love to all I am
ever thy loving
daughter Lily

Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1869-10-10
Title: 1869 October 10, to Muda

I in a waga, Anna & me went in a waga.  Anna & me went in a  waga & went down home.  Walk on the path, walk home right on  a path.  Muda went to Newport & fada & sista Lilly, went to  Newport yesterday.  Sista Lilly went to Newport yesterday.   I see Caroline aday.  I went down our road a day.  Sheep way  up near house  Sista Chelly make Ginna cake.  Farewell Muda  Caroline M Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Sarah B. Corbit
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope:  1794-1863
Date: 1840-03-14
Title: 1840, March 14, Paris, to Rachel R. Cope, Philadelphia

Paris 3rd Month 14th 1840
My Dear Cousin
I suppose you   have through the medium of letters to some of our family   heard of us and our safe arrival in Europe, but in   compliance with thy request and my promise which has not   been forgotten, I thought (altho at a late period) a breif   sketch of our [pastimes] in our new location would be   acceptable hoping that you retain a feeling of interest in   our welfare.  We arrived in London after a short and   altogather pleasant voyage passed ten day’s there was   buisily engaged in visiting the many objects very   interesting to strangers, the Tower, Westminster Abbey, St   Paul’s, House of Lords, and various other places, We then   left; after a travel of four days thro an interesting   country we arrived at Paris, during which time we were all   favoured with health, and our children were very good   scarcely uttering a word of complaint of fatigue or any   thing else, this thee may well suppose enhanced our   pleasure, or at least diminished our difficulties, When we   arrived in Paris, we took posession of apartments engaged   for our reception in a French family who speak English,  the   family consists of this and five American families, who form   a pleasant domestic circle, they are all plainly disposed   people, some very interesting a Doctor Lowell with his wife   and daughter who have visited most of the countries of   Europe, Egypt, Palestine, are with us, English is spoken at   our table, this altho very pleasant retards our progress in   the acquisition of the french language,
We are situated   in Rue de Rivoli opposite theTuileries the garden annexed to the palace, the residence of   the royal family, our location is very pleasant, excepting   that we are in the fourth story of the house (this in   America would not be considered respectable) not so in Paris   the population is so great; that highly respectable and even   wealthy families occupy apartments, consisting of several   rooms on a level, so that a house (of course large) will   accommodate many families, a very small proportion of   residents occupying a house as we do in America, this I felt   to be a great abridgment of my domestic comfort
My   ignorance of the language and the uncertainty of our   continuance induces us to board, I do not wish to encumber   myself with domestic cares, for the management of a family   in Paris is attended by much care, for one who would not   choose to leave every thing to the regulation of servants,    There are several hundred Americans in Paris who form a   pleasant society, it is customary here for those who keep   house to set apart one evening in the week for the reception   of their freinds, who receive an invitation to visit them on   that evening whenever inclination dictates, this promotes   great sociability among those who meet, the simplicity of   the entertainment is to be admired, consisting generally of   a cup of tea and cake only, very seldom serving any other   refreshment, in other respects not so simple, as a great   regard is paid to personal appearance, Dress, Dress, seems   to engross their minds to the exclusion of other and better   considerations,
Our two daughters are at a school of high   repute and we think deservedly so, they are improving in   their studies,We have visited several churches, Catholic and protestant    This we feel to be a very great privation, to have no place   of worship to resort to in accordance with our own views   where we could commune with our own hearts and be still, but   we feel the necessity of recurring to the dictates of that   inward guide, which if obey’d will lead out of all error,    We have visited a great many of the places of interest to   strangers, there are many galleries of paintings very fine,   there is at this time an annual exhibition at the Louvre, of   new pieces, some private collections also
I have in my   silent musing’s in immagination revisited most of your   dwellings,  Dear Aunts Ruth and Margery very frequently   present themselves before me, when we left home they both   seemed feeble, I hope their lives may be prolonged to the   comfort of their children by whom they are surrounded, but   it seemed to me [that] the sun of their day was near   [setting] in a tranquil evening, if My Dear Cousin this   excites sufficient interest in thy breast to induce a reply,   information of them as well as many other members of our   family would be grateful to us who are situated so far from   many they still hold dear, please remember us affectionately   to them All,  Richard and Ruth, Caleb and Martha, Samuel   Henry, and thy children from thy attached Cousin
Sarah B   Corbit
Henry’s partners will inform how to forward   letters to us, if you wish to read our letters to our   family.  Mother who resides in Arch St above Ninth will   willingly show them to you
Poland

Henry Cope
Philadelphia.
For Rachel R. Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Sibylla T. Morris:  b. 1826
Recipient:  Annette Cope:  1843-1916
Date: 1907-11-20
Title: 1911 November 20, Bridgewater Cottage, Hampton, Va, to My very dear friends

Bridgewater Cottage
Hampton – Va: –
Nov: 20th 1907   –

My very dear friends —

We have just finished   reading in the Montrose papers, which my daughter Annie   Sayne brought down to me this p.m. – the account of the   Dedication of dear Clemmie’s donation to all the people of   old Susq: Co: & under its inspiration I feel that I must   immediately x x x x –––––––––1908 Jan. 4th –

— To prove that my dear friends have   not been entirely forgotten, – I have the audacity to   continue this letter – begun so long ago as almost to be   forgotten unless it be for this purpose! –  An interruption   occurred, during which time Minnie told me that she was   writing or had written to you, & when I asked where she wd.   address it, she said "Oh, in c/o Misses Biddle – they are in   Montrose". —  I demurred, but neither of us knew theGermantown address & altho’ I said "No. 1. Walnut St."   always held a clue – & had for nearly 100 yrs. past, – but   she laughed, – said that date was obsolete, – & now I doubt   if you ever did get her letter! –  I wish I cd. see you, & I   think our tongues wd. travel fast, –  Writing has become   rather irksome to me, – particularly with pen & ink as my   fingers have very much stiffened in my old age – so I   generally write with a pencil(when I think my frds. will not   object,) & I do not write much, except to my two sons, – who   are in R.R.d business at Sydney,– Nova Scotia. —

— We   have had such a hard summer,– partly owing to the delusions   these conceited Virginians had,– that "all the world & his   wife" wd. almost break their necks to get here to see their   wonderful state & its historic surroundings – then their   disappointments & losses were not cheerful or conducive to   cheery letter writing, & I hate to write doleful letters. —If it were not so pathetic,– it wd. be very amusing to see   the downfall of the hopes they all had of making such   enormous fortunes.–  Hundreds & thousands of dollars have   been lost, for the whole thing was a complete fizzle & not   being completed until away into October, & therefore but   little attendance,– those who did come disparaging it, & the   day after the gates were closed, it was put right into the   hands of a receiver!! –  Virginia has not had such a   staggering blow since Appomattox! –

— We have seen   very little ofMiss Walcott altho we attend the same church, but she lives   at the farther side of our town & the trip involves a   trolley ride- a ferry across Hapton Creek & a walk to each   end of the line.-
I am so sorry to hear of Carrie’s   increased deafness, - & descouraged too.- for I have grown   very deaf myself. & when she had all the medical faculty of   Europe to consult, & they did not cure her, - it is not   worth while for me to try. - Is it hereditary with her?- I   don’t remember either of your parents beingafflicted in that way. –  The strongest point in my memory   about them – is your father’s good sound "orthodox" dignity   – always so cheerily smoothed over, by your Mother’s   beautiful almost angelic smile which brightened almost   everybody & everything around them. –  I don’t wonder he   went to bed, when she was taken from him, & could never be   persuaded to rise again. –  I must close this now for my   messenger to take to the post office. –

— How I do   wish you would come to see us.  I hardly know any one who   would be more welcome. –  Now, think it over & see if you   can’t come,– particularly if a cold wave strikes Germantown.   —

Good bye – in which both my girls join, – don’t   ever doubt me, but believe me always your loving &   affectionate friend
Sibylla T. Morris.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Taber:  1822-1887
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1841-04
Title: 1841 April, to Frank, Philada.

Dear Frank
Somewhere in the Month of April, AD      1841

If you are in want of a mystery profound enough      to merit the attention and task the scrutiny of your      powerful mind - endeavor to ascertain if you can what whim      has led me to take this mammoth sheet for my letter instead      of confining myself as heretofore to the narrower limits of      a [Quarto]  It has puzzled me – I thought first of greatness      in the Abstract – how greatness Sympathises with greatness –      How you cant get a Barrel of praties in a Bushel Basket –      and wondered if that was the reason – Some I reasoned Are      born to greatness – some achieve greatness and some have      greatness thrust upon them – and I have come to that      conclusion that struggle against it as I may in spite of all      I may do – greatness is my destiny. ------

“Tantaeni      animis celestibus irae!!” as [Maro] said when the Caelicoli      plagued poor Aeneas half out of his wits. ---  I know      Francis that the provocation was extreme – like unto the      emotions of a female Tiger robbed of her young by some      felonious and ruthless hand – some Yankee Menagerie-Keeper –      who reflects (not the Keeper but the Tiger) that her striped      Darlings will be exposed to the vulgar eye far from their      native land. far from her and from her caresses. – who knows      that in them she has lost perhaps the prop of her declining      years and feels that she is altogether lonely –      

“They will never come she said”
“She said I am      a-weary a-weary”
“Would God that I were dead”!      –

like unto her heart-rending emotions are emotions      of a Poet moaning over the loss the abstraction by      unhallowed hands of his fancy’s creations – his children of      the Brain  She whet her incisors – He mends his pen –      
Her sullen growl resounds thro the forest. = fearful      flies the trembling thief – the invader of their domestic      hearth and social joys. – She sees him in the blue distance      farther than any eye can pierce save the eye of a Mother      bereaved of her offspring --  Guilty wretch! and dont thou      expect such crimes to prosper – Fly as thou may the avenger      is behind – She springs from the tangled Brush – one blow      and her little ones are free and the blood of the ravisher =      washes down his bones – The Poets eye rolls in indignant      fury – He paces up and down – and much Ink must be shed.       Black ink – to expiate his wrongs ------

But Frank I      quote from “L’Entreprise No. 8” “Memory is mortal      forgiveness divine” – There is a difference between the      charity of the Christian and the blind revenge of the beasts      that perish – and I see that thou art well acquainted with      the precept concerning the smiting of one cheek and the      subsequent turning of the other – since – when thou wast      informed of the use I had made of thy Serenade thee sends me      on another piece which I am sorely tempted to appropriate to      the same purpose – viz. “The Thief” an Indignation ode      -----

But “L’Entreprise” is of the things that have      been = its star has set – When it again rises and illumes      our horizon once more – any pieces you may favor me with      will meet with particular attention and speedy insertion –      To Encourage your Modesty I will only hint
at the numerous encores and complimentary remarks which I      appropriated at its reading in our Junto. – I must confess I      had some conscience pangs – at thus robbing you of your due      and ventured to hint that they were entirely mistaken about      the Authorship – But all that was attributed to my modesty      and I could not make them believe it – So any more Serenades      you want inserted or Indignation Odes – either – send them      along and I’ll father ‘em with pleasure ----

As to      that little Biographical sketch in the “Ledger” the idea      pleases me exceedingly – It is not always the fate of Genius      to hear its praises Its requiem is rarely listened to – till      Death has untuned the Ear to praise and “cold obstruction”      chilled the heart and closed the eye – But sometimes Fate      decrees otherwise. -- & To your hands I commit with pleasure      myself and my memory – and to encourage you I think you      would make considerable of a Buzzy – I had thought some time      since I could trace thy classic pen in that respectable      Journal – Sometimes perhaps in the Poet’s corner – and again      I have suspected thy assistance (as Charles Lamb and Dun      Stuart have done before thee - ) [Reparter] “compiler      impromptu” composer and Wellerism manufacturer at a fippenny      bit a head

Dont forget Frank to put in how like twin      puppies we hunted the Muses together – How “hand in hand we      climbed the steep ascent of Parnassus” – and drank from the      same pitcher of the sparkling fountain – and if thee wishes      it I dont know that I shall object to thy inserting that      chaste production of thy blushing and almost virgin Muse –      the ode to Fanny – Though I bethink myself that piece would      better become the columns of the “Little Genius” – for there      was about it an independent air – a noble boldness which      some – nay, many – are too narrowed by the conventional and      affected delicacy of the day fully to appreciate and which      the Little Genius so openly advocates and patronises –      

With this I send you a critique on a Philadelphia      poet one who “blossomed in the desert air” of our unfriendly      climate but who like a wise prophet sought honor elsewhere –      No man is a hero to his valet’s deschambre and Pliny would      never have sucked Parnassian pap to advantage if he had      lived and died a Teacher at Providence School – What a      blight this “Times” man seems to want to throw upon poor      Pliny’s Laurels.  – No mincing matters Regulae cut & slash.       – When I see such an article I always fancy the Burden on my      own shoulders – Just Fancy some of your Serenades served in      the same style – Not kidnapped – eloped with out of pure      affection but barbarously mangled, murdered, its throat cut      from ear to ear.  – Like to a Tiger &c &c (on the other page      - )

New England Yearly Meeting of Friends is held at      New Port from 7th day the 12th of the 6th month to 6th day      the 18th inclusive commencing with the Meeting for      Sufferings – which however thou knowst is only patent to      Cardinals and chief priests of the synagogue First Day is      generally “the Yearly Meeting” par eminence and is usually a      great day at New Port.  Then may be seen straight coats of      the strictest sort – straight coats of a more accommodating      
curve – straight coats which one would hardly know were      straight and it grieves me to mention – some utterly devoid      of straightness – Broad Brims black, drab, or otherwise from      six inches in diameter to a lesser number – or a fraction –      Bonnets which the unsullied snow wreath could not rival in      maiden purity setting off eyes of all colors – noses of all      shapes – and mouths of all degrees of prettiness –      interspersed with some of the adornment of the daughters of      vanity ------ flitting past in crowds – and every now & then      the youth of the company indulging in cachinnations calling      down upon them with speedy rebuke of the more serious &      elderly – while old peaceable looking chassis and wagons      drawn by the most demure looking ponies in the world string      along through the streets and all bound to Yearly-Meeting –      New Port has many other attractions besides Yearly Meeting      however – The ride on the Beach – the Glen the [Fort] and      the Sail in the Harbour take away considerably from the      tedium of the long sittings – and besides Paradise &      Purgatory can be visited – much easier than was done in the      times of Hercules & pious Aeneas – as to the girls I have      often told them that I worship them
“as      stars

Whose purity and distance make them      fair”
and thee must get another pilot when thee comes on      such sounding but I do not despair however and may perhaps      with a few Lessons from thee become “a nice young      man”
All this I put forth expecting you to come & visit      us then – If you will be there – day & month aforesaid – I      will meet you and I think I may promise you a pleasant week      – Harry I suppose put more faith in Fanny [Ell---] than in      any one else – so he will hardly affect a Yearly Meeting of      the spiritually “Exercised –

So no more (and quite      enough) from
thy friend Charles TaberFrancis R Cope
care of H. & A. Cope
No 1 Walnut St
Philada.
