----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Martha Leeds:  1810?-1888
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1857-06-17
Title: 1857 June 17, New York, to Anne

New York 6 mo 17th 1857 —

My dear Anne,

Laura   just brought me up thy letter to read I had been lying down   since dinner and after our journey down to meeting felt like   resting –  I felt almost afraid to go down in the   neighbourhood of the City Hall where we went to Stewart’s to   get some tarleton muslin to see if we could not fold it so   as to cover the cracks of William’s big looking glass – it   will look better and I expect Laura will have it hung in the   spare room, where thee can look at thyself from head to foot   when thee comes on –  felt glad that Rebecca happened to be   out ready to take thy place in waiting on thy mother –   forgot to say why I was afraid to go in the neighbourhood of   the City Hall suppose the papers have informed you of the   riot between the police appointed by the Mayor and those   under the Govenor there was a great time yesterday but I   believeit is all quiet at present.  I suppose they have a queer   sort of a mayor here and I felt a hope that after this   outbreak that a new order of things may be instituted and   that we shall have the Streets cleaned –  I want thee to   tell Anna that I feel so much obliged to her for telling me   of the remedy for dyspepsia  I have been so much better   since I commenced taking it –  I hope that I shall be able   soon to partake with others of what is put on the table.  I   am so fond of clams, and as they are so nice here at New   York and we have them frequently, I feel it quite a   deprivation –  Am able to eat strawberries.  We had them in   abundance at Father’s where we went 7th day evening sisters   Amelia & Hannah were there and several cousins went with us   besides Barclay and the country was so beautiful and so   sweet from the clover fields that it did seem to me quite a   treat – we left second day morning in the cars for New York   –  Came in the accommodation trainby the way of Amboy – it was new to me and I enjoyed it much   more than the other route by Trenton –  Last evening Solon   Robinson one who writes for the "Tribune"* [*Is one of the   editors I am told] spent the evening with us he is a near   neighbour – he wrote the "hot Corn" stories for the Tribune   and lately "a day in the country" which appeared in that   paper – a singular looking man his age is 54 – wears a beard   probably 6 inches long and perfectly white, his hair also   long and white – he told us he had travelled with one pair   of horses from New Orleans to Chicago and from thence to New   York $5000 miles and the horses just ready to run away the   day after he got home – he described his attack of Cholera   on the Missisippi and of the enormous dose of opium, Quinine   &c which they gave him of the former quite an ounce he   thought –  I told him of [Gimre’s] himaepathic potion!–  He   also mentioned an illness of the smallpox and said he had it   as badly as it was possible – upon my remarking that he was   not pitted with it he told me howhe prevented it by covering the pustules immediately upon   breaking with collodion –  Some of the pustules were as   large as a hickory nut, others smaller – but not a place on   his whole person where he could have put a quarter of a   dollar down with out touching some – we were entertained   with his conversation but did not admire him any of us –   quite eccentric –  I did not know he wrote the "hot corn   stories" untill he left – he was down on the beggars said it   was sinful to give indiscriminately seemed to think it was   no use to give to them that they could not be made to help   themselves – that they might as well die one time as another   which quite shocked us to hear him say – he has distributed   about $12000 and I suppose has become totally discouraged in   the prospect of doing any good –  He thinks almost all are   petty thieves –  Laura has had 4 articles taken that she had   put out with ashes in – knows not what to do – they will   take even a barrel and break up for firewood –  Thos Leggett   had their door mat stolen as well as Woodwards’ and the next   door the other side –  We have concluded to keep ours in the   hall as it has escaped hithertoEvery few minutes there is a knock at the basement door –    Robinson says "let them knock and take no notice –" does it   not seem queer that a man that could write so feelingly   about the poor should say so? – but indeed we know not what   to do scarcely and to feel that we do right –  I never saw   such a place –  One evening Thos Leggett was in here about   dark we were all in the basement and a poor little thin   creature like Katy came to ask for something –  Tom thought   he would go with her and see her home which he did and after   he returned he could not speak for tears – the scene of   utter destitution affected him so much –  The father could   not work had the ague and he thought that they looked as if   they had all become thin through want of food – she had been   coming here almost daily for food since –  This morning we   saw a group of little ones the largest girl carrying a box   which looked to be an ash box and Laura thought looking back   apprehen-sively.  We thought they had stolen it.  Robinson may feel   more than he pretends to about them –  We heard he wrote for   a long time "City Items" for the Tribune and they almost all   contained some interesting incidents respecting the poor –   he informed us he possessed remarkably  descriptive powers   that nothing he saw escaped his notice &c.  We concluded he   must be a genius and consequently eccentric – he told us he   had an adopted daughter that always shaves him – cuts his   hair makes  all his clothes with the assistance of a sewing   machine as well as all her own sewing and sometimes  her   shoes –  William thinks it likely she is one perhaps that he   has rescued –
We found Nealie here after we returned from   meeting we are all invited up there Seventh day (Barclay and   ourselves)– we expect to go if they get a cook–  A few days   ago an old servant of theirs dropped down dead whilst at   work in the kitchen which was a great shock to them they had   to have a coroners inquest – Laura says perhaps we will go   and take Martha tocook whilst we stay –  Laura has engaged the nicest little   girl to run errands do chamber work  &c – she does work   admirably  sews beautifully – irons &c  they think she will   suit them better than a larger girl – she is a trim little   thing with beautiful hair which she has always in nice order   – got a very good character of her – the gentleman she lived   with (a lawyer) wrote her character – that she was the best   child he had ever known in her capacity – they parted with   her in consequence of going out West –
I do not remember    whether I told you about the Cornell’s friends of Hannah   Leggett who board with them the elder (Eliza) has been a   teacher in one of the best schools in the city received a   salary of $600 – she is going to be married in about three   weeks to Albert Smiley.  she is a sweet looking girl as well   as a younger sister with whom Barclay has become  well   acquainted – JL Woodward is very much interested in them –   he likes young company – when Laura told his wife that she   thought perhaps some of hercousins would come home  with us – she said "Mr Woodward   will be delighted"  We are to take tea there this evening –   Leggetts & ourselves –
5th day.  We heard that Mayor Wood   was obliged to accept warrants from the Metropolitan police   who accompanied by Gen Sandford presented them to him—he is   under arrest – I feel anxious to hear what has transpired to   day –  Lewis & William and every New Yorker I expect are so   much interested –  Wood has behaved  so badly –  It was   thought that Sandford had acted with great circumspection   and he was the hero of the day – but if the Mayor had not   submitted, he told him that the law would be enforced at the   point of the bayonet – happily yesterday passed without   bloodshed –  The mayor with his 800 policemen were in the   City Hall = It was suggested that they might be starved into   submission by preventing egress –
Well Anne dear I hope   thy foot will not trouble thee long it was the best thing to   take care in time of a sprained ancle – such a useful little   body as thee has become  cannot be spared very well –  Laura   joins me in love to all at Awbury – will write soon to thee   herself as I have more time on my hands I have taken the pen   this time and shall be glad 
to have a reply –  I am   looking for an answer to my letter from Julia soon we do   enjoy getting letters so far away from all of you –Must now say farewell as my sheet is filled and remain as   ever thy very affectionate Aunt Martha

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Emily Rose
Recipient:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Date: 1878-07-06
Title: 1878 July 6, Newport, to Clemmy

Newport, July, 6th, 1878

Dearest Clemmy,
I wonder      where your darling little ladyship is at this moment?  I      wish it was here amid all the greenness & breezes of      Newport, Ocean Airs, & perhaps you are or are Coming as I      know you do sometimes.  For me –  You know I was with my      dear Aunt last winter & now that she has taken this fine      house I am with her Still – & certainly it is the perfection      of living.  My Aunt has taken the whole house it is neat &      handsome & an excellent table – $1.000 per month.  when we      are at breakfast our rooms are arranged.the owners live in some mysterious addition to the house but      we never see or hear anything of the machinery
Aunt has      her maid & my cousin –(by the way Clemmy since I cant now      have you for a "Sister" how would "Cousin"– suit thee? he is      very good & wealthy & well born &c?) has his man & horses –       There are lovely trees & fields all round –  We are on "the      Avenue" next the Ocean House, & in front is the large place      of a Cousin – the lady is an only child & her father lately      died leaving 7. millions!  So the world is shared!  They      spent the evening here last night – looking as joyous as tho      they had 7 milns but not at all as tho’ a new tombstone      stood for them in a graveyard,  so the world goes!  But oh!      give me less. & a heart aching to deaths very door for the      filled grave.– however long ago = Who would take joy if it must be      coupled with heartlessness?  Thank God for real griefs      whatever He sends.  Do they not "all work together for      good",  & then there are so many bright delicious joys!       Thank God indeed for them!  The world is so full of      sunshine!  If the railroad is finished into our beautiful      town – Aunt & my Cousin will visit me, & also – "whether or      no" A Cousin of mine who is here now with us – wife of the      late "President of the New York College of [Physiciary] &      Surgeons" & sister of a very lovely lady a Mrs Highbee who      boarded awhile at Mr D. Lathrops in Montrose in 1867, while      I was in Europe.  She seems quite delighted with the      prospect – & now I want you to come also & visit me the      latter part of August & SeptemberI told Aunt she must let me go home then & dear Clemmy I do      want your dear sensible loving heart – & I think I could      make it pleasant to you – I will be very good, & let you go      to Miss Walkers & your other friends & if your parents &      sisters or brothers are up we will entertain them –  Give      them a handsome party as I gave those dear Dr & Mrs Parker      last fall.  Come!  My Cousin Mrs Edwin A Stevens, whose      husband left some 60 or 70 millions has invited me – to      visit her but I would rather have you as my guest –  So now      write me immediately & tell me you are coming to me.  Give      the kindest of all kind remembrances to your parents  Time      or distance never weaken my loving memories –  I went on to      Phil in Apr to Miss Mary Powell’s wedding & was so sorry not      to be able to get out to see you all but I hadso many friends who claimed me for the short time my friends  in N.Y. would spare me.  Hoping to hear soon from you &  sending love to each of your family  Believe me as ever most  affectionately yr friend

Emily Rose,

Care of  Mrs [Goffee]
Cor Berkely & Bellevue Aves
Newport,   R.I.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan S. Reeve:  1833-1866
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1865-05-27
Title: 1865 May 27, Locust Shade, to Annie

Locust Shade. 5. 27. [18]65

My dear Annie, 

It   seems to me that a very improper time has elapsed since the   receipt of they welcome letter, without my having answered   it - but as we are both well hosted in excuses I will not   add to the list.- Just as I began my letter, thy kind note   was handed me - & I truly thank thee for it and should love   to comply with they request - but [dont] see that it would    be possible. Besides dearie I want thee to come here - and   hope to persuade thee to do so.- Your place must indeed   looklovely & I have thought several times how I should like   to look uponits beauty and enjoy your society - which is always so   pleasant, but I must deny myself this time- I want too, to   hear about the wedding & Clemmy & diverse other things. Our   “Strawberry Company” as thee calls it, is not here- tho we   have had several of our friends the past week, - and shall   probably have more [next]. - - Our cook had gone away for a   fortnights visit, half of the time is gone - at which I   rejoice, and this is another reason why I cannot leave home-   the next week father and mother will be away for a Sundays-   and after that I do hope thee will come to see me. Any day   that suits thee we shall gladly welcome thee. - 

I   heard from Deborah Thomas that Clemmy was pleasantly   situated and like her occupation.- Thee must miss her visits   very much & she thine. - Lily seemsquite absented in her work and is turning out a very      managing young lady - it will probably be of great use to      her in calling out her latent energies.- 

How many      remarkable & [steming]  events have transpired since we were      together.- It seems to me we have, every day, reason to      mourn death of our own dear good President -  Johnson is so      different - & if he should get us into a Mexican war it      would be so sad. But we can but hope for the best. Was it      not wonderful how suddenly & completely the Rebellion cam to      an end. Like the “One hoss slay”- it all broke down at      once.- Poor Jeff makes a sorry figure in his humiliation he      is showing very plainly what a poor miserable specimen  of a      man he was.- Niether true courage or honor in the slightest      appreciative of his great crimes. -- We have justhad our Bettie at home for ten days and busy enough we were   with her spring clothing - she comes back again the last of   next month for vacation.- She is growing so companionable   that I miss her when she is gone very much.-
I am glad to   hear Uncle D B Smith sometimes gets to your house. no doubt   it does him good. Wish I could see him. Will thee give him   my love when thee see him.- Suppose Uncle John & Aunt R   Smith & cos Lizzie are out in the broad Ocean. we hear our   cousin Richard Howland was to go with them, but do not know   if its true. If aunt R’s health is improved - it will be   delightful for them all to be together. Would thee not like   to go if thee could do so properly? - I should exceedingly,   but probably never shall, my life seems destined to be very   unadventurous and matter of fact, - all for the best no   doubt.- Do Lilly & her Philip’slive in Germantown? What a favored place you live in all the  nice people do mostly congregate there. R wishes to be  remembered to thee & hopes sometime to accept the very kind  invitation. Just now I [----] [------] are all engrossing. -  I hope thy father is pretty well this spring please remember  me to him.- With much love I am very truly thee thee  at[----] 
S. S. Reeve

I hope thee has not got any  of those little salt sellars yet, as I have has a pair  waiting for thee ever so long, Will send them down next week  if I can. - 


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Samuel Morris:  1827-1905
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1904-08-25
Title: 1904 August 25, Duchy Lausanne, to Rachel C. Evans

Duchy, Lausanne
8/25.1904.

My dear   friend
Rachel C. Evans.

In carrying out our   program for Switzerland, the weather has suddenly changed   from intense heat and a very long drought to a rain of   several days, which while most grateful to the parched   country, interferes materially with views of the charming   Lake of Geneva and the mountains that environ it. Instead   therefore, of our usual outdoor life, this gives just the   opportunity for which I've been wishing, to acknowledge some   of the very kind farewell greetings, received as we left our   native shores. The weather being so variable, it has seemed   best for one to remain in this most comfortable   Eng.-speaking pension, with a delightful out-look upon the   Lake, while my dear Hannah has gone into the 
upper regions, so as to get into closer touch with their   sublime peaks--at least so far as the fickle weather may   permit. Meanwhile therefore, my pen is giving me congenial   occupation in-doors.
Among the loving remembrances to   which I have referred, is thine from Franconia, U. N. of   [--] 28--I was truly glad also thus to receive good accounts   from you, and can only trust your outing in the bracing air   of New Eng. may be permanently helpful to thyself and your   dear Anna, of whom I often think with tender sympathy,   desiring that "the best of Physicians"--may keep her under   his all-wise and loving care. Turning away therefore, from   misgivings, or fears, or failures as they may seem to her,   may there be a more "continual looking into Jesus", not only   "as the author", but "the finisher of her faith". Let her   ever remember that it is this same Saviour of our's, who has   begun his work of grace in her heart that seeks to carry it   on and perfect it
to his praise, and her unspeakable peace. He knows her   better than she knows herself; and therefore, none so well   as He can "speak to her condition". It is thus He has   revealed himself to multitudes of struggling souls, and they   never seek His face in vain. Then it is that anxiety gives   place to a quiet childlike confidence in Him, and impatience   as to a more rapid growth in grace than we may have yet   known finds us more continually dwelling upon the abounding   love of God, and brings about that "patient waiting for   Christ", which the apostle craves for his fellow   believers.
While our best desires are turned in this   direction, there is nothing incompatible with the fullest   appreciation of the outward favors & blessings with which   our Heavenly Father has surrounded us. Indeed, we now   realize that these he has "given us richly to enjoy". We   recognize His good hand in them all, and so a continual   thanksgiving goes up from our hearts to Him, as the   all-bountiful giver. I see little to add to the few
hints as above, and would have thee to use them or not, only   as way may open--Indeed I can quite believe that, if a   fitting, natural opening does not occur, it may be best to   speak to Anna of nothing beyond my continued loving interest   in her.
As to the results of our own rambling, I may   thankfully say that, for myself, there seems a marked gain   in several respects, but, as thou has intimated, the full   benefit of such changes is sometimes felt later. My dear   Hannah could scarcely be in better condition for enjoying to   the full the scenes of rare interest and beauty thr'o which   we are and have been passing. I think however, we shall both   be glad when the time for our return voyage shall have come.   This will be 10/5, by the "Haverford", for Phila, and   shortly after, if the Lord will, we may hope to be once more   among our dear home friends--Please remember us in love to   Jon., while I remain

very sincerely thy friend
Sam   Morris


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1864-08-31
Title: 1864 August 31, Springfield, Mass, to Papa and Mama

Springfield. Mass. Aug. 31st
4th day eve.

Dear   Papa & Mama,
We rec’d your letters this morning just as   we started & were very glad to get them, tho’ sorry to think   they came too late to engage rooms for you at the Cliff   House we were very anxious to hear from you in time, but you   were so long making up your minds, that we almost came to   the conclusion you were not going to at all, & had given it   up.  However Uncle H. thinks there will be no trouble in   getting them by writing afterwards.  We left Newport at 7   o’clock this morning & dined at Worcester very comfortably   about 2 o’clock & arrived here at 6 1/2 about.  Thishotel is delightful, they say it is one of the best in the   Union Sallie Parish says “its where all the brides come to,”   I haven’t seen any yet!  We got a splendid supper & Uncle   Harry & Chell & I took a little stroll through the town  it   seems very pretty as far as gas and star-light would show.    But me thinks we will not see much more of it, we propose   leaving quite early tomorrow morning for [Mt.] Holyoke.    Aunt Mary says “that all things considered she is certainly   remarkably well,” last 1st day she says she felt better than   she has for a year.  She is certainly improved, but don’t   raise your hopes to high or I fear you will be disappointed   – She’s better, but not well.  
They are talking,   talking! all the time, & I can’t write, Aunt [K]. has a very   nice room on the secondfloor, & Chell, Ginnie, & I have three cots put up in an   adjoining private parlor, its quite fine we’re all seated   round the centre table with a bright gas-light above us & a   velvate carpet beneath us, & the most delightful easy chairs   aren’t we splendid?  
Uncle H. says our present intention   is to come home in the 2 o’cl train 7th day (if the   time-table is right) I think we’ll not get out [--] 4, if we   change our plans we’ll telegraph.  Now Mother I must stop   for I want to fix my hat & its getting late.  Aunt M. says   she would have written but she has been retrimming Anna’s   hat & had no time.  Love to all
very   affec’ly
Lillie

P.S.  Resolved-that we take dinner   at Aunt [Annas], & come in quarter before 4P.S.  resolved that you need not expect us till we   come
P.S.  thats wrong!
P.S.  We will probably come   out in the 9 o’clock cars taking tea at the   Continental.
P.S.  Still talking can’t tell if this be   the final decision!
P.S.  Final decision! Seriously!  It   is extremely difficult to fix our plans, & we will   positively come home on 7th day either 1/4 4 or 9 o’cl   trains.
P.S.  Uncle Harry thinks we ought to give a   reason for our indecision.  Reason That we can not find   beforehand how long it will take to visit Mt. Holyoke as we   have to drive part of the way, & that makes it uncertain   whether we will reach New Haven tomorrow night or the next   day


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Joseph Simpson:  1835-1901
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937

Title: 1876 August 16, Sunnyside, Mayfield, near Ashbourne, to My dear Friend

Sunnyside.
Mayfield.
near Ashbourne.

Aug 16.   1876.

My dear Friend,
This morning Agnes received   from thee a very kind & welcome letter which she wishes me   to answer at once, as we are both most anxious not to miss   the visit from you which we have been looking forward to   with so much pleasure.  And please do not leave England   without first spending a few quiet days with us, here.Agnes was strong enough to leave her bed for the first time   yesterday: she is up again today & as each day adds to her   strength, she will soon, we expect, be going about as usual.   We want you, therefore, if possible, to come to us from   North Wales (there is a good service of trains [---] Crewe)   next Friday week, if possible, the 25th inst. & stay over   Sunday, at least.  If you can do this (& please try!) my   Sister Hannah will, I hope, either come with you fromCrewe, or join you here.  She will relieve you of all very   active duties & so take away, we hope, all your most   considerable objections to coming to Mayfield just now.  If   you will only send me word where you will come from, I will   forward a list of our local trains at once. –
Please feel   fully assured that we wd. not press you to do this if we   felt there was any risk to Agnes.  It will be a real treat   to us to have you with us just as long as you can stay, and   a grievousdisappointment if we miss you. –
Since hearing from thee   last, we have often talked of you, & only two days ago. we   were rejoicing that you would now be able to come to us, as   the little stranger had arrived, & was doing well.  I hope   you have good tidings from home; we are enjoying this   delightful weather at our new house exceedingly.  In about   three weeks we hope to welcome James & Mary Taylor, who   winter here.  Caroline Shipley is still with us, much to our   pleasure.  With our warm love to Alexis & thyself, I   am,
Thine very sincerely,
J. Simpson.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1865-05-21
Title: 1865 May 21, Baltimore, to Mother and sisters

Baltimore 5.21

Dear Mother & sisters,

Its   quite long since I have written to you & I expect you think   it strange I have not acknowledged the rect of the [---] by   express wh. arrived safely & timely.  I have not written   because I have been in such a whirl all the week that I   really have not been able to get a needful amt of sleep I   knew too that you wd. be occupied with the wedding, & wld.   not miss my letter.  I suppose the nuptials are over & I   hope passed off satisfactorily — I shall expect a full acct.   shortly.  The same eve that you were enjoying the wedding   festivities at [--------]I also was immersed in scenes of revelry & mirth — much   gayer tho perhaps not more enjoyable than those.  It was the   eve of Jessies grand party, -- wh. was the longest & gayest   I ever attended.  It was like a concentration of weddings   for all looked like brides & there were 80 or 90, — The   supper wh took place at 12 o’ck P.M. was magnificent.  The   meats & the fried crabs & the, sweet-breads--& the elegant   Baltimore confectionery & the ices & the fruits & the   flowers exceeded, as did also the ladies dresses—There were   two or three brides—J Hoag was one, but they were mostly   very gay fashionable people, & I felt some what out of   place--& I am very glad there are not likely to be any more   such entertainments, as I had to teach sch. thro. a sick   head-achenext morn wh. did not pay—I was very glad the skirt arrived   in time, & also that I had taken the precaution to have the   white body made I thot I looked quite nice, considering—at   least I shd. have thot so in Phila but theres no beating   these ‘Baltimo’--Belles--  I was presented by a gentleman   whose name begins with -- [J?] with a very beautiful bouquet   as were many other young ladies  This is the first evening I   have spent at home for a week & I expected to have spent it   in writing but a visitor came in—a young man named   [Joliff?]—he ask us to go to the top of the monument wh. we   have not yet got to, another youth has invited us to go this   week on an expedition to a placed called Federal Hill—so you   see we are quite belles.

The celebrated Emma Congdenfrm. Providence is here now.  She occasions a good many   little tea parties & I have met her several times.  She is   very lovely indeed.  Her father Gilbert C, visited me in my   sch. room the other day & was very cordial saying he   remembered being at our home in Susquea some years   ago.

I believe I have not written to you since the   young Englishman was here, he brot me a letter of   introduction frm. A. Harrison & I had the pleasure of taking   one or two walks & teas with him.  He made himself so   pleasant & agreeable that every body was quite charmed with   him.  He only stayed a few days but expected to be here   again.

Please tell [Amy?] & [Elg.?] dont forget that   Jesse wished me to let them know he had heard of a very good   safe & higly recommended hackney somewhere in these parts   wh. can be purchased for 200 dollars

Thanks for the   generous donation of stamps.  I think it will last me.Please tell them & tell Aunt Caroline that I was very much   obliged for her nice letter wh. I shd. like to reply to when   I can get time.  I lent it & the sermon to M. Cheston, who   seemed grateful.  I will endeavor to return the letter   safely. much love to them all.  I wrote to Tom a letter a   week or two ago wh. I suppose he got.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Annette Cope:  1843-1916
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1867-07-19
Title: 1867 July 19, Laurel House, to Mama

Laurel House July 19th

My  dear Mama,
Rachel has   spent herself so in writing to thee that it seemed hardly   worth while for me to try, so I thought I wld. wait till her   fever was over, & as this eve. she seemed little inclined to   desert the piazza, I concluded to undertake the task.  We   have had a most exercising day in all senses of the word,   but so wonderful is the effect of this mountain air that I   do not feel the least tired.  In the first place this   morning we set off in an open wagon for Haines’ fall a   pleasant ride of about 2 miles, but it was after we got   there the “tug of war” began –  We hada regular scramble, part of the way was so rough that Tom &   Walter concluded to remain behind & before we got through   there was no one left but Harry Ellie & Madge & I, we went   down to the very foot of the lower falls, & were well   repaid; it was a most beautiful spot, a succession of six   lovely little falls ending in cascades & rapids, it was   altogether quite charming, the prettiest place of the kind I   ever saw, & I don’t remember ever to have seen a photograph   of it –  We did not get home till after the dinner bell had   rung, so were obliged just to give a little smoothe to our   hair, & go in in our mountain dresses, but every thing is   very primitive here, & nobody pretends to dress for dinner.    As we were all preparedwe concluded instead of changing our dresses to go after   dinner down the stream about a mile to Bastion falls under   Tom’s piloting, & soon comes in the adventure – we just got   to the head of the fall, & were [nerving] ourselves for a   scramble to the foot, when some one remarked that it was   raining, & sure enough it was, we took shelter under some   trees and concluded it wld. soon be over, & we would wait,   but it got harder & harder, & at last found its way through   the branches, & came down on us in large drops, which were   decidedly wetting, we tried it for a little while, but   finding there was no sign of stopping & we were getting very   wet we concluded to push on home, –  At first it seemed to   have slaked alittle, but it soon began harder than ever, & we went   tearing along jumping over rocks & through bushes till we at   last arrived at the foot of the Kauterskill, & then there   were all those dreadful stairs to go up – however we pushed   on, & at last arrived panting at the house – we were pretty   objects to be sure all wet, & draggled, & hot – there were   several gentlemen sitting round on the piazza, & I thought   it a remarkable instance of politeness that they did not   ever smile, I’m sure I could not have resisted it.  Of   course we retired immediately to our appartments, & changed   every thing making ourselves most comportable & desidedly   more presentable.  Thee need not feel the least concern for   I don’t think we are any of us a bitthe worse, & the most remarkable part is we are not tired.    The only thing that suffered was our hats, but I guess they   will look pretty well when they dry, & we’ll have to retrim   them at Newport –  Thee must be sure & not forget my bonnet   so that if we should arrive 7th day night I may have   something to wear to meeting.  Also mother I think I forgot   to put on the list a thin white body of mine & my best   underbody that I wanted to have done up & brought in the   trunk – Virginia will know.  Tom wrote to Father yesterday   to go by 7th days steamer, & one of us will try to write by   the next.  We are having a most delightful time, & as thee   willsee by my account I am as well as possible, so thee need not   have any anxiety on my account.  I do hope you are getting   along nicely, & don’t feel very lonely, I know thee must   miss Father very much, but I hope he will be a great deal   better for his voyage & come home to us quite strong, & free   from all those miserable head-aches.  
Aunt L & Chell   send love, & the former says she is intending to write to   thee very soon.  
Give a great deal of love to all, &   Virginia especially I want to write to her, she was so very   kind in helping me to get ready to come away, I don’t know   what I should have done without her.  
Good-night dear   Mama,
thy ever loving
Lily
Please remember to bring   the Banner Essays to Newport.


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Elizabeth Sandwith Drinker:  1734-1807
Recipient:  Henry Sandwith Drinker:  1770-1824
Date: 1802-10-21
Title: 1802 October 21, Downingtown, to Henry S. Drinker, near Bristol Pennsylva.

Downingtown Octor. 21. 1802.
My very dear   Son,

This ridiculous whim which thou hast adopted has   given me more pain than I can express,  I cannot conceive   what should induce thee, who is settled in the way thee   wished, on a good farm, which thee knows so well how to   manage and improve, without paying rent: To take it into thy   mind to leave thy all; a young family of precious children,   and parants in precarious health, to go 9000 miles on a   tempestuous sea, in the most dangerous season of the year,   art thou insane?  What can be thy inducement: compare thy   situation with hundred that are quite happy and contented;   Why art thou not so?  Why this unsettled idea? –  If thee   puts this scheme in practice, I hardly expect ever to see   thee again in this world, – even if thou should be spared to   return to those of thy friends that may be left –  Thee   wrote before we left town on this subject to thy father, But   I never saw the letter, WD. told me thee talk’d of going to   India, I expected thy father had wrote thee, and that it was   the thought of a moment that was now given over; thy letter   to thy father and brother rec’d yesterday, I might have   read, but that to William was enough for me, to think thou   art in earnest is more than I can, at times well bear –   consider well, my dear son what thou art [preparing]:   perhaps on thy return, if thou should be so favoured, thee   may find thy parants no more; and some of thy little ones   gone &c.  This is thee may say looking at the worst side of   things, but pray inform me what is the best side,  I see no   good that is likely to result from it–  Can thy scheme be a   view of money making, if so, will the little gain, thy   hardships may obtain, be equal to the loss and devastation   that may occur during thy absence–  do my dear Henry give up   this wild notion, be thankful for what thou hast, make the   best of it, and I trust, more will be added, if ‘tis   necessary for thee.–  thou hast, according to my ideas great   cause ofthankfulness –  thou mayst have trials that I know not of,   but going to the worlds-end will not cure them –  If “an   exemption from evil is a real good” how many evils art thou   exempt from? – be content and resign’d. –  If the former   desire of a trip to Great Britain had revived in thy mind   (tho I should hardly think it would in thy present   situation, and in those times of trouble) I should not   oppose it, at a suitable time of the year, if thou could   leave thy family and farm with propriety:  but this   East-India notion may be ruineous if put in practice –    There is no one that loves thee but would be grieved at such   a procedure – not a single word has past between thy father   and myself on this business, till [ye] day he recd. thy last   letter, when I mentioned my very great concern on thy acct.   he say’d it was a rediculous foolish whim –  Do my dearest   Henry give over all thoughts of leaving all that is near and   dear to thee for a phantom, and if thee does, I am of the   first oppinion thee will never have reason to repent it. –   Thee may remember when thee first concluded to be a Farmer,   I oppos’d it, wishing thee near me while I lived – but   seeing thee seem’d fixed in that way, I gave up my wishes –   and since, the frequent attacks of malignant fever in our   City, I think I may truly say, I have been thankful thee was   so well and happily, as I thought, settled on a good Farm –   where I hope thee will content thyself and remain. –  Jacob   Downing has been several days in and near the City, he wrote   to Sally that the fever was worse, a greater number of new   cases, than at any other time, Dr. Rush told him it wd. be   very improper for our family to return, as there was several   ill, not far from us. –  Joseph Downing has been very unwell   with fever and pain in his head, not yellow fever, he is   rather better – last week we had concluded to return home on   first or second day last, but hearing of the death of a   baker not far from us, and two cases in Elfriths’ Alley, and   several in [Keys’] alley, thy father gave it over for [ye]   present, ‘tho he is very desireous of being at home – To be   seperated from my Children at those times of difficulty is a   trial to me.  Our dear Nancy who has been at times unwell,   has been much in my thoughts, ‘till Iread thy letter to thy brother, which has filled my mind   with little else but thee –  Thy dear father has had many   attacks of his old complaint, and frequently disordered   bowels, has taken liquid ladanum every night for some weeks   past, he is at present better of the gravelly complaint, but   not well in his bowels.–  A Letter, or rather small packet   directed by thee to James Smith came here by some mistake   with thy other two – thy father has sent it back to the City   –  I hope ‘ere long to see thee, after mature deliberation,   fully convinced of thy mistake – which will be a very great   satisfaction to thy trully affectionate mother E.   Drinker

No one here knows any thing of thy intention   that I know of, not a word of it has been mention’d – indeed   it is a subject that we cant bear to talk on  My love is to   Hannah and the Dear Children –Paid 10
Henry S. Drinker
near 
Bristol 
Pennsylva.
Mail

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Joseph Simpson:  1835-1901
Recipient:  Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth) Cope:  1840-1944
Date: 1878-06-28
Title: 1878 June 28, Sunnyside, Mayfield, near Ashbourne, England, to My dear Friend

Sunnyside.
Mayfield.
near Ashbourne.

Jun 28.   1878.

My dear Friend,
I have been waiting till thy   beautiful gift came home, in its Oak Frame, before sending   thee in words the warm thanks which I feel for such an   evidence of thy kind thought. It was, indeed, a surprise, to   me when dear Annie returned, and I shall value the gift not   only for the kind giver’s sake, but for its own intrinsic   beauty.
I wish thee could see it in the Hall – in the   place of honour nearthe Dining Room Door. It is mounted in white, with plain   gilt bead, flat oak frame, unvarnished, and, as all admit,   it is just a household treasure, nothing less. Didst thee   know my weakness for Raphael? I have seven of his Cartoons,   [famed] & his own portrait besides! So thou seest what a   treat thou hast given me! Ere long I hope [thee] will see   the "Candelabri" where it now hangs. –
And you are now in   Florence – close by the Cathedral – & the Grand Duke’s   Palace – & John of Bologna’s masterpiece – & the Pitti &   Uffizzi galleries!  Oh,what would I not give for a quiet day at Fiesole just now?   Of course you have been there, & seen these chaste, quaint,   spirituelle works of the saintly Angelo. I enjoyed them   exceedingly. Almost as much – tho’ in a different way – to   Angelo’s Night & Day &c in the Church of St. Lorenzo. By the   way, I hope you have Childe Harold with you and Roger’s   Italy. Do read both on the spot, and when you next go to the   [----] Room (I forget its [right] name) at the Pitti pray   make, on my behalf, a salaam of special reverence before its   priceless treasures.Agnes will tell you all our domestic details. We should much   like to hear how my dear friend, your Sister Clementine, now   is. If she comes to England during your absence, please send   us word, for I should feel it a pleasure to offer her a   welcome to England on her arrival in L’pool.
Annie has   given us delightful accounts of your adventures. I trust you   both suffer no longer from the cold. Won’t you let us see   your art mementoes on yr. return?  How rich you must   feel!
With our united love to both, – & renewed thanks, I   am thine, sincerely,
J. Simpson

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Taber:  1822-1887
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1846-01-21
Title: 1846 January 21, New Bedford, to F.R. Cope, Philada.

Dear Friend 
New Bedfor[d] 1 mo 21 1846 –

Your   letters were as duly received as unduly attended to.  Not   however that I did not make search for the subscription   paper. actual[--] mon ami by two reasons one to comply with   your request & another to trump up certain delinquents whose   names were therein appended to certain generous figures   which have not as yet been Transferred to my Pocket Book. --   Troubles in the family have since then as you surmised   interfered with all other matters and hence. -- -- --.  But   if I cant find it. put us down viz. W.H. Hussey Jack do. Ed   Rudman Tom do. S.R. Morgan Ben Barker Job A.T. Eddy. Rob’ B   Howland. Ch. Osborne. Aug. & myself for the whole amot.   –

Warned – I am armed.  But Frank you need a rib.    When I consider the imminent danger – you are in Every   Sunday. of blowing away walking home from Meeting alone. I   wonder at your remaining single.  Let her be somewhat solid.   – an anchor to windward – then no matter how the storm may   rage. mignon you may under [bare] [poles] you know ride out   the gale, rocked in the cradle of the Deep –

But a   fig for your predictions – What satisfies me of thine   felicity is in the 1st place & chiefly. I. am dreadful   pertikler myself. & 2dly (see over the leaf.)some others are so likewise – "man & consequently   woman"

Every creature likes his ease
English   French & Roman
I’ve seen men were hard to please
&   consequently Woman –

Womenkind will have their   way
Even tell you go! man!
I like to hear men say   their say
& consequently woman –

But marriage is a   happy lot
He who doubts is no man
Men in plenty may be   got
& consequently woman

You’re a good boy never   fib
Gamble [----] & so, man!
Go and get yourself a   rib
& consequently woman –

As for me you never   fear
Sure I shant be slow, man!
Get some money – then   – oh dear!
& consequently woman
Write me a systematic letter. --  I abominate this way you   have got into of diplomatic correspondence. Every word of   which you might publish in the newspapers.  Hows   [Con—cervis] my next leisure moment, shall be tak[en] up   with a letter to him.  Give New B. my best respects. whither   I [go] on to Balt or not shortly. is doubtful. as every   thing else is in this “wale”. but if “i” do I shall pop in   to your counting room some fine morning –

Write me   first. about the crops & the weather & business & all that   sort of thing you know. a real interesting sensible sort of   a letter. but – the girls –

with much   regard.
yours’ &c
Charles Taber
F. R. Cope
H & A. Cope & Co
Philada.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  H. Simpson
