Date: 1906-12
Title: 1906 December, Cunard R.M.S. Ivernia, to Rachel C. Cope

[12. .1906]
Cunard R. M. S. "IVERNIA"

Tues.   Morning. 

My dearest old Chellie.
If only I could   have thee within earshot, even if it was but by the   agitating telephone, how I could pour forth to thee! But   instead I'm afraid it will be rather a sorry makeshift as my   mind & hand are far from steady,- both of these show up   worse on paper. Dear heart, I don't know how to tell thee   what all this loving thought has meant to me this past week.   It seemed as
if it literally "encompassed" me- such dear words by letter   here [-ailing] with those exquisite flowers & then the sweet   little book- it was all most heast warming & dearer of thee   than I can say- Bless thee again & again - & oh! how very   good is the [--------] deep, true love that I know all these   things represent! I saved the little book as I said, until   we got well away, & each day’s sweet thought has been so   cheering through these rather dismall days. Thy own dear   words, best of all-in spite of Dora Greenwell’s perfect understanding of the   deep things of friendship- Anna’s packet has been a perfect   delight to us & hope to tell her myself if possible. But we   still roll so badly that writing is not very easy, & we have   left it until almost the 11th hour hoping for better things   [we] mail this at [-------]. We found most capital   staterooms waiting for us, & started forth quite gaily with   so many little last hand shakes from our kind friends, but   that first dinner is the only meal we have taken in the   Saloon, & we have kept ever quietly to our rooms except for   a few hours on Sunday when we could sit on deck. Not that we   have had any stormbut it was very cold, snowed a little the first three days,   & we had high seas. This with a heavy cargo of grain has   kept us rolling hard all the way over, for a large export of   cotton that would have steadied the ship, failed to arrive   in time, we hear, & also we are not properly ballasted. But   we are making good time, & hope to be in tomorrow (wed.)    evening probably too late to get home, but in time to lay   our heads on a steady pillow!
In spite of all the   knocking about we have had, trunks traveling across the   floor &c. we have neither of us been down to the crisis, but   intense nausea has made a complete coward of me, & L has had   no ambitions! She sends her dear love & hopes to write soon   her thanks for the lovely carnation & roses. My dear love to   you all, that often
I have recalled my [coming] visit to   you! Fare thee well thee very dear person always thy loving   old 
H


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1867-07-21
Title: 1867 July 21, Laurel House, to Father

Laurel House July 21st/67

My dear Father,
Tom has   written to thee so very lately, that I fear I can hardly   find enough of interest to fill a second letter, & besides I   am almost afraid to write one to go so far, & cost so much;   but perhaps a little Cattskill news would not be unwelcome.    We have been here for several days but owing to the   unkindness of the weather have not been able to accomplish   as much as we could wish – we made one very successful   expedition to Haines’ falls on 6th day morning, we took a   carriage or rather an express-wagon & rode over there, & had   a fine scramble, we went down the stream to the lower falls,   & scrambleddown to the foot, Tom concluded not to go all the way as it   was so rough & hard, & one after another gave out until when   we arrived at the foot there was no one but Harry, Ellie,   Madge & I left, but we were very glad we persevered &   thought ourselves well repaid, you never told us last fall   how beautiful it was.  We did not get home till after they   had gone to dinner so were obliged to go in just as we were   in our mountain dresses, & as we were all prepared concluded   to go under Tom’s guidence to visit Bastion falls   afterwards.  So about 4 we set off prepared to have a very   jolly time, Tom went ahead and cleared the way, & we   followed jumping over the logs & stones which Thomas   declare[d] were not there last fall, & must be the result of   last winters slide;Just as we arrived at the head of the fall, & were   congratulating ourselves on the prospect before us, what   should it do but begin to rain!  At first we thought it   would only be a little shower, & took shelter under the   trees as there were unfortunately no overhanging rocks –   this did very well for a little while, but instead of   stopping the rain got harder & harder, & at last began to   find its way through the trees & onto us – we soon found   ourselves getting very moist, & began to confer on measures   of relief, it was at length concluded as we were already   quite wet, & there was no sign of stopping to start for   home.  At first it seemed to slacked a little & we pushed   bravely on, but it got faster & faster & by the time we   reached the foot of Cauterskillwe were thoroughly drenched & in despair at having to ascend   all those dreadful steps – I wish thee could have seen us as   we came up to the house too tired to run any more dragging   along all dripping & hot, looking as much as possible like   drowned rats.  The gentlemen on the piazza were so polite as   not even to smile, but I’m sure I could not have helped. it.   I don’t think we any of us suffered for it though, & I did   not even feel tired in the evening, this mountain air is so   invigorating.  Yesterday it rained perseveringly & we had to   amuse ourselves as best we could reading, & walking on the   piazza.  The company here is not as congeneal as we could   wish, & we often envy Aunt Annie & Cous. Clem in their   Adirondack society.  One young gentleman regaledus last night with some Scotch songs, but it was very   inferior to Carry Rowland’s performance.  I think Tom told   thee that we have the same room you had last year, & enjoy   it very much, it is so nice having that beautiful view   always before us, I think I enjoy it much more than the map   in front of the Mountain House; it is so constantly   changing, sometimes that distant mountain will be entirely   hid by the clouds, & it is so beautiful to see them coming &   going; we have had no perfectly clear weather since we   arrived, & have become almost discouraged, & the   chamber-maid told me by way of comfort yesterday, that it   sometimes rained strait aheadfor a week, however it really does look like clearing now,   the clouds are drifting away, & there are great patches of   blue-sky.  If it is clear tomorrow we have planned an   expedition to the Plauterkill which I hope will be a   success.  Tom Stokes & Harry had intended starting on a   fishing excursion yesterday but after routing out of their   beds about 4, & eating sandwitches preparatory to starting,   were obliged to give up on account of the rain, & go back to   bed in disgust.  We have only received one letter from home   which reported all well, but by the time this reaches thee   thee will have received more recent news.  All send their   love & wishes for thy welfare wh. means I suppose that they   hope thee is not awfully sick, in which I heartily join,   Thee must notimagin from my description that we are not having a good   time for we are only the rain was a little dampening but   since the sun has come out we feel very lively & up to any   amount of of scrambling.  Write by every steamer & tell us   every thing.
Thy very affectionate
Lily


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Henry W. (Henry Waln) Drinker:  1787-1866
Recipient:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Date: 1817-06-13
Title: 1817 June 13, Stoddartsville, to Thomas P. Cope Esq., Philadelphia

Stoddartsville June the 13th. 1817–
Dear Uncle.
By   William Drinker who pass’d Here on the 9th  I receivd thy   remembrance of the 3d inst–  What Charles Miner has done or   is now about I cannot precisely say not hav[ing] seen Him or   any of his friends since [my] Last
I question the   Establishment of the proposed Bank at Wilkes barre & beleive   also that if it ever does go into Operation it will be by   compromise and by a [di----] of the few offices of [---]   attatched to it–  Humble merit will I presume stand but a   poor chance–
Mr Arndt on whom I depended for [the]   Hemlock Bark Has not yet ground it but I hope He will attend   to it shortly–  if it in any degree succeeds [in] England it   will be Highly important to this Count[r]y as well as   convenient to ship overseas–  I beleive that the mak[ing]   pot & pearl Ash might prove an advantageous thing to us more   than to any other persons [We] owning the nearest Large Body   of suitable timber for the purpose – if it will pay for its   mak[ing] & a reasonable sum for outlay & superintendance it   will answer us as a means of clear[ing] Land –
I am glad   that thy mind is made up for a peep at this quarter of the   world – I think it will be likely to be beneficial to thy   Health as also to Aunts – Some Rough travell[ing] there will   no doubt be – but generaly speak[ing] the Roads are   tolerable to the mouth of Tunkhannock–  Thereare no excelent Taverns on the Route so far as I am   acquainted–  I think the one Here is the Best & likely to be   the most pleasant for the Residence of aunt–  Gentlemen can   be well accomodated at Easton & at Wilkes barre at Mr Whites   in the first nammed place & at Mr Arndts in the second in   Both Houses there is Rather too much noise and Drink[ing] to   be entirely agreeable to Ladies –  Here also we have more   noise than is pleasant–  There be from 15 to 20 of Stoddarts   work[ing] hands quart[ere]d in the House –  
The Road by   Easton is Rather worse than that by Bethlehem & Nazareth & I   think generaly the accommodations are better on this last   Route–  from Nazareth to Hellers at the Wind gap at which   House I have generaly procured tolerable Eating & pretty   clean–  from thence about 17 miles to William Sox’s upon the   top of Pokono – where th[e]y make prety good coffee & give   you what ever they may Have in the House in a tolerably   cleanly stile–  from thence to this place say 12 miles   –
The present is about as pleasant a Time to Travel in   this county as any other Dur[ing] the summer – ere the grain   is cut which will not be Done before the Last of next monthHowever the Weather is now variable and we may expect   occasional Rains, until after Harvest – 
in the Last of   August & to the middle of September is generaly more settled   weather – as to the [Gnats] they Have already come & in the   woods Bite sharply–  This [they] will continue to Do until   September – But out of the woods we do not find them   Troublesome– There are not any curiosities worthy a name   from Philada to this place–  The Habits & manners of the   people on the Route may perhaps afford Something novel – The   scenery also & general Aspect of the County will be new –   [marbly] nature in Her Roughest garb will surround you – you   will have pure Air & pure water & I doubt not to good   [appetites] as to enable you to Encounter much coarser fare   than usual – in the neighbourhood of Easton-Bethlehem &   Nazareth is a lime stone county – & I would have you beware   of the water – it is no doubt wholesome but to persons   [unaccustomed] to it it is often unpleasant in its effects–   if I know when you intend com[ing] up I will endeavor to   join you at Hellers – I have been constantly interupted   since I began writing which must excuse this   scrawl–
affectionaly thy nephew. H.W.Drinker –Stoddartsville 
 12 1/2 
June 14th
Thomas P. Cope   Esq.
Merchant
Philada.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Joseph Simpson:  1835-1901
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1894-11-16
Title: 1894 November 16, Sunnyside, Mayfield, Ashbourne, to My dear Friend

Sunnyside
Mayfield
Ashbourne

Nov.16.1894
<br   My dear Friend,
When I received thy very welcome letter,   & the handsome volumes which accompanied it, I felt once   more that strong desire, which often stirs me, to visit   America, & to see again those dear friends who, nearly   thirty years ago, received me there with such unbounded   kindness.  Some of these have passed away, but a few are   left, and of these thou, my dear friend, with thy good   Brotherand your dear Wives, are kept in very cherished remembrance.   So it was delightful to get thy letter, & since its receipt   I have spent several hours in reading, with great interest,   this excellent Life of your great President.  How it has   recalled the old days!  I have gone over so much that had   lain dormant so long, & am more than ever impressed with   Lincoln’s marvellous development from his miserable early   surroundings. How could any man so outlive his environment?    And who could have believed that any man with such aparentage, & such debasing influences around him in early   life, could, by any innate power, or any outward   circumstance, become the great man Lincoln proved himself   later on.  We are slow to learn God’s lesson that He chooses   his instruments very differently to ourselves.
So far as   I can test Mr. Morse’s accuracy, he is very just; neither   hiding Lincoln’s shortcomings nor wishful to make out “a   case,” pro or con, but to act judicially.  I hope to give   our Workpeople an hour’s talk this Winter, based largely   upon this interesting Biography.Thanks for thy kind message to Agnes & the [baines].  All   are well.  How I wish they could see thee in the flesh, for   they often hear thee quoted, and are familiar with thy face,   through the Portrait which is hung, with Uncle Smith   Harrison’s, in our Library – the much valued gift of thy   good son, Hazen – to whom please give my love.
I trust   you are all well: it would be a real pleasure to see you all   again, but, at present, I see no chance of getting away.    With our united love to all our friends at Awbury, I   am,
Thine, very sincerely
J. Simpson.


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Taber:  1822-1887
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1848
Title: 1848 to Francis R. Cope, Philada.

Oh Poesy! what wight of Wretched State
Een at the lowest   bottom of his woe
When griefs surround him or sad toils   await
When cold misfortunes hand doth round him   blow
But calls on thee to aid against the foe?
Come   gentle soother of wan misery’s train
Before the scowling   can away doth go
Come shower thy spirit down on me   again
*For Frank Cope wants a letter – shall he want in   vain!!!!
*Here the Poet alludes to Danae & Jupiter   olympus an ancient buck

So Henricus is dead! dead ere   his prime!
Alas! that he should share the doom of   man!
Who now is left to build the lofty   rhyme?
Although his altitude was but a span
It   [overtopped] his years. = But no man can
Add cubits to   his stature or his days –
Vain task to stop the fateful   cruel hand
That wields the gory scissons. -- Worldy   praise 
High thought – nor noble deed its destined course   delays. –

(Now all that second Paragraph is   gammon
But if you really think it worth the trouble
If   twill not seem like too great love of mammon
I think you   can get quite as much or double
Prime cost – besides –   perhaps – who knows the bubble
Called Fame / which you’ll   keep for commissions
I want the rhino – all besides is   stubble)
By handing it about without omission
‘Mong'st   those who loudest wail that he's gone to Perdition)
I want you to hand it particularly to Miss B. --------.    Send on the amount collected for the benefit of the author   as soon after the funeral as possible.---

But as in   olden time, when-freshly sprung
From the great Maker’s   hand – all Earth was fair
Excelling in its beauty – fresh   & young
When strength & health perfumed with the balmy   air 
And all Earth’s Gifts were far beyond compare   
With what now ‘neath Heaven’s weary blessing   grows
What time the grove Hesperia apples bare
From   out the salt salt wave fair Venus rose
Graceful her   dripping locks she round her did dispose

So from the   Sorrow tearful deep & sad
Which mourns thy memory   departed Shade
While oer the dust which erst thy spirit   clad
And the loved link which bound thee to us made
We   grieve thou coulds’t not Death’s cold hand evade
Who   plucks the brightest flowers – hard to please
[While]   tears fall fast from all that thou shouldst fade
Love   ever radiant though steeped in tears
Love-rosy tints the   clouds – Love sooths the foamy seas
or Love heavenly love   appears
Just as you please

all the while alluding   in an inexpressibly delicate manner to the very peculiar   situation in which Miss B. ----- and I find ourselves since   Harry’s departure  You may show them to the lady.  Present   them as the first fruits. ----
But enough of this nonsense -  If you are heartily tired of   it remember you began it. --  and when my Muse gets well   under weigh – like Addisons there’s no stopping her. -------   Father has been unwell for some time and so much so that a   good part of the business devolves on me – in connection   with some other domestic affairs – putting a very unlooked   for and regrettable veto on my proposed trip to Philada   –
Perhaps another year may bring around the same   expectations which I hope will not be disappointed
Before   that time however I trust to see you on [here] for although   it is not to be presumed that New Bedford alone should   possess sufficient attractions – to be the terminus of your   visit it may serve as a [stepping] stone to some place that   has more ---
Remember me to [Tom] [&] your   friend
Charles Taber
Francis R. Cope
care of H. & A. Cope
Philada.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna S. Biddle
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1862-09-17
Title: 1862 September 17, to Chellie

Sept. 17th. 1862.

Dear Chellie, 
I have been      waiting for news, before answering your last letter and am      now not much better off, but you write such very short      letters that I am not at all conscientious about making mine      short also.  I wish my dear, that you would make your      letters a little longer, & if you do not you will see mine      gradually decreasing in length, till there is hardly any      letter at all.  Uncle James went off to Harrisburg on Monday      as did Uncle Clem George Emlen John Thayre (my cousins) and      Cousin George Biddle.  Uncle Clem never told a soul that he      was going and on Sunday night when John went to the      Baltimore depot to see Gerge Emlen and John Thayre off to      his surprise he saw Uncle Clem.He was going off without bidding us good-bye when perhaps we      may never see him again.  He always was very queer but this      beats every thing.  Is not the war news splendid?  I have      not been so glad since the battle of Drainsville,      particularly about Howell Cobb the old traitor.  There is      now not the slightest fear of our having Stonewall Jackson      in Philadelphia but I pity the poor citizens of Cincinnati.       Cousin Sam Cox was called to a churchthere (St. Paul’s) and he accepted.  He left town two weeks      from yesterday and when he arrived at Cincinnati he was not      allowed to enter the city but was sent to a boarding house      about two miles from the city.  There he is now with his      wife children and father.  Of their furniture they know      nothing and are not allowed to go to the city to see about      it.  Every morning at five o’clock all the bells in the town      ring and every man who is able to carry a gun assembles in      some perminent place and from thence they go out into the      country to wait for the enemy.  Even clergymen are forced to      fight & Cousin Sam is in almost hourly fear of being made to      serve.  I received a letter from Martha Henderson just now.They are at present in Wiesbaden and Martha says that if her      relations were with her she would never again wish to leave      there, not even for America.  That I cannot understand for      no place can or will ever be the same to me as dear      Philadelphia.  But I am forgetting my determination to make      my letter short and although I am burning to go on I deny      myself for your good as I think a little correction will be      very beneficial to you so I will sign myself y
your ever      loving and for long letters begging friend
Anna

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Martha Leeds:  1810?-1888
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope:  1794-1863
Date: 1833-05-25
Title: 1833 May 25, to My dear Sister

My dear Sister,

Mother had just sent Sally up with an   epistle from thee to her for me to read and with directions   that as I intend writing to do so this afternoon and say   that she is well and getting along admirably – hopes you   will not feel uneasy about them and not hurry home on   account of home –  Indeed she and Aunt look so happy there   together that thee need not console with her in the least on   account of loneliness –  Mother now can ransack and make and   mend at her leesure and without interruption –  Sister Ruth   with her husband & baby and nurse and I with my ditto ditto   ditto spent one first day with her very pleasantly and since   I have [been] taken tea with her but cannot call very often   to see her on account of family affairs  Harriet is still   with me and doing her best  We still have homemade bread and   a very good table in regard to cookery  I had no prospect   that she could have done so well but I have had to work   quite merrily or I should never have things to get done in   time –  We have a good black boy and Ann Clement has come   and suits very well and now if I could meet with a goodSally in the kitchen I should be better fixed than ever   if thee should see one on the road thee is travelling do   tell her the direction of our house –  I have no prospect of   getting one to suit except indeed a faint one of a girl from   Bridgeton that Harriet knows of –  Several have applied but   I am very particular as I do not wish to change very soon   again –  Laura continues as good as she can be sleeps all   the morning and all night without waking –  She has a cough   now and I am little afraid it will prove to be Whooping   Cough as Ann has some thing like it –  Dr Thomas came   yesterday to vaccinate her and says it is a favourable age   and season to have it –
I am pleased to hear that you are   all well and that you are enjoying your travel so much  I   very much hope that it will prove particularly beneficial to   thee –  Tell the boys I quite long to peruse their   interesting journals.  I hope they relate anecdotes and   retail conversations – tell Tommy I expect his will be   humourous and Franky’s abstruse –  Mary’s no doubt will be   quite correct and modestly written as she is so quiet about   it
How gratified William must be with your visit do   persuade him to fit up his handsome house and get a wife to   take care of it.–  I wonder that the idea should have to be   suggested to himSister Frances in her last letter to me desires me to write   particularly about thy health and Sister Rs and desires her   love to be given.  Is she not a lovely woman?  She is so   intelligent affectionate and sprightly –  I love her very   much –  She says that she would have been delighted if we   had visited her but that now she could not ask us at [a--]   [s--] as her children have the whooping cough –  Mother   Pleasants has gone to New York yearly meeting to be absent a   couple of weeks –  She invited Mother and Aunt M Leeds to   spend the day with her before she went, with us but it   rained and we did not get to go
Nothing new or   interesting here I tell to thee I believe in private annals   and of public events the newspaper will inform –  John   Randolp of Roanoke died day before yesterday at the City   Hotel
Give my best love to brother Henry and the children   I shall be glad to see you home again returning with renewed   health and spirits – that it may be so in the ardent wish of   thy affectionate sister –
Martha.PHil 25 May; Paid 
Rachel R. Cope
 Care of William D Cope
 Woodbourne. Susquehanna 
 Penna.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Henry W. (Henry Waln) Drinker:  1787-1866
Recipient:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Date: 1818-11-20
Title: 1818 November 20, Stoddartsville, to Thomas P. Cope Esq., Philadelphia

Thomas P. Cope
Stoddartsville November 20th   1818.
Respected Uncle,
From Father from Wm Drinker &   from B.[T]. Case I have understood that Susquehanna County   Has recd from thee a recent visit & also that our   Philadelphia & Great Bend Turnpike was not without interest   in thy sight–
That this Road Should be deemed of   importance By thee & yet not through my representations of   its incalculable Value affords me much pleasure–  Directly   Interested in it myself & anxious by every Honest means to   ensure its success  Still there were insurmountable   objections to my endeavoring to influence Thee in its   promotion–  I hope I need not explain from whence these   objections proceeded – they are inseparable from the History   of my life & my powers of Memory–
On the 14th I proceeded   to Wilkes barre in order to See Mr Henry Clymer- Thomas   Meredith & others and to definitively establish the Route of   our Turnpike – also to nominate Commissioners & to Petition   the Legislature–  without Know[ing] who would or would not   Serve in Philada we nominated the following subject to   alterations if necessary–
Thomas Stewardson – Thomas P   Cope – John Reed – Condy Raquet, Benjamin R Morgan & John   Gibson – for Philada–
Henry Clymer – Henry W Drinker & Wm   Clark – for Luzerne–
Isaac Ryneerson – Thomas Meredith –   Wm Ward & B[T] Case – for Susquehan[a]
A New Route Had   been Explored By Mr B[T] Case to the Westward several miles   of the one contemplated & Explored for Thomas Stewardson –   shorter in distance & less Hilly than the [first] & far more   interesting to thy Estate on the Meshoppen–
after   minutely examining the apparent advantages of the two   Routes. I gave my assent to adopting the one last explored &   Our Petition was Drawn in conformity thereto–
For want of   a Better map of Common Reference I must make use of Reading   Howells map of Pennsylvania to carry to thee an Idea of the   Route though from the incorrectness of it our Road will   appear more crooked than it will be eventualy found–
Our   Road begins at One Matts Tavern on the Coskectune and Great   Bend Turnpike Towards the Head of Salt [Lick] Creek – where   the Road from Tyoga Point crosses the said Turnpike –    Thence across the Milford & Owego Turnpike – & thence   between Martins Creek & the North Branch of the Tunkhannock   Creek–Thence across the South Branch of the same – & Thence   through Leggets Notch (or Gap) in the Lackawannock Range of   mountains [Formed by Leggets creek a small stream pretty   into the Lackawannock about 15 miles from the Susquehannah   according to Reading Howells map & scale] then across the   East & West Road at one Swartz Tavern – & then across   Roaring Brook or Deep Hollow Creek – Thence nearly Parralel   with the Same to the main Branch of the Lehigh River–    Thence S. 10 E across Tobyhanna Creek & its Branches to the   Sullivans Road & thence by the East End of the Large Pond to   the Turnpike Road on the top of the Pokono mountain at or   near the 30 mile stone from Wilkesbarre–  The whole Distance   Being from Point to point as Explored & measured about Fifty   Three miles – & the Estimated Expence $1000 per mile–  Our   Petition asks the Legislature to incorporate a company with   a capital of $75,000 – but entre nous this is but a [Ruse de   Guerre]–
I do not pretend (from my imperfect knowledge of   the precise situation of thy lands upon the Meshoppen) to be   able to say How far thy interest may be advanced by the   completion of this Road But that it will be more or less   appears evident and plain –  That the Whole of Susquehanna   County – a Part of Luzerne Co. & a part of Pike will feel   its Blessings is not to be denied–  Neither I think will it   be doubted that the Road is interesting to parts of   Northampton – Bucks & Montgomery counties & as will be shown   Peculiarly Interesting to the City & county of   Philadelphia–
We have called it The Philadelphia & Great   Bend Turnpike & with good reason.- it forming the most   Important Link in the chain of communication & the only one   wanting to secure to Philadelphia incalculable advantages–    From the Pokono a good Turnpike Road now Exists (not Log   Turnpike) to the Wind Gap & from thence [are] two good   county Roads to Easton – on to Bethlehem by the way of   Nazareth – or to Janets Bridge in Lower Saucon where a   Turnpike Road is laid out – then by good Roads to either the   Willow Grove or Germantown Turnpikes  to the City of   Philada–.  We might Have called our Turnpike The   Counteracting Turnpike – it being the Only one Ever   projectedcalculated (By Intersecting the Turnpikes Leading to the   City of New York in important points) to counteract the   Influence that City by Her Liberallity Her Geographical   Wisdom and foresight in despight of natural obstructions –   Has obtained–
There is One advantage which will result to   Philada from this Road which (amongst many others) I select   Because it will reach the comprehension of Every man & is   capable of undeniable proof & is indeed Known to very many   persons in Bussiness in Philadelphia–  I speak now of the   Cattle Trade or the Driving of Horned Cattle Sheep & Horses   to the Philadelphia market–  I shall speak of such Facts as   are Known to me – some of which are Known to our Dry good   merchants – some to our Graziers and all to the Drovers   themselves–
The persons Engaged in this Trade are nearly   to a man Store Keepers from the state of New York–  They   receive cattle sheep & Horses in payment for various   merchandize sold by them to farmers in their vicinity.  Or   purchase them with the monies they Receive for their goods–    Their Best market for these cattle is found at Philadelphia   & notwithstanding the circuitous Route they are obliged to   take & the most miserable & wretched Roads which alone Exist   to this market they Drive Annualy cattle sheep & Horses to   the amount of One million of Dollars– (I [think] this season   of Horned cattle alone that near if not quite 1/2 a million   of Dollars in value Has passed By this place & through the N   & South Road  at least I am persuaded that I may rely on the   account I have Received of the number) – if then it be a   fact that near one million of Dollars in cattle sheep &   Horses reaches Philadelphia Every year from the State of New   York and that for want of a Road from Philada- to the   Western part of that state – the whole Sum is Drawn in cash   from Philada and goes to the City of New York & there is   Expended in the purchase of Merchandize Because of good   waggon Roads Connecting that City with the Said western part   of the State – will it not be apparent thatOur Road in Truth is a Philadelphia Turnpike & well Worthy   the Patronage & Support of every liberal minded Citizen–    But that this is the fact Every Drover will admit & I   beleive that they will very generaly declare that they would   much rather purchase their merchandize in Philadelphia than   in New York if it were possible to waggon [their] goods   through Pennsylvania to their Homes–  at least this is the   Sentiment expressed to me as far as I have conversed with   them – in addition Then to these facts – I may state That   Though Cattle forms perhaps a principal Remittance from   Store Keepers in the Western pt of N York–  Yet it is not   the only One – a good deal of Cash also is brought Down by   these persons & this cash also goes to the City of New York   which would if our Road was made Remain in Philada–
I may   State too without fear of contradiction that this Cattle   Trade in despight of Obstacles Has constantly & rapidly   increased that in spight of them it will increase & that if   nothing is done to Counteract the Evil we shall still   continue to pay to the City of New York for the Beef we Eat   – or in other words that the Philadelphia merchant. shall   continue to pay the New York merchant for the whole amount   of cattle Driven from this quarter to Philadelphia–  an   Enormous Annual Ballance Indeed for this one article of our   Consumption – again – This Highly Interesting Section of the   State of New York – [is] Hourly increasing in Wealth &   Importance – in wants of Foreign articles & Resources of   Domestic Wealth – And let me ask where can the merchants of   Philadelphia Find a Body of such customers as exist Here –   where Such a certain& constant Trade–  Where such an increase of Trade where   such certain remittances–  Presenting also at Least one   Million of Dollars per annum Being Drawn out of the City at   this Time & How much Hereafter it is not possible to   predict–  This However may Be reasonably [assumed] as a fact   – that if such now is the amount of this Trade with all the   difficulties which want of Roads present – a good Road will   very materially increase it – in [----] to Enumerate the   advantages to be reaped by Establishing a Free communication   with this Most Fertile Section of New York would more   properly form a Volume than suit the limits of a Letter– Yet   I may add that This Cattle Trade – though in itself of no   mean Importance to Philadelphia is only One amongst many   Valuable Blessings which New York has taken from   Philadelphia By the Superior Foresight of Her Citizens –   There it Has been Esteemed Honorable & not unworthy the   attention of Her first merchants to Examine in to The   Internal Resources of Her State as well as of Her Sister   States – whilst the [reins] of Philadelphians Seems to Have   Been almost altogether Turned Towards the Sea – to Maritime   ports & Latterly to the Great Western Waters–  Yet what   assisted to raise Philadelphia to Her present prosperity &   Rank more than all other Things was the Internal resources   of Her own State & those Sections of other States within   marketable Reach – and it is only as these Blessings   multiply & Have facilities given them to Extend to & Support   Her that She can on any Just grounds expect to advance – If   this possition is True & if I Have notfailed in making good my ground of the Vast advantage of communication with a Section of the State of New York to Philadelphia is not our Road in Truth a Philadelphia Road & entitled to the Best wishes & aid of that City–   in the Magnitude of the Advantages to Be reaped from the State of New York through the Medium of this Road ??? I must not loose sight of the Trade of our own Counties which also at present for want of Roads lead[ing] to Philadelphia likewise goes to the City of New York ??? The amt of this I Have not the present means of ascertain[ing] But it must be considerable & is rapidly increasing??? The Coskectune and Great Bend Turnpike & the Milford & Owego Turnpike are striking at the Best Interests of Philadelphia??? New York City is By these Roads Establishing to Herself a Course of Trade which Though Now Easily Diverted from Her to Philadelphia is growing every day more & more difficult ??? a Timely Exertion an application of one mite of the Vast money Resources of Philada at this time in aid of this apparently insignificant Road will do more than the Expenditure of much Greater sums on Seemingly much Greater undertakings   Our Road will cut the Milford & Owego Road & the Coskectune & Great Bend Turnpike in so delicate a part that the whole Eastern Section of Each will be benumned & rendered lifeless ??? Their object (the secur[ing] the Trade to the City of New York)will be effectualy Counteracted & Defeated – & The Proverb   Be good to Philada – “One man Sows & another reaps the fruit   of His Labour”–
I have gone into a length of detail &   [-----] reasoning that I had not contemplated & I fear Have   tired Thee as well as myself.–  I crave forgiveness for my   fault–  I nevertheless would be much pleased if Thee Should   Think a Publication of Any of these Views – Couched in   different Language and Respectfuly dressed would in any way   be of advantage to us in gett[ing] through with our   important Road – for though I have made it appear that there   is abundant Riches to the West & North West of us & more   wealth than foresight in Philadelphia  Yet the fact must be   told that We are miserably poor – & that unless the City   aids our Road it may Be as long as Troys Seige before it is   Travelld–
Now if Thee would undertake the Herculean Task   of Picking the marrow (if there be any to be found) out of   this Long [map] of writing – Dress it & Suit it to the   palate of our Philadelphians & Serve it up to them in a News   paper I should Hope that it might in time of need possibly   aid us in Subscriptions to our Turnpike Stock –  This   However I leave to thy Better Judgement–
My Best Respects   to Aunt Grandmother & my cousins Generaly remain[ing] as   Ever affectionaly
thy Nephew HWDrinkerStoddartsVille
Novembr. 21st
Paid 25
Thomas P. Cope Esq.
Merchant
Philada

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1864-10-09
Title: 1864 October 9, Newport, to Elizabeth S. Cope, Awbury

Newport Oct 9th  1864, 1st day morn

Dear Sister–
I   recieved thy note (for I cannot call it a letter because it   contained so much nonsense) yester-day morning; but I did   not say poo! because I had an idea it was from Rachel or at   least hoped it did not contain nonsense.  I was glad to   recieve such information as thy note contained, & thought it   was a great compliment to be called handsome by sombody,   although I do not think father was much complimented by   having his hair called an iron gray color; unfortunatly I   did not lose my heart with her, although I think I must have   seen her & was very sorry I could not go to meting but my   knee was not equal to it.  I could have found some time to   write to you or thee butI have been very lazy since I have been here.  I delivered   thy message to Father (about Dr Thomas) but fear he has   forgotten about it, so I will remind him of it & now I must   close for I am getting lazy & will tell thee what we are   doing when there is some thing to tell about of more   consequence.  I believe Mother intends writing a   P.S.
Affec thy brother
TP. Cope Jr
P.S.  when I   said you on the first page near the bottom I meat Rachel &   thyself.  TP Cope Jr.

I am sorry there should be any   mistake about Dr. Thomas  I thought I told you, you would   have to send him word when you were ready to begin  You had   better tell him of myabsence from home so that he may understand why he was not   called on before.  So much for that - the burden of my   [----] is “painting.”  It is the burden on my mind & must of   course show itself in words.  Uncle Tom sent me word that he   had expressed a sample of color which Craig has prepared for   our inspection.  I suppose we may get the package tomorrow –   but what troubles me is the delay – Craig said he would have   it all done so we could come back the 20th.  If he has got   to put on two coats after he hears from us I fear he will   not be ready for us.  We are getting tired of this plan &   anxious to know whether there will be any difficulty about   getting intoour house on the 22nd.  Seventh day week - We have to engage   Staterooms two weeks before to get good ones & I intend   tomorrow to engage them for 6th day the 21st & if you find   the house cannot be got ready by that time you will please   send us word at once so that we can disengage the rooms.    Perhaps if Craig can not get all done & dry he can have the   kitchen & back passages finished & if the last coat is on   the parlors &c we might come in before it is dry–  I feel   sorry to have filled up Toms sheet with nothing but such a   message – try to do better next time.  It has been blowing   strong from the N.W. all day & is cold as charity Alf &   Hazen went to meeting with me in the morning & your   [br]other in the afternoon but its dull work here either   at the larger or smaller body Yankee self conceit shows   nowhere more. 


Elizabeth S. Cope
AwburyNewport Oct 9th  1864, 1st day morn

Date: 1842-08-17
Title: 1842 August 17, Schooley's Mountain, to Rachel Reeve Cope

Schooley's Mountain Aug 17. '42 

Dear Sister Rachel

We had so uneventful a journey, I have been so quiet since our arrival here, that I have scarcely material for a letter. Travellers are expected, I believe, to be particularly entertaining. Now, there is no time when I feel less so. Fatigue, change of air & diet, always for a time, affect my health unfavorably; and then, the turmoil & bustle scatter the little wits I possess. So that, from home, I am an especially stupid correspondent. Still, as you were kind enough to wish to hear from us, and as we exchanged promises about writing, I will not wait for any thing worth saying, --as I may not have it at all, thee knows; -- and my delay may occasion me the disappointment of not receiving here, the speedy return letter from Fourth St, which is to be my reward.-- 

We had quite a pleasant time so far as Trenton, for our first day's exploit. We arrived there about half past five o'clock; and George with our baggage, via. steam-boat and rail-road, very shortly after. In the evening, we made a little visit to Elizabeth Gummere, who lives near the Hotel. They have a fine, large house, in a pleasant part of town, & express themselves, the young folks, most emphatically, pleased with their change of residence. As we were in the immediate neighborhood, we went with Eliza..th, to spend a few minutes with our old friend, Judge Gordon's wife. She looks and seems just the same asI recollect her in the days of my childhood. So it appears that in this bustling life, there are some not easily jostled out of their way. We found the Judge, some years ago, busy with his attempts to sell his map of New Jersey. It still seems a most interesting theme to him; & if we come this way six years hence, I dare say he will even then be ready to speak of its merits & to state that his stock is not yet exhausted.-- Fifth day night brought us within twelve miles of the mountain, and the next day at noon, we reached the end of our journey--and over such roads! I was thinking, perpetually, of the children's song "Here we go up, up, up, & here we go down, down" &c &c. To adopt little Cary's favourite style, the rain had washed such gulleys in the roads, & the stones were so bare, & there were so many of them!-- 
The first two days after we got here, we had three or four showers per day. By way of consolation, we were told, this was a favorable specimen of their weather this season. For the previous ten days, it had rained all the time. "Recorder [Vaux?]" who is here, calls it temperance weather. I wonder if [Espy] is a tee-totaller.--We were beguiled , when we first came, into taking a room in "the cottage" Its superior dimensions, privacy &c were warmly insisted upon. And as we like plenty of room, and don't like much noise, we thought it quite a prize. The sun shone so flatteringly upon the [compact?], that we never thought of the inconvenience of being drenched in going to our meals, or having them drenched  in being brought to us. As we have now had ample opportunity of trying it both ways, and don't relisheither, we begin to murmer. Coming in search of Health, we fancy too, that a sleeping apartment on the ground floor is not exactly the place to meet with her ladyship, this damp summer. We have some of the inconvenient "[Fine-ear]" family, moreover, next us, who have been very near getting us into a scrape. A grand-daughter of John Jacob Astor has been stoping with a Mr Kane, from Albany, and, under what her friends consider, very aggravated circumstances. They came here to spend the Honey moon, & unfortunately, were placed in the room adjoining ours. Job related to me, one day, in a confidential tone of voice, the history of their flight, as just detailed to him by Governor Coles. This they contrived to over-hear, & being displeased thereat, they imagined a series of questions and answers,-- Job & I being the speakers,-- about the pedigree, personal consequence &c of many of the boarders, which they carried directly to the individuals about whom we were said to be so curious, & from there, they came immediately back to us. Happily, they fixed upon people whom we knew perfectly well, & thus the absurdity of our asking who they were whom we had known all our lives, was sufficiently apparent, & created only a little merriment. But we were somewhat annoyed until we discovered the full extent of this eaves-dropping. Thus, the storms without, & the treachery within doors, have given us a thorough distaste to this part of the premises. Besides, there is more of a crowd than we wished to get into, & if the company does not diminish, we shall want to try some quieter region. Direct, here, however, as we shall leave instructions for letters tobe sent to us. -- We have had it very warm & almost clear now for a couple of days, & have been enjoying it by driving about. The country is sufficiently beautiful to render the slow climbing of hills by no means a tedious affair. The roads are kept in quite tolerable order, & occasionally, we come to a level piece of ground where we trot away quite merrily. People tell us wonders about the flush gained and the disease lost among these hills. I hope our cases may add to a reputation, so richly earned, according to all accounts. -- I should write to Caroline, but I am not a very disinterested letter writer; sowing only where I may hope to reap, --& I fear she is scarcely yet at home.--I should like much, to know how you all are, where you now are, & where you are to be for he next few weeks.--Does thee know where Father & Mother are & when Cara returns? When do you go to Susquehanna [---] & how are Anne's eyes? Tell her I have not seen a single cat since I left home; but we have plenty of little ducks & chickens, the feeding of which is a daily source of amusement to the children. I heard them complaining this morning, that the older ladies were interfering with this, their peculiar privilege. Indeed the belles and beaux seem to find it quite as entertaining as they--remember, my dear R, that thee is bound to procure me a letter, in some way. Either from under thy own hand, (how is it?) or from one of those to whom thee can say "do this & he doeth it." If thee is not well enough, I shall calculate a little, too, on the affection & kindness of my nephews & niece. I do not know whether it will be any thing of a bribe-but I always make it a point to answer letters addressed to me--some time or other. If I should not


Henry Cope Esq.
For R. R. Cope.
N. 4th St.
Philadaget time during the excursion, I shall recollect my indebtedness on a future occasion.--Our love to brother H, to your segment of our family circle, & to all othermembers of it who are in the city. The carriage is waiting for me. Fare thee well! in haste, but very affectionately, sayeth thy sister 
E. C. Tyson:----We have determined to leave here on Second day. Will you not so arrange it as that a letter may reach us before then? It will gratify us very much.---

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Francis Cope:  1794-1816
Recipient:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Date: 1813-10-02
Title: 1813 October 2, Chambersburg, to brother

Chambersburg October 2nd 1813
 
My dear brother

 Although I neither gave thee nor any one else a [----] of writing, yet having an idle hour on hand I do not know how to employ it better.  We kept the stage from Philad'a to Harrisburg stayed half a day in Reading & a day & a half in Harrisburg.  As we were informed that it would be impossible to procure a place in the stage without waiting at Harrisburg a week & probably 2 weeks, we in company with two others engaged a hack to bring us to this place.  The expense was no greater than the stage hire & the travelling much more agreeable.  We lodged in Carlisle which from the last we had of it appeared to me the neatest place we have passed through upon leaving home.  We arrived here the next day afternoon.  It commenced raining just as we entered the town & continued with little intermission during the next [---].  On fifth day morning the clouds were broken & promised fine weather.  We accordingly determined to cross the mountain to McConnell [-] if it were possible to procure a chair.  Our landlord discouraged us so much from attempting it in that manner that we determined to try it on horse back.  What dost thou think of Henry's riding in the saddle to the distance of 21 miles & returning the next day over one of the highest mountains in N. America.  It was his own determination for I really was afraid to encourage it.  The experiment however succeeded to admiration & we are here again without hurt or damage.  We had a noble prospect from the top of the mountain.  We both kept journals which will serve to give you some account of our proceedings.  Tomorrow morning at 6 o'clock we are to leave this for Hagerstown.  We travel more like express riders than pleasure hunters.  We had intended to have procured a gig in Harrisburg and visited the cove on the [S-----} but this we found impossible.  In these things I am not disappointed.  They are what I expected and are incident to our mode of travelling.
My love the family
I remain thy affectionate brother
  Francis CopeWilliam D. Cope
Care of
Thomas P. Cope Esq.
Walnut St. Wharf 
Philadelphia
Francis Cope- Chambersburg
10 mo. 2. 1813
Chambersburg 2 nd Oct

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Francis Cope:  1794-1816
Recipient:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Date: 1816-07-28
Title: 1816 July 28, Cape May, to Father

Cape May July 28th 1816

My dear father

To prevent any anxiety which you may feel on our account, I embrace the first opportunity which offers since our arrival to inform you of our welfare.  We arrived at Newcastle on 6th day evening about 7, supped there, went on board the packet-boat at 10 & got under way about two in the morning.  During the day the wind was light & generally ahead.  At twelve last night we were within four miles of this, when the appearance of the weather indicating a squall, we were obliged to come to anchor.  We had a pretty severe thunder-storm from the n. [--] but not accompanied with much wind.  It was however, sufficient to alarm our [-------] a good deal & make them all very sick.  William & one other gentleman had a slight attack which sent them on deck; the rest of us experienced no inconvenience.  The storm did not continue much more than an hour, & by five this morning we anchored within half a mile of our landing place.  A boat immediately put out to us & conveyed us safely to shore, under a pretty high swell.  Four miles riding in carriages brought us here an hour before breakfast.
We found the house nearest the water completely occupied.We have taken lodgings in much the best home in the place at the distance of something better than a square from the shore.  I have walked it once & tho' farther than I should like I hope it will answer.  My knees are no worse, but having returning from my first bathing I can say nothing as to the effect of sea-water.
I send this by my friend Wm. W. Austin who sails tomorrow morning with the packet.  We both [-----] our love to all the family.  You will either see us or hear from us again at the end of the week.
From thy affectionate son
Francis Cope.Thomas P. Cope Esq.
Philadelphia
Wm. W. Austin

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Francis Cope:  1794-1816
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1816-08-02
Title: 1816 August 2, Cape May, to brother

Cape May August 2nd 1816

My dear brother

I wrote father on the day of our arrival by Wm. Austin, and mentioned that if we did return I should write again by the end of the week.  Although as respects the article of pleasure I am entirely satisfied, yet I have concluded it would be prudent for me to remain a few days, perhaps a week, longer.    The party I came down with, all return tomorrow; should I return with them, I shall have been here but six days & have bathed but five times.  This can hardly be called giving the water a fair trial.  Thus far I do not know that I have received any benefit; some of our boarders tell me they think I walk better, but I am myself sensible of no change.  We board much farther from the surf than is agreeable to me, but it was impossible to procure quarters in the home nearest the shore.  On the whole I do not much regret it, as our accommodations are much better than can be had in the other houses.
The party we attached ourselves to, engaged a large room with a bed for each and a stipulation that while we occupied it no others should be admitted.  This party consists of Merritt Canby, Jos. Askers, Ellis Yarnall, Robert Barnes, (a brother to the doctor) Richard Nixon a young englishman, and a very clever fellow & our two selves.  When they are gone we shall shift our quarters into a small apartment.  With respect to the employment of our time, it is sufficiently monotonous, and I fear next week will be still duller.  This however applies to myself.  Those who are well find employment enough in gunning, fishing, walking &c.  I was one of a fishing party to-day, which as it will form  one of the most memorable events of my excursion, deserves to be noted.  The packet boat, General Jackson has a day to spare here on each trip, & to-day she engaged to take as many as chose to go, out to the banks to catch sea-bass.  A more delightful day for the excursion could hardly be conceived.  It was neither too hot, too cold, too windy, nor too calm.  We were unfortunate in but one particular, and that a main one.  We found no fish.  I was among the most fortunate and caught three.  One whole stock amounted to about four dozen.  At our greatest distance we were nearly out of sight of land; our fishing place was near twenty miles from shore.  William was afraid to go for fear of sea sickness.  As all the rest of our party went, and I was fearful he would be sick myself, I did not urge him.  I begin to feel quite sailor like, as respects this said sickness.  I never felt better in my life.  A few of the party were very sickand several others complained.  Jos. [---] was the most severely handled of any person on board; he was really ill.  The most unpleasant part of our expedition was landing through the surf on our return.  We landed in a whale-boat, which was brought down pretty low in the water, by the weight of her cargo, consisting of twenty-three persons.  We rose safely over the surf till our prow touched the beach, when it broke over the stern, rocked us very much & shocked several.  Jos. {----] had his hat knocked off & was amazingly frightened.  McAlpin, the [-------], in riding to shore on the shoulders of one of the boatmen, upset, horse & rider.  We were unpolite enough to laugh a good deal, but he bore it with the greatest good nature.
We shall certainly not exceed our two weeks here.  If the water is at all beneficial to me, I shall be sensible of it by that time.
Our best love to father, mother and all the family.
Thine, my dear brother, most affectionately
Francis Cope.Henry Cope
Philadelphia 
C. H. Yarnall.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Katharine Wistar Evans Stokes:  1841-1904
Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Date: 1887-08-17
Title: 1887 August 17, to Brother

8- 17th 1887
 
My dearest brother, 
Would thee be willing to buy us a basket of peaches on 7th day morning and send them down by the 2.10 trian marked Francis Stokes borrowings, via Perryville- Hannah craves some very much and Dr. Sappington says she may eat a little. They are not to be had here for love or money. Thee can pay for them out of the money thee has of mine. 
Poor dear H. does not seem to improve much & her spirits have failed, soshe is quite down-hearted. She comes down-stairs in the evening but has not strength and no appetite- & is right wretched. 
I wish thee could come down on 7th day & spend 1st day with us. We would be delighted to see thee & would not keep thee in her room. The maids are improving, Sarah is a sitting up and I think Mary will be able to do so tomorrow. 
Esther returned this afternoon looking well and rosy. She will be a great help & Edith feels quite made up again. 
I don't see any prospect at all of my going toNewport and if there is any one else to take my place I hope you will invite them. When Hannah does get better I think the sea-air would do her a great deal of good and I hope build her up, and I know in your kindness you will set an open door before her. It is a great disappointment to Franky but perhaps he can go with her. It sounds very presumptous in me to write all this but you are always so kind and cordial it is apt to make us ['"fresh"]. 
It grows late & I must stop, with warmest love thy K.5th day morning - Hannah seems weak this morning. we had rather a disturbed night, for a water-spout and the closet leaked & Frank & Esther  & I were [bobbing] round in a very [-----] manner. It reminded me of a our experiences one night when the was down here- 2 1/2 inches of rain fell in less than 2  hours. 
Frank says that very nice peaches can be got at the corner of Market & [Merrick] right near the depot. I don't know how much they will be but I suppose $1.50 or $2.00

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Francis R. (Francis Reeve) Cope:  1878-1962
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1892-08-19
Title: 1892 August 19, to Mother

Aug. 19th. 1892

Dear Mother.

We are now in Watertown and expect to stay here for dinner, when we will take the train to Clayton, & go from there to Alexandria Bay by boat.  Uncles & myself have just been to look at carriages but we find that they do not make any two-wheeled carts, so uncle Tom & myself think thee had better order the cart from Bradly without delay.  Uncle Tom expects to go home to Philadelphia nextMonday or Tuesday & uncle Edgar & myself will probably remain two or three days later.  It is pretty hot in Watertown, nevertheless uncle T & myself have been going around the town buying fishing tackle.  I must stop now as we are going in to dinner.  Affec.ly. thy son
F.R. Cope Jr.

Francis R. is a good boy but is too fond of pie & cake.  Uncle Thomas sends his love to you.
T. P. Cope.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Francis R. (Francis Reeve) Cope:  1878-1962
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1892-08-21
Title: 1892 August 21, to Mother

Aug. 21st. 92

Dear Mother,

Thy lettters seem to have come to the right place at the right time, as I have received them all I think.  I am very much discusted at the delay about ordering the wagon.  I can not see but what the two-wheeler is not as safe as a four-wheeler.  At any rate the two-wheeled cart is much the lightest and easier to turn if you should happen to get into a tight place; but the main advantage is that they are lighter, & as we have nostrong horse suitable for the girls to drive, I should think that we had better get the two-wheeler.  If you have desided pretty much not to get the cart, I think you might as well get a light buggie something like thine.  Thee will have to deside now or never if we are going to get it this summer.
The hotel where we are staying now is a very fashionable place, & there is not much fishing or anything else to do.  Yesterday we took a lovely steamboat ride along the Canadian shore & among the islands.  It was verypretty indeed as all the islands on the Canada side belong to the government & are very wild for nobody is aloud to build on them.  Now we have seen the islands there is not much to do, so we intend to leave here tomorrow morning & take the boat to Kingston and from there to Cimcoe Island where the fishing is said to be very fine.
I got a very nice letter last Friday evening from Grandma saying that  Grandpa was going on toNewport, as uncle Thomas was coming home from Berkshire.  Uncle Tom thinks of taking the boat from Cimcoe Island to Toronto and then coming home by Niagara.  But he has not desided certainly about it yet, partly owing to the strike at Buffalo.  If he does that I shall return with him as I may not get another chance for some time.  If uncle Edgar likes the fishing at Cimcoe he will probably stay a few days later.  So thee sees there is nothing certainly desided about coming home.  Uncle E thinks he may stop atTunkhannock on his way to Overbrook and try the fishing in the Susequehanna.  I will return any how by the 1st Sept., and will try and let thee know the day before, when we are coming.
Tell Ellie I will try & right to her soon.
Affec'ly thy son
Francis R. Cope Jr.
Uncle Tom thinks we had better get the cart and try it, and that there need be no danger if we drive carefully.
Uncle Tom sends is love to thee.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1852-07-12
Title: 1852 July 12, Woodbourne, to Ruthanna Cope

Woodbourne 7th mo 12th 1852

Dear Annie,

This is the first sheet of that ream of paper, but for fear thee should be appalled with the anticipation of having the whole of it filled up to thy account, I am going to tell thee in the first place that I ai'nt going to be quite so unconscionable tho' I wont promise how I far I shall short of it.  I thought maybe you would like to know something about my gettings along on my journey, so I will begin at Pottstown up to which place you are informed of what transpired.  Well after taking the last look at you, I turned round & felt a little forlorn at finding nothing but my carpetbag to keep me company, so as I had nobody to talk to (I was very glad I had'nt) I thought I would occupy myself with thinking about you & wondering how you were getting along.  Directly after we started we came whizzing past a train of cars, which I supposed were the ones wh. were to convey you back to Philada.  I was very glad to see them because I knew you would be & I was afraid you might have had to wait there a good while, but it was'nt very pleasant to think that we were speeding away from each other as fast as we could go.  I hope you did'nt feel as [worn] & dusty when you got to Phila as I did when I reached Port Clinton I had'nt much time to think about it however for I had to go quite in traveller like style & superintend as well as I could amid the bustle & din the transportation of our baggage from one car to another, that seen to, I joined my companions & weput ourselves on board the cars for Tamaqua, a ride of two hours brought us to that place about 1 o'clock, there we staid about half an hour most of wh. time I spent in trying to restore my face to a decent shade of color, for I found it in the funniest looking condition thee can imagine, the dust, & the tears occasioned by the cinders, (& something else) had covered [skin] spots with a sort of black paste wh. very much resembled mud & wh. I had some difficulty in removing.  I thought it expedient to [see first] watering place to get out & wash so I performed my ablutions quite comfortably under the spout where the horses were drinking, it reminded me of Aunt Fortunes style of face washing.  The ride over the mountains was just about as usual, except that it was a little bit hotter & dustier & disagreeabler than ever.  We had 9 passengers in the stage not counting carpetbags & blanket shawls wh are an important item in hot weather I hope I have left mine for the enjoyment of somebody who will take a cooler time for it.  We lived all the afternoon in the anticipation of a cooler ride after sunset, but it seemed to grow hotter instead of colder, most of the passengers seemed to forget their discomforts in a nap so I was left to my own entertainment & sat very quietly in one corner thinking about different things among others I amused myself with imagining what you were about at, Oakland, & wishing I was there with you instead of where I was, about 11 1/2 P.M. we were wheeled up before the Phoenix Hotel in Wilkesbarre where as soon as possible (tho' not until morning) we made our way to our sleeping apartments mine did not prove to be much of a sleeping apartment however tho' as much as could have been expected of a roomwithout windows & with featherbeds, they were very full at the Hotel & we were obliged to be content with the kind of accomodations we could get.  Thinking to better my condition I got up the next morning at half past three & found it a decided improvement upon lying in bed We left [W] about 7 o'clock & had a pleasant ride thro' the valley of Wyoming, it is by far the pleasantest part of the journey I think, the country is looking beautifully now, only it was too hot to enjoy it.  We reached Tunkhannock about 12 1/2 PM, & now comes the very dismalest part of all, at this place the two lades with whom I had travelled from Phila & whom I knew very well left me unexpectedly, & I was packed without any ceremony into a kind of open arrangement upon wheels (for it hardly deserved the name of a wagon) & after considerable crowding & pushing, & groaning I managed to squeze in between two fat women & an indiscriminate collection of trunks, & handboxes, & men.  Under these auspicious circumstances we started, the sun basking down upon us in one direction, & some ominous looking black clouds in another, so [hot] I scarcely knew whether to wish most for a drenching or a coo[k]ing I an addition to this the driver was entertaining us with all sorts of awful predictions, he said the roads were terrible, that the bridge had been washed away & he expected we would all be drowned in crossing the creek, & as to his horses he was perfectly certain they never could stand it, & so I thought I shd never get home in the world, that something awful certainly could'nt fail to happen among so many dismal predictions, & they were such a queer set of people, & altogether I felt such an utter sense of forlornness that I eddified them by beginning to cry.  I was provoked at myself for being so foolish but I really could'nthelp it, it did'nt last very long however, for directly one man who seemed to quite pity me turned round & said in the most compassionate tone, "you feel kind'er used up do'nt you."  I was so struck with the applicability of the expression (for in truth I did feel a sort of sense of "goneness") that I began to laugh, & seeming quite pleased that his efforts were so successful, the man set himself to work to entertain me during the rest of the way, he said he always kind, o' hated to see people discouraged, that he never got discouraged in his life & he thought it was'nt a good plan, & so he got me into quite a composed state of mind & I was enabled to bear the rest of the journey with a tolerable degree of calmness, it is well disagreeable things come to an end as well as agreeable ones, thee may imagine how delighted it was to be safely landed at home after all this, without being either drowned or drenched, they were quite surprised to see me arriving in such a forlorn condition.  If Father & mother had known they wd have met me at Tunkhannock.  I believe the reason of our having such a miserable affair was that the stage had broken down the day before, & this was all they had to send.  They are all very well here excepting father who is somewhat stiff yet with the effects of the rheumatism, the children have grown very much.  And now that I have almost filled my letter with an acct of my own doings, let me ask thee about yours.  I want to know how you are getting along, it seems ages since I have heard anything about you.  I do hope thee'll write very soon & tell me about everything.  I feel somehow as if I was farther away than I ever was before, do come up this summer if you possibly can, any of you, we shd be so delighted Mother requested me to give her love & tell you so.  I suppose whether you remember'd our agreement for last night.  I did & thought about it too.  I suppose Julia is in Reading.  Please give a great deal of love to Uncle Henry & Aunt Rachel, Cos Frank & Cos Anna, Cos Thos & Cos Elizabeth & all the rest of the cousins, to Grfather of course & every body else to whom thee sees fit.  Of course thee will write to me [very] soon.  I am at the end of my paper & must conclude, thy affectionate Cos Clementine CopePS. I gave such a dismal acct of our proceedings up here that I am afraid it will not be any encouragement to come, but let me tell thee that things ai'nt always at such a forlorn pass, it only happened to be so at that particular time.
The children send their love & desire me to thank Cos Frank for the books with wh. they were very much pleased.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Taber:  1822-1887
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1841-02-28
Title: 1841 February 28, New Bedford, to Frank, Philada.

New Bedford 2 mo 28 1841

Dear Frank

Among the   many sins of omission & commission with which my Conscience   has been burdened of late – none has laid harder on my   stomach to speak in a physiological metap[h]or than my not   having answered [thine] epistle of – mo. – 1840.  This sheet   then intended as a peace offering and mediator for past   offences “by-gones” comes to thee by the hands of Geo. H.   Dunbar – (a young man of our religious denomination-   somewhat diligent attender of meeting – (where He in company   with the majority of our young men occupies the seat   fronting the women friends – pardon the digression but the   fact is worth recording that as the Mahometan prays with his   face towards Mecca – thou canst draw the parallel) not so   much distinguished as would be best for plainness of speech.   [behavi] and apparel – and inheriting with the rest of us   some failings I fear from Father Adam - ) who is to pass   thro Philada. on his way to Haverford and then to France in   a New Lock Haven packet next week. – A poet moreover and   somewhat unique personage. & can either roar like a lion or   a sucking dove at his pleasure – rhyme to the moon or swear   like a pirate. – I don’t know how long he stays in Philada.   but if you fall in with him you’ll know him.

The   greatest attraction in these parts this winter - & which   must take its share of the blame of having kept me from   attending to my Philada correspondence is a new periodical   entitled “L’Entreprise” which has originated among us and   has claimed a goodly portion of my leisure
The great   charm about you must know is that we have Lady contributors   – Gertrude Hussey “Murray” quondam –
with sundry & divers others – too tedious to mention as the   advertisements would say – with a respectable lot of   Quak[er] lady make considerable of a coterie. – 
Dr Hardy   undertook to join but whether he did not succeed [to] his   mind or whether his practice is too extensive & laborious to   admit of his wasting his time so idly I know not – but he   has not yet contributed – This much however must be said of   him whether through his intrinsic merits or accidental   circumstances he has in fact succeeded in getting into an   extraordinary practice and seems likely to settle down here   and live easy. – Ah!  Francis if I were only as goodlooking   a young man as thou art I should then think that Destiny had   cut me (too) out for a Doctor
Ben Hardy’s whiskers were   always irresistible – but a new bobwig which I find I had   the honor of bringing home from Philada. in one of those   boxes you remember – that new bobwig with the [portage] of   which I was so unconsciously honored – that new bobwig is   worth a thousand dollars a year to him – 

The old   gentleman that was at our house a little while since from   Salem – gave us a few particulars in Ben’s history that will   be useful to any one who shall hearafter have the honor of   compiling his biography – It seems that such was his   enterprise and such too his earnest zeal in the laudable   task of pleasing the women even in early life that after   having studied the art of Crispin in his nativevillage of Kennebunk he was at the pains of a journey and   long residence at Lyme to be initiated into the art &   mystery of making woman’s shoes

How instructive the   lesson that such heroism and model-gallantry teaches –   Frank! that mans life is a lesson to all posterity – Raised   very probably on a [shingle] in that bleak [-egion]   described so emphatically by the poet – 
“Away down East   dere
[Clow] [by] de moon”
then as he grew up from   [clouts] to petticoats from petticoats to breeches to trace   the ardent aspirations of a full soul. – panting after   greatness and distinction. – from the time he first drove a   peg to the time when he last [drove] a peg – still his   potentialities are visible [from] germ to perfection and   full maturity of cobblerhood. – Ah!  if I were only   good=looking enough!
One sin of commission too I must   confess & be shrived of – As I was turning over some old   papers of mine the other day – I accidentally opened an old   letter of thine containing “a Serenade” [which] being   forthwith tempted by the Devil I inserted in a forthcoming   no. of my periodical – Now I am of opinion that the   temptation proceeds from that source because unintentionally   I find I have eclipsed myself altogether I having “done the   poetry” in that [line] till now finding that I shall not be   able to write anything as good myself why “Othello’s   occupation gone”. – 
and I shall be obliged to cultivate a little taste & genius   which I flatter myself I possess [as] “dea[t]h is [shocking]   accident – and suicide Songster.” – By the way I have begun   a pastoral

“Jocund lambkins softly warble” which when   finished shall be forwarded for your criticism and another –   
[Thus] fair brow thoughts richest mine
When thy   bright as diamonds shine
Rivalled only by the glow
of   the bright orbs below – there’s a [touch] for you –   

Remember you dont pay any postage for this letter   
So it is no matter if it is not worth anything
very   sincerely yours
Charles Taber


Francis R. Cope
care of Henry & Alfred Cope<Br>Walnut St.   
Philada.

Title: 1870 August 16, Awbury, to My dear Frank

Awbury 8 mo. 16th 1870      

      My dear Frank,      

      I rec'd thine & Chellie’s letters to day, when Tho's came out from town.  They also had one from Mary, and we are glad to hear of your safe arrival at Snow Shoe and very thankful I am, that you had a doctor so near at hand to extract the bone from thy throat.  I read thy letter first, and was much alarmed. before knowing what the accident thee alluded to was, but Thomas fortunately knew about it from Mary's letter & told me at once.  What a providential thing it was, that there was a Dr. so near at hand.  the children must have been very much frightened, before thee was relieved.--I hope thee will be careful of thyself, and not jump, and injure thy arch again.—
      -
      attached wife Anna S. Cope.  I hope Tom is provided with warm under-clothing.  Mary sends her love & hopes you will have a good time.I hope thee has enough warm clothing, with thee, for I sh'd not be surprised of thr warmest weather is past.  We are having it delightful here at home, the thermometer 68 this morning at 8 o'clock and under 80 at noon.  This afternoon Thomas & Elizabeth Mary & I called at father's, and afterwards at Ellis Yarnall's leaving Mary at father's.  We found them all at home, and had a very pleasant visit.  Lucy Harrison is very bright & agreeable & Anne is lovely.  She told me she had written a note to Lillie, which I would send to her when it comes to hand.  She also told me she was sorry not to go to Snow Shoe with you, but they could not go to Chicago, & as their time is so limited they of course felt anxious to see as much as possible before going home.  they expect to go to Detroit from Chicagoand then on to Niagara.  They expect to leave sometime next week, and take the journey alone.  We all disapprove of them taking such a long journey by themselves, but I suppose Ellis Yarnall will find out some one to look after them.  When they go on, they expect to spend the first night at Altoona, and then travel day & night until they reach Chicago.  I have sent Lillie & Chellie some under-clothing.  2 flannel skirts, 2 under vests, 1 cloth body, 2 pairs thick stockings, 1 pair drawers, 1 [Alpaca?] skirt.  Anna & Carrie are quite well, & the former is invitee to spend tomorrow with cousin Mary [W.?] Brown's little Mary.  I did not [?] like [?]-ing her just now, but could not well decline.  I was at father's this afternoon, and they were all pretty well.  father seems stronger from the change in weather.  I saw bro. John and his boys go off this morning, and hope they had apleasant trip to Altoona.  I am glad you met with such a polite reception at Bellefonte.  I had no idea before, that there was any such spring of water, there as mentions.  63000 gallons a minute is immense.  I think you must have enjoyed the ride up the mountain very much, if the views are so beautiful.  Give my love to Lillie & Chellie, and tell them I hope they will not be put out at my sending them some warm clothing, as I am only sorry they did not send for warm dresses too, as they have nothing warm with them.  It is now bed-time and I must put by my writing; the children are enjoying Anna Hartshorne's company very much.  I hope some of you will write tho' I do not want you to tax yourselves.  I have already been much favored.  Bro Thomas intended sending sister Anne's letter, but it was not returned from Aunt Ruth's in time.  with much love to you all, ever thy
