Recipient:  Mary Elizabeth Brown Hartshorne:  b. 1823
Date: 1847-08-11
Title: 1847, August 10, to My dear Mary

Newport 8 mo 10th / 47
      
      My dear Mary
      
      Frank has been writing to William this morning, and has most likely advised you on all points of interest.- you probably know by this time, that we are all in a good state of health, and we hope that our sister Susan is improving, tho' she still has some head-ache.  Frank & cousin Wistar are very kind and devote themselves almost exclusively to contributing to her comfort & pleasure in every way.  F is devoted to Susan and does evey thing in his power to promote the improvement of her health, his kindness is unparalleled: everything is done for us, and we have nothing to do, but join in the pleasant plans laid out for us.- Elizy H & Susan were concluding before dinner, that they accomplished very little of any thing on account of the time occupied in changing their dresses for the different labors of the day.- About ten in the morning they prepare for bathing or rather we do when Susan does not go-
      /
      not arrive on 7th day tho' we intend to do so if possible.  the Boat did not leave until 5 o'clock this morning.  I expect the irregular lately.- with much love
      aff thy sister Anne
      Susan will accompany us to Hazard's this afternoon
      she is resting since her bath.then return about 12 o'clock.  rest, until time to away for dinner, then about 5 o'clock, a different costume must necessarily be adapted for Sailing especially when the boats, are slightly fishy & a little dirty.- then we come home about ten-time or little past, and another change must be made to appear at [---] which [---] will suffice for the evening.- but all this is done in a good hurry and I cannot say it consumes much time.- I believe I have nothing new to tell thee, and indeed, I expect it would be very puzzling to think of any such thing when Cousin Wistar is of the party, for he writes home to frequently, and describes every thing that seems with so much minuteness, that if you are favored with the perusal of his epistles, ours must seem quite commonplace; this is my conjecture, as we joke Wistar & Sue both, about writing so often.- Only to think- Sixth day evening we leave, if a storm or fog does not prevent us, and Tom has concluded to remain, and return with us last evening tho' fog was so dense that the Bay-State" did not go out, and now we have every prospect, of the same thick state of the atmosphere for this evening consequently.  it seemed hardly worth while for Tom to leave before we did.- The Massachusetts arrived here with Mr. Williams on board, about 11 o'clock thismorning having been lying off Point Judith, even since four o'clock.  Susan & Lizzie went to bathe this morning with F & Wistar leaving me at home to pass the time as I could.  Tom & Moses had gone fishing, and I was quiet enough.  Susan though it best notwithstanding your message, to try the [---] three times faithfully as the Dr directed, and I hope she will not be any worse for it, and perhaps it may strengthen her afterwards.  She says she likes it very much while in the water, but she feels pretty weak for sometime afterwards.  we think she is the best judge for what is best for her, and she does exactly what she wished in the Bathing line; Frank takes her in, giving her three waves as directed, he said the water was very warm & pleasant this morning.  I quite long to go in again but fear I shall not have an opportunity of going more than once or twice more before I leave.- It suits Elizy Hacker exactly, she feels a little tired after coming out, but it seems to brance & strenghthen her, and shee looks better I think in this little time of our [---] here.  I do hope her father will telegraph her to remain with Sue, if the letter does not arrive in time to answer it before our leave.- yester afternoon we were out Sailing in the bay, landed on one of the [dumpling?] rocks gathered some sprigs of green to press, and enjoyedthe novelty of it highly, it was really very pleasant, altho' by the time we returned, our blanket shawls were almost white with the fog.  Sailing seems to suit Susan, very well, but I think clear weather as a general thing is preferable to her.- This afternoon we think of calling at fr'd Hazard’s, we spent a pleasant evening there last Sixth day.  they are certainly a delightful family. Ann[a/e?] Hazard called here this morning with S & A Jenkins who are still staying with them – we intend riding out to see fr'd Jenkins before we go.- 4th day morn.  I was obliged to leave this shut hastily yesterday afternoon, as Thomas Hazard & his wife called upon us inviting us to spend this afternoon with them which we intend doing.  Elizy & Frank are much disappointed I believe in Fanny H’s beauty, but they must see her at [---] before they fully decide.  She is perfect at home.- my love to all- Susan and Lizzie are taking a nap before dinner, and I cannot disturb them now.- there is a thick fog over they bay now 12 at noon, and it will [---] increase- Tom could not have gone last night in consequence of the bay as the boat did not leave, and perhaps it is as well for him to wait for us.  Frank & myself do not think it proper to leave here in a fog or storm and Tom must not think it strange if we do

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1858-08-12
Title: 1858 August 12, Awbury, to My dear sister

Awbury 8 mo 12th / 58
   
   My dear sister
   
   When I last wrote, it seemed so doubtful whether thee would be at uncle William's or on the way home with Edward Biddle, that I concluded to direct the letter to Clemmy in case thee had left there.- Brother Thomas returned home very unexpectedly on second day evening, the very time we were looking for thee, he was much overcome by the voyage, and the anxiety of getting off in a steamer, but I hope is better now,and likely to improve; his strength has been much prostrated, and he has had some fever but the Doctor considers him better this evening, and he does really seem better, tho’ he is still quite weak.  They had a very cold voyage, and he could not keep warm enough & consequently took a severe cold, but thee must not be anxious or uneasy about him, as Dr Rhoads thinks him much better; &he is entirely free of fever this evening.  Alfred is also much better to day for the first time, but he has changed so frequently from better to worse in the course of twenty four hours, that we hardly know how to calculate about him.  But I think the Doctor is more encouraged about him this evening, and I have great hopes that he will soon be on the well list, as he has one tooth through, and he has not coughed quite so hard to day; the rest of the family are all pretty well, father, and mother desire their love to thee, and say thee had better take the first good opportunity to return home, and not to think of coming home alone, without hearing further from us; and Francis also adds that in case Alfred continues better, perhaps he can come up for the next week.-
   With regard to thy medicine, and salve, we will endeavor to send it to thee in some way, as well as the material for aunt Susan’s duster.- Bro' Thomas has bough various little articles for the children, with which they are much pleased; he bought Lilly & Chelly eacha suit of doll’s clothes made in Paris, according to the present style, hats shoes, and even night-gown and cap.  velvet [---] watch & chain, little [---] all furnished in the most minute style, [---], &c little beauties,- the children are so overjoyed, that they show them to everyone that comes, and do not get tired of examining them, at all times in the day, and I do not wonder for they are so elegantly made that you cannot help admiring them.  Sister Elizy and Julia sed their love to Clemmy and thyself, in which I wish to join, also love to Aunt Susan, Annette & Carry- I am sorry I have no news to tell thee, such as thee would like to hear, but as I have not been any where for the last three or four weeks thee must not wonder at it.-
   with much love affectionately
   sister Anna S. Cope
   PS.
   I am obliged to close this in haste, as it is late, and the family have mostly retired
   mother is about as well as usual now.-Tom continues to get better- whether I get up for thee or not will depend on how Alfred is.  He is a good deal better this morning.  I have Aunt Susans cloth which if I do not bring up I will send by envelope.  There seems to be no use of sending thy medicine as thee will hardly have a chance to use it, but I will bring it with me if I come. Dr Evans is not in town now
   afftly thy bro
   F.R.C.Awbury 8 mo 12th / 58

Title: 1875 July 4, Lake Windermere, to Tom & Scrubby

Lockwood Hotel   Lake Windermere
   July 4. 1875
   
   Dear Tom & Scrubby.
   
   I did write a few lones to thee Scrubby from Kendal but I rec'd such a nice letter from thee last Fifth day that I concluded to send thee a longer one; & as I have already rec'd two letters from Tom I thought it would be well to kill two birds with one stone-so here goes-We saw the first of this lake last Fourth day afternoonand will continue to see it till sometime tomorrow.  I haven't the slightest idea where the picture, at the head of this sheet, is taken from;- but I know one thing & that is that I have not as yet seen anything like it nor do I think that there is such a view.  At any rate it gives you no idea of the place.  Now for the narrative- We took a row on the lake soon after arriving here & on Fifth day took the steamer down to [Bowness?] where we expected to get on a carriage & drive over to Coniston.  When we arrived there, however, the sky looked so threatening & Alexis not feeling very well we concluded to leave it till next day, & returned to Louwood.  Arriving in a heavy shower we were at a loss to know what to do, till I decided to go over to Keswick & get our letters that were probably awaiting our arrival there.  So as the stage did not go till 3 o'clock I drove over to Ambleside, bought a full rubbersuit (coat leggings & cap) hired a horse & started off, about 1 o'clock.  You can imagine me clothed in these things sitting on an awfully rough trotter nothing of my usual self being visible except my eyes, nose & mouth, and my shoes.  The suit answered admirably, keeping me perfectly dry in the hardest thunder-storm I was ever out in- Except my shoes wh. in a few minutes were rather soggy.  However it was soon over & I arrived at [Derwentwater?] Hotel, [Portinscale?] at 4 P.M. having ridden on horseback 19 miles.  Here I obtained, first a lunch then the letters, one from each of you.  While waiting here another gust came up & when it had gone over the sky looked brighter & more settled.  So having engaged rooms for 2nd day, at 6 P.M. I set off & had a most beautiful ride past [Thirlmue?] & Helvellyn, Grasmere & Rydal Water back to Ambleside wh. I reached at half past eight.  Drove downto our hotel, took some red-hot tea & then went out to hunt for Lilly & Alexis, whom I found spooning in a bench & who told me that there were three other pairs in the hotel worse off than we were.  Sixth-day we set off for Coniston Water, driving alongside of Windermere & crossing below Bowness, through Hawkshead where Wordsworth went to school & finally reached Coniston where Lillie & I made the tour of the lake in the steam Gondolee as they call it while Alexis ascended the "Old Man."  We had the best of it for, although he immortalized himself by leaving his name & address in full on top of pole of stones which has been placed there, yet he was caught in such a dense fogthat he couldn't see anything & in turn caught a species of chill & fever, from which he is slowly recovering.  Yetserday we went through Grasmere & Rydal & got Lillie pretty well played out.  We rowed down Grasmere Lake & walked to Rydal Mount, (wh we did not see, exceptone window & the chimney's) Lillie & Alexis "preferring rather" to keep on a level while I crossed over the hill from wh. I got an elegant view of Windermere, Rydal Water, Grasmere & [Tharlmere?] besides some small 'towns' and the mountains on all sides.  On coming down I overtook Lou & Alexis spooning by the roadside, On my coming up they had began to talkpleasantly about the weather, Lillie suggesting that it was much cooler than the 3rd of July 2 years ago, at wh. both looked remarkably pleased & mysterious.  I looked very innocent but on making "comparative mathematical calculations" have concluded that it must have been that day they drove over from Connymeade together & took two hours & a half (2 ½ hrs) by the watch to get up to the house from the stable-   

   It’s fearfully hard to get Lillie up in the mornings.  She grumbles incessently because Alexis & myself will order breakfast at half past eight & uses as anargument to the statement, (I wont say in fact) that Father when he was over here did not breakfast till nine.  Another instance, Tom of the force of example.  However we dont give in & in revenge she gener-ally keeps us waiting 15 or 20 minutes.  Alexis thinks it is a good thing that we travel from place to place, as they must think wherever we go that it is a mere accident that we are late.  This miserable climate dont seem to suit me very well.  In the first place the voyage knocked me, clean; for I caught cold some how wh. increased my sore-throat & I haven’t got rid of it yet.  It steadily increased till I got to Warwick wh place seemed to agree with it; for it has been improving since.  Then I had a boil on my skin which troubled me not a little when I ran against anything or Alexis hit me with his umbrella.  I have got it down to a pretty fine point now however & one is coming on my backjust between my shoulders so as to afford me an opportunity of displaying my skill in twisting my arms around.  Beer dont seem to be the thing for me at present, & I have hardly tasted it since leaving Liverpool.  As to the roast-beef, it tastes very much like the same article at home, and they put so much mint with the peas to make them green I suppose that you cant taste any thing else.  But the great charm is that every thing is so nice & clean- no greasy knives &c  You must excuse this writing; but Lillie brought us out here on a most uncomfortable hill-side & insists on sticking it out.  We saw some very pretty little ponies when we were in Wales Srubby; but as we are carrying very small valises & they are pretty full we thought best to defer our purchasefor a season.  I commenced writing on this sheet as you may see but Lou thought it was so important to write on pictured paper that I gave in- Consequently the above marks- I hope that Hazen may succeed in getting up his party & also that he will not ruin the horses driving too much in the park.  I have just thought of a little map wh. I have in my packet wh. I shall enclose in this letter with 5th and 6th sdays excursions marked on them.  Although it may not interest either of you I think mother will like to see it.  I will now cook as it is time for me to be poking Lillie up to go down to dinner,   

   affectly your bro
   Alfred Cope Jr.[Derwentwater] Hotel.
   Portsinscale- Keswick
   7.7.75.
   
   P.S.
   
   2 1/2 P.M.
   
   Have just arrived here & rec'd a letter from T.P.C. Jr. giving a fair "a/c" of the baby, water-works & crops.  Also a bill from Holliday & Storrs I [---] amounting to the enormous sum of [Pound] 5.16.6.  I have come to the conclusion that he is not the man for me.  Lou gaps as much as ever.  This morning just as we were finishing breakfast she commenced raising her elbows to the same level as her shoulders (You probably remember that little habit) but I saw it in time & proposed to up to our rooms to stretch.  Please remember me to the baby- and Chellie.  Also to any other member of the family wh. happens to be at home.  I dont wonder John dont know know where you all are-   

   A.C.Jr.[Alfred's letters from Europe 1875-76   

letter

   Thos. P. Cope Jr.
   Cope Brothers
   Philadelphia
   U.S.A.  

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas) Cope:  1850-1883
Date: 1880-02-08
Title: 1880 February 8, Cannes, to Alexis

Cannes Feb. 8. 1880.
   
   Dear Alexis,
   
   We recd thy letter of Jan. 16th a few days since, & have been thinking over thy proposition.  It wd. be nice to be able to spend part of our summers in Susquehanna Co particularly if you make it your home, but we have not been looking forwarrd to keeping house in our return.  I do not want to live at Connymead again, (indeed I do not think any of us want to; unless we cd. find some one to live with us)  It was too lonely, particularly for me.  & if we did not keep house there in winter, we cd. not keep very well keep house in summer.  How or where we shall live when we go home, I do not know.  Indeed the uncertainties of the future, & what it will be best to do, often weighs upon my mind.  Connymead is no placefor any body to live who wants to be a Friend, or who has any preference for their ways.  Life there was a continual struggle wh. I have no desire to renew, & perhaps we shall never know again [ever/even?] that semblance of a home.  I hope if thee and Lily picked to bring your children up as Friends, you may be able to keep them in a community where Friends live.  For it is pretty hard for a young person who has been uninstructed in what are considered the accomplishments of life to have to live where these are considered all important, & are the chief recupations of those by whom you are surrounded.  It requires a good deal of strength of character to be able to live alone, I [---], & Friends must always do it more or less when they go out from among their own people.  When one has not been brought to play on the piano or sing or draw, or paint, or evento play cards- a not very valuable accomplishment certainly- & yet one in wh. English people who are both intelligent & sensible, seem to while away at least a fourth part of their waking hours; & never to tire of- When I say, one has never been instructed in any of these things, one feels as if one ought to be at least where they are not the chief employment of life.  Of course when living in a delightful pension on the Riviera- one is not supposed to be exactly fulfilling the normal conditions of existence- Existence here (the physical part of it) seems too delightful to be long continued, & I have wonder since we have been here how long 14 human beings could live together, without apparently a shadow of sorrow or anxiety to disturb the delightful days, which seem, to glide away without a cloud either inward or outward, to mar their peacefulness such skies, & such weather , & such walks as we have- only one littleshower in all the two months we have been here- It is the most perfect thing in weather certainly, that we have ever experienced.  If we had come last winter we shd  not have had the same experience of it, for it rained very much even here.  But I have digressed widely from the subject upon wh. I intended to write, [---] the old house of Woodbourne.  Whatever may be my inclincation with regard to it, (& I certainly shd. like very much the idea of being able to live somewhere near you).  I do not thonk C & A have any desire to undertake housekeeping there.  The life of a travelling artist- or even of the traveller, minus the artist- in these delightful regions & pensions where have all the comforts of home without its cares, does not intend to inspire you with a desire to renew the contest with the [biddy?]- in art less America. If only some plan cd. be devised by wh. Woodbourne cd. be converted into a pension.  I have no doubt we shd. spend a good deal of our time there, & shd. think the old house wd. need an immense amount of repairing, & as to the old chairs of the Conklin family, I feel as if I had lost my interest in them & I shd. not think they wd. be worth the sum they mentioned.  It is provoking to have to buy what is your own.  (see 4th page of A's letter)Can thee tell us who paid the drivers on our Naples [---] wh. were packed in the same box with P.C.G.'s- we asked thee to do it & I suppose thee must have- but we have never heard.If not paid
   
   Please pay to the order of Francis C. Haines (who may be too modest to speak of it) 9 francs 15 centimes, as near as you can come at it.
   
   Clementine CopeAlexis T Cope
   
   (Haines St Germantown)
   
   Philadelphia
   Etats-Unis d'Ameriq

Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1880-03-21
Title: 1880 March 21, Hotel de la Paix, Rome, to Lily

March. 21. 1880.
   
   My dear Lily, Behold us in Rome once more!- dear delightful bewitching Rome- The city of cities- I cannot tell with what delight I find myself again threading its labyrinths & wandering amidst its ruins.  We reached here the 6th of March, having left Mentone 2 days before, passing one night in Genoa & thence by the midnight train to Rome.  This being the only train (owing to their very insane & uncomfortable arrangements) wh. gets you here at a respectable hour.  It was a very uncomfortable journey- but then we were coming to- Rome!!  We made a sojourn of two weeks only, at Dr. Müllers- Mentone we thought lovely- Dr M’s house not altogether so.  It is not happily [---] being at the end of one of thos dried up rivers, down wh. torrents of cold airrushed from the mountains.  We thought it much colder & damper than either Cannes or Nice.  & then there was a slight suggestion of boarding school about the household arrangements- & most for much open warfare between the Dr & his spouse to be altogether agreeable.  It is a great pity they have not learned to control their tempers a little in the presence of their guests at least- for at times it was rather to peppery to be pleasant.  Fortunately the storms seemed to be not very lasting.  & they were generally jolly enough- & in fact much more jolly then most people would be who were at their wits ends to make two ends meet.  A lady who was staying there with her family (pretty much as a matter of charity I fancy) told me they were over head & ears in debt & that she had come to the conclusion there was no use in trying to help them, as they never cd. keep any money- altho' they ask a very high price for their accomodations.  The excursions at Mentone were truly lovely, & the Dr. was alwaysready to take us.  In fact we thought he quite preferred the ladies to the boys for he seemed quite put out once or twice at our declining to go.  but they were too hard for me, & I did none of the very long ones.  I shd. think however for those who were up to that sort of thing, Mentone would be one of the most delightful of the Riviera towns, tho' each one of them seems to have its own peculiar charms.  The weather was very warm when we got to Rome, & took the back bone out of me terribly- It however soon changed from mild, to cool, clear & bracing & the last 10 days have been delicious- I never was able to do so much walking in Rome before, & on spring afternoons such as these what luxury cd. be greater than to drive or to wander at will among the ruins all golden in the light of the declining sun- or to watch the funny old models in their gay rags & tatters- (wh. seem to [---] the spirit of the twins-) hanging themselves out on the Spanish Steps to be admiredwith all the rest.  Surely there is no place on earth like Rome.  Last first day was the kings birthday & there was a grand review- & the king & queen & the [---] kindly [---] themselves , to our admiring gaze in the Borghese. It was quite too gay & disappointing to be proper for 1st day.  The usual ceremonies of holy week begin to day, wh. is Palm Sunday.  We did not attend at S. Peters, thinking last year it was rather a sell.  I went to the little Italian [Waldensian] Church, a great contrast indeed to the pomp & [---] of the great Cathedral.  We had got back to our old Hotel della Pace, where we were twice last winter.  We went first to another but did not like it, & so came here, where we found some friends of last summer (the Müllers).  It is a good central situation.  We look down upon the Piazza Barberinni & the old Tritan who is always blowing his stream of water into the air, & then catching it again all over his head & back wh. must be pretty well washed in all the years that it has been trickling over him.  Then on the other side of the street2
   
   is the Barberrini Pal.  & sad eyed Beatrice.  By way of variety the other day we went to one of Miss Brewsters receptions.  It was a kind of afternoon tea fight, of [---] & other distinguished persons like ourselves.  Tea, wine, & talk & many beautiful things to look at.   

   Next, we want to go with her.  Forbes the archaeologist to hear tge Forum explained on the latest authorities.  His explanations one said to be intensely interesting.  In fact Rome is so dissipating- there is such an infinity to see & to read & to learn that it is most distracting.  I hope we shall be here three or four weeks longer at least.  In fact it spoils you so for every thing else that it does’nt seem worth while to go any where afterwards.
   
   I ought to have told thee before, how glad I was to get thine & Agnes' letter at Mentone.  I was greatly struck with the advance of the latter's ideas since her first epistle wh. I have carried ever since, in the pocket of my satchel& wh. was composed mostly of kisses.  I see she is now advancing to the doll & the baby house interests of the little girl-hood.  The way the ideas were put together was very amusing- & the circumstantial acct. of the flight of the nurses & the changing reigns of the lady’s of the nursery very graphic.  Give her a kiss, & tell her Auntie has very much obliged for her letter & thought it very interesting.  Also that she must’not cut any more holes in her apron with her little scissors, but must make some nice little paper dresses for the paper dollys that Aunty sent in the letter.   

   22nd.  Just returned from our excursion to the Forum with Mr Forbes- two hours rummage amoung the ruins- intensely interesting- back nearly broken- head ditto.  General conglomeration of podiums, Tabulariums, demolished temples & roman emperors- but quite worth the 4 francs wh. is the price per head at wh. Mr F. deals out his information.  He has been on the spot for some years & actually seen & superintended the excavations- so of course knows a great deal about it, & sees it in a very interesting way- much more so than [Hare?], who is a dreadfully guide booky old fellow I think- Am too tired to write more   

   Please tell Alexis that the letters of credit came a few days since, & we are much obliged for his attention to them.  Love to all.  Tell Cousin Anna I am going yo ans. her letter as soon as I can find time.  Thy affectionate Sister   

   C.C.

Title: 1880 June 14, Geneva, to Lily

Geneve No 5 Chemin de la Tour. 6.14.1880
   
   My dear Lily,
   
   I expect Caroline will give me "Jesse" as the saying is, if I presume to enter on the stage with her.  Nevertheless as she has occupied the floor for some weeks past in thy favor, I think I shall dare to add a note, tho' she tells me it must be short & upon no account much upon Revenna.  Wherefore conclude she has been expending herself on that ancient & delightful city- & forbear.  Thy letter of-- containing the childrens photographs came tohand two days since, & gave much pleasure.  We think thine, with little Eleanor, is the best of thee we have ever seen, & as to the little E I shd. say she was her Mama in miniature just as little F is his Papa over again only with a few shades more of jollity in his face.  What a sweet little good natur’d  happy kissable face it is & tho' I believe we have understood that he was'nt particularly fond of the latter operation, I doubtnot he has to undergo a good deal of it, & he does'nt look as if he wd. be very refractory under any circumstances, Indeed such a nice little jolly face must be a great comfort to look at, &, I need not suggest for Mamas to be proud of.  I suppose when we get home thee & Alexis will be a grand old couple, sitting up in the middle of your flock, looking very wise & experienced, as you contemplate with "majestic pride" the youthful scions growing & flourishing about you.
   
   I don’t see that thee has a very care worn air however in thy photo-graph.  but on the contrary one might suppose that they cares & worries of domestic life were quite [---] & pleasant.  by what you say I shd. think the heat must have been of that nature wh. wd. have a tendancy to drive you to seek for a cooler clime.  For my part I dont see the use of undertaking to live in such a climate at all, as the chief object of life seems to be with most people to get away from it.  Why not try to live, as I said to the Awbury people yesterday, where such fearful agonies wd. not have contin-ually to be gone thro' with in order to try to effect an escape.
   
   I am very sorry for Madjy's disappointment as her letter to us showed that he hopes were very much set on Europe, & she seems to need some change so much.  It is a great pity they have to undergo such alternations of hope & despair, because they have got [---] on the living side of the Atlantic.  At least it seems to be the side wh. is very much below par with most persons who inhabit it judging from the frantic manner in wh.they rush for the other shore.  The papers say that pretty much Ole America is now on the way to [---].  We concluded that the pleasure to be derived from seeing the play, wh. I think wd. be but doubtful at best, wd. be very much spoiled by the crowd of cooks & other tourists who will infest the country. We therefore have chosen to spend some time insteadin Geneva in French family No 2.  Not that we were disappointed with our experiences in No 1, but that we fell very much in love with this family last fall, when we took some lessons of them.  They are more cultivated people than the others- consequently moreinteresting, & tho' less well off- they are still friench, wh. means that they are practical & know how to be comfortable on a little.  We only pay about half as much as we do at the large Hotels, with more real comfort, beside the very good advantage of hearing the best of french spoken.  The lady has two sons, one a professor in the University & one a clergyman, & two dhrs. all highly educated.  The advantages of the education here for those in moderate circumastances are so very great.  We shall stay probably a month or more until the weather gets to hot wh. does'nt seem very likely- as we are on pretty high ground just outside the city with plenty of green trees & alps in profusion in the distance.
     
   My advice to you is to come & build a cottage on one of the hill sides of Geneva, instead of Woodbourne & get a Savoyard maid as we have, who with her mistresses aid does the work for a household of 9 persons.  We have two dinners daily, of several courses & very well cooked, & how in the world they do it all I cannot conceive.  I suspect that Madam is at the bottom of a good deal, but she does it all with such apparent grace & ease, that one cannot suspect her of cooking.  There are beautiful building lots to be bought here, by the way, on the high ground along the town with the Lake on one side & Mt. Blanc on the other, & there are many beautiful gardens & suburban residences- wh. are quite unseen & [---] by the mere passing traveller.  If it was’nt for those children of yours whom we want to see!- I shd. be quite tempted to invest in one of these little spots & settle down for the rest of my days.  Will thee please ask Alexis to inquire of cousin FRC if he rec'd a letter fm. me posted June 8. containing a cheque for $200.  I also posted one on the 13 June to M.S.C. containing cheque for $100.  As there is some risk of these things being lost shd. be very much obliged if A or some body wd. advertise Provident Life & Trust Company of [---] and [---]. of these two cheques payable to the order of the above mention’d persons.  Hoping soon to have news of you in a cooler clime & under Mrs. Hotchkiss' hospitable roof.  Ever thy affec- sister C.  Ever so many kisses to dear little Agnes & to theothers as for as appreciated by them.

Title: 1880 July 11, Geneva, to Alexis

Geneva, July 11, 1880
   
   Dear Alexis,
   
   I want to ask thee a question.  Is it necessary in order to effect a division of our property (I mean such a division as shall give thee thy portion at Connymead) is it necessary that I return to America in the Autumn with C & A, as it has been our intention to do, (or at least theirs)?  For myself I have not entirely decided, tho' we have partly paid our passages for the 6th Nov. in the steamer "Illinois", on condition that we can change if it seems best to another vessel of the line.  It is late to sail, but there seemed to be no good steamer between the first week of October& the last, & as there will be no moonlight the last of October we thought it wd. be best to wait until the next moon.   

   There are many reasons why I shd. like to return in the Autumn, but the prospect of boarding in Phila is not very attractive, & of keeping house at Connymead still less so- indeed I shd. never be willing to undertake the latter again unless circumstances were very much changed.  C & A prefer the former.  If they were willing to keep house or even to board near Germantown, where we could have the enjoyment of the children, I shd. come home with the greatest pleasure.   

   But this I expect they will never wish to do.  So that until I can think of some way for me to live in that part of the world.  It seems as if I might almost as well stay here- for boardingin Phila wd. not be much better as far as you are concerned.   

   The thought of staying by myself seems a little dismal, but I cd. stay very well in the family where we now are & be as well cared for as I cd. expect or wish to by, by strangers.  Then there is an elderly lady (whom we have met several times (& I think have spoken of) Miss Wetherill, Jno. Price Wetherills dhr, of Phila) who has asked me to join her party, consisting of her niece & [Pebers?] of Phila.  We were with them 8 weeks in Rome & found them very pleasant.  So I could stay very well if I wanted to- Tell me how the idea strikes you, with regard to the business- as, if my presence is necessary to the accomplishment of it, that wd. decide the question.   

   We still continue in Geneva & still continue to like exceedingly our french family.  We intended in coming, to stay a month & then go to the Mts.  But the weather has been almost too cool for anygreat heights, & this, so far (I dont know how it may be in August) seems a happy medium.  We have had a few warmish days, but for the most part it has been a delightful summer climate.  Then too we have had so much gadding about, that we enjoy the quiet & the thought that we are learning something.   

   How often I wish I cd. have Agnes here for a few months.  It would do for her, what years of study at home cannot do for any body.  I never knew before how badly, or rather how little we had been taught at home, how to pronounce french.  Then too this is such a nice family where it wd. be so safe to place a child.  Their ideas about education are good- & they have so much simplicity in their ways & manners- they seem almost like those of friends.  The children have never been allowed to go to the opera or the theater- tho' they have one, within a few doors of them.  Every evening before going to bed, we have a little "culbe"- Madam Duproix reads out of a big bible- & then makes a little extemporaneous prayer- so very simple, that one cannot help but feel as if it came from the heart; After this, we separate for the night with much hand-shaking and many "[---]" & "[---]" & "[---]" &c- The great objection to the french is that they have to say so much about every little thing & are really too polite for comfort.  I think each person at the table says "par-r-r-don"- about 50 times at each meal (with a very great trill to the r- & a very great accent on the last syllable) if all this wasn't accompanied with real kindness of heart (as in this case) one wd. become "very fatigued" of it.   

   We suppose that you are now at Montrose tho' we dont know it.  It has been a perfect age since anyone has written from Awbury.  I sent cous. FRC a letter containing a cheque about5 weeks since & having rec'd no acknowledgement fear it has been confiscated, or that he is not well.  We are anxious to hear how you perform'd the journey & how Montrose goes.  Netty is writing to Lilly as I will not write now 
   
   with much love to her & the children
   
   they aff. sister C :

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1867-09-24
Title: 1867 September 24, Awbury, to blue Brother

Let this be read a day or so after sister Anna & Lilly's letters have digested.
   
   Awbury 9 mo 24th
   3rd day eve
   our parlor table
   
   My poor dear blue Brother
   
   Sister E has just bee reading thy letter to Chelle dated Woodford 9 mo 8th and I am very sorry thee gets so down in the mouth, and could wish I had been along with thee- provided I was wanted and could have done thee good, not that I would place myself before some others Lilly, Chellie, &c, but then maybe thee would not have felt me so much on thy mind, as I think I should have been pretty easily contented even if I did have to stay pretty close by old London.  I would have at least been a "flesh & blood" companionand not one of the ancient curiosities the guide books introduce thee to.  Not to say how much I would have liked to have been along on my own account, and the many little bits of intruction I would have picked up by the way, Well!  not wishing to assume too much I thought maybe I would have been better than nobody.  But when it came to paying call on the Hartshornes and the like, thee might have left me behind, the grandees and I, I fear would not get along very well together, some of them at any rate.
   
   Well would thee like to know what we are about at home.  Brother T at present in scouring vigorously at our new plate glass windows which have justbeen inserted into our front door, sister E has settled down to reading after one of her daddy long-leg excitements, whilst the children are settling off to bed except Ellie, whom Lilly got to come down to your house to tea, Chellie being over at her Grandfathers, while Alfred, and Frank took tea with us, Here they come Lilly, Virginia and Dr Hartshorne as escort, Perhaps thee will scarcely think it worth while for me to write all this.  Sister Anna seems to be consulting various books, following thee in thy travels, she was showing me a picture of- let me see- the old wall of Portsmouth, which thee speaks of in one of thy letters, and this evening she is inquiring for "Old England."  Yesterdaybrother J and wife, with myself took an early start for Wilmington, to pay one of those stated visits to Hannah Richardson.  It was a lovely day and we had a very nice time, and thyself and thy movements were among other topics spoken of.  In the cars that morning I had quite a little talk with James Cox, who also was inquiring after thee, and though absent thou art not forgotten.  I do hope thee found Ellis Yarnall and party on the Continent- and has enjoyed thy trip, and hope it will do thee good, I really fear thee will not get near all the good of the trip we would like, when thee gets so worried, try to look beyond the present difficulty, and think perhaps it will come rightin the end, and then thee will be sorry thee had taken so much trouble, and not gathered more good by the way, And even if it dont turn out what you wish, there are so much greater troubles, that I would have thee try to brighten up.  I dont want thee to finish up with typhoid feaver, this sounds most too bad dont it?  But I hope by the time this reaches thee, thee will feel quite brightened up, with thy trip on the Continent &c.
   
   5th day the 26th.  There has been quite a gap in my letter, the time being taken up in various ways, This morning was meeting morning and a very interesting meeting I thought it, S Emlen addressing the children, and in the course ofhis discourse told an interesting incident relating to a little girl who died lately, and who I suppose was little Mary Rhoads, Charles Rhoads daughter.  I suppose sister Anna told thee of her death, she was only sick 24 hours, and taken insensible almost from the first I believe.  Mary Haines spoke of her as having been a child of the Saviour for a year past.  Samuel Morris followed S.E. in a solemn prayer for the "parents", I think we sometimes have our best meetings on 5th days.  After meeting I went to Aunt Martha's to dine, and have some conversation with her in regard to Eugenia & Samuel, who are now here on a visit.  Aunt Constantia is very anxious S should not return to Washington and we think it veryimportant he should not, but be placed at some boarding-school.  Lilly & Chellie have just come up here, & also brother J and sister M.  Chellie's tongue has been going pretty much like a bell clapper ringing for [fire].  -that last word is fire- thy daughter has been joging her old aunt's elbow, which must account for the above appearance.  General Sheridan comes to Germantown to night, Gtn is coming on.  I suppose he will make quite a stir.  And Gough is coming too [---]!  I have tried to write in the fashionable style of crossing the page but alas!  I have not succeeded.  I hope thee can read it.  Sister Mary says give my love to Frank.  What would thee think of seeing her [---] down by the banks of the BrandywineHer visit there seems to have made quite an impression on her, she goes from home so little, and sees so little of the rural, small things make quite an incident in her quiet life, but the Brandywine is pretty fair for all.  I have not told thee yet how much surprised, almost shocked I was by thy letter to me at E-town telling of thy intention of starting for Europe.  it was so utterly unexpected, and then I was so far away from you, and could not ask what thee had gone for, except I knew it was on business, and then I would have liked to have taken a more affectionate farewell of thee, it had been such a hasty one when thee left Elizabethtown.  We had a very nice time there, Clemmie improved very much I thinkthough she has some cough still at times but it was of very little account, if it had not been for her previous attack.  We visited John Brown’s grave amongst other places, and I have some maple sugar for thee from his place.  I hear sister A and Lilly are both writing, but it is impossible to find a time when there is not some one writing to thee.  So should my letter come in at the little end of the horn, may it at least prove to thee that thee is affectionately remembered by thy far distant but loving
    
   sister Ruthanna
   
   If it should come in thy way to procure an Irish [poplin?] dress for me I would be glad to have one, if they are not too very high, dont get it if over $4.00 per ydI send a pattern of the one I have had, a most excellent one, I would like a dark gray or mode shade, but without a blue or pink shadow in it, my present one has blue in it.  or I would like a pretty brown, but dont take any trouble about it- There may be a kind not-quite-so heavy & expensive as this pattern would be

Title: 1811 February 3, Washington, to son

Washington   Feb.y 3d. 1811
   
   Dear Son
   
   I will consent to the sale of the Brig Eliza to Captn Veacock for $5000- the price offered- on a credit of 3 [?] 6 months- & this is the ultimatum- consult Isrl. & Jasp. on the security, & it would also be well to have the approbation of Thos. Coffin- altho the joint letter from Trickerman & Hussey might justify on in acting without him- But as I am to guarantee or procure a guarantee of the paper, that which Capn Veacock gives must be unexceptionable- Keep it until I return-
   
   I have seenthe President, Gallatin & many other of the great folks of the nation- Have been introduced to Randolph- & heard him harangue Congress yesterday- He is in my opinion the greatest Parliamentary debater of this Country- & I would not have missed the opportunity of hearing him on any [a/c?]  I shall say more about it when I return- We are in such a perpetual round & the parts we visit are so distant from each other, that there is scarce time to write- wh I do with such pen, such ink, such paper & in such place as I can catch- We have examined before a Come. of[---] Senate- they treated us handsomely but I do not believe the Bk will have [---] charter- Love to Mother & all the rest
   
   Affectionately
   
   Thos. P. Cope

Title: 1833 November 7, Philadelphia, to William Forster

Philada. 11 mo 7.  1833
   
   William Forster
   
   Esteemed friend
   
   It is probable that my son Alfred, who is about embarking for Madeira for the benefit of his health, may visit your country on his return homewards.  Should he do so, I have a desire that he should call on thee.  He would like to be made known to some friends in England, among whom he would prefer to spend his time while among you.  He is an exemplary member of the religious Society of Friends, & I shall feel greatly obliged by any act of kindness & attention which may be shown to him.
   
   thy friend
   
   Thos. P. CopeWilliam Forster
   
   Alfred Cope
   
   [Introductn to W. Forster]

Title: 1833 November 7, Philadelphia, to James Cropper

Philada. 11 mo 7.  1833
   
   James Cropper
   
   Dear friend
   
   My son Alfred is about to proceed to Madeira, where he designs to spend the winter, for the benefit of his health.  & as he will probably visit England before returning to America, I feel desirous of making thee acquainted with him.  He will of course incline to be principally among friends, while in your Country, & I shall feel much gratified by thy making him known to some of them.  He is an exemplary member of the religious Society of Friends, & will be found worthy of their regard.  I need scarcely add how much I shall be obliged by thy kind attentions to him-
    
   thine
   
   Thos. P. Cope[Introductn. to Ja's Cropper]
   
   James Cropper
   
   Alfred Cope   Liverpoolobtaining a wife- Henry will doubtless inform thee of thy having another niece.  Rebecca Harrison is very ill & her recovery doubtfull- poor [---], she has been sadly afflicted since last autumn- one disease succeeding to another- until she has been suddenly attacked with inflamatory rheumatism- first in all her limbs, then in the region of the heart.  Thy dear mother takes constant interest in thy welfare & has been anxiously looking for advices from thee- She is much rejoiced to hear of thy safety.  Jane Bettle still lingers-
   
   Other calls compel me to come to a close.
   
   Recommending thee to the protection of that Power, which alone can preserve us from evil- & insure peace & comfort
    
   I am affectionately
   
   Thos. P. Cope

Title: 1833 November 5, Philadelphia, to Robert Benson

Philada. 11 mo 5.  1833
   
   Dear friend
   
   My son Alfred will probably be at Liverpool, on his way home from Madeira, whither he is going to spend the winter- I know not at present what time he may find it convenient to tarry in England- but while in your quarter thy kind attentions to him will be very gratefully received & acknowledged by
   
   thy friend
   
   Thos. P. Cope
   
   Robert Benson
   
   Liverpool[33 Paradise St]
   
   Robert Benson
   
   Alfred Cope   Liverpool
   
   [Introductn. to Robt. Benson]

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1806-1875
Date: 1834-02-28
Title: 1834 February 28, Philadelphia, to Alfred Cope

Philada. 2mo 28. 1834
   
   We have at last my dear son been favoured to hear from thee- thy Letters of the 21st 1mo having reached us 2 days ago- that is one to Henry & one to William.  These are all which have as yet been recd-  Much as all of us have been gratified to learn thy safe arrival at Madeira our pleasure would have been greatly increased to have some assurance of thy health having been improved.  We hope for the best & are thankful to find thou art spending thy time so agreeably- far away from the troubles which surround us on all hands- Our country is indeed in a very portentious condition.  Genl Jackson seems to be determined let the consequences be what they may, to crush the Bank of the United States.  & such is the foolish nay mad devotion of his immediate partizans, that they are as determined to support him, reckless as to the future.  To day we have a message from our Governor, to the Legislature, announcing the failure of his attempts to borrow money.  & labouring to throw the blame on the Bank- besides the injustice of this charge, he appears to be but little aware of the effect this will produce on money lenders at home & abroad.  Who are [---] thy set, & will be alarmed with fears that the state may not be able to pay the interest of its vast debt- Had he posessed the manliness to recommend the recharter of the Bk public confidence would at once have been restored, & with it the facility of borrowing.  He contemplated the stopage of the public works- Who will then be able to calculate the public loss?  There can of course be little or no income, & the works themselves must be injured if not ruined.
   
   Our family concerns are going on much as usual.  Thy brother Wm is in a fair way ofAlfred Cope
   
   Madeira
   
   [T.P Cope 2/28- recd 4/25 1834   [---] Spark]

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1837-10-28
Title: 1837 October 28, Harrisburg, to Henry

Harrisburg 10mo 28.  1837-
   
   Dear Henry
   
   From thy letter of yesterday I perceive that doubts still exist as to the apprehended piracy- & the papers which reach us are full of contradictions & vain conjectures- at one time we were assured that the informtation had reached Norfolk about the same time it reached N Castle- & after that statement had passed current for some days we find by a Balte. paper that the first knowledge they had of it in Norfolk was the 25th in the afternoon.  The pilots if I recollect first reported the capturing schooner to be full of men & black sided- it now seems they kept so far away that they could not see whether the ship was bright sided- still they alledge to have distinctly seen the cross in her foretop sail- This circumstance is the most striking, & yet it is possible that at their distance they might be mistaken even in that.  I observe a story has been circulate in NYork of an oyster boat having supplied the ship at Sea- & that is believed, contradicted & reiterated- If that were true it wd. indeed be some comfort, as it might accot. for the whole affair, making some allowances for discrepancies.  It is altogether a painful subject, & has caused me much perhaps useless anxiety.  but no benefit can arise from despondency.  & it is our duty to submit to the Divine Will- & our best interest too- Let us then hope while hope we may-29th
   
   The letter from Capn. Miller which I read in the papers that reached us last evening, stating that information had been recd. from the Break Water by a Schr. just arrived, that she has passed the Susqa. of Chincoteague, a shr. along side of her- if true, wd. seem to put an end to doubt- But why did not Miller mention the name of the Schr. at the Break Water.  & how did that Schr. know what he saw was the Susqa.  If the ship was in the situation mentioned, & at the time mentioned, it argues a most extraordinary degree of hardy hood in the Pirate.
   
   Yesterday commenced the battle on the Judiciary.  Judge Hopkinson opened the debate- in a masterly manner- he spoke for 3 hours, & then gave way to a motion for adjournment- of course he will proceed with his argument 2d. day morning.  I hear it will prove unavailing- so many of the Convention being resolved on a change.  The discussion will no doubt be protracted thoughout all this week, perhaps even another- so many will try to distinguish themselves on this fruitful subject.  Feeling so much disappointed by the issue of the militia question I can no longer hope for much good from this Convention.  Indeed I care very little now how bad they may make a constitution- the worse perhaps the better-as the people will be the more likely to, reject it.  Earl made his appearance yesterday and forthwith commenced taking notes of Hopkinsons speech- He will attempt a reply- so will I suspect Ingersoll- but the most powerful antagonist will be Woodward- from Luzerne.  He is plausible, argumentative & fluent, but with all a thorough radical & in my judgement a most mischevous politician.  Doran & others are still absent- When I shall be relieved from my unpleasant imprisonment I cannot say.
   
   The morng the Thermometer at sunrise was 35.
   
   With love to Rachel & the children
   I am
    affectionately
   
   Thos. P. Cope
   
   Please say to Wm Evans that I have just recd. his Note with the Pamphlets, of wh. I shall endeavor to make a proper use- but as that subject has been dismissed for the present, & the mind of the members are filled with the Judiciary question I fear were I now to distribute them- they wd. just be glanced at- thrown aside & forgotten- The subject will come up again on 2d. reading & then may be a suitable time for their distribution.  My own fears are however that Friends have little more to hope for from this Convention.Thos. P. Cope
   
   Henry Cope
   Philadelphia
   
   [TP Cope Harrisburg
   10mo 28 1837]

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1806-1875
Date: 1840-08-25
Title: 1840 August 25, Newport, to Alfred

Newport 8mo 25. 1840
   
   Dear Alfred,
   
   It is growing towards being after sunset, but while Job is making arrangements for our departure tomorrow morning in the Massacheusetts Steamer for Providence, it falls to my lot to drop a line by Wm who is intended send with the Carriage & Horses next day, by return of the same Steamer to NYk thence to proceed on his way to Philada.-  You will all be gratified to hear of thy dear mothers improved health, & also of Eleanors- altho we have experienced hot weather for some days, & have qualms as to the propriety of throwing ourselves into a more heated atmosphere-  Stephen P. Morris arrived here yesterday from Providence, & reports the thermometer to have been up to 95 the day before.  The air since dinner to day has become cooler, & we may reasonably hope will improve a pace shortlty-  Other things change as well as the weather- & now after writing so far, a bell man announces that a Balloon Steamer is to be here tomorrow from P. & return again at 3 AM-  We wished originally to go by her- but she has undergone repairs, & there was this morning no certainty when she wd. be here-  We therefore had made up our minds to go by the Massachusetts between 6 & 7 AM-  We intend to visit N. Bedford, Boston, Wooster &c &c.  & stop at Hartford Ct where letters may meet us on our way home, not later than 10 days from today-
   
   We have visited most of the Lions- & among them the Library, where rest the remains of divers elderly volumes-  The discoveries of the Icelanders are there deposited-  We met in the St a certain antiquarian, named Bull, with whom we held learned converse on those discoveries-  On asking him if he had heard of the learned northener who had found a stone with Runic Characters- a temple, & an image representing the Scandanavian God Thor, in Brazil- He said he had not- & then added, "so long as they confined themselves to N. Am, I was willing to concede that point to them- but now that they are going to claim S. Am too, I wont believe any of it"-  The old man may have read our couplet- "They lose the whole who claim too much
    
   As Simon Snyder said in Dutch- And the Danes may now hang up their fiddle, & content themselves with their own Icy shores-The drives abt. Newport are fine- but we have too much dust- the grass is nevertheless very fresh- & the fields are beautiful- We visited a tract at Brenins Point, I side of the Island, & skirted by the Ocean- & a more fertile splendid farm, I do not remember ever to have seen-  They use the seaweed abundantly, as a manure- & also a fish called Manhayden- dragged from the Ocean by nets, & sold at 14 Cts a Bbl- They are very oily- but I do not admire the filthy practice of strewing them over the fields to contaminiate the air-  The bathing here is very good & Job & I use it freely- while mother & E continue their purifications in the warm salt bath-  Among our numerous lodgers we have had Abraham Knickerboker & wife- He the lineal descendant of the true Dietrich- & has his residence at the very spot described by Irving, whose description he says is very correct-  He is an intelligent and well informed man, speaking the English fluently- & his wife interested us very much, by her smiley face, he goodly appearance & good sense-  The good man himself is out of health, & his loving spouse seems very uneasy abt. him-  On leaving us they each gave us a cordial invitation to visit them at their home in the romantic poetical village of Schaghticoke-
     
   While writing Elenor bids me say- you have among you, used her [---] badly, in not even noticing a Letter- wh he took trouble- pains taking man- to endite to some of you- but as she has stepped out- I do not know when manufactured, nor to whom directed- Cara’s epistle of odds & ends- like this of mine- has been received, & was, for her comfort, very satisfactory-
   
   Having in council duly convened decided to go by the Baloon to morrow.  I have come to the conclusion to rest for the present from my labours- to resume if needs be, in the morning but not until I say that we this afternoon paid another visit to the afflicted family mentioned before- none of them are better- the mother indeed much worse- she seems destined we think to take her departure to a better world very soon-
   
   26th
   
   A bright cool air promising a pleasant [---] to Providence- A boarding House forms a pretty good epitomy of life on a larger scale- One generation passeth away & is succeeded by another- so old faces depart [---] & new ones present themselves- In all things said the great Apostle I am instructed- & so we may be even in this day- did not time hurry us with such Rail Road speed as scarcely to permit us more than a glance- Among our imates is a certain Judge Balch of Florida, a thorough going Loco- & reviler of sacred things- He attempted to show that the creation was the result of natural causes, combining & operating on each other- Moses' account he calls a fiction,the mere offspring of a fervid imagination.  He abounds in anecdote- mostly I suspect the product of his own fancy- His atheism offended Knickerbocker much- it shd. be Knickerbacker- marble baker-  I joked & talked politics with the Judge for a while- but finding when hard pressed he became rude, I quit it- yet shd. be amused with his profundity of discourse could I have faith in his word-  He stated for instance that he had furnished the Bk. US. with the first list of Directors for the branch at Nashville- all of whom "Me. Biddle appointed"- He did not however know that while making this statement to me & others he was addressing a man, who had been not only a Director of the Parent Bank at the time, but chairman of the Cme. of elections, who alone reported all nominations of branch directors, to the Board, & who knew the statement to be untrue-  I did not undeceive him, but left him to the enjoyment of his own fiction.  We had a short visit from a mercht. of Havanna- Cpa!  Clapp of the House of Drake, & Co an intelligent man, who, inter alia, gave me a piece of information entirely new, at least to myself- He says that a company of individuals, Spaniards & others, residents in Cuba have purchased a large tract of sand from a native Prince, in Africa, 150 miles square- wh. is to be cultivated with Coffe Sugar &c for commerce- the natives being the Labourers- should the designs of the Comp.y be honest, & fairly carried out- it will carry out Buxtons Scheme, & prove a great blessing to Africa- but considering of whom the Co. is composed, I cannot avoid fears.  C says the Coffee Plantations in Cuba yield but 6 or 7 Pct. while their Sugar Plantations give them 10- the slaves working 14 hours of the 24- The labour is so severe that when suspended, to take food, he has known the slave to fall asleep while on his feet, & prefer rest, even to eating- the waste of life is consequently great.
   
   The change in the weather has produced its usual effect- my E has a headache but will doubtless be better when the sun advances- by the way we have had but one or two foggy mornings since our arrival-  Job & I mean to experiment on a warm bath this morning deeming the sea air is too fresh for our skins-  Love to all- & sympathy in the bargain for any that have tooth ache or the like-
   Thos. P. Cope
   
   As there are so many at Lincolns who have nothing to do, we have half a mind & almost tother half tooto get our dander up for their wicked neglect open in not writing-
   
   I had just sealed this letter when Henry's of the 22d arrived- & have accordingly reopened it to make the acknowledgment- It is gratifying to learn of your continued good condition & of his having parted with his tooth ache- a most troublesome compassion-  I had not heard of any defaltations in the Kent.y Bank- nothing short of making such crimes felony can prevent them-  We have indeed arrived at a such state of morals-  Finding that the next mail goes via Providnce, I shall carry this letter there- & if anything worth penning occur
   
   will make proper not thereof-  We rece.d Franks letter of the 22d recording his & Toms marvellous escape from Hicksite contamination- tho I think they might have broken bread with J.B without fatal consequences-
   
   26th
   
   Here we are at Providence, after a run of abt. 2 hours from Newport-  We lodge at the City Hotel, a large & apparently well regulated House- we have formed no acquaintences but shall probably see some of our friends during the day- Our run up the Narragansett was not very interesting- the shores presenting little variety-  Bristol, Warren & a few neat villages were in view, but trees, those grand ornaments of nature, & wh. impart so much beauty to rural scenery & to City & Town comfort are sadly wanting-  This morn is bright & cool-  As yet we have formed no plans for the day-  When all are up we will hold a councilThe Town meeting to control the Courts is of bad omen- especially as the Judges are by our new Constitution subject for their offices to the popular will- These doings tend to anarchy and despotism, the fruit of Jacksonism- Fanny Wrightism &c[T.P.C. 8/26- Prove- -]
   
   [8/28]
   
   Henry & Alfred Cope
   Philada

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854

Title: 1840 August 25, Newport, to Alfred

Newport 8mo 25. 1840
   
   Dear Alfred,
   
   It is growing towards being after sunset, but while Job is making arrangements for our departure tomorrow morning in the Massacheusetts Steamer for Providence, it falls to my lot to drop a line by Wm who is intended send with the Carriage & Horses next day, by return of the same Steamer to NYk thence to proceed on his way to Philada.-  You will all be gratified to hear of thy dear mothers improved health, & also of Eleanors- altho we have experienced hot weather for some days, & have qualms as to the propriety of throwing ourselves into a more heated atmosphere-  Stephen P. Morris arrived here yesterday from Providence, & reports the thermometer to have been up to 95 the day before.  The air since dinner to day has become cooler, & we may reasonably hope will improve a pace shortlty-  Other things change as well as the weather- & now after writing so far, a bell man announces that a Balloon Steamer is to be here tomorrow from P. & return again at 3 AM-  We wished originally to go by her- but she has undergone repairs, & there was this morning no certainty when she wd. be here-  We therefore had made up our minds to go by the Massachusetts between 6 & 7 AM-  We intend to visit N. Bedford, Boston, Wooster &c &c.  & stop at Hartford Ct where letters may meet us on our way home, not later than 10 days from today-
   
   We have visited most of the Lions- & among them the Library, where rest the remains of divers elderly volumes-  The discoveries of the Icelanders are there deposited-  We met in the St a certain antiquarian, named Bull, with whom we held learned converse on those discoveries-  On asking him if he had heard of the learned northener who had found a stone with Runic Characters- a temple, & an image representing the Scandanavian God Thor, in Brazil- He said he had not- & then added, "so long as they confined themselves to N. Am, I was willing to concede that point to them- but now that they are going to claim S. Am too, I wont believe any of it"-  The old man may have read our couplet- "They lose the whole who claim too much
    
   As Simon Snyder said in Dutch- And the Danes may now hang up their fiddle, & content themselves with their own Icy shores-The drives abt. Newport are fine- but we have too much dust- the grass is nevertheless very fresh- & the fields are beautiful- We visited a tract at Brenins Point, I side of the Island, & skirted by the Ocean- & a more fertile splendid farm, I do not remember ever to have seen-  They use the seaweed abundantly, as a manure- & also a fish called Manhayden- dragged from the Ocean by nets, & sold at 14 Cts a Bbl- They are very oily- but I do not admire the filthy practice of strewing them over the fields to contaminiate the air-  The bathing here is very good & Job & I use it freely- while mother & E continue their purifications in the warm salt bath-  Among our numerous lodgers we have had Abraham Knickerboker & wife- He the lineal descendant of the true Dietrich- & has his residence at the very spot described by Irving, whose description he says is very correct-  He is an intelligent and well informed man, speaking the English fluently- & his wife interested us very much, by her smiley face, he goodly appearance & good sense-  The good man himself is out of health, & his loving spouse seems very uneasy abt. him-  On leaving us they each gave us a cordial invitation to visit them at their home in the romantic poetical village of Schaghticoke-

   26th
   
   A bright cool air promising a pleasant [---] to Providence- A boarding House forms a pretty good epitomy of life on a larger scale- One generation passeth away & is succeeded by another- so old faces depart [---] & new ones present themselves- In all things said the great Apostle I am instructed- & so we may be even in this day- did not time hurry us with such Rail Road speed as scarcely to permit us more than a glance- Among our imates is a certain Judge Balch of Florida, a thorough going Loco- & reviler of sacred things- He attempted to show that the creation was the result of natural causes, combining & operating on each other- Moses' account he calls a fiction,the mere offspring of a fervid imagination.  He abounds in anecdote- mostly I suspect the product of his own fancy- His atheism offended Knickerbocker much- it shd. be Knickerbacker- marble baker-  I joked & talked politics with the Judge for a while- but finding when hard pressed he became rude, I quit it- yet shd. be amused with his profundity of discourse could I have faith in his word-  He stated for instance that he had furnished the Bk. US. with the first list of Directors for the branch at Nashville- all of whom "Me. Biddle appointed"- He did not however know that while making this statement to me & others he was addressing a man, who had been not only a Director of the Parent Bank at the time, but chairman of the Cme. of elections, who alone reported all nominations of branch directors, to the Board, & who knew the statement to be untrue-  I did not undeceive him, but left him to the enjoyment of his own fiction. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas Pim Cope:  1823-1900
