Date: 1852-07-17
Title: 1852 July 17, to Clemmie, Woodbourne

Philadelphia, 7mo 17, 1852
   
   Dear Clemmie,
   Grandfather desired me to acknowledge the receipt of thy acceptable letter of last seventh day. I am sorry for thy sake that it has not fallen into better hand, but if thee will believe that I have the will to send thee such a letter as would give thee a great deal of pleasure, I will rely upon the interest it will have for thee as coming from among and giving thee a great deal of pleasure. I will rely upon the interest it will have for thee as coming from among and giving thee perhaps, the latest news of some of those who think so much of thee. Anne and I entirely agree with thee in considering that the pleasantest part of the days journey was when we were all traveling together. We ran off the track about half an hour after we parted and were four hours in a pretty hot place before we were on our way again. If we had foreseen that we were to pass nearly the whole day on the road might have he fellow travelers a greater distance and lightened me and others burdens. Thee must have had a very tiresome journey all the way home Henry Drinker tells us thee had to ride from Wilkes-Barre in the hot sun in an open wagon: he thinks they did much better. When thee comes down next winder, take thou Scranton unto. We are glad to hear that thee friend Uncle William so much better and the rest all well. Grandfather seems stronger and generally better than when he fist came out in the country- He sends his love to thee and all the family. Aunt Caroline, Frank and Ellie are at Cape May. I forget whetherthey went before thee left: they wrote several days ago that Ellie’s general health was improved We have heard indirectly that Mary was unwell- Julia has gone to Reading for a few weeks. Aunt Mary returned to Jersey yesterday I believe- She was kept in turn an account of Elizabeth’s mother having an attack very much like if not really cholera. She was very ill one night: they have gone to Cape May since with Henry and Ellie. The three families that live in that unnamed corner of this country that is so hard to find am pretty much as the left them they all send their love. Elizabeth says she would be very glad if thee would write to her if thee fells so inclined. Please tell Uncle William that a package for Grandfather by Henry Drinker came safe to hand the morning- Uncle Alfred has taken the letter out to him. He comes in and spends every "third-day" in town.   
   I hope we shall hear from thee often; if thee should write to me it would give me much pleasure.
   
   Affectionately thy cousin,
   Thomas P Cope Jr.
    
   Germantown, 7mo 18, 1852
   
   Dear Clemmie,
   
   Not having a woman's privilege as to postscripts I begin afresh.  I have no objections however to having reason to call the by name again – it seems more natural and sociable and I see thee look up from thy work or from study or quiet wordto hear what I have to say- I finished in a hurry yesterday afternoon intending to mail this before leaving town, but time failing I have an opportunity to say that Anne secured a letter from Eddy last evening in which he says nothing about his bodily conditions, but that his discontent which she had inquired about are improving" Your visit no doubt did him good. Visits from home to a boy at school are a pleasant recollections for the rest of his life.
   
   Thee did not grieve much about they blanket shawl when thee was riding in the stage at night; it will be cooler when thee comes down next fall and we will take care to sent it up to thee in time. Grandfather will be glad to hear from thee and I hope if thee is not afraid of a repetition of what thy first letter has brought upon thee, that thee will write to [.]
   
   With many desire for thy happiness.
 Affectionately, thy Cousin,
   Thomas Cope Jr.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1828-09-10
Title: 1828 September 10, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 9mo. 10. 1828
   
   Dear Brother,   
   If thou should not have invested for me the sum relative to which I wrote to thee on the 2d. ult., having confidence in the success of the C&D Canal, I will be obliged by thy adding to the amt. $1000 or $1500., & charging it to my a/c.  if it had occurred to me at the time, I wd. have made ye same request when I last wrote to thee, and it may be difficult to invest in the canal loan so small an am't as I then mentioned.* - having lately purchased some cattle & implements for my farm, I shall have occasion to draw on ye firm for ab't $100 or $120.  I drew on ye 5 inst., at 3 d/s fav. Porter & Keene for $50.-   
   with particular love to ye members of thy family individually, I remain thy affectionate brother,
   
   Wm D Cope
   
   *I need scarcely add, that I do not wish this to be done, unless entirely convenient to you.Henry Cope
   Care of Thos. P. Cope & Sons
   Philadelphia.
   
   attention of Caleb Carmalt.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1828-11-17
Title: 1828 November 17, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 11mo. 17. 1828
   Dear Brother,
   
   Thy letter of 28 ult. has been rec'd.  Wm Drinker has transferred his claim on Father to Martin Curtis, store-keeper of Montrose.  ye latter mentioned to me, when I was last in Montrose, that Wm has spoken to him on the subject of stopping any legal proceedings that may have been commenced.  this he said he was willing to do, tho' he wd. not relinquish a cent of ye claim, wh he was sure must be all paid: that unless a legal tender had been made, interest cd. be obtained on ye respective sums for ye time of their becoming due: that he knew W. Drinker had pd. a considerable portion of them in cash, because they had been pd.thro' him.  I told him that I tho't he had only heard one side of the case & advised him not to be to confident of success.-  W.D. also says that he subjected himself to considerable inconvenience in order to pay the taxes, but considered that ye debt was in safe hands & wd. ne accumulating by ye addition of interest.
   
   I observe that the Ches. & Dele. Canal loan has not yet risen, if ye public quotations are to be relied on, & shall be glad if thou hast succeeded in making a further investment for me.-  besides the drafts mentione[d] in thy last, I drew on the 6th inst. draft no. 5 for $50.00.- how [---] does ye agitation in ye corn market affect ye shipping interest?  and what freights have ye packets lately had?-  I was sorry to learn that Alfred was again lame.  please mention in thy next ye cause of his lameness.-  with particular love to ye members of thy family individually, I remain thy affectionate brother,   Wm D Cope
   
   I will be obliged by thy collecting the annexed drafts for me.Woodbourne
   11 mo, 17 1828
   
   [11mo 19 1828]
   
   Henry Cope,
   Care of Thomas P Cope & Sons
   Philadelphia.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1829-05-11
Title: 1829 May 11, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 5mo. 11. 1829
   Dear Brother:
   
   I reached this place after a pleasant journey, which occupied, as usual, 2 days.  I had pleasant company, & never before endured so little fatigue in crossing the Pokono.  the road over it is considerably improved.  I had the company of Jos'h [S?]inton  from Nazareth to Wilkes-barre.  he was on his return from attending the Orthodox Yearly Meeting.-  I was much pleased with the verdant appearance of the fields in this part of ye country.  ye season is much less advanced than usual at this time of year, but the grass looks well.-  there has not been so much done at my buildings during my absense as I expected wd. have been done, but ye workmen are now busily employed.  my Scotch farmer, I think it likely, will maintain the character of his countrymen for industry & fidelity, but I have not hired him long enough, fairly to test his qualifications.  ye female part of his family, however, it too numerous to suit me, as I have but little employment for women.-  tho' I have but little to communicate, I tho't I wd. not let a private opp'y pass without informing you of my safe arrival here & present health.  I shall feel anxious to hear from the invalids of thy family, tho' I hope they are not now invalids.-  I hope also that our new Mother may, by this time have regained her usual health.-  please give my love to all my kind friends & relatives, with whom I have so recently passed so many pleasant hours, that ye chain of communication between us, though separated, seems unbroken & strong.-  if thee shd. see Uncle Jasper please tell him, that I delivered his letter to Henry Colt, but that John N Conyngham had left Montrose before I arrived.  I therefore immediately forwarded the letter for him, to Wilkesbarre, & have little doubt but that he received it before leaving there for Bradford County.   I remain thy affectionate brother,
   Wm D CopePlease say to Eleanor, that I hope she will not mention to Cousins Abby Ann & Emma, any remarks that I made with regard to the evening company invited by them a short time before I left the City & of which I was one.  such observations are sometimes repeated under circumstances that give them an air of more seriousness than was intended by the one who makes them.[Note in second hand: W.D. Cope Woodbourne 5mo 11 1829]
   
   [Note in third hand: Journey home & personal allusions-"Our new Mother," etc., Scotch farmer- too many females in his family!]
   
   Henry Cope
   Care of Thomas P Cope & Sons,
   Philadelphia.
   
   attention of Jas C Biddle

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1828-12-12
Title: 1828 December 12, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 12mo. 12-1828
   Dear Brother:
   
   Having an opp'y of writing, I will embrace it if it be only to thank thee for thy kind attention to the subjects mentioned in thine of 22 ult.-  ye mildness of ye season so far, will probably favor the operations of the Ches. & Del. Canal Co.-  I hope the Algonquin may do well at Savannah, as I observe by late a/cts, that no vessels were up there, & freights were brisk, tho' ye rates were low.  if it be not improper, nor too much trouble, please mention in writing to me, ye names of ye authors of any of the essays in "the Friend," that may come to thy knowledge.-  we have lately had a visit in these parts, from two hetorodox friends, Jno. Foulke of Quakertown, Bucks Co., & Salathiel Cleaver, of Montgomery Co.-  they had meetings at Friendsville, & in the neighborhood.  the Presbyterians expressedtheir satisfaction with the communications of J. Foulke.  I did not hear him speak in public, but understand that he did not speak on doctrinal points.  he is a man of venerable appearance, & his plain, communicative, unostentatious habits & manners, are calculated to preposess a stranger in his favour.  amongst other places, that he has visited, is ye settlement of the German Separatists in the Western country.  he speaks of their condition as very comfortable & flourishing.  the canal which is to connect the Lakes with the Ohio, passes thro' their land.
   
   I have just rec'd a letter from Caroline.  please give my love to her & tell her, that I will thank her to use my authority in contradicting any rumours of the kind to which she alludes.-  we are obliged to submit to the mortification of being ye subjects of them, but I think it is no more improper to contradict such, than any other incorrect reports.
   
   I have a paymt. to make before long, & expect to draw on the firm in a few days, to meet it, for about $200.-
   
   With love to all, I remain thy affectionate brother,
   Wm D Cope[Wm D Cope Woodbourne 12mo 12 1828
   
   Mtg at Friendsville
   Jno. Foulke &c
   
   12mo 20 1828-]
   Henry Cope
   Care of Thomas P Cope,
   no.36, North 4th St., or Walnut St. Wharf,
   Philadelphia.-
   
   p. Charles Chandler Esqe.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1828-08-02
Title: 1828 August 2, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 8mo 2nd, 1828
   Dear Brother,
   
   Thine of 24 ult. reached me by last mail as there is no magistrate in my immediate neighborhood, I annex a short power of atty, confirmed by private witness if this should not be sufficient to enable thee to collect the divd. on the M.S. B'k stock. I will be obliged by thy procuring a certified copy of the power in thy hands, as the expense of one cannot I think, be so much but that ye include any amount of ye divd. would soon more than repay it, and may as well have ye use of ye money as the Bank. Please when convenient, invest this and ye sum for Ches. and Del. Canal Co., and the Ches. Del. Canal loan at the current price of said loan, unless it should so happen that you could use it to advantage. I am pleased to hear that you are likely to [acrue] something on your claim against ye estate of Geo. [Yeuillo] as this is not generally a good season for freights, I am willing to hope that other causes besides ye influence of the tariff may be assigned for ye poor freight of the Algonquin. I am sorry that several of our worthy friends are likely to suffer by M. Evans' failure, and I hope they may not be seriously embarrassed. At ye close of thy letter, allusion is made to a subject, on which I feel as if I would at present, as willing be silent, as to open my mouth. I nevertheless, feel grateful for ye interest, expressed by thee. It remains exactly, as far as my knowledge extends, in ye estate in which it was when I last conversed with thee in regard to it. Nothing has passed between ye parties since ye reasons for this, as will as ye subject itself, it does not appear to me to be desirable to portray on paper. A disposition to regret the course that I adopted sometimes arises, but a consciousness of rectitude of intention, check its growth. Though I may fail in practicing upon it, I think ye theory, good, that after having acted our part agreeably to ye best of our judgment and conscience, we should in regard to temporal things, discard anxiety about future events. We unsocialably encounter ills enough without creating such as not ye avoided. I intended answering Caroline's & Alfred's letterswithout much delay. I desire love to the members of thy household and remain thy affectionate brother,
   William D. Cope
   
   Since Writing ye foregoing, I have had occasion to pass ye house of one of our magistrates, and have acknowledged the power of attorney.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1829-07-13
Title: 1829 July 13, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 7 month 13th 1829
   Dear Brother:
   
   Thine of 29th ult. has been rece'd. I was pleased to learn that our parents were well, and hope that Edward & Alfred may be benefited by their proposed excursion and that thou may’st also find time to enjoy ye benefits of ye same kind of recreation. Ye country is now enlivened by visitors from ye City and Susquehanna Co. is favoured with a share of them. James Holly Biddle bro't back with them from Phila. their sisters Sarah Biddle and Mary Drinker, and E. Walker's family have ye company of ye widow Morris, and her daughters, Susan & Elizabeth. We have lately been favoured also with a visit from Joel Woolman and Alvin Keyser, appointed by Abington Quarterly Meeting to visit Friendsville Preparative Meeting. they appeared to be man of plain, unassuming humble manners, and were well received by both Hicksites & Orthodox. Cha's Shoemaker accompanied them as far as a Stroudsburg, where he became so ill, as to present his proceeding further. We have subsequently had a visit from Ja's Bell, another orthodox friend and an elder, appointed by Stroudsburg Monthly Meeting.
    
    Dan'l Stroud has been indisposed, or he also wd. probably have visited this part of his flock.  he occasionally writes excellent letters of advice to afford thee an idea of his decisive and at the same time affectionate letters of language & manner, I will give thee an extract from one of them, recently addressed to E. Walker: "distressing as is ye fact, yet it certainly is the case, that the Hicksites are a distinct Society from Friends, and ye separation proceeded from ye leaders of that seccession having become corrupted with anti-christian doctrines, mostly Socinian, but compounded with some other speculative notions, made up into bills to suit ye subjects to whom they were to be administered, and gilt with specious professions of great spirituality, to captivate members and professors with Friends. this with various practices, such as are too commonly used in electioneering, have beguiled & seduced many, who have not or had not previously embraced those awfully dreadful notions, not fitting to be styled doctrines, when we are speaking of religion, and whether these will become leavened into the mass of infidelity with their leaders, or separate from them remains among the things which futurity must disclose. that thou & I, and ye dear children Providentially entrusted to our care, may be preserved from this direful contagion, I have earnestly craved, feeling some hope, that we may resist every temptation that may beset us, to unsettle us and loss about with every wind of doctrine.
    
   If we ever knew anything, "as we ought to know", le us "walk by ye same rule and mind the same thing." Let us be satisfied with and established in "the faith once delivered to ye saints",and say with ye apostle, "thanks be to God for his unspeakable gift", in uniting Deity & virility so as to provide salvation for our fallen race, consistently with divine justine & mercy, though the august plan & means were such as Angels desired to look into.  and tho' this wonderful union is beyond their conception & ours also, we shd. be grateful for it, for surely it is exactly adapted to the condition & need of us poor frail beings, inasmuch as it is complete, or affords complete salvation, both indemnity & cure. Redemption from the penalty & power of sin; remdemption from the penalty by the atonement made by Jesus Christ, our Lord, being God & man;- and redemption from ye power or government of sin by the Holy Spirit, so received into & operating upon our hearts, as to change them, producing a birth of ye spirit & furnishing divine ability in faithful humility & obedience, to resist temptation & be preserved in divine acceptance."++++- Present my very warm & cordial love to thy very dear children, who I feel expressibly near to me. I remember ye kindness of R. T. also; and entertain sentiments of regard for our dear yound friend W. D. Cope, your near neighbour. under sensations which I am thankful for, I bid you all affectionately fare well." (signed) Daniel Stroud.-
   
   Thy observations with regard to ye precarious tenure of our hold on life, are worthy of being often recalled, & deeply impressed upon ye memory & ye heart.- with thyself, I hope & trust that ye deep concern & unbounded affection of our dear deceased Mother for us, will not have been uttered & felt in vain;- that ye expression of her hopes & fears, her sighs & sorrows, have not been for naught.-  I sincerely desire that ye change in ye management of your business, may be advantageous in a pecuniary point of view to thyself & Alfred, but ye annunciation of it, caused a shade of sorrow to pass over my heart. ye expunging of a name, upon which we have been in ye habit of looking so long, that we look upon it with a degree of veneration, seems somewhat like ye disappearance of an old friend or favourite.
   
   I have had workmen pretty constantly employed at my building since my last return from ye City, sometimes to ye number of 6 or 8, sometimes more. ye attention which these, my farm & Father's estate, occupies my time, pretty fully. ye last mentioned concern requires in its present stage & condition much attention for but little profit. but it is absolutely necessary that something shd. be done to guard against ye effects to which it is liable from an accumulation of taxes & interest. I still look forward however, to a change, decidedly for ye better, but we are so apt to be too fast in our calculations, that it becomes us to be cautious.-  I think it likely from present appearances, that my investment in ye stock of ye Leigh Coal and Navigation Co, will be a good one. I am not displeased to find myself becoming more & more interested in my farm. I form an attachment for every tree & every field, which has called forth my care & attention,- for every hill and every valley, that have afforded me gratification by their smiles & beauties.  ye lover of ye country can often realize ye enthusiasm of [Hervey], & exclaim, "when the little hills rejoice & the vallies laugh & sing, who can forbear joining ye general joy". I have at all events reason for self gratulation, inasmuch as I am more pleased with my present mode of life, than I at one time ever expected to be.- I early perceived that with my limited means, I mustbe contented with advancing slowly, in any improvements that I might wish to make, but it has been very difficult to reconcile myself to making so little progress as yet been able to make, owing to ye circumstance last mentioned as well as others.-  I expect that ye capital & influence that Caleb Carmalt is employing in favour of this County, will be of advantage to it, though we we may not feel their effects immediately in this neighbourhood.  some of E. Walker's Family, who have recently been at Friendsville, mention, that he has 30 men & 9 yoke of oxen at work on his farm.  two of his brothers, & one of his sisters have also pitched their tents at Friendsville.-  his brother James, fm Philada., has purchased a farm of 1000 acres & is employed in improving it.-
   
   With particular love to all, I remain thy affectionate brother,
    Wm D Cope
   
   Since writing ye foregoing, I have received thine of 6 ins’t. I will attend to doing what is necessary, to further ye collection of ye divd on ye Canal loan. I hardly expect that there will be any divd. this year, on ye Lehigh Canal stock, but if there should be, I will be obliged by thy informing me of it.-  in addition to the drafts referred to by thee, I passed one to C. Avery & Co, on ye 10 ins't, numbd. 10, for $50.00.-  I regret that I can get no tidings of my missing papers.-  I am obliged by ye information communicated by thee respecting the C & D Canal.  that great work, seems still to baffle calculation.Woodbourne
   7mo. 13.
   
   [7mo 15 1829]
   Henry Cope
   Care of Thomas P Cope
   Philadelphia.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Joel Baily
Recipient:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Date: 1833-09-13
Title: 1813 September 13, East Marlborough, to William D Cope, Philadelphia

East Marlborough
    September 13th-1813
   
   Esteemed Friend William D Cope,
   
   I have received thy letter of the 30the of August which informes me that thee has accomplished thy journey Westward and is now at thy own home in Philadelphia. Therefore I now purpose writing thee a few lines by way of answer both to the above mentioned letter and that of the 25th of July. Friend Cope I judge thee thinks I am a very lazy fellow for nether meeting thee at West-Chester nor answering thy letter before this-time. but, as for the former I think I have a very good reason for I did not receive the intelligence of thee being there till about 5 days after the appointed time which was the only reason why I was not there for I would have been well pleased to of had the opurtunity of seeing my Friend by going the small distance of ten miles.but, altho thy friend was disappointed of the operturnity he thanks thee kindly for the invitation. The account thee has given me of Lancaster town is very similar to what I expected it was, but as for Columbia I did not expect its adjacent lands were so hilly, or, had such Mountains in them as thee mentions.I understand Friend E Lewis lately buried his son Ennoch with the flux. but I did not understan that the disorder has spread in the family.    
   With a hope that these lines may find thee in as good a state of health as I am in I conclude, and subscribe myself thy affectionate friend.
   
   Joel Baily
    
   William D CopeWilliam D. Cope
   Philadelphia
   
   To the care of Thomas P Cope
   merchant Walnut
   St warf

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William Brown
Recipient:  Susanna Sansom Brown:  1826-1909
Date: 1843-08-24
Title: 1843 August 24, Roxborough, to Sisters, Boston

Roxborough 8st Mo 24st 1843.
   4th day eve
   
   Dear Sisters,
   
    I presume you started as you expected at 7 o'clock this morning and if I may judge by the coolness of the atmosphere here at that hour,  I should think that you needed your blanket shawls on the river, and now perhaps you have them on again pacing the deck of the steamer on the Sound.
   
   But I write now more particularly at Father's request. He wished me to record the uncommon softness and mellow tints of the sky. For the Sun after a cloudy day is setting perfectly clear & the evening is certainly one of the pleasantest we have had this season. Though probably more so to him, having just returned from his business in the city. We miss your company very much, but I have no doubt but that you will enjoy yourselves exceedingly and return refreshed as you expect in body and mind.
    
   I wil now close for this evening and making a short addition tomorrow I will leave the remainder of the sheet to Mary.5th day 24st
   
   Wistar informed Mother last evening that Mamaduke Cope went to New York yesterday in the early line. You must have seen him. He goes to see the English Minister Pease previous to his tour to Canada.
   
   I expect that you have by this time nearly or quite recovered from the fatigue attending your journey. Sue would perhaps feel it the most as she is so unaccustomed to travelling. We intend to send Harry to the city tomorrow and our family will then be very small.
    
   You must write soon as father and all of us would wish to hear. Perhaps you will trouble yourselves to note down some of the most interesting things you see and then you will retain them more fresh in you memory for our benefit, as will as your own. Please remember me to Cousin William. We are all quite well & hoping that you are the same & wishing you every enjoyment
    I bid you adieu-
   
   Your aff Bro William.Dear Sisters,
   
   William & I concluded it would be a good place to set you all example by penning a few lines immediately; accordingly I have seated myself in our old apartment at 12 past 9 o'clock, whilst the rest of the family are quietly giving themselves up to repose, for since your departure we have retired ever earlier if possible than usual, in order to give you an idea how matters work on School house lane. We feel quite impatient to hear how Sue bore the journey. I hope you experienced no detention in consequence of the [---]; we saw by the paper this eve that the passenger cars from New York were notable to come on [---] day as so large an amount of rain had fallen as completely to deluge the road. Our meeting at Arch st was so as very large this morning as it was expected the English friends would be there but owing to the lat[---] storm they could not arrive till this evening I supposed they are now in the city. Francis B was at Uncle Moses' this afternoon perhaps if Anna had been at home he would have done her the favour to have called but as he has now received information that she is not at home he will take precious care that he does not show his face in these parts for several weeks; he had a letter a few days since from Cape May.  the family are all very well and intend coming home in a few days. Frank says if they do not return by second day, which is the last day the boat runs, they will have either to swim or return by land so that it is most probable they will arrive by the the end of this week. Wistar spent this evening with us very pleasantly he says every thing is going on in the city as usual very few persons have as yet returned. Mother wishes that you should buy her a [--] de [---] dress in Boston. If you see any thing that would be suitable; she wishes you to consult your own taste in the matter. If you see one with a small figure that you admire get it or if you see a handsome plain one, not too light a color, something that would be suitable for autumn.  A plain one she would rather prefer if youmet with what suited you. Give my love to Cousins R & Maria and tell the former I regretted exedingly not having an opportunity to bid adieu farewell Mother and I fully expected to have seen him in the city and were quite disappointed in not doing so. I hope you will write soon and let us know how you are coming on as it is the only thing you can do to cheer us during your absence as the evening draws to a close I believe I must now bid you an aff good night. excuse haste.  if you either of choose to favour me with an epistle I will promise to answer it immediately and to some length.  your aff sister Mary.I suppose the Cousins R. & Maria to whom Aunt Mary refers in this letter where Cousins Robert & Maria Earle.  The former was very fond of kissing & Aunt Mary ysed to say that she always kept a pin ready to stick him if he came too near!  Mother must have been 21 at this time, Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue younger- Uncle Will came between Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue.  They were visiting Cousins in New England, where all Grandpa's relations lived.  At the time everybody travelled from New York to Boston by boat.
   letters dated.
   Aug. 1843

   letters dated.

   4th day eve
   
   Dear Sisters,
   
    I presume you started as you expected at 7 o'clock this morning and if I may judge by the coolness of the atmosphere here at that hour,  I should think that you needed your blanket shawls on the river, and now perhaps you have them on again pacing the deck of the steamer on the Sound.
   
   But I write now more particularly at Father's request. He wished me to record the uncommon softness and mellow tints of the sky. For the Sun after a cloudy day is setting perfectly clear & the evening is certainly one of the pleasantest we have had this season. Though probably more so to him, having just returned from his business in the city. We miss your company very much, but I have no doubt but that you will enjoy yourselves exceedingly and return refreshed as you expect in body and mind.
    
   I wil now close for this evening and making a short addition tomorrow I will leave the remainder of the sheet to Mary.5th day 24st
   
   Wistar informed Mother last evening that Mamaduke Cope went to New York yesterday in the early line. You must have seen him. He goes to see the English Minister Pease previous to his tour to Canada.
   
   I expect that you have by this time nearly or quite recovered from the fatigue attending your journey. Sue would perhaps feel it the most as she is so unaccustomed to travelling. We intend to send Harry to the city tomorrow and our family will then be very small.
    
   You must write soon as father and all of us would wish to hear. Perhaps you will trouble yourselves to note down some of the most interesting things you see and then you will retain them more fresh in you memory for our benefit, as will as your own. Please remember me to Cousin William. We are all quite well & hoping that you are the same & wishing you every enjoyment
    I bid you adieu-
   
   Your aff Bro William.Dear Sisters,
   
   William & I concluded it would be a good place to set you all example by penning a few lines immediately; accordingly I have seated myself in our old apartment at 12 past 9 o'clock, whilst the rest of the family are quietly giving themselves up to repose, for since your departure we have retired ever earlier if possible than usual, in order to give you an idea how matters work on School house lane. We feel quite impatient to hear how Sue bore the journey. I hope you experienced no detention in consequence of the [---]; we saw by the paper this eve that the passenger cars from New York were notable to come on [---] day as so large an amount of rain had fallen as completely to deluge the road. Our meeting at Arch st was so as very large this morning as it was expected the English friends would be there but owing to the lat[---] storm they could not arrive till this evening I supposed they are now in the city. Francis B was at Uncle Moses' this afternoon perhaps if Anna had been at home he would have done her the favour to have called but as he has now received information that she is not at home he will take precious care that he does not show his face in these parts for several weeks; he had a letter a few days since from Cape May.  the family are all very well and intend coming home in a few days. Frank says if they do not return by second day, which is the last day the boat runs, they will have either to swim or return by land so that it is most probable they will arrive by the the end of this week. Wistar spent this evening with us very pleasantly he says every thing is going on in the city as usual very few persons have as yet returned. Mother wishes that you should buy her a [--] de [---] dress in Boston. If you see any thing that would be suitable; she wishes you to consult your own taste in the matter. If you see one with a small figure that you admire get it or if you see a handsome plain one, not too light a color, something that would be suitable for autumn.  A plain one she would rather prefer if youmet with what suited you. Give my love to Cousins R & Maria and tell the former I regretted exedingly not having an opportunity to bid adieu farewell Mother and I fully expected to have seen him in the city and were quite disappointed in not doing so. I hope you will write soon and let us know how you are coming on as it is the only thing you can do to cheer us during your absence as the evening draws to a close I believe I must now bid you an aff good night. excuse haste.  if you either of choose to favour me with an epistle I will promise to answer it immediately and to some length.  your aff sister Mary.I suppose the Cousins R. & Maria to whom Aunt Mary refers in this letter where Cousins Robert & Maria Earle.  The former was very fond of kissing & Aunt Mary ysed to say that she always kept a pin ready to stick him if he came too near!  Mother must have been 21 at this time, Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue younger- Uncle Will came between Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue.  They were visiting Cousins in New England, where all Grandpa's relations lived. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna C. (Anna Cope) Hartshorne:  1860-1957
Recipient:  Annette Cope:  1843-1916
Date: 1895-09-01
Title: 1895 September 1, Woodbourne, to Annette

Woodbourne
   Sept. 1st 1895
   
   My dear Annette,
   
   When I reached Holmhurst last week Nanna immediately presented me with thy package, and I opened and found the irresistable little gentleman from Dai Nippon. Where did thee pick him up, I wonder! He will be a most pleasant memento of thee, though I shall hesitate to insult his diginity by inkinghis fine skirts! I have thought of thee, and of you all so much this summer, and greatly wished I could have seen thee and Carrie before we leave. I hoped Mrs. Cope would return while I was at Holmhurst, but she is I supppose still with you. If so please give her my dear love. Thee will forgive me I know for this tardy work, I spent a whole week nominally at Holmhurst, actually between the city, Germantown, and all the [---]. Thee knows onlytoo well what such packing is. Now I am enjoying a few day's rest at Woodbourne before going back to Awbury for a square start westward. Virginia here and sends her love, also says to tell thee that I will meet thee in Italy winter after next. I tell her I give the message as hers, not mine! Much as I should like such a prospect; she is much more liekly to turn up there in the next year or two, than I! Lillie and the girls & Thos. & Elizabeth Cope are entertaining Dr. Norris and a Germandoctor friend in the parlor, else they would doubtless send messages. Please give my love to Carrie and Clementine, I understand you are all together, and are glad to know you have that comfort. With dear love for thy own self, and thanks for thinking of me amid so much sorrow, I am as always,
   
   Affectionally thine
   Anne C. Hartshorne

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  George O. Walker:  b. 1838
Recipient:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Date: 1876-11-20
Title: 1876 November 20, Woodbourne, to Clementine Cope. Connymead

Woodbourne 11 mo. 20. 1876
   
   My very Dear Friend, 
    Clementine Cope, 
   
   Wilt thou be So kind, as to go with me to Florida, about the middle of January next? to that delightgul clime! 
   
   Where the Rose & Catalpa forever Shall bloom, 
    Where the chase cannot tire, nor the deer ever fail 
   Nor the mockingbird's music, 'ere cease in the vale. 
   
   For the sake of enjoying thy pleasant, agreeable company I will pay all expenses there & back. 
   Have long thought, there was not another person in this World, I would prefer to Dear thee! 
   Long Since, I was captivatedby thy winning ways agreeable manners & fine Sense! Thee was always so gentle, true & kind!
    "Alive to every tender feeling, 
    To deeds of Mercy always none, 
   The wounds of pain & sorrow healing, 
    With soft compassion sweetness to me. 
   
   No proud delay, no dark suspicion, 
    Taints the free bounty of her heart, 
   She turns not from the sad petition, 
   But gentle, aid at once impart." 
   
   "To know thee, is to love thee! 
   Thou Knowest that I love thee." 
   "Love & love only is the loan for love. 
   Wilt thou not reciprocate my love? 
   & concent to unite thy destiny with mine? 
   It will always be my greatest de
   -light to consult promote thy happiness
,    I do not approve of long engagements, (does thee?)Our time in this world is too,
   Short to be long in forming its 
   Most happy connection. 
   
   I think our habits, manners, tastes dispoistion are similar & therefore congenial! 
    
   Whilst Dr. Norris his amiable Wife, Sister, Mother & Aunt were here, they cheered my solitude very much by frequently inviting to dine, take tea &c. which I enjoyed. 
   
   Since their depeature for the City, I feel quite lonely & the want of agreeable, cultivated female Society. Some Person that I can love & be kind to, as I have always loved Dear thee, in Sincerity & truth! 
   
   Therefore, wilt thou not return my love & consent to marry me by Friends Cerimony, before going to Florida? Let that be thy Bridal tour? Please write me soon to allay myMy anxiety my suspense & say on what day next week it would be most convienient for thee to favor me with an interview at thy own comfortable home at Connymead & say also at what day & hour it will be convenient to send your carriage to me at your station.
   
   Thanks to kind Providence I am now favored with good health & hope you all will long continue to enjoy the same blessing!
   
   With Love to thy Sister & that love for Dear thee which neither time nor distance can efface.
   
   Ever truly thy sincere & loving friend- Geo. Walker

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Edward W. (Edward Wyatt) Evans:  1882-1976
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1901-09-04
Title: 1901 September 4, The Hague, to Mrs Jonathan Evans, Shropshire

Dear M.  I am writing now from the Hague and am glad to say that I have found the others. Art came to the Hotel and waited for me & then we followed the others to the Hague. They had been in a pension and glad been on a trip to the Island of Marken. Of course, it is perfectly great to see them. Hope you are all well. With love E.W.E.  To-morrow we goto Delft & return here.BRIEFKAART
   
   AAN Mrs Jonathan Evans
   Hydropathic Hotel
   Church Stretton
   Shropshire
   England.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Edward W. (Edward Wyatt) Evans:  1882-1976
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1904-09-04
Title: 1904 September 4, Conanicut, to Mother

Conanicut
   Sept 4th 1904
   
   Dearest Mother, 
   
   Sunday and a large dinner having brought a temporary lull in the activities of our household I am going to get in a letter to thee before thee leaves Franconia. 
   
   With a jolly crowd, good weather and plenty to do we are enjoying ourselves very much and if only thee and Anna were here with us we could ask for little to make things complete. But since that may bot be we are rejoicing that we shallor at least some of us, see you before long at Batemans. 
   
   Since a week ago yesterday we have kept moving at quite a rapid gait, leaving for the most part out of doors and hence cultivating large healthy appetites. Plates are busy, I can tell thee, passing up and down the "festive board", and as for the butter words fail. Of course our for us of entertainment are not so tremendously varied but they are good ones and hence we do not grow tired of repeating. We generally start out the day by playing some good active to properly shake our breakfast down and to put ourselves proper frame of mind for a swim and  when this is attained we descend like "wolves on the fold" of those good friends of ours, the Whitalls, who in spite of our filling up their boat house and bath house still seem to preserve their equanimity of temper. For which let us be truly thankful, for really I don't know how we could get along without our good swim off their pier. 
   
    Sailing is our principal other pastime and we have had several good times in the faithful "Three Sisters". However, as we only hire the boat four days out of seven there are times when we must occupy ourselces in other ways. One of those days last we went on a picnic to Beaver Tail and had a splendid time the large express wagon up the Newport Transfer Co. sevred as our charist and pulled by four large horses kept in a gallop most of the way by our energetic driver we must I'm sure have made an imposing spectacle. The little cove where we usually go took on quite a homelike cozy air as it's walls reflected back the glow of our blazing bonfire round  which we sat while some of the musical members entertained us. I think I enjoy our Beaver Tail picnics more than any others. Still whereI think of one we had only yesterday over on the mainland near where the boys once camped in narrow River I am tempted to qualify that statement. 
   
   The Family Emlen are qutie prevalent here this Sunday Sam and Art have come up over labor Day, Sam staying here and Art at the Kimbers while Cousins Ellie and George are just across the way from us. It is very nie to have so many friends here. 
   
   I am sorry that my long delay in writing has this time not even an excuse of verse but a mother's forbearance is so easily imposed on, that I hope thee will forgive me once more I am very glad thee liked the poem. By the way, I never told thee that I would be very glad to hear what Miss Simpson has to say about my studying law. 
   
   With a great deal of love to ann and thyself. 
   
   Thy affectionate son
   Edward

Title: 1906 June 26, Woodbourne, to Mother

Woodbourne
   June 26th 1906
   
   Dearest Mother, 
   
   My postal from New York will have informed you that the first part of my journey was safely accomplished and you will be glad to know that the ending was also successful. After fooling around in the Natural History Museum till about eleven o'clock I went down town  again via the subway and boarded the Black Diamond in Jersey City. It was a fine day and very pretty coming up. The trip on the little train from Tunkhannock to Woodbourne was especially pretty. Many of the fields were a mass of white and yellow with daisies and buttercups and the soft late afternoon sunlight still brightness the hillsides. I arrived at Woodbourne just about ontime, that is, 7 o'clock and Frank and Er drove down to meet me. They are all well and happy apparently, disquieted only by the fact that Theadora has a habit of yelling like a trooper where put to bed. Tell Father and Miss Richardson that I placed two kisses, one on each check for the respective ones which they sent. She didn't burst into tears as you mighthave expected but only weathered me with a stony stare. 
   
   Last night was beautifully dear and today is bright. I hope the fog has been blown away from Conanicut. Aunt Lilly seeds her love and says to thank thee very much for thy letter; she will write soon. Please give my love to Father and Anna and tell the former that the mileage book was not good on the Lehigh Valley. 
   
   Affectionately thy son
   Edward

Title: 1905 June 17, S.S. Minnehaha, to Mother

Please return!
   
   [mailed NYC 6/17/1905] 
   
   Dear Mother, 
   
   Here we are safe and sound on board the old craft and out of sight of land already at 7.30 a.m.  I am writing this to go by the pilot as he has not left us yet. The main reason for our being out of sight of land is that the fog is ratherthick.  I didn't turn out very early and am just as glad that I didn't as there wasn't much to be seen I guess, coming down the harbor. Ed didn't either, though he had thought of it last night.  Our roommates are named Argill and O'Brien. The latter appears to be a self-made Irishman, but rather good company I guess. Argill I have not seen yet in his civilized clothes. He is not what youwould call a sleeping beauty. George says he has a very nice man in his room.    A Mr Tucker. 
   
   Class Day and commencement went off very well and we had very good weather a very seemtial point. Uncle Will made nice address. 
   
    Please thank Anna very much for her steamer letter. It was very good of her to write. Please give my love and Aunty Lily and Ellie. Ed sends love to them and to both Ann & thyself in which I join. 
   
    Lovingly thy son, 
   Ernest
   
   June 17. 1905
   P.S. I forgot to thank thee for thy steamer letter too, dear.

Title: 1905 August 16, Hotel de Rome & Suisse, Venise, to Grandpa

Dear Grandpa,
   
   As mother in her last letter makes some mention of forwarding letters to you at North East I am going to try to give thee a little direct news instead of such second hand stuff. We are; as this large poster at the top of the page is intended to indicate, I suppose, staying at this Hotel de Rome in Venice. Hotel de New York would be a more apporopriate title as the house is full of Americans. 
   
   Venice is certainly a most picturesque and interesting place and would be a most attractive place for a long stay if it were not for the Italians and the smells. However in this last respect it is nothing to Desenzano, which  has certainly pleanty of "loacl atmosphere" about it. We arrived in Venice on Fifth day (8/24) and since then have been trying to see something of the sights of the old city. It was certainly a most complete change to embark on a gondola and be rowed, paddled, or whatever they call it, to our hotel. It seemed as though we were living in a picture. Fortunality our hotel  is on the grand Canal and only about five minutes walk from the square of St. Marks. We have spent quite a good deal of our time about the last and have enjoyed the fine old church much. The more one seens of it the more you begin to appreciate it. The mosaics are wonderful and the whole effect of the interior of the church (though somewhat interfered with by scaffolding, just now) is one of great richness of color. I think though that at least as far as architecture is concerned I prefer some of the fine onld English ministers. the Doges Place is also very fine in many ways but not nearly so attractive as St. Mark. The ceiling decorations are too heavyand intricate for my taste. We spent about two hours of one afternoon in a gondola on the Grand Canal, a most lazy but throughly enjoyable way of spending our time. Thee old canals are, I think, decidely the most attractive part of the place, and the gondola seems to fit them admirably. We want from one side to the other of the Grand Canal and were finally landed on our own doorstep. A most easy and satisfactory performance. 
   
   An emormous Italian (or French (?)) gentleman who is staying at our hotel is probably not so enthusiastic on this last subject as he managed to fall overboard during the performance to-day. Edward and I were aroused from the writing room by a great screaming of women and ran out on the porch expecting that something serious had happened, only to fin this great lump sitting on the steps, wet up to waist, and looking like some old sealion. He was so mad that he raged about in true Italian style and for some time refused to pay his gondoleer, or "poppe" I believe they call the man who runs the craft.  It was really very amusing. 
   
   This morning we went to the picture Gallery here.  The colors of some of the old masterpieces are very fine but I am afraid that I am not educated up to an appreciation of them.  The faces are so impassive that it quite destroys the sentiment and feeling in the work.  Uncle Tom I suppose will laugh at this, but I can't help it.  They are impassive.  Titian's "Assumption of the Madonna" was thr finest work we saw there I think.  The coloring and grouping in it are fine. 
   
   To-morrow we leave for Milan and thence on Second day we expect to go up into Switzerland again by way of Lago Maggiore.  It will be quite a relief in some ways, for I don't care for the Italian people or their smells.  Please give Uncles Tom & Will and Aunt Carrie my love.  Also please give a great deal of love to Grandma.  Ed sends his love to thee and Grandma.  With much love from thy affectionate Grandson Ernest.

Title: 1904 August 14, Jamestown, to Mother

[1904]
   
   Jamestown
   Aug 14th
   
   Dear Mother
   I was very glad to get thy letter - and am sorry I have not written more frequently of late.  I am also sorry that thee missed thy sleep even though it was for the benefit of thy son.  I hope thee don't wake up at such times usually. 
   
   We returned from [---] on Sixth day afternoon.  There were two crowds at the Lodge at different times- and so Margaret asked me to stay over I had a fine long visit from Monday morning until Friday noon.  Katharine, Mildred, & Marianna Buffum and Mary Reamy (a school friend of Margaret's) went over on the 6.15 trip of the Conanicut with Harold and me, and arrived at the Lodge, via. Mickford, at about two o'clock Margaret and George drove down and Mr Buffum and Billy rode on horse back.  We welcomed them to the Lodge about twelve, Mrs BuffumCope and George, the coachman, arrived about four.  Thus the first crowd migrated in small flocks.  Miss Blodgett came on Third day afternoon.  She is an East Greenwich girl and seems very nice and jolly though I dont know her very well -as I had never set eyes on her before she came to camp.  She stayed until Friday, but Katharine Mildred & Miss Reamy came up on Fourth day afternoon with Harold & George, so I was left a stranger among strangers.  The others who came late Tuesday night & on Wednesday morning were Mary Sands & Frida Paine (both Newporters) [---] Spencer and Geo. Phillips, the last being a Boston fellow.  Now I believe I have catalogued the crowd.  Thee knows that the Lodge is right on the Qiocompang Pond, a lake a little over a mile long and a little over half a mile wide.  The shores are quite irregular and are wooded right down to the very brink, the underbrush overhanging the water in many places, so the lake, though small is very pretty.  If you paddle to the far end of the lake from the Lodgeand then push up into a little reedy cove and make a carry of about 30 or 40 yards, you find yourself in [---] Pond- a small pond quite different in character from Qiocompang- as the shores are steep and there is a narrow stoney beach all around.  If you paddle to the far end of [---] Pond and then land and climb the hill through woods you can look out across the country and see the ocean beyond.  Which is a pretty nice thing to do.  I went down twice once with Katharine and again with Miss Blodgett.We had some good walks too.  The woods are pretty around that section and the whole country is surprisingly wild and unspoiled.  There are deer and grouse in fairly good numbers and they say that there are trout in the streams and bass and pickerel & pirch in the lake.  There are a good many nice wood trails to walk along and it is great sport exploring and seeing where you bring up.  You have to be careful though as you can lose yourself without much difficulty.  We had a great walk on Fourth day morning in a pouring rain.  Most ofthe way over (we went to Natchang Pond a lake about five miles from the Lodge by the way we went over) was through the woods for most of the way and through little trails.  I was piloting the party over and as I had only taken the walk once and that was two years ago I was a little nervous but by good luck turned out O.K.  Harold had been over this way with us the time before and Mr Buffum knew the general lay of the land pretty well so it wasn't so bad as it sounds.  It rained like everything and we simply drenched but had great sport.  Some of the girls went in bathing suits. 
   
   So much for [---].  I'll try to get down & things nearer home.  If it suits you I am thinking of coming up to see you for a few days.  As I have just been away and as there are great attractions here in the shape of a prospective canoeing party on the Ten Mile River and Henry Scattergood and possibly Frank Stokes on Seventh and First day, I think that I wont come up until to-morrow week Aug 22nd and stay until Sixth day the 26th.  If this don't suit you I hope you will let me know.  I feel as if I had been off on a great many side trips since this summer and don't feel as if I ought to be the one to go again.  It seems as though the other boys ought to have a turn.  But it looks now as though I were going to be this forward one again.  So I am looking forward to seeing you on the 22nd if all goes well.  It will be fine. 
   
   Esther arrived yesterday and Elizabeth Roberts is staying with us too and as Stodgell Stokes took dinner with us we are quite gay.  Yesterday afternoon Katharine and I walked down to Beaver tail.  It was very nice down there as usual tho. there was no surf.  We sat on the rocks for a while and got back just about seven.  The rest of them took a drive except Harold who played tennis with Margaret Buffum at the club.  Esther Emlen is staying at the Emlens.  She wanted me to send her love to thee and A. Please give the latter much love and keep much for thyself. 
   As ever thy affectionate son
   
   Ernest P.S. I think I will come up on the train leaving Boston at 10.00 & arriving at Littleton at 4.30 If Littleton is not the sta. please let me know.  Esther & Ed send love.

Title: 1884 August 8, Meadow Farm, to Anna

Meadow Farm
   8 Mo 8th/84
   
   My dear little Anna
    
   I have thought of thee very often since thee left us on 4th day morning and shall be glad to hear how thee and Ethel made out on your journey, did she behave well? and was thee very tired when thee got to Montrose? I expect you have had a great many nice plays together, I mean thee, Agnes, Franky and Ellie, not Ethel and thee! I left Germantown the day after thee did and came down  to Maryland with cousins George Emlen and Katy Stokes, Edith came over to Conowingo to meet us, with Robert, and they put the trunk in the front of the carriage and sat on it instead of a seat, cousin George rode up with Horace Stokes, so we all got home nicely, only the roads are very rough and we were well shaken up. Just after dinner today we had a very hard rain and Wistar, Edith and Franky put on thin bathing clothes and ran about out doors until it was nearly over and then they went down to the streamthat crosses our lane and here they found the water so deep they took another bath in that, which they thought was great fun. They have a kitten a little larger than yours but she is nearly all white except her tail which is grey with a white tip; aunt Kate says her name is Pennyroyal but Edith don't like that at all, and Wistar says she ought to be called Tip. We expect Henry home tomorrow and shall be very glad to see him. Cousin George, Ellie and the children are not staying with us now, theyare at Gideon Smiths but the children, all except Sam, are to go home tomorrow. I hope Franky's trumpet did not get bent going up, and that he liked it and the game. I am afraid Aunt Lilly won't care to have him blow the trumpet very near the house, perhaps you take it when you go out rowing on the lake or walking in the woods. I hope thee will get quite strong and fat and have a very good time. Give my love to aunt Lilly and Anna and a great deal to thy self with a kiss from thy aunt Hannah.The Children have all gone to bed or they would send love to thee.Anna Cope Evans
Dimock PO
Susquehanna Co
Penna.

Title: 1902 August 3, Locust Avenue, to sister

[Tear this up when you have read it.  I have answered it.] 
   
   Locust Avenue
   8 Mo 3rd
   
   My dear sister
   
   I am once more at home and quite miss hearing of thy welfare and dear Anna's from Jonathan's letters.  I hope you still continue to gain and enjoy the mountain air.  When I got home last 2nd day, I felt very much used up with the heat & the change in air, but now have become accustomed to it and feel quite well, tho' the amount of moisture in the air makes things damp & sticky.  No doubt thee has heard particulars of E.W. Copes last hours, the close must have been very peaceful, both Ellie & Madgie express their feelings of thankfulness that their mother did not have to endure long confinement and great suffering.  The funeral was small, so many are away, S. Morris and E Allen bore testimony to her character, there was nothing said at the grave but there was such a sweet, quiet feeling as we stood silently there in the evening lights, everything looking so beautiful & peaceful, words did not seem to be needed.  E. Allen said after meeting today to Eleanor & me, that after sheheard of E.W. Copes death she went into her room and such a sweet feeling came over her, she felt it was a forecast of the rest & peace into which Elizabeth Cope had entered.  I rode to the ground with cousin Rebecca Evans, she spoke of cousin Elizabeth, said the letter thee wrote her had been such a particular comfort and help to her, that Rebecca had felt she must write & tell thee but has been rather burdened with calls, so I said I would let thee know about it, I think R sent her love to thee.  Will & Grace have both had mumps, and little Mary, (Alice'sdaughter) has been very sick, she is now gaining down at the Dennis and Grace has been there with them.  Cousin Wm & John Rhoads have gone to T. Brown's camp for their vacation.  I send thee one of Esthers letters as thee may be interested to hear something of the Conference.  It seems to have been a time of spiritual refreshment & uplifting & I hope may prove of use to the building up of the Church.  Eleanor says the spirit of love & unity was very marked, Alfred urged that all [---] and feelings of antagonism between old & young, conservative & progressive should be laidaside, which seemed to be the case.  Alfred seems to feel his mind relieved of the concern, he went back to Bupshire yesterday & is going on to Northfield.  Frank Goodhue also went to Bupshire will spend today there & go on to Brattleboro taking little Mary with him.  Edith Silver came up on 5th day eve, it was very pleasant to see her, she went home yesterday, Betty & little Elizabeth & Sam Mason all went with her.  Betty intends spending a couple of weeks at Swallowfield where she hopes to have a good rest.  Francis Jr is at Bupshire so all the children are cared for.  Sister Eleanor & Tom I believe are going to Bupshire soon & Wistar to the South on business so the house will be deserted  for awhile.  Katy & the childrenpropose coming home on 3rd day.  Frank came on to the funeral but went back last night, I am glad for him to have a visit there.  Emma Edwards fell in her house and broke her hip, she is now very ill not expected to live & her life is not to be [---] under the circumstances.  I had an active time last week attending meetings but got on better than I expected to, tomorrow is Phila Quarterly Mg & 5th day ours, after that I shall take a rest and do a little here at home, as I see many things that need looking after.  I dont know when Esther will come home probably in about a week.  A great deal of love to dear Anna & also for thyself from thy attached sister
   
   Hannah B. Evans
