Date: 1905-09-05
Title: 1905 September 5, Jamestown R.I., to Mother

Jamestown R.I.
   Sept 5th 1905
   
   Dear Mother
   
   I was just about to write to thee, in fact I started a letter last night, getting as far as the date,- when I received thine this morning.  I wrote to Mr. Wood on Sixth day and I suppose he has received it by this time.  It is rather a new experience writing to elderly gentlemen, so I hope I didn't say anything queer. 
   
   Art Brown arrived a week ago last First-day and he and Paul and I had a very good time.  Art is very different from the rest of mankind- he is so very anxious to please and writes letters at such an awful rate.  In one mail he sent eight or nine letters including postals.  Isn't that awful? We jollied him a great deal, Paul and I, too much I am afraid, but he was so good-natured about it that it was hard to know when to stop.  On Third-day, after we had been to tennis, Margaret Mellor asked us all to go out sailing.  I could not go as I had to play in the tennis tournament, but Paul and Art went and had a rather amusing time.  Then she asked us down to a marshmallow roast on Fifth-day night.  We were not very keen about going but nevertheless went and had a very crazy time.  In the first place the crowd did not know each other at all,- some of them were very gay and sporty while others were sedate and sober like myself.  Paul and Art spent most of the time having a marshmallow fight.  Eleanor Haydock was there (this was the one saving feature of the evening) and so I managed to survive.  The consequence of these two invitations wasthat we decided we ought to try to do some thing in return.  Sixth-day was Arts last day so we tried to find out what he wanted to do and finally decided to take a sail in the morning and the Ocean Drive in the afternoon.  Paul decided he would rather play tennis so Art and I went down to the Bay Voyage and asked Margaret Mellor and Eleanor Haydock to go.  I am not especially keen about Margaret Mellorm so she, of course, went, while Eleanor, who was staying at [---] Wharton's, decided she had better return and see whether they had anything for her to do.  We took three large fat magazines and managed to have a pretty good time.  In the afternoon we took the Ocean Drive and nearly died laughing.  The swells were out in force with their footmen and coachmen, and, as
Paul and Art were not much used to them, some of their remarks were very amusing.  They kept speaking to the different ones they passed and then went off in fits of laughter.  We drove back over the hills back of the golf-course, and it certainly was mighty pretty.  Art left that night and went down to Elsie Smith's house-party the next day.  Paul left on Seventh day morning on the nine o'clock train for Boston and went up to the White Mts (as far as Plymouth by the same train as we took).  He is at present at the Flume House, and I should not be so very much surprised if he came over your way some of these days.  His father and mother, Ellis and he are going to stay there for a couple of weeks and Paul told me that his father had been going up there for the last fifty years and had only missed about
ten.  I don't know whether this is true or not but Paul said so!  Alg and the rest of the crowd arrived about an hour after Paul departed this island (You say "departed this life" so I don't see why you should not say "departed this island").  Things began to move [instanter?] and the first thing done was a game of roof-ball in which Art and I defeated Joe and Alg most ignominiously after which we inquired if they could play marbles or any such game!  A little baby-in-the-hat was the result but unfortunately was interrupted by swimming.  On Seventh-day afternoon Jim asked me to race with him in his new half-rater (15 footer).  I accepted with great pleasure and went down to Whitall's to lunch.  Six of the little boats, all exactly alike, started.  There were two of E.D. Morgan's (one sailed by his daughter and the other byhis son) one of the Lippitt's, on of the Wetherill's and one sailed by Miss Grosvenor.  Miss Morgan did not understand the course and started off wrong, but instead of giving up the race she kept her nerve and came chasing after us.  When we rounded the last buoy we were third but were soon passed by another boat.  From that time on Miss Morgan and we did not follow the rest but showed our independence, and we won while she came in second.  I was pretty nearly as glad to see her beat the rest of them as I was that we won.  It was Jim's first victory so I think I must have been his mascot!  When we awoke on First-day morning a good old southeaster was snoring outside but we braved the elements and went to meeting.  Comong home it rained so hard that it went right through my rain coat,and rendered thy little Willie boy quite damp.  Second-day was still fine and wet so we fooled round the house most of the day.  In the morning we read a couple of Kenneth Grahame's "Dream Days" stories, and they certainly are pretty good.  We also read a crazy story by Paul [---] entitled "Love Will Find a Way" and "The Maltese Cat" by Rudyard Kipling.  In the afternoon we tried to take a sail but failed as Father had told the captain he could have a holiday.  However we went up to Whitall's and Greta and Alg and I went out  in a row-boat with a sail in it.  The little craft went sideways pretty nearly as fast as it did forwards so we did not get very far.  The rest of them went out in the rowboat and took a row.  This morning was cloudywhen we got up, but we had decided to go on a picnic over to Gilbert Stuart's so we did and before we had fairly started the sun shone forth in all his grandeur and we had a fine day.  I took Colin along and he behaved very well and seemed to enjoy it though he was pretty tired before we got home.  Altogether we walked about thirteen miles so thee sees we had plenty of exercise.  After lunch we walked back toward Kingston and got a good view of the country.  We had to hustle back to catch the five-thirty boat, but when we got to Saunders town we found we had time enough to eat some ice cream at a fair that was going on behind the hotel.  We walked over from the West Ferry and then Joe, Art, Alg and I took a short swim at Whitall's.  It is getting pretty late, the news and this sheet are rapidly coming to a close and I am tired so good night.With lots of love for both thee and Anna
   I am as ever
   Harold
   
   Please give my love to Miss Richardson.  Katherine and Jacquee say to thank thee very much for thy letter.  If any of you think of it you can remember me to the Leeds and the Hodges.  Tell me about the tournament and give my congratulations to the young Miss Hodge if she won. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Harold Evans:  1886-1977
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1907-07-11
Title: 1907 July 11, Chester, to Grandparents

Chester
   July 11th, 1907
   
   My Dearest Grandparents, 
   
     I have been meaning to write to you for some time, but somehow have not got it done so far, with the exception of one poor postal. 
    
   Well, we have been having the best kind of a time. The voyage was most enjoyable for there were some very jolly people on board and there was lots of deck-room for games. 
   
    Since landing we have had a good deal of rainy weather but we don't seem to mind rain at all, and it has not interfered with our plans except once or twice when we have taken the coach instead of walking in the rain. The cold too, for it has been pretty chilly at times, has been rather a blessing than otherwise for it has made our walks and sightseeing tours all the more enjoyable, and the soft coal fires have been very nice and cheerful. 
    
   Our trip through Devonshire was a great success, though we can scarcely call it a walking trip as we walked only two days instead of four. From London we went straight to Tintagel, arriving there Seventh day evening. The cliffs are perfectly magnificent and we spent most of First day morning admiring them from King Arthur's Castle which is on a beautiful promontory. Finding it was impossible to get our bags to Bude on the Sabbath we took the only course open and drove there,  taking them with us. It was disappointing to miss the walk, but we had the more time at Tintagel of which we were very glad. Bude was rather uninteresting, but the walk from there to Clovelly is certainly charmingly quaint, though the tourists have, I suppose, come in such swarms that it seems as though the place were artificially natural (if you can guess what I mean by that). From Clovelly we went to Ilfracombe by boat and thence we coached to Lynton. Here again we had expected to walk but were again prevented, this time by rain. Lynton and Lynmouth took my fancy very much, and Paul Brown and I had a delightful walk up the Valley of the Lyn to Watermeet (where the East and West Lyn come together)The next day we walked to Porlock in spite of the rain.  We were very fortunate, however, and each time a shower overtook us we were able to reach shelter.  The dark, low-flying clouds with here and there a burst of sunshine rather added to the wildness of Exmoor and it was not hard to imagine that the Doones might almost still be living in some of the wild valleys.  We saw a herd of the wild Exmoor ponies but were not fortunate enough to see any of the red-deer which we were told at Porlock are not at all uncommon.  From Porlock we went to Tintern by train.  It was a rather tedious journey with a good deal of waiting.  The two place are only about thirty miles apart in a straight line, but it took us six hours toreach our destination.
   
   Tintern Abbey is a fine old ruin and takes you back to the Middle Ages, giving the whole town an air of antiquity.  The little chapel on the hill, which they say is older than the abbey was also very interesting and we spent last Seventh-day morning (till train time) wandering around them and taking pictures of them.
   
   We came straight to Chester from Tintern, and I must say I was rather disappointed in it.  The Cathedral is fine but the Walls do not amount to very much it seems to one.  We left here First-day evening and went to Carnarvon where we were very much interested in the Castle which dates I believe from 1256.  At Carnarvon the rain again interfered with our walking, and this time it rained so hard that the coach did not run and we were obliged to go to Bedd-gelert by train.  In some ways Bedd-gelert appeals to me more than most of the places we have seen.  It is such a quiet little town, "far from the madd'ning crowd's ignoble strife," nestled in the heart of the Welsh Mts, that I felt I should like to have more time there.  In the afternoon it stopped raining and we walked down the Pass of Aberglaslyn where they say the cliffs rise eight hundred feet from the road.  It is especially fine now as the recent rains have filled the streams very full and the little brooks tumbling over themselves down the mountainsides are very beautiful.
   
   When we awoke the next morning we were again greeted by the pleasant patter of rain, but we decided to walk to Beltus-y-coed at any rate.  I am very glad we did as it soon stopped raining and it was a very pretty walk.  At Capel-Curig we again saw the king (we had seen him twice in London) this time in plain every-day clothes in an automobile, on his way to Carnarvon.  The people had gathered from far and near and greeted him enthusiastically.  I was interested to her them sing the Welsh national anthem in their native language, which is certainly most unintelligible.  This morning we returned here and this afternoon visited the Cathedral after which Arthur and I went to see Eaton Hall, the Duke of Westminster's place.  As he is now in London we were allowed to go over his house, of course for a shilling, (everything is for a shilling) and were very much interestedto see how he lives.  It is a most magnificent place, "rich but not gaudy" and somehow seems much more "fit" than some of the summer cottages at Newport, though I imagine, as far as money goes that Newport's "cozy little cottages" are quite as grand.  Eaton Park is a beautiful stretch of land about three miles (or more) long and the deer grazing in the open fields were very pretty.
   
   I have now come to the end of my letter, and as it is growing late I must close.  Please give a great deal of love to Uncle Tom and to Aunt C. and Uncle W and their family and keep a great great deal for yourselves
   from your loving grandson
   Harold. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Harold Evans:  1886-1977
Recipient:  Francis Reeve  Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1907-07-11
Title: 1907 July 11, Chester, to Grandparents

Chester
   July 11th, 1907
   
   My Dearest Grandparents, 
   
     I have been meaning to write to you for some time, but somehow have not got it done so far, with the exception of one poor postal. 
    
   Well, we have been having the best kind of a time. The voyage was most enjoyable for there were some very jolly people on board and there was lots of deck-room for games. 
   
    Since landing we have had a good deal of rainy weather but we don't seem to mind rain at all, and it has not interfered with our plans except once or twice when we have taken the coach instead of walking in the rain. The cold too, for it has been pretty chilly at times, has been rather a blessing than otherwise for it has made our walks and sightseeing tours all the more enjoyable, and the soft coal fires have been very nice and cheerful. 
    
   Our trip through Devonshire was a great success, though we can scarcely call it a walking trip as we walked only two days instead of four. From London we went straight to Tintagel, arriving there Seventh day evening. The cliffs are perfectly magnificent and we spent most of First day morning admiring them from King Arthur's Castle which is on a beautiful promontory. Finding it was impossible to get our bags to Bude on the Sabbath we took the only course open and drove there,  taking them with us. It was disappointing to miss the walk, but we had the more time at Tintagel of which we were very glad. Bude was rather uninteresting, but the walk from there to Clovelly is certainly charmingly quaint, though the tourists have, I suppose, come in such swarms that it seems as though the place were artificially natural (if you can guess what I mean by that). From Clovelly we went to Ilfracombe by boat and thence we coached to Lynton. Here again we had expected to walk but were again prevented, this time by rain. Lynton and Lynmouth took my fancy very much, and Paul Brown and I had a delightful walk up the Valley of the Lyn to Watermeet (where the East and West Lyn come together)The next day we walked to Porlock in spite of the rain.  We were very fortunate, however, and each time a shower overtook us we were able to reach shelter.  The dark, low-flying clouds with here and there a burst of sunshine rather added to the wildness of Exmoor and it was not hard to imagine that the Doones might almost still be living in some of the wild valleys.  We saw a herd of the wild Exmoor ponies but were not fortunate enough to see any of the red-deer which we were told at Porlock are not at all uncommon.  From Porlock we went to Tintern by train.  It was a rather tedious journey with a good deal of waiting.  The two place are only about thirty miles apart in a straight line, but it took us six hours toreach our destination.
   
   Tintern Abbey is a fine old ruin and takes you back to the Middle Ages, giving the whole town an air of antiquity.  The little chapel on the hill, which they say is older than the abbey was also very interesting and we spent last Seventh-day morning (till train time) wandering around them and taking pictures of them.
   
   We came straight to Chester from Tintern, and I must say I was rather disappointed in it.  The Cathedral is fine but the Walls do not amount to very much it seems to one.  We left here First-day evening and went to Carnarvon where we were very much interested in the Castle which dates I believe from 1256.  At Carnarvon the rain again interfered with our walking, and this time it rained so hard that the coach did not run and we were obliged to go to Bedd-gelert by train.  In some ways Bedd-gelert appeals to me more than most of the places we have seen.  It is such a quiet little town, "far from the madd'ning crowd's ignoble strife," nestled in the heart of the Welsh Mts, that I felt I should like to have more time there.  In the afternoon it stopped raining and we walked down the Pass of Aberglaslyn where they say the cliffs rise eight hundred feet from the road.  It is especially fine now as the recent rains have filled the streams very full and the little brooks tumbling over themselves down the mountainsides are very beautiful.
   
   When we awoke the next morning we were again greeted by the pleasant patter of rain, but we decided to walk to Beltus-y-coed at any rate.  I am very glad we did as it soon stopped raining and it was a very pretty walk.  At Capel-Curig we again saw the king (we had seen him twice in London) this time in plain every-day clothes in an automobile, on his way to Carnarvon.  The people had gathered from far and near and greeted him enthusiastically.  I was interested to her them sing the Welsh national anthem in their native language, which is certainly most unintelligible.  This morning we returned here and this afternoon visited the Cathedral after which Arthur and I went to see Eaton Hall, the Duke of Westminster's place.  As he is now in London we were allowed to go over his house, of course for a shilling, (everything is for a shilling) and were very much interestedto see how he lives.  It is a most magnificent place, "rich but not gaudy" and somehow seems much more "fit" than some of the summer cottages at Newport, though I imagine, as far as money goes that Newport's "cozy little cottages" are quite as grand.  Eaton Park is a beautiful stretch of land about three miles (or more) long and the deer grazing in the open fields were very pretty.
   
   I have now come to the end of my letter, and as it is growing late I must close.  Please give a great deal of love to Uncle Tom and to Aunt C. and Uncle W and their family and keep a great great deal for yourselves
   from your loving grandson
   Harold.

Title: 1905 June 17, New York, to F., Jamestown

6/17/05
4.15 P.M.
Dear F.
We have been detained all day just off Coney Island on account of the fog.  It has cleared off now & we have just weighed anchor.  I guess we will be at least a day late on the other side
thine E.W.E.Mr Jonathan Evans
Jamestown P.O.
R.I.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Edward W. (Edward Wyatt) Evans:  1882-1976
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1906-09-30
Title: 1906 September 30, Awbury, to Mother

Awbury
   9/30/1906
   
   Dear Mother, 
   
   It certainly does seem much more than two days since we parted from thee and Anna, Miss Richardson and Harold on the ferry wharf at Jamestown. I don't know why the time should seem so long but it is even hard to realize that only last Tuesday father and I were looking out over the Bay blue as could be in the sunlight of a splendid September day as we sat on the deck of the "General" on our way to Wickford. It seemed a great shame to spend so good a day in that stuffy parlor car.
   
   We got through the packing very comfortably, and (although father did say that in the middle of one night he thought we would never be able to get it all done) with very little worry I think. The only thing now is that none of the freight has yet come. We seem to be getting along very nicely on what we have brought.
   
   Since my arrival at home I have been to see two of my doctor friends. Dr. Van Pelt and Dr. Bassett the latter fixed me up without doing anything very much, a lucky escape for me because I haven't been to the dentist for over a year and Dr. Van Pelt is going to make an examination of my eyes with the aid of drops later on in the year. He goes away tomorrow and thought there would hardly be time to do it now. 
   
    Last sixth day afternoon Father and I took a drive. We went up through the Wissahickon, pretty as usual though the foliage hasn't changed much and then stopped at the Philadelphia Cricket Club grounds where I met Alg. And we had some tennis. Father seems pretty well I think and says he has enough to keep him busy in town for some time so perhaps it is just as well the freight hasn't come yet or he might try to do something at once.
    
    Yesterday I went up the  Rancocas with Harold, George and Esther, Eleanor Haydock and Anita Downing. I believe Harold thought some of the members of the house party wouldn't be able to go so did not try to get there to-gether this time. In spite of the fact that it was a threatening day and rained just as we reached the ferry and notwithstanding the fact that Harold and I forgot to eat any lunch we had a very nice time and escaped any wetting. It cleared up before we got back and the moonlight was beautiful. Our only accidents were, I think, that Esther [---] on the [---] of a very irascible old Irish woman in the trolley car who swore around at a great rate and was not at all mollified by Esther's apology. Then Eleanor dropped her umbrellaafter meeting broke up. John and Mary Emlen were there and altho. they tried to get off pretty quickly thee may be sure a lot of us caught them and detained them for a word or two.
   
    Alf. is coming to us for supper which will be very nice. Alg. is now reclining on the sofa reading and sends his love to thee and Anna and Aunt Lilly. Before I close I must ask if thee has heard of the latest engagement--Billy Haines to a Miss Janvier, of Orange, NJ and niece of Thomas Janvier who writes for the magazines somewhat.    
     [---] in Alg's message of love to you all and [---]
   
   They affectionate son
   Edward   

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Recipient:  Francis Algernon Evans:  1878-1946
Date: 1891-09-20
Title: 1891 September 20, Hotel Milan & Pension Anglaise, Venise, to Algie

September twentieth
   ninety-one
   
   My dearest Algie,
   I think thee is awfully good to keep on writing me such perfect letters, and when I got the last one, which was a dandy by the way, I just decided that thee deserved a letter and was going to get one too.  I suppose thee is up at Woodbourne now, having a fine time with Frank.  I can just imagine you getting up at some unearthly hour of the morning and kicking up such a row, so that nobody else can possibly sleep, because you have caught a mouse or some other poor little animal in a figure four.  I bet Aunt Carrie was mad when you waked her up, I remember she always used to be.  Tell Frank I was very much shack[---] to hear of his playing such a wicken trick on Aunt Carrie.  I hope he has been severely lectured for it.  I think he must be getting very wild.  I wish he would write me a letter, but I suppose he has so many other girls to write to he would hardly have time to spare a few minutes to me.  I suppose thee sees from the top of thisletter that we are in Venice at present, and I wish I could change places with thee for a minute or two, and let thee see what it is like.  I am not very good at describing things, as I guess thee knows by this time, if thee has [wadded?] through many of my stupid letters, however, I will do my best.  In the first place it is very beautiful and very different from anything else that I ever saw, or that anybody ever saw I guess.  The Gondolas are perfectly fascinating.  They are all painted black, and are long and narrow, with pointed ends curled up.  That's graphic, isn't it?  Never mind, I am going to draw thee a picture of one.There it is!  Thee sees the man stands at the back and works the boat with one oar.  It is more like paddling than anything else, only the man stands up and throws himself forward on  the oar each time.  It is a very graceful motion, and they do it beautifully feathering the oar each time.  I never saw anything like the way in which they guide the great long boats in and out among each other, and around sharp corners, without any collissions.  It is really wonderful.  Oh!  Algie!  Thee gave me such a scare about Colin.  I really criedwhen I heard he was lost.  and when I read thy next letter and found it was all right, I was too delighted for words.  Why I hardly said good-bye to the old fellow, and to think of not seeing him again nearly broke my heart.  Wasn't it queer his going off that way.  I hope he wont do it again.  We have gotten some lovely letters since I stopped writing and amoung them  was a paper tellingall about the Tennis Tournament, which Papa had sent to me.  I enjoyed reading it immensely, & got very much excited over the descriptions of the different matchs.  I felt almost as if I was there seeing them.  Some of them must have been fine.  I would love to have seen the one between Hovey and young Sears, it must have been awfully exciting.  I am sorry poor Huntington was not in it this year.  I am awfully glad he won the doubles anyway.  Campbell must have played beautifully and you must just have held your breaths all through the matchbetween him and Hobart.  From what I gathered it was intensely exciting, wasn't it?  I can just imagine how sorry you were when Hovey was beaten.  I know how broken hearted I was when Huntington was done up last year.  It must have been something the same, at least it says that Hovey gave out entirely in the end, and evidently was not well, and that was just the way with Huntington.  Now Algie, I must stop.  I guess thee is sick of hearing me talk about the tournament and will not be very sorry.  Good-night old boy!  Take a great big kiss and hug and all the love thee wants from
   Thy very, very loving Sister. P.S. Please give my best love to Agnes, and tell her I am waiting eagerly for a letter from her.  Why don't it come?  Give Ellie my love too, and tell her she is a perfect jewel to write to me, and that I will try and answer it if I can find time.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Date: 1901-03-07
Title: 1901 March 7, to Family

Wednesday.
   
   Dearest Family, 
   
   I have so many things to thank you for & tell you about that I dont know hardly which to begin with.  First, dear Father, thank thee ever so much for all thy trouble in spending me my photos, etc.  I am afraid it was quite a bother, but I was so glad to get them & have enjoyed showing them to the different ones, as well as having them around my room.  And then the flowers!  They were & still are lovely, dearie, & thank thee ever & ever so much.  If you could all see my room now, I should have lots to show you, for I havehad a lot of presents lately!  My bureau is decorated with Fathers daffys & some beautiful roses Miss Wendell sent me last week, with such a swell little note saying she wanted to come & see me if Dr. Stedman would let her & I felt like seeing her.  I told her when I wrote that I certainly did& that Dr. Stedman was quite willing so I expect I may have a visit from her before long.  She has gone or is going away from home just now on her Mother's account.  You know her Father has just died.  Well to go on with my decorations.  Around my mirror ivy is twining (that sounds swell, doesn't it?).  Miss Barnard, one of thr patients have me a plant of it,as she heard me say I wanted one, & I am so pleased with it.  Then on my mantel are some of Father's roses, & the little daisies, & on my table a vase of pussy willows which Mary the waitress brought me, & what do you think? - a little bowl of gold fish!  Miss Stedman brought them to me the other day, &they are so pretty- I think it was very sweet of her, & of them all, & I feel very rich with so many things given to me.  The gold fish are quite an object of interest.  Dr. Shine appeared this morning with a long pole with a line & bent pin dangling from it, & I had to rescue them from his clutches!  He is great fun, & I came up stairslast evening with my side fairly aching from laughter.  Oh, I forgot in my [---] to mention the dear little witch Aunt Lilly sent me.  She brought it in the witch house in Salem, & it is very cute. 
   
   Now what do you think I have been doing this week?  Wouldnt you be surprised to hear I had been to Boston to see some pictures?  It's all true, though.  Last Monday Miss Webb & I went in to the exhibition of "Fair Children" at Copley Hall, & I certainly enjoyed it.  We didnt stay long & I was very much pleased that I didnt get more tired.  Copley Hall is quite near the Back Bay Station so we didnt waste much time getting there.  It is jolly beinglanded so near the Library & the Art Museum & all, for it will be so easy to reach them.  I saw the Brunswick.  It was funny, as we weren't on the street but about 15 minutes all together & met very few people, that one of them should happen to be Bishop Mc[---], & that I should so have the pleasureof speaking to someone I know. 
   
   I have decided to finish this letter up & send it this afternoon, instead of [---] till some other day.  This means I must say good by now, however & leave the rest till another time.  I have some very nice letters to thank you for.  A perfect daisy from thee, Father with lots of news, & a [---] nice one from Alg, with ditto ditto.  I am not sure I ever thanked thee either for the one thee wrote last week, which thee started by saying that thee was sleepy & it would probably suffer.  I dont know how much more brilliant it would have been if thee had been more awake, but I certainly did not find it in the least stupid!I hope thee is [---] all right again, dear old Benjamin.  Thee has my sympathy, though it is rather late for that I fancy, & I hope thee hasn't needed it much all along.  Does thee remember when we had the real measles together? 
   
   And now with a great deal of love to you all Father, Alg, Ted, Ern, [---] & thee too, dearest little Mother, for they will send this to thee, I suppose I am
   your very loving
   Daughter  & Sister

Title: 1907 May 8, Cottage Hotel, to Grandma

Cottage Hotel
May the eighth

Dearest Grandma,
I thought thee might like to see these little pictures, although this place is too beautiful for pictures to do it justice.  You lose the height, & also the color, which is very lovely- partly because of the red soil & partly, I expect, on account of the wonderful lights & shadows.  Yesterday afternoon a shower swept across the water toward us with a rainbow in its midst & theeffect against a dark background of clouds was beautiful.  I know how thee would love & enjoy it all, & I long to send it across to thee.  The streams are very rocky & swift & the fresh delicate [---] of the [---] along their banks makes a beautiful picture.  The primroses are exquisite- so delicate, but I have not seen any violets like ours at Awbury!

Miss R. wants me to give thee her love.  She has thy little pincushion hanging by our mirror & we feel quite decorated!  Please give my dear love to Grandpa & to Uncle Tom & Uncle Hazen & Aunt Margaret.  Also to Aunt Anna & Aunt Carrie if thee should think of it.  With a great deal for thyself, I am thy very loving Anna.Lynton Cottage Hotel,A Devonshire Lane, Nr Lynton.Allerford bridge.Salisbury, The Close, Pretty Corner.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1873-06-08
Title: 1873 June 8, Cozzens West Point Hotel, to mother

Cozzens West Point Hotel
   6mo 8. 1873. 
   
   Knowing you will be glad to know of our whereabouts and our welfare I suggested this afternoon to Chellie that I should write to thee dear mother-  We are now seated on the balcony overlooking the Hudson and enjoying ultimately the lovely view and thoughts of the dear ones left at Germantown-
   
   But to go back to where our sixth day letters left off-  It was then our intention to have gone to Overlook yesterday.  But Chellie woke up with a headache and as the boat left pretty early in the morning we gave it up-  After breakfast Chellie feeling much better we concluded to come as far as this place and spend firtst-day here and go onto Overlook tomorrow.  Which plan we have thus far carried out-  Our ride up the Hudson was perfectly beautiful-  The afternoon being cool with just enough soft flucy clouds floating about to make the hills beautiful in light and shadow.  I have never been to Cozzens before and it certainly is a most delightful place-  The view is much more extended than from Roe's, (and seen when the Highlands are covered with the soft purple light of evening and the western sky filled with a gorgeously colored clouds or when softened by the moonlight pouring over the top of the opposite hills and silvering the waters of the Hudson), it is remarkably beautiful-  I hope you are having a share of the delightfully cool air we are enjoying today and I wish some of you at home and thee especially could be invigorated after all the fatigue both bodily and mentally thee has undergone within the past few weeks with its mountain pureness-
   
   Our plans for tomorrow are to leave here on the steamboat and go to  Rondout and go up the mountain the afternoon reaching the Hotel sometime in the evening-  As to what we have been doing I guess I had better follow Chellies advice and say nothing about it, as under the circumstances we should probably be laughed at whatever we did-  However I will tell thee, for I know it will meet thy approbation that we have kept pretty quiet that Chellie (and myself as to that) might rest-
   
   Chellie is going to add a postscript to this so must leave her some room so with a quiet deal of love to father Lily and all the rest at home I will
   conclude.  With much love I am thy
   affectionate  son
   
   J. Evans It seems hardly worth while, dear mother, to add to Jonathan's epistle for he has told about all there is to tell, but one thing he has not told thee, and that is what good care he has taken of this daughter of thine, how he writes on her as she has never been waited on before, until she tells him that she is afraid he will spoil her by making too much of her; though I hope there is no danger of that, and I don't truly think it will.
   
   We have so enjoyed our visit here, that I think it is just as well probably that we were detained, and spent our First-day here instead of at Overlook, and if we only have such lovely weather at the latter place as we have had here we can desire nothing better. With much love to father Lilly, Hazen, my dear little sisters and all, I remain thy loving daughter
   Rachel C. Evans
   Tell Hazen to write to us, when he has time. A.S. Cope
   
   Francis R. Cope
   No 1 Walnut St
   Philadelphia

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Francis Reeve  Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1873-06-08
Title: 1873 June 8, Cozzens West Point Hotel, to mother

Cozzens West Point Hotel
   6mo 8. 1873. 
   
   Knowing you will be glad to know of our whereabouts and our welfare I suggested this afternoon to Chellie that I should write to thee dear mother-  We are now seated on the balcony overlooking the Hudson and enjoying ultimately the lovely view and thoughts of the dear ones left at Germantown-
   
   But to go back to where our sixth day letters left off-  It was then our intention to have gone to Overlook yesterday.  But Chellie woke up with a headache and as the boat left pretty early in the morning we gave it up-  After breakfast Chellie feeling much better we concluded to come as far as this place and spend firtst-day here and go onto Overlook tomorrow.  Which plan we have thus far carried out-  Our ride up the Hudson was perfectly beautiful-  The afternoon being cool with just enough soft flucy clouds floating about to make the hills beautiful in light and shadow.  I have never been to Cozzens before and it certainly is a most delightful place-  The view is much more extended than from Roe's, (and seen when the Highlands are covered with the soft purple light of evening and the western sky filled with a gorgeously colored clouds or when softened by the moonlight pouring over the top of the opposite hills and silvering the waters of the Hudson), it is remarkably beautiful-  I hope you are having a share of the delightfully cool air we are enjoying today and I wish some of you at home and thee especially could be invigorated after all the fatigue both bodily and mentally thee has undergone within the past few weeks with its mountain pureness-
   
   Our plans for tomorrow are to leave here on the steamboat and go to  Rondout and go up the mountain the afternoon reaching the Hotel sometime in the evening-  As to what we have been doing I guess I had better follow Chellies advice and say nothing about it, as under the circumstances we should probably be laughed at whatever we did-  However I will tell thee, for I know it will meet thy approbation that we have kept pretty quiet that Chellie (and myself as to that) might rest-
   
   Chellie is going to add a postscript to this so must leave her some room so with a quiet deal of love to father Lily and all the rest at home I will
   conclude.  With much love I am thy
   affectionate  son
   
   J. Evans It seems hardly worth while, dear mother, to add to Jonathan's epistle for he has told about all there is to tell, but one thing he has not told thee, and that is what good care he has taken of this daughter of thine, how he writes on her as she has never been waited on before, until she tells him that she is afraid he will spoil her by making too much of her; though I hope there is no danger of that, and I don't truly think it will.
   
   We have so enjoyed our visit here, that I think it is just as well probably that we were detained, and spent our First-day here instead of at Overlook, and if we only have such lovely weather at the latter place as we have had here we can desire nothing better. With much love to father Lilly, Hazen, my dear little sisters and all, I remain thy loving daughter
   Rachel C. Evans
   Tell Hazen to write to us, when he has time. A.S. Cope
   
   Francis R. Cope
   No 1 Walnut St
   Philadelphia
   Pa Cozzens West Point Hotel

Title: 1873 June 8, Cozzens West Point Hotel, to mother

Cozzens West Point Hotel
   6mo 8. 1873. 
   
   Knowing you will be glad to know of our whereabouts and our welfare I suggested this afternoon to Chellie that I should write to thee dear mother-  We are now seated on the balcony overlooking the Hudson and enjoying ultimately the lovely view and thoughts of the dear ones left at Germantown-
   
   But to go back to where our sixth day letters left off-  It was then our intention to have gone to Overlook yesterday.  But Chellie woke up with a headache and as the boat left pretty early in the morning we gave it up-  After breakfast Chellie feeling much better we concluded to come as far as this place and spend firtst-day here and go onto Overlook tomorrow.  Which plan we have thus far carried out-  Our ride up the Hudson was perfectly beautiful-  The afternoon being cool with just enough soft flucy clouds floating about to make the hills beautiful in light and shadow.  I have never been to Cozzens before and it certainly is a most delightful place-  The view is much more extended than from Roe's, (and seen when the Highlands are covered with the soft purple light of evening and the western sky filled with a gorgeously colored clouds or when softened by the moonlight pouring over the top of the opposite hills and silvering the waters of the Hudson), it is remarkably beautiful-  I hope you are having a share of the delightfully cool air we are enjoying today and I wish some of you at home and thee especially could be invigorated after all the fatigue both bodily and mentally thee has undergone within the past few weeks with its mountain pureness-
   
   Our plans for tomorrow are to leave here on the steamboat and go to  Rondout and go up the mountain the afternoon reaching the Hotel sometime in the evening-  As to what we have been doing I guess I had better follow Chellies advice and say nothing about it, as under the circumstances we should probably be laughed at whatever we did-  However I will tell thee, for I know it will meet thy approbation that we have kept pretty quiet that Chellie (and myself as to that) might rest-
   
   Chellie is going to add a postscript to this so must leave her some room so with a quiet deal of love to father Lily and all the rest at home I will
   conclude.  With much love I am thy
   affectionate  son
   
   J. Evans It seems hardly worth while, dear mother, to add to Jonathan's epistle for he has told about all there is to tell, but one thing he has not told thee, and that is what good care he has taken of this daughter of thine, how he writes on her as she has never been waited on before, until she tells him that she is afraid he will spoil her by making too much of her; though I hope there is no danger of that, and I don't truly think it will.
   
   We have so enjoyed our visit here, that I think it is just as well probably that we were detained, and spent our First-day here instead of at Overlook, and if we only have such lovely weather at the latter place as we have had here we can desire nothing better. With much love to father Lilly, Hazen, my dear little sisters and all, I remain thy loving daughter
   Rachel C. Evans
   Tell Hazen to write to us, when he has time. A.S. Cope
   
   Francis R. Cope

Date: 1873-06-10
Title: 1873 June 10, Overlook, to brother

Overlook 6mo 10th 73
   
   My dear brother
   
   It was very nice upon our arrival here yesterday to find thy letter awaiting us, and as it was the first tidings we had from home we were not long in opening it-  We were very glad to learn that you thought of sending cake to the various persons, as in the multitude of other things we never thought of that-  [---] have received our West Point letters, I hope, and know of our doings or rather of our goings up to that time-  The next morning we left at half past eleven in the Daniel Drew.  The weather was pretty warm but when we got on the boat we had a nice breeze-  The Drew maintains her old expectation for speed, and running at the rate of eighteen or twenty miles an hour soon brought us to Rhinebeck which is opposite of Rondout-  We got our dinner on the boat, and were seated at a table with a party of Irish people who amused us very much.  As soon as seated they ordered of one of the waiters "three plates of roast beef" which they continued to order of the various waiters as they passed.  The waiter of our table having gone out after our dinner of course none of the others paid any attention so them and they waited for some time, whereupon they began to talk in a very funny way-  When our waiter came they asked him how soon they were going to get their dinner.  He said they had not ordered yet whereupon they waxed quite pathetic and said they could not tell who they ordered it of but they had ordered of three or four and they all looked just alike- when we left they were comforting themselves with roast beef but were grumbling that they were missing all the beautiful scenery-  When wereached Rhinebeck we found the boat "The Lark" (peculiar name is it not for a boat but we thought in our case rather [---] for this occasion as we felt inclined for going on "a Lark") waiting and were soon landed at Rondout-  Here we had to walk about a square to the depot, depot did I say, no, I dont mean that, but to the street corner from which the cars start-  Thee would have been amused to see the manner of conducting the railroad-  The told us the cars started from that corner and the train would be ready in a few minutes-  Some time after the time for starting we saw the engine coming from down toward a wharf and were not a little surprised to see a horse car coming towards us from the opposite direction upon the same track.  It occurred to us we would just as leave be where we were as in either- but when they got close to=gether they stopped and did not attempt pass upon the same trackChellie asked out Conductor if they used the same track promiscously and he relieved our minds by saying "no"-  After we left Kingston the car was pretty full and some of the people were real characters.  The front seat in our car was occupied by a real old fashioned farmer and his wife .  Presently a man came though the car and stopped and spoke to him very hard and then it seemed all of sudden to dawn upon him who he was and he hollared ? out "How'd you do my hearty" and pulled him down on to the seat with his wife and himself-  The poor little woman was almost crished and the whole thing was very amusing in the reality, more so I am afriad than I have made it seem.  Afterward the two men went to another seat and the farmer sat with his arm around the other mans neck in a most affectionate manner-  As Chellieis writing home very fully and as [---] is rather scarce, I am afraid I shall [repent?] so well bid thee farewell-  Please give my love to father and mother Lilly and my two little sisters and with a large share for thyself I am thy attached bro
   JE. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Francis Hazen Cope:  1859-1909
Date: 1873-07-26
Title: 1873 July 26, London, to brother

London 7 mo 26th 73
   
   Dear brother
   
   I have been intending for some time to write thee a letter but since our arrival in London there has been so much to do and so little time for writing that I have dont next to nothing in that line-  And now what shall I tell thee about for between Chellie and Tom both of whom have written I feel as if there was nothing left for me to say-  On fifth day last we went to the Zoological Garden and I do wish thee could have been along, we were very much amused as well as interested-
   
   The first thing that struck us in particular was the storks.  With their long legs (only one of which they stand upon at a time) their necks which they draw well down between their hunched up shoulders, their grave or rather I may say melancholy expression gives them a ridiculous appearance and when they gyrate or give a great jump as they sometimes do with no apparent object it was perfectly [inesistable]-  The monkey house also proved a place of no small amusement-  as we visited it about 11 o'clock I suppose it was the hour for the old monkies to be taking their morning naps however that may be a number of them were asleep-  One old ape amused us very much he was taking a nap upon one of the bars and apparently the last idea that had entered his head beforefalling asleep was that it would be desirable to scratch his head so he would raise his arm until his hand nearly reached his head and then down it would drop, this he repeated over and over again-  In another cage there were three asleep upon one of the roosts with their arms around each other0  In other cages there were the usual pranks and absurdities going on which monkies indulge in. 
   
   The keeper of the laughing hyenas was very obliging and gave us the opportunity of hearing "the very remarkable noise" which the song informs us the animal makes every fifteen minutes"- 
   
   In the snake house every thing seemed to be in a very quiet state most of the snakes being coiled up  under their blankets-  One or two of the Boa Constrictors were tied up in sundry knots and laid out on the tree to sun-  We saw quite as much of them as we care to snakes not being our favorites-  We next visited the Hippopotomi and Rhinoceros.  The former are the most ungainly looking animals I ever saw.  There is a little one only eight months old and altho' so young its body so much longer than an ox.  The keeper brought some grass to feed them and made them open their mouths-  But I will stop for I am afraid I have said too much already about animals-  I think thee would be very amused at some of the servants we see here the absurd way they are dressed-  Not unfrequently5
   we see footmen with drab coats with brass buttons, crimson breeches, white stockings, low shoes and with either white wigs or powdered hair-
     
   The other day I saw an old fashioned coach by an old fashioned coach I mean one driven in the style of olden time four horses with a guard who had a long horn which he was blowing as they drove through the streets.  I believe it is owned and driven by a young lord who having plenty of money and a fancy for that sort of thing amuses himself in this way-  He has men to attend to all the money matters and to the passengers while he just drives-  Yesterdat we went out to the Crystal Palace and spent most of the day there-  It is a wonderful place so much to see-  It is something like our Sanitary Fair was, if thee remembers that, only on a larger scale.  We went around until we were very tired and then we dined.  After dinner we continued out investigations visiting amongst other things the "[---] animals"- These are large creatures made to represent what they suppose some of the extinct species were like-  They are placed about among the trees and on the edge of one of the lakes in natural positions but it struck us there was a good deal of humbling about it-  One sixth day evening last Tom, Rueben, & I went to Parliament-  We couldnot get seats for Chellie and H as they told us they were often engaged a week ahead in the ladies gallery-  We had rather an amusing experience-  We reached the hall about five minutes of nine and were told we would have to wait for a few minutes as the  House was just being made up.  We were seated with a number of others upon benches in the Hall and after waiting for sometime the first was told it might go in and then the second-  We passed up a long flight of stairs and went into a little toom where our tickets (which Tom had purchased from a man in the afternoon) were examined we were in a bitter trepidation while this was going on as we did not know whether they were good for anything or not, however they passed us- As soon as weentered the gallery the janitor came to us and pointed us to seats into which we sank he then told us we must park our hats under the seats, then he turned to another man and told him he must not raise up to see, then he made another man put his umbrella upon the seat behind him not allowing him to hold it in his hand so if he had ordered us to pull off our shoes I should not have been surprised- We heard three or four speeches upon the Army bill and were very much amused-  Every once in a while the speakers would get rather muddled and there would come a succession of aws and grunts and hesitations which was absurd-  And then there were occasional mysterious sounds which at9
   last we discovered was applause in the shape of hear! hear!-  How they made such sounds I dont know it was a kind of mingled mumble and rattle it put me in mind of the child that swallowed the bead necklace-  We stayed until nearly half past eleven and then concluded we had got nearly two shillings worth and would go. 
   
   This morning we went to Westminster meeting and were not a little surprised upon going into see Chas & Anna Sharples and their daughter-  After meeting we had quite a talk with them and learn that they are going to sail on the second of next mo:-  They have visited Vienna Switzerland France &c [---] trip ideed-  We also met Wm Bradford (the Artist) who is spending the summer in London) he was very kind and invited us to come to his studio-  Bevan Braithwaite was at meeting and pressed us to come and see him when we return a very warm hearted Friend.  We expect to leave tomorrow for the north-  Tell mother we are all pretty well-  Please give a great deal of love to father and mother and each one of brothers & sisters.  Tell them none must feel slighted when letters are not addressed to them individually for all our letters are intended for all.  Please give love to them at Uncle Johns & Toms also at School Lane.  Chellie joins me in message of love.  Please excuse this writing as I am using a quill pen which writes better on this paper than a steel one-  With much love I am thy affectionate brother
   JEvans  First Steamer

Frances R Cope
No1 Walnut St
Philadelphia
Pennsylvania
U.S.A.

Francis Hazen Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1873-08-05
Title: 1873 August 5, Lowwood Hotel, Lake Windermere, to mother

Lowwoord Hotel
   Lake Windermere
   
   My dear Mother
   
   Altho I have written to father and Tom has also written a long letter so that I am afraid they will be as uninteresting as "twice-told tales" yet I am going to send thee a few lines in a scrappy way for they own edification. We do so enjoy having Tom with us and he seems to be not only enjoying himself but improving--when he first joined us at London he looked very badly not having recovered from the sea voyage I suppose he was very pale and thin, but has been gaining pretty steadily so that now his cheeks have quite a color and he looks fuller in the face than I ever remember to have see him--I do not think his leg troubles him much, as he says it does not hurt him, and he walks about a good deal--we shall try to keep him from doing too much--
   
   I think Chellie seems stronger than when we left home, as she is certainly able to walk more and does not get as fatigued as she would at home--
   
   She has gained some flesh but is not what you would call stout yet. For a day or two her throat has been a little swelled, but I shall get her some [tannin?] or a gargle and I think that will relieve her. I have written [---] particularly in regard to health as I know thee would like to know. The weather except a few days in London has been cool so that we have generally not been able to wear our [thin?] clothes. Chellie has not found her waterproof dress to wear for traveling and now that we are going north shawls are called into acquisition. Evening 9.05. I wish thee could look in upon us this evening and see how snugly we are fixed, seated around a centre table in our cosey little parlor with four candles burning upon on the table and at this point Tom came in and proposed we should take a row upon the lake in the moonlight and as it was a lovely evening we went and now have just returned--I did wish for some of the girls form Awbury for it was so perfectly beautiful that even the [staid manied?] people almost grew sentimental--The lake was just rippled by the gentle wind and the moon was hanging over the western mountains throwing a silvered path across the water, and on the shores we could dimly see the outlines of Wray Castle and the pretty residences with which the shores are studded, and in which the lights were brightly shining. The rain which continued most of the day stopped toward evening and although the roads were rather muddy we started out for exercise and had a pleasant walk of three miles toward Bowness. [---] tt has cleared we expect to start early tomorrowmorning for Keswick. As this letter is for thy information on little points in travels I will tell thee of our general hours. We find it suits us best not to dine later than three or half past and so whether we take our dinner at the hold or elsewhere try to have it at that hour. We breakfast generally at half past eight and then take tea at half past seven or eight and spend our evening in our sitting room either writing home or in journals or in talking over the scenes of the day and planning for the morrow. In traveling we generally manage to have a car to ourselves and Reuben looks after the baggage and Tom eitherkeeps him or assists Chellie and H, while I am buying our tickets-  We get along very nicely indeed-  In the last letters thee said that some of them at home thought "thee was writing too much", I hope thee will not stay thy hand on that account, but only as thy strength will warrant, for I can assure thee every detail of home news is very interesting-  We think of you very very often and I hope the time may come when thee will enjoy the beauties which we are visiting, but altho the present is so full of enjoyment the future (when we shall return to your midst) looks very pleasant.
   
   The little books dear mother, which thee gave us just before leaving are our constant compantions in our travels and it is pleasant to think as we read them morning and evening that thee too has them and altho the time may be different yet we read them the same day-  I enclose a little bunch of wild flowers which I picked while visiting Swarthmore part of them I gathered at the meeting house and part from the Hall, I wish they were better preserved but they were pressed under difficulties in my pocketbook and I had to arrange them for pressing as we walked.  I send them thinking thee might like a little memento of Swarthmore-  I am afraid this will prove a scrappy letter and rather uninteresting for it is madeup of little nothings-  Hannah desires her love to thee and the rest of the Awbury family-  When thee sees them at School Lane please give them my love also a great deal to all at home and at Uncle Toms and Uncle John's, Chellie has retired or would join me in these messages-  With much love I am thy loving son
   J.Evans.
   P.S.  I dont know if any mention has been made of how Reuben is and as his father and mother were rather anxious about him when we left, will thee tell them that I think he is much better, but would improve faster if he took more rest especially in writing his letters and journal as he often sets up late and is up early-  

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1874-07-20
Title: 1874 July 20, Greenbrier White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia, to Mother

7th mo 20th 1874
   
   My dear Mother
   
   I hope this evening that no one has written home for a day or two and know thee will like to hear often so I will send a few lines this evening before the mail closes.  We have had a very warm day the thermometer standing at 83 [degrees] a good deal of the time and there has been very little air stirring-  This morning Mary, Alexis Alf, John Hazen and Henry made an excursion to the top of Kate's Mountain.  They had an early breakfast and got off about 8 oclock and did not get back until nearly one.  They had a pretty rough scramble and some how did not get to the right place and so missed the view-  I was glad they went as they thought it paid and I am afraid they find it rather monotonous-  The life is a very lazy one and while it is so warm in the middle of the day there is very little to be done in the way of excercize, with any comfort-  I think Alf seems better and the water suits him but Hazen is not able to drink the sulphur water and does not seemed to have impreoved as much as I hoped he would-  I do not mean that he is sick but he still looks pale.  He seems bright and much less nervous than when he left home and I hope he will improve more after his return-  Lily has bathed twice (yesterday and today) having her bath at about 100 [degrees] and says she thinks it suited her for after lying down she felt refreshed and better-  but of course it is too soon for there to be much change-  She stayed in the first day only about 2 minutes and today 5 so thee sees she is feeling her way.
   
   This afternoon Lily and Alexis took a drive-  I have been disappointed 3
   in the air here it is not bracing at all-  and as the mountains are all around us often we get but little breeze-
   
   The daily routine of our life here is not thrilling-  We rise about half past seven and it is often half past eight before we get assembled at the breakfast table-  After breakfast (which we rarely get through until quarter past nine) we walk around the grounds for a little while visiting the spring, Japanese Store, Post Office &c and then spend the time until 11 o'ck (when we bathe) either in reading, writing or talking-.  After the bath we put in the time as best we may until dinner time 2 O'clk.  After dinner we set out under the trees upon the lawn or upon our piazza and read aloud or talk until tea time and after tea we generally take a walk and then sit in the parlor until bedtime "and thus our days go on, go on"  The boys vary it occasionally by a little walk upon their own account or by going swimming or sometimes we roll a game of ten pins-  I have gone very much into details and I have no doubt father and Tom will laugh at the letter and groan over such a life (so do I) but I thought these little nothings would interest thee and moreover there is very little else to tell-  Our movements in the future are very uncertain and as yet we cannot say when we shall home or whether some will remain- as soon as some conclusion is arrived at we will let you know.  Please give a great deal of love to father Tom Anna & Carrie in which Chellie would join me if she knew I was writing but I am in the gentlemans writing room and she does not know of it-  With much love for thyself I am thy loving son J. Evans

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1857-1897
Date: 1875-11-28
Title: 1875 November 28, Church Lane, to brother

Church Lane 11 mo 28. 75
   
   My dear brother
   
   Having received a message from thee through a letter to Tom, and not being able to plead sickness as a reason for not writing, I am going to send thee a greeting-  Well we are not going to see thee until next spring, it seems a long time, and we were all of us not a little disappointed when the news came.  We were counting the days until the time when thee was to sail and beginning to speculate upon the probable length of the passage, when suddenly all our hopes were dashed-  I was going to say I would not flatter thee by telling thee what lamentations there were on the part of some of us, but I think it does no one harm to know how much they are loved and missed at home, on the contrary I think  to a young man it does good, tending perhaps to keep him out of some things by which he might otherwise be tempted-  Now for the scrape of news I can glean up-  Last fourth day Tom and I drove over to Haverford to bring away thy [chattels?]-  We arranged to go on third day, but on that day we had a regular old fashioned Nor'easter and it poured most of the day-  The next morning about nine oclock Tommy appeared at our house in the [---] with Lady and Eric (Harry having been laid up some time with sore feet) after getting some more warm wraps for it had cleared off quite cold when we started-  The roads were in a pretty miserable state of muddiness and as we undertook to go by the Lancaster road we almost stuck so to speak-  However we reached the College about half past eleven, and finding the students in recitation we went up stairs and explored-  We found all thy things had been moved out of thy room and were locked up in another closet of which the matron hadkey so she had to be hunted up-  We packed most of the books and some other things in a drawer which Tommy and I carried down to the front door Tommy saying it was "like carrying down a little coffin"-  We donated to Frank Haines a bottle of eye wash, a little bottle of carbolic acid and a few other valuables?-  Thus were the last rites performed-  We packed the books in the bottom of the wagon, and put the precious articles, around with we supposed tender associations ( clung , (a broken fan with names thereon &c) between folds of the down cover-  We drove home to dinner reaching Awbury about quarter of four-  We had a good laugh at Tom - one of the objects over was to bring home the hanging book shelf and we forgot all about it, and came home without it - which rankled in Tommy's breast-  By the way talking of Haverford does thee know they have raised a sufficient amount of money to enable them to build, and Samuel Alsop Jr told me it was decided to go ahead-  The day we werethere was the day before Thanksgiving day, and as I waited upstairs in the entry while Tom was hunting up the Matron I was amused at two of the students, one was in the hall down stairs and as the other came out I suppose from recitation - he announced the fact that they were going to have Turkey for dinner, whereupon there went up such a howl of rejoicing as almost upset me-  We hoped while at Haverford to have had time to have called upon Margaret Yarnall, but we spent to much time at Any Marys that we had not time.  I suppose you have heard that Ellis and M Yarnall are boarding at [---] during the Winter.  I am glad to hear they are vert comfortably fixed-  It seems an out of the way kind of place for them, a good deal away from most of the latter's friends, I should think she would long to have her daughter with her.  I do feel for them very much-  First day 12/5.  A week, my dear Afred, has passed since I commenced this letter yet it is not finished.5
   During the week we have been pained from day to day to hear of Uncle Alfred's increasing illness.  As early as the beginning of the week Dr Wister said he seemed to be failing, and on second day they telegraphed for James, they received an answer the next morning only saying "will come" and that is all they have heard.  Up to second day Uncle Alfred has been able to get over into the library, this he has accomplished with the aid of a man who has been staying with him at night for a number of weeks- assisting him to dress and undress.  One second day he was so much weaker that he had to remain in bed- and since then he has been gradually growing weaker and weaker, until yesterday afternoon about three o'clock he quietly passed away-  He does not seem to have had any acute disease-  His appetite almost entirely gave out, and he gradually weakened - with the exception of a pain in one of his lungs I do not think he has suffered any-  Since last first day Uncle Tom and John E Carter have been sitting up with him half of alternate nights, the nurse sitting up the other half.  Lilly and Edward have been staying over at Fairfield for the last day or two-  Yesterday morning having heard how he was the evening before Father, Uncle Tom and Aunt Lizzie went over there, the Doctor came soon after they arrived and said he did not think he could live but a few minutes.  They went up into his room (except Father who had gone on to town) and sat there for two hours awaiting the close- he seemed entirely conscious but lay perfectly still excepting once when he passed his hand through his hair as his custom was and once he put his hand under his head-  They went to dinner and a few minutes after dinner was over he passed away, no one but Aunt Rebecca, Lily and Edward being present.  Just at the close, there was a short spasm and then to him all was joy and peace and rest-  What a wonderful and glorious change it must be for him after a long life of ill health and suffering during which I suppose he could never have said he really felt well, to awake inthat Holy City none of whose inhabitants can say I sick and where "there shall be no more death, neither sorrow nor crying, neither shall there be ay more pain: for the former things are passed away"-  Aunt Caroline seems to feel it very much, not having seen for some time except a few days ago, when hearing how sick he was she went out to see him, but ut was thought best for her not to go in the room or let him see her so she looked at him through the door-  The only remarks I have heard that Uncle Alfred made (though he probably said more which I have not heard) were that some days ago he told J.E.C. "that it made very little difference which way it ended" meaning his sickness-  To E. Allen who visited home within a few days, and as she was leaving said she supposed she should never see him on earth again and that she did not doubt but that the change would be a glorious one to him he replied "I have been forced to feel very quiet and peaceful"  I think those were the words he used-  The funeral is to be next third day at two oclock.  It will be a great trial I doubt not to James to find all over when hearrives - 
   
   Last sixth day Uncle Tom commenced his winter readings and it was said to have been a very interesting occasion-  Neither Chellie nor I was able to get there-  There is a good deal of stir in our City now over the meetings of Moody & Sankey-  They have fitted up the old freight depot of the Pennsylvania RR so that it will seat about eleven thousand and meetings are being held I think twice on week days and three times on first days - they are largely attended and from accounts some of them must be impressive.  I hope they may do good-
   
   I suppose Mother in her weekly letter told you that Hazen had sprained his ancle, turned it under him as he was rushing out of the side door to catch the train-  Tommy seems to think it was a mercy he sprained it as it will probably save him from something worse if he will only take warning.  He had to hold it up for nearly a week.  However he is about again now tho he says it feels weak.  Aunt Lizzie Brown is still down at Atlantic City where she has been for some 9
   weeks and from accounts does not seem much better.  Aunt Fanny went down last third day taking with her a maid to stay with aunt Lizzie-  I am afraid her sickness is a pretty serious one and not to be gotten over in a hurry.  The rest of them at Grandfathers are pretty well now-  Grandfather has had a cold but is better-  Aunt Martha Leeds I suppose you have heard is at the Frankford Asylum, and from last accounts was not much better in her mind and was also very sick with [---] in her head-  I dont know whether thee has heard or not that the new building at Haverford is to go up next year they having got enough subscribed to warrant them in commencing so Samuel Alsop Jr told me.
   
   Lillies letter from [---] arrived on sixth day last and we were very glad to hear of your being so comfortably and pleasantly fixed-  Please give a great deal of love to both Lilly and Alexis and tell them I often think of them both with much affection and truly it does seem a long long time since we parted with them.  I do hope the stay will do you all a great deal of good-  I am afraid you have missed some of our letters Chell and I both misunderstood and have been directing our letters to Brown-Shipley & Co Liverpool - and I am afraid they have not forwarded them-  I wrote not long ago a letter to thee and one to Lilly and Alexis enclosing a photograph of the baby to each-  If they have never come to hand I will send you another-  Harry has at last made up his mind to return to Minneapolis - he expects to start next fourth day.  I hope he will have a more prosperous time the coming year than he has had the last-  Upon looking over the forepart of this letter which I wrote a week ago I find I have mentioned about the building at Haverford in that so thee will please excuse my telling it again-  I dont feel like rewriting the letter-  Chell sends her love to you all in which I join and wish you "a merry Christmas" and "a happy New Year"-  I remain thy
   loving brother
   J Evans

Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1883-06-20
Title: 1883 June 20, Philadelphia, to wife

Philadelphia, 6 mo. 20 1883
   
   My Darling wife. Altho I sent thee a postal from NY this AM for I am going to post a few lines the afternoon. I reached Philada about half past one and found the weather very different from Newport. The thermo. hanging by my side as I write standing at between 85° and 86° and the air somehow feels lifeless. I came away in such a hurry at the last that I forgot several things. Tell Hazen we need not have hurried if we had know for I waited nearly an hour before the boat arrived. I carried of the Post office key which I enclose herewith. I think sister Ann has my pocket knife which I lent her yesterday morning and either Algie or Edward has my [rule?]. These last I do not need and you can keep them until I come on or until some one is coming this way. I forgot to tell thee that I wish that bucket of solution of [copperas?] poured down the kitchen sink and then lit John put about two double handfuls more of it into a bucket of water and let it stand for about a week and then pour that down and put about a pailful down any week. I wish thee would call and see Truman Pickham some evening as you come home from a ride and ask him about the well and the drains I went to see him but he was not at home and he is at work except after six in the evening or between 12 and 1 at noon. I had not time to call again. If the cow you have does not prove satisfactory get Hazen to see what Ward will rent his cow for he did not tell me definitely and if he would take 4.00 per week I would take her if this one does not prove satisfactory.I do hope my dearest thee will take things easy. I am afraid the care will be so much that thee will not gain much and please do remember that it is my special wish that thee shall either have extra help or have the washing done out or anything that will [unnerve?] thee. I wish I could be on hand to help and relieve this. I do hope you are all well and are getting on comfortably. If I was only sure that the well and the drains were all right, I should feel much more happy. I hope they are and have done all I know how. I fully intended to have brought on two of those [Appolinans?] bottles full of the well water for Reuben Haines to have examined. I wish theewould send them on by the first opportunity. Please give my love to the two Annas and Hazen and with lots for the dear children and thy own dear self. I shall try not to worry about you but leave you in the care of our loving Heavenly Father who I feel has been and is very good to us and to whom we should give our love and thanks. Here are kisses for the [---]. 
   Kiss Anna
   Kiss Algie
   Kiss Edward
   
   Farwell dearest from thy loving husband, 
   J Evans.

Date: 1883-07-01
Title: 1883 July 1, Awbury, to wife

Awbury 7 mo1. 83
   
   My very dear wife, 
   
   I am writing at home before meeting so as to take the letter with us to meeting and mail it. This is a very cool morning the thermo at 6.40 standing at 56° and although it has grown considerably warmer since yet it is still quite cool. Oh! my dear how I wish I could see you I do love you so. I feel quite anxious to hear how you are but suppose I shall hear nothing now until I see Tom--I had indulged a vain hope that somehow I might spend the fourth with you but there is so much to do at the office that I could not leave just at that time but I am hoping I can get off so as to come on the latter part of the week, but don't count on it too certainly but I will if I anyhow can. They want me to spend the fourth down in Maryland and I think I shall although it will hardly pay as I shall not be able to go down until the 5 o'clock train third day evening or early fifth day morning. I enclose a letter I received from Kate this morning it came enclosed in one to Madgie. I do hope you are getting along comfortably and are all well--give my love to the family. I paid John's wife the $25 yesterday. Thee can tell him that they were all well.Mother had a postal yesterday from aunt E. Brown she is still at the [Rigi?] something and expects to stay there all summer she seemed in good spirits. I am ashamed to say that I have not been over to call upon the Newhalls yet but from reports they are very much pleased with the place. There mother seems stronger and sleeps better. I am afraid dearest my letters are very stupid- writing every day there is not much chance for a collection of news but then thee knows each one contains any quantity of love and sympathy and dearestI feel that we are growing nearer and dearer to each other all the time and it is such a comfort. Margaret is still at Awbury but expects to go home tomorrow-morning. The carriage has just come up so I must bring this to a sudden pull up.
   
   With dear love to the children and lots for thyself I am dearest they loving husband
   
   J Evans

Title: 1806 February 8 to Henry Cope, Westown, PA

Philada 2nd mo 8th [1806]

Dear Henry

I receivd   thy letter, and am Pleasd to hear that there is a day set   apart for letter writing as I hope we shall hear oftener   from you, as writing is next to seing and talking with you,   to tell you (for I include Frances) that I love you, and   long to see you, would be like a tale twice told,   

your Cousin H D wrote from New Castle the 5th of the   2d moth that he was just setting of and expected to be at   sea in 48 hours, was much pleasd with the Captain, they were   detaind 2 weeks by the Ice, He seemd to go of in pretty good   sperits, as he went with the approbation of his Friends, I   have the pleasure to inform the that he appeard to be in an   improving way, I hope he will be preferred and kept in the   road that leads to peace

I am glad to hear that the   is contented, and willing to stay and get all the   instruction the can, I hope thee will get through all the   branches so as to come home next Summerthe river is froze over and I saw a number of people on it   as I return[e]d from Meeting this morning

Arther has   not got into any Buiseness yet, & is Desir[ou]s of paying   you a viset If he can get a Horse.

your Father &   mother is well, Caroline & allfred very lively, mother is   well of for help—Cousin Lydia is with me still and Sends her   love to the and Francis as does [Catherine] except of a   large Portion From your loveing grandmother

Rachel   Drinker

mary’s Father and Mother & Brother have been   commited to jail on suspion of Murder how it will go with   them we can’t tell now I think I have told you all the news   good and badHenry Cope
Westown
give my love to Friend 
Sharpless

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Mary Stokes:  1825-1847
Recipient:  Elizabeth W. (Elizabeth Stokes Waln) Cope:  1780-1852
