Title: 1839 March 6, to Elizabeth W. Cope, Philadelphia

3d moth 6th 1839

My Dear aunt

I expect this   will be the last letter I shall write to thee this session   as the time is drawing near when we shall go home.  we are   now reviewing and it is not so hard as I expected it would   be  we have to be very industrious [about] our studies as   some of them are very hard particularly the history and I am   very much afraid I shall fail in that at examination as the   greater part of it I have not learned for I have not been in   that class, all the session.  Thomas Kite’s wife is here   spending a day or two and her daughter also.  I suppose thee   has heard of the little boy who has been so ill here he was   taken with the measles and that layed the foundation for the   consumption and after suffering for a long time he was taken   away at three o clock in the morning of the first of spring    we had no school on six or seventh day but we all went to   our school rooms and red our bibles and on seventh day   morning we were taken into see his corpse and he was buried on seventh day afternoon   his name was Nathan Comstock and he was an orphan he lived   in Lockport New York  he has a brother and sister here and   his sister is a lovely girl but I know very little about his   brother.  Benjamin Sharpless was here to thee funeral and he   asked me if I had ever seen him at Tommy Cope’s and I told   him no., but I have often heard of him.  I am looking for   uncle Samuel to come and see me as he has been away so long   and I think he might come to see me this session
Aunt   Lydia is not at all well she has a very bad cold and a good   deal of pain in that lump on her face and she keep her bed   the greater part of the day but she is rathe better at   present than she has been lately  I think she would of been   better if she had not of gone down to supper last night   through the cold entry.  I have some things to write for and   I do not think I shall have any more time to write to thee.    Cousin L sends her respects to all of you. but I send my   love to all be lieve me as ever thy affectionate   niece

Mary Stokes JrThomas P Cope 
For Elizabeth W Cope
No 272 Spruce St 
Philadelphia

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas S. Brown:  b. 1828
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1839-11-10
Title: 1839 January 10, West Haverford, to Anna S. Brown, Philadelphia

1 moth 10. 5 day 1839
Dear sister

I hope you are      all well, My cold is quite well.  Freind Mary Davis sends      her love to Mother.  I am glad to hear that Aunt Ann is so      much better and, I hope that she will continue so, and I am      glad also that thee is getting well enough to walk out  How      is Aunt Hannah and uncle Thos, and Harry  Where is Williams      slipers  I think ought to be done.  It snowed last night      there a little.  The green house is nearly finished but the      plants are not yet aranged. we have had some pretty good      sleding.  It is tirsome work to write a letter, Dan B Smith      give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they      are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as      thoes that thee expects to attend  he showes us so many      pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to      have a kiss from Fanny  I will send her one down below  I      expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to  I      [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and      part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou  I remain thy aff brother
Thos S      Brown
Kiss


Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them.  He has beguiled some of the hours of his confinement      in doors, by reading “Rollo’s vacation” to me – & we have      found it quite entertaining –  I think it arrived just at      the right moment –  So much for Thomas –.  now for Willie –      with whom I am becoming better acquaintedas the ice is now broken – & he frequently pays us a visit      in our parlor –  He tells me – he is more comfortable than      formerly – & that the cause of his unhappiness is re-moved –      what this cause was, I do not know – but he looks so      pleasant & happy that I am inclined to believe he is not      depressed by any great weight of troubles –  They are very      different boys but both have found means to interest me      warmly for them – & I think I shall not soon cease to love      them – Tom is sitting by me begging me to proceed – but the      end of my paper warns me that I may already have tired thee      – therefore will take the hint after desiring my love to thy      mother – and assuring thee of
the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.



WestHaverford
Jan 11th.
 
Jeremiah Brown 
Philadelphia
For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning      and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee      for some time  I am glad to see that thee is so much better      than thee was when I last heard from thee  I was astonished      to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea      that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts      that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much.       Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in      this letter  I was disapointed as well as thyself for I      expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we      all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company      staid out a half an hour  I hope when thee gets perfectly      well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one      of thee boys  I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with      her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet      in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete      baby house with old black [---] amongst them  I hope by the      next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly      well  I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the      holy land in two volumes by an American  I found it very      interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a      botany for William but I never received it and I should like      to know wether you sent it or not  Tom is very much pleased      with his present  I have no more room sister so I will haft      to bid adieu at present  thine [ever] – W.A. BrownI thought I would haft to stop but Elisabeth Davis proposed      to me to cross it  I have accordingly done it  The snow as      not yet left us and we had a little more on 4th day evening      last  How is mother and father I have not heard from them      for sometime somehow or other thee always leaves them out in      thy letters  Aunt Rachel is better [she] says  I should like      to know what is the matter with her for her diseas seems      very changeble  dont thee think dear sister that it is      singular that I never write to my Aunts and uncles for most      other boys do  I have never yet attempted it however I      suppose it is just as well that I should not but I think I      would like to write to Grandmother or father some of [these]      days but I dont know I dont suppose that I should hardly      know how as I never done such a thing.  My cold has now got      very well indeed at least It is all gone now.  I now often      go into Friend Davis’s parlour and I found it very pleasent       I am at present here and spend many a happ evening I expect      that they will be surprised to find three difrent hands in      this letter and I am rather inclined to think that it was      worth the postage.  I will now haft to end in good      earnest
Thy [Aff] Brother William A. Brown1 moth 10. 5 day 1839
Dear sister

I hope you are      all well, My cold is quite well.  Freind Mary Davis sends      her love to Mother.  I am glad to hear that Aunt Ann is so      much better and, I hope that she will continue so, and I am      glad also that thee is getting well enough to walk out  How      is Aunt Hannah and uncle Thos, and Harry  Where is Williams      slipers  I think ought to be done.  It snowed last night      there a little.  The green house is nearly finished but the      plants are not yet aranged. we have had some pretty good      sleding.  It is tirsome work to write a letter, Dan B Smith      give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they      are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as      thoes that thee expects to attend  he showes us so many      pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to      have a kiss from Fanny  I will send her one down below  I      expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to  I      [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and      part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou  I remain thy aff brother
Thos S      Brown
Kiss


Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them.  He has beguiled some of the hours of his confinement      in doors, by reading “Rollo’s vacation” to me – & we have      found it quite entertaining –  I think it arrived just at      the right moment –  So much for Thomas –.  now for Willie –      with whom I am becoming better acquaintedas the ice is now broken – & he frequently pays us a visit      in our parlor –  He tells me – he is more comfortable than      formerly – & that the cause of his unhappiness is re-moved –      what this cause was, I do not know – but he looks so      pleasant & happy that I am inclined to believe he is not      depressed by any great weight of troubles –  They are very      different boys but both have found means to interest me      warmly for them – & I think I shall not soon cease to love      them – Tom is sitting by me begging me to proceed – but the      end of my paper warns me that I may already have tired thee      – therefore will take the hint after desiring my love to thy      mother – and assuring thee of
the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.



WestHaverford
Jan 11th.
 
Jeremiah Brown 
Philadelphia
For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning      and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee      for some time  I am glad to see that thee is so much better      than thee was when I last heard from thee  I was astonished      to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea      that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts      that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much.       Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in      this letter  I was disapointed as well as thyself for I      expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we      all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company      staid out a half an hour  I hope when thee gets perfectly      well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one      of thee boys  I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with      her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet      in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete      baby house with old black [---] amongst them  I hope by the      next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly      well  I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the      holy land in two volumes by an American  I found it very      interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a      botany for William but I never received it and I should like      to know wether you sent it or not  Tom is very much pleased      with his present  I have no more room sister so I will haft      to bid adieu at present  thine [ever] – W.A. BrownI thought I would haft to stop but Elisabeth Davis proposed      to me to cross it  I have accordingly done it  The snow as      not yet left us and we had a little more on 4th day evening      last  How is mother and father I have not heard from them      for sometime somehow or other thee always leaves them out in      thy letters  Aunt Rachel is better [she] says  I should like      to know what is the matter with her for her diseas seems      very changeble  dont thee think dear sister that it is      singular that I never write to my Aunts and uncles for most      other boys do  I have never yet attempted it however I      suppose it is just as well that I should not but I think I      would like to write to Grandmother or father some of [these]      days but I dont know I dont suppose that I should hardly      know how as I never done such a thing.  My cold has now got      very well indeed at least It is all gone now.  I now often      go into Friend Davis’s parlour and I found it very pleasent       I am at present here and spend many a happ evening I expect      that they will be surprised to find three difrent hands in      this letter and I am rather inclined to think that it was      worth the postage.  I will now haft to end in good      earnest
Thy [Aff] Brother William A. Brown1 moth 10. 5 day 1839
Dear sister

I hope you are      all well, My cold is quite well.  Freind Mary Davis sends      her love to Mother.  I am glad to hear that Aunt Ann is so      much better and, I hope that she will continue so, and I am      glad also that thee is getting well enough to walk out  How      is Aunt Hannah and uncle Thos, and Harry  Where is Williams      slipers  I think ought to be done.  It snowed last night      there a little.  The green house is nearly finished but the      plants are not yet aranged. we have had some pretty good      sleding.  It is tirsome work to write a letter, Dan B Smith      give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they      are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as      thoes that thee expects to attend  he showes us so many      pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to      have a kiss from Fanny  I will send her one down below  I      expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to  I      [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and      part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou  I remain thy aff brother
Thos S      Brown
Kiss


Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them.  He has beguiled some of the hours of his confinement      in doors, by reading “Rollo’s vacation” to me – & we have      found it quite entertaining –  I think it arrived just at      the right moment –  So much for Thomas –.  now for Willie –      with whom I am becoming better acquaintedas the ice is now broken – & he frequently pays us a visit      in our parlor –  He tells me – he is more comfortable than      formerly – & that the cause of his unhappiness is re-moved –      what this cause was, I do not know – but he looks so      pleasant & happy that I am inclined to believe he is not      depressed by any great weight of troubles –  They are very      different boys but both have found means to interest me      warmly for them – & I think I shall not soon cease to love      them – Tom is sitting by me begging me to proceed – but the      end of my paper warns me that I may already have tired thee      – therefore will take the hint after desiring my love to thy      mother – and assuring thee of
the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.

Jeremiah Brown 
Philadelphia
For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning      and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee      for some time  I am glad to see that thee is so much better      than thee was when I last heard from thee  I was astonished      to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea      that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts      that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much.       Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in      this letter  I was disapointed as well as thyself for I      expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we      all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company      staid out a half an hour  I hope when thee gets perfectly      well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one      of thee boys  I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with      her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet      in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete      baby house with old black [---] amongst them  I hope by the      next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly      well  I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the      holy land in two volumes by an American  I found it very      interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a      botany for William but I never received it and I should like      to know wether you sent it or not  Tom is very much pleased      with his present  I have no more room sister so I will haft      to bid adieu at present  thine [ever] – W.A. My cold has now got      very well indeed at least It is all gone now.  I now often      go into Friend Davis’s parlour and I found it very pleasent       I am at present here and spend many a happ evening I expect      that they will be surprised to find three difrent hands in      this letter and I am rather inclined to think that it was      worth the postage.  I will now haft to end in good      earnest
Thy [Aff] Brother William A. Brown

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William A.  Brown:  b. 1824
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1839-11-10
Title: 1839 January 10, West Haverford, to Anna S. Brown, Philadelphia

1 moth 10. 5 day 1839
Dear sister

I hope you are      all well, My cold is quite well.  Freind Mary Davis sends      her love to Mother.  I am glad to hear that Aunt Ann is so      much better and, I hope that she will continue so, and I am      glad also that thee is getting well enough to walk out  How      is Aunt Hannah and uncle Thos, and Harry  Where is Williams      slipers  I think ought to be done.  It snowed last night      there a little.  The green house is nearly finished but the      plants are not yet aranged. we have had some pretty good      sleding.  It is tirsome work to write a letter, Dan B Smith      give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they      are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as      thoes that thee expects to attend  he showes us so many      pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to      have a kiss from Fanny  I will send her one down below  I      expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to  I      [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and      part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou  I remain thy aff brother
Thos S      Brown
Kiss


Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them.  He has beguiled some of the hours of his confinement      in doors, by reading “Rollo’s vacation” to me – & we have      found it quite entertaining –  I think it arrived just at      the right moment –  So much for Thomas –.  now for Willie –      with whom I am becoming better acquaintedas the ice is now broken – & he frequently pays us a visit      in our parlor –  He tells me – he is more comfortable than      formerly – & that the cause of his unhappiness is re-moved –      what this cause was, I do not know – but he looks so      pleasant & happy that I am inclined to believe he is not      depressed by any great weight of troubles –  They are very      different boys but both have found means to interest me      warmly for them – & I think I shall not soon cease to love      them – Tom is sitting by me begging me to proceed – but the      end of my paper warns me that I may already have tired thee      – therefore will take the hint after desiring my love to thy      mother – and assuring thee of
the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.



WestHaverford
Jan 11th.
 
Jeremiah Brown 
Philadelphia
For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning      and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee      for some time  I am glad to see that thee is so much better      than thee was when I last heard from thee  I was astonished      to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea      that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts      that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much.       Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in      this letter  I was disapointed as well as thyself for I      expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we      all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company      staid out a half an hour  I hope when thee gets perfectly      well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one      of thee boys  I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with      her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet      in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete      baby house with old black [---] amongst them  I hope by the      next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly      well  I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the      holy land in two volumes by an American  I found it very      interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a      botany for William but I never received it and I should like      to know wether you sent it or not  Tom is very much pleased      with his present  I have no more room sister so I will haft      to bid adieu at present  thine [ever] – W.A. BrownI thought I would haft to stop but Elisabeth Davis proposed      to me to cross it  I have accordingly done it  The snow as      not yet left us and we had a little more on 4th day evening      last  How is mother and father I have not heard from them      for sometime somehow or other thee always leaves them out in      thy letters  Aunt Rachel is better [she] says  I should like      to know what is the matter with her for her diseas seems      very changeble  dont thee think dear sister that it is      singular that I never write to my Aunts and uncles for most      other boys do  I have never yet attempted it however I      suppose it is just as well that I should not but I think I      would like to write to Grandmother or father some of [these]      days but I dont know I dont suppose that I should hardly      know how as I never done such a thing.  My cold has now got      very well indeed at least It is all gone now.  I now often      go into Friend Davis’s parlour and I found it very pleasent       I am at present here and spend many a happ evening I expect      that they will be surprised to find three difrent hands in      this letter and I am rather inclined to think that it was      worth the postage.  I will now haft to end in good      earnest

Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them. the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.

For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning      and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee      for some time  I am glad to see that thee is so much better      than thee was when I last heard from thee  I was astonished      to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea      that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts      that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much.       Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in      this letter  I was disapointed as well as thyself for I      expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we      all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company      staid out a half an hour  I hope when thee gets perfectly      well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one      of thee boys  I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with      her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet      in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete      baby house with old black [---] amongst them  I hope by the      next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly      well  I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the      holy land in two volumes by an American  I found it very      interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a      botany for William but I never received it and I should like      to know wether you sent it or not  Tom is very much pleased      with his present  I have no more room sister so I will haft      to bid adieu at present  thine [ever] – W.A. BrownI thought I would haft to stop but Elisabeth Davis proposed      to me to cross it  I have accordingly done it  The snow as      not yet left us and we had a little more on 4th day evening      last  How is mother and father I have not heard from them      for sometime somehow or other thee always leaves them out in      thy letters  Aunt Rachel is better [she] says  I should like      to know what is the matter with her for her diseas seems      very changeble  dont thee think dear sister that it is      singular that I never write to my Aunts and uncles for most      other boys do  I have never yet attempted it however I      suppose it is just as well that I should not but I think I      would like to write to Grandmother or father some of [these]      days but I dont know I dont suppose that I should hardly      know how as I never done such a thing.  My cold has now got      very well indeed at least It is all gone now.  I now often      go into Friend Davis’s parlour and I found it very pleasent       I am at present here and spend many a happ evening I expect      that they will be surprised to find three difrent hands in      this letter and I am rather inclined to think that it was      worth the postage.  I will now haft to end in good      earnest
Thy [Aff] Brother William A. Brown

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Elizabeth H.  Farnum:  1814-1898?
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1839-11-10
Title: 1839 January 10, West Haverford, to Anna S. Brown, Philadelphia

1 moth 10. 5 day 1839
Dear sister

I hope you are      all well, My cold is quite well.  Freind Mary Davis sends      her love to Mother.  I am glad to hear that Aunt Ann is so      much better and, I hope that she will continue so, and I am      glad also that thee is getting well enough to walk out  How      is Aunt Hannah and uncle Thos, and Harry  Where is Williams      slipers  I think ought to be done.  It snowed last night      there a little.  The green house is nearly finished but the      plants are not yet aranged. we have had some pretty good      sleding.  It is tirsome work to write a letter, Dan B Smith      give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they      are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as      thoes that thee expects to attend  he showes us so many      pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to      have a kiss from Fanny  I will send her one down below  I      expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to  I      [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and      part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou  I remain thy aff brother
Thos S      Brown
Kiss


Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them.  He has beguiled some of the hours of his confinement      in doors, by reading “Rollo’s vacation” to me – & we have      found it quite entertaining –  I think it arrived just at      the right moment –  So much for Thomas –.  now for Willie –      with whom I am becoming better acquaintedas the ice is now broken – & he frequently pays us a visit      in our parlor –  He tells me – he is more comfortable than      formerly – & that the cause of his unhappiness is re-moved –      what this cause was, I do not know – but he looks so      pleasant & happy that I am inclined to believe he is not      depressed by any great weight of troubles –  They are very      different boys but both have found means to interest me      warmly for them – & I think I shall not soon cease to love      them – Tom is sitting by me begging me to proceed – but the      end of my paper warns me that I may already have tired thee      – therefore will take the hint after desiring my love to thy      mother – and assuring thee of
the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.



WestHaverford
Jan 11th.
 
Jeremiah Brown 
Philadelphia
For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning      and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee      for some time  I am glad to see that thee is so much better      than thee was when I last heard from thee  I was astonished      to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea      that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts      that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much.       Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in      this letter  I was disapointed as well as thyself for I      expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we      all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company      staid out a half an hour  I hope when thee gets perfectly      well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one      of thee boys  I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with      her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet      in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete      baby house with old black [---] amongst them  I hope by the      next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly      well  I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the      holy land in two volumes by an American  I found it very      interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a      botany for William but I never received it and I should like      to know wether you sent it or not  Tom is very much pleased      with his present  I have no more room sister so I will haft      to bid adieu at present  thine [ever] – W.A. BrownI thought I would haft to stop but Elisabeth Davis proposed      to me to cross it  I have accordingly done it  The snow as      not yet left us and we had a little more on 4th day evening      last  How is mother and father I have not heard from them      for sometime somehow or other thee always leaves them out in      thy letters  Aunt Rachel is better [she] says  I should like      to know what is the matter with her for her diseas seems      very changeble  dont thee think dear sister that it is      singular that I never write to my Aunts and uncles for most      other boys do  I have never yet attempted it however I      suppose it is just as well that I should not but I think I      would like to write to Grandmother or father some of [these]      days but I dont know I dont suppose that I should hardly      know how as I never done such a thing.  My cold has now got      very well indeed at least It is all gone now.  I now often      go into Friend Davis’s parlour and I found it very pleasent       I am at present here and spend many a happ evening I expect      that they will be surprised to find three difrent hands in      this letter and I am rather inclined to think that it was      worth the postage.  I will now haft to end in good      earnest
Thy [Aff] Brother William A. Brown1 moth 10. 5 day 1839

It is tirsome work to write a letter, Dan B Smith      give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they      are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as      thoes that thee expects to attend  he showes us so many      pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to      have a kiss from Fanny  I will send her one down below  I      expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to  I      [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and      part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou  I remain thy aff brother

Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them. the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Rachel Drinker
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1806-06-19
Title: 1806 June 19 to Henry and Francis, Weston

6th mo 19th 1806.
Dear Henry & Francis
I have been to   meeting, cald at your house, after it broke up your dear   mother handed me a letter from Francis,  she was so kind as   to send me Henrys last letter, where I was affection[ate]ly   rememberd and expressing a desire that I should not forget   you no be asurd I never Shall while I retain my sences, I   have Had a great deal of trouble since I saw you  I have   seen a dear loving Daughter go before me,.  to enjoy the   fruits of a well Spent life, I Continue with poor Uncle and   Johnny, thay request me not to leave them, we have had   pleasent accounts of the Conduct of of your & Cousins, and   are in dayly expectation of seeing them, poor lads they will   be much affected when thay come, they will not be likely to   hear of the chang that has taken place since they left us   till they arive.  I want very much to see you, I hope you   will come and pay us a visit, I am still Favoured with   Health, and that you may enjoy that Blessing is the Desire   of your affectinate Grandmother
Rachel DrinkerDear Cousins

Our dear Grandmother is Kind enough to   permit me to add a few lines to her letter–  I wish it was   in my power to communicate to you something that would   afford pleasure.  But alas!  I have lived to see the   melancholy period that death has seperated from me one of   the best of mothers, whose affection I believe I possessed;   and that I loved her with sincere affection, affords me no   small share of consolation–  She suffered much during her   illness, but such was her Christian fortitude that she never   discovered the least impatience, and constantly maintained   her usual cheerful serenity of mind, which was her   characteristic through a life of trials.  It was painful to   see her suffer so much bodily pain, but infinitly more so to   see her breath her last, a[l]though she suffered not the   pangs of death, but passed from this terrestrial world to   one where peace, happiness and pleasure reign triumphantly;   and where she now enjoys the blissful harvest of a spotless   and well spent life–  Such has been the immutable decree of   heaven to deprive me of an affectionate Mother and you an   affectionate Aunt– We are still blest with having our dear   Grandmother to cheer us–  She enjoysher usual health, which I hope she may enjoy for years to   come–
The last letter we received from Arthur states that   he and Cousin Henry are both well, and expect to leave the   West Indies very shortly; we of course expect them   daily–
Uncle is at present in good health, and I hope   will long continue so; here I must close this short epistle   and hope that I will see you before long –  I remain your   affectionate
cousin
John D Thomas6 mo. 19th 1806
Henry Cope
Weston6th mo 19th 1806.
Dear Henry & Francis
I have been to   meeting, cald at your house, after it broke up your dear   mother handed me a letter from Francis,  she was so kind as   to send me Henrys last letter, where I was affection[ate]ly   rememberd and expressing a desire that I should not forget   you no be asurd I never Shall while I retain my sences, I   have Had a great deal of trouble since I saw you  I have   seen a dear loving Daughter go before me,.  to enjoy the   fruits of a well Spent life, I Continue with poor Uncle and   Johnny, thay request me not to leave them, we have had   pleasent accounts of the Conduct of of your & Cousins, and   are in dayly expectation of seeing them, poor lads they will   be much affected when thay come, they will not be likely to   hear of the chang that has taken place since they left us   till they arive.  I want very much to see you, I hope you   will come and pay us a visit, I am still Favoured with   Health, and that you may enjoy that Blessing is the Desire   of your affectinate Grandmother
Rachel DrinkerDear Cousins

Our dear Grandmother is Kind enough to   permit me to add a few lines to her letter–  I wish it was   in my power to communicate to you something that would   afford pleasure.  But alas!  I have lived to see the   melancholy period that death has seperated from me one of   the best of mothers, whose affection I believe I possessed;   and that I loved her with sincere affection, affords me no   small share of consolation–  She suffered much during her   illness, but such was her Christian fortitude that she never   discovered the least impatience, and constantly maintained   her usual cheerful serenity of mind, which was her   characteristic through a life of trials.  It was painful to   see her suffer so much bodily pain, but infinitly more so to   see her breath her last, a[l]though she suffered not the   pangs of death, but passed from this terrestrial world to   one where peace, happiness and pleasure reign triumphantly;   and where she now enjoys the blissful harvest of a spotless   and well spent life–  Such has been the immutable decree of   heaven to deprive me of an affectionate Mother and you an   affectionate Aunt– We are still blest with having our dear   Grandmother to cheer us–  She enjoysher usual health, which I hope she may enjoy for years to   come–
The last letter we received from Arthur states that   he and Cousin Henry are both well, and expect to leave the   West Indies very shortly; we of course expect them   daily–
Uncle is at present in good health, and I hope   will long continue so; here I must close this short epistle   and hope that I will see you before long –  I remain your   affectionate
cousin
John D Thomas6 mo. 19th 1806
Henry Cope
Weston

Rachel DrinkerDear Cousins

Our dear Grandmother is Kind enough to   permit me to add a few lines to her letter–  I wish it was   in my power to communicate to you something that would   afford pleasure.  But alas!  I have lived to see the   melancholy period that death has seperated from me one of   the best of mothers, whose affection I believe I possessed;   and that I loved her with sincere affection, affords me no   small share of consolation–  She suffered much during her   illness, but such was her Christian fortitude that she never   discovered the least impatience, and constantly maintained   her usual cheerful serenity of mind, which was her   characteristic through a life of trials.  It was painful to   see her suffer so much bodily pain, but infinitly more so to   see her breath her last, a[l]though she suffered not the   pangs of death, but passed from this terrestrial world to   one where peace, happiness and pleasure reign triumphantly;   and where she now enjoys the blissful harvest of a spotless   and well spent life–  Such has been the immutable decree of   heaven to deprive me of an affectionate Mother and you an   affectionate Aunt– We are still blest with having our dear   Grandmother to cheer us–  She enjoysher usual health, which I hope she may enjoy for years to   come–
The last letter we received from Arthur states that   he and Cousin Henry are both well, and expect to leave the   West Indies very shortly; we of course expect them   daily–
Uncle is at present in good health, and I hope   will long continue so; here I must close this short epistle   and hope that I will see you before long –  I remain your   affectionate
cousin
John D Thomas6 mo. 19th 1806
Henry Cope
Weston

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Sibylla T. Morris:  b. 1826
Recipient:  Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth) Cope:  1840-1944
Date: 1905-08-14
Title: 1905 August 14, Bridgewater Cottage, to My very dear friends

Bridgewater Cottage
8.14. ’05 —

My very dear   friends –
I was very glad to hear again of you,– tho’   sorry to learn of your semi-invalidism,– in which I can   fully sympathise,– but I am overwhelmed – by your generous   check – which was so thoughtful – & so useful! –  I cannot   express myself with sufficient gratitude, & can only say   that it is accepted in the same loving spirit in which it   was sent, & for the inherited friendship of our re-spective parents & grandparents.–
– Did you ever know, or   hear among your family traditions of the strong intimacy   there was between yr. grandfather,– Thomas P. Cope – the   shipping merchant,– & my grandfather – Philip Price the   Superintendent of Westtown School, nearly 100 yrs. ago?–  My   grandfather had a large family of 10 children to educate &   c.– & when his eldest son,– Dr. Wm. Price rec.d his   diploma,– yr. grandfather gave him a double position on one   of his ships going to China,– those of Dr. & also of   supercargo,– & he made 2 trips,– each for 3 yrs,–  It was a   great event in the P. family
I am glad you are having a   pleasant summer in your quiet retreat.–  I am preaching "the   simple life"– more as weknew it in our quiet country homes, or in the simplicity of   Friends.–  I enjoy social life in a quiet way with good   neighbors & a few friends calling in the evenings – but the   constant round of it all day & every day is wearing.
–   What halcyon days we used to have at Woodbourne,– and my   children have no knowledge of it &, only the older ones –   have a bare recollection of dear Cousin Sarah, with none at   all of your lovely Mother.–  What a sunbeam she was!–  I   have some lovely memories to look back upon, but I don’t   seem to acquire in my old age the gentle loveliness of so   many of our old Friends, tho’ I am frequently called upon to   say with a dear old cousin of my Mother’s – Priscilla   Townsend,– (whowas the Mother of the Dentist Elisha K. Townsend who   founded the Philada. Dental College–) "Let me number my   blessings!"–  And another saying of an old Irish neighbor we   had – who had many trials & sorrows – but would end up her   stories with – "but sure, Welcome be the Will of the   Lord!"–
– But I am too reminiscent for young people, &   this letter is terribly egotistic, so I will stop but your   kindness & dear Annette’s letter have brought back many   delightful memories.–  The years are rapidly rolling by, & I   have now entered my eightieth. –
Good bye,– with dear   love to you both & many thanks I remain
your old   friend
S. T. Morris –

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan E. (Jonathan Evans) Rhoads:  1830-1914

Title: 1910 November 1, Wilmington, Delaware, to Jonathan Evans

Jonathan E. Rhoads
908 Franklin Street

Jonathan E   Rhoads
11 mo 1.1910

Wilmington, Delaware
11 mo   1 1910

My Dear Cousin Jonathan Evans

Thine of   yesterday is at hand--I am not sorry I wrote to thee as thy   answer assures me there was misapprehension on my part as to   thy expression. We had spoken of the discipline at Westtown   and of the laying aside of rules there and at Haverford   which were difficult of enforcement and some of them   unnecessary to proper order. Afterwards, if I recollect   right, thee expressed thyself in favor of rescinding all   rules, the word discipline being used; which I supposed   referred to that of our Y.Mg. when I now think the   discipline at Westtown may have been in thy mind.
I am   glad to be corrected, and to have thy opinion of the Revised   Discipline as given in thy letter.--I greatly long
to have unity of belief and effort in upholding essential   Truth and its principles by Friends, and increased   recognition of the intent of our Lord and Master when He   taught His followers the deep meaning of "The Kingdom of   Heaven."
Some few practices of the most substantial   Friends I am willing to leave to individual conscience for   adoption, if their rejection does not contravene any plainly   stated law or principle in the New Testament.  Thus in   dress, simplicity is conformity to the law of Christianity;   and truthfulness is necessary to speech when addressing   others.

With love thy cousin
Jona. E Rhoads


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Recipient:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Date: 1863-12-11
Title: 1863 December 11, Awbury, to Cousin Clementine

Awbury Dec. 11th 1863

Here’s a nice stormy 6th day   afternoon at last, My dear Cousin Clementine, in which I can   find a little time to write to thee, I expect thee thinks I   am very naughty indeed not to have found a little time   before, but if I had thee here I could so completly convince   thee in half an hour, that thee would entirely agree with   me, that it is a moral impossibility ever to get any time to   write letters.  We have learned a great many things   Angelica, since last I had the pleasure of conversing with   thee, (I wonder how many months it has been) Yardley as well   as Mary Haines has become ourinstructor, other-wise intelligently he is teaching us to   ride, thee don’t know what fun it is, we have splendid   times,  Yardley & one of his daughters always goes, &   sometimes Tom or Reuben, & Cousin Lillie, Jammy or Casper, &   very rarely Tom Stokes, however I believe Yardly don’t   approve of him as Rachel & he behaved badly the other   afternoon riding too far ahead for Yardley’s notions, so he   came posting over in the evening & held a private   conversation on the piazza with father, to R’s extreme   disgust & indignation.  I suppose thee has heard of our   charities over at the meeting house, we have got up some   contraband meetings for the benefitof the “Young Friends Association” they have a man to cut   out the things, & then they are sent round to the various   meetings to be made up.  We have a branch concern here every   3rd day evening & have a great deal of fun, especialy after   Yardley & his daughters leave, we get tired of our work by   that time, & have a little music “both vocal &   instrumental”.  
But the last & greatest fun, that we   have now, is skatting, Oh! Cousin Clem, I do wish thee would   come over, yesterday afternoon was grand, I haven’t enjoyed   any thing so much for ages, the ice was delightfully smooth,   & my skates elegantly sharp, & they glided over so swiftly,   as to give metwo or three pretty hard tumbles.  Some of the gentlemen   rolled splendidly, the Sun in particular he was one of the   best skaters on the dam.  Compositions are as horrid as   ever, imagin my having to write one last night in addition   to all my other lessons after I got home, with my head full   of every thing else; I missed thy help very much, does thee   remember how thee used to give me ideas, last winter.  O!    Cousin Clem I wish thee would come back again.  We had the   nicest walk last 1st day afternoon that ever was, we went   all round by Harpers & Butlers dams thee knows, a whole   party of us Stokes & Awbury folks in addition toMiss A.C. Smith, I said we had a delightful walk, & so we   had as far as the walk went, but I believe I wasn’t in a   very good mood to enjoy, however I am not going to tell thee   about my mopy fits, I never have them now, ever since I had   that talk with thee at Newport I determined to have nothing   more to do with them; & I was dreadfully provoked at myself   for indulging last first-day afternoon, I beleive a   conversation I had in the morning rather effected my   spirits.  But how foolish I am!  thee’ll think I haven’t   improved a bit if I go on rattling about myself this way.    But CousinClementine thee will have to come over here right-soon, or I   shall begin to think we are never to see thee again.  
I   was very much obliged for thy photograph, though I must say   I can’t flatter thee on it thee way Uncle Harry did, whats   thee think he said about it?  he was looking over my album,   & when he came to it he said to me “thats a fancy piece aint   it”.  I laughed & told him who it was, & he said “it was so   pretty it ought to be put in the stores in Chestnut St.”    wasn’t that complementary now?  But I don’t think it is near   pretty enough to be put in Chestnut St. nor do I think it at   all does thee justice, & I hope thee won’tforget thee has promised me one of those really pretty ones.   But now I geuss thee is beginning to be quite tired of my   nonsense so I will close; hoping thee will answer this very   soon in person

ever thy affec. little Lily

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan S. Reeve:  1833-1866
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1865-11-18
Title: 1865 November 18, Locust Shade, to Ruthanna Cope


Locust Shade 11.18.1865

My Dear Annie

That   thy very interesting letter has thus long remained   unanswered has been that I have not very often thought of   thee, as I trust thee knowst- and I was much disappointed to   find that I had gone to Germantown a week too soon to see   thee. This to be sure I had but a few hours to stay there,   still I had hoped to spend part of them with thee.- I hope   dear Annie thee is better for thy sojourn at Newport. For I   know the return home without thy father’s welcome must have   been very painful.- even with all the love & kindness of thy   brothers & 
sisters and with the strong consolation thee has of   believing that thy dear parents are forever “where adieus   and farewells are a sound unknown”.- May we realize more &   more the infinite importance of eternal things.- For myself   I seem to glide on day after day occupied with a round of   duties, but in a kind of lethargy in regard to spiritual   things Certainly without that earnest striving which is   commanded & which we may believe is essential to Christian   progress- But confession of our faults avails little without   amendment & I should not burden the with mine. 
We have   parted with our Lizzie to go to Select school. She boards   with John and Sallie Hilles who very kindly offered to take   her- & so far likes her school very much better
than any she ever attended before. I loved that school very   much & whenever I think of it, always see, in my minds eye,-   thee & Julia & Clemmy coming in - &  going to the cloak   room.-
We miss Lizzie exceedingly & I am ready to wonder   how we shall do without her for six months.- She is to come   home after every monthly examination & I long for the time   to arrive.-
Has Clemmy been much with thee lately? I have   scarcely heard of her since her return from Baltimore or of   Julia for a long time- I saw some of George’s pictures   favorably noted in an “art criticism” the other day, at   least I supposed they were his. George B. Wood is his name,   isnt it?
How sad it is that Mary Ann Morris
continued so poorly- tho indeed it is not to be wondered at.   Mary wrote me a few days ago- that she was still much   afflicted with sleeplessness - &  was very nervous. The   former must be most distressing & very [wearing] upon the   constitution.- I hope cousin Eliza will be better for living   in Germantown as the trips out there have done her so much   good. It is to be hoped their walls will not tumble down   before they get moved tho [-----] does not think it would be   son fine &  exciting. – I think their house will be a good   way from you will it not? I am hoping dear Annie to spend a   few days with thee before a very great while- tho I cannot   now see when it will be – probably not for some weeks.- Tho   I do want exceedingly to see thee & as I said before fully   expected to before this. Please write to me when thee feels   like it.- Father  mother have gone out to teaor would said their love- Mine please to thy sister Lizzie &   a large share for thy self from they truly attached   
Susie-


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas) Cope:  1850-1883
Date: 1865-05-10
Title: 1865 May 10, Baltimore, to Tom

Baltimore 5. 10th. 65

Dear Tom,
Thee must excuse   me for having been so long answering thy letter, & not think   that I did not care about it, for I was right pleased that   thee wrote to me, & I have said to myself ever so many times   [said] that I must write to that “Little “Toms”—  but thee   sees now I have got to be a school mistress, I have so many   cares that I cant always do[o] what I’d like & then I have   had a good many letters to write to different people &   knowing that thee saw the home ones & knew all about me, I   took it the easier.
I have now been “school”mom=’en” long   enough to get a prety good idea of the business – & my idea   of it is, thatits a good deal easier to be a scholar than I teacher, – so   thee can remember that for thy comfort when thee has a hard   lesson to learn.  To teach a school of troublesome boys I   shd. say was one of the hardest businesses’s that cld. well   be got up..  The girls are bad enough, but when it comes to   boys – – they’re the [---] of man.  I have in my school   about 35 boys & a dozen girls between the ages of 6 & 15 —   The girls I have but little trouble with, but the little   boys are regular monkeys.  No sooner is my back turned than   they begin their discussions of wh. they have a variety —    Its the hardest thing in the world to keep them still, & if   they get a good chance there’s not one of them that is too   good to get up & takea dance or a fight or any other such little amusement that   they think will set the school in an uproar.+  [+ Throwing   spit balls is a very bad habit they have – also dancing “Ham   fat”]  My punishments are various.  Sometimes I shake the   culprit & if that wont do, tie em up hand & foot & put em in   the corner — wh. is a very troublesome operation to me.  But   it seems as if nothing wld. beat it into their heads that   school is any thing but a place to play in.  
Most of   them can read a little some not at all, & like “Busy” – they   must always spell girl gril and dirt – drit –.  It seems as   if it came natural —  One of their best accomplishments is   singing wh. we sometimes let them do in school.  My children   know “my”native country thee” & the colored “Wolunteer”— wh.   they shout out with great effect. But I guess I’ve told thee   enough about the darkies  We’ll talk a little abt.the whites.  How comes on work at Haverford?  By the way thy   hand writing is coming on so well, that when I got thy   letter I thot. it was Busy’s himself, it was so good.    Have’nt you a boy named Allen Thomas,?  I expect he’s a nice   fellow & has two very nice brothers whom I met last eveng.    There are [---] pleasant frieds here & I do not often have a   chance to feel lonely or home sick.  How does Prof. Cope &   his botany lectures?  I am going to try to write him a note   to send in this & consequently must say farewell or shall   not have time.  Thee can take this down home with thee next   7th day & tell ‘em it’s all they’ll get this week.— as they   dont deserve any for some time.  Give my love to all, & if   thee gets time write again to thy affec sister C

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1865-06-07
Title: 1865 June 7, B, to Mother and sister Annte

B 6/7—65—

Dear Mother & sister Annte.

I think   I’ll address you collectively this time, as I suppose   Caroline’s head’ll be turned with weddings & unable to   appreciate common topics. I recd. yr. very interesting &   spirited epistles this morn.g & reply at once, in order that   you may not have cause to complain of remissness this time,   & upon what ground you did it last, I must say I cld. not   discover, as I think I have been up to the mark quite as   much as you have. Thy remarks [a] on properness &c were   quite edifying. I expect thee wd. be charmed with the   Baltimore people. They are certainly most social & charming   in their manners, tho’ I dont believe afterall, when you come to the foundation of things that there is   any more good substantial material among them than among   some of that despised class denominated "the proper." As to   the gentlemen I cant say that I have met any whom I consider   very deeply interesting As far as gallantry & politeness go   they are certainly very attractive Bt if we cld. only   introduce a little more of these elements with some of our   [imperturbables] I incline to think these wld. be found   quite as deep in the long run. I must say it is refreshing   to get hold of some thing that is more [impressible] than a   stone & I intend to [---] up Baltimore ways loudly when I   get home. Tell Cousin Mary she must hurry & come down as   fast as she can, or I fearI shall not get to have my sprees with her. This morn the   new teacher who is going to take my sch. arrived & I was   promoted or depressed I dont know wh. to the rank of   assistant to Mr Waterman, the principal of the sch. It is a   splendid change for me, as his room is much pleasanter & I   have none of the discipline to do but only the hearing of   the lessons—intellectually, it seems a most magnificent   advance frm. a-b only to geography and arithmetic & I shd.   be quite willing to teach there for weeks if it was’nt for   the hot weather, as it is, however, considering the [--] &c   I think I had better not stay much after the three months   are up wh. will be abt. the mid of June--& very soon—as you   will perceive, so you may make preparations for me, soon   after that time—I hope you’ll havepleasant little surprise prepared for me in the way of a   closet—wh. wont be the linen closet—I have to keep up such   an everlasting foolding and unfolding here that I shall be   perfectly delighted to get a place to "hang up" in.

I   expect I am indebted to my frd. Jesse for this release frm.   the infants—I said to him in joke some time ago that I thot,   I shd. give "notice" soon for them to get another teacher &   he took it in earnest but I am very glad, on some accts, as   I shd like to get some ideas about older teaching frm Mr.   W.

I expect you’ll enjoy [Mr. N’s] wedding most as   much as Lilly’s—There was a young gentleman here the other   day who told somebody that he thot L’s wedding was   dreadfully stupid, & that he thot’ one or two of the   bridesmaids (he did’nt say all) were the ugliest girls he   had ever seen—not a very complimentary speech I think.
As I shall probably come home so soon it will not be worth   while to send the things by express—tho’ if I cld only have   had them now they wld. have been exceedingly useful -- I   think maybe I’ll try & get myself a beige skt. here & we   shall not be likely to have many more tea parties now the   warm weather has come -- We’ve never heard any more abt.   Jessies strawberry party & we’re afraid he’s forgotten it.   He took us to a small one out at his bro. James’ night   before last. We went in a buggy & pair & came home by   moonlight—quite romantically -- The buggy is only used on   very romantic occasions, I believe. Its so nice here   moonlight nights—the ladies all dress up in their whites &   sit out on the front door steps, & go round [seeing?] one   another with beaux or beau less just as it happens.Has Fanny Drinker gone home? I reckon she has & where is   Cous. Sarah? Give my love to her if she is about still. I   ought to have written to her. Give my love also to all the   Wynndowners also please give my love & congratulations to   all the bride cousins & tell them I’m very sorry not to be   giving them anything-- Maybe if I aint so lazy I’ll make em   something after I get home. But dont tell em that. I believe   this is all I have to say at present—will write and fix the   day of course before I come. If Cous. M. comes soon please   send the shawl and the [b----] skt. as I [---] much love to   all—yrs. affec

ClemmyI shd. be pleased to have some [---] my return & also before   my return

Date: 1865-05-00
Title: [1865 May ?], 190 Calvert st, to Mother and sisters

2nd day eve
190 Calvert st

Dear Mother & sisters,   Tired as I am I must write you a few words to night, as I   shall probably be at the sch, in the morn & the mail closes   at 1 P.M. & I thought you’d like to know that we arrived   safely about 5 this aft. & I am installed in my new boarding   house wh. promises to be very nice.  They ladies were   exceedingly kind & welcomed me as if I had been an old   friend  They are so free & easy.  One of them Miss Talbot   came right up in my room & talked to me while I was getting   dressed – & was as kind as possible  They used to know uncle   Jasper & quantities of our friends, so that I begin to feel   quite at home already  It is a large 4story house with a very nice pleasant parlor, & a   comfortable dining room, where we had tea on a little   refreshment table—the 4 school “marms”—as cozy as possible.    They say “thee” & call me by name wh. makes me feel much   less strange
Jesse called a few minutes after we arrived   in his elegant carriage, having been to one of the dipots to   meet us, but we unfortunately had got out at the wrong one;   & very much out of our way.  The ladies seem in very   moderate circumstances only keeping one servant, & a sch. of   near 40 day scholars.   consequently they have not much time   to attend to housekeeping nor much talent in that way I shd.   think.  Their kindness however makes amends.The house is on a very high situation & there is a fine view   of the city fr[m]. my room, wh is in the 2nd story & very   airy & pleasant.  But there is no closet unfortunatley wh.   is remarkably home like & seems to be my fate.  Not a place   to hang a dress, but I have 5 beaureau drawers & can make   out.  So much for the house.  3rd day morn.  We went last   evening to see the sch. & I was most agreeably disappointed   in it in every respect..  The rooms are well ventilated &   airy & no disagreeable odour.  & their state of advancement   is surprising.  There were a few to be sure who reminded me   of Busy—in his attempt to spell girl—but mostly they were   astonishingly quick--& cld. add & subtract like quite   accomplished arithmeticaians.  Quite as fast as I cld.   myself.  They were mostly adults.  In the morningThey are children.
I am to have a class of 30 & am very   glad to find that I shall be in the school with Miss Field,   who is a very pleasant young lady about my own age I shd.   judge, & we can go backwards & forward to gether, & shall be   companionable I hope.  The morning session is frm. 9 till 1   1/2 not 3.  The evening teaching you can take part in or not   as you choose.  So it will not be very laborous & in every   respect, it is going to be I think, much pleasanter than I   had anticipated.  & if you are only satisfied I think I can   be very comfortable & enjoy the work & the change.Love to Cousin Sarah.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1864-10-09
Title: 1864 October 9, Newport, to Elizabeth S. Cope, Awbury

Newport Oct 9th  1864, 1st day morn

Dear Sister–
I   recieved thy note (for I cannot call it a letter because it   contained so much nonsense) yester-day morning; but I did   not say poo! because I had an idea it was from Rachel or at   least hoped it did not contain nonsense.  I was glad to   recieve such information as thy note contained, & thought it   was a great compliment to be called handsome by sombody,   although I do not think father was much complimented by   having his hair called an iron gray color; unfortunatly I   did not lose my heart with her, although I think I must have   seen her & was very sorry I could not go to meting but my   knee was not equal to it.  I could have found some time to   write to you or thee butI have been very lazy since I have been here.  I delivered   thy message to Father (about Dr Thomas) but fear he has   forgotten about it, so I will remind him of it & now I must   close for I am getting lazy & will tell thee what we are   doing when there is some thing to tell about of more   consequence.  I believe Mother intends writing a   P.S.
Affec thy brother
TP. Cope Jr
P.S.  when I   said you on the first page near the bottom I meat Rachel &   thyself.  TP Cope Jr.

I am sorry there should be any   mistake about Dr. Thomas  I thought I told you, you would   have to send him word when you were ready to begin  You had   better tell him of myabsence from home so that he may understand why he was not   called on before.  So much for that - the burden of my   [----] is “painting.”  It is the burden on my mind & must of   course show itself in words.  Uncle Tom sent me word that he   had expressed a sample of color which Craig has prepared for   our inspection.  I suppose we may get the package tomorrow –   but what troubles me is the delay – Craig said he would have   it all done so we could come back the 20th.  If he has got   to put on two coats after he hears from us I fear he will   not be ready for us.  We are getting tired of this plan &   anxious to know whether there will be any difficulty about   getting intoour house on the 22nd.  Seventh day week - We have to engage   Staterooms two weeks before to get good ones & I intend   tomorrow to engage them for 6th day the 21st & if you find   the house cannot be got ready by that time you will please   send us word at once so that we can disengage the rooms.    Perhaps if Craig can not get all done & dry he can have the   kitchen & back passages finished & if the last coat is on   the parlors &c we might come in before it is dry–  I feel   sorry to have filled up Toms sheet with nothing but such a   message – try to do better next time.  It has been blowing   strong from the N.W. all day & is cold as charity Alf &   Hazen went to meeting with me in the morning & your   [br]other in the afternoon but its dull work here either   at the larger or smaller body Yankee self conceit shows   nowhere more. 


Elizabeth S. Cope
