Affec thy brother
TP. Cope Jr
P.S.  when I   said you on the first page near the bottom I meat Rachel &   thyself.  TP Cope Jr.

I am sorry there should be any   mistake about Dr. Thomas  I thought I told you, you would   have to send him word when you were ready to begin  You had   better tell him of myabsence from home so that he may understand why he was not   called on before.  So much for that - the burden of my   [----] is “painting.”  It is the burden on my mind & must of   course show itself in words.  Uncle Tom sent me word that he   had expressed a sample of color which Craig has prepared for   our inspection.  I suppose we may get the package tomorrow –   but what troubles me is the delay – Craig said he would have   it all done so we could come back the 20th.  If he has got   to put on two coats after he hears from us I fear he will   not be ready for us.  We are getting tired of this plan &   anxious to know whether there will be any difficulty about   getting intoour house on the 22nd.  Seventh day week - We have to engage   Staterooms two weeks before to get good ones & I intend   tomorrow to engage them for 6th day the 21st & if you find   the house cannot be got ready by that time you will please   send us word at once so that we can disengage the rooms.    Perhaps if Craig can not get all done & dry he can have the   kitchen & back passages finished & if the last coat is on   the parlors &c we might come in before it is dry–  I feel   sorry to have filled up Toms sheet with nothing but such a   message – try to do better next time.  It has been blowing   strong from the N.W. all day & is cold as charity Alf &   Hazen went to meeting with me in the morning & your   [br]other in the afternoon but its dull work here either   at the larger or smaller body Yankee self conceit shows   nowhere more. 


Elizabeth S. Cope
Awbury

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Stewardson Brown  Cope:  1822-1916
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1864-10-09
Title: 1864 October 9, Newport, to Elizabeth S. Cope, Awbury

Newport Oct 9th  1864, 1st day morn

Dear Sister–
I   recieved thy note (for I cannot call it a letter because it   contained so much nonsense) yester-day morning; but I did   not say poo! because I had an idea it was from Rachel or at   least hoped it did not contain nonsense.  I was glad to   recieve such information as thy note contained, & thought it   was a great compliment to be called handsome by sombody,   although I do not think father was much complimented by   having his hair called an iron gray color; unfortunatly I   did not lose my heart with her, although I think I must have   seen her & was very sorry I could not go to meting but my   knee was not equal to it.  I could have found some time to   write to you or thee butI have been very lazy since I have been here.  I delivered   thy message to Father (about Dr Thomas) but fear he has   forgotten about it, so I will remind him of it & now I must   close for I am getting lazy & will tell thee what we are   doing when there is some thing to tell about of more   consequence.  I believe Mother intends writing a   P.S.
Affec thy brother
TP. Cope Jr
P.S.  when I   said you on the first page near the bottom I meat Rachel &   thyself.  TP Cope Jr.

I am sorry there should be any   mistake about Dr. Thomas  I thought I told you, you would   have to send him word when you were ready to begin  You had   better tell him of myabsence from home so that he may understand why he was not   called on before.  So much for that - the burden of my   [----] is “painting.”  It is the burden on my mind & must of   course show itself in words.  Uncle Tom sent me word that he   had expressed a sample of color which Craig has prepared for   our inspection.  I suppose we may get the package tomorrow –   but what troubles me is the delay – Craig said he would have   it all done so we could come back the 20th.  If he has got   to put on two coats after he hears from us I fear he will   not be ready for us.  We are getting tired of this plan &   anxious to know whether there will be any difficulty about   getting intoour house on the 22nd.  Seventh day week - We have to engage   Staterooms two weeks before to get good ones & I intend   tomorrow to engage them for 6th day the 21st & if you find   the house cannot be got ready by that time you will please   send us word at once so that we can disengage the rooms.    Perhaps if Craig can not get all done & dry he can have the   kitchen & back passages finished & if the last coat is on   the parlors &c we might come in before it is dry–  I feel   sorry to have filled up Toms sheet with nothing but such a   message – try to do better next time.  It has been blowing   strong from the N.W. all day & is cold as charity Alf &   Hazen went to meeting with me in the morning & your   [br]other in the afternoon but its dull work here either   at the larger or smaller body Yankee self conceit shows   nowhere more. 


Elizabeth S. Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan S. Reeve:  1833-1866
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1865-03-15
Title: 1865 March 15, Locust Shade, to Annie

Locust Shade. 3. 15. 1865

My dear Annie

Does   thee think I have quite forgotten thee and all thy kindness,   & my delightful visit to you? That I have been such a long   while without writing to thee. Indeed I have not, & never   shall I hope- but my wonderings [early] terminated last 7th   day & since then I have had a very bad cold, which thee   knows makes one lazy. - I have wanted to know how thee   faired after our parting on the hill. My walk was brisk & I   did not keep Maggie’s [---] waiting long, and did not feel   tired. I fear thee did not fare so well. Our visit to our   Wilmington friends was very pleasant.
Richie, thee knows, joined me in that. Tho he was not well   enough to enjoy it thoroughly. Lizzie seems very happy & we   hope is learning something, - at least she gets very good   numbers. - The roads were so bad it was not easy to get   about & my journey to Faulkland was a [arduous] one. but the   pleasure of cheering cousin Mary a little & hearing Dr   [Fell]  talk,- a great deal more than repaid me for it.-   

When I returned to Phila John & Sallie Hilles & I   went over to see Charles Rhoads. It was very touching to see   those five little motherless children. Charles looks tens   years older and much broken down.- His sister was very   pleasant- I never knew her before. They are certainly much   favored in having such kind caretakers & hardly feel their   loss as they will after awhile. - I often think of   what

thee said to me in the car after our visit to Clemmy. dear   Annie, with loving sympathy. Deserving too that I may fully   appreciate the blessing of a mothers love while mine is   still spared to me. - I hear Clemmy is going, or has gone to   Baltimore, to teach the Freedmen. What do you think of it?   It seems to me that anything that would give interesting   employment to both mind and body, would be good for her. Tho   I’m right sorry to have her go so far away. - Thee will miss   her too. - Do write some & tell me all about her plans. -   Lilly Collins seems to like her situation very well. I found   a letter from her awaiting me on my return.- She gives an   amusing account of a colored meeting which she attended, - a   real happy [----------] affair.- Lilly enjoys the variety I   should think & it keeps her from being homesick.- Cousin   Elizalooked & seemed more cheerful when I called - but she   certainly is very weak.-

I suppose the preparations   for the wedding are proceeding briskly- Does the go? I quite   want to hear about it. - Lizzie Brown’s sister is to be   married tomorrow & I hope the threatened storm will not come   to spoil all their nice dresses.- Lizzie’s friend Edward   Balderson stayed with us last night. He is to wait on a   young lady from Jersey -  so I fear the love affair between   him & Lizzie is all over - but time will make manifest. Has   thee seen anything more of the interesting students- Till   thy brother Thomas his opinion of the [-----] position of   Carpenters is very family impressed upon my mind.- It makes   me smile now to think how frightened I was, I deserved   rebuke too.- Do please write to me soon dear Annie.- My love   please to thy father & sister E & with a large share of the   same for thyself I am thy sincerely attached & grateful   friend
 
S. S. Reeve

Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865

Title: 1805 September 18 to Henry Cope, Wesston

9 mo 18 1805

Dear Henry

I am Still in town,   and was present when thy letter and [---] came, It gave me   great pleasure to see thy improvement in writing, and to   find that you ar so well Contented, and I must note the   acceptance of thy acepable letter, and present; I am   desireous of Comeing to See my Dear Boys if I can, If I Cant   I must wait with patience your coming; I have been a   thinking what a favour it is to have the Company of T-S with   you so long; as I beleive he has the good of the Youth much   at Heart I hope you will proffet by it, I am going to   farehill and cant’ tell when I shall be in town again, I   should be glad to see the [---] fill’d, but, I shan’t have   time, I expect to be Call’d for Every minute 

I   Continue to be your Affectinate Grandmother Rachel Drinker9 mo 18th 1805
 Henry Cope 
 Wesston

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Edgar Cope:  1838-1895
Date: 1856-03-09
Title: 1856 March 9, to Ed

3rd 9th 2nd day [morn]

Dear Ed, Got thy cousin Thomas letter [for] 6th days mail - Suppose the credit of it is due to him not to thee - Therefore thee will not have looked towards getting an answer That was rather an awkward sort of a business wh. Joseph & Jonathan enlisted in where they undertook the Italian Opera I guess Joseph thought it did not operate very well- & he must have felt decidedly the most awkward of the actors. Well, for you was it, that the charge this time happened to be false. For I greatly fear me that some of you, at some other times, have not been overly scrupulous about such transgressions. - So for this consideration let us try & be lenient to the poor Professor remembering that poor human nature is apt to err. & if you are only innocent it will not trouble you much.
Wish regard to my coming down! (every body has to "come down" She knows & as you all seem to be trying to brings me down, I shall not wonder at finding myself fallen in among you some of these days. If they dont get well before Geo.gets ready to start - I shall think it incumbent upon me to go with him. (I do want them to keep very sick on my acct only a very little will be enough) for me to come on, as I have been on the look out for some excuse this Great while. (Don't for pity's sake think that's earnest.) I was sorry enough to hear how really sick poor Harry had been & I feel right anxious to know how he is. If thee hears from them wont thee let us know. It will be sad if they shd all get the measles together as Julia anticipates.
I wrote to thee so lately that I do not seem to have much on my mind just at present. "The storm's rose & the winds blew (blew) might be said of our weather. If I do go down with Geo. I will endeavor to get out to see thee. If I do I've got no time to spend writing to thee that's another thing so adieu adieu [jusqu an remain]". Find out what what means in the French Dic. Thee can tell cousin Thos. I seem to be humble & willing to come down. But this world's a region of certainty - Write at an early period & remember thy ever affec   Sister

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Eleanor Cope Tyson:  1807-1847
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1821-02-22
Title: 1821, February 22, Trenton, to Brother

Thee will reccollect my dear Brother that when I last saw thee I promised to write to thee in a short time.  Thee will conclude that my short time is a pretty long one but I have been pretty constantly employed since I returned and have not felt in a very letter-writing humour.  I wrote to Caroline about 3 weeks ago and have not yet received an answer I hope thee will prove a better correspondent than she or I shall have but little encouragement to write.  I have begun tolearn french and I like it very much as far as I have gone.  Sister Rachel told me when I was at [Home] that Hannah Bolton had returned from Weston I should be obliged if thee would give my love to her when thee sees her.  Thee desired to know what I was studying.  I am studying, Geography, Grammar, history and spelling and at present how to write a letter worth reading.  Tell sister Rachel I should be pleased to receive a letter from her though I am not willing to risk writing just again but if she will write to me I will endeavour to be more punctual in the answering of her's than I have been of thine.
When thee writes please to tell me how mother is for I believe all ourfamily have forgotten me and therefore I need not look for a letter from any of them.  Tell Alfred I will answer his letter as soon as I possibly can.  mean-while he must wait patiently.  I must now stop for the present as school is just going to close.
Thee desires to know how the swelling is behind my ear I believe it is much the same as it was when I left home.
Please to give my love to Father, Mother, Grandmother, Rachel, William, Caroline & Alfred and accept a large share for thyself & little Mary From thy affectate sister 
Elenor

Trenton 2nd mo: 22nd 1821.Henry Cope
No 36 north 4th st
Philada

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1880-06-14
Title: 1880 June 14, Geneva, to Lily

Geneve No 5 Chemin de la Tour. 6.14.1880
   
   My dear Lily,
   
   I expect Caroline will give me "Jesse" as the saying is, if I presume to enter on the stage with her.  Nevertheless as she has occupied the floor for some weeks past in thy favor, I think I shall dare to add a note, tho' she tells me it must be short & upon no account much upon Revenna.  Wherefore conclude she has been expending herself on that ancient & delightful city- & forbear.  Thy letter of-- containing the childrens photographs came tohand two days since, & gave much pleasure.  We think thine, with little Eleanor, is the best of thee we have ever seen, & as to the little E I shd. say she was her Mama in miniature just as little F is his Papa over again only with a few shades more of jollity in his face.  What a sweet little good natur’d  happy kissable face it is & tho' I believe we have understood that he was'nt particularly fond of the latter operation, I doubtnot he has to undergo a good deal of it, & he does'nt look as if he wd. be very refractory under any circumstances, Indeed such a nice little jolly face must be a great comfort to look at, &, I need not suggest for Mamas to be proud of.  I suppose when we get home thee & Alexis will be a grand old couple, sitting up in the middle of your flock, looking very wise & experienced, as you contemplate with "majestic pride" the youthful scions growing & flourishing about you.
   
   I don’t see that thee has a very care worn air however in thy photo-graph.  but on the contrary one might suppose that they cares & worries of domestic life were quite [---] & pleasant.  by what you say I shd. think the heat must have been of that nature wh. wd. have a tendancy to drive you to seek for a cooler clime.  For my part I dont see the use of undertaking to live in such a climate at all, as the chief object of life seems to be with most people to get away from it.  Why not try to live, as I said to the Awbury people yesterday, where such fearful agonies wd. not have contin-ually to be gone thro' with in order to try to effect an escape.
   
   I am very sorry for Madjy's disappointment as her letter to us showed that he hopes were very much set on Europe, & she seems to need some change so much.  It is a great pity they have to undergo such alternations of hope & despair, because they have got [---] on the living side of the Atlantic.  At least it seems to be the side wh. is very much below par with most persons who inhabit it judging from the frantic manner in wh.they rush for the other shore.  The papers say that pretty much Ole America is now on the way to [---].  We concluded that the pleasure to be derived from seeing the play, wh. I think wd. be but doubtful at best, wd. be very much spoiled by the crowd of cooks & other tourists who will infest the country. We therefore have chosen to spend some time insteadin Geneva in French family No 2.  Not that we were disappointed with our experiences in No 1, but that we fell very much in love with this family last fall, when we took some lessons of them.  They are more cultivated people than the others- consequently moreinteresting, & tho' less well off- they are still friench, wh. means that they are practical & know how to be comfortable on a little.  We only pay about half as much as we do at the large Hotels, with more real comfort, beside the very good advantage of hearing the best of french spoken.  The lady has two sons, one a professor in the University & one a clergyman, & two dhrs. all highly educated.  The advantages of the education here for those in moderate circumastances are so very great.  We shall stay probably a month or more until the weather gets to hot wh. does'nt seem very likely- as we are on pretty high ground just outside the city with plenty of green trees & alps in profusion in the distance.
     
   My advice to you is to come & build a cottage on one of the hill sides of Geneva, instead of Woodbourne & get a Savoyard maid as we have, who with her mistresses aid does the work for a household of 9 persons.  We have two dinners daily, of several courses & very well cooked, & how in the world they do it all I cannot conceive.  I suspect that Madam is at the bottom of a good deal, but she does it all with such apparent grace & ease, that one cannot suspect her of cooking.  There are beautiful building lots to be bought here, by the way, on the high ground along the town with the Lake on one side & Mt. Blanc on the other, & there are many beautiful gardens & suburban residences- wh. are quite unseen & [---] by the mere passing traveller.  If it was’nt for those children of yours whom we want to see!- I shd. be quite tempted to invest in one of these little spots & settle down for the rest of my days.  Will thee please ask Alexis to inquire of cousin FRC if he rec'd a letter fm. me posted June 8. containing a cheque for $200.  I also posted one on the 13 June to M.S.C. containing cheque for $100.  As there is some risk of these things being lost shd. be very much obliged if A or some body wd. advertise Provident Life & Trust Company of [---] and [---]. of these two cheques payable to the order of the above mention’d persons.  Hoping soon to have news of you in a cooler clime & under Mrs. Hotchkiss' hospitable roof.  Ever thy affec- sister C.  Ever so many kisses to dear little Agnes & to theothers as for as appreciated by them.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas Pim Cope:  1823-1900
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1806-1875
Date: 1835-06-08
Title: 1835 June 8, Haverford, to Uncle

Haverford 6th month 8th 1835
   
   Dear Uncle,
   
   As I suppose that thee has by this time returned from Sykens' Valley, I will endeavour this morning, to fulfil my promise.  I wish that I could find something to say that would interest thee but I am afraid that in a place like this a person is much better able to hear than to relate news.  Had thee a pleasant time at Sykens' Valley?  It is now rather later in the season than it was when we visited it several years ago.  I recollect that the country was very pleasant then, and I suppose that it is still more so now unless the lateness of the season has retarded the growth of the plants in such a degree as that they should not be any more in bloom than they were then.  I expect that in thy promised letter thee will give a very interesting account of the journey.  I must not forget to mention that we expect to have a French teacher here next week.  He is a Frenchman and has lately come from Ireland where he had been living since his banishment and where his wife now is.  He was a captain under Buonaparte and showed us a number of wounds which he received in the battle ofLeipsic with lances, and several places where bullets had gone entirely through his arms.  When the Pope was taken prisoner by Buonaparte he was guard over him and he treated the Pope so kindly that when he was liberated he made him captain of the Guards of Honor.  He appears to be a very pleasing and goodn-natured man and like all the French, extremely polite.  We expect that he will tell us many very interesting accounts of the battles that he has been present at.  He appears to be a very intelligent man and speaks Arabic, Spanish, Italian and English very fluently.  He accompanied his father who was minister to the Count of Persia and while there acquired a knowledge of the Arabic language.  His name his D'Mouillon.  I do not know whether I have spelt it right or not, but that is the way that it is pronounced.  As it is nearly time for this letter to go to the Post office and, as I wish to write a few lines to father on the same sheet I must conclude with 
   
   Thy affectionate nephew
   
   Thomas P Cope jrHaverford 6th mo 8th 1835
   
   Dear Father,
   
   As there is plenty of room on this sheet for a few lines more, I may as well fill it up with some of our wants.  Please send us out our Jacobs Greek Readings and a new supply of money as that which we had before is nearly exhausted.  Thy affect son
   
   Thomas P Cope jr
   
   We are very well[Buck Tavern-
   June 8th,]
   
   Alfred Cope
   Care of H&A Cope
   Philadelphia
   
   [TPCope jr-6/8-'35
   ansd-15-]

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas Pim Cope:  1823-1900
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope:  1794-1863
Date: 1835-05-16
Title: 1835 May 16, Haverford, to Mother, Philadelphia

Haverford 5mo 16th, 1835
   
   Dear Mother,
    
    I had intended to write as soon as it was determined in what class we were to be placed. We are in a class Preparatory to the third session and which will join the third junior at the commencement of the fall session. We like the school very well so far but I suppose that we have not had time to give it a fair trial. I mentioned that a boy by the name of Caleb Needles was with Offleg Sharpless in town I was mistaken in the boy: it was not him. The boys seem to regret Samuel Hilles' leaving them and seem to miss him very much. Please to get us Morocco Portfolios to keep our papers in nearly all the boys have them. Please to get us one yard of figures baire to cover our desks with there is some which is very pretty at Townsend Sharpless: Please send out Franky's Surveying, Mathematical Instruments, History of [Chart] and my Latin Grammar and History of Chart a couple of boxes of blacking, two cups to be used when we wash our teeth and some quills. Saml Linch had a meeting yesterday, afternoon at the meeting house. We received father's letter and are glad to hear you well we are well. We get very good meals except the coffee which is miserable. I am they affectionate.
    
   Thomas P Cope jr.Buck Tavern Pa
   May 16th
   
   [5mo 18]
   
   Henry Cope
   Care of H & A. Cope
   Philadelphia
   
   for Rachel R Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas Pim Cope:  1823-1900
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1806-1875
Date: 1835-08-05
Title: 1835 August 5, Haverford, to Uncle, Philadelphia

Haverford 8mo 5th, 1835
   
   Dear Uncle,
   
   As I have but little to do to day why should I not be punctual in answering thy very interesting letter? Perhaps my desire to answer thy letter is not a little increased by what thee says in the latter past of it, that I am indebted to a white-wash woman for it. I have puzzled myself a great deal about how that could  be and at last have come to the conclusion that the said wash-woman is white-washing Grandfathers house, and thee had on that account been obliged to go down to the store, where having nothing to do in the business may, has very kindly taken it into they head to answer my last, especially as the seems to have anticipated a something from the letter that was lying on the desk. However I hope they next will solve the mystery.
    
   As to Monsieur, I told thee all that I knew about what had happened to give us a bad opinion of him, I merely heard that he had moved to be something of an imposter. If he is an Imposter for I can hardly believe that he is, he must be capable of acting the part of the hypocrite extremely well.Thee says that thee cannot accept my excuse for not writing a long letter and that I did not squeeze the right way; whether I squeezed the right way or not, I cannot tell, but when there is nothing to come, nothing will come. As thee had been please to liken the case to milking a cow, suppose I do the same. If the cow has had nothing to eat (in other words if nothing has happened for one to tell about) squeeze might [mong] or stand still as the woman Grandmother Drinker told about did nothing can come: such is my case. Perhaps thee will say "why did not tell thee about those things that thee mentioned last: With respect to the first I have already told thee all I knew about. Monsieur which to be sure is precious little, and with respect to Wm Dennis Address it cost but a trifle, not worth mentioning. Look there! Haven't I argufied  my case right well; at any rate, if I haven't made out any good reasons, I have made it help fill my sheet. Don't thee think that I have made out as good an excuse as thee did for not answering mine sooner.
   
   Thee will please excuse my using the offensive phrase "do not understand": I would not wish thee to understand by that, that they letters are unintelligible to me; they are not by any means. The personages I alluded to thee says are a distinguished inhabitant of the renowned city of Moodle doosie and his faithful and only friend Tom, who by the way thee says is apig. Quite a Compliment! The boys of the 3rd Class (of which there are about a dozen) have just returned from an excursion they have been making this afternoon to the Inclined Plane with Daniel B Smith to obtain minerals. According to their account of the matter they had a delightful time after having obtained the objects for which they went, they went in swimming in the Schuylkill , and found the water very warm, notwithstanding it has been such a cold morning. They were at one time within a mile of the city, and I think had I been with them, that the temptation to run in to the city and say "how-dye-do" to all the folks at home would have been almost sufficient to have induced me to do so, if I could have stayed but a half an hour. Now won't thee acknowledge that I have written a pretty long letter, considering what a poor hand I am? I shall expect a sheet well filled with interesting matter (a thine usually are) to arrive very shortly folded up and dissected to me. I hope top thee mill acknowledge that I have been very punctual in answering thy last. Time slips away very fast and very pleasantly with me. Why does thee not come out and pay us a visit some day.   
   They affectionate Nephew,
   Thomas P Cope Jr.Alfred Cope
   No 36 Nth 4th St
   Philadelphia
   
   Politness of
    [---] Morgan

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas Pim Cope:  1823-1900
Recipient:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Date: 1852-09-14
Title: 1852 September 14, Philadelphia, to Clemmy

Philada. 9th mo. 14th 1852
   
   Dear Clemmy,
   
   Grandfather this morning told me he wished me to write to thee for him and invite thee to come down and spend the winter with him, and he sends thee the enclosed notes to pay thy passage.  So thee sees he takes it for granted that thee will come, and when we consider how lonely as he says himself he will be it seems so desirable to all the family that he should have thee with him that we trust Uncle William and Aunt Susan will be willing to spare thee again.  I need not tell thee how glad we shall be to have thee among us, though we do not forget that it will make a break in your family circle.  Grandfather spent yesterday in town (which is the day I began this letter & was interrupted and it is the 15th now) and went out to Uncle Edward’s in the afternoon to stay about a week: from there he will go to pay a visit at Uncle Nathaniel's: he does not expect to return to Uncle Alfred's.  He has been generally much better than he was in the spring & more cheerful.Elizabeth and Anne received thy "double almond" letter as it might be called inasmuch as there were two very good kernels in a shell and as I see that they have torn them apart and Elizabeth has her half in her keeping, I have no doubt she intends to consider it a whole letter and send thee a whole answer which shall not be a postscript to some one else's.  I do not recollect any thing new or strange to tell thee and I will not undertake to entertain thee with the particulars of Harry's advances in talking & Franky's in gymnastics which are uppermost in our thoughts and might come out first if I would let them.  Julia returned from Reading a few days ago having spent a couple of weeks there after her grandfather's death, and we are all together again and jogging along as usual.  Mary & Carry Yarnall spent a few days with us lately.  Aunt Mary is at Chester and I do not suppose she will return home much before Grandfather.
   
   This is a very pleasant task Grandfather has put upon me.  I was not surprised at his sending for thee for I thought from remarks he had made several times during the summer that it was very likely he would do so, and now that the time for his return home draws near we are old and young united in thinking it very desirable, for it would not do for him to have no one living with him but Aunt Mary, it would be lonely for both & if she was unwell at any time he would have no one with him.  Send us word in time when andhow thee will come down.  thy blanket shawl we will send up if we can find a conveyance early enough, unless thee tells us that thee does not want it.  Being in town next winter will give thee an opportunity of continuing some of thy studies though the sciences of baking and nursing and general housekeeping may be neglected for a while.  Anne and Julia expect to continue French at School- whether they will go on with the other studies or part of them is undetermined but not very likely, but we hope they will find some way of making good use of their time.
   
   Our three families send their love & hope soon to have thee [am]ong us.  Julia says she will write in a few days.  Ann[e is] spending the evening with Laura.  Hoping soon [---] from thee and soon after to see thee, I am affectionately
   
   thy cousin
   
   Thos. P. Cope JrClementine Cope
   Care of William D. Cope
   Dimock
   Susquehanna Co
   Pa.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope) Haines:  1819-1890

Title: 1811 June 12, Newgarden College, to Mary Cope, Philadelphia

[Newgarden College 5
   Master Lewis- Enoch Lewis]
   
   June 12th 1811
   
   I suppose Father has told you that I arrived here safe and therefore it is needless for me to say anything in that respect.  I found it was harder to part with Father than I expected:  I felt the difference between being with my connections and Master Lewis' family; however I have got pretty well used to their noise and have got once more settled down to my studies pretty much in the old way.  I am sorry to have it to tell you that the cloth I got while I was at home is damaged.  there is a very ugly place goes round the sleeve of the coat and there are a few spots in other parts of the cloth.  I dare say this will be very disagreeable news, and I am sorry for it but can not help it.
   
   I did not find Alice as I hoped to find her, down stairs, nor is she able to come down now.
    
   I would tell thee nothing to tell Grandmother but I shall give her the pleasure or I hope I shallof informing her myself.  perhaps thee may wonder what I mean by saying, I hope I shall; I dont mean that I hope I shall write to her but I hope it will give her pleasure if I do write.
   
   I have read Think-I-to-myself since I cam back and I think it is a very interesting tale; but I suppose thee would much rather hear that I had read the Bible and so I have read some of it.  perhaps thee will say to thyself, I wonder how much; why I can tell thee 3 verses at least.  perhaps thee may now say to thyself, very little indeed; but hower if used rightly it might be better than none.  I have not heard from Caroline since I left her at West-town but she seemed to leave us quite contentedly, an indication I think (though I dont pretend to know much about it) of a strong mind.  I can easily see a difference between me and her in that respect, (but it is best to be sensible of our faults Jacob Lindley tells us) for I am pretty sure that I felt more dejected when Father left me than Caroline did when Father left her.I would like to hear how Father & Alfred got home but I suppose if any of their legs or arms or any of their bones at all had been broken I should have heard of it.
   
   The preceeding lines have been written several days ago and I was waiting for a favorable opportunity to send them which I now have by Charles Allen.  one of my hands is again affected by poison.
   
   The spots on my coat have in a great measure disappeared.
   
   With love to you all I remain
   Thy affectionate Son
   
   Wm. D. CopeMary Cope
   No36 North Fourth St
   Philada.

Title: 1830 July 29, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 7mo. 29th 1830
   Dear Brother:
   
   The idea presented in thine of ye 20 inst. of finding me out in the woods, I may truly say, excited in me very pleasant feelings; tho' at ye same time, I feel as if I can scarcely dare to invite you, for reasons that I think it wd. not be proper to mention in a letter. I will give thee a remote exception of what amongst other things, I allude to, by refering to a frequent remark, that in every flock, there is a black sheep, & a Judas in every community. more than this, I ought not to say. I believe I have never hesitated to answer any query put to me by relatives & friends respecting my situation, nor have I any objections to doing so, unless I may have a very particular reason for secrecy. but Marmaduke will perhaps from having been an impartial spectator, be more likely to give thee a satisfactory description of Woodbourne than myself.- E. Walker bro't me thy letter whilst I was spending ye evening as usual, with his family. I mentioned what was said by thee about visiting me. George desired me to tell thee that they shd. be very glad to see thee: and Priscilla said, tell him to bring Rachel &Martha. they all seemed to be as glad to see Marmaduke & our other cousins, as if they had been their own relations. it seemed to me to be quite like an era in ye history of Woodbourne, when my City relations had actually paid me a visit.- I think you had better come on, and take us by surprise as they did, and thus give us no time to think about any obstructions, objections, or difficulties. with regard to any pecuniary considerations, I think I cd. fully satisfy my neighbours, tho' they will not listen to any direct proposition relative to consideration money.- in expressing what precedes, I have used ye freedom, which ought to exist in ye intercourse between brothers. to one, who does not stand in ye same relationship to me as thyself, I wd. have felt some hesitation in saying what I have said to thee.- I was much interested in reading thy description of ye proposed institution for imparting instruction in ye higher branches of learning to the children of Friends, and had no idea that so great an advance had been made towards affecting ye object in view. it is a noble undertaking, & if accomplished, will tend to increase ye reputation of the Society. the sup-position or opinion, that our profession, principles or religion acquires ye discouragement of literary knowledge & intelligence, appears to me pretty evidently to be a mistake.-  I was fearful that there wd. be an appearance of ambiguity in my observations with regard to the Union Canal stock.  In my last communication on ye subject, I expressed a willingness to invest, if I cd. obtain five per cent on the am't invested.  this I shd. receive, were I to give $240 per share, or 120 per cent.  consequently, if I am right in my estimate, ye price is still below my limits.  but of course, there would be no advantage in offering a high price, if there is none of the stock for sale.-  I am much obliged to thy attention to the subject.  supposing that the Bank of Penna has declared ye dame divd. for ye last as for ye previous half year, I inclose a Power of Att'y for its collection, & one also for the interest on the C & D Canal loan.  if the Lehigh Co. shd. have disclosed a divd. please inform me.  I see by the news-papers, that 3 1/2% has been declared by the U.S. B'k.
   
   With best love to family & friends, I remain thy affectionate brother,
   Wm D Cope
   
   I have drawn, under date of 5mo. 3-'30, draft no. 25, fav. C. Avery for $50.+  and no 26, under date of 7mo. 1-'30, fav. Avery & Drinker, for same am't, & both at 3 d/s.  also no. 27, at 3 d/s, fav. Avery & Drinker, dated 7mo.13-'30, for $50.00
   I lately spoke to G. Mallery about ye P. Thomson tract & he promised me that he will again lay ye subject before ye Com's & when their decision is ascertained, will write to me.
   
   + before advised ofKnow all men by these presents, that I, William D Cope of the Township of Springville, County of Susquehanna and State of Pennsylvania, have authorized and appointed, and do authorize and appoint, Henry Cope, of the firm of Henry & Alfred Cope, Philadelphia, my true and lawful attorney, to demand and receive from the Chesapeak & Delaware Canal Company, the interest due me on Nine thousand five hundred dollars ($9500.) Loan of said Company.
   
   In witness whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seal rgw twenty-ninth day of the 7mo. (August) 1830
   Signed and sealed in the presence of
   Jonathan Nichols
   Lyman BaldwinWoodbourne
   7mo.30.
   
   [8mo 1 1830-]
   Henry Cope,
   care of Henry & Alfred Cope,
   Philadelphia.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Joel Baily
Recipient:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Date: 1813-07-19
Title: 1813 July 19, East Marlborough, to William D. Cope, Philadelphia

East Marlborough July 19th 1813
   
   I now take up my pen to write to thee my much esteemed Friend William D Cope. whose letters of the 15th, 21th (of June), and the 1th of July have received. by that of the 15th thee has informed me of a sorrowful circumstance respecting thy dear cosin, a circumstance which by thee and many others I judge will not be soon forgotten. And altho thee and has been so kind as to inform me of some very important circumstances respecting the affares of the Country, yet I believe thee will not think strange of me if I say but little or nothing on that ssubject, as what little news I get is unly such as thee has heard thyself, for it is principally from the Westchester paper which is extracted from the papers of the City. I was at Ennoch Lewis's about three weeks ago and I think the boys are nether better contented there than they were last winter, for the rules are somewhat milder, they are now allowed to go to bed when they please. And as for going out of bounds I believe there is but little attention payd to  it, that I think Friend William, (altho I was so tired of it last winter) I could spend a few months more there very well. I believe about two thirds of the boys are such as ware there when I was and of think thy all appeared to be in good health.John Taylor was at our house a few days ago and informed me that he had lately received a letter from John Elliott, which stated that his brother that went into the Army was shot at the time of the battle at Far York. I understood he was not in the battle at the time he was shot, but was out some distance from the Army with a few others and ware met by about fourty Indian's, who immediately fired at them and killed nine. I understood Johns Brother rode about a mile on Horseback after he had received three shots. One in his arm and two in his body, He was then taken off his Horse. But expireed in a few minutes after one of our neighbour's had his barn burned a few days ago by the lightening and his crop was all burned in it which was to him a considerable loss as he was not in very affluent circumstances. I think Friend Cope if thy double letter had miscarried and been broken open by any person he or she would of seen something in it worth a laughing at. I mean the part respecting thy beard. I understand thee is so tormented with thy huge beard that thee has been studying what thee should get that would kill it. But as thee is not likely to get anything that will answer the purpose, thee has requested thyFriend to take up a resolution and to good for evil (that is for pulling his whiskers) by contriving something that will answer the 8th purpose. but of should not think it a friendly act to destroy that which nature has formed as an ornament for my Friend.
   
   I am thy Friend Joel BailyWilliam D. Cope
   Philadelphia
   
   to the care of Thomas P Cope, merchant

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  M.H. Garrett
Recipient:  Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth) Cope:  1840-1944
Date: 1883-09-30
Title: 1883 September 30, Germantown, to Carrie

Germantown, 9.30.83.
   
   My Dear Carrie-
   I hope the expression of sympathy & affection may be acceptable, even though there may be no new thoughts of comfort to suggest.
   
   I was so sorry to hear from Sister Lillie today that Edgar's health had been poor. I though of him as a strong man. It will be a pleasure, no doubt, though mingled with sadness, to Nettie & thee, to minister to the comfort of your remaining brother.
   
   The memory of Alexis is one of calmness & sweetness. I did not know him well, yet recall with pleasure the queit cordiality of his greeting. Samuel Morris, who rode in the same carriagewith me at the funeral, said he had learned to love him much. I think it is grateful to look back on his life here as a happy one, & his life there as is fit & glorious consummation. And he left a dear legacy in his children. I am glad you have them. I count myself so rich in my dear nephews & nieces, my young brothers & sisters, as I sometimes call them. Does thee know I am a great-aunt? My oldest nephew, Joseph Rhoads, has a wee Edgar, away out in Plainfield Indiana, where he has gone to teach. Hetty  is out there, helping. Has been away nearly 7 weeks & we don't know when we shall get her back. She went to help furnish & arrange the new little home.
   
   Fanny & Alfred Garret were here last evening a while. We do think Fannya very lively have character, & Alfred seems to be coming out a fine manly boy, & doing well at college. 
    
   How the time does fleet away! Think of it being 50 years since we were at West-town together! And what can those fleeting years show? For me, a life made up of many little things, & with too many idle hours. I enjoy my work of various kinds though; simple household cares, an extensive correspondence, partly for pleasant sympathies, partly for teaching, & on the rest days, a restful work in the care of my first-day class. Dr. Rhoads holds a school at our house and I have as my class nearly 20 boys & girls from 9 to 14 years old who troop up to my room with me. I will not claim to do them much good. I don't believe in direct religious teaching exceptwhere there is an opening for it, but I think the hour passes not unprofitably, & they learn to find the study of the Bible pleasant.    
   I hope Ellie Alderson may continue to improve. I should be glad to hear from thee if thee can feel like writing, & to be told what your prospects are.
   With Love to Nettie & Thyself,
   ever thy affectionate friend
   
   M. H. Garrett

Title: 1911 May 24, Philadelphia, to Rachel C. Evans

5. 24. 1911
   
   Rachel C. Evans
   My Dear Cousin,
   
   I enclose herewith copy of minutes adopted at the last meeting of the Board of Managers of Haverford College and which I was directed to send to thee.
   
   I cannot tell thee how I missed cousin Jonathan at this meeting. He wasone of those I always counted on for sympathy and enouragement.
   
   Sincerely thine,
   CJ RhoadsI hereby certify that the following is a true and correct copy from the minutes of action taken at a meeting of the Board of Managers of THE CORPORATION OF HAVERFORD COLLEGE held 5th Month 19th, 1911.
   
   The President reminded the Board that since our last meeting two of our fellow Managers had had been taken from us by death, and it was unanimously resolved that the following minutes be entered on our records.
   
    On 3rd Month 26th, 1911, Jonathan Evans passed away in his 67th year. He was elected a Manager of this Corporation on 10th Month 12th, 1897, and continued in active service until his death. We shall always remember his as one who loved his fellow men, which trait endeared him to those with whom he came in contact. For many years he took a lively interest in all the out-door activites at the College and by frequent visits to the campus kept himself informed of the condition and needs of the grounds and buildings. On this account his judment on question that came before us was the more valuable because it was based on personal knowledge. He was personally known to many of the students, who were often helped by his affectionate sympathy with all their interests. His fellow Managers will truly miss his presence at their meetings, at which he was a faithful and regular attendant.***********   
   Charles J Rhoads
   Secretary.

Title: 1905 June 17, S.S. Minnehaha, to Mother

Please return!
   
   [mailed NYC 6/17/1905] 
   
   Dear Mother, 
   
   Here we are safe and sound on board the old craft and out of sight of land already at 7.30 a.m.  I am writing this to go by the pilot as he has not left us yet. The main reason for our being out of sight of land is that the fog is ratherthick.  I didn't turn out very early and am just as glad that I didn't as there wasn't much to be seen I guess, coming down the harbor. Ed didn't either, though he had thought of it last night.  Our roommates are named Argill and O'Brien. The latter appears to be a self-made Irishman, but rather good company I guess. Argill I have not seen yet in his civilized clothes. He is not what youwould call a sleeping beauty. George says he has a very nice man in his room.    A Mr Tucker. 
   
   Class Day and commencement went off very well and we had very good weather a very seemtial point. Uncle Will made nice address. 
   
    Please thank Anna very much for her steamer letter. It was very good of her to write. Please give my love and Aunty Lily and Ellie. Ed sends love to them and to both Ann & thyself in which I join. 
   
    Lovingly thy son, 
   Ernest
   
   June 17. 1905
   P.S. I forgot to thank thee for thy steamer letter too, dear.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Harold Evans:  1886-1977
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1905-03-11
Title: 1905 March 11, Haverford College, to Mother

Dear Mother
   It certainly does not seem over two weeks ago that I saw you at Aldine, and I can scarcely tell what I have been doing with myself.  The Sophomore-Freshman debate caame off the Third-day of the week after I saw you, and so I was pretty busy preparing for that.  Unfortunately we lost.  It was the first thing the Freshmen had beaten us in, so we were rather sour.  Then the next night came the Entertainment for the Preston Boys' Club.  I had no idea of staying till the dance but go to talking and didn't get back till after twelve!  It was very good fun and I enjoyed it very much.  It is rather good fun to watch other people dance even though you don't dance yourself.  It was a success financially too, and we cleared $156.25 all of which, I am glad to say was given to the Boys' Club through Dr. Babbitt.  For a wonder the newspaper report about Emily Fox and the Biddles was true except that I think it was greatly exaggerated.  Detectives have been put on the case, I believe and they hope to recover at least some of the things.  I don't know whether they think they lost it or that it was stolen.  It certainly was mighty hard luck as I believe some of Emily's things were valuable on account of being heir looms. 
   
   Ernest's knee, I think is just about all right.  He can walk around on it all right but I imagine it is still weak. 
   
   The weather here has been quite warm and the snow has been melting pretty fast, but there is a good deal of ice over things and it takes a good while to melt that off.  To-day however is quite cool again, though I imagine it will warm up toward the middle of the day as the sun has so much power.  It sounds fine to hear of May days and violets and daffodils but it will not be so very long before we too shall be getting spring, for here it is about a third of  the way through March.  It certainly seems funny to think that there are only three more weeks of the third quarter left; for the fourth quarter goes by like grease-lightening.  I am glad I am not in Ernest's shoes. 
   
   To-night the gymnasium competition with Lehigh University comes off and I certainly hope we win.  Last week our team went up to Rutgers, and when the last event began we were several points behind, but we won the event and the meet by one point!  I hope it will be as exciting to-night. 
   
   It is fine to hear of all that Anna can do.  Please give her a great deal of love from me and tell her that this letter is for her too.  I suppose thee has heard of President Sharpless' illness.  He has not been at college for nearly three weeks, I think.  They took him into the Pennsylvania Hospital where Fred Sharpless  is one of the physicians, but he is better now. 
   
   Last Fourth day afternoon we had another festivity in the way of a Faculty tea for the Sophomores.  It was rather good fun, though I don't think much of teas.  They are too stiff and formal. 
   
   I think I shall have to cry a halt as my slender stock of news is about exhausted.  With lots of love for you both and thanking thee very much for thy letter, 
   
   Thy very affectionate son   Harold.   

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1857-1897
Date: 1875-11-28
Title: 1875 November 28, Church Lane, to brother

Church Lane 11 mo 28. 75
   
   My dear brother
   
   Having received a message from thee through a letter to Tom, and not being able to plead sickness as a reason for not writing, I am going to send thee a greeting-  Well we are not going to see thee until next spring, it seems a long time, and we were all of us not a little disappointed when the news came.  We were counting the days until the time when thee was to sail and beginning to speculate upon the probable length of the passage, when suddenly all our hopes were dashed-  I was going to say I would not flatter thee by telling thee what lamentations there were on the part of some of us, but I think it does no one harm to know how much they are loved and missed at home, on the contrary I think  to a young man it does good, tending perhaps to keep him out of some things by which he might otherwise be tempted-  Now for the scrape of news I can glean up-  Last fourth day Tom and I drove over to Haverford to bring away thy [chattels?]-  We arranged to go on third day, but on that day we had a regular old fashioned Nor'easter and it poured most of the day-  The next morning about nine oclock Tommy appeared at our house in the [---] with Lady and Eric (Harry having been laid up some time with sore feet) after getting some more warm wraps for it had cleared off quite cold when we started-  The roads were in a pretty miserable state of muddiness and as we undertook to go by the Lancaster road we almost stuck so to speak-  However we reached the College about half past eleven, and finding the students in recitation we went up stairs and explored-  We found all thy things had been moved out of thy room and were locked up in another closet of which the matron hadkey so she had to be hunted up-  We packed most of the books and some other things in a drawer which Tommy and I carried down to the front door Tommy saying it was "like carrying down a little coffin"-  We donated to Frank Haines a bottle of eye wash, a little bottle of carbolic acid and a few other valuables?-  Thus were the last rites performed-  We packed the books in the bottom of the wagon, and put the precious articles, around with we supposed tender associations ( clung , (a broken fan with names thereon &c) between folds of the down cover-  We drove home to dinner reaching Awbury about quarter of four-  We had a good laugh at Tom - one of the objects over was to bring home the hanging book shelf and we forgot all about it, and came home without it - which rankled in Tommy's breast-  By the way talking of Haverford does thee know they have raised a sufficient amount of money to enable them to build, and Samuel Alsop Jr told me it was decided to go ahead-  The day we werethere was the day before Thanksgiving day, and as I waited upstairs in the entry while Tom was hunting up the Matron I was amused at two of the students, one was in the hall down stairs and as the other came out I suppose from recitation - he announced the fact that they were going to have Turkey for dinner, whereupon there went up such a howl of rejoicing as almost upset me-  We hoped while at Haverford to have had time to have called upon Margaret Yarnall, but we spent to much time at Any Marys that we had not time.  I suppose you have heard that Ellis and M Yarnall are boarding at [---] during the Winter.  I am glad to hear they are vert comfortably fixed-  It seems an out of the way kind of place for them, a good deal away from most of the latter's friends, I should think she would long to have her daughter with her.  I do feel for them very much-  First day 12/5.  A week, my dear Afred, has passed since I commenced this letter yet it is not finished.5
   During the week we have been pained from day to day to hear of Uncle Alfred's increasing illness.  As early as the beginning of the week Dr Wister said he seemed to be failing, and on second day they telegraphed for James, they received an answer the next morning only saying "will come" and that is all they have heard.  Up to second day Uncle Alfred has been able to get over into the library, this he has accomplished with the aid of a man who has been staying with him at night for a number of weeks- assisting him to dress and undress.  One second day he was so much weaker that he had to remain in bed- and since then he has been gradually growing weaker and weaker, until yesterday afternoon about three o'clock he quietly passed away-  He does not seem to have had any acute disease-  His appetite almost entirely gave out, and he gradually weakened - with the exception of a pain in one of his lungs I do not think he has suffered any-  Since last first day Uncle Tom and John E Carter have been sitting up with him half of alternate nights, the nurse sitting up the other half.  Lilly and Edward have been staying over at Fairfield for the last day or two-  Yesterday morning having heard how he was the evening before Father, Uncle Tom and Aunt Lizzie went over there, the Doctor came soon after they arrived and said he did not think he could live but a few minutes.  They went up into his room (except Father who had gone on to town) and sat there for two hours awaiting the close- he seemed entirely conscious but lay perfectly still excepting once when he passed his hand through his hair as his custom was and once he put his hand under his head-  They went to dinner and a few minutes after dinner was over he passed away, no one but Aunt Rebecca, Lily and Edward being present.  Just at the close, there was a short spasm and then to him all was joy and peace and rest-  What a wonderful and glorious change it must be for him after a long life of ill health and suffering during which I suppose he could never have said he really felt well, to awake inthat Holy City none of whose inhabitants can say I sick and where "there shall be no more death, neither sorrow nor crying, neither shall there be ay more pain: for the former things are passed away"-  Aunt Caroline seems to feel it very much, not having seen for some time except a few days ago, when hearing how sick he was she went out to see him, but ut was thought best for her not to go in the room or let him see her so she looked at him through the door-  The only remarks I have heard that Uncle Alfred made (though he probably said more which I have not heard) were that some days ago he told J.E.C. "that it made very little difference which way it ended" meaning his sickness-  To E. Allen who visited home within a few days, and as she was leaving said she supposed she should never see him on earth again and that she did not doubt but that the change would be a glorious one to him he replied "I have been forced to feel very quiet and peaceful"  I think those were the words he used-  The funeral is to be next third day at two oclock.  It will be a great trial I doubt not to James to find all over when hearrives - 
   
   Last sixth day Uncle Tom commenced his winter readings and it was said to have been a very interesting occasion-  Neither Chellie nor I was able to get there-  There is a good deal of stir in our City now over the meetings of Moody & Sankey-  They have fitted up the old freight depot of the Pennsylvania RR so that it will seat about eleven thousand and meetings are being held I think twice on week days and three times on first days - they are largely attended and from accounts some of them must be impressive.  I hope they may do good-
   
   I suppose Mother in her weekly letter told you that Hazen had sprained his ancle, turned it under him as he was rushing out of the side door to catch the train-  Tommy seems to think it was a mercy he sprained it as it will probably save him from something worse if he will only take warning.  He had to hold it up for nearly a week.  However he is about again now tho he says it feels weak.  Aunt Lizzie Brown is still down at Atlantic City where she has been for some 9
   weeks and from accounts does not seem much better.  Aunt Fanny went down last third day taking with her a maid to stay with aunt Lizzie-  I am afraid her sickness is a pretty serious one and not to be gotten over in a hurry.  The rest of them at Grandfathers are pretty well now-  Grandfather has had a cold but is better-  Aunt Martha Leeds I suppose you have heard is at the Frankford Asylum, and from last accounts was not much better in her mind and was also very sick with [---] in her head-  I dont know whether thee has heard or not that the new building at Haverford is to go up next year they having got enough subscribed to warrant them in commencing so Samuel Alsop Jr told me.
   
   Lillies letter from [---] arrived on sixth day last and we were very glad to hear of your being so comfortably and pleasantly fixed-  Please give a great deal of love to both Lilly and Alexis and tell them I often think of them both with much affection and truly it does seem a long long time since we parted with them.  I do hope the stay will do you all a great deal of good-  I am afraid you have missed some of our letters Chell and I both misunderstood and have been directing our letters to Brown-Shipley & Co Liverpool - and I am afraid they have not forwarded them-  I wrote not long ago a letter to thee and one to Lilly and Alexis enclosing a photograph of the baby to each-  If they have never come to hand I will send you another-  Harry has at last made up his mind to return to Minneapolis - he expects to start next fourth day.  I hope he will have a more prosperous time the coming year than he has had the last-  Upon looking over the forepart of this letter which I wrote a week ago I find I have mentioned about the building at Haverford in that so thee will please excuse my telling it again-  I dont feel like rewriting the letter-  Chell sends her love to you all in which I join and wish you "a merry Christmas" and "a happy New Year"-  I remain thy
   loving brother
   J Evans

Title: 1889 September 20, Awbury, to Lilly

Awbury.
Sept. 20. 1889.

My dear Lilly.  I know   that thee has thought it strange that I have never written   to thee all summer. but one thing and another always turned   up. & [---] the days go by without doing so – now that I   really have something to tell thee perhaps it won’t be so   hard! but I wont go on like Elliston Morris – but will get   to the point of my tale which is simply that I am engaged to   Will Lewis!  The engagement is not to be announced for a   long time yet –  This is especiallyimportant on Will Lewis’ account and I am sure thee will   help us to keep it quiet and be very careful not to let the   children or anyone else suspect the truth!  It does seem   strange that I should be engaged to one whom neither thee or   Chellie know – but I Sincerely hope you will soon know him   and learn to like him as one of the family!  My happiness is   so complete that I can scarcely realize all that has   happened –  that what I have prayed and longed for for so   many months has actually come to pass and I am engaged to   him whom I have loved for so long a time – it has all been   Sosudden! the Change – that I feel as if I was in a dream &   cannot realize the truth!  Our own immediate families are   the only ones who are to know anything about it for the   present – so please be very careful not to mention the   subject –  I really think it would be better to talk about   it as little as possible – for "little pitchers have big   ears" thee knows! of course thee won’t have anyone to talk   to about it now.  but I meant especially when J and R. go up   & after you all got home.
The mail is about to go –& news is scarce at present – so I wont continue scrawling.   
With love – I am thine 
very   affectionately
Carrie.

Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872

Title: 1865 June 7, B, to Mother and sister Annte

B 6/7—65—

Dear Mother & sister Annte.

I think   I’ll address you collectively this time, as I suppose   Caroline’s head’ll be turned with weddings & unable to   appreciate common topics. I recd. yr. very interesting &   spirited epistles this morn.g & reply at once, in order that   you may not have cause to complain of remissness this time,   & upon what ground you did it last, I must say I cld. not   discover, as I think I have been up to the mark quite as   much as you have. Thy remarks [a] on properness &c were   quite edifying. I expect thee wd. be charmed with the   Baltimore people. They are certainly most social & charming   in their manners, tho’ I dont believe afterall, when you come to the foundation of things that there is   any more good substantial material among them than among   some of that despised class denominated "the proper." As to   the gentlemen I cant say that I have met any whom I consider   very deeply interesting As far as gallantry & politeness go   they are certainly very attractive Bt if we cld. only   introduce a little more of these elements with some of our   [imperturbables] I incline to think these wld. be found   quite as deep in the long run. I must say it is refreshing   to get hold of some thing that is more [impressible] than a   stone & I intend to [---] up Baltimore ways loudly when I   get home. Tell Cousin Mary she must hurry & come down as   fast as she can, or I fearI shall not get to have my sprees with her. This morn the   new teacher who is going to take my sch. arrived & I was   promoted or depressed I dont know wh. to the rank of   assistant to Mr Waterman, the principal of the sch. It is a   splendid change for me, as his room is much pleasanter & I   have none of the discipline to do but only the hearing of   the lessons—intellectually, it seems a most magnificent   advance frm. a-b only to geography and arithmetic & I shd.   be quite willing to teach there for weeks if it was’nt for   the hot weather, as it is, however, considering the [--] &c   I think I had better not stay much after the three months   are up wh. will be abt. the mid of June--& very soon—as you   will perceive, so you may make preparations for me, soon   after that time—I hope you’ll havepleasant little surprise prepared for me in the way of a   closet—wh. wont be the linen closet—I have to keep up such   an everlasting foolding and unfolding here that I shall be   perfectly delighted to get a place to "hang up" in.

I   expect I am indebted to my frd. Jesse for this release frm.   the infants—I said to him in joke some time ago that I thot,   I shd. give "notice" soon for them to get another teacher &   he took it in earnest but I am very glad, on some accts, as   I shd like to get some ideas about older teaching frm Mr.   W.

I expect you’ll enjoy [Mr. N’s] wedding most as   much as Lilly’s—There was a young gentleman here the other   day who told somebody that he thot L’s wedding was   dreadfully stupid, & that he thot’ one or two of the   bridesmaids (he did’nt say all) were the ugliest girls he   had ever seen—not a very complimentary speech I think.
As I shall probably come home so soon it will not be worth   while to send the things by express—tho’ if I cld only have   had them now they wld. have been exceedingly useful -- I   think maybe I’ll try & get myself a beige skt. here & we   shall not be likely to have many more tea parties now the   warm weather has come -- We’ve never heard any more abt.   Jessies strawberry party & we’re afraid he’s forgotten it.   He took us to a small one out at his bro. James’ night   before last. We went in a buggy & pair & came home by   moonlight—quite romantically -- The buggy is only used on   very romantic occasions, I believe. Its so nice here   moonlight nights—the ladies all dress up in their whites &   sit out on the front door steps, & go round [seeing?] one   another with beaux or beau less just as it happens.Has Fanny Drinker gone home? I reckon she has & where is   Cous. Sarah? Give my love to her if she is about still. I   ought to have written to her. Give my love also to all the   Wynndowners also please give my love & congratulations to   all the bride cousins & tell them I’m very sorry not to be   giving them anything-- Maybe if I aint so lazy I’ll make em   something after I get home. But dont tell em that. I believe   this is all I have to say at present—will write and fix the   day of course before I come. If Cous. M. comes soon please   send the shawl and the [b----] skt. as I [---] much love to   all—yrs. affec

ClemmyI shd. be pleased to have some [---] my return & also before   my return

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Recipient:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Date: 1833-10-17
Title: 1833 October 17, Bloomsdale, to William D. Cope

Bloomsdale Oct. 17th 1833.
   
   "I long have thought my absent friends, a something to have sent you,
   Tho' it should serve nae other ends, than just a kind memento."
   
   Thy letter bearing date of twenty seventh of last month- came to hand after some detention- and has determined me to set about writing immediately- as I owe it, both to my duty, and my feelings, to send a speedy reply to thy communication- containing intelligence of a nature- which astonished & vexed me not a little.  I was astonished, thee should suppose me to be the author of that document, styled by thee, the "witty letter;" and vexed, that any one should descend to such meanness- as thus to endeavour to practice upon thy credulity.  As for me, I must disclaim all knowledge or connection with it in any way- and I do not envy the person who could be guilty of such an action- any of the wit it displayed- or grammatical learning- which if I understood thee rightly it is woefully deficient in.
   
   By the bye, I am much indebted for the compliment, of having so fine a piece of wit and learning, attributed as the production of my hand and pen- at the same time I will frankly own- from some expressions in thy letter- I think the shadow of a doubt more than [---] crossed thy mind as to my being in reality, the author.
   
   And now the question is- who can have been the offenders and against whom are we to direct our honest indignation? for I assure thee I feel no small share- I have not the slightest idea who it can be and yet some one it wd. seem, who had some knowledge of the circumstances- must have had a hand in it.  I think the want of learning displayed- could only have been a part of their plan to avoid detection- and not from real ignorance of the rules of grammar.  I've a womans curiosity to see the letter, and know all about it.
whether the writing resembles mine- if 'twas dated B........ with my name appended to it; all of which enquired I hope to have answered.
   
   The says in thy letter- ro please the ladies- thee must not broach serious subjects- if thee wishes to please my ladyship- and thee has professed as much- thee may make choice of any subject- whether "sober prose, or prose run mad"- I shall not object to anything and 'tis quite a mistaken idea- that ladies are never pleased with serious subjects- notwithstanding the author of the witty letter to the contrary.- Although thee may think there is very little like sobriety, or a disposition to moralize, in my character- I think my heart can duly appreciate and respond to good sentiments, whenever it is my good fortune to meet with them.
   
   Have we not had a very delightful Autumn?  such beautiful weather for riding or walking- and yet we have not availed ourselves of the bright sunshineand pleasant air- to make any rambling excursions in the woods or along by the banks of the river- the scattered foliage is already strewn upon the pathway- and in a few short days- we shall have the bare and leafless branches- telling us of the desolation of natures beauties.  Spring has always been my favorite season- but in all its gaiety and animation- it could not spread a scene more showy or more varied than the one now before us- such a happy blending of colours- but we have no beautiful hills or fertile [---]- where nature at this season appears so prominently beautiful.  In the "far off country" which thee inhabits- there must be every variety and beauty of scene- but then the distance is such a barrier- so many hundred miles from all ones friends-  I almost wonder thee has not been tempted to move within the reach of those thee holds most dear---
   
   I am sorry thee has experienced any uneasiness onaccount of having read to me those New York letters;- since it is so- I regret thee favourd me with a sight- at the same time I feel very certain of not having betrayed the confidence reposed in me- and have not the most distant idea who the lady can be.  I think the young lady- with so many [trunks?] – must have played the coquette very skillfuly- to have secured so many offers in so short a time- she knew her power I suppose- and was determined to excersize it- at the expense of her numerous admirers- Before I close my letter I must not forget to acknowledge the receipt of two newspapers- sometime in the month of August- for which accept my thanks the tale which they contained (the title of it I forget just now) I quite admired.--  The other day I met with something which pleased me exceedingly, in one of [Lardners?] papers.- It was an essay on lovers- and described the different kinds of lovers, most admirably- I recognized more than one or two, or three of my acquaintance in the descriptions.  I wd. like them to see it.-  I must now conclude my letter- as I have already written more- than I expected to- or that can afford thee much interest in the perusal.  with [---] of    rememberance-
   I remain sincerely thy friend,
   S.....
   
   Thy letters have all been duly received- Pray admire the beautiful direction- especially the D.10 Mo. 24 at Montrose
   
   William D. Cope.
   Woodbourne
   Susquehanna Coty.
   
   From S.
   date Oct. 17. 1833.- ans'd 10 mo. 18. '33
