Title: 1834 March 10, Bloomsdale, to Wm D Cope

I am giving thee dear William- a proof of my sincere and unabated affection- in this early replying to thy most welcome letter of the 8th which only came to hand this morning- thee may be sure its arrival was awaited by me, with more than usual impatience- I could not believe another week wd. be suffered to elapse- without the accustomed message of love, and rememberence,- and every day I wd. say to myself well- I certainly will hear to day- but very many times have I been doomed to suffer disappointment- how however- I am relieved by the actual presence of the well known hand writing- and will thus evince my greatful feelings- in its early acknowledgement.-  Let me tell thee dear William- I think thee greatly undervalues thy epistolary talents, thy letters cannot be any thing but interesting to me- and if I acknowledge them to be so- why that,- must be as much as thee can desire- as for my own I have long since despaired of arriving at any thing like excellence in the art,- and the only and slight merit- if merit it may called- which they posess- is the spirit of affection which they [---], & which prompts me to the undertaking I have not the least partiality for the employment thee knows- and often with merely for the purpose of receiving in return.-  To day I was [---] gratified & delighted- for independent of the pleasure thine afforded me- there was one from my dear sister Caroline.  I will not tell thee what she says, now- but when thee comes- thee shall see it.- I do not know that I recollect to observation thee alludes to- as having been made by me- when last here- at least I am not certain what it was.- The will find in me as usual- a very ready and willing listener to all thee may have to communicate- I hope my presence will not prove talismanic and cause thee to forget what thee had to say- I did not find it necessary to apply to Father for information respecting the time of holding our monthly meeting- it has just passed, last week- and the next oneoccurs- on the ninth of April- The [---] is- the first fourth day after the first second day in the month.- I had a sweet little note from cousin Edith the other day- it contained an invitiation for us to come, or rather go out to make them a visit- I knew it wd. not be very pleasant just now and in my answer, declined the invitation for myself- and promised to deliver the one to thee when next we met- Edith styles thee, her "cousin elect" already.-  What an appalling spectacle the burning of the Wm Penn must have been- It will have an effect I think, to increase the fears of [---] travellers-.  How sorrowful I felt, upon learning of the death- of R.B. [Thornson?], during her life we had each of us, made attempts to become better acquainted- but were never very successful- and now in her death, I feel as if I had almost lost a dear friend- her family will feel her loss to be irreparable- I should like to have some particulars of her death- I trust it was a happy one- holding out consolation to her afflicted and berieved family-.  Dearest Wm. I must now say farewell! as it is fast-approaching [---] 6 o'clock- and I am encroaching not a little [---] the time usually devoted to the indifference of my friends [---]- with a thousand assurances of undiminished affection
   remain as ever thy own
   S.
   
   March 10. 1834.
   
   P.S. If thee wd. like to avoid the observation of a certain person in B. who is always upon the look out- thee can do it by going up the street where the market is and round by the [?-nch]*- I hear of our engagement from all quarters- will thee excuse the brevity of this letter- I write this evening because time will not permit to morrow.  again
   Adieu!
   *tis very little further
   
   I cannot make the direction come in the right place.from S. [1834]
   dated 3 mo. 10. 1834.
   
   [---]no 6
   
   Wm D Cope
   36 N. 4th
   Philadelphia

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1833-06-27
Title: 1833 June 27, Philadelphia, to S.

Thy letter of 25 inst. I have just rece'd & feel a deep sense of gratitude for thy kindness in answering my last to thee. I had made arrangements for my departure for Woodbourne early tomorrow morning, but I shall postpone my return thither in order to see thee tomorrow. I should come immediately, were it not my plans require some change. I should have left this vicinity with much regret, without having had another interview with thee, and I cannot now think of doing so, without trying to do everything in my power to remove unpleasant feelings, and substitute those of a better kind in their place. I shall make thee a full & renewed avowal of my sentiments & feelings to and in regard to thee, and shall acknowledge my past errors. for such indeed they would seem to be, when viewed in the abstract. I must confess, tho' perhaps the acknowledgement will not serve as an extenuation, that as remarked by thee, I am inexperienced with regard to that part of human nature, comprehended in the female character. I shall repose entire confidence in the safety with which I may communicate with thee, and will thee not Dear Susan do the same in regard to me? let us consider that the heart of each is to be a sacred secure depository of the thoughts & feelings of the other. do, Susan, let me see thee look cheerful. it wounds me deeply to see thee otherwise. May we realize the truth of the last but not the first lines of the following stanza:The greatest joys those seldom prove,   Who free from quarres live.   O! tis the sweetest part of love,   Each other to forgive
   
   Let us cast the veil of oblivion over everything that has taken place of an unpleasant nature between us & begin anew, or rather continue as it were our acquaintance from its most auspicious & happy one.- Believe me, to be faithful & true and as heretofore, thy attached,
   
   W.D.C
   6/27/1833

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  George O. Walker:  b. 1838
Recipient:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Date: 1876-11-20
Title: 1876 November 20, Woodbourne, to Clementine Cope. Connymead

Woodbourne 11 mo. 20. 1876
   
   My very Dear Friend, 
    Clementine Cope, 
   
   Wilt thou be So kind, as to go with me to Florida, about the middle of January next? to that delightgul clime! 
   
   Where the Rose & Catalpa forever Shall bloom, 
    Where the chase cannot tire, nor the deer ever fail 
   Nor the mockingbird's music, 'ere cease in the vale. 
   
   For the sake of enjoying thy pleasant, agreeable company I will pay all expenses there & back. 
   Have long thought, there was not another person in this World, I would prefer to Dear thee! 
   Long Since, I was captivatedby thy winning ways agreeable manners & fine Sense! Thee was always so gentle, true & kind!
    "Alive to every tender feeling, 
    To deeds of Mercy always none, 
   The wounds of pain & sorrow healing, 
    With soft compassion sweetness to me. 
   
   No proud delay, no dark suspicion, 
    Taints the free bounty of her heart, 
   She turns not from the sad petition, 
   But gentle, aid at once impart." 
   
   "To know thee, is to love thee! 
   Thou Knowest that I love thee." 
   "Love & love only is the loan for love. 
   Wilt thou not reciprocate my love? 
   & concent to unite thy destiny with mine? 
   It will always be my greatest de
   -light to consult promote thy happiness
,    I do not approve of long engagements, (does thee?)Our time in this world is too,
   Short to be long in forming its 
   Most happy connection. 
   
   I think our habits, manners, tastes dispoistion are similar & therefore congenial! 
    
   Whilst Dr. Norris his amiable Wife, Sister, Mother & Aunt were here, they cheered my solitude very much by frequently inviting to dine, take tea &c. which I enjoyed. 
   
   Since their depeature for the City, I feel quite lonely & the want of agreeable, cultivated female Society. Some Person that I can love & be kind to, as I have always loved Dear thee, in Sincerity & truth! 
   
   Therefore, wilt thou not return my love & consent to marry me by Friends Cerimony, before going to Florida? Let that be thy Bridal tour? Please write me soon to allay myMy anxiety my suspense & say on what day next week it would be most convienient for thee to favor me with an interview at thy own comfortable home at Connymead & say also at what day & hour it will be convenient to send your carriage to me at your station.
   
   Thanks to kind Providence I am now favored with good health & hope you all will long continue to enjoy the same blessing!
   
   With Love to thy Sister & that love for Dear thee which neither time nor distance can efface.
   
   Ever truly thy sincere & loving friend- Geo. Walker

Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1883-07-01
Title: 1883 July 1, Awbury, to wife

Awbury 7 mo1. 83
   
   My very dear wife, 
   
   I am writing at home before meeting so as to take the letter with us to meeting and mail it. This is a very cool morning the thermo at 6.40 standing at 56° and although it has grown considerably warmer since yet it is still quite cool. Oh! my dear how I wish I could see you I do love you so. I feel quite anxious to hear how you are but suppose I shall hear nothing now until I see Tom--I had indulged a vain hope that somehow I might spend the fourth with you but there is so much to do at the office that I could not leave just at that time but I am hoping I can get off so as to come on the latter part of the week, but don't count on it too certainly but I will if I anyhow can. They want me to spend the fourth down in Maryland and I think I shall although it will hardly pay as I shall not be able to go down until the 5 o'clock train third day evening or early fifth day morning. I enclose a letter I received from Kate this morning it came enclosed in one to Madgie. I do hope you are getting along comfortably and are all well--give my love to the family. I paid John's wife the $25 yesterday. Thee can tell him that they were all well.Mother had a postal yesterday from aunt E. Brown she is still at the [Rigi?] something and expects to stay there all summer she seemed in good spirits. I am ashamed to say that I have not been over to call upon the Newhalls yet but from reports they are very much pleased with the place. There mother seems stronger and sleeps better. I am afraid dearest my letters are very stupid- writing every day there is not much chance for a collection of news but then thee knows each one contains any quantity of love and sympathy and dearestI feel that we are growing nearer and dearer to each other all the time and it is such a comfort. Margaret is still at Awbury but expects to go home tomorrow-morning. The carriage has just come up so I must bring this to a sudden pull up.
   
   With dear love to the children and lots for thyself I am dearest they loving husband
   
   J Evans

Title: [1805-1809?] to Henry Cope, Weston

Dear Henry

I have been writing or rather Scrawling to   William and Caroline, & thought I would Stain a little more   paper, how is our dear Francis He has had an afficting   trying time, I hope it will be the last, and thee has had   thy Share in simpathising with him, and attending on him   which I hope will have its use thee sertainly will have thy   reward for thy kind attention to an afficted brother, give   my best love to him I want much to see you, I expect to see   the in a few weeks I hope I Shan’t be disapointed we are all   faver’d with Health, the Rebeckah is come and I expect has   made a good voige I dont know of any thing new to tell you,   with Desires for your wellfare I remain your Affectinate   grangmother

Rachel DrinkerFor
Henry Cope
Weston

Title: 1911 April 2, Awbury, to Lilly

Awbury –
April 2.nd.

Dearest Lilly –
I don’t   know what thee has thought of me for not thanking thee   before for thy Most generous Contribution to our Collection   for the Colored Summer Home –  it came on the day of the   evening when Jonnie was stricken. & I forgot about it   entirely until the following Tuesday, the day of our   Collection, & I should have sat downright then & written. but Anna was writing to thee & I sent   a message. & thought I would wait until I had more time to   write a longer letter.  but that time has scarce seemed to   come until now!  We have just finished dining at Mother’s –   & while Mother is engaged in her usual occupation with the   dishes in the pantry. I had sat down in the library with Tom   & Will who are both reading. to write to thee.  Anna was so   long ingetting her letter off to thee.  I imagine the Contents told   everything up to within a day or two –  Chellie is very   wonderful,– perfectly calm & like herself –  but she looks   badly – & I fear as the days go on & she realizes more &   more what has happened. that she will show it even more –   but she is blessed with four devoted Sons who are looking   after her in every way –  Miss Richardson of Course, as thee   knows is with them – & they kept theNurse, whom they had for Jonnie, until yesterday.  Anna too   keeps well. & so far is entirely natural – but Miss   Richardson watches her like a hawk. & never lets her be   alone long – they want her to go away.– but she does not   want to.– & Miss R. told me yesterday that they would not   insist upon it – which I am glad of – for I think we cannot   always judge what is best for others at these   times.
Mother, I am thankfulto say, is very well – & with Anna & my being here   alternately she has gotten along very well with the new maid   whom Anna got for her – but of course she is not a Companion   – or a trained nurse – and I think we are going to be able   to get Susan Stewart out next week for a few weeks until she   (Susan) goes to the Hospital –  We may be able to keep her   until Mother goes to North East, but thatI Cannot say –  Chellie was in hopes that Mother would   [heed] this nurse who has been with her this week.  & if she   liked her to have her go to Northeast with her.  but Mother   was strongly opposed to it –  I think largely because she   was a stranger – now we had proposed Miss Moses’ name.  &   she wants her –  So I expect she will be gotten –  I had had   a talk with her. & she is entirely willing to undertake it   if she is wanted. & both Mother & Tomseem to want it – tho’ Tom says he wants nothing except what   Mother wants –  The trouble is about Miss Moses she will   have to [leave] Mother to be home by the first of October –    I am quite sure she will be a very devoted nurse – and I   think it will be very hard for Mother to let her go –  I   only wish we could get a permanency –  Before Jonnie died   Miss R. had told Mother that she would come back to her in   the fall. & I think Mother ishoping for that –  but I feel that is not to be counted   upon.
Please forgive such a lenghty epistle –  Mother has   now returned from the pantry – the men have departed & I   must say goodbye to thee –
Please give my love to Ellie &   much for thyself –
from thy loving sister
[Care]

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1867-08-26
Title: 1867 August 26, Newport, to father

Newport 8th. mo. 26th. 1867.

Dear father
I rec’d   thy letter 5th day morning.  Thy accounts quite make me wish   to see England some time although I dont know that that time   will ever come.  On 4th day we sailed round Canonicut, and   since Lilly says she has given thee a condensed account of   our trip, I will copy our log by way of variety.  The   officers were: Capt. Geo. F Merritt, 1st mate T.P. Cope Jr   2nd mate A Cope Jr; Seaman T.K. Longstreth, Cabin boy F.H.   Cope.  Steward M. C Collins.  Cook V. Hartshorne and 6   passengers, A Newhall, M Newhall, M Farnum, H Carter, M.   Collins, & E.S. Cope.
Log of the Canonicut Party – Yacht   “TCope [Deferred]”
(Rations limited)
Started from the   pier at 8 1/2, A.M., arrived at the lighthouse at 8.40.   there met M.C. Cope and party in a row boat, who wished us   joy,and desired us to report all new discoveries; soon after we   commenced telling fortunes.  2 m. of 9 o’clock saw a   porpoise on the starboard side.  9.22. off fort Adams,   weather, calm, thin canopy of clouds, at this moment it was   proposed to “put more steam on.”  Three persons forward of   the “Lobster Box.”  progress, “slow but awfully sure.”  10.   o’clock, interesting information concerning the compass, by   Capt. Merritt.  surf seen at Bever Tail, fears entertained   for the health of the party.  Some excitement caused by the   appearance of two fish, which produced restlessness on the   part of the cabin boy –  10.11. opposite the Dumplings.  11   o’clock opposite Castle Hill the game of quintettes played   with interest by the 1st mate, cook, and several of the   passengers; the steward seiged with headache – at this time   doubts were expressed by the captain as to the probability   of the winds changing before 6 P.M. weather still calm.  [8]   m after 11. met a sailing vessel commanded by captain Henry   Merritt, rowed by the capt. and sculled by Henry Merritt jr   who hailed us, and threw a small lobster into the boat one   of the passengers was badly bitten which caused great   excitement untill she was rescued from the jaws of the   carnivorous creature.  11 1/2 A.M. Slight windthe South and visible, stood off to welcome it.  Party   regaled themselves with rations. 12. M. South wind   continues.  candy handed.  Met a schooner and were saluted   by a dog on board.  Long swells, health good.  12.10.   conversation on the weather prohibited– a number of the   passengers retired to rest – Cabin boy reclining on a   passenger–  cook on the dinner basket–  1st mate absorbed in   a book.  12.45. Point Judith lighthouse in sight.  After   serious consideration it was decided to pursue our journey   on which account three cheers were given.  12.50. Passing   Bever Tail.  three more cheers – passengers happy – saluted   by the horn and a towel was waved to us, which compliment   was returned passengers waving handkerchiefs.  2. P.M.   Dinner – great dispute on the subject of ringing the   triangle.  2.45. from “Lobster Box” end–  dinner   accomplished satisfactorily leaving the voyagers in a   quiescent state of mind–  dinner consisted of 9 courses   closed with sour-drops–  opposite M. Williams’- Bay   comparatively speaking very rough!  Fast passing Wickford –   Slight excitement Fortunes being told again aft. The 1st   mate has just restored the cabin to order, after dinner.    Aft becoming very impudent.  Bow hair dressing.  1st matesweeping and thereby discomboberating all – 2.55. Patience   in sight.  sentiment in the bow, 3.12. Approaching the end   of Canonicut Greenwich off the larboard bow.  Patience and   Rocky Pt. ahead.  the breeze delightful, and all of the   party very comfortable, some reading, some working zephyr   work.  3.20. Rounding the north end of Canonicut.  Three   cheers given by all the party.  3.35. P.M. Rounding   Canonicut.  Newport in view – on our homeward trip – breeze   good.  some of the party wishing to land we are going to (we   did’nt) 3.38. Met the Providence steamboat- Needless anxiety   on the part of the passengers.  Now dashing gaily towards   Newport.  3.55 Proceeding fondly – just played games of   authors and consequences.  3 m. of 5.P.M. off the   Lighthouse. health good.  Fine breeze- Band tuning up for a   song before we reach the pier.  Arrived at the pier at   5.P.M.  On first day evening we took a walk to Tammany Hill.   we started after a 6 o’clock tea but were not able to get   there untill dark or dusk.  It is the first time I was ever   there.  We saw the lights at Point Judith, the Light Ship,   Bever Tail and the Break water.  Yesterday was splendidlyclear.  In the morning we took a short float, I cant call it   a sail there wasn’t any wind, after which we went bathing.    In the afternoon I made up a small sailing party consisting   of Alice Carter, Abby Newhall, Tom Longstreth and Alfred, we   went out to the Dumplings and landed, & afterwards came back   to take Caroline Mary her first sail.  She could’nt have had   a more pleasant evening it neither too cold nor too warm, &   there was a splendid breeze.  We went around Rose Island and   got back in good season.  though not strictly obeying her   mothers instructions about being home at half past 6.  This   morning we went bathing as usual and also engaged the boat,   Alfred preferring to go to Coddingtons Cove to bathing.    Thee will observe that I’ve been getting about as much good   out of boating as possible this season.  Since we arrived   Alf has become a staunch friend of Geo. Merritt’s and Hazen   of Geo. Barlow’s. Its quite remarkable how devoted Alf is,   he spends the big parts of his time at the reading room with   George.  This morning I got a new key fitted, formy valise, having lost the other since my arrival.  We were   not able to mail these letters in time to go by the [La---]   so they will have to take their chance by going via New   York.  There are 24 folks going to Philadelphia the night we   go, which will make a pretty effectual change in Mary   Williams’ boarders, and there will be no one left but Tom   Longstreth to do the honors of the occasion.  We are rather   puzzled as to what to do if we were left by the 7 o’clock   train from New York, since the 10 o’clock train has been   taken off the line.  We will have to run the risk, I   suppose, of getting the 8.40, Washington train, stopped at   Frankford.  Having run out of news and since mother is also   writing I will stop.
affecty thy son
T.P. Cope Jr.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Eleanor Cope Tyson:  1807-1847
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope:  1794-1863
Date: 1831-08-01
Title: 1831 August 1, Philadelphia, to Sister

Philada 8th. mo 1st. 1831

I dare say, my dear sister,   thee has felt inclined since we parted, sometimes, to apply   to me the old adage with regard to promising people vis.   that, 
“A ready maker
Is a ready breaker:”
since   the offer to write to thee was entirely voluntary on my   part, and yet I have suffered two weeks, nearly, to pass   without making an effort to fulfil my engagement.- As usual,   I am rich in excuses--the most prominent of which, is the   impossibility I found in obtaining a certain direction to my   letter; and either imagining the epistle, when completed,   would be too valuable to be thrown away, or else deeming, (I   did not stop to analyze feelings), my time too precious to   be expended upon that which would profit my correspondant   nothing, I concluded to defer writing altogether, until   Henry came up to this, our quarterly   solemnity.---

And now, having got thro’ the most   important and generally most stupid part of epistolary   communications, vis. the preface, let me dash at once into   my stock of news, and  cull for thy benefit such pieces of   information as will be likely to interest thee. I greatly   fear the selection will be a small one, for summer is a   particularly unsocial season, unless it is with our most   intimate friends and of course, we hear but little of what   is passing in
the world without.- I suppose thee will say it is respecting   the movements of friends thee would wish to be informed; and   if they would only do something, in the least degree, and of   the common line, I should take great pleasure in   transmitting an account of it to thee; but they are all   pursuing their usual routine of occupations, enjoying   themselves in a most provoking state of quiescence, and   doing and saying nothing that would give use to any   comments.----- Maryann tarried about two weeks at [Calcon]-   Hook, and she says passed her time very pleasantly,   notwithstanding the ungracious sounds, issuing from young   master Frank’s mouth, which occasionally saluted her   maidenly ears.-- I believe she could say, very pathetically,   “I am never merry when I hear such music,” she thinks, I   imagine, that we need never apprehend consumption in the   case of our little nephew, adopting, as I opine she does,   Anna Braithwaites favorite maxim that all our faculties,   bodily as well as mental, may be “strengthened by reason of   use”.-- Father, Mother, the aforenamed cousin, and myself,   spent a day with Caroline not long since.-- She seems quite   comfortable and very well; she is fattening on cottage   cheese and “lovely, rich cream.” and fortifying her bodily   powers by riding frequently on horse-back- Her darling son   looks admirably, walks boldly  alone and chatters at a most   rapid rate.* [Note at bottom edge of page: “lest thee should   be led into the mistake of supposing him, even a more   marvellous child than he really he is, I must state that his   conversations are carried on in a language peculiar to   himself, and are quite unintelligible to ordinary   hearers----“] I must do him the justice to say that he   behaved himself very gentlemanly during the whole period of   our visit and struttedabout in his apron of thy purchasing, (with which, by the   bye, he is delighted), with quite the air of a person of   importance---------

We had a considerable collection   of friends at our mansion during the whole time of the   conference—Jeremiah Hubard and his wife, two female friends   from Providence, and cousin A. Barker lodged with us, and   they attracted others during the day—so that we had a real   miniature yearly meeting-- With the consignment from your   house, we were all, I believe, much amused—Oh! if thee had   but been present at the relation of their courtship given by   the husband, and heard the gentle, deprecatory tone in which   the wife endeavored to ward off the narration, & the very   singular intonation of her voice in her exclamations of “oh,   Jeremiah, now dont”!! It was absolutely irresistible!—She   has now gone with “cousin [Nat]” to visit her relations in   Virginia, and her better half has taken refuge from the   intolerable heat of our city, at Joel Woolman’s.—Now this, I   should say was “a bitter change, severer for severe,” for a   more exposed, comfortless-looking country dwelling I have   seldom seen than the residence of this same   milkman.--------

I hope the purchases I have made for   thee will prove satisfactory—the cambric, I procured as   nearly like Henry’s cravat as I could.—Do take notice of the   beautiful picture on the cologne water bottle.- I have often   heard of the angel of health coming with healing in his   --
wings, but the idea of being kicked into “salubrity” (to use   Caleb’s phrase), is quite novel, and from the position in   which the ministering spirit here stands, I should suppose   the virtue lay in his heels—Uncle Jaspar’s family have been   very regularly heard from.—Abbeyann is much better but   Uncle’s eye still continues bad and they fear he will be   obliged to have an operation performed when they reach   Cincinnati.- I saw Martha on sixth day and never saw her   look better--- Mother is somewhat improved—She and Father   have at last fixed upon this week for leaving home.- the   latter part of it I expect.—Mary Stokes is added to the   party---- I have almost filled my sheet and have not said a   word about the fire we had had—It was “horribly beautiful”   but terribly allarming 

Rachel R. Cope
DealI must refer thee to Henry for particulars.---- I am glad to  hear the boys areenjoying themselves-- Give my love to them and tell them not  to be tooventuresome.-- I dislike apologies about letters, but in  looking over this I cannotbut be struck with the triffling nature of its  contents.—However, the weather is too warm to be  intellectual, even supposing I had it in my power, and it is  only on rare occasions that I am sentimental. Such as it is,  I hope thee will deem it worthy an early reply to thy  attached sister
Eleanor

Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879

Title: 1858 August 4, to Ruth Anna Cope


Awbury 8 mo 4th [1858]
Fourth day night

Dear   Nanny,

Its frightfully late, and if I say so--thee   may be sure it is late; my eyelids have told me so sometime   since, and bed, over yonder, looks wonderous inviting--but   remembering Uncle's last injunction to write-- I begin forth   with, though thee must'nt expect much from sleepy folks--I   only am going to deliver Uncles message, which I have tried   to remember and transcribe exactly in his words-- "We only   desired thy return with Edward Biddle, thinking thee might   not have another opportunity for some time, if thee chooses   to run the risk of another escort do so--" I have just been   repeating this to Cousin Frank & he says, oh tell Anna there   will be some way of her getting home and to stay longer, if   she wishes it--We
do not want thee at home till thee gets better--and get   along pretty well without thee, I don't suppose Aunt Rachel   fares quite so well as if thee were here--but I do try to do   my best--Cousin Elizbt's letter of last eving told thee she   was'nt quite well--she is some better to-day--and I hope   tomorrow will be better still--(Oh my! There--I've actually   fallen asleep over my letter--thee wont feel much   complimented I'm afraid) Tell Clemmy we got her first   letter--and think we are very remiss not to have   ex[patiated] on its sweetness for [-]
Wellm [--rsis]   Mother is on--some of us have called upon her yet--somebody   must tomorrow, as she returns home Seventh day.
George   sends his love--and I expect the folks generally would,
I forgot to ask them--
Farewell--I'm so dreadfully   sleepy--thine Julie--

Oh my! I must wake up and tell   thee we got letters this afternoon--Cos Thos expected to   start in a sailing vessel from Havre on the 24 or 26th--So   he's on the ocean now--tossing about--Poor fellow! Frank was   travelling about in Scotland when last heard from, and   cousin Thos has advised him to return in a steamer thinking   he could not reach Havre time enough to sail with   him--Is'ent this too bad--to come home this way,   piece-meal--Cos Thos seems real blue--but rejoicing at the   thoughts of home. he cannot be here before 30 days, Uncle   says,
what a long time to wait--Is'ent it-- The [----] of love to   Clemmy and Aunt Susan--and all the rest--tell the two former   I hope they are attending to their [-obes]--the 29th is most   here--and they're both going to have written   invitations--they're names are down on the list--but the   invitations are not written yet--
Anna thee must come   home prepared to be very bright, and help me to remember my   friends those to whom I must send cards--Cousin John thinks   he cannot have his children now--tho he would like to go up   for thee very well, if they [---] well--They are very   restless at nights--We expect Uncle Edward 6th or 7th   day.--


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Mary Stokes:  1825-1847
Recipient:  Elizabeth W. (Elizabeth Stokes Waln) Cope:  1780-1852
Date: 1839-03-06
Title: 1839 March 6, to Elizabeth W. Cope, Philadelphia

3d moth 6th 1839

My Dear aunt

I expect this   will be the last letter I shall write to thee this session   as the time is drawing near when we shall go home.  we are   now reviewing and it is not so hard as I expected it would   be  we have to be very industrious [about] our studies as   some of them are very hard particularly the history and I am   very much afraid I shall fail in that at examination as the   greater part of it I have not learned for I have not been in   that class, all the session.  Thomas Kite’s wife is here   spending a day or two and her daughter also.  I suppose thee   has heard of the little boy who has been so ill here he was   taken with the measles and that layed the foundation for the   consumption and after suffering for a long time he was taken   away at three o clock in the morning of the first of spring    we had no school on six or seventh day but we all went to   our school rooms and red our bibles and on seventh day   morning we were taken into see his corpse and he was buried on seventh day afternoon   his name was Nathan Comstock and he was an orphan he lived   in Lockport New York  he has a brother and sister here and   his sister is a lovely girl but I know very little about his   brother.  Benjamin Sharpless was here to thee funeral and he   asked me if I had ever seen him at Tommy Cope’s and I told   him no., but I have often heard of him.  I am looking for   uncle Samuel to come and see me as he has been away so long   and I think he might come to see me this session
Aunt   Lydia is not at all well she has a very bad cold and a good   deal of pain in that lump on her face and she keep her bed   the greater part of the day but she is rathe better at   present than she has been lately  I think she would of been   better if she had not of gone down to supper last night   through the cold entry.  I have some things to write for and   I do not think I shall have any more time to write to thee.    Cousin L sends her respects to all of you. but I send my   love to all be lieve me as ever thy affectionate   niece

Mary Stokes JrThomas P Cope 
For Elizabeth W Cope
No 272 Spruce St 
Philadelphia

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1867-07-28
Title: 1867 July 28, Laurel House, to Father

Laurel House
7th mo. 28th. 1867.

Dear Father
Lilly and Chelly having been keeping up such an active correspondence by the last two steamers, I thought I would reserve my efforts untill they had got through. 
We received a letter from uncle Tom inclosing a letter from thee informing us of the loss of thy masticators, it      would have been remarkably unfortunate if thee had not had      an extra set with thee.  I hope by this time thee is      enjoying thyself on terra firma, but since the difference of      time between where thee is and where we are is so great, we      find it hard to guess what thee is about.  We received letters from home last night, dated the 25th., saying they   were all well and preparing to leave for Newport on 5th day.   Mother had also received a letter from thee mailed at   Halifax
On last 6th day we rode to Stony Clove, an   entirely new place to me, about 10 miles distant.  The road   is quite rough, and runs between two mountains, one of which   rises almost perpendicularly about 1000 ft, as near as we   could judge, and on each side there are large rocks under   which we found ice: they say the sun never gets there and   the ice under the rocks never melts during the summer.  On   approaching this place the air becomes perceptably cooler   and on leaving it becomes warm again.  We took dinner at a   little farm house and although it was plain weenjoyed it very much.  After dinner we had to leave right   away for home.  Going back we had a splendid view of those   distant mountains you see on your way to the Plauterkill   Clove.
Yesterday morning we, that is Tom Stokes, Harry,   some other gentlemen and myself, walked down to Bastion   Falls to take a bath, thee remembers what a fine basin there   is at the foot of the falls, well it was there we went in;   the water was pretty cool on first going in but after we had   been in a little while, and had kicked around a good bit we   got quite warm and all in a glow.  We went under the fall   where it hit the rocks for a second time, but even there the   water stung like hail-stones, and I preferredthe pool to getting such a warming as that.  In the      afternoon we walked over to the Mountain House to see the      view, on starting it was beautifully clear but when we had      gone about half way, two clouds, very considerately, came      rolling down upon us, one from North and one from South      mountain, and by the time we got to the precipice both the      view and ourselves were completely mistified; we accordingly      went into the House and got weighed, and since thee will not      object to hearing how much some of the members of thy      immediate family weigh, I will give thee part of the      table:
R.R.C.  125 lbs.   E.S.C.  98 lbs.   T.P.C.  90      lbs.     Rachel has gained 7 lbs. since last sum- mer, and its becoming quite dreadful; I'm afraid, if she      goes on gaining, we will be obliged to have her put up in a      barrel and roll her home from Newport.  Tom Stokes, Ellie,      Madjie, and Walter are going home tomorrow morning: the rest      of us expect to leave here fourth day and go to Albany, we      will stay there that night, and go to Boston the next day;      leaving Boston 6th. day afternoon we will arrive at Newport      in time for tea.  I suppose mother has told thee that she      succeeded in engaging both the Georges during our stay      there.  The weather here has been very warm and showery; to      day it is very pleasant but it has been so very showery we      were afraid to try going to walk. Aunt Lizzie received two letters from the Adirondacks to      day one from cousin Clemmy and one from aunt Annie, giving      an account of a trip which they had taken to lake Placid by      the way of John Brown's grave; aunt Annie said the grave was      very plain, there was a tombstone with some engraving on it      and on a boulder nearby was the plain inscription "John      Brown - 1859."  She also said cousin Clemmy was a good deal      stronger and was able to bear fatigue as well as the rest of      them  They were both very much surprised to hear of thy      sudden leaving for England.  Lilly and Chelly send their      love.  We are all well and have had a most splendid time      considering that our "pa" is on the other side of the Atlantic and now having given thee   all the news I can remember I will   stop.
affectionately
thy son Thos P. Cope Jr


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas S. Brown:  b. 1828
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1839-11-10
Title: 1839 January 10, West Haverford, to Anna S. Brown, Philadelphia

1 moth 10. 5 day 1839
Dear sister

I hope you are      all well, My cold is quite well.  Freind Mary Davis sends      her love to Mother.  I am glad to hear that Aunt Ann is so      much better and, I hope that she will continue so, and I am      glad also that thee is getting well enough to walk out  How      is Aunt Hannah and uncle Thos, and Harry  Where is Williams      slipers  I think ought to be done.  It snowed last night      there a little.  The green house is nearly finished but the      plants are not yet aranged. we have had some pretty good      sleding.  It is tirsome work to write a letter, Dan B Smith      give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they      are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as      thoes that thee expects to attend  he showes us so many      pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to      have a kiss from Fanny  I will send her one down below  I      expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to  I      [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and      part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou  I remain thy aff brother
Thos S      Brown
Kiss


Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them.  He has beguiled some of the hours of his confinement      in doors, by reading “Rollo’s vacation” to me – & we have      found it quite entertaining –  I think it arrived just at      the right moment –  So much for Thomas –.  now for Willie –      with whom I am becoming better acquaintedas the ice is now broken – & he frequently pays us a visit      in our parlor –  He tells me – he is more comfortable than      formerly – & that the cause of his unhappiness is re-moved –      what this cause was, I do not know – but he looks so      pleasant & happy that I am inclined to believe he is not      depressed by any great weight of troubles –  They are very      different boys but both have found means to interest me      warmly for them – & I think I shall not soon cease to love      them – Tom is sitting by me begging me to proceed – but the      end of my paper warns me that I may already have tired thee      – therefore will take the hint after desiring my love to thy      mother – and assuring thee of
the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.



WestHaverford
Jan 11th.
 
Jeremiah Brown 
Philadelphia
For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning      and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee      for some time  I am glad to see that thee is so much better      than thee was when I last heard from thee  I was astonished      to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea      that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts      that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much.       Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in      this letter  I was disapointed as well as thyself for I      expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we      all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company      staid out a half an hour  I hope when thee gets perfectly      well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one      of thee boys  I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with      her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet      in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete      baby house with old black [---] amongst them  I hope by the      next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly      well  I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the      holy land in two volumes by an American  I found it very      interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a      botany for William but I never received it and I should like      to know wether you sent it or not  Tom is very much pleased      with his present  I have no more room sister so I will haft      to bid adieu at present  thine [ever] – W.A. BrownI thought I would haft to stop but Elisabeth Davis proposed      to me to cross it  I have accordingly done it  The snow as      not yet left us and we had a little more on 4th day evening      last  How is mother and father I have not heard from them      for sometime somehow or other thee always leaves them out in      thy letters  Aunt Rachel is better [she] says  I should like      to know what is the matter with her for her diseas seems      very changeble  dont thee think dear sister that it is      singular that I never write to my Aunts and uncles for most      other boys do  I have never yet attempted it however I      suppose it is just as well that I should not but I think I      would like to write to Grandmother or father some of [these]      days but I dont know I dont suppose that I should hardly      know how as I never done such a thing.  My cold has now got      very well indeed at least It is all gone now.  I now often      go into Friend Davis’s parlour and I found it very pleasent       I am at present here and spend many a happ evening I expect      that they will be surprised to find three difrent hands in      this letter and I am rather inclined to think that it was      worth the postage.  I will now haft to end in good      earnest
Thy [Aff] Brother William A. Brown1 moth 10. 5 day 1839
Dear sister

I hope you are      all well, My cold is quite well.  Freind Mary Davis sends      her love to Mother.  I am glad to hear that Aunt Ann is so      much better and, I hope that she will continue so, and I am      glad also that thee is getting well enough to walk out  How      is Aunt Hannah and uncle Thos, and Harry  Where is Williams      slipers  I think ought to be done.  It snowed last night      there a little.  The green house is nearly finished but the      plants are not yet aranged. we have had some pretty good      sleding.  It is tirsome work to write a letter, Dan B Smith      give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they      are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as      thoes that thee expects to attend  he showes us so many      pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to      have a kiss from Fanny  I will send her one down below  I      expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to  I      [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and      part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou  I remain thy aff brother
Thos S      Brown
Kiss


Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them.  He has beguiled some of the hours of his confinement      in doors, by reading “Rollo’s vacation” to me – & we have      found it quite entertaining –  I think it arrived just at      the right moment –  So much for Thomas –.  now for Willie –      with whom I am becoming better acquaintedas the ice is now broken – & he frequently pays us a visit      in our parlor –  He tells me – he is more comfortable than      formerly – & that the cause of his unhappiness is re-moved –      what this cause was, I do not know – but he looks so      pleasant & happy that I am inclined to believe he is not      depressed by any great weight of troubles –  They are very      different boys but both have found means to interest me      warmly for them – & I think I shall not soon cease to love      them – Tom is sitting by me begging me to proceed – but the      end of my paper warns me that I may already have tired thee      – therefore will take the hint after desiring my love to thy      mother – and assuring thee of
the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.



WestHaverford
Jan 11th.
 
Jeremiah Brown 
Philadelphia
For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning      and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee      for some time  I am glad to see that thee is so much better      than thee was when I last heard from thee  I was astonished      to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea      that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts      that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much.       Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in      this letter  I was disapointed as well as thyself for I      expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we      all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company      staid out a half an hour  I hope when thee gets perfectly      well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one      of thee boys  I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with      her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet      in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete      baby house with old black [---] amongst them  I hope by the      next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly      well  I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the      holy land in two volumes by an American  I found it very      interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a      botany for William but I never received it and I should like      to know wether you sent it or not  Tom is very much pleased      with his present  I have no more room sister so I will haft      to bid adieu at present  thine [ever] – W.A. BrownI thought I would haft to stop but Elisabeth Davis proposed      to me to cross it  I have accordingly done it  The snow as      not yet left us and we had a little more on 4th day evening      last  How is mother and father I have not heard from them      for sometime somehow or other thee always leaves them out in      thy letters  Aunt Rachel is better [she] says  I should like      to know what is the matter with her for her diseas seems      very changeble  dont thee think dear sister that it is      singular that I never write to my Aunts and uncles for most      other boys do  I have never yet attempted it however I      suppose it is just as well that I should not but I think I      would like to write to Grandmother or father some of [these]      days but I dont know I dont suppose that I should hardly      know how as I never done such a thing.  My cold has now got      very well indeed at least It is all gone now.  I now often      go into Friend Davis’s parlour and I found it very pleasent       I am at present here and spend many a happ evening I expect      that they will be surprised to find three difrent hands in      this letter and I am rather inclined to think that it was      worth the postage.  I will now haft to end in good      earnest
Thy [Aff] Brother William A. Brown1 moth 10. 5 day 1839
Dear sister

I hope you are      all well, My cold is quite well.  Freind Mary Davis sends      her love to Mother.  I am glad to hear that Aunt Ann is so      much better and, I hope that she will continue so, and I am      glad also that thee is getting well enough to walk out  How      is Aunt Hannah and uncle Thos, and Harry  Where is Williams      slipers  I think ought to be done.  It snowed last night      there a little.  The green house is nearly finished but the      plants are not yet aranged. we have had some pretty good      sleding.  It is tirsome work to write a letter, Dan B Smith      give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they      are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as      thoes that thee expects to attend  he showes us so many      pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to      have a kiss from Fanny  I will send her one down below  I      expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to  I      [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and      part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou  I remain thy aff brother
Thos S      Brown
Kiss


Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them.  He has beguiled some of the hours of his confinement      in doors, by reading “Rollo’s vacation” to me – & we have      found it quite entertaining –  I think it arrived just at      the right moment –  So much for Thomas –.  now for Willie –      with whom I am becoming better acquaintedas the ice is now broken – & he frequently pays us a visit      in our parlor –  He tells me – he is more comfortable than      formerly – & that the cause of his unhappiness is re-moved –      what this cause was, I do not know – but he looks so      pleasant & happy that I am inclined to believe he is not      depressed by any great weight of troubles –  They are very      different boys but both have found means to interest me      warmly for them – & I think I shall not soon cease to love      them – Tom is sitting by me begging me to proceed – but the      end of my paper warns me that I may already have tired thee      – therefore will take the hint after desiring my love to thy      mother – and assuring thee of
the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.

Jeremiah Brown 
Philadelphia
For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning      and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee      for some time  I am glad to see that thee is so much better      than thee was when I last heard from thee  I was astonished      to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea      that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts      that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much.       Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in      this letter  I was disapointed as well as thyself for I      expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we      all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company      staid out a half an hour  I hope when thee gets perfectly      well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one      of thee boys  I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with      her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet      in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete      baby house with old black [---] amongst them  I hope by the      next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly      well  I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the      holy land in two volumes by an American  I found it very      interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a      botany for William but I never received it and I should like      to know wether you sent it or not  Tom is very much pleased      with his present  I have no more room sister so I will haft      to bid adieu at present  thine [ever] – W.A. My cold has now got      very well indeed at least It is all gone now.  I now often      go into Friend Davis’s parlour and I found it very pleasent       I am at present here and spend many a happ evening I expect      that they will be surprised to find three difrent hands in      this letter and I am rather inclined to think that it was      worth the postage.  I will now haft to end in good      earnest
Thy [Aff] Brother William A. Brown

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William A.  Brown:  b. 1824
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1839-11-10
Title: 1839 January 10, West Haverford, to Anna S. Brown, Philadelphia

1 moth 10. 5 day 1839
Dear sister

I hope you are      all well, My cold is quite well.  Freind Mary Davis sends      her love to Mother.  I am glad to hear that Aunt Ann is so      much better and, I hope that she will continue so, and I am      glad also that thee is getting well enough to walk out  How      is Aunt Hannah and uncle Thos, and Harry  Where is Williams      slipers  I think ought to be done.  It snowed last night      there a little.  The green house is nearly finished but the      plants are not yet aranged. we have had some pretty good      sleding.  It is tirsome work to write a letter, Dan B Smith      give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they      are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as      thoes that thee expects to attend  he showes us so many      pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to      have a kiss from Fanny  I will send her one down below  I      expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to  I      [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and      part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou  I remain thy aff brother
Thos S      Brown
Kiss


Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them.  He has beguiled some of the hours of his confinement      in doors, by reading “Rollo’s vacation” to me – & we have      found it quite entertaining –  I think it arrived just at      the right moment –  So much for Thomas –.  now for Willie –      with whom I am becoming better acquaintedas the ice is now broken – & he frequently pays us a visit      in our parlor –  He tells me – he is more comfortable than      formerly – & that the cause of his unhappiness is re-moved –      what this cause was, I do not know – but he looks so      pleasant & happy that I am inclined to believe he is not      depressed by any great weight of troubles –  They are very      different boys but both have found means to interest me      warmly for them – & I think I shall not soon cease to love      them – Tom is sitting by me begging me to proceed – but the      end of my paper warns me that I may already have tired thee      – therefore will take the hint after desiring my love to thy      mother – and assuring thee of
the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.



WestHaverford
Jan 11th.
 
Jeremiah Brown 
Philadelphia
For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning      and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee      for some time  I am glad to see that thee is so much better      than thee was when I last heard from thee  I was astonished      to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea      that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts      that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much.       Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in      this letter  I was disapointed as well as thyself for I      expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we      all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company      staid out a half an hour  I hope when thee gets perfectly      well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one      of thee boys  I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with      her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet      in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete      baby house with old black [---] amongst them  I hope by the      next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly      well  I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the      holy land in two volumes by an American  I found it very      interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a      botany for William but I never received it and I should like      to know wether you sent it or not  Tom is very much pleased      with his present  I have no more room sister so I will haft      to bid adieu at present  thine [ever] – W.A. BrownI thought I would haft to stop but Elisabeth Davis proposed      to me to cross it  I have accordingly done it  The snow as      not yet left us and we had a little more on 4th day evening      last  How is mother and father I have not heard from them      for sometime somehow or other thee always leaves them out in      thy letters  Aunt Rachel is better [she] says  I should like      to know what is the matter with her for her diseas seems      very changeble  dont thee think dear sister that it is      singular that I never write to my Aunts and uncles for most      other boys do  I have never yet attempted it however I      suppose it is just as well that I should not but I think I      would like to write to Grandmother or father some of [these]      days but I dont know I dont suppose that I should hardly      know how as I never done such a thing.  My cold has now got      very well indeed at least It is all gone now.  I now often      go into Friend Davis’s parlour and I found it very pleasent       I am at present here and spend many a happ evening I expect      that they will be surprised to find three difrent hands in      this letter and I am rather inclined to think that it was      worth the postage.  I will now haft to end in good      earnest

Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them. the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.

For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning      and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee      for some time  I am glad to see that thee is so much better      than thee was when I last heard from thee  I was astonished      to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea      that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts      that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much.       Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in      this letter  I was disapointed as well as thyself for I      expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we      all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company      staid out a half an hour  I hope when thee gets perfectly      well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one      of thee boys  I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with      her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet      in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete      baby house with old black [---] amongst them  I hope by the      next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly      well  I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the      holy land in two volumes by an American  I found it very      interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a      botany for William but I never received it and I should like      to know wether you sent it or not  Tom is very much pleased      with his present  I have no more room sister so I will haft      to bid adieu at present  thine [ever] – W.A. BrownI thought I would haft to stop but Elisabeth Davis proposed      to me to cross it  I have accordingly done it  The snow as      not yet left us and we had a little more on 4th day evening      last  How is mother and father I have not heard from them      for sometime somehow or other thee always leaves them out in      thy letters  Aunt Rachel is better [she] says  I should like      to know what is the matter with her for her diseas seems      very changeble  dont thee think dear sister that it is      singular that I never write to my Aunts and uncles for most      other boys do  I have never yet attempted it however I      suppose it is just as well that I should not but I think I      would like to write to Grandmother or father some of [these]      days but I dont know I dont suppose that I should hardly      know how as I never done such a thing.  My cold has now got      very well indeed at least It is all gone now.  I now often      go into Friend Davis’s parlour and I found it very pleasent       I am at present here and spend many a happ evening I expect      that they will be surprised to find three difrent hands in      this letter and I am rather inclined to think that it was      worth the postage.  I will now haft to end in good      earnest
Thy [Aff] Brother William A. Brown

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Elizabeth H.  Farnum:  1814-1898?
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1839-11-10
Title: 1839 January 10, West Haverford, to Anna S. Brown, Philadelphia

1 moth 10. 5 day 1839
Dear sister

I hope you are      all well, My cold is quite well.  Freind Mary Davis sends      her love to Mother.  I am glad to hear that Aunt Ann is so      much better and, I hope that she will continue so, and I am      glad also that thee is getting well enough to walk out  How      is Aunt Hannah and uncle Thos, and Harry  Where is Williams      slipers  I think ought to be done.  It snowed last night      there a little.  The green house is nearly finished but the      plants are not yet aranged. we have had some pretty good      sleding.  It is tirsome work to write a letter, Dan B Smith      give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they      are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as      thoes that thee expects to attend  he showes us so many      pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to      have a kiss from Fanny  I will send her one down below  I      expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to  I      [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and      part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou  I remain thy aff brother
Thos S      Brown
Kiss


Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them.  He has beguiled some of the hours of his confinement      in doors, by reading “Rollo’s vacation” to me – & we have      found it quite entertaining –  I think it arrived just at      the right moment –  So much for Thomas –.  now for Willie –      with whom I am becoming better acquaintedas the ice is now broken – & he frequently pays us a visit      in our parlor –  He tells me – he is more comfortable than      formerly – & that the cause of his unhappiness is re-moved –      what this cause was, I do not know – but he looks so      pleasant & happy that I am inclined to believe he is not      depressed by any great weight of troubles –  They are very      different boys but both have found means to interest me      warmly for them – & I think I shall not soon cease to love      them – Tom is sitting by me begging me to proceed – but the      end of my paper warns me that I may already have tired thee      – therefore will take the hint after desiring my love to thy      mother – and assuring thee of
the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.



WestHaverford
Jan 11th.
 
Jeremiah Brown 
Philadelphia
For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning      and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee      for some time  I am glad to see that thee is so much better      than thee was when I last heard from thee  I was astonished      to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea      that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts      that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much.       Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in      this letter  I was disapointed as well as thyself for I      expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we      all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company      staid out a half an hour  I hope when thee gets perfectly      well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one      of thee boys  I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with      her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet      in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete      baby house with old black [---] amongst them  I hope by the      next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly      well  I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the      holy land in two volumes by an American  I found it very      interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a      botany for William but I never received it and I should like      to know wether you sent it or not  Tom is very much pleased      with his present  I have no more room sister so I will haft      to bid adieu at present  thine [ever] – W.A. BrownI thought I would haft to stop but Elisabeth Davis proposed      to me to cross it  I have accordingly done it  The snow as      not yet left us and we had a little more on 4th day evening      last  How is mother and father I have not heard from them      for sometime somehow or other thee always leaves them out in      thy letters  Aunt Rachel is better [she] says  I should like      to know what is the matter with her for her diseas seems      very changeble  dont thee think dear sister that it is      singular that I never write to my Aunts and uncles for most      other boys do  I have never yet attempted it however I      suppose it is just as well that I should not but I think I      would like to write to Grandmother or father some of [these]      days but I dont know I dont suppose that I should hardly      know how as I never done such a thing.  My cold has now got      very well indeed at least It is all gone now.  I now often      go into Friend Davis’s parlour and I found it very pleasent       I am at present here and spend many a happ evening I expect      that they will be surprised to find three difrent hands in      this letter and I am rather inclined to think that it was      worth the postage.  I will now haft to end in good      earnest
Thy [Aff] Brother William A. Brown1 moth 10. 5 day 1839

It is tirsome work to write a letter, Dan B Smith      give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they      are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as      thoes that thee expects to attend  he showes us so many      pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to      have a kiss from Fanny  I will send her one down below  I      expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to  I      [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and      part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou  I remain thy aff brother

Haverford–
My dear Anna
I      promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his      letter, inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill      the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I      shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding      page –  Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or two, in      consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye –  It was      occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in      the hand of one of his companions, & seem’d at first rather      disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application      of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly      that it occasions no inconvenience, & is but slightly      discoloured –  He seems to think that eye is particularly      unfortunate, as it is the same one which was hurt some time      ago –  I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about it,      as we shall try to take all necessary care of him, if any      more is needed –  In regard to being careful himself, he      needs some few cautions, tis true – but I will tell it to      his credit, that for an active, adventurous little boy he is      very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises      to adopt it, is, I believe, very scrupulous in fulfilling      them. the friendship of thy      affectionate
E.H. Davis.
