Title: 1859 August 18, Awbury, to My dear Chellie

Awbury 8 mo 18th 1859

My dear Chellie

As Dr Rhoads very kindly offered to take this note to thee, I thought perhaps thee would like to hear how thy little brothers are getting along at home and therefore take the opportunity to send a few hasty lines.  Alfred was very happy in a few minutes after papa and Willy & Tom left us; I went to ride with uncle Thomas the latter part of the afternoon, and took him along, we had a few errands to do in Germantown.-
Uncle Alfred & Aunt Rebecca Cope with Annie, called to see us yesterday afternoon and we had a very pleasant visit from them.  Uncle Alfred's knee is still rather troublesome, but his foot is better.  Cousin Edward is going to the WhiteMountains with uncle Edward Yarnall & Aunt Caroline, very soon.  Tell Aunt Lizzie that I saw grandma Brown at meeting this morning, she told me they were all pretty well except Ridgely and he was threatened with [cramp?] last night, but was much better to day, indeed quite relieved; they sent for Dr Rhoads who saw him again this morning before grandma came to meeting.  Tell papa that wonders will never cease, Aunt Mary Haines & mamma are going to spend this evening with Ann Haines to meet B Yarnall's family.-

in great haste
affly thy mother

A S Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Alfred Cope:  1857-1897
Recipient:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Date: 1875-07-04
Title: 1875 July 4, Lake Windermere, to Tom & Scrubby

Lockwood Hotel   Lake Windermere
   July 4. 1875
   
   Dear Tom & Scrubby.
   
   I did write a few lones to thee Scrubby from Kendal but I rec'd such a nice letter from thee last Fifth day that I concluded to send thee a longer one; & as I have already rec'd two letters from Tom I thought it would be well to kill two birds with one stone-so here goes-We saw the first of this lake last Fourth day afternoonand will continue to see it till sometime tomorrow.  I haven't the slightest idea where the picture, at the head of this sheet, is taken from;- but I know one thing & that is that I have not as yet seen anything like it nor do I think that there is such a view.  At any rate it gives you no idea of the place.  Now for the narrative- We took a row on the lake soon after arriving here & on Fifth day took the steamer down to [Bowness?] where we expected to get on a carriage & drive over to Coniston.  When we arrived there, however, the sky looked so threatening & Alexis not feeling very well we concluded to leave it till next day, & returned to Louwood.  Arriving in a heavy shower we were at a loss to know what to do, till I decided to go over to Keswick & get our letters that were probably awaiting our arrival there.  So as the stage did not go till 3 o'clock I drove over to Ambleside, bought a full rubbersuit (coat leggings & cap) hired a horse & started off, about 1 o'clock.  You can imagine me clothed in these things sitting on an awfully rough trotter nothing of my usual self being visible except my eyes, nose & mouth, and my shoes.  The suit answered admirably, keeping me perfectly dry in the hardest thunder-storm I was ever out in- Except my shoes wh. in a few minutes were rather soggy.  However it was soon over & I arrived at [Derwentwater?] Hotel, [Portinscale?] at 4 P.M. having ridden on horseback 19 miles.  Here I obtained, first a lunch then the letters, one from each of you.  While waiting here another gust came up & when it had gone over the sky looked brighter & more settled.  So having engaged rooms for 2nd day, at 6 P.M. I set off & had a most beautiful ride past [Thirlmue?] & Helvellyn, Grasmere & Rydal Water back to Ambleside wh. I reached at half past eight.  Drove downto our hotel, took some red-hot tea & then went out to hunt for Lilly & Alexis, whom I found spooning in a bench & who told me that there were three other pairs in the hotel worse off than we were.  Sixth-day we set off for Coniston Water, driving alongside of Windermere & crossing below Bowness, through Hawkshead where Wordsworth went to school & finally reached Coniston where Lillie & I made the tour of the lake in the steam Gondolee as they call it while Alexis ascended the "Old Man."  We had the best of it for, although he immortalized himself by leaving his name & address in full on top of pole of stones which has been placed there, yet he was caught in such a dense fogthat he couldn't see anything & in turn caught a species of chill & fever, from which he is slowly recovering.  Yetserday we went through Grasmere & Rydal & got Lillie pretty well played out.  We rowed down Grasmere Lake & walked to Rydal Mount, (wh we did not see, exceptone window & the chimney's) Lillie & Alexis "preferring rather" to keep on a level while I crossed over the hill from wh. I got an elegant view of Windermere, Rydal Water, Grasmere & [Tharlmere?] besides some small 'towns' and the mountains on all sides.  On coming down I overtook Lou & Alexis spooning by the roadside, On my coming up they had began to talkpleasantly about the weather, Lillie suggesting that it was much cooler than the 3rd of July 2 years ago, at wh. both looked remarkably pleased & mysterious.  I looked very innocent but on making "comparative mathematical calculations" have concluded that it must have been that day they drove over from Connymeade together & took two hours & a half (2 ½ hrs) by the watch to get up to the house from the stable-   

   It’s fearfully hard to get Lillie up in the mornings.  She grumbles incessently because Alexis & myself will order breakfast at half past eight & uses as anargument to the statement, (I wont say in fact) that Father when he was over here did not breakfast till nine.  Another instance, Tom of the force of example.  However we dont give in & in revenge she gener-ally keeps us waiting 15 or 20 minutes.  Alexis thinks it is a good thing that we travel from place to place, as they must think wherever we go that it is a mere accident that we are late.  This miserable climate dont seem to suit me very well.  In the first place the voyage knocked me, clean; for I caught cold some how wh. increased my sore-throat & I haven’t got rid of it yet.  It steadily increased till I got to Warwick wh place seemed to agree with it; for it has been improving since.  Then I had a boil on my skin which troubled me not a little when I ran against anything or Alexis hit me with his umbrella.  I have got it down to a pretty fine point now however & one is coming on my backjust between my shoulders so as to afford me an opportunity of displaying my skill in twisting my arms around.  Beer dont seem to be the thing for me at present, & I have hardly tasted it since leaving Liverpool.  As to the roast-beef, it tastes very much like the same article at home, and they put so much mint with the peas to make them green I suppose that you cant taste any thing else.  But the great charm is that every thing is so nice & clean- no greasy knives &c  You must excuse this writing; but Lillie brought us out here on a most uncomfortable hill-side & insists on sticking it out.  We saw some very pretty little ponies when we were in Wales Srubby; but as we are carrying very small valises & they are pretty full we thought best to defer our purchasefor a season.  I commenced writing on this sheet as you may see but Lou thought it was so important to write on pictured paper that I gave in- Consequently the above marks- I hope that Hazen may succeed in getting up his party & also that he will not ruin the horses driving too much in the park.  I have just thought of a little map wh. I have in my packet wh. I shall enclose in this letter with 5th and 6th sdays excursions marked on them.  Although it may not interest either of you I think mother will like to see it.  I will now cook as it is time for me to be poking Lillie up to go down to dinner,   

   affectly your bro
   Alfred Cope Jr.[Derwentwater] Hotel.
   Portsinscale- Keswick
   7.7.75.
   
   P.S.
   
   2 1/2 P.M.
   
   Have just arrived here & rec'd a letter from T.P.C. Jr. giving a fair "a/c" of the baby, water-works & crops.  Also a bill from Holliday & Storrs I [---] amounting to the enormous sum of [Pound] 5.16.6.  I have come to the conclusion that he is not the man for me.  Lou gaps as much as ever.  This morning just as we were finishing breakfast she commenced raising her elbows to the same level as her shoulders (You probably remember that little habit) but I saw it in time & proposed to up to our rooms to stretch.  Please remember me to the baby- and Chellie.  Also to any other member of the family wh. happens to be at home.  I dont wonder John dont know know where you all are-   

   A.C.Jr.[Alfred's letters from Europe 1875-76   

letter

   Thos. P. Cope Jr.
   Cope Brothers
   Philadelphia
   U.S.A.

Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1867-09-24
Title: 1867 September 24, Awbury, to blue Brother

Let this be read a day or so after sister Anna & Lilly's letters have digested.
   
   Awbury 9 mo 24th
   3rd day eve
   our parlor table
   
   My poor dear blue Brother
   
   Sister E has just bee reading thy letter to Chelle dated Woodford 9 mo 8th and I am very sorry thee gets so down in the mouth, and could wish I had been along with thee- provided I was wanted and could have done thee good, not that I would place myself before some others Lilly, Chellie, &c, but then maybe thee would not have felt me so much on thy mind, as I think I should have been pretty easily contented even if I did have to stay pretty close by old London.  I would have at least been a "flesh & blood" companionand not one of the ancient curiosities the guide books introduce thee to.  Not to say how much I would have liked to have been along on my own account, and the many little bits of intruction I would have picked up by the way, Well!  not wishing to assume too much I thought maybe I would have been better than nobody.  But when it came to paying call on the Hartshornes and the like, thee might have left me behind, the grandees and I, I fear would not get along very well together, some of them at any rate.
   
   Well would thee like to know what we are about at home.  Brother T at present in scouring vigorously at our new plate glass windows which have justbeen inserted into our front door, sister E has settled down to reading after one of her daddy long-leg excitements, whilst the children are settling off to bed except Ellie, whom Lilly got to come down to your house to tea, Chellie being over at her Grandfathers, while Alfred, and Frank took tea with us, Here they come Lilly, Virginia and Dr Hartshorne as escort, Perhaps thee will scarcely think it worth while for me to write all this.  Sister Anna seems to be consulting various books, following thee in thy travels, she was showing me a picture of- let me see- the old wall of Portsmouth, which thee speaks of in one of thy letters, and this evening she is inquiring for "Old England."  Yesterdaybrother J and wife, with myself took an early start for Wilmington, to pay one of those stated visits to Hannah Richardson.  It was a lovely day and we had a very nice time, and thyself and thy movements were among other topics spoken of.  In the cars that morning I had quite a little talk with James Cox, who also was inquiring after thee, and though absent thou art not forgotten.  I do hope thee found Ellis Yarnall and party on the Continent- and has enjoyed thy trip, and hope it will do thee good, I really fear thee will not get near all the good of the trip we would like, when thee gets so worried, try to look beyond the present difficulty, and think perhaps it will come rightin the end, and then thee will be sorry thee had taken so much trouble, and not gathered more good by the way, And even if it dont turn out what you wish, there are so much greater troubles, that I would have thee try to brighten up.  I dont want thee to finish up with typhoid feaver, this sounds most too bad dont it?  But I hope by the time this reaches thee, thee will feel quite brightened up, with thy trip on the Continent &c.
   
   5th day the 26th.  There has been quite a gap in my letter, the time being taken up in various ways, This morning was meeting morning and a very interesting meeting I thought it, S Emlen addressing the children, and in the course ofhis discourse told an interesting incident relating to a little girl who died lately, and who I suppose was little Mary Rhoads, Charles Rhoads daughter.  I suppose sister Anna told thee of her death, she was only sick 24 hours, and taken insensible almost from the first I believe.  Mary Haines spoke of her as having been a child of the Saviour for a year past.  Samuel Morris followed S.E. in a solemn prayer for the "parents", I think we sometimes have our best meetings on 5th days.  After meeting I went to Aunt Martha's to dine, and have some conversation with her in regard to Eugenia & Samuel, who are now here on a visit.  Aunt Constantia is very anxious S should not return to Washington and we think it veryimportant he should not, but be placed at some boarding-school.  Lilly & Chellie have just come up here, & also brother J and sister M.  Chellie's tongue has been going pretty much like a bell clapper ringing for [fire].  -that last word is fire- thy daughter has been joging her old aunt's elbow, which must account for the above appearance.  General Sheridan comes to Germantown to night, Gtn is coming on.  I suppose he will make quite a stir.  And Gough is coming too [---]!  I have tried to write in the fashionable style of crossing the page but alas!  I have not succeeded.  I hope thee can read it.  Sister Mary says give my love to Frank.  What would thee think of seeing her [---] down by the banks of the BrandywineHer visit there seems to have made quite an impression on her, she goes from home so little, and sees so little of the rural, small things make quite an incident in her quiet life, but the Brandywine is pretty fair for all.  I have not told thee yet how much surprised, almost shocked I was by thy letter to me at E-town telling of thy intention of starting for Europe.  it was so utterly unexpected, and then I was so far away from you, and could not ask what thee had gone for, except I knew it was on business, and then I would have liked to have taken a more affectionate farewell of thee, it had been such a hasty one when thee left Elizabethtown.  We had a very nice time there, Clemmie improved very much I thinkthough she has some cough still at times but it was of very little account, if it had not been for her previous attack.  We visited John Brown’s grave amongst other places, and I have some maple sugar for thee from his place.  I hear sister A and Lilly are both writing, but it is impossible to find a time when there is not some one writing to thee.  So should my letter come in at the little end of the horn, may it at least prove to thee that thee is affectionately remembered by thy far distant but loving
    
   sister Ruthanna
   
   If it should come in thy way to procure an Irish [poplin?] dress for me I would be glad to have one, if they are not too very high, dont get it if over $4.00 per ydI send a pattern of the one I have had, a most excellent one, I would like a dark gray or mode shade, but without a blue or pink shadow in it, my present one has blue in it.  or I would like a pretty brown, but dont take any trouble about it- There may be a kind not-quite-so heavy & expensive as this pattern would be

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Recipient:  Sarah Miller Walker:  1799-1874
Date: 1873-01-27
Title: 1873 January 27, Connymede, to Sarah Walker

Connymede 1 mo 27
   2d day
   
   My dear friend
   Sarah Walker
   
   I little while ago Carry handed me thy letter to read- which was received today, and dated 1 mo 22d and 24th and asked if I would write to thee.  From the tenor of thy letter thee seems to think there has been an improvement is Uncle Wm's condition.  But though for a little while, since being in bed- he was able to take cream again, to some little amount, he is now very low indeed, and taking only a very little wine, about a teaspoonful at a time.  TheDr told them he might not live through last night.  I came over yesterday afternoon.  About 7 O'clk  the girls and Edgar were around his bed.  He was asking about one or two of them; and who it was at the foot of the bed?  when told it was Nettie, said he could’nt see- still I think there was but little light in the room- The remark was made that he had a good many kind children round him, I think he tried hard to say yes- but seemed unable, something like a slight spasm coming on, from that time for a while, it seemed as if he might be dying.  but he again revived, and was able to speak out quite loud during the night.  calling outhis wishes he does not seem able to modulate his voice.  He is very childlike and dependant upon those around him.  How frail we are truly!  Human nature seems to be utter weakness at such times.  He  has been generally & uncomplaining during his sickness, although within a day or two there has been some moaning, apparently from weakness he dont speak as if he suffers much.  He seems very appreciative of the attention of his friends.  I do not think any of them now look for his recovery.  And from present appearances, it does not seem likely the end is very far off and yet I feel as if it was hard to know how long it may be.  He is very very sick looking now.  By dear aunt Susans removal, pooruncle Wm seems of course more thrown upon his children, And it is indeed pleasant to see their kindness & attention.  dear Clemmie especially, [*] but perhaps I should not draw any comparison, but she is the oldest and has felt perhaps more responsibility, especially before her father was confined to bed, and others had stepped in to assist.  The girls seem pretty well and much composed.  Nettie is suffering with headache to day.  and Clemmie was a day or two ago.  Edgar does not look very well to me but he was up a good deal last night.  Alexis seems very well.  Of course thee knows the girls have been passing through a great deal.  but I hope the Lord has been near may an eternal inheritance be granted uncle Wm if he is taken
   
   *more striking with Clemmie than Carry & Nettie, because of her former shrinkingClemmie seemed much distressed and unnerved last evening, when her father seemed to be reviving again, and she had been in hopes it was almost over.  His groaning was distressing  to her.  but I do not know that he was suffering so much.  If it was suffering, I should suppose it was from weakness and distress.  Cousin Frank and Mary Yarnall have been very kind and attentive.  We are expecting brother Thos out to night.  I will now close this biding thee farewell.  I fear this is a very different letter from what it might have been had one of the girls written it.*  Affectionately thy friend
   
   R Anna Cope
   
   *they perhaps would have been netter able to tell of their ownsorrow.  I fear I am dificient in entering into the feelings of others, as some do
   
   Dear R.A. Cope
   with [---] of her
   dear Uncle passing
   away-
   1.31.73-

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Recipient:  Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas) Cope:  1850-1883
Date: 1876-04-14
Title: 1876 April 14, Delaware Water Gap, to Alexis & Lillie

Del Water Gap 4 mo 14th
   1876
   
   My dear Alexis & Lillie
   
   Shall your tardy Aunt Anne try to write you a bit of a letter from this substantial land perhaps to meet you in the land of antiquity, art, and beauty.  I cannot describe Pompeii, I cannot say I have been where Paul landed so long, long ago.  Yet give me the land of protestant vigorous American for my home, before stale Itily [sic]!  do you think that very unappreciative?  Do not suppose I think there is nothing of interest there.  There seems to me much of the spirit of this world which you may see when abroad, more than in our more practical land.
   
   Let me tell you I have thought of you and have been looking towards writing sometime.  I [---] say how gratifying it was toreceive  the little card remembrance sent from Mentone long since to me, I have been long in acknowledging it, but it was truly acceptable to Aunty  I have an idea I sent a message about it lately in some one elses letter.  As my own writing had been and seemed to be a poor dependance I had a short attack of sickness lately,- though I have not been very mighty for some time- and Dr Darrah suggested my going to the shore, but I prefered coming here.  I have Mary Creeth with me, she is pleasant company.  And I am glad to have the opportunity of hearing about dear uncle Alfred.  She seems to have thought very much of him.  The old home as it was with its inmates will be forever gone when you return- if so permitted- We know all is so uncertain.  What a wipingout!  James and Louise left for Oxford last 7th day week.  Mary Creeth thinks James much improved.  And we may hope his good traits will appear to his advantage.  He took articles of clothing with him belonging to his parents and one or two articles which he took of his fathers I was glad to hear of; it seemed to show an affectionate feeling connected with the old association.  Perhaps you heard that Philip and Lillie Garrett expect to take Fairfield this summer.  And John Biddle take Philip's house in Germantown this summer after it is vacated.I find it does not well answer to write on both sides of my paper so take another sheet.
   
   The streams are so beautiful this time we have been here, so much water & charmingly clear.  We have driven several times.  And I hope we are both gaining.  Has mother told you of the prospect of my keeping house at Atlantic City this summer?  With Jane Taylor for housekeeper.  If I get there I hope some of the family may feel it attractive enough to accept hopsitality under my roof.  The house is a private one, on the Avenue next above the beacth & between the Surf House and Denis' Cottage.  It has three rooms on each floor, and backs towards the ocean, with not as open a view of the rolling deep as I could desire.  What will be the result remains to be known.  Whether we get establishedand if so, how things will turn out?  I may not be there all the time even though I should be the back bone of The Rest by the sea.  Now my foreign relations dont feel too saucy about this sandy place.  I know it is not Mentone or the Bay of Naples.  But indeed I wish it had some rocks for the waves to dash over, and some greenness to add its beauty.
   
   St. Cloud Hotel Phila [---] I came direct to this place from the Water Gap and my own dear Lillie thy own nice letter to me came to my hand here.   I was glad I already commenced a letter to thee before thine arrived that I might be credited for my intention or wish to write whether there was any letter or not for me.  The Yearly Meeting opened yesterday, but I did not leave the Water Gap in time to attend the first sitting.  I arrived last evening & Madgiemet me here and stayed with me that night.  It is less exertion to remain in the city if you attend the meeting.
   
   19th The date of my letter will be rather old but perhaps it will make little difference to you.  Ellie came to stay with me tonight and George took tea with us, they have gone to call at George's uncle's.  Brother T. and sister E. Madgie and Clemmie dined with me to day also.  Mary expects to come tomorrow.  Poor Madgie is again troubled with her eye.  it looks very badly and it seems to be a serious affection which she is subject to.  Dr Norris allows her to go out though.  Anthony K. created an excitement in meeting to day, in persevering in reading a chapter in the Bible, suffering no indifference of friends to stop him said he had got the book 3 years ago with the intention of reading the chapter in meeting.  saying hethought he now had the strength to read it and expected to read it through, which I understood he did  I forget the chapter, but understood it was a prophecy against the unfaithful shepherds.  No one seconded him in this thing, at any rate not in meeting and I heard they afterwards had one of the best meetings they had had at all.  It is time for me to prepare for bed, I will bid you an affectionate farewell.  Give my love to Alfred.  And with love to you your affectionately interested
    
   Aunt Anne

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)  Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1876-04-14
Title: 1876 April 14, Delaware Water Gap, to Alexis & Lillie

Del Water Gap 4 mo 14th
   1876
   
   My dear Alexis & Lillie
   
   Shall your tardy Aunt Anne try to write you a bit of a letter from this substantial land perhaps to meet you in the land of antiquity, art, and beauty.  I cannot describe Pompeii, I cannot say I have been where Paul landed so long, long ago.  Yet give me the land of protestant vigorous American for my home, before stale Itily [sic]!  do you think that very unappreciative?  Do not suppose I think there is nothing of interest there.  There seems to me much of the spirit of this world which you may see when abroad, more than in our more practical land.
   
   Let me tell you I have thought of you and have been looking towards writing sometime.  I [---] say how gratifying it was toreceive  the little card remembrance sent from Mentone long since to me, I have been long in acknowledging it, but it was truly acceptable to Aunty  I have an idea I sent a message about it lately in some one elses letter.  As my own writing had been and seemed to be a poor dependance I had a short attack of sickness lately,- though I have not been very mighty for some time- and Dr Darrah suggested my going to the shore, but I prefered coming here.  I have Mary Creeth with me, she is pleasant company.  And I am glad to have the opportunity of hearing about dear uncle Alfred.  She seems to have thought very much of him.  The old home as it was with its inmates will be forever gone when you return- if so permitted- We know all is so uncertain.  What a wipingout!  James and Louise left for Oxford last 7th day week.  Mary Creeth thinks James much improved.  And we may hope his good traits will appear to his advantage.  He took articles of clothing with him belonging to his parents and one or two articles which he took of his fathers I was glad to hear of; it seemed to show an affectionate feeling connected with the old association.  Perhaps you heard that Philip and Lillie Garrett expect to take Fairfield this summer.  And John Biddle take Philip's house in Germantown this summer after it is vacated.I find it does not well answer to write on both sides of my paper so take another sheet.
   
   The streams are so beautiful this time we have been here, so much water & charmingly clear.  We have driven several times.  And I hope we are both gaining.  Has mother told you of the prospect of my keeping house at Atlantic City this summer?  With Jane Taylor for housekeeper.  If I get there I hope some of the family may feel it attractive enough to accept hopsitality under my roof.  The house is a private one, on the Avenue next above the beacth & between the Surf House and Denis' Cottage.  It has three rooms on each floor, and backs towards the ocean, with not as open a view of the rolling deep as I could desire.  What will be the result remains to be known.  Whether we get establishedand if so, how things will turn out?  I may not be there all the time even though I should be the back bone of The Rest by the sea.  Now my foreign relations dont feel too saucy about this sandy place.  I know it is not Mentone or the Bay of Naples.  But indeed I wish it had some rocks for the waves to dash over, and some greenness to add its beauty.
   
   St. Cloud Hotel Phila [---] I came direct to this place from the Water Gap and my own dear Lillie thy own nice letter to me came to my hand here.   I was glad I already commenced a letter to thee before thine arrived that I might be credited for my intention or wish to write whether there was any letter or not for me.  The Yearly Meeting opened yesterday, but I did not leave the Water Gap in time to attend the first sitting.  I arrived last evening & Madgiemet me here and stayed with me that night.  It is less exertion to remain in the city if you attend the meeting.
   
   19th The date of my letter will be rather old but perhaps it will make little difference to you.  Ellie came to stay with me tonight and George took tea with us, they have gone to call at George's uncle's.  Brother T. and sister E. Madgie and Clemmie dined with me to day also.  Mary expects to come tomorrow.  Poor Madgie is again troubled with her eye.  it looks very badly and it seems to be a serious affection which she is subject to.  Dr Norris allows her to go out though.  Anthony K. created an excitement in meeting to day, in persevering in reading a chapter in the Bible, suffering no indifference of friends to stop him said he had got the book 3 years ago with the intention of reading the chapter in meeting.  saying hethought he now had the strength to read it and expected to read it through, which I understood he did  I forget the chapter, but understood it was a prophecy against the unfaithful shepherds.  No one seconded him in this thing, at any rate not in meeting and I heard they afterwards had one of the best meetings they had had at all.  It is time for me to prepare for bed, I will bid you an affectionate farewell.  Give my love to Alfred.  And with love to you your affectionately interested
    
   Aunt Anne

Recipient:  William Forster:  1784-1854
Date: 1833-11-07
Title: 1833 November 7, Philadelphia, to William Forster

Philada. 11 mo 7.  1833
   
   William Forster
   
   Esteemed friend
   
   It is probable that my son Alfred, who is about embarking for Madeira for the benefit of his health, may visit your country on his return homewards.  Should he do so, I have a desire that he should call on thee.  He would like to be made known to some friends in England, among whom he would prefer to spend his time while among you.  He is an exemplary member of the religious Society of Friends, & I shall feel greatly obliged by any act of kindness & attention which may be shown to him.
   
   thy friend
   
   Thos. P. CopeWilliam Forster
   
   Alfred Cope
   
   [Introductn to W. Forster]

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  James Cropper:  1773-1840
Date: 1833-11-07
Title: 1833 November 7, Philadelphia, to James Cropper

Philada. 11 mo 7.  1833
   
   James Cropper
   
   Dear friend
   
   My son Alfred is about to proceed to Madeira, where he designs to spend the winter, for the benefit of his health.  & as he will probably visit England before returning to America, I feel desirous of making thee acquainted with him.  He will of course incline to be principally among friends, while in your Country, & I shall feel much gratified by thy making him known to some of them.  He is an exemplary member of the religious Society of Friends, & will be found worthy of their regard.  I need scarcely add how much I shall be obliged by thy kind attentions to him-
    
   thine
   
   Thos. P. Cope[Introductn. to Ja's Cropper]
   
   James Cropper
   
   Alfred Cope   Liverpoolobtaining a wife- Henry will doubtless inform thee of thy having another niece.  Rebecca Harrison is very ill & her recovery doubtfull- poor [---], she has been sadly afflicted since last autumn- one disease succeeding to another- until she has been suddenly attacked with inflamatory rheumatism- first in all her limbs, then in the region of the heart.  Thy dear mother takes constant interest in thy welfare & has been anxiously looking for advices from thee- She is much rejoiced to hear of thy safety.  Jane Bettle still lingers-
   
   Other calls compel me to come to a close.
   
   Recommending thee to the protection of that Power, which alone can preserve us from evil- & insure peace & comfort
    
   I am affectionately
   
   Thos. P. Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1806-1875
Date: 1834-02-28
Title: 1834 February 28, Philadelphia, to Alfred Cope

Philada. 2mo 28. 1834
   
   We have at last my dear son been favoured to hear from thee- thy Letters of the 21st 1mo having reached us 2 days ago- that is one to Henry & one to William.  These are all which have as yet been recd-  Much as all of us have been gratified to learn thy safe arrival at Madeira our pleasure would have been greatly increased to have some assurance of thy health having been improved.  We hope for the best & are thankful to find thou art spending thy time so agreeably- far away from the troubles which surround us on all hands- Our country is indeed in a very portentious condition.  Genl Jackson seems to be determined let the consequences be what they may, to crush the Bank of the United States.  & such is the foolish nay mad devotion of his immediate partizans, that they are as determined to support him, reckless as to the future.  To day we have a message from our Governor, to the Legislature, announcing the failure of his attempts to borrow money.  & labouring to throw the blame on the Bank- besides the injustice of this charge, he appears to be but little aware of the effect this will produce on money lenders at home & abroad.  Who are [---] thy set, & will be alarmed with fears that the state may not be able to pay the interest of its vast debt- Had he posessed the manliness to recommend the recharter of the Bk public confidence would at once have been restored, & with it the facility of borrowing.  He contemplated the stopage of the public works- Who will then be able to calculate the public loss?  There can of course be little or no income, & the works themselves must be injured if not ruined.
   
   Our family concerns are going on much as usual.  Thy brother Wm is in a fair way ofAlfred Cope
   
   Madeira
   
   [T.P Cope 2/28- recd 4/25 1834   [---] Spark]

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1806-1875
Date: 1840-08-25
Title: 1840 August 25, Newport, to Alfred

Newport 8mo 25. 1840
   
   Dear Alfred,
   
   It is growing towards being after sunset, but while Job is making arrangements for our departure tomorrow morning in the Massacheusetts Steamer for Providence, it falls to my lot to drop a line by Wm who is intended send with the Carriage & Horses next day, by return of the same Steamer to NYk thence to proceed on his way to Philada.-  You will all be gratified to hear of thy dear mothers improved health, & also of Eleanors- altho we have experienced hot weather for some days, & have qualms as to the propriety of throwing ourselves into a more heated atmosphere-  Stephen P. Morris arrived here yesterday from Providence, & reports the thermometer to have been up to 95 the day before.  The air since dinner to day has become cooler, & we may reasonably hope will improve a pace shortlty-  Other things change as well as the weather- & now after writing so far, a bell man announces that a Balloon Steamer is to be here tomorrow from P. & return again at 3 AM-  We wished originally to go by her- but she has undergone repairs, & there was this morning no certainty when she wd. be here-  We therefore had made up our minds to go by the Massachusetts between 6 & 7 AM-  We intend to visit N. Bedford, Boston, Wooster &c &c.  & stop at Hartford Ct where letters may meet us on our way home, not later than 10 days from today-
   
   We have visited most of the Lions- & among them the Library, where rest the remains of divers elderly volumes-  The discoveries of the Icelanders are there deposited-  We met in the St a certain antiquarian, named Bull, with whom we held learned converse on those discoveries-  On asking him if he had heard of the learned northener who had found a stone with Runic Characters- a temple, & an image representing the Scandanavian God Thor, in Brazil- He said he had not- & then added, "so long as they confined themselves to N. Am, I was willing to concede that point to them- but now that they are going to claim S. Am too, I wont believe any of it"-  The old man may have read our couplet- "They lose the whole who claim too much
    
   As Simon Snyder said in Dutch- And the Danes may now hang up their fiddle, & content themselves with their own Icy shores-The drives abt. Newport are fine- but we have too much dust- the grass is nevertheless very fresh- & the fields are beautiful- We visited a tract at Brenins Point, I side of the Island, & skirted by the Ocean- & a more fertile splendid farm, I do not remember ever to have seen-  They use the seaweed abundantly, as a manure- & also a fish called Manhayden- dragged from the Ocean by nets, & sold at 14 Cts a Bbl- They are very oily- but I do not admire the filthy practice of strewing them over the fields to contaminiate the air-  The bathing here is very good & Job & I use it freely- while mother & E continue their purifications in the warm salt bath-  Among our numerous lodgers we have had Abraham Knickerboker & wife- He the lineal descendant of the true Dietrich- & has his residence at the very spot described by Irving, whose description he says is very correct-  He is an intelligent and well informed man, speaking the English fluently- & his wife interested us very much, by her smiley face, he goodly appearance & good sense-  The good man himself is out of health, & his loving spouse seems very uneasy abt. him-  On leaving us they each gave us a cordial invitation to visit them at their home in the romantic poetical village of Schaghticoke-
     
   While writing Elenor bids me say- you have among you, used her [---] badly, in not even noticing a Letter- wh he took trouble- pains taking man- to endite to some of you- but as she has stepped out- I do not know when manufactured, nor to whom directed- Cara’s epistle of odds & ends- like this of mine- has been received, & was, for her comfort, very satisfactory-
   
   Having in council duly convened decided to go by the Baloon to morrow.  I have come to the conclusion to rest for the present from my labours- to resume if needs be, in the morning but not until I say that we this afternoon paid another visit to the afflicted family mentioned before- none of them are better- the mother indeed much worse- she seems destined we think to take her departure to a better world very soon-
   
   26th
   
   A bright cool air promising a pleasant [---] to Providence- A boarding House forms a pretty good epitomy of life on a larger scale- One generation passeth away & is succeeded by another- so old faces depart [---] & new ones present themselves- In all things said the great Apostle I am instructed- & so we may be even in this day- did not time hurry us with such Rail Road speed as scarcely to permit us more than a glance- Among our imates is a certain Judge Balch of Florida, a thorough going Loco- & reviler of sacred things- He attempted to show that the creation was the result of natural causes, combining & operating on each other- Moses' account he calls a fiction,the mere offspring of a fervid imagination.  He abounds in anecdote- mostly I suspect the product of his own fancy- His atheism offended Knickerbocker much- it shd. be Knickerbacker- marble baker-  I joked & talked politics with the Judge for a while- but finding when hard pressed he became rude, I quit it- yet shd. be amused with his profundity of discourse could I have faith in his word-  He stated for instance that he had furnished the Bk. US. with the first list of Directors for the branch at Nashville- all of whom "Me. Biddle appointed"- He did not however know that while making this statement to me & others he was addressing a man, who had been not only a Director of the Parent Bank at the time, but chairman of the Cme. of elections, who alone reported all nominations of branch directors, to the Board, & who knew the statement to be untrue-  I did not undeceive him, but left him to the enjoyment of his own fiction.  We had a short visit from a mercht. of Havanna- Cpa!  Clapp of the House of Drake, & Co an intelligent man, who, inter alia, gave me a piece of information entirely new, at least to myself- He says that a company of individuals, Spaniards & others, residents in Cuba have purchased a large tract of sand from a native Prince, in Africa, 150 miles square- wh. is to be cultivated with Coffe Sugar &c for commerce- the natives being the Labourers- should the designs of the Comp.y be honest, & fairly carried out- it will carry out Buxtons Scheme, & prove a great blessing to Africa- but considering of whom the Co. is composed, I cannot avoid fears.  C says the Coffee Plantations in Cuba yield but 6 or 7 Pct. while their Sugar Plantations give them 10- the slaves working 14 hours of the 24- The labour is so severe that when suspended, to take food, he has known the slave to fall asleep while on his feet, & prefer rest, even to eating- the waste of life is consequently great.
   
   The change in the weather has produced its usual effect- my E has a headache but will doubtless be better when the sun advances- by the way we have had but one or two foggy mornings since our arrival-  Job & I mean to experiment on a warm bath this morning deeming the sea air is too fresh for our skins-  Love to all- & sympathy in the bargain for any that have tooth ache or the like-
   Thos. P. Cope
   
   As there are so many at Lincolns who have nothing to do, we have half a mind & almost tother half tooto get our dander up for their wicked neglect open in not writing-
   
   I had just sealed this letter when Henry's of the 22d arrived- & have accordingly reopened it to make the acknowledgment- It is gratifying to learn of your continued good condition & of his having parted with his tooth ache- a most troublesome compassion-  I had not heard of any defaltations in the Kent.y Bank- nothing short of making such crimes felony can prevent them-  We have indeed arrived at a such state of morals-  Finding that the next mail goes via Providnce, I shall carry this letter there- & if anything worth penning occur
   
   will make proper not thereof-  We rece.d Franks letter of the 22d recording his & Toms marvellous escape from Hicksite contamination- tho I think they might have broken bread with J.B without fatal consequences-
   
   26th
   
   Here we are at Providence, after a run of abt. 2 hours from Newport-  We lodge at the City Hotel, a large & apparently well regulated House- we have formed no acquaintences but shall probably see some of our friends during the day- Our run up the Narragansett was not very interesting- the shores presenting little variety-  Bristol, Warren & a few neat villages were in view, but trees, those grand ornaments of nature, & wh. impart so much beauty to rural scenery & to City & Town comfort are sadly wanting-  This morn is bright & cool-  As yet we have formed no plans for the day-  When all are up we will hold a councilThe Town meeting to control the Courts is of bad omen- especially as the Judges are by our new Constitution subject for their offices to the popular will- These doings tend to anarchy and despotism, the fruit of Jacksonism- Fanny Wrightism &c[T.P.C. 8/26- Prove- -]
   
   [8/28]
   
   Henry & Alfred Cope
   Philada

Title: 1840 August 25, Newport, to Alfred

Newport 8mo 25. 1840
   
   Dear Alfred,
   
   It is growing towards being after sunset, but while Job is making arrangements for our departure tomorrow morning in the Massacheusetts Steamer for Providence, it falls to my lot to drop a line by Wm who is intended send with the Carriage & Horses next day, by return of the same Steamer to NYk thence to proceed on his way to Philada.-  You will all be gratified to hear of thy dear mothers improved health, & also of Eleanors- altho we have experienced hot weather for some days, & have qualms as to the propriety of throwing ourselves into a more heated atmosphere-  Stephen P. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas Pim Cope:  1823-1900

Date: 1852-07-17
Title: 1852 July 17, to Clemmie, Woodbourne

Philadelphia, 7mo 17, 1852
   
   Dear Clemmie,
   Grandfather desired me to acknowledge the receipt of thy acceptable letter of last seventh day. I am sorry for thy sake that it has not fallen into better hand, but if thee will believe that I have the will to send thee such a letter as would give thee a great deal of pleasure, I will rely upon the interest it will have for thee as coming from among and giving thee a great deal of pleasure. I will rely upon the interest it will have for thee as coming from among and giving thee perhaps, the latest news of some of those who think so much of thee. Anne and I entirely agree with thee in considering that the pleasantest part of the days journey was when we were all traveling together. We ran off the track about half an hour after we parted and were four hours in a pretty hot place before we were on our way again. If we had foreseen that we were to pass nearly the whole day on the road might have he fellow travelers a greater distance and lightened me and others burdens. Thee must have had a very tiresome journey all the way home Henry Drinker tells us thee had to ride from Wilkes-Barre in the hot sun in an open wagon: he thinks they did much better. When thee comes down next winder, take thou Scranton unto. We are glad to hear that thee friend Uncle William so much better and the rest all well. Grandfather seems stronger and generally better than when he fist came out in the country- He sends his love to thee and all the family. Aunt Caroline, Frank and Ellie are at Cape May. I forget whetherthey went before thee left: they wrote several days ago that Ellie’s general health was improved We have heard indirectly that Mary was unwell- Julia has gone to Reading for a few weeks. Aunt Mary returned to Jersey yesterday I believe- She was kept in turn an account of Elizabeth’s mother having an attack very much like if not really cholera. She was very ill one night: they have gone to Cape May since with Henry and Ellie. The three families that live in that unnamed corner of this country that is so hard to find am pretty much as the left them they all send their love. Elizabeth says she would be very glad if thee would write to her if thee fells so inclined. Please tell Uncle William that a package for Grandfather by Henry Drinker came safe to hand the morning- Uncle Alfred has taken the letter out to him. He comes in and spends every "third-day" in town.   
   I hope we shall hear from thee often; if thee should write to me it would give me much pleasure.
   
   Affectionately thy cousin,
   Thomas P Cope Jr.
    
   Germantown, 7mo 18, 1852
   
   Dear Clemmie,
   
   Not having a woman's privilege as to postscripts I begin afresh.  I have no objections however to having reason to call the by name again – it seems more natural and sociable and I see thee look up from thy work or from study or quiet wordto hear what I have to say- I finished in a hurry yesterday afternoon intending to mail this before leaving town, but time failing I have an opportunity to say that Anne secured a letter from Eddy last evening in which he says nothing about his bodily conditions, but that his discontent which she had inquired about are improving" Your visit no doubt did him good. Visits from home to a boy at school are a pleasant recollections for the rest of his life.
   
   Thee did not grieve much about they blanket shawl when thee was riding in the stage at night; it will be cooler when thee comes down next fall and we will take care to sent it up to thee in time. Grandfather will be glad to hear from thee and I hope if thee is not afraid of a repetition of what thy first letter has brought upon thee, that thee will write to [.]
   
   With many desire for thy happiness.
 Affectionately, thy Cousin,
   Thomas Cope Jr.

Title: 1829 May 11, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 5mo. 11. 1829
   Dear Brother:
   
   I reached this place after a pleasant journey, which occupied, as usual, 2 days.  I had pleasant company, & never before endured so little fatigue in crossing the Pokono.  the road over it is considerably improved.  I had the company of Jos'h [S?]inton  from Nazareth to Wilkes-barre.  he was on his return from attending the Orthodox Yearly Meeting.-  I was much pleased with the verdant appearance of the fields in this part of ye country.  ye season is much less advanced than usual at this time of year, but the grass looks well.-  there has not been so much done at my buildings during my absense as I expected wd. have been done, but ye workmen are now busily employed.  my Scotch farmer, I think it likely, will maintain the character of his countrymen for industry & fidelity, but I have not hired him long enough, fairly to test his qualifications.  ye female part of his family, however, it too numerous to suit me, as I have but little employment for women.-  tho' I have but little to communicate, I tho't I wd. not let a private opp'y pass without informing you of my safe arrival here & present health.  I shall feel anxious to hear from the invalids of thy family, tho' I hope they are not now invalids.-  I hope also that our new Mother may, by this time have regained her usual health.-  please give my love to all my kind friends & relatives, with whom I have so recently passed so many pleasant hours, that ye chain of communication between us, though separated, seems unbroken & strong.-  if thee shd. see Uncle Jasper please tell him, that I delivered his letter to Henry Colt, but that John N Conyngham had left Montrose before I arrived.  I therefore immediately forwarded the letter for him, to Wilkesbarre, & have little doubt but that he received it before leaving there for Bradford County.   I remain thy affectionate brother,
   Wm D CopePlease say to Eleanor, that I hope she will not mention to Cousins Abby Ann & Emma, any remarks that I made with regard to the evening company invited by them a short time before I left the City & of which I was one.  such observations are sometimes repeated under circumstances that give them an air of more seriousness than was intended by the one who makes them.[Note in second hand: W.D. Cope Woodbourne 5mo 11 1829]
   
   [Note in third hand: Journey home & personal allusions-"Our new Mother," etc., Scotch farmer- too many females in his family!]
   
   Henry Cope
   Care of Thomas P Cope & Sons,
   Philadelphia.
   
   attention of Jas C Biddle

Title: 1829 July 13, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 7 month 13th 1829
   Dear Brother:
   
   Thine of 29th ult. has been rece'd. I was pleased to learn that our parents were well, and hope that Edward & Alfred may be benefited by their proposed excursion and that thou may’st also find time to enjoy ye benefits of ye same kind of recreation. Ye country is now enlivened by visitors from ye City and Susquehanna Co. is favoured with a share of them. James Holly Biddle bro't back with them from Phila. their sisters Sarah Biddle and Mary Drinker, and E. Walker's family have ye company of ye widow Morris, and her daughters, Susan & Elizabeth. We have lately been favoured also with a visit from Joel Woolman and Alvin Keyser, appointed by Abington Quarterly Meeting to visit Friendsville Preparative Meeting. they appeared to be man of plain, unassuming humble manners, and were well received by both Hicksites & Orthodox. Cha's Shoemaker accompanied them as far as a Stroudsburg, where he became so ill, as to present his proceeding further. We have subsequently had a visit from Ja's Bell, another orthodox friend and an elder, appointed by Stroudsburg Monthly Meeting.
    
    Dan'l Stroud has been indisposed, or he also wd. probably have visited this part of his flock.  he occasionally writes excellent letters of advice to afford thee an idea of his decisive and at the same time affectionate letters of language & manner, I will give thee an extract from one of them, recently addressed to E. Walker: "distressing as is ye fact, yet it certainly is the case, that the Hicksites are a distinct Society from Friends, and ye separation proceeded from ye leaders of that seccession having become corrupted with anti-christian doctrines, mostly Socinian, but compounded with some other speculative notions, made up into bills to suit ye subjects to whom they were to be administered, and gilt with specious professions of great spirituality, to captivate members and professors with Friends. this with various practices, such as are too commonly used in electioneering, have beguiled & seduced many, who have not or had not previously embraced those awfully dreadful notions, not fitting to be styled doctrines, when we are speaking of religion, and whether these will become leavened into the mass of infidelity with their leaders, or separate from them remains among the things which futurity must disclose. that thou & I, and ye dear children Providentially entrusted to our care, may be preserved from this direful contagion, I have earnestly craved, feeling some hope, that we may resist every temptation that may beset us, to unsettle us and loss about with every wind of doctrine.
    
   If we ever knew anything, "as we ought to know", le us "walk by ye same rule and mind the same thing." Let us be satisfied with and established in "the faith once delivered to ye saints",and say with ye apostle, "thanks be to God for his unspeakable gift", in uniting Deity & virility so as to provide salvation for our fallen race, consistently with divine justine & mercy, though the august plan & means were such as Angels desired to look into.  and tho' this wonderful union is beyond their conception & ours also, we shd. be grateful for it, for surely it is exactly adapted to the condition & need of us poor frail beings, inasmuch as it is complete, or affords complete salvation, both indemnity & cure. Redemption from the penalty & power of sin; remdemption from the penalty by the atonement made by Jesus Christ, our Lord, being God & man;- and redemption from ye power or government of sin by the Holy Spirit, so received into & operating upon our hearts, as to change them, producing a birth of ye spirit & furnishing divine ability in faithful humility & obedience, to resist temptation & be preserved in divine acceptance."++++- Present my very warm & cordial love to thy very dear children, who I feel expressibly near to me. I remember ye kindness of R. T. also; and entertain sentiments of regard for our dear yound friend W. D. Cope, your near neighbour. under sensations which I am thankful for, I bid you all affectionately fare well." (signed) Daniel Stroud.-
   
   Thy observations with regard to ye precarious tenure of our hold on life, are worthy of being often recalled, & deeply impressed upon ye memory & ye heart.- with thyself, I hope & trust that ye deep concern & unbounded affection of our dear deceased Mother for us, will not have been uttered & felt in vain;- that ye expression of her hopes & fears, her sighs & sorrows, have not been for naught.-  I sincerely desire that ye change in ye management of your business, may be advantageous in a pecuniary point of view to thyself & Alfred, but ye annunciation of it, caused a shade of sorrow to pass over my heart. ye expunging of a name, upon which we have been in ye habit of looking so long, that we look upon it with a degree of veneration, seems somewhat like ye disappearance of an old friend or favourite.
   
   I have had workmen pretty constantly employed at my building since my last return from ye City, sometimes to ye number of 6 or 8, sometimes more. ye attention which these, my farm & Father's estate, occupies my time, pretty fully. ye last mentioned concern requires in its present stage & condition much attention for but little profit. but it is absolutely necessary that something shd. be done to guard against ye effects to which it is liable from an accumulation of taxes & interest. I still look forward however, to a change, decidedly for ye better, but we are so apt to be too fast in our calculations, that it becomes us to be cautious.-  I think it likely from present appearances, that my investment in ye stock of ye Leigh Coal and Navigation Co, will be a good one. I am not displeased to find myself becoming more & more interested in my farm. I form an attachment for every tree & every field, which has called forth my care & attention,- for every hill and every valley, that have afforded me gratification by their smiles & beauties.  ye lover of ye country can often realize ye enthusiasm of [Hervey], & exclaim, "when the little hills rejoice & the vallies laugh & sing, who can forbear joining ye general joy". I have at all events reason for self gratulation, inasmuch as I am more pleased with my present mode of life, than I at one time ever expected to be.- I early perceived that with my limited means, I mustbe contented with advancing slowly, in any improvements that I might wish to make, but it has been very difficult to reconcile myself to making so little progress as yet been able to make, owing to ye circumstance last mentioned as well as others.-  I expect that ye capital & influence that Caleb Carmalt is employing in favour of this County, will be of advantage to it, though we we may not feel their effects immediately in this neighbourhood.  some of E. Walker's Family, who have recently been at Friendsville, mention, that he has 30 men & 9 yoke of oxen at work on his farm.  two of his brothers, & one of his sisters have also pitched their tents at Friendsville.-  his brother James, fm Philada., has purchased a farm of 1000 acres & is employed in improving it.-
   
   With particular love to all, I remain thy affectionate brother,
    Wm D Cope
   
   Since writing ye foregoing, I have received thine of 6 ins’t. I will attend to doing what is necessary, to further ye collection of ye divd on ye Canal loan. I hardly expect that there will be any divd. this year, on ye Lehigh Canal stock, but if there should be, I will be obliged by thy informing me of it.-  in addition to the drafts referred to by thee, I passed one to C. Avery & Co, on ye 10 ins't, numbd. 10, for $50.00.-  I regret that I can get no tidings of my missing papers.-  I am obliged by ye information communicated by thee respecting the C & D Canal.  that great work, seems still to baffle calculation.Woodbourne
   7mo. 13.
   
   [7mo 15 1829]
   Henry Cope
   Care of Thomas P Cope
   Philadelphia.

Title: 1830 May 15, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne, 5 month 15th 1830
   Dear Brother:
   
   Thy acceptable letter of 7th inst.  has been rec'd.  thy observations with regard to retirement & the Christian's duty, are certainly correct in the abstract, but I think it will be readily admitted by thee on reflection, that remotely placed as thou art from ye scene in which I move, a correct opinion of ye course most proper for me to pursue, cannot easily be formulated, either by thyself, or any one similarly situated.  to be candid; I may mention, that I think myself pretty fortunate in being able by some excersize or display of management, to make a live,- to use a significant term of the Yankees here,- to possess or enjoy ye common comforts of life.  I have therefore, not much time or inducement to propound to myself sentimental or metaphysical queries in regard to duties, problematical, or supposed to be omitted.  I may be compared in some measure to an honest & benevolent day labourer. (not insinuating that I have a claim to ye character of benevolence.)-  if a distressed fellow creature cross his path or approach his cabin, no one is more willing to dispense ye comforts with which he may be blessed.  but he cannot, like his more wealthy & independent fellow-citizens, go in quest of objects of charity.-  ye call of benevolence, shd. be heard & obeyed, and I freely acknowledge that it ought to be our aim, so to arrange our temporal concerns, as to be in the way of receiving benefit & advantage from our fellow men, or of administering ye same to them, as opportunities present.  this view & reflection, I wish to bring home to myself.  but I have undertaken a business & entered upon a course of life which I had but little previous knowledge, for which I had but little previous education & of which I had formed erroneous expectations.  it wd. certainly have been better on some accounts, if I had taken up my abode in a town or village, upon my first making this county my residence.  if I had excluded farming & building from my views, my business wd. have been much simplified.  but I wished to select ye most adventageous situation for promoting the interest & settlement of Father's est'e: and I think by showing that I consider ye land and ye country good enough for myself, a favorable effect has been & will continueto be produced.  ye difficulty of obtaining assistance here, is a great drawback to ye comfort & satisfaction of ye farmer.  yet as I have put ye machine in motion, I must keep it moving, & as I am harnessed in, I must move with it, unless I have some one to supply my place.  I still indulge ye hope that I shall be able to pull things into proper train, but I begin to think that it will require about as many years to accomplish ye object, as I supposed it would of weeks, before commencing ye undertaking.  I am often however enabled, gratefully to call to mind ye advantage of my present situation, to that of remaining in the City, a victim to disease.  tho' I am thankful that my circumstances are what they are, I trust I shall have sense enough to keep in view that I am not a man of fortune, in ye sense that ye term is generally understood; and when I see how easily my income & more than my income, is fittered away, and how little is to be seen of its effects, I am induced to pause, before launching out into expensesm without calculation.  when & how, ye returns are to come, is uncertain.  a farm in a new county is indeed a quicksand, so great are its absorbing qualities; & we have to deal here with a shewd set of sharpers.  a man who is considered to be in tolerably good circumstances, & is supposed to have money, must expect to be asked two prices for everything, & they will be Jewed or Yankeed out of him, if he does not look about him with eagle eyes.-  Dr. Rose, to be sure, in ye course of upwards of twenty years has done much: but ye course pursued by one man, does not form a rule for another, differently circumstanced.  he has had a numerous class of settlers, of diversified trades & occupations to assist him, to whom he has sold land for good prices, & from many of whom he wd. probably have obtained nothing, had he not have taken pay in such kind of assistance.-  Caleb Carmalt is similarly situated.-  speaking of Caleb, reminds me of a circumstance which occurred at the last Friendsville Preparative Meeting.  he was present, and John Kite, the clerk, objected to proceeding with ye business, whilst one who was not a member of the Society, was in ye house.  Caleb said that he supposed he was ye person alluded to, but that he had proof of his being a member of the Society of Friends, which he cd. produce if necessary.  one of the Hicksites remarked, that ye meeting itself had no information, or at least no official information of C. Carmalt's disownment.  a number of remarks were made in bothsides, but there seemed to be a general sentimentin favour of proceeding with what was before the meeting, without further discussion or excitement, and the clerk accordingly complied with what seemed to be the wish of the meeting.-  this is about ye substance of an account given by a Hicksite to E. Walker.-  what I mentioned in ye preceding part of my letter with regard to charity & benevolence, also recalls to recollection ye case of Uniah Estes, one of Father's settlers, who for ye last 6 weeks or 2 months, has been afflicted with mental alienation.  Jno. Mann kept him at his house several weeks.  by judicious management there, he has been so far resolved, that it was considered safe to suffer him to return to his family.  if he shd. have a relapse which is feared, it is tho't that it wd. be advisable to send him to Friends' Assylum.  if ye information is in thy possession or can be conveniently obtained by thee, I will thank thee to mention in thy next, ye lowest term on which poor patients are rec'd into that institution.  he is a member of the Society of Friends & belongs to a monthly meeting in ye State of New York.-  Elias Bennet, an old & respectable settler on ye Susqa. Co. Tract, who, Father will probably recollect was grievously afflicted with a cancer, died in ye early part of this Spring.  he has bequeathed his farm, or his right in it, to two of his sons.-  my annual subscription in advance, to "the Friend," became due in ye early part of this month.  I will be obliged by thy having it paid when convenient, & having a rec't taken.-  please not to forget my subscription to the Athenaeum.  I wish I were well rid of my share of stock.  I did not intend to have omitted to mention, that there was no charge in my a/c with the old firm of Thomas P Cope & Sons, for my proportion of ye amo't of subscription to the "Morning Journal."  it would I think be no more than right that I shd. pay part of it.-  I shall be anxious relative to Sister Caroline, & will be obliged by thy giving me information relative to her state of health, as soon as convenient.
   
   With love to all, I remain affectionately thy Brother,
   Wm D Cope
   
   I drew on 5 ult. in fav. C. Avery & Co., at 3 d/s, draft no 24 for $100.  and no 25 on ye 3d ins't at samesight fav. C. Avery for $50.0-Woodbourne
   5mo.15.
   
   [5 mo 19]
   
   Henry Cope
   care of Henry & Alfred Cope,
   Philadelphia.

Title: 1834 January 6, Philadelphia, to Susan

(by mail)
   Philada. 1 mo. 6. 1833
   Dear Susan:
   
   As I had hoped and expected I received the thrice welcome communication of which we had been speaking, the evening of the same day I left thee. it was handed to me by my Father, who said that he had taken charge of it in the morning, upon finding it at the Counting House. so thou had'st been thinking of me during the three weeks' interval of non-intercourse. thee is a a dear creature,  (pardon the familiarity of the expression) and I thank thee much, for it. how delightful to be though of and remembered, by those that we love! "Tho' my pen has been idle this long, my thoughts have not". I recalled these expressions of thy "talking letter", again and again, and tho' the construction admits of doubt with regard to its correctness, yet the influence that thee was thinking of me was so agreeable that I concluded to assume it as the right and proper interpretation. at all events thy thoughts must have been indirectly, if not directly turned towards me. I am unable to answer satisfactorily thy quiery with regard to the authorship of the poetical effusion that I sent thee from Woodbourne. I have frequently recurred to it during moments of calm and quiet meditation, and have derived soathing satisfaction from the consoling and pious spirit that it breathes. I suppose that I shall in due time be informed by thee who the "intruder" is, who has had the presumption to invade thy tranquil haunts, whilst occupied with thoughts of me. If he shall molest or disturb any more, he will incur my high displeasure. restingsatisfied for the present with the expectation or supposition just expressed, I bid thee affectionaly adieu. I wishing thee, "Health of body, peace of mind, quiet by day; sound sleep by night".
    Thine,
   [Philimus]
   
   I hope to have the pleasure of seeing thee in a few days.
   
   Philada. 1mo. 13. 1834
   
   I reached the City, about dusk in the evening of the day that I left Bloomsdale, after a tolerably pleasant passage. the coach was not crowded, and I did not make any very interesting acquaintances, nor any with whom I felt much disposed to enter into conversation, or to enlarge upon the topics of the day. and if I had felt such disposition, it would have been an unpleasant exertion to have attempted to make my voice heard or to elevate it above the noise & rattling of the stage coach, owing to my cold, and the condition of my throat. But tho' my voice was "idle my thoughts were not". And I suspect that thou cannot give a pretty good guess as to who and what were the subjects of them. ipon glancing over the pages of Father's copy of the "Sentimental Journey", I espied the article recommended for my perusal by my friend Adeline. It is contained under the heading, "The Remise. Calais". Vol. 1 I am highly pleased with the delicate manner used by thee in adverting to the postage subject. It has reminded me of the following stanza by Pope:
   "Men should be taught as tho’ you taught them not;
     And things unknown rehearsed as thing forgot.Tis not enough your counsels still be true:   Blunt truth more mischief than nice falsehoods do.
   
   the sentiment is open to criticism, but think that there is sufficient truth in it to make it worth of a consideration. I am fearful that I may have been considered by thee remotely or in some measure, changeable with bluntness in my manner of suggesting to thee, that it would perhaps be best not to advert to any circumstances that might be of disagreeable or unpleasant nature. the suffered suitable time and opportunity to pass for alluding to the circumstance in the course of conversation with embracing it. As I am now "an engaged man", I shall be desirous of complying with all the duties and requisitions thereof, and shall therefore take care not to forget to profit by thy kind hint relative both aforesaid item of those duties. I want thee as to admired applied to another, the following line of the Poet Burns, whilst I will admire them as applied to thyself:
   
   "A gaudy dress and gentle air may slightly touch the heart,
   But its innocence and modesty that polishes the dart."
   'Tis this in Susan pleases me, 'tis this enchants my soul,
    For absolutely in my heart the reigns without control."
   
   if it were not however that the metre and force of the third line would be destroyed by so doing I am say, this is one thing in Susan, or this is part of what pleases me. I am not certain that I am literally correct in the quotations that I have made, as I depend for their correctness upon my memory, but I believe I have nearly the substance. I have made my arrangements to as to be at B. about the usual time this week, having concluded to procrastinate,fare-thee-wells. a thousand good wishes I send thee and more love than I can mention of which last may.
    
   "Thine but the impression stronger make,   Is stream their channels deeper wear."
   
   Thine unchangeably,
   [Philimus]
   
   procrastinate the two weeks interval till another time. I thought it would be so. How readily we form plans & [exences] for doing what is agreeable.

Title: 1832 November 27, Philadelphia, to S.

Philada. 11mo. 27. 1832
   
   I may say the worst that I have for years   I have had a dreadfully bad cold, and though I think it would have done me good to see thee, I must now bid all hail! to Susquehanna County, and did not feel much inclined to go into company nor was I in a very suitable condition for so doing.  I hasten to the country of cloud-capped eminences, invigorating breezes, placid lakes, ever-varying surface and romantic scenery.-  there to feel myself reinstated in the occupation which is the height of my ambition, that of an independent farmer.-  an occupation for which I do not think my partiality as yet has diminished.  "Ye generous yeomen, [---] the plough"!  before taking my flight, I wish to let thee know that I did not forget the subject of "Friendship’s Offering" relative to which we had some conversation during our last rural walk.  the reason for my not sending the said work, I will give when I again see thee.  this seems to be a small matter to [---] to, but I think it best thus to do it, as I have never yet forfeited my word or violated an engagement, and I do not wish to give any cause for so however slight for supposing that I wd. do so.  if thee gets married to any one, while I am gone, be sure that it is to a clever fellow.  I am still somewhat inclined I should like to have had one sweet kiss of thy pretty mouth, before, peradventure, I should forever be [---] the opportunity (5); however thee knows we ought to learn to submitto submit with fortitude to our fate.  I am still somewhat inclinded to the opinion, which I have before hinted to thee, that I am not well qualified to undergo the ordeal of a systematic courtship, such as is frequently, perhaps generally expected & practiced in this part of the world.  if I ever succeed in making a capture of that fair citadel, or seat of love,- a lady’s heart; it must, I apprehend be by storm, rather than by gradual approaches, long trains, dexterous manouvers, or a regular siege.
   
   I have now only to say,
   "Adieu! a heartfelt warm adieu"! from thy still affectionate friend,
   
   if thou wilt only be persuaded, dear Susan, a drab bonnet, I will on my part agree to shade my face with a broad-brim.  if we do not then attract universal admiration, who will be so bold as to say that we will not at least command general respect.
   
   I have received a notice requiring my immediate departure from the City, if possible, in order to attend the next Court to be held at Montrose.  excuse haste and all the nonsense contained in these lines.-I expect to have the agreeable company of my Cousin Rebecca Drinker as far as [Stoddartsville].  being of a cheerful disposition, I expect she will prevent my spirits from flagging.To S,
   dated Philada. 11mo. 27. 1832.
   
   (3) "Though I to" distant "lands must [---],   Pursuing fortune's [sliddery] [---],   With melting heart & [brimful] eye,   I'll mind thee when I’m far away."
   
   (5) by some spruce, fashionable [---].  plague on such I say.
   
   Ph

Title: 1813 September 13, East Marlborough, to William D Cope, Philadelphia

East Marlborough
    September 13th-1813
   
   Esteemed Friend William D Cope,
   
   I have received thy letter of the 30the of August which informes me that thee has accomplished thy journey Westward and is now at thy own home in Philadelphia. Therefore I now purpose writing thee a few lines by way of answer both to the above mentioned letter and that of the 25th of July. Friend Cope I judge thee thinks I am a very lazy fellow for nether meeting thee at West-Chester nor answering thy letter before this-time. but, as for the former I think I have a very good reason for I did not receive the intelligence of thee being there till about 5 days after the appointed time which was the only reason why I was not there for I would have been well pleased to of had the opurtunity of seeing my Friend by going the small distance of ten miles.but, altho thy friend was disappointed of the operturnity he thanks thee kindly for the invitation. The account thee has given me of Lancaster town is very similar to what I expected it was, but as for Columbia I did not expect its adjacent lands were so hilly, or, had such Mountains in them as thee mentions.I understand Friend E Lewis lately buried his son Ennoch with the flux. but I did not understan that the disorder has spread in the family.    
   With a hope that these lines may find thee in as good a state of health as I am in I conclude, and subscribe myself thy affectionate friend.
   
   Joel Baily
    
   William D CopeWilliam D. Cope
   Philadelphia
   
   To the care of Thomas P Cope
   merchant Walnut
   St warf

Title: 1887 May 18, Brooklyn, N.Y., to Cousin Anna

356 Adelphi st
   Brooklyn, N.Y.
   5/18. 87
   
   Dear Cousin Anna,
   
   I recd thy note announcing the death of thy dear sister, and it was very thoughtful and loving of them to remember me-  though I had, the day before, recd a short note from Henry himself. It was sudden as sad to me, as I had heard nothing of her further declining health or illness. When I saw cousin Mary last was at Mt. Pleasant about 2 years ago. Then, though looking delicate, she seemed as bright and reminded me strongly of the days of her beautiful girlgood. O, those dreamlike days! of your cousins, in your Arch st. home, and the several Paradises, that the 'Doctor', and cousin Frank and I need to riflealong the Schuykill and Wissahiccon every spring- for the first and fairest flowers and how you loved to prink your happy parlors with them. I replied quite at length. For me to Henry’s letter, and told him I hoped to come on to P. to see my brothers soon, and hoped to see him which I still wish to do. It would have been a great comfort to me, if I could have come on to the funeral, but my state of health at that time prevented by a sudden change in the weather I had taken. A touch of Pleurisy which I had to break up I and we all, Mariann and Anna (who meet Cousin Mary at mt. Pleasant), were with you that sad afternoon in mournful communion. Is n't itremarkable, that you all, of your sisterhood of five, shd. have been spared to Each other so long. And as these days Mary was always so joyous a nature you must all miss her sunshine. How could our hearts bear up under all the partings on our dearest me, on Earth did we not see the vision of the Angel world and among them, our "family in Heaven". Where hope assues me we shall meet beyond all partings I fear illegible note, will find there and thin in health and with love to all and to cousins Susan & Lizzie & Fanny. I will close adding only that [Marien?] & Anna wish their love to you. Excuse my not replying to thy letters, Dear Cousin Anna, which I wasvery grateful for. For if the Dr. had not written, I should have heard, very sorrowfully so I have in several cases of Philada relations, when the first news I heard was long after: Knowing of it and I could mingle with you in Spirit, and live over our happy long days and anticipate those happier ones to come. That Death cannot end, nor sorrow overcast.
   Love especially to cousin Frank.
   
   From thy Afft,
   Cousin Edward
   
   P.S. After I wrote this last note Cousin Anna, recd Alfred cards & those for Sister Anna & Henry wh. We have forwarded to Boston. It mush be a very happy affair. All sounds and we should be glad to be present but Anna will have too send cards instead. Aff, EdwardNot Being sure of your home P.S. address I mail this for Brr David to forward.
