Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1899-04-26
Title: 1899 April 26, Rosemont, to Lily

4 mo 26. 1899
   
   Dear Lily,
   
   There has been a lack of vocal or written sympathy with thee this winter, and this brief message is only to assure thee of my love and frequent thought being freshly flowing.That mere words would only weary thee I know and I only sent messages to thee by notes to Rachel. It was my hope that long before this my own strength would have retuned and enabled me to go to thee. But that is not the case as only a very little exertion ispossible yet - writing, almost is a lost art. Excuse this detail, because I could not otherwise explain my absence. Now we have heard of Edward's illness, and I wish to send by thee my love to Jonathan and Rachel, when it is convient to thee.
   
   We Also understand Edward is much beter, I hope convalescent.Dear, believe me, thy loss is shared in some degree by me, for thy lovely Agnes was especially near to me, her gentle pure spirit now a lasting place in my heart.
   
    She always seemed as one apart from our every-day routine, and now she is in full & glourious development of all her Savoir has prepared her to be for Him. Always lovingly thy
    Hannah R. Garrett.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  M.H. Garrett
Recipient:  Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth) Cope:  1840-1944
Date: 1883-09-30
Title: 1883 September 30, Germantown, to Carrie

Germantown, 9.30.83.
   
   My Dear Carrie-
   I hope the expression of sympathy & affection may be acceptable, even though there may be no new thoughts of comfort to suggest.
   
   I was so sorry to hear from Sister Lillie today that Edgar's health had been poor. I though of him as a strong man. It will be a pleasure, no doubt, though mingled with sadness, to Nettie & thee, to minister to the comfort of your remaining brother.
   
   The memory of Alexis is one of calmness & sweetness. I did not know him well, yet recall with pleasure the queit cordiality of his greeting. Samuel Morris, who rode in the same carriagewith me at the funeral, said he had learned to love him much. I think it is grateful to look back on his life here as a happy one, & his life there as is fit & glorious consummation. And he left a dear legacy in his children. I am glad you have them. I count myself so rich in my dear nephews & nieces, my young brothers & sisters, as I sometimes call them. Does thee know I am a great-aunt? My oldest nephew, Joseph Rhoads, has a wee Edgar, away out in Plainfield Indiana, where he has gone to teach. Hetty  is out there, helping. Has been away nearly 7 weeks & we don't know when we shall get her back. She went to help furnish & arrange the new little home.
   
   Fanny & Alfred Garret were here last evening a while. We do think Fannya very lively have character, & Alfred seems to be coming out a fine manly boy, & doing well at college. 
    
   How the time does fleet away! Think of it being 50 years since we were at West-town together! And what can those fleeting years show? For me, a life made up of many little things, & with too many idle hours. I enjoy my work of various kinds though; simple household cares, an extensive correspondence, partly for pleasant sympathies, partly for teaching, & on the rest days, a restful work in the care of my first-day class. Dr. Rhoads holds a school at our house and I have as my class nearly 20 boys & girls from 9 to 14 years old who troop up to my room with me. I will not claim to do them much good. I don't believe in direct religious teaching exceptwhere there is an opening for it, but I think the hour passes not unprofitably, & they learn to find the study of the Bible pleasant.    
   I hope Ellie Alderson may continue to improve. I should be glad to hear from thee if thee can feel like writing, & to be told what your prospects are.
   With Love to Nettie & Thyself,
   ever thy affectionate friend
   
   M. H. Garrett

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Hannah Sansom Vaux
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1840-07-31
Title: 1840 July 31, Philadelphia, to Anna, near Germantown

Philadelphia 7th mo 31st 1840.
   
   My dearest Anna,
    
   When we last parted I had intended to fulfill my promise of writing to thee at a much earlier period than I have done, but my time has been so much occupied that I have found it impossible to do so, and trust thee will not attribute it to forgetfulness, as I can assure thee that although absent, thee is not forgotten. Several of the family have been very much indisposed, grandfather has indeed had quite a severe attack, we scarcely thought he would recover for a day or two, but he is now very much improved and able to be about his room. The weather has been so very warm, I expect you enjoy the country exceedingly there  are but a few persons now remaining in the city, the streets are quite deserted, great numbers have gone to Cape May and other watering places. I understood from a gentleman who had just returned from Saratoga Springs, that the Hotels there were very much crowded, about four hundred visitors at one house.
    
   I regretted exceedingly you were unable to hear Friend Gurney once more before his departure, I can scarcely realise that he has indeed left our native land forever, as he now supposes; there was a little girl inquired of him if he would never return here, and was almost broken hearted, when he placed his hand upon his head and replied, that "his docks were too grey ever to expect to revisit this country". I had several op-portunities of being in company with him and they were much more delightful on account of being unexpected.
   
   The First day morning before he left he attended the North Meeting, and gave us a very interesting and beautiful sermon, taking his text from the sixty third chapter of Isaiah, ninth Verse. After meeting Sister Mary and myself were returning home, when Friend Paul joined us and said, that she had fully expected we would have called to see Friend Gurney the evening before, that there was a number of friends and young people assembled at their house, between sixty and seventy she thought, to bid him Farewell, and insisted upon our going home with her; as she said that it would be our last oppurtunity, we accordingly accepted her invitation, highly grateful as thee may suppose. Our particular facourite E. P. Kirkbride was there when we arrived, and seveal other friends. Friend Gurney was very much pleased to see us, he said that he had been expecting us, and was very glad we had come, he seated himself close by us and conversed awhile very sweetly, after which we bade him adieu, wishing him a prosperous voyage and safe return, he sent his Love to all the family a kiss to the younger ones. He had an appointed meeting at the Arch Street house in the evening. (I was very much surprised a few days after to hear that you had not attended it). It was very large, he addressed us in a very interesting manner and furnished with a most touching prayer, in which he commended all his Endeared Friends, to the protection of that Saviour, who had so long sheltered him under his parent wing, and had been with him, in joy and in sorrow in this land."
   
   When the meeting had concluded, every one rushed to shake hands with him, I think he must have stood twenty minutesbidding all farewell, until I thought his hand really must ache however all were finally satisfied, and we had just returned home, when to our utter amazement who should arrive directly after, but Joseph John he said he must see us all once more, he sat a short time with us, and we then bade him adieu, although I trust it will not be forever. He sailed in "The Roseius" on the 25th, I shall be truly glad when I hear of his safe arrival at home, for surely his children and relations must ardently desire to behold him again, if he makes such an impression upon strangers what must their feelings be? I shall leave the remainder to thy imagination; I have written a long narrative about him my Dear Anna, supposing it would interest thee, if it does not thee must excuse the length of it, and not waste thy time in perusing it. I suppose thee has most probably heard of the death of Harry Collins, and Maria’s loss of her dear little babe, his namesake, so near the same time, poor girl she must feel it very deeply. Sister Susan and family have gone into the country expecting to remain three weeks. Cousin S. Cresson is no anxiously awaiting the arrival of her son Charles &c they intended sailing on the 25th in the "Great Western" for New York, I suppose they will arrive here in a week or ten days.
   
   Brother Wm is very anxious that some of us should take a trip through Pennslyvania, we had thought of going to Cape May for the benefit of the bathing the Dr. having recommended it for George, but Mama was so unwilling that he should be near the sea, we have concluded that a mountain ride, will perhaps be equally beneficial, I do not think it likely we shall be absent longer than a week. My letter has become so very lengthy, that I have only room to add do write me a very long letter and very soon, give my love to all inquiring friends of course reserving a lrage portion for thyself and hoping this will find you all in a perfect state of salubrity believe mestill thy sincerely attached friend and cousin
   
   Hannah S Vaux
   
   P.S. Please excuse all blunders and do not allow any one to read this but thyself. (A speedy answer Dear Anna).

Title: 1888 December 23, Woodbourne, to Clementine Cope

Woodbourne 12/23- 88
   
   My very Dear Friend Clementine Cope,   Many thanks for your lovely Christmas Greeting & for  Christmas Box ccontaining a superior Down Comfortable Superior Oranges grapes &c for which I am much obliged very grateful & much oblidged yesterday I tested the quality of the Down for keeping warm  It was certainly very thoughtful & kind in sending a covering. So useful to protect from severe cold from the severity soften think of Elizabeth the exile of Siberia undertakiing a journey two thousand miles to obtain a pardon from the Emperor of Russia for her Father. When the weather is more congenial than at present, I hope that you three lovely Sisters may not hesitate to perform a visit to yournative land where you will be certain to obtain a kind welcome we miss your agreeable manners & refined good sense more than words can tell. May we not anticipate the pleasure of a good long visit next summer three lovely sister.  I sincerely wish you one & all a very Happy Christmas & New Year & Many happy returns of the Same. Thanks to a kind Providence I am still favored to enjoy good health with the exception of Rheumatism. I enjoy a good appetite & sleep will at nights for which I am very thankful. Please write soon to your deserted lonely friend & with that love which neither nor distance can efface for Dear thee Clementine I remain very truly & sincerely thy affectionate loving friend G Walker

Title: 1902 July 30, Girard Trust Co, to Mother

Girard Trust Co
   7/30/02
   
   Dear Mother
   My letters do not seem to have any regular time for going to thee this summer and I cant remember when I last wrote but this is to tell thee about Aunt Lizzie Cope.  Thee probably has heard that she was not so well lately and on 2nd day Grandpa and uncle Tom went down for the day to Ventnor to see her.  They found that she was, as they had expected, much worse than when she left Awbury tho she was very glad to see them.  She had a great deal of 2
   
   trouble breathing.  Yesterday morning they up at uncle Thomas received a telegram from down there saying that she was worse and later on in the morning another one came saying that she had pneumonia which of course made them fear the worst.  Late in the afternoon another message came that she had quietly passed away at about 4 oclock in the afternoon.  Cousin Madgie, Ellie & John were all down there at the time and cousin Harry & Walter went down in the afternoon.  I did not know anything about it until late last night when I came home from the Harris (Joes) where a lot of us were at a porch party so that I did not get a  3
   
   Chance to write until this morning.  Grandpa, uncle Tom also had very little time to write as Cousin Eliza came over to supper (as cousin Walter had gone down) and Ridlgley Brown had also been asked to supper.  I do not know any thing further as of course we have not heard anything more.  I dont know when the funeral will be. 
   
   As I said before she had been much weaker lately and her heart not been as strong so that they were very much concerned about her tho the Dr did not give up hope as she said you could not tell in heart cases how long a person might live.  When Grandpa was down on 2nd day they did not know that she had pneumonia tho she was much worse than she had been.  She was up 4
   
   when they saw her.  She had a bad night and in the morning the Dr said she had pneumonia and did not look for her to recover.  I do not know how she took cold. 
   
   I have been having a great deal going on in a special way lately so that I have not had a chance to do all the things I have wanted to do,- one of which was to may Joe Morris a visit.  Alf & Henry are out there now but Joe & Ev go up to Woodbourne [---] about the 1st.  I have not time to write more at present.  Things certainly have kept moving this summer & I have had a mighty good time.  We are all very well.  Please give my love to Anna, with lots for thyself  I am as ever thine
   Algernon

Title: 1906 April 8, Awbury, to Mother

Awbury
   4/8/06
   
   Dearest Mother
   I am very sorry I have been so long in answering thy letter but after Edw wrote and told thee about father I did not feel it nearly so much as my mind tho I have been walking to work and tell thee that thy letter was much appreciated and also to let thee know that I still remembered there was such a person even tho I did not write.
   
   Last week in spite of the fact that we no longer had the  rummage sale on our minds was pretty full.  On 2nd day we had our "Discipline Class" & on 3rd day Frank Ev & I read as usual.  The baby has not been as well as she might be, having had a slight [bilious?] attack.  So she has been a little more fruitful during the day tho she has been very good indeed when I have been over there in the evenings.  Ev also has not been very well as she has had a mild attack of hives which have however now passed away I believe.  While I am on the health of their family I might add that they heard the other daythat Ell has been right sick having had an attack of Gripp and there after getting better having a relapse from which I think she is now recovering.  It is too bad that she should have been sick just as this time, especially as they are getting ready to move.  but it is a good thing that Aunt L is down there to look after them.  To continue the health bulletin- Father seems to be pretty well and cheerful tho his ankle does not seem to get much better tho he [---] it.  He drives a great deal and occassionally goes out to supper & dinner (I dont know how much he goes out to dinner).  We have not had very much company in the evening tho Davis came up one night and Frank & Betty were over on 5th day night which Father enjoyed.  I expect it would be good for him if we had some more company but it seems very hard to find a time when we have not got engagements.
   
   Yesterday Joe Morris & I went up to the Rancocas and canoed.  It was a very fine day in the morning and a pretty good afternoon tho a little disappointing after the way the day started.  We had a first class time by ourselves and came home with that comfortable tired sleepy feeling.  The main reason for our going was that I wanted to ship our canoe & Sam Emlen's up to Browns Mills so that we can come down the stream next 6th day which is Good Friday and therefore a holiday.  A big crowd of people which Natalie and Elsie have asked are also going up to Browns Mills to stay over Easter and Ernest expects tobe one of them.  Edw. & I were not asked as the girls seem to think that new blood is needed which sounds very well.  I dont know exactly who all are going with them but the ladies are Natalie Elsie Mildred Sue Margaret [Werner] Katharine Buffum Eliz [Weston?], the fellows are Art, Bill, Ernest, and some other new bloods I am not certain who all. 
   
   I dont know certainly who of us are coming down in canoes but Ed & I will probably be in one boat & Sam & Marion in the other.  Tho the latter are always more or less uncertain now!  Thee knows they are expecting to married in June and Sam has asked Edw & myself to be ushers.  By the way Ed wishes me to thank thee for him for thy letter and also to give thee his love.  Harold is down at Atlantic City, or rather in transit from Atlantic City I suppose, and Ernest has taken Esther Emlen over to the Shoemakers to heat some singing so they can not send their love.  This morning I stopped for a few minutes at Uncle Franks and saw Esther.  She seemed very bright & well.  Ed stayed over there to dinner and then returned and took a drive with father while Frank & I went on a good long tramp. 
   
   Please excuse the writing blotts spelling etc for I am feeling rather sleepy & careless tho it is not late at all, the clock just having struck 9.30.  I think I will however call this to a close & go to bed which I know will please thee.  I have been getting to bed often much earlier than usual lately!!  Please give a great deal of my love to Anna & remember me to Miss R.  It will be very nice to see you all again.  With great deal of love for thyself I am always thine
   Algernon

Title: 1910 September 2, Philadelphia, to Mother

Phila
   9/2/10
   
   Dear Mother
   I am going to try to mend my ways and write thee a real letter!  Thee sees thee suffers from the fact thee is so good natured about our short comings.  I am afraid I sometimes write to other members of the family and not to thee because I think thee will understand it is not because I do not love thee I do not write.  I guess thee does understand this but likes to hear all the same.
   
   I was surprised to hear thee started so soon for North East Harbor and I hope that gay house party did not wear thee out so thee was not rested enough to go.  I hope at any rate thee will have a Chance to get rested at North East.  It is too bad thee has had so much trouble with thy knee but perhaps a change of air will be good for it.  I understand it is rheumatism- isnt it?  There seems to be a great deal of it around.  The other day- last 7th day it was- I had planned with Ernest to take a walk in the afternoon but suddenly in the middle of the morning a little rheumatism settled in my knee and it got quite sore so we went up to the Rancocas and canoed.  I cured mine in a jiffy by rubbing it that night with [---] which I think is fine stuff.  Has thee tried it on thy knee?  I think it might help it. 
   
   Last night I very unexpectedly went up the Valley to the Roberts with Edward Jack & Joe.  We had a very good time.  Elizabeth Perot came over to supper and helped keep things moving.  She has been having quite a bad time with rheumatism in one of her eyes but it is much better now.  We spent the night and retuned to Phila this morning. 
   
   Tonight Ernest & I are expecting to go to Uncle Franks to supper and tomorrow we start for Woodbourne on the Black Diamond which gets us up there in time for supper.  I am sorry that Evelyn fine stuff.  Has thee tried it on thy knee?  I think it might help it. 
   
   Last night I very unexpectedly went up the Valley to the Roberts with Edward Jack & Joe.  We had a very good time.  Elizabeth Perot came over to supper and helped keep things moving.  She has been having quite a bad time with rheumatism in one of her eyes but it is much better now.  We spent the night and retuned to Phila this morning. 
   
   Tonight Ernest & I are expecting to go to Uncle Franks to supper and tomorrow we start for Woodbourne on the Black Diamond which gets us up there in time for supper.  I am sorry that Evelyn will not be up there but I am looking forward with much pleasure to seeing the others.  I do not think Edw has planned to go away over the end of the week so he will be out at [Dimdale?]. 
   
   Next week I suppose will bring quite a change in the numbers at Germantown as people generally have to come home about the 10th.  It has been very quiet since we came back from the [---] and it will be nice to see some more people around once again. 
   
   I suppose the family will stay up at Jamestown until some time about the 23rd though I have not heard any date mentioned.  Harold said he expected to come home about the 10th to do some work By the way I got from the barrel of Educators over at Grand[---] 5lbs the other day.  I do now know how much they are a lb. & I wonder whether thee would mind settling with uncle Tom for them.  I only took 5lbs as the barrel  was pretty empty and I thought I had better have some in it.  I think there are about 5lbs left. 
   
   Family affairs move along very quietly and very reasonably smoothly.  Occassionally our fair Margaret gets a little ruffled under the collar but we have had nothing serious happen at all.  As her second childhood is coming on she gets more and more  forgetful so that sometimes I think it will not be long before we  will be summoned to table and find it almost unused.  The other night she admitted supper was late because she had put the lima beans on to cook but when she went to take them off she found nothing but boiling water as she had forgotten to put the beans in the pot!!  It does very nicely for summer time when no one is in a hurry but it would be a little annoying if such things happened when we are busy. 
   
   The days are getting so short now we do not have much chance to play tennis unless we get an early start and as Ernest does not  get out of town until the 505 at the earliest we have not played much.  Edw and I however had a little practice.  We have also been kept from playing by a great deal of [---] cool,- almost cold,- weather.  Yesterday it rained very hard but has cleared up Today and I hope we will have clear weather over the end of the weak, though we will have a very good time no doubt even if the skies are cloudy.
   
   Please give a great deal of love to Grandma.  And with the same for thyself I am
   Thy loving son
   Algernon
   
   Also please give my love to uncle T. (over) P.S.
   I almost again forgot to thank thee for those very pretty little needle & thread holders which thee sent Harold & me.  We really appreciated them very much and they were most convenient to have.

Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1882-09-03
Title: 1882 September 3, Meadowfield, to sister

Meadowfield 9.3.
   
   My beloved sister
   I feel as tho' I wanted to send thee another greeting before you leave Newport, thy last letter was very welcome with its good report of your welfare, I trust you have all continued in good case & will return home strengthened for the cares & duties of the winter.  As to dear little Edward, I do not suppose we shall know him, nor doubt he has changed much, I hope he will make up his mind to take food when he really needs it, perhaps he may take to a cup & spurn if a bottle is too insulting to his dignity.  Rebekah Smith's little boy is growing nicely & is a cute baby with the large dark eyes, your children ought to our ideas, & tho' his fractures are rather too large now for baby beauty he promises to develope that trait after awhile; at present his great charm is his good behavior, which is a real comfort to his mamma as her nurse left her sooner than she wished & she has only a young girl to assist her in taking care of him.  I suppose it will not be very long now before you are turning your faces homeward & it will be pleasant to think of your bring near us.  tho' we shall not see one another for awhile.  I am glad to hear from a letter to Katharine from Jthat you will not move into your own house until the 11th month, as I would like to be on hand at that season, having a fancy for such dissipations.  I have seen allusions in the papers to the burning of The Cliff House, but have not seen any account of the event, what a favor you were not there! & how about the boarders, did they lose their things was anyone hurt, poor Mrs Emmons I hope she was not there, (or thy Aunt Lizzie).  By the way what do you hear of the latter.  I trust her trip to England has been of use to her, when do you expect her back.  I am sorry to hear that Hazen is not very strong, perhaps he did too much, it seemed a very short time to be absent.  Since our last letter to thee we have had a visit from Susan Kito & Amy Roberts, they are bothundemonstrative people, especially Susan, but they enjoyed being here I think, SK was not well & did not like to ride so we had a quiet time, reading, talking, examining flowers & looking at objects in the compound microscope, one of Frank's late investments; they took tea at sister Eleanor's & also at Joshua's.  Sister Eleanor's summer home was vacated on 3rd day, she, Tom, Ellie, & Walter drove home with the two horses & carriage she spent one night at Arondale & one at HM Stokes at Chester & reached Germantown on 5th day evening.  Hetty & Wistar have gone to "Uncle Gideon's" & Betty is staying with us; the stay down here has been a real succes, the children have been very well & happy, have found much to interest & occupy them.Wistar & Franky have spent many hours in "bug hunts" & do manifest much zeal in the collection of beetles, butterflys & moths, & really have quite a large number; we labor under great difficulty as far as the study of the subject is concerned, as we have no books on Entomology except one by [Wood?] which treats of British insects, I quite want to get some good work & be able to learn the names of some of the creatures the boys have.  I have wandered away from my starting point, sister Eleanorfound the quiet of the country life & the absense of the many demands on her time & thoughts that she has to meet in Germantown a great rest, & altho' the house has not much to attract as regards situation it did not make the same difference to her it would to us, as she is so fond of riding she was out almost daily & enjoyed taking others drives.  Thee may remember Katharine & I find great comfort in sitting under the trees or lying in the hammocks when not busy sewing.  I suppose Hetty will stay down some weeks yet, her trip to Mt [Desert?] brokeinto her summer & I think she dont feel at all ready to leave Maryland.  John & Walter came down yesterday with Frank but dont expect to make much of a visit as they talk of going back tomorrow.  We heard a report that Sophy Kimber was to be married at Newport this summer, does thee know if it is so, her certificate has been sent on from 12th st, we shall miss her from Germantown she is so efficient & willing.  Now my dear sister when thee writes, which I hope may be [---] long, please tell us how thee is, Katharine wishes to know if thee has picked up any fat in the cool air, how does thy nurse geton, I hope she has proved an efficient help.  It is raining quite heavily now, which is not as acceptable as at some seasons, but when I think how we have longed for it in former days I dont like complaining.  The season of canning has arrived & folks in this part of the country are busy enough putting up corn, tomatoes & peaches &c, I should feel dubious about eating the products of some of the factories, as they employ Bohemians whose cleanliness is more than doubtful.  We were quite startled to see the death of Mary Morton yesterday, she spent a few days with Rebekah some 2 weeks ago, but was not well then & wished to get to Phila, it is such a favor she went up when she did or she might have died here.  Please give my love to thy mother & Lilly, kiss the dear children for me & accept for thyself a message of warmaffection from thy attached sister K sends love Hannah B. Evanscan thee tell us anything of the Newhalls.  Ive not heard from A for some time & fear her mother is more poorly.

Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Date: 1885-08-16
Title: 1885 August 16, Meadow Farm, to brother

Meadow Farms
   8 Mo 16.85.
   
   My beloved brother
    
   Thy letter of love and sympathy was very acceptable for tho' our friends cannot do much for us just now we do appreciate their sympathy. I am sorry I cannot tell thee that dear Katy is better, her fever still continues tho her temperature is one degree down this morning. I believe I told thee the typhoid symptoms had disappeared, which conclusion I jumped at from hearing the Dr. say the trouble about the abdomen was gone, and tongue clearing off, but on saying something like it to the Dr., he replied he thought they seemed to be developing much more then in the first weeks of the sickness.  Dr. Newlin Stokes came down to G. Smith's funeral yesterday, saw Katy and had a consultation with Dr. Sapington. Yesterday for the 1st time a few spots appeared in the abdomen and the Dr.s both said that was the 9th day of the typhoid fever, so dear child she has a long siege before her yet. It was a great satisfaction that Dr. Stokes said the case had been treated just as he should have done and he had no change to suggest except giving valerian instead of bromide to quiet her at night. They both unite in giving little medicine, only quinen to keep up her strength and all the nourishment she can take. Dr. [Lapingson?] thought perhaps Valentines extract did not suit her so we now squeeze the bloodOut of raw beef and give her that every four hours. Sam will send us down a druggists press, which will be a help in getting the juice out. Both Dr.'s said we ought to have a nurse, Dr. Stokes said he know of one he thought we could get, Frank telegraphed for her and I think Thomas Cope will probably see her for us tomorrow and if suitable send her down. It will be a comfort to have some one who is skilful and can move and change Katy with less fatigue than we do. Frank stays with Katy part of every night and helps much with the nursing, but Katherine is so anxious and nervous I fear she will be quite laid up unless we have some help. Katy's fever is not high, 102 2/10 the highest her temperature has reached and todayit is a degree less. She has little disturbance of the bowels and no head ache, her mouth and throat are very uncomfortable, feel gummy and sore and she feels very weak and weary. Slept but little last night and the hours were long and tedious for her, she is very patient but at times is nervous. Edith seems to be gaining, is taken down stairs everyday and takes tea with us, Dr. took her temperature today and found it a little below normal, says she must have a little brandy. It is rather depressing for her and [Esther?] and frankly, we are so taken up with Katy and the house has to be kept so quiet, so it is proposed for them to go to Uncle's for a few days and when Edith is stronger they may go to Awbury. If sister Eleanor takes Ellie away perhaps the girls could accompany her. I am glad to know you are better for Newport air, we had a very nice letter from dear Rachel please thank her for it and let her see this as I shall not have time to write to her now. I rejoice to think thee spent some days at Batemans and do hope thee feels stronger for it, thee will be lonely at Awbury with so many of both families away. With much love from usAll I am thy attached sister Hannah. I remember this is thy birthday.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Hannah Bacon Evans:  1839-1939
Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Date: 1885-08-19
Title: 1885 August 19, to Jonathan Evans

8 Mo 19. [1885]
Dr says Katy is holding her own very well, her temperature is rather lower this morning than at the same time yesterday.  101 today & her skin more natural.  She slept a good deal last night, but does not seem quite so drowsy this morning & therefore more conscious of her discomforts.  Dear child she gets discouraged  at times, the days seem so long.  I was writing for a tooth brush but Katharine says Katy has just got a nice soft one.  Sam sent us down a press for the beef, so we can get the juice out with less labor.  I hope Ernest is doing well, my love to Rachel & the others at Newport.  With love thine truly
H.B.E.Jonathan Evans
160 North 22nd St.
Philadelphia
Pa

Date: 1902-08-03
Title: 1902 August 3, Locust Avenue, to sister

[Tear this up when you have read it.  I have answered it.] 
   
   Locust Avenue
   8 Mo 3rd
   
   My dear sister
   
   I am once more at home and quite miss hearing of thy welfare and dear Anna's from Jonathan's letters.  I hope you still continue to gain and enjoy the mountain air.  When I got home last 2nd day, I felt very much used up with the heat & the change in air, but now have become accustomed to it and feel quite well, tho' the amount of moisture in the air makes things damp & sticky.  No doubt thee has heard particulars of E.W. Copes last hours, the close must have been very peaceful, both Ellie & Madgie express their feelings of thankfulness that their mother did not have to endure long confinement and great suffering.  The funeral was small, so many are away, S. Morris and E Allen bore testimony to her character, there was nothing said at the grave but there was such a sweet, quiet feeling as we stood silently there in the evening lights, everything looking so beautiful & peaceful, words did not seem to be needed.  E. Allen said after meeting today to Eleanor & me, that after sheheard of E.W. Copes death she went into her room and such a sweet feeling came over her, she felt it was a forecast of the rest & peace into which Elizabeth Cope had entered.  I rode to the ground with cousin Rebecca Evans, she spoke of cousin Elizabeth, said the letter thee wrote her had been such a particular comfort and help to her, that Rebecca had felt she must write & tell thee but has been rather burdened with calls, so I said I would let thee know about it, I think R sent her love to thee.  Will & Grace have both had mumps, and little Mary, (Alice'sdaughter) has been very sick, she is now gaining down at the Dennis and Grace has been there with them.  Cousin Wm & John Rhoads have gone to T. Brown's camp for their vacation.  I send thee one of Esthers letters as thee may be interested to hear something of the Conference.  It seems to have been a time of spiritual refreshment & uplifting & I hope may prove of use to the building up of the Church.  Eleanor says the spirit of love & unity was very marked, Alfred urged that all [---] and feelings of antagonism between old & young, conservative & progressive should be laidaside, which seemed to be the case.  Alfred seems to feel his mind relieved of the concern, he went back to Bupshire yesterday & is going on to Northfield.  Frank Goodhue also went to Bupshire will spend today there & go on to Brattleboro taking little Mary with him.  Edith Silver came up on 5th day eve, it was very pleasant to see her, she went home yesterday, Betty & little Elizabeth & Sam Mason all went with her.  Betty intends spending a couple of weeks at Swallowfield where she hopes to have a good rest.  Francis Jr is at Bupshire so all the children are cared for.  Sister Eleanor & Tom I believe are going to Bupshire soon & Wistar to the South on business so the house will be deserted  for awhile.  Katy & the childrenpropose coming home on 3rd day.  Frank came on to the funeral but went back last night, I am glad for him to have a visit there.  Emma Edwards fell in her house and broke her hip, she is now very ill not expected to live & her life is not to be [---] under the circumstances.  I had an active time last week attending meetings but got on better than I expected to, tomorrow is Phila Quarterly Mg & 5th day ours, after that I shall take a rest and do a little here at home, as I see many things that need looking after.  I dont know when Esther will come home probably in about a week.  A great deal of love to dear Anna & also for thyself from thy attached sister
   
   Hannah B. Evans   

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Edward W. (Edward Wyatt) Evans:  1882-1976
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1906-09-30
Title: 1906 September 30, Awbury, to Mother

Awbury
   9/30/1906
   
   Dear Mother, 
   
   It certainly does seem much more than two days since we parted from thee and Anna, Miss Richardson and Harold on the ferry wharf at Jamestown. I don't know why the time should seem so long but it is even hard to realize that only last Tuesday father and I were looking out over the Bay blue as could be in the sunlight of a splendid September day as we sat on the deck of the "General" on our way to Wickford. It seemed a great shame to spend so good a day in that stuffy parlor car.
   
   We got through the packing very comfortably, and (although father did say that in the middle of one night he thought we would never be able to get it all done) with very little worry I think. The only thing now is that none of the freight has yet come. We seem to be getting along very nicely on what we have brought.
   
   Since my arrival at home I have been to see two of my doctor friends. Dr. Van Pelt and Dr. Bassett the latter fixed me up without doing anything very much, a lucky escape for me because I haven't been to the dentist for over a year and Dr. Van Pelt is going to make an examination of my eyes with the aid of drops later on in the year. He goes away tomorrow and thought there would hardly be time to do it now. 
   
    Last sixth day afternoon Father and I took a drive. We went up through the Wissahickon, pretty as usual though the foliage hasn't changed much and then stopped at the Philadelphia Cricket Club grounds where I met Alg. And we had some tennis. Father seems pretty well I think and says he has enough to keep him busy in town for some time so perhaps it is just as well the freight hasn't come yet or he might try to do something at once.
    
    Yesterday I went up the  Rancocas with Harold, George and Esther, Eleanor Haydock and Anita Downing. I believe Harold thought some of the members of the house party wouldn't be able to go so did not try to get there to-gether this time. In spite of the fact that it was a threatening day and rained just as we reached the ferry and notwithstanding the fact that Harold and I forgot to eat any lunch we had a very nice time and escaped any wetting. It cleared up before we got back and the moonlight was beautiful. Our only accidents were, I think, that Esther [---] on the [---] of a very irascible old Irish woman in the trolley car who swore around at a great rate and was not at all mollified by Esther's apology. Then Eleanor dropped her umbrellaafter meeting broke up. John and Mary Emlen were there and altho. they tried to get off pretty quickly thee may be sure a lot of us caught them and detained them for a word or two.
   
    Alf. is coming to us for supper which will be very nice. Alg. is now reclining on the sofa reading and sends his love to thee and Anna and Aunt Lilly. Before I close I must ask if thee has heard of the latest engagement--Billy Haines to a Miss Janvier, of Orange, NJ and niece of Thomas Janvier who writes for the magazines somewhat.    
     [---] in Alg's message of love to you all and [---]
   
   They affectionate son
   Edward   

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Date: 1901-02-15
Title: 1901 February 15, to Family

Friday the 15th
   2/16/01
   
   Dearest Family, 
    
   I have just been reading a very nice letter from Polly, which I was rightly glad to get. If you think of it tell her so with a great deal of love and many thanks from me. Then I have some more beautiful flowers to thank thee for,  Father dear. They were truly beautiful, and are still lovely though some of them, the roses especially, show their age! Miss Richardson thought they were packed better and seemed fresher if anything than the ones from [Waltemates?]. I suppose my attack of Grippe was the excuse for my having these, but I am afraid it sounded more than it was.  I dont think the doctor was atallsure it was Grippe, & if it was I dont think Ive heard of such a light case!  Thank thee [---] so much , dearie, for the lovely flowers and the letter that came with them.  I'd like some more of the last mentioned article whenever thee has time & feels like it but thee really mustnt send me any more of the former.  While we are on the flower subject, just pay thyself $5.00 from me, will thee?  I have moneyin bank I think, & my flower bill this month or lately will about amount to that I think.  I have been indulging myself by sending some to different people.  Some violets to Miss Stedman (who has had a cold) etc.  People have been so kind to me here.
   
   I havent got to the boys photo. yet, there are so many things to say.  I think it is mighty nice, & I am so glad to have it.  It is a little like seeing them.  It stands on my bureau & this morning I burst out laughing just looking at it.  I could just imagine from seeing their expressions the kind of time they had getting it taken.  Edwards expression especially makes me laugh.  Thank you all for it ever so much.  You must feel somewhat repaid for all your trouble, for it is so nice to have it.  If AuntLilly or Ellie have room I think I'd like some of my other photos.  Any that you can find.  Also my other belt buckle, if you can find it easily.  I think I had it at Conanicut.  It is a clasp & looks something like silver.  It isnt important at all.  If you have a copy of "She Stoops to Conquer" that isnt too nice perhaps you would send that too by them, ormail it to me later if you havent finished reading it by the time they come.  I just thought maybe I'd like to read it as you all are.  Oh & if you know where my visiting cards are I think it would just as well for me to have some & a card case if you can find one.  I dont suppose I need them, but I might want one for something later on.  I'd rather also like to have my black bloomers (sort ofsilk they are made of) sometime, but there is no hurry.
   
   I am sending thee, dearest Mother, something I started for thee last Fall, but have only finished lately.  I thought thy old one was pretty well worn.  I dont think I showed thee when thee was here the hound glass I got Miss Webb to get me as a birthday present from thee.  Does thee remember thee told me to get one & never did? It is a very nice one I think.  The usual shape & white celluloid I think.  Now I am talking to thee.  I'll just say one or two things I want to.  First Miss Richardson asked me to thank thee for thy message & to remember her to thee.  She is so nice.  Sweet & jolly- I think I am very fortunate.  Thee ought to hear us laughing over things sometimes.  Sheis young & ready for fun.  Then if thee thinks of it when thee writes to Cousin Hannah wont thee give her my dear love and thanks for the little book & the letter she sent me at Christmas.  And please give my love to Cousin Sallie too and thank them both for the very nice message they sent me when I was first taken sick.  I have on the table in front of me a nice fat looking letter from thee, Mother dear, but I'm afraidI wont have time to read it before I finish this, as I am going sleighing in a few minutes & the postman may come before I get back.  Thank thee for it though ever so much.  And thank thee, dear Ern, for thy nice one which came the early part  of the week.  It was nice to hear from thee once again.  If there are any loose pictures ofour house & Awbury floatinh around send those with the other photos.
   
   Now good-by.  With a great deal of love for each one of you, dear ones, I am
   Your loving
   Anna
   
   PS.  Please give my love to the girls & remember me to Simon if he is still with us.

Date: 1901-03-21
Title: 1901 March 21, to Mother

Thursday-
   March 21st
   
   Darling little Mother, 
   
   I am going to begin my letter to thee to-day, though I dont think I will send it at once, as I sent one home yesterday, which I imagine thee will receive the end of this week, that is if they send it on at once.  But as  I am expecting to be taken sick to-morrow or next day & may not feel like writing.  I dont think I will do any [---] to begin my letter now.  I think I have told most of the news in my letter home.  Wasn’t it fine about my going in to see the pictures?  I think I will mail thee the catalogueas thee might be interested, & it is very prettily gotten up.  I am sorry that the pictures in the catalogue are not the ones I especially enjoyed, for I should like to have had copies of some of them, & the pictures in the catalogue are pretty enough to frame-  I mean the finish & all.  The coloring of the Blue Boy & his pose Iliked, also the coloring of the “Little Girl with Doll” was lovely, but I didn’t care much for them.  The Blue Boys [---] was an unusual shade of blue, bordering on green but soft & not starey & there were lovely shades of old rose in the Little Girl etc.  The ones I marked were the ones I liked, especially “The Elder Sister,” & the Romney ones,a dear little head by Bougereau & perhaps some others I dont just think of.  The little childs head by Gilbert Stuart I was interested in & rather liked.  I hardly saw the modern ones at all, as we had only about 20 minutes there. 
   
   Wednesday morn. 
   I am almost sorry I didnt finish this letter up some days ago & send it  even if I could say all I wanted to- for I shant be able to do that now, as I want it to go by this morning’s mail-  I have been unwell since I started this- taken just on the day, isnt it fine?- I’ve been as regular as can be lately- in fact ever since last Fall sometime.  But I must hurry up &say some at least of the things I want to.  I sent the catalogue of the pictures to thee last Monday, but dont know whether thee will ever receive it, as I directed it to Berkley- Thee put Berkley, Md, at the head of thy letter so I thought I’d try it & I put my address on it, so it will come back to me, I guess,if it never reaches thee.  I also sent thee the little [sagne?] & hoods & socks I have been making, thinking thee might like to see them.  I hope thy trunk isnt very crowded or they may not be as welcome as I should like.  I directed them to Darlington, I dont believe the little sagne would bebig enough for Edith’s baby, so dont bother about it.  Thee will probably be a baby some of these days I shall want it for, & the little hoods may be useful, too.  I’m glad to have learned how to make them at any rate. 
   
   It is nearly time for  the post man, so I’m going to say good-by & write the rest again.  If any one of the boys should want to know something to give me on my birthday, I’m very fond of Burne-Jones “Hope” & should like a photo of it, but remember only if they want to knowsomething.  I must finish in a rush & with a great great deal of love, darling from
   
   Thy little Daughter.     

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1873-08-05
Title: 1873 August 5, Lowwood Hotel, Lake Windermere, to mother

Lowwoord Hotel
   Lake Windermere
   
   My dear Mother
   
   Altho I have written to father and Tom has also written a long letter so that I am afraid they will be as uninteresting as "twice-told tales" yet I am going to send thee a few lines in a scrappy way for they own edification. We do so enjoy having Tom with us and he seems to be not only enjoying himself but improving--when he first joined us at London he looked very badly not having recovered from the sea voyage I suppose he was very pale and thin, but has been gaining pretty steadily so that now his cheeks have quite a color and he looks fuller in the face than I ever remember to have see him--I do not think his leg troubles him much, as he says it does not hurt him, and he walks about a good deal--we shall try to keep him from doing too much--
   
   I think Chellie seems stronger than when we left home, as she is certainly able to walk more and does not get as fatigued as she would at home--
   
   She has gained some flesh but is not what you would call stout yet. For a day or two her throat has been a little swelled, but I shall get her some [tannin?] or a gargle and I think that will relieve her. I have written [---] particularly in regard to health as I know thee would like to know. The weather except a few days in London has been cool so that we have generally not been able to wear our [thin?] clothes. Chellie has not found her waterproof dress to wear for traveling and now that we are going north shawls are called into acquisition. Evening 9.05. I wish thee could look in upon us this evening and see how snugly we are fixed, seated around a centre table in our cosey little parlor with four candles burning upon on the table and at this point Tom came in and proposed we should take a row upon the lake in the moonlight and as it was a lovely evening we went and now have just returned--I did wish for some of the girls form Awbury for it was so perfectly beautiful that even the [staid manied?] people almost grew sentimental--The lake was just rippled by the gentle wind and the moon was hanging over the western mountains throwing a silvered path across the water, and on the shores we could dimly see the outlines of Wray Castle and the pretty residences with which the shores are studded, and in which the lights were brightly shining. The rain which continued most of the day stopped toward evening and although the roads were rather muddy we started out for exercise and had a pleasant walk of three miles toward Bowness. [---] tt has cleared we expect to start early tomorrowmorning for Keswick. As this letter is for thy information on little points in travels I will tell thee of our general hours. We find it suits us best not to dine later than three or half past and so whether we take our dinner at the hold or elsewhere try to have it at that hour. We breakfast generally at half past eight and then take tea at half past seven or eight and spend our evening in our sitting room either writing home or in journals or in talking over the scenes of the day and planning for the morrow. In traveling we generally manage to have a car to ourselves and Reuben looks after the baggage and Tom eitherkeeps him or assists Chellie and H, while I am buying our tickets-  We get along very nicely indeed-  In the last letters thee said that some of them at home thought "thee was writing too much", I hope thee will not stay thy hand on that account, but only as thy strength will warrant, for I can assure thee every detail of home news is very interesting-  We think of you very very often and I hope the time may come when thee will enjoy the beauties which we are visiting, but altho the present is so full of enjoyment the future (when we shall return to your midst) looks very pleasant.
   
   The little books dear mother, which thee gave us just before leaving are our constant compantions in our travels and it is pleasant to think as we read them morning and evening that thee too has them and altho the time may be different yet we read them the same day-  I enclose a little bunch of wild flowers which I picked while visiting Swarthmore part of them I gathered at the meeting house and part from the Hall, I wish they were better preserved but they were pressed under difficulties in my pocketbook and I had to arrange them for pressing as we walked.  I send them thinking thee might like a little memento of Swarthmore-  I am afraid this will prove a scrappy letter and rather uninteresting for it is madeup of little nothings-  Hannah desires her love to thee and the rest of the Awbury family-  When thee sees them at School Lane please give them my love also a great deal to all at home and at Uncle Toms and Uncle John's, Chellie has retired or would join me in these messages-  With much love I am thy loving son
   J.Evans.
   P.S.  I dont know if any mention has been made of how Reuben is and as his father and mother were rather anxious about him when we left, will thee tell them that I think he is much better, but would improve faster if he took more rest especially in writing his letters and journal as he often sets up late and is up early-  

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1874-07-20
Title: 1874 July 20, Greenbrier White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia, to Mother

7th mo 20th 1874
   
   My dear Mother
   
   I hope this evening that no one has written home for a day or two and know thee will like to hear often so I will send a few lines this evening before the mail closes.  We have had a very warm day the thermometer standing at 83 [degrees] a good deal of the time and there has been very little air stirring-  This morning Mary, Alexis Alf, John Hazen and Henry made an excursion to the top of Kate's Mountain.  They had an early breakfast and got off about 8 oclock and did not get back until nearly one.  They had a pretty rough scramble and some how did not get to the right place and so missed the view-  I was glad they went as they thought it paid and I am afraid they find it rather monotonous-  The life is a very lazy one and while it is so warm in the middle of the day there is very little to be done in the way of excercize, with any comfort-  I think Alf seems better and the water suits him but Hazen is not able to drink the sulphur water and does not seemed to have impreoved as much as I hoped he would-  I do not mean that he is sick but he still looks pale.  He seems bright and much less nervous than when he left home and I hope he will improve more after his return-  Lily has bathed twice (yesterday and today) having her bath at about 100 [degrees] and says she thinks it suited her for after lying down she felt refreshed and better-  but of course it is too soon for there to be much change-  She stayed in the first day only about 2 minutes and today 5 so thee sees she is feeling her way.
   
   This afternoon Lily and Alexis took a drive-  I have been disappointed 3
   in the air here it is not bracing at all-  and as the mountains are all around us often we get but little breeze-
   
   The daily routine of our life here is not thrilling-  We rise about half past seven and it is often half past eight before we get assembled at the breakfast table-  After breakfast (which we rarely get through until quarter past nine) we walk around the grounds for a little while visiting the spring, Japanese Store, Post Office &c and then spend the time until 11 o'ck (when we bathe) either in reading, writing or talking-.  After the bath we put in the time as best we may until dinner time 2 O'clk.  After dinner we set out under the trees upon the lawn or upon our piazza and read aloud or talk until tea time and after tea we generally take a walk and then sit in the parlor until bedtime "and thus our days go on, go on"  The boys vary it occasionally by a little walk upon their own account or by going swimming or sometimes we roll a game of ten pins-  I have gone very much into details and I have no doubt father and Tom will laugh at the letter and groan over such a life (so do I) but I thought these little nothings would interest thee and moreover there is very little else to tell-  Our movements in the future are very uncertain and as yet we cannot say when we shall home or whether some will remain- as soon as some conclusion is arrived at we will let you know.  Please give a great deal of love to father Tom Anna & Carrie in which Chellie would join me if she knew I was writing but I am in the gentlemans writing room and she does not know of it-  With much love for thyself I am thy loving son J. Evans

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1857-1897
Date: 1875-11-28
Title: 1875 November 28, Church Lane, to brother

Church Lane 11 mo 28. 75
   
   My dear brother
   
   Having received a message from thee through a letter to Tom, and not being able to plead sickness as a reason for not writing, I am going to send thee a greeting-  Well we are not going to see thee until next spring, it seems a long time, and we were all of us not a little disappointed when the news came.  We were counting the days until the time when thee was to sail and beginning to speculate upon the probable length of the passage, when suddenly all our hopes were dashed-  I was going to say I would not flatter thee by telling thee what lamentations there were on the part of some of us, but I think it does no one harm to know how much they are loved and missed at home, on the contrary I think  to a young man it does good, tending perhaps to keep him out of some things by which he might otherwise be tempted-  Now for the scrape of news I can glean up-  Last fourth day Tom and I drove over to Haverford to bring away thy [chattels?]-  We arranged to go on third day, but on that day we had a regular old fashioned Nor'easter and it poured most of the day-  The next morning about nine oclock Tommy appeared at our house in the [---] with Lady and Eric (Harry having been laid up some time with sore feet) after getting some more warm wraps for it had cleared off quite cold when we started-  The roads were in a pretty miserable state of muddiness and as we undertook to go by the Lancaster road we almost stuck so to speak-  However we reached the College about half past eleven, and finding the students in recitation we went up stairs and explored-  We found all thy things had been moved out of thy room and were locked up in another closet of which the matron hadkey so she had to be hunted up-  We packed most of the books and some other things in a drawer which Tommy and I carried down to the front door Tommy saying it was "like carrying down a little coffin"-  We donated to Frank Haines a bottle of eye wash, a little bottle of carbolic acid and a few other valuables?-  Thus were the last rites performed-  We packed the books in the bottom of the wagon, and put the precious articles, around with we supposed tender associations ( clung , (a broken fan with names thereon &c) between folds of the down cover-  We drove home to dinner reaching Awbury about quarter of four-  We had a good laugh at Tom - one of the objects over was to bring home the hanging book shelf and we forgot all about it, and came home without it - which rankled in Tommy's breast-  By the way talking of Haverford does thee know they have raised a sufficient amount of money to enable them to build, and Samuel Alsop Jr told me it was decided to go ahead-  The day we werethere was the day before Thanksgiving day, and as I waited upstairs in the entry while Tom was hunting up the Matron I was amused at two of the students, one was in the hall down stairs and as the other came out I suppose from recitation - he announced the fact that they were going to have Turkey for dinner, whereupon there went up such a howl of rejoicing as almost upset me-  We hoped while at Haverford to have had time to have called upon Margaret Yarnall, but we spent to much time at Any Marys that we had not time.  I suppose you have heard that Ellis and M Yarnall are boarding at [---] during the Winter.  I am glad to hear they are vert comfortably fixed-  It seems an out of the way kind of place for them, a good deal away from most of the latter's friends, I should think she would long to have her daughter with her.  I do feel for them very much-  First day 12/5.  A week, my dear Afred, has passed since I commenced this letter yet it is not finished.5
   During the week we have been pained from day to day to hear of Uncle Alfred's increasing illness.  As early as the beginning of the week Dr Wister said he seemed to be failing, and on second day they telegraphed for James, they received an answer the next morning only saying "will come" and that is all they have heard.  Up to second day Uncle Alfred has been able to get over into the library, this he has accomplished with the aid of a man who has been staying with him at night for a number of weeks- assisting him to dress and undress.  One second day he was so much weaker that he had to remain in bed- and since then he has been gradually growing weaker and weaker, until yesterday afternoon about three o'clock he quietly passed away-  He does not seem to have had any acute disease-  His appetite almost entirely gave out, and he gradually weakened - with the exception of a pain in one of his lungs I do not think he has suffered any-  Since last first day Uncle Tom and John E Carter have been sitting up with him half of alternate nights, the nurse sitting up the other half.  Lilly and Edward have been staying over at Fairfield for the last day or two-  Yesterday morning having heard how he was the evening before Father, Uncle Tom and Aunt Lizzie went over there, the Doctor came soon after they arrived and said he did not think he could live but a few minutes.  They went up into his room (except Father who had gone on to town) and sat there for two hours awaiting the close- he seemed entirely conscious but lay perfectly still excepting once when he passed his hand through his hair as his custom was and once he put his hand under his head-  They went to dinner and a few minutes after dinner was over he passed away, no one but Aunt Rebecca, Lily and Edward being present.  Just at the close, there was a short spasm and then to him all was joy and peace and rest-  What a wonderful and glorious change it must be for him after a long life of ill health and suffering during which I suppose he could never have said he really felt well, to awake inthat Holy City none of whose inhabitants can say I sick and where "there shall be no more death, neither sorrow nor crying, neither shall there be ay more pain: for the former things are passed away"-  Aunt Caroline seems to feel it very much, not having seen for some time except a few days ago, when hearing how sick he was she went out to see him, but ut was thought best for her not to go in the room or let him see her so she looked at him through the door-  The only remarks I have heard that Uncle Alfred made (though he probably said more which I have not heard) were that some days ago he told J.E.C. "that it made very little difference which way it ended" meaning his sickness-  To E. Allen who visited home within a few days, and as she was leaving said she supposed she should never see him on earth again and that she did not doubt but that the change would be a glorious one to him he replied "I have been forced to feel very quiet and peaceful"  I think those were the words he used-  The funeral is to be next third day at two oclock.  It will be a great trial I doubt not to James to find all over when hearrives - 
   
   Last sixth day Uncle Tom commenced his winter readings and it was said to have been a very interesting occasion-  Neither Chellie nor I was able to get there-  There is a good deal of stir in our City now over the meetings of Moody & Sankey-  They have fitted up the old freight depot of the Pennsylvania RR so that it will seat about eleven thousand and meetings are being held I think twice on week days and three times on first days - they are largely attended and from accounts some of them must be impressive.  I hope they may do good-
   
   I suppose Mother in her weekly letter told you that Hazen had sprained his ancle, turned it under him as he was rushing out of the side door to catch the train-  Tommy seems to think it was a mercy he sprained it as it will probably save him from something worse if he will only take warning.  He had to hold it up for nearly a week.  However he is about again now tho he says it feels weak.  Aunt Lizzie Brown is still down at Atlantic City where she has been for some 9
   weeks and from accounts does not seem much better.  Aunt Fanny went down last third day taking with her a maid to stay with aunt Lizzie-  I am afraid her sickness is a pretty serious one and not to be gotten over in a hurry.  The rest of them at Grandfathers are pretty well now-  Grandfather has had a cold but is better-  Aunt Martha Leeds I suppose you have heard is at the Frankford Asylum, and from last accounts was not much better in her mind and was also very sick with [---] in her head-  I dont know whether thee has heard or not that the new building at Haverford is to go up next year they having got enough subscribed to warrant them in commencing so Samuel Alsop Jr told me.
   
   Lillies letter from [---] arrived on sixth day last and we were very glad to hear of your being so comfortably and pleasantly fixed-  Please give a great deal of love to both Lilly and Alexis and tell them I often think of them both with much affection and truly it does seem a long long time since we parted with them.  I do hope the stay will do you all a great deal of good-  I am afraid you have missed some of our letters Chell and I both misunderstood and have been directing our letters to Brown-Shipley & Co Liverpool - and I am afraid they have not forwarded them-  I wrote not long ago a letter to thee and one to Lilly and Alexis enclosing a photograph of the baby to each-  If they have never come to hand I will send you another-  Harry has at last made up his mind to return to Minneapolis - he expects to start next fourth day.  I hope he will have a more prosperous time the coming year than he has had the last-  Upon looking over the forepart of this letter which I wrote a week ago I find I have mentioned about the building at Haverford in that so thee will please excuse my telling it again-  I dont feel like rewriting the letter-  Chell sends her love to you all in which I join and wish you "a merry Christmas" and "a happy New Year"-  I remain thy
   loving brother
   J Evans    

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1883-07-15
Title: 1883 July 15, Awbury, to wife

Awbury 7/15-83
   
   My own dear wife
   
   Anna and Hazen arrived home yesterday in good condition and as Anna wrote to mother yesterday I will not go into details of the journey or arrival.  They were however the [---] of various testimonials of love to me so that I feel quite rich.  Dear little children how sweet it was of them, however I am going to write each of them a letter either today or tomorrow.  I am ever so much obliged dearest for thy letter-  I am so glad to hear that Algie seems so much better and hope he will continue to improve-  I am glad thee is not pressing the Cod Liver oil as I am afraid it will upset his stomach and thus do more harm than good.  When thee writes tell me what the Dr thinks of his condition.  I am more and more inclined to think he caught the disease from Edward.
   
   We have been to meeting this morning and had sermons from E. Allen and W Kite and a prayer from Sarah Johnson.  The meeting was small.  We brought Cousin Anna Rhoads home with us as she was all alone-  Cousin James having gone to New Hope to spend First day.  Hazen and Anna expect to go over to Cousin C Hartshorne to tea this evening.  We are getting along very nicely dearest and thee need not feel the least concerned about.  I am really very comfortable and as to health am much better I have a good appetite in fact I expect I eat too much for my dyspepsia - which however is better - And now dearest I want to tell thee that I am sorry I said what I did at Newport-  I know my natural tendency is when everything goes along smoothly to settle down build castles in thr air and enjoy this world and I have no doubt that I need to be [---] more and more from this world and that our loving and merciful Heavenly Father breaks up my rest and [---] this world's pleasures that I may look beyond and have my heart fixed on Heaven and Heavenly things -  Our Heavenly Father does not willingly affect and if it only has the effect intended it will be but one of the light affliction which last but for a moment-  Therefore my dearest pray that I may grow better and better - I reallylong that such may be the case but the flesh is very weak.  I feel as our dear children are growing up I should be a better example to them -  So dearest do not worry about me but try and get well and strong-  I think of thee very very often with the tenderest love and pray that we may grow together in best things which I know will make us happen and happen in each other and in out Children.  Farewell dearest.  Give my love to Mother and Aunt Mary and the [---] abd with lots for thy own dear self 
      I am thy loving husband
      JE.  

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1864-08-21
Title: 1864 August 21, Newport, to Mother

Newport Aug 21 1864
  1st day
  
  Dear Mother
  
  Aunt Mary received thy letter this morning or rather we did as we all read it first & then gave it to aunt Mary.  Cousin Charles & Carry & cousin Ellie Yarnall arrived last night or rather this morning, as the boat didnt get in till after 5 o'clock, consequently they were so tired that they are not going to get up till dinner time.  they could not get any state rooms & had to take berths so were very sick.  We took cousin Becky Howell & Annie out riding yesterday afternoon over to the three beaches & had a splendid time & got a good many shells, then in the evening we went out rowing on the bay with Eddie Howell & uncle H (the former makes a pretty good [bean?]) in the moonlight & sought the waves of the steam boats coming in, it was splendid, Lilly tried to row a little, but did not succeed very well.  Tell Aunt Annie I am going to get the story of the Haunted House fresh from Hannah Williams & Lilly or I will write it to her if she wants to know it very badly.  We were very glad to hear that you have cooler weather at home it must have been very hot - (pardonme, mamma) but it is only a slip of the tongue, I have in vain looked for hot in thy letters it's only "excessively warm."  Tell Hazen, Anna says she is going to bring home some shells to him & she wants him to answer her letter to him as soon as possible.  Aunt Mary sends her love & says she thinks she feels a little stronger though she don't attempt to walk far.  Anna wants me to tell Franky that some of the shells she is going to bring him are called boats & if he will put them in water they will float.  Love to papa, Alfred, Nannie & all at home & believe me thy loving daughter
  Chellie 2nd day
  
  Dear Sister-
  Chellie received thy letter at the dinner table to day, but feels rather disinclined to write in the few minutes we have to spare before going to ride.  We had a fine South West wind yesterday and again to day so that the surf at the bathing beach was first rate this morning.  Charles and Carry, Elly and our party with two ladies from this house made a [load?] for the omnibus and we all enjoyed the sight and sound of the beaches very much, but Henry, Jimmie, Elly, and Lilly, were the only ones to go in.  they had a splendid bath they said.  H. unfortunately is deaf in one ear since and does not feel quite well so I doubt their going in tomorrow unless C. escorts them - and he has the rheumatism - Charly thinks Newport air is all sufficient without bathing.-  H. says I have no time to write as the carriage will be here.  Chelly is quite well, and all the rest.  aff thy sister Mary
  Love to Frank and the children. P.S. Dear Frank - In writing my review which is on hand, I want to make sure of a word I think wrongly used in the book review, and have no dictionary here.  Will thee please look in your Imperial Dictionary, - or the Text of the Iconographic (Anatomical part) & send me word, if found, in your next letter, whether there are not two words, ilium and ileum,
  and the definition of the latter, if,
  as I am almost certain, there are the two,
  affly - [---] Newport Aug 21 1864
  1st day

H. unfortunately is deaf in one ear since and does not feel quite well so I doubt their going in tomorrow unless C. escorts them - and he has the rheumatism - Charly thinks Newport air is all sufficient without bathing.-  H. says I have no time to write as the carriage will be here.  Chelly is quite well, and all the rest.  aff thy sister Mary
  Love to Frank and the children. P.S. Dear Frank - In writing my review which is on hand, I want to make sure of a word I think wrongly used in the book review, and have no dictionary here.  Will thee please look in your Imperial Dictionary, - or the Text of the Iconographic (Anatomical part) & send me word, if found, in your next letter, whether there are not two words, ilium and ileum,
  and the definition of the latter, if,
  as I am almost certain, there are the two,
  affly - [---] 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Mary  Brown
Recipient:  Francis Reeve  Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1864-08-21
Title: 1864 August 21, Newport, to Mother

Newport Aug 21 1864
  1st day
  
  Dear Mother
  
  Aunt Mary received thy letter this morning or rather we did as we all read it first & then gave it to aunt Mary.  Cousin Charles & Carry & cousin Ellie Yarnall arrived last night or rather this morning, as the boat didnt get in till after 5 o'clock, consequently they were so tired that they are not going to get up till dinner time.  they could not get any state rooms & had to take berths so were very sick.  We took cousin Becky Howell & Annie out riding yesterday afternoon over to the three beaches & had a splendid time & got a good many shells, then in the evening we went out rowing on the bay with Eddie Howell & uncle H (the former makes a pretty good [bean?]) in the moonlight & sought the waves of the steam boats coming in, it was splendid, Lilly tried to row a little, but did not succeed very well.  Tell Aunt Annie I am going to get the story of the Haunted House fresh from Hannah Williams & Lilly or I will write it to her if she wants to know it very badly.  We were very glad to hear that you have cooler weather at home it must have been very hot - (pardonme, mamma) but it is only a slip of the tongue, I have in vain looked for hot in thy letters it's only "excessively warm."  Tell Hazen, Anna says she is going to bring home some shells to him & she wants him to answer her letter to him as soon as possible.  Aunt Mary sends her love & says she thinks she feels a little stronger though she don't attempt to walk far.  Anna wants me to tell Franky that some of the shells she is going to bring him are called boats & if he will put them in water they will float.  Love to papa, Alfred, Nannie & all at home & believe me thy loving daughter
  Chellie 2nd day
  
  Dear Sister-
  Chellie received thy letter at the dinner table to day, but feels rather disinclined to write in the few minutes we have to spare before going to ride.  We had a fine South West wind yesterday and again to day so that the surf at the bathing beach was first rate this morning.  Charles and Carry, Elly and our party with two ladies from this house made a [load?] for the omnibus and we all enjoyed the sight and sound of the beaches very much, but Henry, Jimmie, Elly, and Lilly, were the only ones to go in.  they had a splendid bath they said.  H. unfortunately is deaf in one ear since and does not feel quite well so I doubt their going in tomorrow unless C. escorts them - and he has the rheumatism - Charly thinks Newport air is all sufficient without bathing.-  H. says I have no time to write as the carriage will be here.  Chelly is quite well, and all the rest.  aff thy sister Mary
  Love to Frank and the children. P.S. Dear Frank - In writing my review which is on hand, I want to make sure of a word I think wrongly used in the book review, and have no dictionary here.  Will thee please look in your Imperial Dictionary, - or the Text of the Iconographic (Anatomical part) & send me word, if found, in your next letter, whether there are not two words, ilium and ileum,
  and the definition of the latter, if,
  as I am almost certain, there are the two,
  affly - [---] Newport Aug 21 1864
