Date: 1806-06-17
Title: 1806 June 17th, Weston, to Dear Mother

Weston 6.th mo. 17th 1806.
Dear Mother.
I cannot express my feelings, when I first read thy letter.  To lose two such near, and beloved, relations, so near the same time, and also to see the danger, our dear cousins Henry, and Arthur, have escaped.  I feel, I scarcely know how.  I feel, very unhappy.  I hope you will not refuse, to let us come home soon.  We have but 11 days to stay before our time is up.  I promise I will not be running about the streets as thou has mentioned in thy letter.  I will stay with you, read to you, and promise I will do all I can to make you happy as I know thou and Father must undergo a great deal of anxiety on account of our dear uncle and cousins.  I wonder why you did not inform us of grandmoth-er's illness or perhaps she was taken very unexpecdedly. I am ashamed to say, I know very little about the eclipse.  All that I know is that is occasioned by the passing of the moon between the sun and the earth and that part of the sun that the moon passes over appears dark to us. Please to give my love to Dear Father and uncle and cousin John Thomas. 
 From thy affectionate and loving son 
Francis Cope.6 mo 17th 1806

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Eleanor Cope Tyson:  1807-1847
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1821-02-22
Title: 1821, February 22, Trenton, to Brother

Thee will reccollect my dear Brother that when I last saw thee I promised to write to thee in a short time.  Thee will conclude that my short time is a pretty long one but I have been pretty constantly employed since I returned and have not felt in a very letter-writing humour.  I wrote to Caroline about 3 weeks ago and have not yet received an answer I hope thee will prove a better correspondent than she or I shall have but little encouragement to write.  I have begun tolearn french and I like it very much as far as I have gone.  Sister Rachel told me when I was at [Home] that Hannah Bolton had returned from Weston I should be obliged if thee would give my love to her when thee sees her.  Thee desired to know what I was studying.  I am studying, Geography, Grammar, history and spelling and at present how to write a letter worth reading.  Tell sister Rachel I should be pleased to receive a letter from her though I am not willing to risk writing just again but if she will write to me I will endeavour to be more punctual in the answering of her's than I have been of thine.
When thee writes please to tell me how mother is for I believe all ourfamily have forgotten me and therefore I need not look for a letter from any of them.  Tell Alfred I will answer his letter as soon as I possibly can.  mean-while he must wait patiently.  I must now stop for the present as school is just going to close.
Thee desires to know how the swelling is behind my ear I believe it is much the same as it was when I left home.
Please to give my love to Father, Mother, Grandmother, Rachel, William, Caroline & Alfred and accept a large share for thyself & little Mary From thy affectate sister 
Elenor

Trenton 2nd mo: 22nd 1821.Henry Cope
No 36 north 4th st
Philada

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Eleanor Cope Tyson:  1807-1847
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope:  1794-1863
Date: 1842-08-17
Title: 1842 August 17, Schooley's Mountain, to Rachel Reeve Cope

Schooley's Mountain Aug 17. '42 

Dear Sister Rachel

We had so uneventful a journey, I have been so quiet since our arrival here, that I have scarcely material for a letter. Travellers are expected, I believe, to be particularly entertaining. Now, there is no time when I feel less so. Fatigue, change of air & diet, always for a time, affect my health unfavorably; and then, the turmoil & bustle scatter the little wits I possess. So that, from home, I am an especially stupid correspondent. Still, as you were kind enough to wish to hear from us, and as we exchanged promises about writing, I will not wait for any thing worth saying, --as I may not have it at all, thee knows; -- and my delay may occasion me the disappointment of not receiving here, the speedy return letter from Fourth St, which is to be my reward.-- 

We had quite a pleasant time so far as Trenton, for our first day's exploit. We arrived there about half past five o'clock; and George with our baggage, via. steam-boat and rail-road, very shortly after. In the evening, we made a little visit to Elizabeth Gummere, who lives near the Hotel. They have a fine, large house, in a pleasant part of town, & express themselves, the young folks, most emphatically, pleased with their change of residence. As we were in the immediate neighborhood, we went with Eliza..th, to spend a few minutes with our old friend, Judge Gordon's wife. She looks and seems just the same asI recollect her in the days of my childhood. So it appears that in this bustling life, there are some not easily jostled out of their way. We found the Judge, some years ago, busy with his attempts to sell his map of New Jersey. It still seems a most interesting theme to him; & if we come this way six years hence, I dare say he will even then be ready to speak of its merits & to state that his stock is not yet exhausted.-- Fifth day night brought us within twelve miles of the mountain, and the next day at noon, we reached the end of our journey--and over such roads! I was thinking, perpetually, of the children's song "Here we go up, up, up, & here we go down, down" &c &c. To adopt little Cary's favourite style, the rain had washed such gulleys in the roads, & the stones were so bare, & there were so many of them!-- 
The first two days after we got here, we had three or four showers per day. By way of consolation, we were told, this was a favorable specimen of their weather this season. For the previous ten days, it had rained all the time. "Recorder [Vaux?]" who is here, calls it temperance weather. I wonder if [Espy] is a tee-totaller.--We were beguiled , when we first came, into taking a room in "the cottage" Its superior dimensions, privacy &c were warmly insisted upon. And as we like plenty of room, and don't like much noise, we thought it quite a prize. The sun shone so flatteringly upon the [compact?], that we never thought of the inconvenience of being drenched in going to our meals, or having them drenched  in being brought to us. As we have now had ample opportunity of trying it both ways, and don't relisheither, we begin to murmer. Coming in search of Health, we fancy too, that a sleeping apartment on the ground floor is not exactly the place to meet with her ladyship, this damp summer. We have some of the inconvenient "[Fine-ear]" family, moreover, next us, who have been very near getting us into a scrape. A grand-daughter of John Jacob Astor has been stoping with a Mr Kane, from Albany, and, under what her friends consider, very aggravated circumstances. They came here to spend the Honey moon, & unfortunately, were placed in the room adjoining ours. Job related to me, one day, in a confidential tone of voice, the history of their flight, as just detailed to him by Governor Coles. This they contrived to over-hear, & being displeased thereat, they imagined a series of questions and answers,-- Job & I being the speakers,-- about the pedigree, personal consequence &c of many of the boarders, which they carried directly to the individuals about whom we were said to be so curious, & from there, they came immediately back to us. Happily, they fixed upon people whom we knew perfectly well, & thus the absurdity of our asking who they were whom we had known all our lives, was sufficiently apparent, & created only a little merriment. But we were somewhat annoyed until we discovered the full extent of this eaves-dropping. Thus, the storms without, & the treachery within doors, have given us a thorough distaste to this part of the premises. Besides, there is more of a crowd than we wished to get into, & if the company does not diminish, we shall want to try some quieter region. Direct, here, however, as we shall leave instructions for letters tobe sent to us. -- We have had it very warm & almost clear now for a couple of days, & have been enjoying it by driving about. The country is sufficiently beautiful to render the slow climbing of hills by no means a tedious affair. The roads are kept in quite tolerable order, & occasionally, we come to a level piece of ground where we trot away quite merrily. People tell us wonders about the flush gained and the disease lost among these hills. I hope our cases may add to a reputation, so richly earned, according to all accounts. -- I should write to Caroline, but I am not a very disinterested letter writer; sowing only where I may hope to reap, --& I fear she is scarcely yet at home.--I should like much, to know how you all are, where you now are, & where you are to be for he next few weeks.--Does thee know where Father & Mother are & when Cara returns? When do you go to Susquehanna [---] & how are Anne's eyes? Tell her I have not seen a single cat since I left home; but we have plenty of little ducks & chickens, the feeding of which is a daily source of amusement to the children. I heard them complaining this morning, that the older ladies were interfering with this, their peculiar privilege. Indeed the belles and beaux seem to find it quite as entertaining as they--remember, my dear R, that thee is bound to procure me a letter, in some way. Either from under thy own hand, (how is it?) or from one of those to whom thee can say "do this & he doeth it." If thee is not well enough, I shall calculate a little, too, on the affection & kindness of my nephews & niece. I do not know whether it will be any thing of a bribe-but I always make it a point to answer letters addressed to me--some time or other. If I should not


Henry Cope Esq.
For R. R. Cope.
N. 4th St.
Philadaget time during the excursion, I shall recollect my indebtedness on a future occasion.--Our love to brother H, to your segment of our family circle, & to all othermembers of it who are in the city. The carriage is waiting for me. Fare thee well! in haste, but very affectionately, sayeth thy sister 
E. C. Tyson:----We have determined to leave here on Second day. Will you not so arrange it as that a letter may reach us before then? It will gratify us very much.---

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Brown Cope Stork:  b. 1862
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1874-08-10
Title: 1874 August 10, Awbury, to Lilly

Awbury
Aug 9th 1874

Dear Lily
I got thy very nice note day before yesterday and was very glad to get it. Yesterday was very rain and about 7 o-clock  it just poured. Haines and High Street & Locust Avenue bridges were all washed away and a man and a and a boy were going along Locust avenue after darkand the lamps were not lit because of the rain I suppose and the both of them were drowned. Uncle Harry & Aunt Mary and Anna are staying over here and we are having a splendid time. Brother Jonnie & Chellie & Hazen came home yesterday to dinner and we think they look better except Hazen but we are going to sent him down to Atlantic City tomorrow to get fat. Cousin Clemmie came over to meeting today and went to Uncle Tom's to dinner. I am going to wait till Alexis is smart enough to writeto me before I write to him. As I have nothing more to say I will close. Hoping thee will excuse this very great scribble I remain they very affectionate sister
Anna B. Cope
P.S. Please give my love to the rest of the party remaining.My dear [Lulu] - As A.B.C. has left a blank page I concluded to fill it, having had it on my mind to send you a word of greeting all day & not having accomplished it. J. & I are at father's this evening ['leaving"], & are now sitting in the library with quite a party. Uncle H & aunt Mary (who with Anna are staying here) cousin Clem, aunt Lizzie, Mary, Henry, & "the family". Father's [----] have yielded to- I don't know what- but he seems to have recovered pretty much & goes to meeting, town[--] as usual. Tom is not quite up to par, but seems in excellent spirits. J& I are about as when we left you I was somewhat tired with the journey but feel pretty much rested now. Last night we had a regular pelting rain, so that the country was flooded in parts, and the bridgesswept away our Armalt St. & High a man & a boy were drowned crossing at Armalt St. Tom has recovered his clothes from the Custom House & is now wearing one of the suits. Father says before he goes to [-] S. Springs, he's rather go to sea & be sick so there is not much hope of his joining you. J says to give you his love & tell you he's sorry for you. Love to all. 
R. C. E.Elizabeth S. Cope
Old Sweet Springs 
Monroe Co. 
W. VirginiaAwbury

Title: 1869 October 10, Philadelphia, to Mother

[10.10.1869]

Dear Mother
I am at home. I am glad to get home. I was nearly home-sick at Haverford. Carry wrote a letter to thee. Carry sleep in father's room and she has stopped taking her bottle. I left my hat at Haverford. Thy affectionate daughter. 

AnnaDear Mama 

I stay home a day 

ie. sister Lilly & muda went a Newport

C M CopeAnna S. Cope
Care of Mary Williams
Newport R.I.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Francis Cope:  1794-1816
Recipient:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Date: 1810-02-09
Title: 1810 February 9, to Brother

February 9th 1810

Dear Brother. 

It seems as if it always came to my lot to write to thee, and although I have not much objection in common, especially when I have any thing to tell thee of that may give thee pleasure, yet when anything of a contrary nature happens, I think I had rather give up the pen to an able hand which while it informs of the affliction, can at the same time mingle some portion of consolation therewith, but as no other has time to write, I must, however unpleasant the task, proceed to inform thee of thee sorrowful loss we have sustained in our family, since thee last heard from us. 

Death stalks forth in darkness, his approach is silent as the grave, his hand is ev-ry where; no one can say he will see the light of tomorrow; our dear, our beloved, our affectionate Samuel is no more.  The unrelenting tyrant has taken him from us in the prime & vigour of his life; that sweet voice, which has oft  been the first sound, that has struck my ear upon awaking in the morning, 

alas! is silenced forever; that little tender bill that so oft hath received its food from my hand is stiff, cold, dead!  On fourth day evening just before I went to school I got up and look'd at him in his cage, he was sitting sorrowfully in one corner. "If he lives till tomorrow" said I, "I will take him up stairs, put him out at the window, perhaps the sun & fresh air may revive him."  I then went to school. After school I again look'd at him, he was sitting in the corner as before, very sorrowfully and look'd very poorly indeed.  I went down cellar & caught him 3 or 4 spiders he eat them, poor fellow!  it was the last morsel he eat. after havinggiven him the spiders I sat down to read.  I had not read long before I heard him struggling.  I immediately got up & look'd in the cage he was lying on the bottom apparently dead; I opened the cage & took him out,  I hold him to the fire & warmed himmy hands & breath, it revived him, he sat up on my hand & seem'd considerably better; Grandmother then took he sat on her finger for awhile & he flew off on to the floor, Grandmother then said she was afraid he would fly into the fire, & we had better put him into the cage, we accordingly put him in & got some tow for him to lie on, for poor fellow he was so weak he could scarcely stand.  Sally was the afraid he would get his feet entangled in the tow & accordingly she took him out & took the tow away & put a piece of muslin in its plase.  I believe the exertion of taking him our & putting him back again was too much for him, he laid down on the muslin, struggled, strech'd himself out, and ----died----peace to his ashes.  The next morning I sat myself down & wrote the following little tribute to his memory, And is thy little spirit fled? And art thou number'd with the dead? Thy little heart has ceas'd to beat; And lifeless lay thy little feet; How stiff, how cold, thy tender wing; Thy warb'ling throat hath ceas'd to sing; Thy spark'ling eyeball erst so bright, Is clos'd forever from the light. And is thy little spirit fled?And art thou number'd with the dead? Sweet warbler, now my gladden'd ear, No more thy tender notes shall hear. No more thy voice at early dawn, I shall welcome in the summer morn. No more thy little nimble feet, Shall run the offered food to meet. And is thy little spirit fled? And art thou number'd with the dead? How oft enraptur'd have I heard, Thy warbling notes sweet gifted bird, And thought as all amaz'd I stood; I heard each songster of the wood, Alas!  no more my gladden'd ear, Thy tender warbling notes shall hear.Alas!  thy little spirit's fled, And thou art number'd with the dead.We have found thy books and I expect we shall send them along with this letter.  Grandmother sends her love and says "tell him nobody was present when the bird died but thee & I, we attended on it the last."
From thy affectionate Brother
 FrancisWe have found thy books and I expect we shall send them along with this letter.  Grandmother sends her love and says "tell him nobody was present when the bird died but thee & I, we attended on it the last."
From thy affectionate Brother
 Francis
NB I have neither seen nor heard anything of a letter to E. Drinker, pray what is the reason of this?  is thee mad?Francis Cope - Philadelphia 2 mo. 9 1810 elegy of [?] mockingbird William D. CopeWeston

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Francis Cope:  1794-1816
Recipient:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Date: 1811-01-11
Title: 1811 January 11, Philadelphia, to Bill

January 11th 1811

Dear Bill

Mother not being very well she desires me to write to thee, and I being in no great humour for writing just now shall cut the matter as short as possible. Glad thee examined the date of mother's last letter thee would have perceived the reason of her not acknowledgeing the receipt of thine, they both having been written on the same day. She sends thee thy gloves and pantaloons and a little something to pull sleds wherewithal. Grandmother sends her love to thee, she has not been very well these days past but is better.  All well besides. 

 Francis

Feeling something better, I would add a little to thy Brothers short communication.  He had forgot thy complaint that my letter was not dated.  I expected Henry S.D. would hand it to thee on the 26th of last year, the next day after it was written; but was not done.  I desired him to tell thee how it was, and likewise that we had found the Elements of Morality -- but he forgot both.  C. is willing to wait till thee comes for the other book.  I cannot help thinking that the perusal of thy last letter was of use to her; I fancied I could percieve thee caught a little of the spirit of it, for she has been more dutiful since in her behaviour to me.  I mention it for thy encouragement.  I suppose thou will hardly believe, what is nevertheless true -- that is, the great good even children may do by their example; especially the elder set of children inFamily's.
 I could but be thankful to Great Inspirer of all virtue in thought and deed, for the disposition thy last letter evinced.  The propriety of manner -- the modesty of thyrequests -- the gratitude it breathed -- and the discernment so indicative of good sense, that it is thy happiness alone I seek -- were all such symptoms of promise -- such signs ofripening worth, that my heart rejoiced as in the embryo buds which in the spring time of Life [shew?] forth the beginnings of those excellent fruits which, bye the Sun of Righteousness, shining in the Soul, are in due time brought to perfection. Dearest William! the desire to do right, and the fear of not doing so exactly, are precious sensibilities.  May they never be extinguished in thy Breast!
Betsy was pleased with thy becoming notice of her part in the present -- it was becoming, according to thy apprehension, whether thy idea was just or not.  In reallity tho', Ann had the largest share in the cake making & baking business -- Betsy was very busy about other things and Ann & I had it chiefly to ourselves -- I believe she was determined however, if the acknowledgement did not belong to her then, it should e'er long -- for she has set her mind upon sending the some mince pyeWilliam D. Cope.
W
W Westone
William D. Cope

Mary Cope & Francis Cope.
Philadelphia.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Katharine Wistar Evans Stokes:  1841-1904
Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Date: 1887-08-17
Title: 1887 August 17, to Brother

8- 17th 1887
 
My dearest brother, 
Would thee be willing to buy us a basket of peaches on 7th day morning and send them down by the 2.10 trian marked Francis Stokes borrowings, via Perryville- Hannah craves some very much and Dr. Sappington says she may eat a little. They are not to be had here for love or money. Thee can pay for them out of the money thee has of mine. 
Poor dear H. does not seem to improve much & her spirits have failed, soshe is quite down-hearted. She comes down-stairs in the evening but has not strength and no appetite- & is right wretched. 
I wish thee could come down on 7th day & spend 1st day with us. We would be delighted to see thee & would not keep thee in her room. The maids are improving, Sarah is a sitting up and I think Mary will be able to do so tomorrow. 
Esther returned this afternoon looking well and rosy. She will be a great help & Edith feels quite made up again. 
I don't see any prospect at all of my going toNewport and if there is any one else to take my place I hope you will invite them. When Hannah does get better I think the sea-air would do her a great deal of good and I hope build her up, and I know in your kindness you will set an open door before her. It is a great disappointment to Franky but perhaps he can go with her. It sounds very presumptous in me to write all this but you are always so kind and cordial it is apt to make us ['"fresh"]. 
It grows late & I must stop, with warmest love thy K.5th day morning - Hannah seems weak this morning. we had rather a disturbed night, for a water-spout and the closet leaked & Frank & Esther  & I were [bobbing] round in a very [-----] manner. It reminded me of a our experiences one night when the was down here- 2 1/2 inches of rain fell in less than 2  hours. 
Frank says that very nice peaches can be got at the corner of Market & [Merrick] right near the depot. I don't know how much they will be but I suppose $1.50 or $2.00

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Francis R. (Francis Reeve) Cope:  1878-1962
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1884-07-23
Title: 1884 July 23, Woodbourne, to Grandpa

Woodbourne 7/23/84

Dear Grandpa:

We went down to the Lake & caught some catfish with Uncle Tom in the boat.  We have a box of cards up here.  They are cut in pieces & we make things of them.  Uncle Tom shot at a board out by the stone wall.  I shot too.  Mamma is afraid for me to do it but Uncle Tomthinks it's very nice.  We went to Montrose yesterday afternoon with Miles, & Uncle Tom & Annie, & I bought a tin-elephant & a tin-cart for ten cents with my own money. Uncle Tom found his [--------].  Miles found it in the grocery store, & Mrs. Walker found it in the little narrow-gauge train & sent it there.
Thy affectionate grandson 
Francis R. Cope Jr.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Francis R. (Francis Reeve) Cope:  1878-1962
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1890-08-17
Title: 1890 August 17, Woodbourne, to Grandma

Dear Grandma

I was very much obliged for the book thee sent me on my birthday, about General Wolf in Canada.  I have read some if it and I think it is veryinteresting.  Please tell Algie I was very much obliged for the paper he sent me, tell him that I will write to him soon.  I got a very nice fishing-pole from Mama & uncle Tom, & a reel & some lines from Grandpa.  I also got a history of England from Mama which I think interesting.  Agnes & Mrs. Oliver each gave me a book, and Ellie gave me a knife.  Cousin Anna & Virginia gave me a box of blocks & a set of old maids.
Thy affec. grandson
Francis R. Cope Jr.
Woodbourne Aug. 17th, 90.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Rachel Drinker
Recipient:  Eleanor Cope Tyson:  1807-1847
Date: 1820-04-01
Title: 1820 April 1, to Ellenor

4 mo 1 1820

My Dear Ellenor

I think it is time to acknowledge the receipt of thy letter.  It was pleasant to find thee had not forgot thy Grandmother.  I want to see thee.  I would rather talk than write to thee.  I hope it won't be long before we shall have the pleasure of haveing thee with us.  We have not Horses and can't with convenience make thee a visit, but I Hope Mother will make out to go when the Committee meet; she wishes it. Caroline is learning French and is much occupied with that, and the Reading society.  Allfred is very busily gardening: he has got a good many Flowers bloom & seems much Delighted with them.  We have had a man gardening for us; got the walk new gravelled and it looks very nice; with wishes for thy Health and Happenings, I conclude thy loveing grandmother
Rachel DrinkerI wish thee not [----] my letters.  They are not worth seeing; I allways was a poor hand at letter writing.  No wonder at the advanced age of 89 I should not write a letter fit for the [-----] of this age to see.
I forgot to tell thee that Caroline's feet are got so well that she has gone to see Susan [----].  Thee may critticise so much as thee pleases but there is not need of letting it go the Rounds of the Criticisers.
 Maria gives her love to thee.

 It would indeed be a treat to take a peep at my Elenor at the same time answering my appointment as a member of the Committee, but thou may judge whether it is likely I shall do so, when thou heardst how I am circumstanced.
Well then, besides having no Horses of our own, & no conveyance but the stage, which is too cold at this season for my frail fabric, besides all this, next 5th day is the appointed time for the marriage of Benjamin Rodman & Susan D. Morgan, on which occasion I am one of a committee deputized by M.M. to oversee the wedding; thy Father is another.  So that if he was inclined to provide a way & take me to Weston we should be pinched for time & over-hurried.  The wedding is to be held at John Drinkers who is not in very good health; neither is his wife: [--] own Aunt of Eliza's too, Anne Wells of Trenton, has a few days since ended her mortal pilgrimage; for which several reasons, & a dislike of parade & bustle, they intend inviting but very few to attend on the occasion.  Susan has no Brides-Maids & Benjamin, no Groomsmen, a good example! which I hope may be followed; as simplicity in manners, sobriety, & moderation so much becomes our profession.
Thy Cousin Harry Drinker is married in the Beach Woods to a young girl named Wragg.  A House is erected on his own land & there they are settled, probably for Life.  Richard is goingup there too in about a month, to settle on [a] tract his Father has given him. Rebecca Gordon, late love, has been in the City on a visit.  She is well, & enquired about thee with affectionate interest.  I have a pair of nice looking oranges here before me that I saved for thee & wish to send, but Alfred seems afraid they are too soft, or squishy, as he says. If however, D. Howell will take charge of them they may take their chances.
I hear often of thy being at Sewing School but I can immagine what thee does there- for there is Alfred's shirt, that has been there as long as thyself and I hear no more about it than if had sunk in the Earth - how is this? My dear daughter must strive to be industrious - She knows not what occasion she may hereafter have to exert this Virtue & to acquire the habit of industry, which is so highly important, so invaluable to its possessor - can never hurt her.  Take this as a stimulating watch-word from thy ever-loving Mother.
Mary Cope4 mo. 1. 1819
Elenor Cope
Weston4 mo 1 1820

Susan has no Brides-Maids & Benjamin, no Groomsmen, a good example! which I hope may be followed; as simplicity in manners, sobriety, & moderation so much becomes our profession.
Thy Cousin Harry Drinker is married in the Beach Woods to a young girl named Wragg.  A House is erected on his own land & there they are settled, probably for Life.  Richard is goingup there too in about a month, to settle on [a] tract his Father has given him. Rebecca Gordon, late love, has been in the City on a visit.  She is well, & enquired about thee with affectionate interest.  I have a pair of nice looking oranges here before me that I saved for thee & wish to send, but Alfred seems afraid they are too soft, or squishy, as he says. If however, D. Howell will take charge of them they may take their chances.
I hear often of thy being at Sewing School but I can immagine what thee does there- for there is Alfred's shirt, that has been there as long as thyself and I hear no more about it than if had sunk in the Earth - how is this? My dear daughter must strive to be industrious - She knows not what occasion she may hereafter have to exert this Virtue & to acquire the habit of industry, which is so highly important, so invaluable to its possessor - can never hurt her.  Take this as a stimulating watch-word from thy ever-loving Mother.
Mary Cope4 mo. 1. 1819
Elenor Cope
Weston

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1876-02-22
Title: 1876 February 22, Awbury, to Lillie

Awbury 2nd mo. 22nd 
/76
My dear Lillie
Yesterday when I was called to dinner I was agreeably surprised to find thine [-] Alexis's nice letters [-] two postal cards from Alf which were quite cheering, as we have not seen a sign of his handwriting since the 30th of November.  The dates of your letter were from the 6th to the 8th og Feb - and we were very glad to hear of your pleasant excursion to ["Turbia"], and the ["Bercean"], and that you had [----] with such agreeable company [-----] Arthur Albright? from Birmingham!  Thee does not mention Lilly Bright & her sisters, so we suppose, they never have left [M------], tho thee has not said so.  I expect thy father has already apprised you of the sad news of Aunt Rebecca Cope's death.  when I wrote to you last I had no idea that she was dangerously sick but the sudden attack of Pneumonia & paralysis was very unexpected to all of them, and they were not alarmed about her until 5th day noon tho she hadthen been suffering from Pneumonia and the Dr. had told her that one lung was seriously enveloped and she told him that she felt resigned either to live or die.  On 5th day night she was attacked by paralysis on the right side and when the Dr. saw her that morning (6th day) he thought there was no hope of her recovery and she died at 5 o'clock that afternoon.  She was perfectly conscious to the very end, and tho' her speech was difficult they were able to understand what she said by close attention and she called James by name a few minutes before her death.  James & Louise, Cousin Lillie Garrett & her niece Fanny Garrett, who was much attached to her  were all in the room with her, and she was perfectly calm, not appearing to suffer except from short breathing, tho' they could not tell certainly as thee was so much serenity. 
Mother had not time to finish this letter but I thought as possibly Alfs letter might be forwarded to some other place than yours I had better let this go so that you might be [----] to hear of Aunt R's death.  It is a lovely bright day for the funeral - very different from the day uncleA. was buried.  You will see a great many changes when you return home.  So different from what it was when I was abroad.  Then all our immediate family & friends I found when I came back very much as I left them - but it has been very much otherwise now.  If we were all so well prepared as Uncle A & Aunt R. how little real difference it would make.  Only a little longer separation - But as it is it is a fearful consideration to some of us.  I have no time to write more.
Afftly your father
F.R.CopeAwbury 2nd mo. 22nd

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope) Haines:  1819-1890
Recipient:  Eleanor Cope Tyson:  1807-1847
Date: 1819-10-09
Title: 1819 October 9, Philadelphia, to Ellen

I have just recieved my dear Ellens Letter of 5th addess'd to me; and am much more pleased with the stile in which it is written, than I was with the one that preceded it, address'd to thy Sister.  The latter done no credit either to thy heart or judgement.  Thy Father condemned it in to-to, as the sauciest little girls Letter he thought he had ever seen; & thou knowest he is not very rigid; or as some would say, not at all particular or precise; so when he is offended thou mayest conclude thy improprieties must be very striking indeed.  My Daughter should ever recollect that when she asks a favor, it should not be in the high tone of a demand: it should not be claimed as a Right, which if not immediately complied with is to be forthwith resented as an injury; but when she wishes for attentions, her wishes should be modestly insinuated, not as tho' she believed them due to her merit, on account of her great worth & services for which she expected extraordinary returns; but as tho her Affection prompted her to desire them, at the same time that she was conscious she could do & had done but little, for her friends; while their time & thought, & industry was often exerted in providing for her Wants, & promoting her Welfare.  This would lead her to be content with such portions as they could conveniently bestow, & grateful when she recieved them: she would dwell upon every instance of their kindness & cherish the remembrance of it, as an evidence of love for which she had never, as yet, had the power to render an equivalent, & she would hasten to qualify herself to become useful to them, in her turn, especially to her Mother, who, if she lives, must shortly be overtaken by Age & its attendant infirmities.  Then the kind offices, the endearments & domestic services of a dutiful affectionate Daughter, are an invaluable treasure.  These considerations, when once embraced, cannot fail to sink deep in the heart of sensibility" & will, if cherished, bring forth those substantial [-------] of Virtue in my beloved daughter, which my heartincessantly longs for.  After all my dear Ellen, I still flatter myself, that in regard to the said saucy letter the fault lays more in the manner & language, than the heart that dictated it:  I am by no means displeased that thou should'st prize our love & cover the marks of it; & am in hopes that the fear, the dread, & horror of being hated (so earnestly express'd & often repeated) will operate to induce thee to be best calculated to win back affection, even if it has fled.  But on this subject I need not enlarge.  Thou knowest well what my desires for thee are.  Thou hast only to look back & reflect on my frequent labors of love, & painful anxieties on thy account (lest thou should not be what my heart craves,) and it will be enough: - yet there is one still remains untouch'd, on which I feel in duty bound to refresh thy memory.  I mean the observance of respect to thy Teachers & superintendants; absolute & complete perfection is seldom found among Mortals; as least it takes (in most of us) nearly a whole Life to attain it: do not therefore indulge a disposition in thyself, neither take part with any who do so, to make exceptions or look out for faults in those who have so great a weight of Care & responsibility upon them; but rather turn thy attention to thy own deficiencies & need of improvement.  If their patience & sweetness is not uniform, recollect that thy own, if in their situation, would probably come far short of what is expected , remember that it is for the sake of order, & for thy own, or the general good.  By forgetfulness or ignorance of these truths, Children often display the weakness of their understandings, their excess of selfish feeling, & total want of feeling for others.  It is never too early to begin to do good, & few little girls, who were resolved to make a firm stand against these errors: but it must begin at one, & how proud should I be, would but my Ellen resolve to be that one what a happiness would it be to know that she had been the instrument of giving a new tone of feeling & action to the whole of the little community of which she is a Member - a tone so correct & beautiful too, as to excite general approbation!on the contrary, what a pain to find her banded with a company not only so childish, but so vulgar, so void of all true taste ; so void of all gentility, refinement & delicacy - so completely low, as to speak of "throwing old shoes &c" - Indeed I am almost ashamed to write it, or think of it.  Those who desire respect or attention for themselves - who expect ever to be esteemed as gentlewomen, should have more regard to propriety & true dignity of character.

Thy copy of Verses is very pretty, & if they express thy own thoughts & feelings, very acceptable ; except the last stanza, which represents a forlorn destitute state, not at all applicable to thy situation.  As to thy request about a jingling Letter, I must inform thee that such music is not always at my finger ends - & for thyself I would much rather thou would'st improve in good prose-writing , before any attempt at poetry is made - unless indeed it should come of itself without such "hard striving".
It was singular I think that thou should'st dream of thy Grandmother Cope never having seen her - but I have no doubt the inscription on white, which thou could'st not read is indeed of thy admirable Brother.  For him was exemplified all that gentleness & delicacy of character, which I so warmly recommend to my Ellen.  In whatever School or family he was placed his behaviour, & his memory now, that he has left the World & all us, [--] less pure inhabitants to mingle in the Society of angelic Spirits; & his watery Urn has been plentifully bedew'd with those tears of sadness which mingled, as it were with the waves that overwhelmed him; now, henceforth & forever, will the remembrance of him be precious; yea, sweeter than a garden of Roses after the Summer.

I expect thy Grandmother D-r every minute from Burlington-- Thy various messages have mostly been delivered, & all desire their love in return - (Mariam in particular) - thy  Brother Henry cannot recollect about M.G.'s Letter: but if he had the charge of it I dare answer for his punctuality.  If he does not often send his love in form, he loves thee none the less.  I believe he has hope of thee, for he sometimes comforts me by saying he thinks thy faults are much like his own were at thy age; only, his were in thought, for he was affraid to shew them because he knew they were not allowed: indeed he did not dare to let them be seen, lest he should give offence: for he loved his parents tenderly, & could not bear to give them pain; & I have heard him say when a Boy, on seeing others misbehave - get into disgrace - & excite disgust, - I am glad my parents never suffered me to get into such habits.  Now there is this difference between you, supposing you both to have been under the same temptations to evil in your childhood - that all thy virtue will be voluntary, & therefore more meritorious - that is, it will originate in a love of goodness, & desire to attain it, in thy own breast, & for its own sake - whereas he was assisted in his endeavours by the Authority of his parents, & the divine blessing superadded to both; and thou hast beenleft more to thyself: at least in thy education, persuasion has been used more than compulsion.  Let me entreat thee therefore my Daughter, not to dissapoint thy Father; when belief has been so sanguine that his Daughters could be won to Virtue thro' the medium of the Understanding, by the force of Reason & good counsel; yet tho I entreat thee, I know - & I am in duty bound to tell thee so - I know, that without earnest & frequent intercession, with thy Saviour, in true humility of heart, accompanied by love of his divine perfections, & fear of offending him - in short, without his aid & blessing, thou can'st do nothing:  As he said himself - "Without me of yourselves, ye can do nothing": - So, tho' it is possible to conform to outward rules of good behaviour, at times, & for a time, (which is better than being always bad) yet to become establish'd to be immovable in virtuous intention, to be steadfast in resisting every temptation to evil, is impossible without him:  for this cause is he stiled a Saviour, a Redeemer from the bondage of Sin; and we are assured by a revelation from God "that there is no name given under Heaven or amongst men, whereby they can be saved, but by the name of Jesus" - How great then is his goodness & how much do we owe him who tho' he needs nothing from us, has given his Life for us in the body of flesh be assumed; & ever stands, as it were knocking at our hearts by his gentle checks & intimations wooing us to good - meeting & strengthening our feeble desires after it - & all for the sake of our eternal happiness!

Well my dears, thou wilt perhaps think, if I have not written thee many Letters, I am making up for it in the length of this: and not to tire thee quite out I will now conclude
Thy truly loving mother
Mary Cope
P.S. Mother is not come; but we hear is coming the last of next Week.  Thy Capes are done, I was pleased with thy proposition to make them thyself, as a mark of industry; but would rather thee would make the shirt to learn to darn neatly.  We have had so much company (not many at a time, but almost constantly somebody) - & have had so much to do since we opened the house, that we have been pinched for time to do all.  Louisa, too, having a gathering on her hand could not work, & did not come home when we expected her.  She is not come yet.  Does thee know her?  She is Uncle Israels - Jem's sister, & our Joseph's Cousin, & my Cook.
Philada. 10 mo 9. 1819.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth) Cope:  1840-1944
Date: 1861-04-10
Title: 1861 April 10, to Sisters

1861
Third day 4/10 -- 60
My dear sisters, 
Have just rec' yr. letters & will write right off before what you say has time to get out of our minds It was quite refreshing & encouraging to me to get yr. letters for do you know this morning I was pretty near giving up in despair of having anything pretty or uncommon about our house.  Mother got aunt R & Anne & cous Lizzie to go with her after meeting to a furniture store & there they selected just about as ugly a set of hair cloth chairs as I wld. wish to see.  Of course they think its not a very important matter & Mother is just willing to havemost anything, that they like, wh. very much goes against the grain with me.  This thing of getting things that "will do" I never had any unity with, & as you say I had much rather take trouble now & get pretty things than to be dissatisfied with them afterwards, & I do think we might as well get what suits us, as what suits other people.  It seems foolish to be so particular & objects to what is thought best, & I'd give anything to have one of you here to consult, without having to ask the rest of the folks.  To be sure the furniture is not everything.  I wld give all the select sofas in the world for a pleasanter situation but as that cannot be had we must have it as pleasant as we can 'a [propos] of sofas, it is thought very unwise indeed to get plush ones, they are hot in summer, & very hard to keep clean &c &c.  Moreover they cost several dollars more than the hair cloth & I am not sure that they wldbe advisable, tho' much prettier no doubt.  My plan is to leave as much as possible till you come down & then we can [fix] & arrange what we want.  But they all say oh! no get everything now.  Make [yr] minds easy about the parlor carpet at least.  We have concluded to leave that & get nothing.  But then if we get plush chairs we wld. not know what color to get till we get the carpet.  Plush armchairs cost 30 & 40 dollars hair cloth 10 dollars less.  They want to get a hair cloth sofa for the entry.  I want to get some kind of a fancy lounge or [settee].  As you say its dreadful unsatisfactory to write about such things, & I think I'll just trust to getting them afterwards & come home, & then we can talk things over & get them arranged.  I am hoping all the time that something will happen so that we wont get off till fall at any rate.another thing I have forgotten to tell you wh. will greatly comfort you & that is that good Cousin' Thos' is going to buy us some nice kinds of vines to plant.  Wisteria & honeysuckles, & roses, &c &c.  Edgar thinks of small importance but I'm going to stand up for that.  I planted when I was out there two poor little bits of ivy (the best I cld get), but that takes so very long to grow.  It will seem like a different place with vines growing.  It seems so forlorn, down in this populous county to live on a public road without a tree or a vine to shelter you what cld. have possessed anybody to build a house there when there were so many other spots more secluded & inviting.  I cant imagine, but theres no use now.  I must tell thee Carry that I was talking to a young man named Philip Garrett a few days ago, who was expressing his regret that [He] (C) had declined being [brides] maid, as he said he had expected to have had the pleasure of [waiting] on thee.Yet I cant imagine why thee wants so many small quantities of double [zephyr].  I believe they do not [sell] it in less than half [an] [gr.] of an oz.  We wish endeavor to get the other things.  Mother has told you what the prospects are about coming Do'nt expect her on 7th day, for I do not think there is much probability of her getting off.  Edgar & I may stay a week longer but I shall not consent to stay long.  Am going to take tea at Dr [Morris] with Cos Sarah is'nt it [awful].  With love to [Father] & Love Ever yr sister C

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan S. Reeve:  1833-1866
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1866-04-15
Title: 1866 April 15, Locust Shade, to Ruthanna Cope

Locust Shade. 4.15.1866

My Dear Annie

I have   been very sorry to see day after day passing away without   any acknowledgment sent of thy very interesting &  welcome   lettter, which was a real treat to me. I wish there was some   hope of thy getting as good a one in reply but what with   colds & headache the little wit I ever had seems to have   departed, for which loss I console with my corespondents   every time one of my stupid effusions goes to the Post   Office.- I think a visit from thee & Clemmy would have an   enlivening effect & when summer comes so must you.- It was   very kind to send me that excellent Photo of Uncle Daniel,   after my negligence in the
matter of which I have been duly ashamed- and I am very much   obliged for it.- We had a nice visit to him had we not? If I   had not gone then, I fear I should not have seen him at all-   except that we did meet in the cars the other day- as being   sick in Wilmington entirely spoiled my Germantown visit. so   that I could make none of the calls I hoped to.-
How thee   must have enjoyed having Clemmy so long with thee. You had   splendid times I know. Indeed no one can be at your house   without enjoying themselves- At least that is my   experience.-
Thee knows perhaps that I have been a good   deal with my friend Lizzie Howell this winter.- Her mothers   death was so very sudden- only sickda little more that half   & hour- that the shock was fearful & Lizzie

was a long time recovering from it.- She is yet very sad-   and her brother being in poor health adds to the feeling.-   She was so sick for some weeks as rarely to get down stairs.   nervous & weak- but is now stronger & brighter & very busy   she writes me.- It is often a great blessing I think to   those in sorrow to have duties pressing upon them with must   be attended to & so the mind is diverted from its greif and   made to realize that life has yet much in store for them.   –
Did thee know our Georgie has been sent adrift from his   home into the city? We do miss him sadly- but he likes his   situation in a wholesale store in Market St, very well &    perhaps it is the right thing for him.- We hope that he may   be preserved from the temptations that summoned him.- Lizzie   has come home
for yearly meeting week.- We have been looking for aunt   Rachel Howland & her family every day but hear now they are   not coming till next week.-
Has thee been after “Trailing   Arbutus” this spring? [-] and I went the other day &  found   some pale blossoms. but very sweet.- Isnt it delightful to   hunt under the dead leaves for the delicate things- it seems   to make one feel young again fot the time.- Thee asks have I   read “Snow Bound”—Only a little of it &  have not happened   even to see it in a volume. But intend to get it soon if I   can.- The part I read was pleasant, simple &  [s-----] , -   as thee says more understandable than much of the latter day   poetry.- We have been reading “Across the Continent” and I   have indulged dreams of someday seeing the “Yosemite Valley”   if my finances get into sufficiently prosperous conditions   for such a journey.- Don’t thee 
want to go to Europe with the party that starts next month?-   It must be bery pleasant to look forward to & finer still to   experience if all things are fair & no anxieties to follow   you.- Wonder if John Wood &  Lily will go.- John says he   wants to & I guess Lily would not object.- I liked John   better than I expected to- but he is certainly neither   handsome nor dignified- but [-------] & kind hearted. I   should think.- Is’nt it a comfort Mary Ann Morris is so much   better? I cannot help hoping she will be entirely herself   again before very long.- Their house is very bright &   pleasant & I should think they might be very happy there-   This to be sure happiness is not a thing of outward   circumstances [----]Did thee remember that yesterday was the anniversary of our   dear Presidents death? Wonder where another year will find   us.- What do thy brothers think of our prospects with such a   man as Johnson at the helm.- It is a comfort that the crew   of out ship of State are so staunch & true.-
Suppose   Marry Emma Stokes passed meeting last third day- I do like   Alexander Wood very much. He seems so open & honest.- Will   they have a wedding  I wonder- or just be married & go   travelling.- I hear friends at Arch Street did not accept   Sue Farnum’s resignation. Had she violated discipline before   presenting it? The usual yearly mtg storms seems to be   brewing this evening- but I hope it wont come this.- Does   thee go in and out every day?.- Please excuse this [prosy]   sheet dear Annie & write very soon.- My love please to thy   sister E. – Very loving by thine
S S Reeve

Title: 1870 August 16, Awbury, to My dear Frank

Awbury 8 mo. 16th 1870      

      My dear Frank,      

      I rec'd thine & Chellie’s letters to day, when Tho's came out from town.  They also had one from Mary, and we are glad to hear of your safe arrival at Snow Shoe and very thankful I am, that you had a doctor so near at hand to extract the bone from thy throat.  I read thy letter first, and was much alarmed. before knowing what the accident thee alluded to was, but Thomas fortunately knew about it from Mary's letter & told me at once.  What a providential thing it was, that there was a Dr. so near at hand.  the children must have been very much frightened, before thee was relieved.--I hope thee will be careful of thyself, and not jump, and injure thy arch again.—
      -
      attached wife Anna S. Cope.  I hope Tom is provided with warm under-clothing.  Mary sends her love & hopes you will have a good time.I hope thee has enough warm clothing, with thee, for I sh'd not be surprised of thr warmest weather is past.  We are having it delightful here at home, the thermometer 68 this morning at 8 o'clock and under 80 at noon.  This afternoon Thomas & Elizabeth Mary & I called at father's, and afterwards at Ellis Yarnall's leaving Mary at father's.  We found them all at home, and had a very pleasant visit.  Lucy Harrison is very bright & agreeable & Anne is lovely.  She told me she had written a note to Lillie, which I would send to her when it comes to hand.  She also told me she was sorry not to go to Snow Shoe with you, but they could not go to Chicago, & as their time is so limited they of course felt anxious to see as much as possible before going home.  they expect to go to Detroit from Chicagoand then on to Niagara.  They expect to leave sometime next week, and take the journey alone.  We all disapprove of them taking such a long journey by themselves, but I suppose Ellis Yarnall will find out some one to look after them.  When they go on, they expect to spend the first night at Altoona, and then travel day & night until they reach Chicago.  I have sent Lillie & Chellie some under-clothing.  2 flannel skirts, 2 under vests, 1 cloth body, 2 pairs thick stockings, 1 pair drawers, 1 [Alpaca?] skirt.  Anna & Carrie are quite well, & the former is invitee to spend tomorrow with cousin Mary [W.?] Brown's little Mary.  I did not [?] like [?]-ing her just now, but could not well decline.  I was at father's this afternoon, and they were all pretty well.  father seems stronger from the change in weather.  I saw bro. John and his boys go off this morning, and hope they had apleasant trip to Altoona.  I am glad you met with such a polite reception at Bellefonte.  I had no idea before, that there was any such spring of water, there as mentions.  63000 gallons a minute is immense.  I think you must have enjoyed the ride up the mountain very much, if the views are so beautiful.  Give my love to Lillie & Chellie, and tell them I hope they will not be put out at my sending them some warm clothing, as I am only sorry they did not send for warm dresses too, as they have nothing warm with them.  It is now bed-time and I must put by my writing; the children are enjoying Anna Hartshorne's company very much.  I hope some of you will write tho' I do not want you to tax yourselves.  I have already been much favored.  Bro Thomas intended sending sister Anne's letter, but it was not returned from Aunt Ruth's in time.  with much love to you all, ever thy

Title: 1847, August 10, to My dear Mary

Newport 8 mo 10th / 47
      
      My dear Mary
      
      Frank has been writing to William this morning, and has most likely advised you on all points of interest.- you probably know by this time, that we are all in a good state of health, and we hope that our sister Susan is improving, tho' she still has some head-ache.  Frank & cousin Wistar are very kind and devote themselves almost exclusively to contributing to her comfort & pleasure in every way.  F is devoted to Susan and does evey thing in his power to promote the improvement of her health, his kindness is unparalleled: everything is done for us, and we have nothing to do, but join in the pleasant plans laid out for us.- Elizy H & Susan were concluding before dinner, that they accomplished very little of any thing on account of the time occupied in changing their dresses for the different labors of the day.- About ten in the morning they prepare for bathing or rather we do when Susan does not go-
      /
      not arrive on 7th day tho' we intend to do so if possible.  the Boat did not leave until 5 o'clock this morning.  I expect the irregular lately.- with much love
      aff thy sister Anne
      Susan will accompany us to Hazard's this afternoon
      she is resting since her bath.then return about 12 o'clock.  rest, until time to away for dinner, then about 5 o'clock, a different costume must necessarily be adapted for Sailing especially when the boats, are slightly fishy & a little dirty.- then we come home about ten-time or little past, and another change must be made to appear at [---] which [---] will suffice for the evening.- but all this is done in a good hurry and I cannot say it consumes much time.- I believe I have nothing new to tell thee, and indeed, I expect it would be very puzzling to think of any such thing when Cousin Wistar is of the party, for he writes home to frequently, and describes every thing that seems with so much minuteness, that if you are favored with the perusal of his epistles, ours must seem quite commonplace; this is my conjecture, as we joke Wistar & Sue both, about writing so often.- Only to think- Sixth day evening we leave, if a storm or fog does not prevent us, and Tom has concluded to remain, and return with us last evening tho' fog was so dense that the Bay-State" did not go out, and now we have every prospect, of the same thick state of the atmosphere for this evening consequently.  it seemed hardly worth while for Tom to leave before we did.- The Massachusetts arrived here with Mr. Williams on board, about 11 o'clock thismorning having been lying off Point Judith, even since four o'clock.  Susan & Lizzie went to bathe this morning with F & Wistar leaving me at home to pass the time as I could.  Tom & Moses had gone fishing, and I was quiet enough.  Susan though it best notwithstanding your message, to try the [---] three times faithfully as the Dr directed, and I hope she will not be any worse for it, and perhaps it may strengthen her afterwards.  She says she likes it very much while in the water, but she feels pretty weak for sometime afterwards.  we think she is the best judge for what is best for her, and she does exactly what she wished in the Bathing line; Frank takes her in, giving her three waves as directed, he said the water was very warm & pleasant this morning.  I quite long to go in again but fear I shall not have an opportunity of going more than once or twice more before I leave.- It suits Elizy Hacker exactly, she feels a little tired after coming out, but it seems to brance & strenghthen her, and shee looks better I think in this little time of our [---] here.  I do hope her father will telegraph her to remain with Sue, if the letter does not arrive in time to answer it before our leave.- yester afternoon we were out Sailing in the bay, landed on one of the [dumpling?] rocks gathered some sprigs of green to press, and enjoyedthe novelty of it highly, it was really very pleasant, altho' by the time we returned, our blanket shawls were almost white with the fog.  Sailing seems to suit Susan, very well, but I think clear weather as a general thing is preferable to her.- This afternoon we think of calling at fr'd Hazard’s, we spent a pleasant evening there last Sixth day.  they are certainly a delightful family. Ann[a/e?] Hazard called here this morning with S & A Jenkins who are still staying with them – we intend riding out to see fr'd Jenkins before we go.- 4th day morn.  I was obliged to leave this shut hastily yesterday afternoon, as Thomas Hazard & his wife called upon us inviting us to spend this afternoon with them which we intend doing.  Elizy & Frank are much disappointed I believe in Fanny H’s beauty, but they must see her at [---] before they fully decide.  She is perfect at home.- my love to all- Susan and Lizzie are taking a nap before dinner, and I cannot disturb them now.- there is a thick fog over they bay now 12 at noon, and it will [---] increase- Tom could not have gone last night in consequence of the bay as the boat did not leave, and perhaps it is as well for him to wait for us.  Frank & myself do not think it proper to leave here in a fog or storm and Tom must not think it strange if we do

Title: 1880 February 8, Cannes, to Alexis

Cannes Feb. 8. 1880.
   
   Dear Alexis,
   
   We recd thy letter of Jan. 16th a few days since, & have been thinking over thy proposition.  It wd. be nice to be able to spend part of our summers in Susquehanna Co particularly if you make it your home, but we have not been looking forwarrd to keeping house in our return.  I do not want to live at Connymead again, (indeed I do not think any of us want to; unless we cd. find some one to live with us)  It was too lonely, particularly for me.  & if we did not keep house there in winter, we cd. not keep very well keep house in summer.  How or where we shall live when we go home, I do not know.  Indeed the uncertainties of the future, & what it will be best to do, often weighs upon my mind.  Connymead is no placefor any body to live who wants to be a Friend, or who has any preference for their ways.  Life there was a continual struggle wh. I have no desire to renew, & perhaps we shall never know again [ever/even?] that semblance of a home.  I hope if thee and Lily picked to bring your children up as Friends, you may be able to keep them in a community where Friends live.  For it is pretty hard for a young person who has been uninstructed in what are considered the accomplishments of life to have to live where these are considered all important, & are the chief recupations of those by whom you are surrounded.  It requires a good deal of strength of character to be able to live alone, I [---], & Friends must always do it more or less when they go out from among their own people.  When one has not been brought to play on the piano or sing or draw, or paint, or evento play cards- a not very valuable accomplishment certainly- & yet one in wh. English people who are both intelligent & sensible, seem to while away at least a fourth part of their waking hours; & never to tire of- When I say, one has never been instructed in any of these things, one feels as if one ought to be at least where they are not the chief employment of life.  Of course when living in a delightful pension on the Riviera- one is not supposed to be exactly fulfilling the normal conditions of existence- Existence here (the physical part of it) seems too delightful to be long continued, & I have wonder since we have been here how long 14 human beings could live together, without apparently a shadow of sorrow or anxiety to disturb the delightful days, which seem, to glide away without a cloud either inward or outward, to mar their peacefulness such skies, & such weather , & such walks as we have- only one littleshower in all the two months we have been here- It is the most perfect thing in weather certainly, that we have ever experienced.  If we had come last winter we shd  not have had the same experience of it, for it rained very much even here.  But I have digressed widely from the subject upon wh. I intended to write, [---] the old house of Woodbourne.  Whatever may be my inclincation with regard to it, (& I certainly shd. like very much the idea of being able to live somewhere near you).  I do not thonk C & A have any desire to undertake housekeeping there.  The life of a travelling artist- or even of the traveller, minus the artist- in these delightful regions & pensions where have all the comforts of home without its cares, does not intend to inspire you with a desire to renew the contest with the [biddy?]- in art less America. If only some plan cd. be devised by wh. Woodbourne cd. be converted into a pension.  I have no doubt we shd. spend a good deal of our time there, & shd. think the old house wd. need an immense amount of repairing, & as to the old chairs of the Conklin family, I feel as if I had lost my interest in them & I shd. not think they wd. be worth the sum they mentioned.  It is provoking to have to buy what is your own.  (see 4th page of A's letter)Can thee tell us who paid the drivers on our Naples [---] wh. were packed in the same box with P.C.G.'s- we asked thee to do it & I suppose thee must have- but we have never heard.If not paid
   
   Please pay to the order of Francis C. Haines (who may be too modest to speak of it) 9 francs 15 centimes, as near as you can come at it.
   
   Clementine CopeAlexis T Cope
   
   (Haines St Germantown)
   
   Philadelphia
   Etats-Unis d'Ameriq

Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937

Title: 1880 June 14, Geneva, to Lily

Geneve No 5 Chemin de la Tour. 6.14.1880
   
   My dear Lily,
   
   I expect Caroline will give me "Jesse" as the saying is, if I presume to enter on the stage with her.  Nevertheless as she has occupied the floor for some weeks past in thy favor, I think I shall dare to add a note, tho' she tells me it must be short & upon no account much upon Revenna.  Wherefore conclude she has been expending herself on that ancient & delightful city- & forbear.  Thy letter of-- containing the childrens photographs came tohand two days since, & gave much pleasure.  We think thine, with little Eleanor, is the best of thee we have ever seen, & as to the little E I shd. say she was her Mama in miniature just as little F is his Papa over again only with a few shades more of jollity in his face.  What a sweet little good natur’d  happy kissable face it is & tho' I believe we have understood that he was'nt particularly fond of the latter operation, I doubtnot he has to undergo a good deal of it, & he does'nt look as if he wd. be very refractory under any circumstances, Indeed such a nice little jolly face must be a great comfort to look at, &, I need not suggest for Mamas to be proud of.  I suppose when we get home thee & Alexis will be a grand old couple, sitting up in the middle of your flock, looking very wise & experienced, as you contemplate with "majestic pride" the youthful scions growing & flourishing about you.
   
   I don’t see that thee has a very care worn air however in thy photo-graph.  but on the contrary one might suppose that they cares & worries of domestic life were quite [---] & pleasant.  by what you say I shd. think the heat must have been of that nature wh. wd. have a tendancy to drive you to seek for a cooler clime.  For my part I dont see the use of undertaking to live in such a climate at all, as the chief object of life seems to be with most people to get away from it.  Why not try to live, as I said to the Awbury people yesterday, where such fearful agonies wd. not have contin-ually to be gone thro' with in order to try to effect an escape.
   
   I am very sorry for Madjy's disappointment as her letter to us showed that he hopes were very much set on Europe, & she seems to need some change so much.  It is a great pity they have to undergo such alternations of hope & despair, because they have got [---] on the living side of the Atlantic.  At least it seems to be the side wh. is very much below par with most persons who inhabit it judging from the frantic manner in wh.they rush for the other shore.  The papers say that pretty much Ole America is now on the way to [---].  We concluded that the pleasure to be derived from seeing the play, wh. I think wd. be but doubtful at best, wd. be very much spoiled by the crowd of cooks & other tourists who will infest the country. We therefore have chosen to spend some time insteadin Geneva in French family No 2.  Not that we were disappointed with our experiences in No 1, but that we fell very much in love with this family last fall, when we took some lessons of them.  They are more cultivated people than the others- consequently moreinteresting, & tho' less well off- they are still friench, wh. means that they are practical & know how to be comfortable on a little.  We only pay about half as much as we do at the large Hotels, with more real comfort, beside the very good advantage of hearing the best of french spoken.  The lady has two sons, one a professor in the University & one a clergyman, & two dhrs. all highly educated.  The advantages of the education here for those in moderate circumastances are so very great.  We shall stay probably a month or more until the weather gets to hot wh. does'nt seem very likely- as we are on pretty high ground just outside the city with plenty of green trees & alps in profusion in the distance.
     
   My advice to you is to come & build a cottage on one of the hill sides of Geneva, instead of Woodbourne & get a Savoyard maid as we have, who with her mistresses aid does the work for a household of 9 persons.  We have two dinners daily, of several courses & very well cooked, & how in the world they do it all I cannot conceive.  I suspect that Madam is at the bottom of a good deal, but she does it all with such apparent grace & ease, that one cannot suspect her of cooking.  There are beautiful building lots to be bought here, by the way, on the high ground along the town with the Lake on one side & Mt. Blanc on the other, & there are many beautiful gardens & suburban residences- wh. are quite unseen & [---] by the mere passing traveller.  If it was’nt for those children of yours whom we want to see!- I shd. be quite tempted to invest in one of these little spots & settle down for the rest of my days.  Will thee please ask Alexis to inquire of cousin FRC if he rec'd a letter fm. me posted June 8. containing a cheque for $200.  I also posted one on the 13 June to M.S.C. containing cheque for $100.  As there is some risk of these things being lost shd. be very much obliged if A or some body wd. advertise Provident Life & Trust Company of [---] and [---]. of these two cheques payable to the order of the above mention’d persons.  Hoping soon to have news of you in a cooler clime & under Mrs. Hotchkiss' hospitable roof.  Ever thy affec- sister C.  Ever so many kisses to dear little Agnes & to theothers as for as appreciated by them.

Recipient:  Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas) Cope:  1850-1883
