Title: 1880 July 11, Geneva, to Alexis

Geneva, July 11, 1880
   
   Dear Alexis,
   
   I want to ask thee a question.  Is it necessary in order to effect a division of our property (I mean such a division as shall give thee thy portion at Connymead) is it necessary that I return to America in the Autumn with C & A, as it has been our intention to do, (or at least theirs)?  For myself I have not entirely decided, tho' we have partly paid our passages for the 6th Nov. in the steamer "Illinois", on condition that we can change if it seems best to another vessel of the line.  It is late to sail, but there seemed to be no good steamer between the first week of October& the last, & as there will be no moonlight the last of October we thought it wd. be best to wait until the next moon.   

   There are many reasons why I shd. like to return in the Autumn, but the prospect of boarding in Phila is not very attractive, & of keeping house at Connymead still less so- indeed I shd. never be willing to undertake the latter again unless circumstances were very much changed.  C & A prefer the former.  If they were willing to keep house or even to board near Germantown, where we could have the enjoyment of the children, I shd. come home with the greatest pleasure.   

   But this I expect they will never wish to do.  So that until I can think of some way for me to live in that part of the world.  It seems as if I might almost as well stay here- for boardingin Phila wd. not be much better as far as you are concerned.   

   The thought of staying by myself seems a little dismal, but I cd. stay very well in the family where we now are & be as well cared for as I cd. expect or wish to by, by strangers.  Then there is an elderly lady (whom we have met several times (& I think have spoken of) Miss Wetherill, Jno. Price Wetherills dhr, of Phila) who has asked me to join her party, consisting of her niece & [Pebers?] of Phila.  We were with them 8 weeks in Rome & found them very pleasant.  So I could stay very well if I wanted to- Tell me how the idea strikes you, with regard to the business- as, if my presence is necessary to the accomplishment of it, that wd. decide the question.   

   We still continue in Geneva & still continue to like exceedingly our french family.  We intended in coming, to stay a month & then go to the Mts.  But the weather has been almost too cool for anygreat heights, & this, so far (I dont know how it may be in August) seems a happy medium.  We have had a few warmish days, but for the most part it has been a delightful summer climate.  Then too we have had so much gadding about, that we enjoy the quiet & the thought that we are learning something.   

   How often I wish I cd. have Agnes here for a few months.  It would do for her, what years of study at home cannot do for any body.  I never knew before how badly, or rather how little we had been taught at home, how to pronounce french.  Then too this is such a nice family where it wd. be so safe to place a child.  Their ideas about education are good- & they have so much simplicity in their ways & manners- they seem almost like those of friends.  The children have never been allowed to go to the opera or the theater- tho' they have one, within a few doors of them.  Every evening before going to bed, we have a little "culbe"- Madam Duproix reads out of a big bible- & then makes a little extemporaneous prayer- so very simple, that one cannot help but feel as if it came from the heart; After this, we separate for the night with much hand-shaking and many "[---]" & "[---]" & "[---]" &c- The great objection to the french is that they have to say so much about every little thing & are really too polite for comfort.  I think each person at the table says "par-r-r-don"- about 50 times at each meal (with a very great trill to the r- & a very great accent on the last syllable) if all this wasn't accompanied with real kindness of heart (as in this case) one wd. become "very fatigued" of it.   

   We suppose that you are now at Montrose tho' we dont know it.  It has been a perfect age since anyone has written from Awbury.  I sent cous. FRC a letter containing a cheque about5 weeks since & having rec'd no acknowledgement fear it has been confiscated, or that he is not well.  We are anxious to hear how you perform'd the journey & how Montrose goes.  Netty is writing to Lilly as I will not write now 
   
   with much love to her & the children
   
   they aff. sister C :

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Recipient:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Date: 1834-03-10
Title: 1834 March 10, Bloomsdale, to Wm D Cope

I am giving thee dear William- a proof of my sincere and unabated affection- in this early replying to thy most welcome letter of the 8th which only came to hand this morning- thee may be sure its arrival was awaited by me, with more than usual impatience- I could not believe another week wd. be suffered to elapse- without the accustomed message of love, and rememberence,- and every day I wd. say to myself well- I certainly will hear to day- but very many times have I been doomed to suffer disappointment- how however- I am relieved by the actual presence of the well known hand writing- and will thus evince my greatful feelings- in its early acknowledgement.-  Let me tell thee dear William- I think thee greatly undervalues thy epistolary talents, thy letters cannot be any thing but interesting to me- and if I acknowledge them to be so- why that,- must be as much as thee can desire- as for my own I have long since despaired of arriving at any thing like excellence in the art,- and the only and slight merit- if merit it may called- which they posess- is the spirit of affection which they [---], & which prompts me to the undertaking I have not the least partiality for the employment thee knows- and often with merely for the purpose of receiving in return.-  To day I was [---] gratified & delighted- for independent of the pleasure thine afforded me- there was one from my dear sister Caroline.  I will not tell thee what she says, now- but when thee comes- thee shall see it.- I do not know that I recollect to observation thee alludes to- as having been made by me- when last here- at least I am not certain what it was.- The will find in me as usual- a very ready and willing listener to all thee may have to communicate- I hope my presence will not prove talismanic and cause thee to forget what thee had to say- I did not find it necessary to apply to Father for information respecting the time of holding our monthly meeting- it has just passed, last week- and the next oneoccurs- on the ninth of April- The [---] is- the first fourth day after the first second day in the month.- I had a sweet little note from cousin Edith the other day- it contained an invitiation for us to come, or rather go out to make them a visit- I knew it wd. not be very pleasant just now and in my answer, declined the invitation for myself- and promised to deliver the one to thee when next we met- Edith styles thee, her "cousin elect" already.-  What an appalling spectacle the burning of the Wm Penn must have been- It will have an effect I think, to increase the fears of [---] travellers-.  How sorrowful I felt, upon learning of the death- of R.B. [Thornson?], during her life we had each of us, made attempts to become better acquainted- but were never very successful- and now in her death, I feel as if I had almost lost a dear friend- her family will feel her loss to be irreparable- I should like to have some particulars of her death- I trust it was a happy one- holding out consolation to her afflicted and berieved family-.  Dearest Wm. I must now say farewell! as it is fast-approaching [---] 6 o'clock- and I am encroaching not a little [---] the time usually devoted to the indifference of my friends [---]- with a thousand assurances of undiminished affection
   remain as ever thy own
   S.
   
   March 10. 1834.
   
   P.S. If thee wd. like to avoid the observation of a certain person in B. who is always upon the look out- thee can do it by going up the street where the market is and round by the [?-nch]*- I hear of our engagement from all quarters- will thee excuse the brevity of this letter- I write this evening because time will not permit to morrow.  again
   Adieu!
   *tis very little further
   
   I cannot make the direction come in the right place.from S. [1834]
   dated 3 mo. 10. 1834.
   
   [---]no 6
   
   Wm D Cope
   36 N. 4th
   Philadelphia

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1867-09-24
Title: 1867 September 24, Awbury, to blue Brother

Let this be read a day or so after sister Anna & Lilly's letters have digested.
   
   Awbury 9 mo 24th
   3rd day eve
   our parlor table
   
   My poor dear blue Brother
   
   Sister E has just bee reading thy letter to Chelle dated Woodford 9 mo 8th and I am very sorry thee gets so down in the mouth, and could wish I had been along with thee- provided I was wanted and could have done thee good, not that I would place myself before some others Lilly, Chellie, &c, but then maybe thee would not have felt me so much on thy mind, as I think I should have been pretty easily contented even if I did have to stay pretty close by old London.  I would have at least been a "flesh & blood" companionand not one of the ancient curiosities the guide books introduce thee to.  Not to say how much I would have liked to have been along on my own account, and the many little bits of intruction I would have picked up by the way, Well!  not wishing to assume too much I thought maybe I would have been better than nobody.  But when it came to paying call on the Hartshornes and the like, thee might have left me behind, the grandees and I, I fear would not get along very well together, some of them at any rate.
   
   Well would thee like to know what we are about at home.  Brother T at present in scouring vigorously at our new plate glass windows which have justbeen inserted into our front door, sister E has settled down to reading after one of her daddy long-leg excitements, whilst the children are settling off to bed except Ellie, whom Lilly got to come down to your house to tea, Chellie being over at her Grandfathers, while Alfred, and Frank took tea with us, Here they come Lilly, Virginia and Dr Hartshorne as escort, Perhaps thee will scarcely think it worth while for me to write all this.  Sister Anna seems to be consulting various books, following thee in thy travels, she was showing me a picture of- let me see- the old wall of Portsmouth, which thee speaks of in one of thy letters, and this evening she is inquiring for "Old England."  Yesterdaybrother J and wife, with myself took an early start for Wilmington, to pay one of those stated visits to Hannah Richardson.  It was a lovely day and we had a very nice time, and thyself and thy movements were among other topics spoken of.  In the cars that morning I had quite a little talk with James Cox, who also was inquiring after thee, and though absent thou art not forgotten.  I do hope thee found Ellis Yarnall and party on the Continent- and has enjoyed thy trip, and hope it will do thee good, I really fear thee will not get near all the good of the trip we would like, when thee gets so worried, try to look beyond the present difficulty, and think perhaps it will come rightin the end, and then thee will be sorry thee had taken so much trouble, and not gathered more good by the way, And even if it dont turn out what you wish, there are so much greater troubles, that I would have thee try to brighten up.  I dont want thee to finish up with typhoid feaver, this sounds most too bad dont it?  But I hope by the time this reaches thee, thee will feel quite brightened up, with thy trip on the Continent &c.
   
   5th day the 26th.  There has been quite a gap in my letter, the time being taken up in various ways, This morning was meeting morning and a very interesting meeting I thought it, S Emlen addressing the children, and in the course ofhis discourse told an interesting incident relating to a little girl who died lately, and who I suppose was little Mary Rhoads, Charles Rhoads daughter.  I suppose sister Anna told thee of her death, she was only sick 24 hours, and taken insensible almost from the first I believe.  Mary Haines spoke of her as having been a child of the Saviour for a year past.  Samuel Morris followed S.E. in a solemn prayer for the "parents", I think we sometimes have our best meetings on 5th days.  After meeting I went to Aunt Martha's to dine, and have some conversation with her in regard to Eugenia & Samuel, who are now here on a visit.  Aunt Constantia is very anxious S should not return to Washington and we think it veryimportant he should not, but be placed at some boarding-school.  Lilly & Chellie have just come up here, & also brother J and sister M.  Chellie's tongue has been going pretty much like a bell clapper ringing for [fire].  -that last word is fire- thy daughter has been joging her old aunt's elbow, which must account for the above appearance.  General Sheridan comes to Germantown to night, Gtn is coming on.  I suppose he will make quite a stir.  And Gough is coming too [---]!  I have tried to write in the fashionable style of crossing the page but alas!  I have not succeeded.  I hope thee can read it.  Sister Mary says give my love to Frank.  What would thee think of seeing her [---] down by the banks of the BrandywineHer visit there seems to have made quite an impression on her, she goes from home so little, and sees so little of the rural, small things make quite an incident in her quiet life, but the Brandywine is pretty fair for all.  I have not told thee yet how much surprised, almost shocked I was by thy letter to me at E-town telling of thy intention of starting for Europe.  it was so utterly unexpected, and then I was so far away from you, and could not ask what thee had gone for, except I knew it was on business, and then I would have liked to have taken a more affectionate farewell of thee, it had been such a hasty one when thee left Elizabethtown.  We had a very nice time there, Clemmie improved very much I thinkthough she has some cough still at times but it was of very little account, if it had not been for her previous attack.  We visited John Brown’s grave amongst other places, and I have some maple sugar for thee from his place.  I hear sister A and Lilly are both writing, but it is impossible to find a time when there is not some one writing to thee.  So should my letter come in at the little end of the horn, may it at least prove to thee that thee is affectionately remembered by thy far distant but loving
    
   sister Ruthanna
   
   If it should come in thy way to procure an Irish [poplin?] dress for me I would be glad to have one, if they are not too very high, dont get it if over $4.00 per ydI send a pattern of the one I have had, a most excellent one, I would like a dark gray or mode shade, but without a blue or pink shadow in it, my present one has blue in it.  or I would like a pretty brown, but dont take any trouble about it- There may be a kind not-quite-so heavy & expensive as this pattern would be

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Recipient:  Sarah Miller Walker:  1799-1874
Date: 1873-01-27
Title: 1873 January 27, Connymede, to Sarah Walker

Connymede 1 mo 27
   2d day
   
   My dear friend
   Sarah Walker
   
   I little while ago Carry handed me thy letter to read- which was received today, and dated 1 mo 22d and 24th and asked if I would write to thee.  From the tenor of thy letter thee seems to think there has been an improvement is Uncle Wm's condition.  But though for a little while, since being in bed- he was able to take cream again, to some little amount, he is now very low indeed, and taking only a very little wine, about a teaspoonful at a time.  TheDr told them he might not live through last night.  I came over yesterday afternoon.  About 7 O'clk  the girls and Edgar were around his bed.  He was asking about one or two of them; and who it was at the foot of the bed?  when told it was Nettie, said he could’nt see- still I think there was but little light in the room- The remark was made that he had a good many kind children round him, I think he tried hard to say yes- but seemed unable, something like a slight spasm coming on, from that time for a while, it seemed as if he might be dying.  but he again revived, and was able to speak out quite loud during the night.  calling outhis wishes he does not seem able to modulate his voice.  He is very childlike and dependant upon those around him.  How frail we are truly!  Human nature seems to be utter weakness at such times.  He  has been generally & uncomplaining during his sickness, although within a day or two there has been some moaning, apparently from weakness he dont speak as if he suffers much.  He seems very appreciative of the attention of his friends.  I do not think any of them now look for his recovery.  And from present appearances, it does not seem likely the end is very far off and yet I feel as if it was hard to know how long it may be.  He is very very sick looking now.  By dear aunt Susans removal, pooruncle Wm seems of course more thrown upon his children, And it is indeed pleasant to see their kindness & attention.  dear Clemmie especially, [*] but perhaps I should not draw any comparison, but she is the oldest and has felt perhaps more responsibility, especially before her father was confined to bed, and others had stepped in to assist.  The girls seem pretty well and much composed.  Nettie is suffering with headache to day.  and Clemmie was a day or two ago.  Edgar does not look very well to me but he was up a good deal last night.  Alexis seems very well.  Of course thee knows the girls have been passing through a great deal.  but I hope the Lord has been near may an eternal inheritance be granted uncle Wm if he is taken
   
   *more striking with Clemmie than Carry & Nettie, because of her former shrinkingClemmie seemed much distressed and unnerved last evening, when her father seemed to be reviving again, and she had been in hopes it was almost over.  His groaning was distressing  to her.  but I do not know that he was suffering so much.  If it was suffering, I should suppose it was from weakness and distress.  Cousin Frank and Mary Yarnall have been very kind and attentive.  We are expecting brother Thos out to night.  I will now close this biding thee farewell.  I fear this is a very different letter from what it might have been had one of the girls written it.*  Affectionately thy friend
   
   R Anna Cope
   
   *they perhaps would have been netter able to tell of their ownsorrow.  I fear I am dificient in entering into the feelings of others, as some do
   
   Dear R.A. Cope
   with [---] of her
   dear Uncle passing
   away-
   1.31.73-

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1806-1875
Date: 1834-02-28
Title: 1834 February 28, Philadelphia, to Alfred Cope

Philada. 2mo 28. 1834
   
   We have at last my dear son been favoured to hear from thee- thy Letters of the 21st 1mo having reached us 2 days ago- that is one to Henry & one to William.  These are all which have as yet been recd-  Much as all of us have been gratified to learn thy safe arrival at Madeira our pleasure would have been greatly increased to have some assurance of thy health having been improved.  We hope for the best & are thankful to find thou art spending thy time so agreeably- far away from the troubles which surround us on all hands- Our country is indeed in a very portentious condition.  Genl Jackson seems to be determined let the consequences be what they may, to crush the Bank of the United States.  & such is the foolish nay mad devotion of his immediate partizans, that they are as determined to support him, reckless as to the future.  To day we have a message from our Governor, to the Legislature, announcing the failure of his attempts to borrow money.  & labouring to throw the blame on the Bank- besides the injustice of this charge, he appears to be but little aware of the effect this will produce on money lenders at home & abroad.  Who are [---] thy set, & will be alarmed with fears that the state may not be able to pay the interest of its vast debt- Had he posessed the manliness to recommend the recharter of the Bk public confidence would at once have been restored, & with it the facility of borrowing.  He contemplated the stopage of the public works- Who will then be able to calculate the public loss?  There can of course be little or no income, & the works themselves must be injured if not ruined.
   
   Our family concerns are going on much as usual.  Thy brother Wm is in a fair way ofAlfred Cope
   
   Madeira
   
   [T.P Cope 2/28- recd 4/25 1834   [---] Spark]

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas Pim Cope:  1823-1900
Recipient:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Date: 1852-07-17
Title: 1852 July 17, to Clemmie, Woodbourne

Philadelphia, 7mo 17, 1852
   
   Dear Clemmie,
   Grandfather desired me to acknowledge the receipt of thy acceptable letter of last seventh day. I am sorry for thy sake that it has not fallen into better hand, but if thee will believe that I have the will to send thee such a letter as would give thee a great deal of pleasure, I will rely upon the interest it will have for thee as coming from among and giving thee a great deal of pleasure. I will rely upon the interest it will have for thee as coming from among and giving thee perhaps, the latest news of some of those who think so much of thee. Anne and I entirely agree with thee in considering that the pleasantest part of the days journey was when we were all traveling together. We ran off the track about half an hour after we parted and were four hours in a pretty hot place before we were on our way again. If we had foreseen that we were to pass nearly the whole day on the road might have he fellow travelers a greater distance and lightened me and others burdens. Thee must have had a very tiresome journey all the way home Henry Drinker tells us thee had to ride from Wilkes-Barre in the hot sun in an open wagon: he thinks they did much better. When thee comes down next winder, take thou Scranton unto. We are glad to hear that thee friend Uncle William so much better and the rest all well. Grandfather seems stronger and generally better than when he fist came out in the country- He sends his love to thee and all the family. Aunt Caroline, Frank and Ellie are at Cape May. I forget whetherthey went before thee left: they wrote several days ago that Ellie’s general health was improved We have heard indirectly that Mary was unwell- Julia has gone to Reading for a few weeks. Aunt Mary returned to Jersey yesterday I believe- She was kept in turn an account of Elizabeth’s mother having an attack very much like if not really cholera. She was very ill one night: they have gone to Cape May since with Henry and Ellie. The three families that live in that unnamed corner of this country that is so hard to find am pretty much as the left them they all send their love. Elizabeth says she would be very glad if thee would write to her if thee fells so inclined. Please tell Uncle William that a package for Grandfather by Henry Drinker came safe to hand the morning- Uncle Alfred has taken the letter out to him. He comes in and spends every "third-day" in town.   
   I hope we shall hear from thee often; if thee should write to me it would give me much pleasure.
   
   Affectionately thy cousin,
   Thomas P Cope Jr.
    
   Germantown, 7mo 18, 1852
   
   Dear Clemmie,
   
   Not having a woman's privilege as to postscripts I begin afresh.  I have no objections however to having reason to call the by name again – it seems more natural and sociable and I see thee look up from thy work or from study or quiet wordto hear what I have to say- I finished in a hurry yesterday afternoon intending to mail this before leaving town, but time failing I have an opportunity to say that Anne secured a letter from Eddy last evening in which he says nothing about his bodily conditions, but that his discontent which she had inquired about are improving" Your visit no doubt did him good. Visits from home to a boy at school are a pleasant recollections for the rest of his life.
   
   Thee did not grieve much about they blanket shawl when thee was riding in the stage at night; it will be cooler when thee comes down next fall and we will take care to sent it up to thee in time. Grandfather will be glad to hear from thee and I hope if thee is not afraid of a repetition of what thy first letter has brought upon thee, that thee will write to [.]
   
   With many desire for thy happiness.
 Affectionately, thy Cousin,
   Thomas Cope Jr.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas Pim Cope:  1823-1900
Recipient:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Date: 1852-09-14
Title: 1852 September 14, Philadelphia, to Clemmy

Philada. 9th mo. 14th 1852
   
   Dear Clemmy,
   
   Grandfather this morning told me he wished me to write to thee for him and invite thee to come down and spend the winter with him, and he sends thee the enclosed notes to pay thy passage.  So thee sees he takes it for granted that thee will come, and when we consider how lonely as he says himself he will be it seems so desirable to all the family that he should have thee with him that we trust Uncle William and Aunt Susan will be willing to spare thee again.  I need not tell thee how glad we shall be to have thee among us, though we do not forget that it will make a break in your family circle.  Grandfather spent yesterday in town (which is the day I began this letter & was interrupted and it is the 15th now) and went out to Uncle Edward’s in the afternoon to stay about a week: from there he will go to pay a visit at Uncle Nathaniel's: he does not expect to return to Uncle Alfred's.  He has been generally much better than he was in the spring & more cheerful.Elizabeth and Anne received thy "double almond" letter as it might be called inasmuch as there were two very good kernels in a shell and as I see that they have torn them apart and Elizabeth has her half in her keeping, I have no doubt she intends to consider it a whole letter and send thee a whole answer which shall not be a postscript to some one else's.  I do not recollect any thing new or strange to tell thee and I will not undertake to entertain thee with the particulars of Harry's advances in talking & Franky's in gymnastics which are uppermost in our thoughts and might come out first if I would let them.  Julia returned from Reading a few days ago having spent a couple of weeks there after her grandfather's death, and we are all together again and jogging along as usual.  Mary & Carry Yarnall spent a few days with us lately.  Aunt Mary is at Chester and I do not suppose she will return home much before Grandfather.
   
   This is a very pleasant task Grandfather has put upon me.  I was not surprised at his sending for thee for I thought from remarks he had made several times during the summer that it was very likely he would do so, and now that the time for his return home draws near we are old and young united in thinking it very desirable, for it would not do for him to have no one living with him but Aunt Mary, it would be lonely for both & if she was unwell at any time he would have no one with him.  Send us word in time when andhow thee will come down.  thy blanket shawl we will send up if we can find a conveyance early enough, unless thee tells us that thee does not want it.  Being in town next winter will give thee an opportunity of continuing some of thy studies though the sciences of baking and nursing and general housekeeping may be neglected for a while.  Anne and Julia expect to continue French at School- whether they will go on with the other studies or part of them is undetermined but not very likely, but we hope they will find some way of making good use of their time.
   
   Our three families send their love & hope soon to have thee [am]ong us.  Julia says she will write in a few days.  Ann[e is] spending the evening with Laura.  Hoping soon [---] from thee and soon after to see thee, I am affectionately
   
   thy cousin
   
   Thos. P. Cope JrClementine Cope
   Care of William D. Cope
   Dimock
   Susquehanna Co
   Pa.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas Pim Cope:  1823-1900
Recipient:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Date: 1852-08-30
Title: 1852 August 30, Philadelphia, to Clemmy, Dimock

Philadelphia 8mo 31, 1852
   
   Dear Clemmy,
    
    Thy very welcome letter came safe in to enclosure. I should have been quite disappointed if thee had not written to me and would like to think that there was not much debate in thy mind about it or at least that inclination took some part in it. Thee would give me a great deal of pleasure if thee would write often good long letters and thee may be very sure that I shall be interested in every thing thee chooses to tell me of thy doings and thinkings. I looked often for a sign that thee had not forgotten us, to appear on opening the letters we received from home while we were at Cape May and when we returned and still received no such sign, nothing but the belief from day today that we should certainly hear from thee before the next, save this from a letter about  it in which I expect I should have let fall some little misgivings which I should have reported of as soon as I got thy note. We had a pleasant and restful visit to the seashore and would  have been very glad if thee could have had thee with us. I should be almost sorry however that thy first acquaintance with the sea should be made when there is such a throng of visitors, it take away very much from your real enjoyment. I am glad that my first recollections of thesea at Cape May of other places here no such associations so that it seems to me in looking back on if it was always First Day it was so quite and pleasant. There were a number of new friends with us this summer, part of the time, all of Elizabeth's family except the little boys and several of Uncle Nathaniel's Mother has quite benefited by his visit and the swelling of his feet has almost disappeared.
     
   If thee had told me that thee took a walk every morning before breakfast I should answer that I doubted whether it would be good for thee, but I do not suppose once in a month or two will hurt thee. But to be up and about before breakfast and before sunrise I think is very useful and very pleasant. I am excellent habit, not very easy to get into. I used often when I was at Haverford at school to get up some time before sunrise and watch the coming in of day and I have not forgotten the freshness of the morning and the pleasant sight, and sounds there are at that quiet time. I As people are said to require less sleep as they grow old I hope to enjoy it all again and if I lived now, in such a pleasant country as Susquehanna Co. I don’t know what it might do for me. And it is very good to have a little time to yourself before the day begins, not very hard to get into the practice, very easy to help in it and easy to fall out of it, as I know. Do not think I am making light of thy "improving." I used for a long timeNot very long ago to be up some time before breakfast and desire very much to get back into the habit and intend to when I begin to practice my preaching's to thee on this and other matters.
    
   I will not believe that thee is not fond of rambling about the woods until I have a chance of cross-questioning thee about it. I dare say it would turn out that it was being overtired that thee does not enjoy.
   
   I believe I have not much family or other news to send thee. Aunt Caroline has been kept to her bed for some time, but is getting better. Mary I suppose thee knows was at the sea shore with us. Aunt Rebecca and son James B. are pretty much well. Grandfather continues very well for him and seems contented and comfortable at Uncle Alfred's.  Our [] families both great and small members are almost as usual. Is Mary Anne Morris a sort of cousin to thine? If she is, thee will have to make a little room in the place when thee keeps thy cousins, for Sandy Martin.
    
   Now Clemmy thee will agree with me that this is not an interesting letter. That is what I never did and never expect to write and thee must not take it as any measure of my good will toward thee. If I had followed my inclination it would have been written very soon after I got thine, and I hope thee will find time amid thy household cares, if this finds thee still at the head of affairs to answer it very soon. I send Elizabeth love on my own responsibility and if I was at Germantown should have various such messages for thee. If I have not replied to every thing in thyletter it is not because I do not find a great deal of interest on whatever thee tells me about thyself. I am much obliged to thee for taking my lectures so kindly and remember them so well.
   
   Affectionately thy Cousin,
   Thomas P Cope Jr.Clementine Cope
   Care of William D. Cope
   Dimock
   Susquehanna Co.
   Pa  

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Caroline R. (Caroline Rachel) Cope Yarnall:  1802-1881
Date: 1826-09-12
Title: 1826 September 12, Montrose, to Sisters, Philadelphia

Montrose 9mo 1826
   
   My Dear Sisters,
   
   Your acceptable communication of 29th [---] has reached me.  it was truly grateful to my soul to enter into fellow feeling with you, in traveling in th't to ye Heavenly Mansion to which it has pleased the Father of Spirits to call the purified spirit of our deceased Mother.  tho' in general, I wd. be ye last to discourage an affable, benevolent, & christian cheerfulness, yet I believe we will find that it is sometimes, "better to go to ye house of mourning than go to ye house of feasting": that sorrow is better than [---].  Pa[-]ly ye sadness of ye countenance ye heart is made better."  I trust that we shall often be refreshed when thus dwelling together in unity & sympathy.-  when I reflect upon ye great affection which our departed Mother manifested to us, upon ye moment when she has prest me to her bosom, when, she has evinced her maternal care by instilling into my mind, new & useful ideas, my feelings are affected with a sensability, which language is inadequate to convey to another.
   
   "Thy constant flow of love, that knew no fall,   Ne'er roughened by those cataracts & breaks,   That humour interposed, too often makes;-   This, still is legible in mem'ry's page,   And still will be so to my latest age."
   
   When my tho'ts are thus led, there seems to be a sacredness in them, which it wd. be sacrilige to interrupt by words or ye common occurances of ye world around us.  I experience a degree of that feeling which is produced in approaching ye Sanctuary of the Most High & calling to mind ye injunction, "The Lord is in his Holy Temple, let all the Earth, keep silence before him."
   
   I[---][Montrose P
   Sept 8th]
   
   9mo 12. 1826,
   
   Caroline R Cope
   care of Thomas P Cope
   Philadelphia

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1829-02-16
Title: 1829 February 16, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 2 mo 16 1829
   
   Dear Brother:
   
   I tho't it ye less necessary to take a formal leave of thee before my departure from ye City, as I had a prospect of revisiting you, before ye lapse of a very long period of time. I therefore was not satisfied with bidding thee farewell, thro’ ye medium of thy "better half". No material incident occurred during my journey hither. We were amused by ye remarks and minute observations of one of our fellow passengers, a young man of respectable appearance, probably 25 years of age, who, as I understood him to say, had never before been 14 miles from Philadelphia and had never seen a mountain. As we approached the Blue Ridge, his curiosity seemed on tip toe. The most novel circumstance that I have heard of having taken place during my absence from Woodbourne, in a hunt after wild boars. G. Walker shot one during ye day which was occupied in the chase. I will give thee an idea of other enjoyment that we may have in ye country, in Winter, by transcribing an extract of a letter from an accomplished young lady of the City of N. York to her friend at Woodbourne, who has permitted me to enter it, in my diary: "I have just returned from a visit to ye country, and have been indulging my taste for Winter scenery, checked vegetation and leafless tress to perfection. I had not indeed ye warmth of a good Schuylkill coal fire, to counterbalance ye want of which, I adopted ye beautiful sentiment of ye late Dr. Drake, "to make our climate in ye heart, & I feel 'tis Summer there."  what delightful privileges we have in ye country.  in ye gay Metropolis, we cannot as there, throw round our shoulders, ye old cloak, pitch on ye slouched hat, & slip on ye leather shoes-, then, race off, with ye freedom of untamed savages.  no, my dear, ye glass must be consulted with percision, ye dress arranged for observation,- ye hop, skip & jump, exchanged for ye measured step, or mincing gait, & a certain air of nonchalance, thrown over ye whole exterior."-  a few days after my return hither, E. Walker reached home.  ye joy of ye family was extreme, on again seeing him, after an absense of 7 mos.-  his seemed equally keen.  whatever may be his deficiencies, he is certainly a most affectionate father, & ye attachment between ye different members of his family, seems to be mutual.  this feeling extends even to the servants.-  a pleasing instance occurred on my arrival.  a nice little Germantown girl, was ye first to see me.  she ran eagerly to inform the family, but so excited were her feelings, that she cd. only say, Mr. Cope, Mrs. Cope, unaccompanied with any explanation of ye cause of her agitation.  they inform me that she shed tears on my leaving them for Philada.-  in my intercourse with ye head of the family, herementioned, as well as with others, I have been lead into this train of reflection: if we associate with those only that are perfect, who are to be our companions?  is it not wise to accept thankfully of kindness from ye hands of a fellow-being, whatever extended, to return like with like & good for evil, (a hard thing for poor human nature to do,) to condemn in a mild, frank & friendly manner, his faults, & try to show him by our own conduct, a good example for imitation.-  it is probably a fortunate circumstance, that, in a new country, we are almost obliged to hold more free inercourse with one another, than people in other situations.-  many prejudices are thus removed, & we are taught to know that tho' thro' selfishness of men, we may be injured, we can also be benefitted by them.  but I acknowledge it is a nice point, to avoid shipwreck, upon the rocks of misanthropy on the one hand, & the quicksands of good natured credulity, on the other.-  E.W’s mind seems much beclouded on ye subject of religious & society concerns, tho' he seems to harbour no asperity towards any party, but evinces kind & good natured feelings towards all.
   
   I found thy letter of 8 ult. safe in the P.Office here, & return thee thanks for ye names it furnishes, of the authors of communications for "the Friend".  several of them, I had not ascertained during my stay in the City.  "the Voyage to India," I was informed, is ye production of Dr. Reynell Coates.
   
   Please give best love to all, from thy
 affectionate brother,
   Wm D CopeWoodbourne
   2mo.16.
   
   [2mo 20 1829]
   Henry Cope
   Care of Thomas P Cope & Sons,
   Philadelphia.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1830-07-29
Title: 1830 July 29, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 7mo. 29th 1830
   Dear Brother:
   
   The idea presented in thine of ye 20 inst. of finding me out in the woods, I may truly say, excited in me very pleasant feelings; tho' at ye same time, I feel as if I can scarcely dare to invite you, for reasons that I think it wd. not be proper to mention in a letter. I will give thee a remote exception of what amongst other things, I allude to, by refering to a frequent remark, that in every flock, there is a black sheep, & a Judas in every community. more than this, I ought not to say. I believe I have never hesitated to answer any query put to me by relatives & friends respecting my situation, nor have I any objections to doing so, unless I may have a very particular reason for secrecy. but Marmaduke will perhaps from having been an impartial spectator, be more likely to give thee a satisfactory description of Woodbourne than myself.- E. Walker bro't me thy letter whilst I was spending ye evening as usual, with his family. I mentioned what was said by thee about visiting me. George desired me to tell thee that they shd. be very glad to see thee: and Priscilla said, tell him to bring Rachel &Martha. they all seemed to be as glad to see Marmaduke & our other cousins, as if they had been their own relations. it seemed to me to be quite like an era in ye history of Woodbourne, when my City relations had actually paid me a visit.- I think you had better come on, and take us by surprise as they did, and thus give us no time to think about any obstructions, objections, or difficulties. with regard to any pecuniary considerations, I think I cd. fully satisfy my neighbours, tho' they will not listen to any direct proposition relative to consideration money.- in expressing what precedes, I have used ye freedom, which ought to exist in ye intercourse between brothers. to one, who does not stand in ye same relationship to me as thyself, I wd. have felt some hesitation in saying what I have said to thee.- I was much interested in reading thy description of ye proposed institution for imparting instruction in ye higher branches of learning to the children of Friends, and had no idea that so great an advance had been made towards affecting ye object in view. it is a noble undertaking, & if accomplished, will tend to increase ye reputation of the Society. the sup-position or opinion, that our profession, principles or religion acquires ye discouragement of literary knowledge & intelligence, appears to me pretty evidently to be a mistake.-  I was fearful that there wd. be an appearance of ambiguity in my observations with regard to the Union Canal stock.  In my last communication on ye subject, I expressed a willingness to invest, if I cd. obtain five per cent on the am't invested.  this I shd. receive, were I to give $240 per share, or 120 per cent.  consequently, if I am right in my estimate, ye price is still below my limits.  but of course, there would be no advantage in offering a high price, if there is none of the stock for sale.-  I am much obliged to thy attention to the subject.  supposing that the Bank of Penna has declared ye dame divd. for ye last as for ye previous half year, I inclose a Power of Att'y for its collection, & one also for the interest on the C & D Canal loan.  if the Lehigh Co. shd. have disclosed a divd. please inform me.  I see by the news-papers, that 3 1/2% has been declared by the U.S. B'k.
   
   With best love to family & friends, I remain thy affectionate brother,
   Wm D Cope
   
   I have drawn, under date of 5mo. 3-'30, draft no. 25, fav. C. Avery for $50.+  and no 26, under date of 7mo. 1-'30, fav. Avery & Drinker, for same am't, & both at 3 d/s.  also no. 27, at 3 d/s, fav. Avery & Drinker, dated 7mo.13-'30, for $50.00
   I lately spoke to G. Mallery about ye P. Thomson tract & he promised me that he will again lay ye subject before ye Com's & when their decision is ascertained, will write to me.
   
   + before advised ofKnow all men by these presents, that I, William D Cope of the Township of Springville, County of Susquehanna and State of Pennsylvania, have authorized and appointed, and do authorize and appoint, Henry Cope, of the firm of Henry & Alfred Cope, Philadelphia, my true and lawful attorney, to demand and receive from the Chesapeak & Delaware Canal Company, the interest due me on Nine thousand five hundred dollars ($9500.) Loan of said Company.
   
   In witness whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seal rgw twenty-ninth day of the 7mo. (August) 1830
   Signed and sealed in the presence of
   Jonathan Nichols
   Lyman BaldwinWoodbourne
   7mo.30.
   
   [8mo 1 1830-]
   Henry Cope,
   care of Henry & Alfred Cope,
   Philadelphia.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1830-09-02
Title: 1830 September 2, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 9 month 2. 1830
   Dear Brother:
   
   The kind sympathy expressed in thy letter of 25 ult. for the loss of my buildings etc, was very grateful. I have become, as I hoped wd. be the case when I last wrote, much better reconciled to my loss than I then was. I occasionally leave a sigh as I pass by ye remains of a beautiful rosebush or shrub, on which I have often looked with sensation of pleasures, now reduced to a black & unsightly stem, or a fine fruit tree, scathed & withered by ye scorching heat. But my feelings seem to become settled under ye conviction, that regrets are vain  & useless, for what cannot be restored. The joint invitation of thyself & Rachel to G. Walker was very acceptable both to him & the family. He hesitated to accept it, on account of not being personally acquainted with thee, but, upon further consideration, desired me to express his thanks to you, & to say that he wd. accept it, though he expected that most of his leisure time, when not occupied with attention to his duties as an Anti-Masonic delegate, wd.  he divided amongst his relatives & friends. He expects to leave here in ye stage on ye morning of ye 8th, & to reach Philada. on ye evening of ye 9th [inst]. I feel glad that he has concluded to accept of your kind offer, shall consider myself indebted for any little kind offices done for him, or services rendered, & will credit you for them as if performed for myself. I think ye members of E. Walker's family, are of real benefit in promoting & advancing ye interest of this Country, or of this part of it. They seem to serve as pioneers for ye better classes of society, & consequently ye more desriable kind of population.  their extensive correspondence & acquaintance brings ye country into notice, & their hospitality to those who visit it, creates an impression in its favour. They at present have 6 of their relatives with them as guests , from Philada. & Wynne Wood, in ye neighourhood of ye City: Mary Jones, whose beautiful & wealthy daughter was lately married to Levi, son of Israel W. Morris, her son, Levi & his bride, the widow Jones, Mother of Stephenson & Cornelius Smith, and her grandson. Thiscompany was increased ye day before yesterday by ye arrival of James Bell from Stroudsburg, & 3 of this family. Having but a small house, thou wilt conclude that to accommodate such a company good management & contrivance are requisite. Their hospitality costs them a good deal of labour, if nor a great amount of money. Today, Daniel Stroud, his wife, George Spencer, Peter Robeson's wife, & another woman friend, have stopped to breakfast on their way from Friendsville.
   
   With Love, to all, I remain thy affectionate brother,
   Wm D Cope[Note on other hand: W.D. Cope Woodbourne   9mo 2 1830]
   
   Woodbourne
   9mo. 3
   
   [9mo 6]
   
   [Note in third hand: Loss of house- Aug 1830    Description of E. Walker’s family – Benefit   to area
   
   Levi
   Morris, son of Sarah]
   
   Henry Cope
   care of Henry & Alfred Cope,
   Philadelphia.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Sarah Miller Walker:  1799-1874
Date: 1833-03-21
Title: 1833 March 21, White Cottage, Woodbourne, to Susan Newbold

I have experienced some little embarrassment in my recent intercourse with thee, and in that spirit of candour which I admire, however small may be the portion of it that I possess, I wish to explain, or advert to the cause of it. the amount & substance of what I wish to say, is, that I hope, if I may have shown that I like thee, or that I have a partiality for thee, then wilt not suppose that I am striving to alienate thy affections from another quarter. and injustice has been done me if it has been represented to thee, that I have in any way, made such an attempt. I do not altogether like this formal mode of making this communication, but there has not seemed to be a suitable opportunity of doing it in conversation. whatever may be our future connexions or situation in life, I am desirous that nothing should occur to mar the friendship which I believed has always subsisted between us since we have been acquainted with each other. and I think it is not surprising that I should have some feelings on this subject, when it is considered that thou art the only person in the community, whose sentiments coincide with my own. I have often admired the moderate firmness with which, almost single handed and as it were alone, thou hast adhered to principles, and as I believe correct principles; and not the less, because they have been adhered to by thee, more steadfastly than bythan by myself. I sometimes allow myself a latitude in light or perhaps rather unmeaning conversation, as well as in some other respects & things, which I would not do, if I tho’t that I was wandering so far from the conduct of my true & guiding polar star, as to endanger my return to its salutary influence and correct path. though the trials and vicissitudes that thou hath had to encounter may be small in comparison to those which are allotted to some, I know that they have been hard to bear, and I have been pleased to witness the cheerfulness with which thou hast been sustained under their pressure. I hope that in all those which in common with mother may be meted out to thee in the course of thy earthly pilgrimage, there may be still found alleviating circumstances, and a sustaining hand.- I think I shall always remember with gratitude the kind-heartedness shown toward me by thyself and thy dear deceased Sister Priscilla. Indeed my heart sometimes overflows with kindly feelings when I reflect upon it. In Priscilla, I think I may say, I always found an advocate & support in correct principles. I sometimes in the course of conversation with her, did not at first think so, but explanation & a free interchange of sentiments generally convinced me that she was correct in the groundwork & substance of true piety.- having now expressed so much as I have, allow me to say further, that if thou hath at any time, any impropriety in word or deed, to allege against me, I hope thou wilt represent it to me, with frankness, but with such proper caution as not unnecessarilynot unnecessarily to wound my feelings. I have thought it times past, that I observed a tendency to a different course. tho' I believe at the same time, that thou didst endeavour to use proper caution on certain occasions, if we do wrong, let us mention & state, our faults to each other with mildness. conscience, if not [---] is a sufficiently severe accuser. as I think I once before observed to thee, there are ills enough, which we cannot avoid, without unnecessarily creating others. It is a melancholy reflection that "man is to man, the sorest, surest foe." It is however consoling to think that there are exceptions to all general rules, and I trust there are many to this. I have not the vanity to think and thou of course wilt not understand me to suppose, that I have the power of causing a transfer of thy affections, but thee knows the attempt might be made without the power.    My Brother Henry mentions in a letter recently received from him that our Cousin A. Barker is slowly recovering her health.
    
   3 mo. 21. 1833.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Joel Baily
Recipient:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Date: 1833-09-13
Title: 1813 September 13, East Marlborough, to William D Cope, Philadelphia

East Marlborough
    September 13th-1813
   
   Esteemed Friend William D Cope,
   
   I have received thy letter of the 30the of August which informes me that thee has accomplished thy journey Westward and is now at thy own home in Philadelphia. Therefore I now purpose writing thee a few lines by way of answer both to the above mentioned letter and that of the 25th of July. Friend Cope I judge thee thinks I am a very lazy fellow for nether meeting thee at West-Chester nor answering thy letter before this-time. but, as for the former I think I have a very good reason for I did not receive the intelligence of thee being there till about 5 days after the appointed time which was the only reason why I was not there for I would have been well pleased to of had the opurtunity of seeing my Friend by going the small distance of ten miles.but, altho thy friend was disappointed of the operturnity he thanks thee kindly for the invitation. The account thee has given me of Lancaster town is very similar to what I expected it was, but as for Columbia I did not expect its adjacent lands were so hilly, or, had such Mountains in them as thee mentions.I understand Friend E Lewis lately buried his son Ennoch with the flux. but I did not understan that the disorder has spread in the family.    
   With a hope that these lines may find thee in as good a state of health as I am in I conclude, and subscribe myself thy affectionate friend.
   
   Joel Baily
    
   William D CopeWilliam D. Cope
   Philadelphia
   
   To the care of Thomas P Cope
   merchant Walnut
   St warf

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Edward Brown
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1887-05-18
Title: 1887 May 18, Brooklyn, N.Y., to Cousin Anna

356 Adelphi st
   Brooklyn, N.Y.
   5/18. 87
   
   Dear Cousin Anna,
   
   I recd thy note announcing the death of thy dear sister, and it was very thoughtful and loving of them to remember me-  though I had, the day before, recd a short note from Henry himself. It was sudden as sad to me, as I had heard nothing of her further declining health or illness. When I saw cousin Mary last was at Mt. Pleasant about 2 years ago. Then, though looking delicate, she seemed as bright and reminded me strongly of the days of her beautiful girlgood. O, those dreamlike days! of your cousins, in your Arch st. home, and the several Paradises, that the 'Doctor', and cousin Frank and I need to riflealong the Schuykill and Wissahiccon every spring- for the first and fairest flowers and how you loved to prink your happy parlors with them. I replied quite at length. For me to Henry’s letter, and told him I hoped to come on to P. to see my brothers soon, and hoped to see him which I still wish to do. It would have been a great comfort to me, if I could have come on to the funeral, but my state of health at that time prevented by a sudden change in the weather I had taken. A touch of Pleurisy which I had to break up I and we all, Mariann and Anna (who meet Cousin Mary at mt. Pleasant), were with you that sad afternoon in mournful communion. Is n't itremarkable, that you all, of your sisterhood of five, shd. have been spared to Each other so long. And as these days Mary was always so joyous a nature you must all miss her sunshine. How could our hearts bear up under all the partings on our dearest me, on Earth did we not see the vision of the Angel world and among them, our "family in Heaven". Where hope assues me we shall meet beyond all partings I fear illegible note, will find there and thin in health and with love to all and to cousins Susan & Lizzie & Fanny. I will close adding only that [Marien?] & Anna wish their love to you. Excuse my not replying to thy letters, Dear Cousin Anna, which I wasvery grateful for. For if the Dr. had not written, I should have heard, very sorrowfully so I have in several cases of Philada relations, when the first news I heard was long after: Knowing of it and I could mingle with you in Spirit, and live over our happy long days and anticipate those happier ones to come. That Death cannot end, nor sorrow overcast.
   Love especially to cousin Frank.
   
   From thy Afft,
   Cousin Edward
   
   P.S. After I wrote this last note Cousin Anna, recd Alfred cards & those for Sister Anna & Henry wh. We have forwarded to Boston. It mush be a very happy affair. All sounds and we should be glad to be present but Anna will have too send cards instead. Aff, EdwardNot Being sure of your home P.S. address I mail this for Brr David to forward.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Mary J.B. Chew
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1909-11-09
Title: 1909 November 9, Radnor, to Cousin Anna

November 9th 1909
   
   Dear Cousin Anna
   
   Martha and I wish to tell thee how much we appreciate being asked to go to Awbury today-    I can remember so well the day of your & Cousin Frank's Wedding, and the evening soon after which you spent with my father and Mother. I was only seven years old but itmade a great impression upon me- and cousin Frank's kind greeting to me then was never forgotten. as I grew older and learned to know more about him my childish regard grew into respect and reverence and from that time until now, it has been a happiness to know that I could claim as a cousin one whose character I so thoroughly admired and respected- it is indeed men such as he was, who makeour country great and at the same time have all the gentle qualities which inspire admiration and affection-  We cannot regret that he has gone, for he had billed the full measure of his days, we can only remember that "Precious in the light of the Lord is the death of his Saints"
   
   With love from Martha and Me, I am dear Cousin Anna.
    Most affectionately, Mary J.B. Chew

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Reed Cary
Recipient:  Francis Algernon Evans:  1878-1946
Date: 1911-06-29
Title: 1911 June 29, to Alg

6/29/11
   
   Dear Alg-
   
   Words are so hopelessly futile and especially are they so when cold on the paper that I hesitate to make the attempt to express the very deep feelings that the recent news inspired in me.  Our meetings together during the past year had had the effect of developing in me desires for development and usefulness as thosewhich most manifestly animated him and especially during the past few months I had looked forward to a future where we might work for the common object of developing in ourselves and thence to our meeting and Society a deeper truer life.  And so it comes that I feel as though I might to at least make the attempt to tell you all how deep is my sense ofof personal loss and there fore how sincerely I sympathize with thee and the rest of his family in the loss of him from your circle.
   
   I know of no one person who, of recent years, has had more influence for good when upon me than did Ernest and it seemed to me that the bottom had dropped out of every thing when I learned that he wastaken but tho it does still seem that way there is the perfectly sure knowledge that the very little knowledge I have of his life will stay with me as an inspiration.  Tho it was seldom we got together I feel as tho I, too, had lost a brother.
   
   With sympathy which I really cannot express
   sincerely
   Charles Reed Cary

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Davis H. (Davis Hoopes) Forsythe:  1858-1934
Recipient:  Francis Algernon Evans:  1878-1946
Date: 1911-03-27
Title: 1911 March 27, Westtown, to Boys

Westtown Pa.
   3 mo 27th 1911
   
   Dear Boys
   
   This morning's mail brings to me a sad  letter from your cousin Elizabeth Goodhue. It is my last wish to intrude upon your sorrow but I must make just a few words for my sake if not for yours.
   
   The greatesttrial of my life & even yet in retrospect it seems very great, your father was the very embodiment of kindness to me, the sort of kindness that allows your weakness to grow a little stronger from his strength & this and more than thisif possible he was to me. I remember, it was many years ago, the summer before Algernon went to College, your dear father said to me in the school house office "I did not sleep last night, for the thought of the responsibility of the rear-ing of these children of mine got so on my nerve that it banished sleep." I could ask for no better legacy for you dear fellows than that a father would wrestle in prayer the night through that God's blessing might rest on you & on his effort. He answered that prayer & long ago gave your father the assurance that he sought. I could write on and on for Icannot help mingling my tears with yours. With a messageof love to you mother & to Anna.
   Your Friend
    
   Davis H. Forsythe

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Hannah Rhoads Haines Garrett:  1846-1901
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1899-04-26
Title: 1899 April 26, Rosemont, to Lily

4 mo 26. 1899
   
   Dear Lily,
   
   There has been a lack of vocal or written sympathy with thee this winter, and this brief message is only to assure thee of my love and frequent thought being freshly flowing.That mere words would only weary thee I know and I only sent messages to thee by notes to Rachel. It was my hope that long before this my own strength would have retuned and enabled me to go to thee. But that is not the case as only a very little exertion ispossible yet - writing, almost is a lost art. Excuse this detail, because I could not otherwise explain my absence. Now we have heard of Edward's illness, and I wish to send by thee my love to Jonathan and Rachel, when it is convient to thee.
   
   We Also understand Edward is much beter, I hope convalescent.Dear, believe me, thy loss is shared in some degree by me, for thy lovely Agnes was especially near to me, her gentle pure spirit now a lasting place in my heart.
   
    She always seemed as one apart from our every-day routine, and now she is in full & glourious development of all her Savoir has prepared her to be for Him. Always lovingly thy
    Hannah R. Garrett.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  M.H. Garrett
Recipient:  Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth) Cope:  1840-1944
Date: 1883-09-30
Title: 1883 September 30, Germantown, to Carrie

Germantown, 9.30.83.
   
   My Dear Carrie-
   I hope the expression of sympathy & affection may be acceptable, even though there may be no new thoughts of comfort to suggest.
   
   I was so sorry to hear from Sister Lillie today that Edgar's health had been poor. I though of him as a strong man. It will be a pleasure, no doubt, though mingled with sadness, to Nettie & thee, to minister to the comfort of your remaining brother.
   
   The memory of Alexis is one of calmness & sweetness. I did not know him well, yet recall with pleasure the queit cordiality of his greeting. Samuel Morris, who rode in the same carriagewith me at the funeral, said he had learned to love him much. I think it is grateful to look back on his life here as a happy one, & his life there as is fit & glorious consummation. And he left a dear legacy in his children. I am glad you have them. I count myself so rich in my dear nephews & nieces, my young brothers & sisters, as I sometimes call them. Does thee know I am a great-aunt? My oldest nephew, Joseph Rhoads, has a wee Edgar, away out in Plainfield Indiana, where he has gone to teach. Hetty  is out there, helping. Has been away nearly 7 weeks & we don't know when we shall get her back. She went to help furnish & arrange the new little home.
   
   Fanny & Alfred Garret were here last evening a while. We do think Fannya very lively have character, & Alfred seems to be coming out a fine manly boy, & doing well at college. 
    
   How the time does fleet away! Think of it being 50 years since we were at West-town together! And what can those fleeting years show? For me, a life made up of many little things, & with too many idle hours. I enjoy my work of various kinds though; simple household cares, an extensive correspondence, partly for pleasant sympathies, partly for teaching, & on the rest days, a restful work in the care of my first-day class. Dr. Rhoads holds a school at our house and I have as my class nearly 20 boys & girls from 9 to 14 years old who troop up to my room with me. I will not claim to do them much good. I don't believe in direct religious teaching exceptwhere there is an opening for it, but I think the hour passes not unprofitably, & they learn to find the study of the Bible pleasant.    
   I hope Ellie Alderson may continue to improve. I should be glad to hear from thee if thee can feel like writing, & to be told what your prospects are.
   With Love to Nettie & Thyself,
   ever thy affectionate friend
   
   M. H. Garrett

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Phebe E.H. Haines
Recipient:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Date: 1909-11-08
Title: 1909 November 8, to Thomas

My dear Thomas:-
   
   As my thoughts have gone out in sympathy for thee in the great loss of thy dear father, I have recalled an acrostic which he wrote for my mother after my father's death, just twenty years ago; and which we valued very much. I think it is most touchingly beautiful, especially so, that it now seems almost prophetic of his own entranceinto the heavenly city.
   "Joined to the loved ones who, expectant long,
    On yonder shore his coming did await,
    Singing their jubilant, thanksgiving song,
    Early & late, before the pearly gate,
    Palms in their hands; And robed in spotless
 white,
   Happy to praise their Savior day and night!
   How must his soul have thrilled with rapture,
 when
    On quicken ear, burst the ecstatic song!
    With what transporting joy, behold again
    Earths lost ones gathered in that Heavnely
 throng! 
   Loving, as only ransomed spirits love,
   Love centered in Him who is Eternal love."
   
   Please give my love & sympathy to thy mother and sisters andBelieve me, with sincere sympathy.
   
   Thy Friend,
   Phebe E. H. Haines
   
   5433 Wayne Ave.
   11 mo. 8th. 1909.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna C. (Anna Cope) Hartshorne:  1860-1957
Recipient:  Annette Cope:  1843-1916
Date: 1895-09-01
Title: 1895 September 1, Woodbourne, to Annette

Woodbourne
   Sept. 1st 1895
   
   My dear Annette,
   
   When I reached Holmhurst last week Nanna immediately presented me with thy package, and I opened and found the irresistable little gentleman from Dai Nippon. Where did thee pick him up, I wonder! He will be a most pleasant memento of thee, though I shall hesitate to insult his diginity by inkinghis fine skirts! I have thought of thee, and of you all so much this summer, and greatly wished I could have seen thee and Carrie before we leave. I hoped Mrs. Cope would return while I was at Holmhurst, but she is I supppose still with you. If so please give her my dear love. Thee will forgive me I know for this tardy work, I spent a whole week nominally at Holmhurst, actually between the city, Germantown, and all the [---]. Thee knows onlytoo well what such packing is. Now I am enjoying a few day's rest at Woodbourne before going back to Awbury for a square start westward. Virginia here and sends her love, also says to tell thee that I will meet thee in Italy winter after next. I tell her I give the message as hers, not mine! Much as I should like such a prospect; she is much more liekly to turn up there in the next year or two, than I! Lillie and the girls & Thos. & Elizabeth Cope are entertaining Dr. Norris and a Germandoctor friend in the parlor, else they would doubtless send messages. Please give my love to Carrie and Clementine, I understand you are all together, and are glad to know you have that comfort. With dear love for thy own self, and thanks for thinking of me amid so much sorrow, I am as always,
   
   Affectionally thine
   Anne C. Hartshorne

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna C. (Anna Cope) Hartshorne:  1860-1957
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1909-11-10
Title: 1909 November 10, to Aunt Anna

16 [---]
   Nov-10-1909
   
   Dearest Aunt Anna,
   
    There is nothing to say to thee but that I think of thee all the time, and long to be near thee instead of on the other side of the earth. The letters with any definite news will be very slow in coming, as these of mine must seem late and longin reaching you. But thee knows, and you all know, how my heart is with you. I have been thinking of Father’s last message to his "more than brother", and of what both he and thee have been to me all my life. From my babyhood thee has made me feel almost as much thy child as mother’s and to me it seems those tiesare not broken but made strong for eternity, where our beloved cross to the Beyond. My desire is to be worthy of such an inheritance of affliction as mine. My love can never repay it, but that thee has always.
   
   Ask some to write me a line when they can. My Love to them all.
   
   Thy always loving niece,
   Anna C. Hartshorne

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Hartshorne:  1829-1908
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1860-05-08
Title: 1860 May 8

Six years ago, when ever joyous Spring 
   scattered rich gifts upon this earth of our's 
   Far sweeter than the sweetest of her flowers, 
   One flower did God to our own garden bring. 
   
   He planted it a noble plant, and gave 
   The charge of it into our loving care, 
   To train it tenderly, so it might bear 
   Fruit to His praise who for such fruit I did crave. 
   
   Ah! how kept we our trust? Was ours the love, 
   Which while it prized the gift loved more the given, 
    And sought with tears, how is might best deliver 
   The entrusted talent back to him above? 
   
   Oh! earthly love, oh! selfish human heart, 
   Weak and mistrustful of God's providence 
   Troubled for many things of time and sense, 
   Yet careless of the one thing needful, the good path! 
   
   Therefore when God our ill kept graden saw, 
   And marked how weeds were climbing o’er the flowers
    So that the refreshing Heavenly showers 
   Might hardly reach them; gently did he draw 
   
   One flower from our keeping, it may be
    Not only to preserve that one from harm, 
But that our careless souls be might alarm, 
   And waken from their false security. 
   Ah me! How little had we dreamed of this
!    Listless, beside our cherished flowers we lay. 
   And as we breathed their fragrance day by day. 
   Looked for no pride awakening from own bliss. 
   
   In distant meadows could we often hear
    The stern old mower what his fatal sythe; 
   But yet our hearts beat ever free & blythe, 
   Since to our garden still he drew not near. 
   
   Angel of Death! Ah! who may ever tell 
   The bitter anguish of our souls, but now 
   No doubt can e'er disturb our faith that thou 
   Wast sent by Him who doeth all things well. 
   
   He called our flower Willie; twas a name 
   Borne by one dearly loved, whose gentle heart
    Waited e'en then the summons to depart; 
   And joyfully received it when it came. 
   
   And we had hoped, that in our brother's stead
    Our darling might be found by name & all 
   His guiltless actions, ever to recall 
   The cherised memories of the loved & dead. 
   
   Such was wour hope; yet may we not repine; 
    Twas matchless wisdom and unbounded love 
   Drew both our precious ones to him above; 
   To make them in His Heavenly courts to shine. 
  Now other names we trust to them are given, 
   In that blest land where our loved flower is growing. 
    The stream of life beside him ever ever flowing, 
   Which maketh glad the heritage of Heaven. 
   
   And now on this his Natal Day, 
   We humbly bend the knee, and pray 
   To Thee, who wast his God always, 
    God of all Consolation, 
   
   That thou our hearts may so incline, 
   So bend our stubborn wills to thine, 
   That we no longer may repine
   In our deep tribulation
   
   We thank Thee God, that Thou hast taken 
   Our Willie from this world of pain, 
   Before upon his robes the stain 
   Of deadly sin did cling. 
   
   And in his sweet simplicity, 
   That thou, most precious thoughts of Thee
    And of Thy Heaven, continually, 
   Before his mind did bring. 
   
   overSo, when thy summons to him came, 
   While suffering racked his tender frame, 
   The call was welcome, as the claim 
   Of friend long dearly known. 
   
   An doubting naught, his willing feet 
   Hastened the messenger to meet, 
   As one he trustingly could greet, 
   Who came to take him home. 
   
   Oh Lord! Thou gainest the victory! 
   Not unto him, but unto Thee 
   Let all the praise and honor be 
   Oh, Lord! our God most glorius! 
   
   Oh! In the darkness of our night 
   When we too wage the fearful fight, 
   May we be made through thy blessed light, 
    Like him o'er death victorious. 
   
   5th  month 8th 1860.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Hartshorne:  1829-1908
