Title: 1908 May 19, Fairfield, to Lillie

Fairfield5-19-08Dear Lillie,I enclose for the new genealogy work, my check for $100, as I promised. I hope the has felt thee could write to John E. Carter one of thy pleasant letters, such as thee sent me -- I shall be surprised if he does not take an interest in the work and help it on. I have not found a good opportunity to speak to our Alfred about it -- his mind is absorbed in his beloved Porto Rico plans, I don't know how he will feel.Ever aff's thine  EW Garrett

--------------------------------------------------------RELIGION

--------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Richard Randolf
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1879-01-06
Title: 1879 January 6, Philadelphia, to RuthAnna Cope, Germantown

247 North 12th St.
Philada 1/6.1879.

My dear   friend:
As I did not gather from thy message when I last   called at Aubrey that thou wouldst have declined seeing me   if not unusually occupied, and as I deem it one of the first   duties of social life, if not the very first, to seek so to   supply one another (to honour a figure from astronomy.) with   the elements of our several orbits, that we may always know   as exactly as may be, where to find one another; and as a   stubborn lameness, some still more urgent engagement, and   the recent icy walking has combined to prevent my again   calling as I have ever since desired; under these   circumstances I feel at liberty to send thee another brief   letter. Had I succeeded in seeing thee at that last call, I   should perhaps have had little to say but 
I had not presumed on tasking thee with any perusal or   examination of this MS. I left for H.W.S., and that there   was a method--something I trusted of the gospel "decently   and in order", even in the seeming caprice of my movement. I   could not but be conscious of my own appearance of   insensibility; but I may humbly and thankfully assert that I   was and am at least sensible of having a fixed object in   living, which reaches even to the relationship of such   comparative strangers as thou and I must as yet confess   ourselves to be, and which is even necessary, (coupled with   confessed infirmity) to account for some show of   vacillation, or spasmodic irregularity. For instance, I hope   not to leave the world without doing something to the   formation and definite recognition of an "inner circle of   friendship" in which superlative epithets, such as "dearest"   &c. will not be regarded as necessarily exclusive, and into   which a subtle form of witchcraft whichI must not here particularize (for the Bible, as the   Westminster Review justly claims, "must stand or fall with   the doctrine of Witchcraft") shall not be able to enter. And   how difficult must the steadfast upholding of such a   doctrine be in a community whose Social Code, and whose very   theory of the family, commit it to the assumption that   universal tithe shall be the weakest rather than the   strongest! 
I am not now sure but that like one of old I   shall have to appeal from ecclesiastical indifference or   opposition, to the "Cesar" of public sentiment. A recent   Essay on "Stages of Faith", tracing the course of   consciousness from the experience of physical or outward   immunity (i.e. the Salvation which is common to "all men". 1   Tim.  iv,10) to that of spiritual power and causation, and   recognizing the intellectual element as both the social and   the mediatoreal phase of Christianity, and Lo, through the   continued presence of our Lord with his followers "to the   end of the world", the ground and surety of an uninterrupted   progress to that dread but glorious consummation,--in short   recognizing that element as being the witnessing of "the   water" (1 Jno. v.8);--such an Essay, I say, has been offered   by me to each of the weekly Philadelphia Journals claiming   to represent Quakerism, and declined by at least two of   them. Even if the other two shall do likewise I mean to look   for the sympathy of some of our fellow professors in   publishing it, and would like to include some of the Cope   family, if I have not already overdosed them with my   manuscripts and my manners. I must not, I suppose, ask thee   to write me, even on their behalf. If thou would only call   to see my sister M., I think I might regard it as a token   for good. I feel sure she could not have a more acceptable   visitor--at any rate not beyond her nearest kindred--Please   give my love to thine with thee, and believe me, very   sincerely, though too untruly (some hair-splitting or   nail-splitting is needed there) thy friend, Richd   Randolph

To R. Anna Cope
Germantown


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1865-04-11
Title: 1865 April 11, B, to Mother and sisters

B – 4/11

Dear Mother & sisters,
I think I shall            take to writing to you in a journal form, as I often have            little times when I can sit down for a few minutes & no            longer.  I recd thy letter Carry of the 9th wh. was very            nice & also the cuffs, wh. were also very nice, & I am very            much obliged to whoever did ‘em & that person was mother I            reckon & it was very good of her & they were just what I            wanted. & now if you can only send me a white skirt, I shall            be so [g---] for I can hardly get along without, as I find            the one I brot will hardly bear another washing.
On 4th            day eve. I took tea at Mart. Chestons & had such a nice            time.  Altho’ she is so feeble that she washardly able to sit up all the even, she insisted upon      inviting a few others to make it pleasant for me – & I thot      it was so kind in her. The party consisted of H Lytle (who      is such a nice & good person) Julia Valentine Dr Thomas H.      King & Jesse – & we had such a nice home-like time, & such      an elegant tea & Ice cream & all.  I thought it the nicest      visit I have paid, & then in the evening as it was rainy she      wd. insist upon sending us home in the carriage & she asked      me so kindly to come there any time when I felt like it,      that I felt quite gratified.  It rained so much the      afternoon I was to go out to Careys – that it was deferred      so I have not been yet, & I believe I have’nt done anything      in particular else, since [---] wrote last.  While I think      of it Caroline Ill ans. thy questions. There are 200 chil’n      in our sch. & 4 teachers wh. makes 1 to every 50.  Mine is      the least advanced class & consequently the least      interesting.  Ages, frm. abt, 7 yrs. to 15 or 16. & strange      to say the smallest chil’n in my sch are generally the best      scholars. The greater proportion are boys, about a third      girls. They are children of this place who have not hitherto      had the advantage of free schools.
End of first sitting.3rd day – 18th
I have laid aside my letter for two or      three days, – for we have all felt so sad since hearing the      dreadful news that I cld. not feel like writing abt.      ordinary things & there seemed little to say on the one      great subject – the presidents dreadful death, wh. seemed      dreadful enough to strike every one dumb with horror &      astonishment.  It seemed so near to us, & the more so      because the very day after wh. it occurred we had planned to      make a little excursion to Washington for the day having      been invited by one of Miss M’s frds. who often goes down.       So you can judge of our horror when a few min. before      setting out, this dreadful intelligence was brot. to us. The      feeling here against the seccessionists has been intense as      they have been heard to rejoice in the sts. at thedreadful news, & to have prophesied a few days since that   our rejoicings wld. be turned to sorrow.  The city was under   martial law for a day or two – but by the strict vigilance   of the authorities was kept quiet.  but they compelled every   secessionist as well as union on the principal business sts   to drape their stores in mourning & [if] the appearance it   presents is very solemn & sad.  I suppose it is the same in   Phila. – & everywhere.  It seems really a more horrible   thing than some we have shrunk frm. reading in books of   history.  People here seem to be sanguine about the new   administration – & the prospects of peace, but that does not   take away frm. the horrible fact that there can exist in our   midst such a wicked & fiendish spirit.
4th day morn — our   school has been dismissed to day on account of the   solemnities wh. are to be observed in the churches &   elsewhere
We also had a holliday on 2nd day & Jesse Tyson   very kindly took advantage of it to take us a very beautiful   ride to a lake abt. 7 miles frm. here wh. is situated among   hills & woods as beautiful as any Iever saw.  I had no idea there was anything of the kind so   near to the city.  It was delightful to get a sight of the   beautiful spring in the country.  The trees are just putting   out their first leaves, & look so lovely, & we cld. not but   enjoy it in spite of the mournful circumstances wh. have   been so much in our minds,  Jesse took us past his place,   where he wishes to erect his model house.  It is a very   beautiful situation indeed with views of the city & the bay   &c.
I suppose you (that is some of you) are in the midst   of yearly meeting now. but the sad newsmust have thrown a great damp over every thing.
We have   been spending two or three afternoons this week at the   meeting house sewing for the refugees.  The friends have a   sewing machine there, & meet every day this week to sew.  &   they will get a good deal accomplished no doubt.  Julia   Valentine seems to be very active & is a very nice frd.  I   [am] [you] [will] try to call on [Tamy] Miller when she is   in P again as she — Aunt has been so kind in asking me to   come out there &c.
Clementine Cope.
If you can find   out when [Tamy] will be in P I have no doubt she wld. bring   any package.  I want to go out this morning to get one or   two thins so I will bring my letter to a close.  Hope I   shall get one frm. you today but suppose you have felt   unlike writing as I have.  But for this, I shd. have written   to Tom this week, tell him.  Give my love to Cous. T. & all   enquiring frds. am glad to hear you miss me a little some   times.  Yours affec Clemmy
I miss you very much

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1867-08-26
Title: 1867 August 26, Newport, to father

Newport 8th. mo. 26th. 1867.

Dear father
I rec’d   thy letter 5th day morning.  Thy accounts quite make me wish   to see England some time although I dont know that that time   will ever come.  On 4th day we sailed round Canonicut, and   since Lilly says she has given thee a condensed account of   our trip, I will copy our log by way of variety.  The   officers were: Capt. Geo. F Merritt, 1st mate T.P. Cope Jr   2nd mate A Cope Jr; Seaman T.K. Longstreth, Cabin boy F.H.   Cope.  Steward M. C Collins.  Cook V. Hartshorne and 6   passengers, A Newhall, M Newhall, M Farnum, H Carter, M.   Collins, & E.S. Cope.
Log of the Canonicut Party – Yacht   “TCope [Deferred]”
(Rations limited)
Started from the   pier at 8 1/2, A.M., arrived at the lighthouse at 8.40.   there met M.C. Cope and party in a row boat, who wished us   joy,and desired us to report all new discoveries; soon after we   commenced telling fortunes.  2 m. of 9 o’clock saw a   porpoise on the starboard side.  9.22. off fort Adams,   weather, calm, thin canopy of clouds, at this moment it was   proposed to “put more steam on.”  Three persons forward of   the “Lobster Box.”  progress, “slow but awfully sure.”  10.   o’clock, interesting information concerning the compass, by   Capt. Merritt.  surf seen at Bever Tail, fears entertained   for the health of the party.  Some excitement caused by the   appearance of two fish, which produced restlessness on the   part of the cabin boy –  10.11. opposite the Dumplings.  11   o’clock opposite Castle Hill the game of quintettes played   with interest by the 1st mate, cook, and several of the   passengers; the steward seiged with headache – at this time   doubts were expressed by the captain as to the probability   of the winds changing before 6 P.M. weather still calm.  [8]   m after 11. met a sailing vessel commanded by captain Henry   Merritt, rowed by the capt. and sculled by Henry Merritt jr   who hailed us, and threw a small lobster into the boat one   of the passengers was badly bitten which caused great   excitement untill she was rescued from the jaws of the   carnivorous creature.  11 1/2 A.M. Slight windthe South and visible, stood off to welcome it.  Party   regaled themselves with rations. 12. M. South wind   continues.  candy handed.  Met a schooner and were saluted   by a dog on board.  Long swells, health good.  12.10.   conversation on the weather prohibited– a number of the   passengers retired to rest – Cabin boy reclining on a   passenger–  cook on the dinner basket–  1st mate absorbed in   a book.  12.45. Point Judith lighthouse in sight.  After   serious consideration it was decided to pursue our journey   on which account three cheers were given.  12.50. Passing   Bever Tail.  three more cheers – passengers happy – saluted   by the horn and a towel was waved to us, which compliment   was returned passengers waving handkerchiefs.  2. P.M.   Dinner – great dispute on the subject of ringing the   triangle.  2.45. from “Lobster Box” end–  dinner   accomplished satisfactorily leaving the voyagers in a   quiescent state of mind–  dinner consisted of 9 courses   closed with sour-drops–  opposite M. Williams’- Bay   comparatively speaking very rough!  Fast passing Wickford –   Slight excitement Fortunes being told again aft. The 1st   mate has just restored the cabin to order, after dinner.    Aft becoming very impudent.  Bow hair dressing.  1st matesweeping and thereby discomboberating all – 2.55. Patience   in sight.  sentiment in the bow, 3.12. Approaching the end   of Canonicut Greenwich off the larboard bow.  Patience and   Rocky Pt. ahead.  the breeze delightful, and all of the   party very comfortable, some reading, some working zephyr   work.  3.20. Rounding the north end of Canonicut.  Three   cheers given by all the party.  3.35. P.M. Rounding   Canonicut.  Newport in view – on our homeward trip – breeze   good.  some of the party wishing to land we are going to (we   did’nt) 3.38. Met the Providence steamboat- Needless anxiety   on the part of the passengers.  Now dashing gaily towards   Newport.  3.55 Proceeding fondly – just played games of   authors and consequences.  3 m. of 5.P.M. off the   Lighthouse. health good.  Fine breeze- Band tuning up for a   song before we reach the pier.  Arrived at the pier at   5.P.M.  On first day evening we took a walk to Tammany Hill.   we started after a 6 o’clock tea but were not able to get   there untill dark or dusk.  It is the first time I was ever   there.  We saw the lights at Point Judith, the Light Ship,   Bever Tail and the Break water.  Yesterday was splendidlyclear.  In the morning we took a short float, I cant call it   a sail there wasn’t any wind, after which we went bathing.    In the afternoon I made up a small sailing party consisting   of Alice Carter, Abby Newhall, Tom Longstreth and Alfred, we   went out to the Dumplings and landed, & afterwards came back   to take Caroline Mary her first sail.  She could’nt have had   a more pleasant evening it neither too cold nor too warm, &   there was a splendid breeze.  We went around Rose Island and   got back in good season.  though not strictly obeying her   mothers instructions about being home at half past 6.  This   morning we went bathing as usual and also engaged the boat,   Alfred preferring to go to Coddingtons Cove to bathing.    Thee will observe that I’ve been getting about as much good   out of boating as possible this season.  Since we arrived   Alf has become a staunch friend of Geo. Merritt’s and Hazen   of Geo. Barlow’s. Its quite remarkable how devoted Alf is,   he spends the big parts of his time at the reading room with   George.  This morning I got a new key fitted, formy valise, having lost the other since my arrival.  We were   not able to mail these letters in time to go by the [La---]   so they will have to take their chance by going via New   York.  There are 24 folks going to Philadelphia the night we   go, which will make a pretty effectual change in Mary   Williams’ boarders, and there will be no one left but Tom   Longstreth to do the honors of the occasion.  We are rather   puzzled as to what to do if we were left by the 7 o’clock   train from New York, since the 10 o’clock train has been   taken off the line.  We will have to run the risk, I   suppose, of getting the 8.40, Washington train, stopped at   Frankford.  Having run out of news and since mother is also   writing I will stop.
affecty thy son
T.P. Cope Jr.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Rachel Drinker
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865

Title: 1806 February 8 to Henry Cope, Westown, PA

Philada 2nd mo 8th [1806]

Dear Henry

I receivd   thy letter, and am Pleasd to hear that there is a day set   apart for letter writing as I hope we shall hear oftener   from you, as writing is next to seing and talking with you,   to tell you (for I include Frances) that I love you, and   long to see you, would be like a tale twice told,   

your Cousin H D wrote from New Castle the 5th of the   2d moth that he was just setting of and expected to be at   sea in 48 hours, was much pleasd with the Captain, they were   detaind 2 weeks by the Ice, He seemd to go of in pretty good   sperits, as he went with the approbation of his Friends, I   have the pleasure to inform the that he appeard to be in an   improving way, I hope he will be preferred and kept in the   road that leads to peace

I am glad to hear that the   is contented, and willing to stay and get all the   instruction the can, I hope thee will get through all the   branches so as to come home next Summerthe river is froze over and I saw a number of people on it   as I return[e]d from Meeting this morning

Arther has   not got into any Buiseness yet, & is Desir[ou]s of paying   you a viset If he can get a Horse.

your Father &   mother is well, Caroline & allfred very lively, mother is   well of for help—Cousin Lydia is with me still and Sends her   love to the and Francis as does [Catherine] except of a   large Portion From your loveing grandmother

Rachel   Drinker

mary’s Father and Mother & Brother have been   commited to jail on suspion of Murder how it will go with   them we can’t tell now I think I have told you all the news   good and badHenry Cope
Westown
give my love to Friend 
Sharpless

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Joe (Joseph Paul) Morris:  1879-1919
Recipient:  Francis Algernon Evans:  1878-1946
Date: 1911-06-29
Title: 1911 June 29, Dundale, to Alg

Dundale
June 29, 1911

Dear Alg,

Thee and   all the others know in part how I love you. I wish that my   love and the love of all your friends were strong enough to   be able and wise enough to know how, to come now and take   your burden and bear it for you. We are bearing it with   you.

But may He Whose Love is infinitely Strong and   who doesunderstand and who is so close to you, give to all of you   the assurance that He is indeed with you now, bearing it   with you and for you ever more than you can yourselves. May   He put his unfailing arms around you and give you His   Strength and His Comfort and His brave peace. And I know He   will.

Dear Ern, still he will be ever near to me as I   know he is to you all. May Christ always bring us nearer to   Himselfand so nearer to each other. Dear Alg, I can only send thee   and every member of thy family my truest love from my   heart.

Thy loving,
Joe.




----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Mary Stokes:  1825-1847
Recipient:  Elizabeth W. (Elizabeth Stokes Waln) Cope:  1780-1852
Date: 1839-03-06
Title: 1839 March 6, to Elizabeth W. Cope, Philadelphia

3d moth 6th 1839

My Dear aunt

I expect this   will be the last letter I shall write to thee this session   as the time is drawing near when we shall go home.  we are   now reviewing and it is not so hard as I expected it would   be  we have to be very industrious [about] our studies as   some of them are very hard particularly the history and I am   very much afraid I shall fail in that at examination as the   greater part of it I have not learned for I have not been in   that class, all the session.  Thomas Kite’s wife is here   spending a day or two and her daughter also.  I suppose thee   has heard of the little boy who has been so ill here he was   taken with the measles and that layed the foundation for the   consumption and after suffering for a long time he was taken   away at three o clock in the morning of the first of spring    we had no school on six or seventh day but we all went to   our school rooms and red our bibles and on seventh day   morning we were taken into see his corpse and he was buried on seventh day afternoon   his name was Nathan Comstock and he was an orphan he lived   in Lockport New York  he has a brother and sister here and   his sister is a lovely girl but I know very little about his   brother.  Benjamin Sharpless was here to thee funeral and he   asked me if I had ever seen him at Tommy Cope’s and I told   him no., but I have often heard of him.  I am looking for   uncle Samuel to come and see me as he has been away so long   and I think he might come to see me this session
Aunt   Lydia is not at all well she has a very bad cold and a good   deal of pain in that lump on her face and she keep her bed   the greater part of the day but she is rathe better at   present than she has been lately  I think she would of been   better if she had not of gone down to supper last night   through the cold entry.  I have some things to write for and   I do not think I shall have any more time to write to thee.    Cousin L sends her respects to all of you. but I send my   love to all be lieve me as ever thy affectionate   niece

Mary Stokes JrThomas P Cope 
For Elizabeth W Cope
No 272 Spruce St 
Philadelphia

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1867-07-28
Title: 1867 July 28, Laurel House, to Father

Laurel House
7th mo. 28th. 1867.

Dear Father
Lilly and Chelly having been keeping up such an active correspondence by the last two steamers, I thought I would reserve my efforts untill they had got through. 
We received a letter from uncle Tom inclosing a letter from thee informing us of the loss of thy masticators, it      would have been remarkably unfortunate if thee had not had      an extra set with thee.  I hope by this time thee is      enjoying thyself on terra firma, but since the difference of      time between where thee is and where we are is so great, we      find it hard to guess what thee is about.  We received letters from home last night, dated the 25th., saying they   were all well and preparing to leave for Newport on 5th day.   Mother had also received a letter from thee mailed at   Halifax
On last 6th day we rode to Stony Clove, an   entirely new place to me, about 10 miles distant.  The road   is quite rough, and runs between two mountains, one of which   rises almost perpendicularly about 1000 ft, as near as we   could judge, and on each side there are large rocks under   which we found ice: they say the sun never gets there and   the ice under the rocks never melts during the summer.  On   approaching this place the air becomes perceptably cooler   and on leaving it becomes warm again.  We took dinner at a   little farm house and although it was plain weenjoyed it very much.  After dinner we had to leave right   away for home.  Going back we had a splendid view of those   distant mountains you see on your way to the Plauterkill   Clove.
Yesterday morning we, that is Tom Stokes, Harry,   some other gentlemen and myself, walked down to Bastion   Falls to take a bath, thee remembers what a fine basin there   is at the foot of the falls, well it was there we went in;   the water was pretty cool on first going in but after we had   been in a little while, and had kicked around a good bit we   got quite warm and all in a glow.  We went under the fall   where it hit the rocks for a second time, but even there the   water stung like hail-stones, and I preferredthe pool to getting such a warming as that.  In the      afternoon we walked over to the Mountain House to see the      view, on starting it was beautifully clear but when we had      gone about half way, two clouds, very considerately, came      rolling down upon us, one from North and one from South      mountain, and by the time we got to the precipice both the      view and ourselves were completely mistified; we accordingly      went into the House and got weighed, and since thee will not      object to hearing how much some of the members of thy      immediate family weigh, I will give thee part of the      table:
R.R.C.  125 lbs.   E.S.C.  98 lbs.   T.P.C.  90      lbs.     Rachel has gained 7 lbs. since last sum- mer, and its becoming quite dreadful; I'm afraid, if she      goes on gaining, we will be obliged to have her put up in a      barrel and roll her home from Newport.  Tom Stokes, Ellie,      Madjie, and Walter are going home tomorrow morning: the rest      of us expect to leave here fourth day and go to Albany, we      will stay there that night, and go to Boston the next day;      leaving Boston 6th. day afternoon we will arrive at Newport      in time for tea.  I suppose mother has told thee that she      succeeded in engaging both the Georges during our stay      there.  The weather here has been very warm and showery; to      day it is very pleasant but it has been so very showery we      were afraid to try going to walk. Aunt Lizzie received two letters from the Adirondacks to      day one from cousin Clemmy and one from aunt Annie, giving      an account of a trip which they had taken to lake Placid by      the way of John Brown's grave; aunt Annie said the grave was      very plain, there was a tombstone with some engraving on it      and on a boulder nearby was the plain inscription "John      Brown - 1859."  She also said cousin Clemmy was a good deal      stronger and was able to bear fatigue as well as the rest of      them  They were both very much surprised to hear of thy      sudden leaving for England.  Lilly and Chelly send their      love.  We are all well and have had a most splendid time      considering that our "pa" is on the other side of the Atlantic and now having given thee   all the news I can remember I will   stop.
affectionately
thy son Thos P. Cope Jr


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Rachel Drinker
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1806-06-19
Title: 1806 June 19 to Henry and Francis, Weston

6th mo 19th 1806.
Dear Henry & Francis
I have been to   meeting, cald at your house, after it broke up your dear   mother handed me a letter from Francis,  she was so kind as   to send me Henrys last letter, where I was affection[ate]ly   rememberd and expressing a desire that I should not forget   you no be asurd I never Shall while I retain my sences, I   have Had a great deal of trouble since I saw you  I have   seen a dear loving Daughter go before me,.  to enjoy the   fruits of a well Spent life, I Continue with poor Uncle and   Johnny, thay request me not to leave them, we have had   pleasent accounts of the Conduct of of your & Cousins, and   are in dayly expectation of seeing them, poor lads they will   be much affected when thay come, they will not be likely to   hear of the chang that has taken place since they left us   till they arive.  I want very much to see you, I hope you   will come and pay us a visit, I am still Favoured with   Health, and that you may enjoy that Blessing is the Desire   of your affectinate Grandmother
Rachel DrinkerDear Cousins

Our dear Grandmother is Kind enough to   permit me to add a few lines to her letter–  I wish it was   in my power to communicate to you something that would   afford pleasure.  But alas!  I have lived to see the   melancholy period that death has seperated from me one of   the best of mothers, whose affection I believe I possessed;   and that I loved her with sincere affection, affords me no   small share of consolation–  She suffered much during her   illness, but such was her Christian fortitude that she never   discovered the least impatience, and constantly maintained   her usual cheerful serenity of mind, which was her   characteristic through a life of trials.  It was painful to   see her suffer so much bodily pain, but infinitly more so to   see her breath her last, a[l]though she suffered not the   pangs of death, but passed from this terrestrial world to   one where peace, happiness and pleasure reign triumphantly;   and where she now enjoys the blissful harvest of a spotless   and well spent life–  Such has been the immutable decree of   heaven to deprive me of an affectionate Mother and you an   affectionate Aunt– We are still blest with having our dear   Grandmother to cheer us–  She enjoysher usual health, which I hope she may enjoy for years to   come–
The last letter we received from Arthur states that   he and Cousin Henry are both well, and expect to leave the   West Indies very shortly; we of course expect them   daily–
Uncle is at present in good health, and I hope   will long continue so; here I must close this short epistle   and hope that I will see you before long –  I remain your   affectionate
cousin
John D Thomas6 mo. 19th 1806
Henry Cope
Weston6th mo 19th 1806.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  John D.  Thomas
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1806-06-19
Title: 1806 June 19 to Henry and Francis, Weston

6th mo 19th 1806.
Dear Henry & Francis
I have been to   meeting, cald at your house, after it broke up your dear   mother handed me a letter from Francis,  she was so kind as   to send me Henrys last letter, where I was affection[ate]ly   rememberd and expressing a desire that I should not forget   you no be asurd I never Shall while I retain my sences, I   have Had a great deal of trouble since I saw you  I have   seen a dear loving Daughter go before me,.  to enjoy the   fruits of a well Spent life, I Continue with poor Uncle and   Johnny, thay request me not to leave them, we have had   pleasent accounts of the Conduct of of your & Cousins, and   are in dayly expectation of seeing them, poor lads they will   be much affected when thay come, they will not be likely to   hear of the chang that has taken place since they left us   till they arive.  I want very much to see you, I hope you   will come and pay us a visit, I am still Favoured with   Health, and that you may enjoy that Blessing is the Desire   of your affectinate Grandmother
Rachel DrinkerDear Cousins

Our dear Grandmother is Kind enough to   permit me to add a few lines to her letter–  I wish it was   in my power to communicate to you something that would   afford pleasure.  But alas!  I have lived to see the   melancholy period that death has seperated from me one of   the best of mothers, whose affection I believe I possessed;   and that I loved her with sincere affection, affords me no   small share of consolation–  She suffered much during her   illness, but such was her Christian fortitude that she never   discovered the least impatience, and constantly maintained   her usual cheerful serenity of mind, which was her   characteristic through a life of trials.  It was painful to   see her suffer so much bodily pain, but infinitly more so to   see her breath her last, a[l]though she suffered not the   pangs of death, but passed from this terrestrial world to   one where peace, happiness and pleasure reign triumphantly;   and where she now enjoys the blissful harvest of a spotless   and well spent life–  Such has been the immutable decree of   heaven to deprive me of an affectionate Mother and you an   affectionate Aunt– We are still blest with having our dear   Grandmother to cheer us–  She enjoysher usual health, which I hope she may enjoy for years to   come–
The last letter we received from Arthur states that   he and Cousin Henry are both well, and expect to leave the   West Indies very shortly; we of course expect them   daily–
Uncle is at present in good health, and I hope   will long continue so; here I must close this short epistle   and hope that I will see you before long –  I remain your   affectionate
cousin
John D Thomas6 mo. 19th 1806
Henry Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Joe (Joseph Paul) Morris:  1879-1919
Recipient:  Francis Algernon Evans:  1878-1946
Date: 1911-10-28
Title: 1911 October 28, Str. “Dalmatia”, to Alg

Str. “Dalmatia”, Oct. 28, 1911.

Dear Alg,

I   meant or wanted to write to thee sooner, but thought I would   wait until we were really touching Palestine. I have my map   at hand in the case which thee presented me, and I think it   is going to be fine. So far nothing is blocking our plans –   neithercholera nor fanaticism aroused by war – and we are due at   Beirut tomorrow to go on to Damascus and take a two or three   weeks’ trip across country to Hermon, Galilee, and Samaria,   and so down to Jerusalem. To-day we have been looking, from   our ship, up at nothing less than Mount Carmel. Haifa as   thee knows is built at its foot and is of course very   picturesque. Part of the mountain’s sides is bare and brown,   rather, but part is covered with small trees, carob and oak,   I believe, which isa very pretty sight. Six or seven miles up the coast we can   see Acre with all its crusading associations. And as we have   been thinking of some of the associations of Mount Carmel it   is of course intensely interesting. I have a fine pair of   number eight binoculars which add to our enjoyment   greatly.

Nat Groton and I get along very well. He is   very patient with me; my awkwardness and unnecessary anxiety   in giving fees must be a great source of trial tohim, but he bears it well. With all these fellows coming   after you and towards you and around you for “bakshish” all   the time, it is very trying sometimes. Yesterday I had my   first – and I hope my last, as it is not pleasant –   experience of being cursed up and down and out and out by   one of the fellows who brought us out again to the Steamer   from Jaffa, for giving too little bakshish.

We went   ashore forpart of the day yesterday at Jaffa, or Joppa, which was   our first contact with Palestine. It was not calculated to   be sentimental. The disembarking is not easy, for there is   no harbor, and the rowboats are hard to get into from the   steamer. As I stepped down, the boat happened to sink in the   trough of a wave and I had the queer feeling of stepping   down into space.We were rowed in in a pelting rain, too, which made the   little streets of Joppa literally inches deep with – not   mud, but filth. The old tomb of Tabitha was only discovered   recently, but is old. The “house of Simon the tanner” may   well have been in a different place from the one which is   shown you. But after you think it over, these things make no   difference. It is Joppa. And the tanner’s house was just the   sort of one which is shown, and hisbusiness was a tannery, I suppose to make leather bottles   for water and wine. His house no doubt opened out on unclean   courts, and he was contaminated in Jewish eyes by touching   dead animals, swine at that. So where was a better place   than such a little house, with its unclean factory in the   midst and its flat roof looking out to sea and its host none   the less hospitable for any of these things, for Peter to be   prepared for his wonderful vision? And in this needy, little   town Tabitha did live. And thesame intensely interesting, picturesque life goes on its   crooked, little streets and alleys to-day. We saw a man   sitting, grinding meal between an upper and a lower   mill-stone, small ones, the upper of which he turned by   hand. We squeezed by long strings of camels, and walked   through swarms of turbaned Arabs. There are lots of other   interesting things in Joppa which stay with you in spite of   the filth through which  you wade, and the variegated odors   which assail your nostrils, but I must stop now. Please give   my love to thy mother, and Anna, and Harold, and my kind   remembrances to Miss Richardson, and if I may still trouble   thee, much love to Jac and Ed, and thyself

from Joe.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Annette Cope:  1843-1916
Date: 1865-04-25
Title: 1865 April 25, Baltimore, to Net

Baltimore 4.25.

Dear Net,
I have just got thy   letter of the 1st to the 19th inclusive, (where has it been   so long?)  Its very well I did’nt go on with the great scold   I began yesterday — I thot, I wld defer it one day longer &   see – Why I dont believe you know how long you’ve been   neglecting me, & thee must remember while thee’s   journalizing that thy writing every day is’nt my getting   it,.  However it was very interesting if not very late news.   Thee does’nt say a word about having got either of my last   letters,  I hope the one containing my elaborate sketch of   the Environs of the city & my room as a centre, did not get   lost, as it wld. have been a waste of artistic   effort.
The presidents death has indeed made mourning in   our land.  The ways of Providence are very inscrutable.  I   told you in my last letter of the feeling produced here, so   I will notrevert to it..  The day of the funeral procession here was   very solemn.  We dismissed our school, & went by particular   invitation to where we cld. have an excellent view of the   whole as it passed, at the store of an old gentleman in   market st, where we had a room to ourselves & refreshments   provided wh. seemed rather singular but is his custom.  It   was the most touching & mournful procession I ever saw    Perhaps you saw it in Phila.  It will take a long time to   forget the grief & horror of this sad event,– but work has   to be done & yesterday our sch. began [afresh] after the   interruptions of the week before, & while sch. lasts we are   forced to forget every thing but the work before us.  It is   what you might call intense work. & wld. be wearing [--]   [----] [----] if incessant.  Thy description of getting   home, & the nice clean room & all most made me home-sick.  I   miss great many of the little home luxuries and cleannesses   here,– but cannot expect to have them in boarding.  We dont   get any good Mrs [Mcaff--] [----] [butter] &c — excepting   when we get invited out to our rich frds.
I was perfectly   charmed with my visit at Carey’s last 6th day night.  Their   place is perfectly magnificent & the house keeping   altogether princely compared to this.  I went out in the   afternoon & returned next morning.  Their house situated on   the tip top of a [very] hill seems like something up in the   air, & the view splendidSusan Carey has gone to Phil. & expects to return next 7 or   2 day.  She very kindly offered to bring anything for me —   said she wld. have room for any sized bundle, so that I   might get my silk skt.  But it is so late in the season that   I think I can do without it, & I shd. not like to ask her to   bring so large a thing.  I wld. like tho’ to have my old   blk. silk body & I wish thee wld send me a little brown   grenadine bag of horse hair in the right hand corner of my   upper beaureau drawer.  These things however are not very   important, & you need not send them if inconvenient.+    [+Perhaps you can send them by T Miller instead.]  S Carey   stays at Anthony Kimbers cor. 13. & Arch.  I yesterday recd   the skt. sent by Alford Coale for wh. I am much obliged.    Mary Pennyman called yesterday & was very pleasantLizzie Hopkins of the house where Lizzie Edge, Jenny Harris   &c staid, called to see me also, & some Matthews wh. lives   in the country said Lizzie E had written to her that I was   here & that she intended to invite me out to her place in   the country, a very pleasant one I understand.  A gentleman   called here night before last — Miller M Kim whom you have   perhaps heard of — one of the Freedmens board in Phila. &   [----] me a message frm. Cous. Frank whom he had seen the   day before.  Tho’ a stranger he seemed quite like somebody   from home.  To night I am going with H Lytle to the frds.   bible class, meeting at Dr. Thomas’ — it is attended by   frds. mostly, altho’ Ellen Carey who is an episcopalean &   one or two others attend.  They say it is very interesting,   tho’ I have’nt been before.  A few days ago I went to hear   Thomas Beecher a (brother of H Wards) speak, but was   disappointed, as it was nothing very interesting.     I cld.   not make out by thy journal exactly when your visit to Aunt   C’s began or ended, but am glad you had a nice time.  Give   my love to them & tell them I hope they’ll ans. my note.    Love also to Cous. F & M.  You were quite enterprising to   walk up to Athensville.  I am going to try & write to Tom

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1863-08-30
Title: 1863 August 30, Catskill, to My dear Mother

1863
Catskill Aug. 30th 
1st day eve

My dear   Mother

I had to leave off writing very suddenly last   time, as thee must have seen by the letter having no   direction.  We got to writing in bed at West Point as we   woke up early, & were not going to take breakfast till 8   1/2; but we had to go at 9 1/2, & as we were very pokey we   did not get down to breakfast till 9 o’clock-hence my great   hurry.  We left West P. in the boat, the rest of the way up   the Hudson was not however nearly so interesting, we soon   got out of the Highlands & then it seemed very tame.  This   is the most magnificent place we were ever, or are likely   ever, to be in; The view from the front of the house is very   extencive & beautifulfrom one place we can see the top of Mount Washington with   the opera glass.  The house is quite a large one tho’ mostly   old fashioned except the parlor wh. is up stairs, & has I   think most probably been altered the passages are the most   intricate I ever was in, & sometimes I feel completely lost.   We are on the very top of the mountain with dreadful   prespicise’s all around us, & it is the most dreadful place   to get up to that ever was, thee knows its a twelve miles   drive up the mountain from the landing, & how long does thee   ’spose we were getting up? 5 1/2 hours- just think of it the   horses walked nearly all the way, & stoped ever few   minut[e]s to rest; after we got fairly to the foot of the   mountain within about three miles from the house father &   Tom got out to walk, “& the consequence was” they got here   an hour & a quarter before us.the last part of the way poor Rach, was dreadfully sick, the   boat & stage together were too much for her, & as soon as we   got there I helped her get right to bed, she slept pretty   well however after she once did get to sleep tho’ she   suffered dreadfully poor child, thee knows her headaches are   so hard to bear, but don’t worry she’s quite well to day.    This morning they had service in the parlor to wh. Cous.   Clem, Chell & I went with papa’s leave. the sermon was   pretty good & I must confess I think it much better that   poking round all 1st day & going no where, if you can’t go   to meeting go to church – “thems my sentiments.”  After   service we all went out to take a ramble & after a good deal   of hunting round for paths & scrambling up them when found,   we at last arrivedat the top of South Mountain It was a beautiful walk   although it seemed to scare poor aunt Annie terribly to see   us so near the edge of these awful prespicise’s wh. surround   us every where; the rocks covered with ferns, mosses,   litgens are really beautiful.  We passed through what they   call “[Pudding]–stone Hall” a large cleft in the rocks   formed of pudding–stone & also through the lemon-squeezers   another crevise.  We are altogether enjoying ourselves very   much I think & propose staying here till 3rd day afternoon   when we will probably leave for Saratog[a], & thence to Lake   George.  at least those are present prospects but as we have   changed our plans several times to day I wont say certainly,   if we p[u]rsue the plan now proposed wewill stop at Belloes Falls on our way to Boston & spend   next 1st day at Nahant if we can.  We have rather a funny   time altogether about our meals & sleeping apartments here   things are not extremely clean, & it is so crowded we have   to come to the second table & therefore have to take our   breakfast at ten & dinner at four & now about 6 the supper   bell has rung, but I ‘spose we’ll come second class there   to.  We are quite glad of our thick dresses Mother, & have   worn nothing else hardly since we left home.  its right cold   to night, & we have to wear shawls & things all the time to   keep warm.  It is getting almost to dark for me towrite any more dear Mother so I think the[e] must let me   close.  I hope we shall hear from home tomorrow we want to   hear very much how you all are.  I shall try to write soon   again if we get to a stopping place  we have been going so   steadily that there has been hardly any time to do any   thing, but see the sights  Please excuse all defects – &   with love to all I am
ever thy loving
daughter Lily

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872

Title: 1865 May 3, Baltimore, to Mother and Sisters

1865
Baltimore 5/3
Dear Mother and sisters,
I am very glad to find yr. letter to day that you are at least conscious of your deficiencies wh. have been very apparent to me lately.  I did not write at my usual time this week, for I was determined to stand upon my dignity & not write until I hear from you.  The long-looked-for- howver camr this morn. & the mention of M Wilsons name, caused in a measure my forgiveness, as I well know what her name means.  &, Nat I fully sympat with thy sentiment on the disgusting nature of clothing.  I have to stick up in my room here every spare minute [---] tho' I thout I was pretty much ready for spring yetI have to keep up a [----] all the time.  &c.  The prices of things are perfectly tremendous - no decent bonnet ribbon to be got under $1.  +$1.50 pr. yard.  In consequence of wh. I am broke.  Can't you send me a V or an X in next letter?  I find it necessary to get several things [----] she's "cream of Baltimore society."  is so [highly?] dressy that its very troublesome.  [----] The last few days we have had an inpouring of invitations.  No less than three this afternoon.  1st to go out to Susan Matthews' a friend who lives a few miles in the country & who invites us to come out in the [Carr?] to take tea tomorrow 2nd - to another frds' by the name of [Janney?] - 3rd to Cous L. Jeffries.  4th - to Judge Bonds - & 5thly to a [?] of Jesse's [ellegant?] dinner parties.  At least we have reason to think that there is onevery near at hand.  As usual they all come together.  Now if I only had my silk [?] it would come in [?].  but by the time I cld. get it even if I sent it by express the [sprees?] I fear wld. be over.  I had no idea when I [came?] of doing so much wishing.  Jesse has been exceedingly polite taking us riding, ice-creaming &c.  wh. is a part of the cream of society I enjoy our entertainment at home being rather poor sometimes we appreciate outside treats.
Last 7th day afternoon I took a very pleasant excursion with the Kings (Francis his two dhrs. & his two brothers, eligible young bachelors?) out on the rail road 6 or 7 miles where we had a very nice afternoon pic-nic.  They told me abt. Phila.  Mary said she was [?] pleased with them Carrie & with S Walker.  She's a very nice girl in deed.  Galway & M. Cheston called in their carriage & took me to ride & [she?] [?]  totea with them.  wh. I thought was very kind.  I have no tell Cous M that her Aunt thinks she is improving.  Alice Murdock called to see me.  The people here are the greatest callers.  & make the most immense calls.  I ever heard of.  We are often kept in the whole afternoon.  wh. accts. for my having to send you such [?] I meant to have written Cous Mary & to Tom this week but have not the time.  Mother thee need not fear that I shall injure myself with teaching as it does not tire me so much as at first.  I shall [enjoy?] the rest of home.  I believe.  Must stop.  Give my love to Father Edgar You & all enquiring frds.  Yours affec[?] Clemmy.
