Title: 1732 February 6, Caln in Chester County in Pensilvania, to Uncles Thomas & Joshua Pim

Caln in Chester County in Pensilvania
the 6th. of ye.   2nd. month 1732

Dear Uncles
Thomas & Joshua Pim   /

I wrote to my Bror. John &c the 17th. of last mo:   aqt.ing them of a great alteration in my ffamily, wch.   letter I supose went in a ship just then ready to sail to   Ireland and now I acquaint you that it hath pleased Divine   Providence to remove my wife from me by Death,  She was   taken Ill of (that Dreadfull distemper) the smallpox about   the 4th. of last moth: & departed in the night between the   14th. & 15th. of ye. same being Sorely afflicted wth. the   distemper, but verry sencible all the time & I hope made   good use of sd. time, often praying & praising God, & tho:   in the time of her health she did not seem as fully as I   cou’d a wisht to Joyn wth. ffrds.  (tho she- went to no   other worship that I know off since we came here but   severall times to ffriends meetings) yet in her Illness she   was desirous of the company of sollid ffrds & severall of   such did visit her & I think are generally in good hopes   that she Dyed in Peace & I believe few who knew her here   were streangers to her former circumstance for my part I did   not endeavour to conceall the truth from Honest ffriends,   and before I pesumed to appoint her buriall I requested   leave of ffriends to Bury her in their ground, which was soe   readily granted that they told me they thought it needless   to ask it, phaps you may desire to know wt. I recd of the   debt due to me I cannot say yt. I recd. none tho: (I thought   more was due,) for Just at last, she desired it might be   forgot or forgiven wch. I think implyed some acknowledgment    I think for above a year past she grew the most sollid &   sober yt. I have known her at all – & I cannot but admire   how much her loss is lamented in this neighbourhood, for she   was a verry oblieging neighbour & skillfull in many   things

I mentioned to my Bror. &c [---] [---] of the   Illness of my youngest Child, we thought it was dying the   next day after its mothers death, yet it continued for   fifteen days longer for the most pt. in great extremity &   then Died, wch. long Illness I believe helped to wean me   from it, soe that its Death did not affect me soe much as I   believe it wd. if it had a died soon, for it was a verry   pleasant Child, it was 7 months old when it fell   sick

I mentioned in a former letter to my Brother the   Death of my servant Jo: Gavin who was the first of my   ffamily who was taken Ill, & Died about a week or 6 days   before the next began my ffamily then consisted of 12 psons   (i:e: before this sickness) whereof 7 was to have it, & of   the 7: 3 is dead, wch. we may conclude was a great stroake,   tho: I may tell you that it does not yet seem soe hard for   me to bear as wt. I formerly bore, but the Death of my poor   wife seemd a greater exercise than I expected it wd. a been,   however I still endeavour to be patient & content wth. what   Providence permits to be my lot in this troublsom   world

I am through [meny] greatly favoured wth.   Health & my five Children are now pitty well tho: my Son   Thos. has had a hard time & a narrow escape with his life   thro: the smallpox

I have been verry well furnisht   with good neighbours during this trouble pticularly Thos.   M.cChuns wife (being a nurse) did not see her own house for   two weeks of the time of my poor Babes Illness,  I have this   comfort that my poor Children seems verry to’rdly, & my Dtr.   Sarah considering her age verry pitty as to her knowledge in   the way of Houskeeping, & on her and my maid Mary Turner.  I   think that pt. must pitty much depend at [pesant]

now   Dear Uncles I shall use some further freedom wth. you, this   Cheange in my ffamily ocasions many thoughts in my mind, one   whereof is to this purpose that since the cause of my   leaving you, my ffriends, & my native Country, is now   remov’d, why shou’d not I return there again, least I shou’d   be taken from my Children & they left more destitute a mong   streangers, but in answer to that, can I think that I should   be brought all the way to this remote pt. of the world for   no other end than to bury my wife, this Country I find more   agreeable to my Health (else it is wth. working harder) this   Country also is governed by more agreeable Laws than that   here are plenty of good ffriends (tho: not my near   Relations) who I believe wd. take care of my Children were I   taken from them, & phaps I may have opptunity to [---] be of   more servis here than there, & thu---] reasoni--] concerning   wch. I desire your sollid Consideration & answer as [---] as   PossibleHowever if you please to Inform me how the woolen trade is   now in Ireland & whether, I am freed from that holding wch.   I was liable to, I am as I mentioned to you before pitty   much Involvd. in Debt & do find it hard to pay Debts wth.   this way of living. corn being low & money scearce, but do   think my self now more at liberty than before to consider of   some other way of making my life Easier, but not by any   alteration soe suddenly as [y.] year

I desire a   pticular account of your [---] familys & my Cousin Wm.   Glaister & of our ffamily in Generall & of ffrds &   neighbours where any alteration has happen’d since my   leaving you,

Soe wth. Dear Love to you all I Conclude   your Loving nephew & affectionate ffriend

Wm   Pim

P:S: the Smallpox continues to spead over this   Country this being the 3d. time of its being here since   settled by the English, it mises but few ffamilyes, & takes   off many heads of familyes especially men in their prime,   here are many widdows now in this County  I am in   expectation of Ja: Nicholson in a little time [p] whom I   expect an act. from Irland & if he dont bring me a servant   or servants I shall be in great want for I am soe now, I   hired. an Indifferant hand lately at Husbandry & it Cost me   36s for 4 weeks (& diat) this has povd. a hard winter &   Spring [fother] is now verry scearce wth. many people but   mine holds out, tho: I lost one cow, yesterday & the night   before here fell a great Snow wch. seems streange to the   people,

W.P—

my Love is to my Dear Brother   John
who I desire may se this –
To   Joshua Pim   In Mountrath   Queens County   Ireland

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Sarah B. Corbit
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope:  1794-1863
Date: 1840-03-14
Title: 1840, March 14, Paris, to Rachel R. Cope, Philadelphia

Paris 3rd Month 14th 1840
My Dear Cousin
I suppose you   have through the medium of letters to some of our family   heard of us and our safe arrival in Europe, but in   compliance with thy request and my promise which has not   been forgotten, I thought (altho at a late period) a breif   sketch of our [pastimes] in our new location would be   acceptable hoping that you retain a feeling of interest in   our welfare.  We arrived in London after a short and   altogather pleasant voyage passed ten day’s there was   buisily engaged in visiting the many objects very   interesting to strangers, the Tower, Westminster Abbey, St   Paul’s, House of Lords, and various other places, We then   left; after a travel of four days thro an interesting   country we arrived at Paris, during which time we were all   favoured with health, and our children were very good   scarcely uttering a word of complaint of fatigue or any   thing else, this thee may well suppose enhanced our   pleasure, or at least diminished our difficulties, When we   arrived in Paris, we took posession of apartments engaged   for our reception in a French family who speak English,  the   family consists of this and five American families, who form   a pleasant domestic circle, they are all plainly disposed   people, some very interesting a Doctor Lowell with his wife   and daughter who have visited most of the countries of   Europe, Egypt, Palestine, are with us, English is spoken at   our table, this altho very pleasant retards our progress in   the acquisition of the french language,
We are situated   in Rue de Rivoli opposite theTuileries the garden annexed to the palace, the residence of   the royal family, our location is very pleasant, excepting   that we are in the fourth story of the house (this in   America would not be considered respectable) not so in Paris   the population is so great; that highly respectable and even   wealthy families occupy apartments, consisting of several   rooms on a level, so that a house (of course large) will   accommodate many families, a very small proportion of   residents occupying a house as we do in America, this I felt   to be a great abridgment of my domestic comfort
My   ignorance of the language and the uncertainty of our   continuance induces us to board, I do not wish to encumber   myself with domestic cares, for the management of a family   in Paris is attended by much care, for one who would not   choose to leave every thing to the regulation of servants,    There are several hundred Americans in Paris who form a   pleasant society, it is customary here for those who keep   house to set apart one evening in the week for the reception   of their freinds, who receive an invitation to visit them on   that evening whenever inclination dictates, this promotes   great sociability among those who meet, the simplicity of   the entertainment is to be admired, consisting generally of   a cup of tea and cake only, very seldom serving any other   refreshment, in other respects not so simple, as a great   regard is paid to personal appearance, Dress, Dress, seems   to engross their minds to the exclusion of other and better   considerations,
Our two daughters are at a school of high   repute and we think deservedly so, they are improving in   their studies,We have visited several churches, Catholic and protestant    This we feel to be a very great privation, to have no place   of worship to resort to in accordance with our own views   where we could commune with our own hearts and be still, but   we feel the necessity of recurring to the dictates of that   inward guide, which if obey’d will lead out of all error,    We have visited a great many of the places of interest to   strangers, there are many galleries of paintings very fine,   there is at this time an annual exhibition at the Louvre, of   new pieces, some private collections also
I have in my   silent musing’s in immagination revisited most of your   dwellings,  Dear Aunts Ruth and Margery very frequently   present themselves before me, when we left home they both   seemed feeble, I hope their lives may be prolonged to the   comfort of their children by whom they are surrounded, but   it seemed to me [that] the sun of their day was near   [setting] in a tranquil evening, if My Dear Cousin this   excites sufficient interest in thy breast to induce a reply,   information of them as well as many other members of our   family would be grateful to us who are situated so far from   many they still hold dear, please remember us affectionately   to them All,  Richard and Ruth, Caleb and Martha, Samuel   Henry, and thy children from thy attached Cousin
Sarah B   Corbit
Henry’s partners will inform how to forward   letters to us, if you wish to read our letters to our   family.  Mother who resides in Arch St above Ninth will   willingly show them to you
Poland

Henry Cope
Philadelphia.
For Rachel R. Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Sibylla T. Morris:  b. 1826
Recipient:  Annette Cope:  1843-1916
Date: 1907-11-20
Title: 1911 November 20, Bridgewater Cottage, Hampton, Va, to My very dear friends

Bridgewater Cottage
Hampton – Va: –
Nov: 20th 1907   –

My very dear friends —

We have just finished   reading in the Montrose papers, which my daughter Annie   Sayne brought down to me this p.m. – the account of the   Dedication of dear Clemmie’s donation to all the people of   old Susq: Co: & under its inspiration I feel that I must   immediately x x x x –––––––––1908 Jan. 4th –

— To prove that my dear friends have   not been entirely forgotten, – I have the audacity to   continue this letter – begun so long ago as almost to be   forgotten unless it be for this purpose! –  An interruption   occurred, during which time Minnie told me that she was   writing or had written to you, & when I asked where she wd.   address it, she said "Oh, in c/o Misses Biddle – they are in   Montrose". —  I demurred, but neither of us knew theGermantown address & altho’ I said "No. 1. Walnut St."   always held a clue – & had for nearly 100 yrs. past, – but   she laughed, – said that date was obsolete, – & now I doubt   if you ever did get her letter! –  I wish I cd. see you, & I   think our tongues wd. travel fast, –  Writing has become   rather irksome to me, – particularly with pen & ink as my   fingers have very much stiffened in my old age – so I   generally write with a pencil(when I think my frds. will not   object,) & I do not write much, except to my two sons, – who   are in R.R.d business at Sydney,– Nova Scotia. —

— We   have had such a hard summer,– partly owing to the delusions   these conceited Virginians had,– that "all the world & his   wife" wd. almost break their necks to get here to see their   wonderful state & its historic surroundings – then their   disappointments & losses were not cheerful or conducive to   cheery letter writing, & I hate to write doleful letters. —If it were not so pathetic,– it wd. be very amusing to see   the downfall of the hopes they all had of making such   enormous fortunes.–  Hundreds & thousands of dollars have   been lost, for the whole thing was a complete fizzle & not   being completed until away into October, & therefore but   little attendance,– those who did come disparaging it, & the   day after the gates were closed, it was put right into the   hands of a receiver!! –  Virginia has not had such a   staggering blow since Appomattox! –

— We have seen   very little ofMiss Walcott altho we attend the same church, but she lives   at the farther side of our town & the trip involves a   trolley ride- a ferry across Hapton Creek & a walk to each   end of the line.-
I am so sorry to hear of Carrie’s   increased deafness, - & descouraged too.- for I have grown   very deaf myself. & when she had all the medical faculty of   Europe to consult, & they did not cure her, - it is not   worth while for me to try. - Is it hereditary with her?- I   don’t remember either of your parents beingafflicted in that way. –  The strongest point in my memory   about them – is your father’s good sound "orthodox" dignity   – always so cheerily smoothed over, by your Mother’s   beautiful almost angelic smile which brightened almost   everybody & everything around them. –  I don’t wonder he   went to bed, when she was taken from him, & could never be   persuaded to rise again. –  I must close this now for my   messenger to take to the post office. –

— How I do   wish you would come to see us.  I hardly know any one who   would be more welcome. –  Now, think it over & see if you   can’t come,– particularly if a cold wave strikes Germantown.   —

Good bye – in which both my girls join, – don’t   ever doubt me, but believe me always your loving &   affectionate friend
Sibylla T. Morris.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Taber:  1822-1887
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1841-04
Title: 1841 April, to Frank, Philada.

Dear Frank
Somewhere in the Month of April, AD      1841

If you are in want of a mystery profound enough      to merit the attention and task the scrutiny of your      powerful mind - endeavor to ascertain if you can what whim      has led me to take this mammoth sheet for my letter instead      of confining myself as heretofore to the narrower limits of      a [Quarto]  It has puzzled me – I thought first of greatness      in the Abstract – how greatness Sympathises with greatness –      How you cant get a Barrel of praties in a Bushel Basket –      and wondered if that was the reason – Some I reasoned Are      born to greatness – some achieve greatness and some have      greatness thrust upon them – and I have come to that      conclusion that struggle against it as I may in spite of all      I may do – greatness is my destiny. ------

“Tantaeni      animis celestibus irae!!” as [Maro] said when the Caelicoli      plagued poor Aeneas half out of his wits. ---  I know      Francis that the provocation was extreme – like unto the      emotions of a female Tiger robbed of her young by some      felonious and ruthless hand – some Yankee Menagerie-Keeper –      who reflects (not the Keeper but the Tiger) that her striped      Darlings will be exposed to the vulgar eye far from their      native land. far from her and from her caresses. – who knows      that in them she has lost perhaps the prop of her declining      years and feels that she is altogether lonely –      

“They will never come she said”
“She said I am      a-weary a-weary”
“Would God that I were dead”!      –

like unto her heart-rending emotions are emotions      of a Poet moaning over the loss the abstraction by      unhallowed hands of his fancy’s creations – his children of      the Brain  She whet her incisors – He mends his pen –      
Her sullen growl resounds thro the forest. = fearful      flies the trembling thief – the invader of their domestic      hearth and social joys. – She sees him in the blue distance      farther than any eye can pierce save the eye of a Mother      bereaved of her offspring --  Guilty wretch! and dont thou      expect such crimes to prosper – Fly as thou may the avenger      is behind – She springs from the tangled Brush – one blow      and her little ones are free and the blood of the ravisher =      washes down his bones – The Poets eye rolls in indignant      fury – He paces up and down – and much Ink must be shed.       Black ink – to expiate his wrongs ------

But Frank I      quote from “L’Entreprise No. 8” “Memory is mortal      forgiveness divine” – There is a difference between the      charity of the Christian and the blind revenge of the beasts      that perish – and I see that thou art well acquainted with      the precept concerning the smiting of one cheek and the      subsequent turning of the other – since – when thou wast      informed of the use I had made of thy Serenade thee sends me      on another piece which I am sorely tempted to appropriate to      the same purpose – viz. “The Thief” an Indignation ode      -----

But “L’Entreprise” is of the things that have      been = its star has set – When it again rises and illumes      our horizon once more – any pieces you may favor me with      will meet with particular attention and speedy insertion –      To Encourage your Modesty I will only hint
at the numerous encores and complimentary remarks which I      appropriated at its reading in our Junto. – I must confess I      had some conscience pangs – at thus robbing you of your due      and ventured to hint that they were entirely mistaken about      the Authorship – But all that was attributed to my modesty      and I could not make them believe it – So any more Serenades      you want inserted or Indignation Odes – either – send them      along and I’ll father ‘em with pleasure ----

As to      that little Biographical sketch in the “Ledger” the idea      pleases me exceedingly – It is not always the fate of Genius      to hear its praises Its requiem is rarely listened to – till      Death has untuned the Ear to praise and “cold obstruction”      chilled the heart and closed the eye – But sometimes Fate      decrees otherwise. -- & To your hands I commit with pleasure      myself and my memory – and to encourage you I think you      would make considerable of a Buzzy – I had thought some time      since I could trace thy classic pen in that respectable      Journal – Sometimes perhaps in the Poet’s corner – and again      I have suspected thy assistance (as Charles Lamb and Dun      Stuart have done before thee - ) [Reparter] “compiler      impromptu” composer and Wellerism manufacturer at a fippenny      bit a head

Dont forget Frank to put in how like twin      puppies we hunted the Muses together – How “hand in hand we      climbed the steep ascent of Parnassus” – and drank from the      same pitcher of the sparkling fountain – and if thee wishes      it I dont know that I shall object to thy inserting that      chaste production of thy blushing and almost virgin Muse –      the ode to Fanny – Though I bethink myself that piece would      better become the columns of the “Little Genius” – for there      was about it an independent air – a noble boldness which      some – nay, many – are too narrowed by the conventional and      affected delicacy of the day fully to appreciate and which      the Little Genius so openly advocates and patronises –      

With this I send you a critique on a Philadelphia      poet one who “blossomed in the desert air” of our unfriendly      climate but who like a wise prophet sought honor elsewhere –      No man is a hero to his valet’s deschambre and Pliny would      never have sucked Parnassian pap to advantage if he had      lived and died a Teacher at Providence School – What a      blight this “Times” man seems to want to throw upon poor      Pliny’s Laurels.  – No mincing matters Regulae cut & slash.       – When I see such an article I always fancy the Burden on my      own shoulders – Just Fancy some of your Serenades served in      the same style – Not kidnapped – eloped with out of pure      affection but barbarously mangled, murdered, its throat cut      from ear to ear.  – Like to a Tiger &c &c (on the other page      - )

New England Yearly Meeting of Friends is held at      New Port from 7th day the 12th of the 6th month to 6th day      the 18th inclusive commencing with the Meeting for      Sufferings – which however thou knowst is only patent to      Cardinals and chief priests of the synagogue First Day is      generally “the Yearly Meeting” par eminence and is usually a      great day at New Port.  Then may be seen straight coats of      the strictest sort – straight coats of a more accommodating      
curve – straight coats which one would hardly know were      straight and it grieves me to mention – some utterly devoid      of straightness – Broad Brims black, drab, or otherwise from      six inches in diameter to a lesser number – or a fraction –      Bonnets which the unsullied snow wreath could not rival in      maiden purity setting off eyes of all colors – noses of all      shapes – and mouths of all degrees of prettiness –      interspersed with some of the adornment of the daughters of      vanity ------ flitting past in crowds – and every now & then      the youth of the company indulging in cachinnations calling      down upon them with speedy rebuke of the more serious &      elderly – while old peaceable looking chassis and wagons      drawn by the most demure looking ponies in the world string      along through the streets and all bound to Yearly-Meeting –      New Port has many other attractions besides Yearly Meeting      however – The ride on the Beach – the Glen the [Fort] and      the Sail in the Harbour take away considerably from the      tedium of the long sittings – and besides Paradise &      Purgatory can be visited – much easier than was done in the      times of Hercules & pious Aeneas – as to the girls I have      often told them that I worship them
“as      stars

Whose purity and distance make them      fair”
and thee must get another pilot when thee comes on      such sounding but I do not despair however and may perhaps      with a few Lessons from thee become “a nice young      man”
All this I put forth expecting you to come & visit      us then – If you will be there – day & month aforesaid – I      will meet you and I think I may promise you a pleasant week      – Harry I suppose put more faith in Fanny [Ell---] than in      any one else – so he will hardly affect a Yearly Meeting of      the spiritually “Exercised –

So no more (and quite      enough) from
thy friend Charles TaberFrancis R Cope
care of H. & A. Cope
No 1 Walnut St
Philada.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan E. (Jonathan Evans) Rhoads:  1830-1914
Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Date: 1910-11-01
Title: 1910 November 1, Wilmington, Delaware, to Jonathan Evans

Jonathan E. Rhoads
908 Franklin Street

Jonathan E   Rhoads
11 mo 1.1910

Wilmington, Delaware
11 mo   1 1910

My Dear Cousin Jonathan Evans

Thine of   yesterday is at hand--I am not sorry I wrote to thee as thy   answer assures me there was misapprehension on my part as to   thy expression. We had spoken of the discipline at Westtown   and of the laying aside of rules there and at Haverford   which were difficult of enforcement and some of them   unnecessary to proper order. Afterwards, if I recollect   right, thee expressed thyself in favor of rescinding all   rules, the word discipline being used; which I supposed   referred to that of our Y.Mg. when I now think the   discipline at Westtown may have been in thy mind.
I am   glad to be corrected, and to have thy opinion of the Revised   Discipline as given in thy letter.--I greatly long
to have unity of belief and effort in upholding essential   Truth and its principles by Friends, and increased   recognition of the intent of our Lord and Master when He   taught His followers the deep meaning of "The Kingdom of   Heaven."
Some few practices of the most substantial   Friends I am willing to leave to individual conscience for   adoption, if their rejection does not contravene any plainly   stated law or principle in the New Testament.  Thus in   dress, simplicity is conformity to the law of Christianity;   and truthfulness is necessary to speech when addressing   others.

With love thy cousin
Jona. E Rhoads


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Sarah W. Rhoads
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1908-12-10
Title: 1908 December 10, Germantown, To Rachel C. Evans

152 School-house Lane
Germantown

My dear   friend
Rachel C. Evans--

I think that I can fully   understand thy feelings as expressed in thy touching note of   last week--and have waited to reply, until the Friends   having the matter in charge, could confer together;
this they did this morning; and now I must tell thee, that   after giving our earnest consideration to the subject, the   proposal of thy name for this service was our unanimous   decision; and I was requested to let thee know that thee had   been thought of as most suitable, by each member of our   committee before we mettogether: May we not conclude therefore, that this decision   is in the right ordering, according to our best light and   Judgment, while hoping that thee will be willing to accept   it as such.
And now may I personally express my sympathy   for thee, should thee feel it right to serve in this   responsible position--and also the desire that thee may   realize the words "He giveth forever to the faint; and to   them that have no might he increaseth strength."  
While   I remain with love Sincerely thy friend
Sarah W.   Rhoads

Dec--10th 1908


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas) Cope:  1850-1883
Date: 1865-05-10
Title: 1865 May 10, Baltimore, to Tom

Baltimore 5. 10th. 65

Dear Tom,
Thee must excuse   me for having been so long answering thy letter, & not think   that I did not care about it, for I was right pleased that   thee wrote to me, & I have said to myself ever so many times   [said] that I must write to that “Little “Toms”—  but thee   sees now I have got to be a school mistress, I have so many   cares that I cant always do[o] what I’d like & then I have   had a good many letters to write to different people &   knowing that thee saw the home ones & knew all about me, I   took it the easier.
I have now been “school”mom=’en” long   enough to get a prety good idea of the business – & my idea   of it is, thatits a good deal easier to be a scholar than I teacher, – so   thee can remember that for thy comfort when thee has a hard   lesson to learn.  To teach a school of troublesome boys I   shd. say was one of the hardest businesses’s that cld. well   be got up..  The girls are bad enough, but when it comes to   boys – – they’re the [---] of man.  I have in my school   about 35 boys & a dozen girls between the ages of 6 & 15 —   The girls I have but little trouble with, but the little   boys are regular monkeys.  No sooner is my back turned than   they begin their discussions of wh. they have a variety —    Its the hardest thing in the world to keep them still, & if   they get a good chance there’s not one of them that is too   good to get up & takea dance or a fight or any other such little amusement that   they think will set the school in an uproar.+  [+ Throwing   spit balls is a very bad habit they have – also dancing “Ham   fat”]  My punishments are various.  Sometimes I shake the   culprit & if that wont do, tie em up hand & foot & put em in   the corner — wh. is a very troublesome operation to me.  But   it seems as if nothing wld. beat it into their heads that   school is any thing but a place to play in.  
Most of   them can read a little some not at all, & like “Busy” – they   must always spell girl gril and dirt – drit –.  It seems as   if it came natural —  One of their best accomplishments is   singing wh. we sometimes let them do in school.  My children   know “my”native country thee” & the colored “Wolunteer”— wh.   they shout out with great effect. But I guess I’ve told thee   enough about the darkies  We’ll talk a little abt.the whites.  How comes on work at Haverford?  By the way thy   hand writing is coming on so well, that when I got thy   letter I thot. it was Busy’s himself, it was so good.    Have’nt you a boy named Allen Thomas,?  I expect he’s a nice   fellow & has two very nice brothers whom I met last eveng.    There are [---] pleasant frieds here & I do not often have a   chance to feel lonely or home sick.  How does Prof. Cope &   his botany lectures?  I am going to try to write him a note   to send in this & consequently must say farewell or shall   not have time.  Thee can take this down home with thee next   7th day & tell ‘em it’s all they’ll get this week.— as they   dont deserve any for some time.  Give my love to all, & if   thee gets time write again to thy affec sister C

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Samuel Morris:  1827-1905
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1904-08-25
Title: 1904 August 25, Duchy Lausanne, to Rachel C. Evans

Duchy, Lausanne
8/25.1904.

My dear   friend
Rachel C. Evans.

In carrying out our   program for Switzerland, the weather has suddenly changed   from intense heat and a very long drought to a rain of   several days, which while most grateful to the parched   country, interferes materially with views of the charming   Lake of Geneva and the mountains that environ it. Instead   therefore, of our usual outdoor life, this gives just the   opportunity for which I've been wishing, to acknowledge some   of the very kind farewell greetings, received as we left our   native shores. The weather being so variable, it has seemed   best for one to remain in this most comfortable   Eng.-speaking pension, with a delightful out-look upon the   Lake, while my dear Hannah has gone into the 
upper regions, so as to get into closer touch with their   sublime peaks--at least so far as the fickle weather may   permit. Meanwhile therefore, my pen is giving me congenial   occupation in-doors.
Among the loving remembrances to   which I have referred, is thine from Franconia, U. N. of   [--] 28--I was truly glad also thus to receive good accounts   from you, and can only trust your outing in the bracing air   of New Eng. may be permanently helpful to thyself and your   dear Anna, of whom I often think with tender sympathy,   desiring that "the best of Physicians"--may keep her under   his all-wise and loving care. Turning away therefore, from   misgivings, or fears, or failures as they may seem to her,   may there be a more "continual looking into Jesus", not only   "as the author", but "the finisher of her faith". Let her   ever remember that it is this same Saviour of our's, who has   begun his work of grace in her heart that seeks to carry it   on and perfect it
to his praise, and her unspeakable peace. He knows her   better than she knows herself; and therefore, none so well   as He can "speak to her condition". It is thus He has   revealed himself to multitudes of struggling souls, and they   never seek His face in vain. Then it is that anxiety gives   place to a quiet childlike confidence in Him, and impatience   as to a more rapid growth in grace than we may have yet   known finds us more continually dwelling upon the abounding   love of God, and brings about that "patient waiting for   Christ", which the apostle craves for his fellow   believers.
While our best desires are turned in this   direction, there is nothing incompatible with the fullest   appreciation of the outward favors & blessings with which   our Heavenly Father has surrounded us. Indeed, we now   realize that these he has "given us richly to enjoy". We   recognize His good hand in them all, and so a continual   thanksgiving goes up from our hearts to Him, as the   all-bountiful giver. I see little to add to the few
hints as above, and would have thee to use them or not, only   as way may open--Indeed I can quite believe that, if a   fitting, natural opening does not occur, it may be best to   speak to Anna of nothing beyond my continued loving interest   in her.
As to the results of our own rambling, I may   thankfully say that, for myself, there seems a marked gain   in several respects, but, as thou has intimated, the full   benefit of such changes is sometimes felt later. My dear   Hannah could scarcely be in better condition for enjoying to   the full the scenes of rare interest and beauty thr'o which   we are and have been passing. I think however, we shall both   be glad when the time for our return voyage shall have come.   This will be 10/5, by the "Haverford", for Phila, and   shortly after, if the Lord will, we may hope to be once more   among our dear home friends--Please remember us in love to   Jon., while I remain

very sincerely thy friend
Sam   Morris


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1864-08-31
Title: 1864 August 31, Springfield, Mass, to Papa and Mama

Springfield. Mass. Aug. 31st
4th day eve.

Dear   Papa & Mama,
We rec’d your letters this morning just as   we started & were very glad to get them, tho’ sorry to think   they came too late to engage rooms for you at the Cliff   House we were very anxious to hear from you in time, but you   were so long making up your minds, that we almost came to   the conclusion you were not going to at all, & had given it   up.  However Uncle H. thinks there will be no trouble in   getting them by writing afterwards.  We left Newport at 7   o’clock this morning & dined at Worcester very comfortably   about 2 o’clock & arrived here at 6 1/2 about.  Thishotel is delightful, they say it is one of the best in the   Union Sallie Parish says “its where all the brides come to,”   I haven’t seen any yet!  We got a splendid supper & Uncle   Harry & Chell & I took a little stroll through the town  it   seems very pretty as far as gas and star-light would show.    But me thinks we will not see much more of it, we propose   leaving quite early tomorrow morning for [Mt.] Holyoke.    Aunt Mary says “that all things considered she is certainly   remarkably well,” last 1st day she says she felt better than   she has for a year.  She is certainly improved, but don’t   raise your hopes to high or I fear you will be disappointed   – She’s better, but not well.  
They are talking,   talking! all the time, & I can’t write, Aunt [K]. has a very   nice room on the secondfloor, & Chell, Ginnie, & I have three cots put up in an   adjoining private parlor, its quite fine we’re all seated   round the centre table with a bright gas-light above us & a   velvate carpet beneath us, & the most delightful easy chairs   aren’t we splendid?  
Uncle H. says our present intention   is to come home in the 2 o’cl train 7th day (if the   time-table is right) I think we’ll not get out [--] 4, if we   change our plans we’ll telegraph.  Now Mother I must stop   for I want to fix my hat & its getting late.  Aunt M. says   she would have written but she has been retrimming Anna’s   hat & had no time.  Love to all
very   affec’ly
Lillie

P.S.  Resolved-that we take dinner   at Aunt [Annas], & come in quarter before 4P.S.  resolved that you need not expect us till we   come
P.S.  thats wrong!
P.S.  We will probably come   out in the 9 o’clock cars taking tea at the   Continental.
P.S.  Still talking can’t tell if this be   the final decision!
P.S.  Final decision! Seriously!  It   is extremely difficult to fix our plans, & we will   positively come home on 7th day either 1/4 4 or 9 o’cl   trains.
P.S.  Uncle Harry thinks we ought to give a   reason for our indecision.  Reason That we can not find   beforehand how long it will take to visit Mt. Holyoke as we   have to drive part of the way, & that makes it uncertain   whether we will reach New Haven tomorrow night or the next   day


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Elizabeth Sandwith Drinker:  1734-1807
Recipient:  Mary Sandwith
Date: 1771-07-13
Title: 1771 July 13, Bristol, to Mary Sandwith

Bristol July 13. 1771 – 7th day 1 oClock
My dear   Sister

My Henry came here last evening in seeming   good spirits but indifferent Health; he eat a very light   supper, and sett off this morning (after a poor breakfast)   about 8 oClock.  He has a fine day, and I hope riding and   relaxation from business will restore him; he talked of   returning to Bristol on 5th day or perhaps not untill 7th   day next.  Thy continued Confinement and constant care give   me many an anxious minute; but I trust the time will come   when it may please kind Providence to make things easier to   thee.  I was not quite so well yesterday as usual & my dear   Henrys coming to me so unwell gave me pain.  I am quite   bravely to day after coming out of the water but full of   thought about my dear little crowing Henry.  Doct. D.*   [*Denormandie] came here last evening, and, after the usual   salutation, said to me, he was come to have some serious   talk with me; I smiled; nay said he I am in earnest; about   what Doctor? – weaning your little son; such a hearty   growing boy, who seems to live upon you, is enough to draw a   pain in a weakly person, where there had never been one   before; besides he keeps you waking at nights, and prevents   your using means that might restore you; if it was not on   his account you might now go with Mr. Drinker to the sea   shore, and so forth.  There are several women here who I   beleive have put it into the Doctors head that I ought not   to suckle the Child.  My Henry seconded him, and said he   would write this morning to thee, but as he was poorly, I   undertook to do it.–  Do not think my dear, from what I have   written, that I am worse; Indeed I am not through mercy, but   have had the pain in my breast oftener than I had sometime   ago, which I told the Doctor.  I beleive that if I had a   Girl with me that was worth a fig, it would be different,   for the one I have has no knack of making the Child fond of   her.  Doctr. D. says as Doctr. Evans knows my Constitution,   he would have him spoken to. –  I would have thee see the   Doctor and talk with him.  Patty would do a great deal   better than the Girl I have, and should she offer again, I   would not have thee entirely discourage her, but tell her   thee beleives the girl I have does not suit me, and if she   thinks she can behave so as to please me, thee would have   her call again.  It will be time enough (after theehas spoken to Doct. Evans) to come to any conclusion when my   Henry returns.  I had a room full of visitors yesterday   afternoon; two Chariotts full besides others; T. Ringold &   Wife from Maryland; Sally Hoffman, Sukey Pintard, her sister   Boudinott from New York; Serlis’ wife, Betsy Tilghman from   Philada. and Billy Coxe’s daughter, and Sally Tredwell the   Doctors sister.  We all went in the evening to Bath.  I go   but little a visiting, and they all think that my little   dear keeps me at home, and every ones cry is wean him, wean   him; thee would be charmed to see the dear little fellow,   how he daily improves in cunning antick tricks.  I long to   see thee and my dear Children, but dont know how to bring it   about.  My Henry was saying that he was well pleased that I   did not get his letter by Billy Hodge (as he had mentioned   thy being unwell) as thee is now better. – I would have thee   my dear take half a spoonful of the Elixir every day to   strengthen thee.  I have not had occasion to take any since   I came up as yet, but thee knows it was of great use to me   taken in small quantity.  I have been but a little while   writing thus far, but as I have not stopped since I began, I   grow tired, and my dear little one is crying for me; My dear   love is to thee & to my sweet Children, to whom I intend to   write when I can conveniently; they must not be impatient,   but good and kind to each other, & very dutiful & mindful of   their Aunty’s will, which will give great pleasure to their   very affectionate mammy
I am, my dear Sister, thine &c   –
E. Drinker

My dear, dear, kind Henry looked so   unwell as he slept this morning as made my heart ache; he   was last night more than commonly chearful, which I have   observed often to be the case when he is unwell.  how unlike   the generality of Mankind is he in his natural disposition   many ways.  he was last night at supper affectionately   acknowledging thy tender care of him, & saying how clever it   was to have two Wives.  We were likewise wishing that it was   convenient to thee to spend one month here, free from care   of us & ours. –  I hope it may please God to spare me and   restore me to health for my Henrys sake, & that I may be   enabled to make up in some measure to my dear Husband and   Sister their many, many kindnesses to me; but shouldshould it happen otherwise, may I be enabled to say, the   Lords will be done. –

5 oClock – Billy Parr has been   here; he says he saw thee, & that you are all well.  he has   gone to Trenton, where Peggy, Nancy and Caleb are to go   tomorrow; they want me to go, but I shall not.  Molly Foulke   is expected here this evening or in the morning.  Mag.   Divine next second day, so that we shall have the house   full.  Peggy gives her love to thee.  Henry’s asleep, & I am   going to Bath.  farewell my dear Sister for the   present.
E.D.
I wrote yesterday by S. Le Gay, which   letter I suppose thee has received.  I make no doubt but my   dear Henry will return bravely.  tomorrow will be a lonesome   day to me.  my love to neighbour James – 
E.D.Bristol July 13. 1771
Elizabeth Drinker to Mary Sandwith

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Annette Cope:  1843-1916
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1867-07-19
Title: 1867 July 19, Laurel House, to Mama

Laurel House July 19th

My  dear Mama,
Rachel has   spent herself so in writing to thee that it seemed hardly   worth while for me to try, so I thought I wld. wait till her   fever was over, & as this eve. she seemed little inclined to   desert the piazza, I concluded to undertake the task.  We   have had a most exercising day in all senses of the word,   but so wonderful is the effect of this mountain air that I   do not feel the least tired.  In the first place this   morning we set off in an open wagon for Haines’ fall a   pleasant ride of about 2 miles, but it was after we got   there the “tug of war” began –  We hada regular scramble, part of the way was so rough that Tom &   Walter concluded to remain behind & before we got through   there was no one left but Harry Ellie & Madge & I, we went   down to the very foot of the lower falls, & were well   repaid; it was a most beautiful spot, a succession of six   lovely little falls ending in cascades & rapids, it was   altogether quite charming, the prettiest place of the kind I   ever saw, & I don’t remember ever to have seen a photograph   of it –  We did not get home till after the dinner bell had   rung, so were obliged just to give a little smoothe to our   hair, & go in in our mountain dresses, but every thing is   very primitive here, & nobody pretends to dress for dinner.    As we were all preparedwe concluded instead of changing our dresses to go after   dinner down the stream about a mile to Bastion falls under   Tom’s piloting, & soon comes in the adventure – we just got   to the head of the fall, & were [nerving] ourselves for a   scramble to the foot, when some one remarked that it was   raining, & sure enough it was, we took shelter under some   trees and concluded it wld. soon be over, & we would wait,   but it got harder & harder, & at last found its way through   the branches, & came down on us in large drops, which were   decidedly wetting, we tried it for a little while, but   finding there was no sign of stopping & we were getting very   wet we concluded to push on home, –  At first it seemed to   have slaked alittle, but it soon began harder than ever, & we went   tearing along jumping over rocks & through bushes till we at   last arrived at the foot of the Kauterskill, & then there   were all those dreadful stairs to go up – however we pushed   on, & at last arrived panting at the house – we were pretty   objects to be sure all wet, & draggled, & hot – there were   several gentlemen sitting round on the piazza, & I thought   it a remarkable instance of politeness that they did not   ever smile, I’m sure I could not have resisted it.  Of   course we retired immediately to our appartments, & changed   every thing making ourselves most comportable & desidedly   more presentable.  Thee need not feel the least concern for   I don’t think we are any of us a bitthe worse, & the most remarkable part is we are not tired.    The only thing that suffered was our hats, but I guess they   will look pretty well when they dry, & we’ll have to retrim   them at Newport –  Thee must be sure & not forget my bonnet   so that if we should arrive 7th day night I may have   something to wear to meeting.  Also mother I think I forgot   to put on the list a thin white body of mine & my best   underbody that I wanted to have done up & brought in the   trunk – Virginia will know.  Tom wrote to Father yesterday   to go by 7th days steamer, & one of us will try to write by   the next.  We are having a most delightful time, & as thee   willsee by my account I am as well as possible, so thee need not   have any anxiety on my account.  I do hope you are getting   along nicely, & don’t feel very lonely, I know thee must   miss Father very much, but I hope he will be a great deal   better for his voyage & come home to us quite strong, & free   from all those miserable head-aches.  
Aunt L & Chell   send love, & the former says she is intending to write to   thee very soon.  
Give a great deal of love to all, &   Virginia especially I want to write to her, she was so very   kind in helping me to get ready to come away, I don’t know   what I should have done without her.  
Good-night dear   Mama,
thy ever loving
Lily
Please remember to bring   the Banner Essays to Newport.

Title: 1865 June 7, B, to Mother and sister Annte

B 6/7—65—

Dear Mother & sister Annte.

I think   I’ll address you collectively this time, as I suppose   Caroline’s head’ll be turned with weddings & unable to   appreciate common topics. I recd. yr. very interesting &   spirited epistles this morn.g & reply at once, in order that   you may not have cause to complain of remissness this time,   & upon what ground you did it last, I must say I cld. not   discover, as I think I have been up to the mark quite as   much as you have. Thy remarks [a] on properness &c were   quite edifying. I expect thee wd. be charmed with the   Baltimore people. They are certainly most social & charming   in their manners, tho’ I dont believe afterall, when you come to the foundation of things that there is   any more good substantial material among them than among   some of that despised class denominated "the proper." As to   the gentlemen I cant say that I have met any whom I consider   very deeply interesting As far as gallantry & politeness go   they are certainly very attractive Bt if we cld. only   introduce a little more of these elements with some of our   [imperturbables] I incline to think these wld. be found   quite as deep in the long run. I must say it is refreshing   to get hold of some thing that is more [impressible] than a   stone & I intend to [---] up Baltimore ways loudly when I   get home. Tell Cousin Mary she must hurry & come down as   fast as she can, or I fearI shall not get to have my sprees with her. This morn the   new teacher who is going to take my sch. arrived & I was   promoted or depressed I dont know wh. to the rank of   assistant to Mr Waterman, the principal of the sch. It is a   splendid change for me, as his room is much pleasanter & I   have none of the discipline to do but only the hearing of   the lessons—intellectually, it seems a most magnificent   advance frm. a-b only to geography and arithmetic & I shd.   be quite willing to teach there for weeks if it was’nt for   the hot weather, as it is, however, considering the [--] &c   I think I had better not stay much after the three months   are up wh. will be abt. the mid of June--& very soon—as you   will perceive, so you may make preparations for me, soon   after that time—I hope you’ll havepleasant little surprise prepared for me in the way of a   closet—wh. wont be the linen closet—I have to keep up such   an everlasting foolding and unfolding here that I shall be   perfectly delighted to get a place to "hang up" in.

I   expect I am indebted to my frd. Jesse for this release frm.   the infants—I said to him in joke some time ago that I thot,   I shd. give "notice" soon for them to get another teacher &   he took it in earnest but I am very glad, on some accts, as   I shd like to get some ideas about older teaching frm Mr.   W.

I expect you’ll enjoy [Mr. N’s] wedding most as   much as Lilly’s—There was a young gentleman here the other   day who told somebody that he thot L’s wedding was   dreadfully stupid, & that he thot’ one or two of the   bridesmaids (he did’nt say all) were the ugliest girls he   had ever seen—not a very complimentary speech I think.
As I shall probably come home so soon it will not be worth   while to send the things by express—tho’ if I cld only have   had them now they wld. have been exceedingly useful -- I   think maybe I’ll try & get myself a beige skt. here & we   shall not be likely to have many more tea parties now the   warm weather has come -- We’ve never heard any more abt.   Jessies strawberry party & we’re afraid he’s forgotten it.   He took us to a small one out at his bro. James’ night   before last. We went in a buggy & pair & came home by   moonlight—quite romantically -- The buggy is only used on   very romantic occasions, I believe. Its so nice here   moonlight nights—the ladies all dress up in their whites &   sit out on the front door steps, & go round [seeing?] one   another with beaux or beau less just as it happens.Has Fanny Drinker gone home? I reckon she has & where is   Cous. Sarah? Give my love to her if she is about still. I   ought to have written to her. Give my love also to all the   Wynndowners also please give my love & congratulations to   all the bride cousins & tell them I’m very sorry not to be   giving them anything-- Maybe if I aint so lazy I’ll make em   something after I get home. But dont tell em that. I believe   this is all I have to say at present—will write and fix the   day of course before I come. If Cous. M. comes soon please   send the shawl and the [b----] skt. as I [---] much love to   all—yrs. affec

ClemmyI shd. be pleased to have some [---] my return & also before   my return

Title: 1846 January 21, New Bedford, to F.R. Cope, Philada.

Dear Friend 
New Bedfor[d] 1 mo 21 1846 –

Your   letters were as duly received as unduly attended to.  Not   however that I did not make search for the subscription   paper. actual[--] mon ami by two reasons one to comply with   your request & another to trump up certain delinquents whose   names were therein appended to certain generous figures   which have not as yet been Transferred to my Pocket Book. --   Troubles in the family have since then as you surmised   interfered with all other matters and hence. -- -- --.  But   if I cant find it. put us down viz. W.H. Hussey Jack do. Ed   Rudman Tom do. S.R. Morgan Ben Barker Job A.T. Eddy. Rob’ B   Howland. Ch. Osborne. Aug. & myself for the whole amot.   –

Warned – I am armed.  But Frank you need a rib.    When I consider the imminent danger – you are in Every   Sunday. of blowing away walking home from Meeting alone. I   wonder at your remaining single.  Let her be somewhat solid.   – an anchor to windward – then no matter how the storm may   rage. mignon you may under [bare] [poles] you know ride out   the gale, rocked in the cradle of the Deep –

But a   fig for your predictions – What satisfies me of thine   felicity is in the 1st place & chiefly. I. am dreadful   pertikler myself. & 2dly (see over the leaf.)some others are so likewise – "man & consequently   woman"

Every creature likes his ease
English   French & Roman
I’ve seen men were hard to please
&   consequently Woman –

Womenkind will have their   way
Even tell you go! man!
I like to hear men say   their say
& consequently woman –

But marriage is a   happy lot
He who doubts is no man
Men in plenty may be   got
& consequently woman

You’re a good boy never   fib
Gamble [----] & so, man!
Go and get yourself a   rib
& consequently woman –

As for me you never   fear
Sure I shant be slow, man!
Get some money – then   – oh dear!
& consequently woman
Write me a systematic letter. --  I abominate this way you   have got into of diplomatic correspondence. Every word of   which you might publish in the newspapers.  Hows   [Con—cervis] my next leisure moment, shall be tak[en] up   with a letter to him.  Give New B. my best respects. whither   I [go] on to Balt or not shortly. is doubtful. as every   thing else is in this “wale”. but if “i” do I shall pop in   to your counting room some fine morning –

Write me   first. about the crops & the weather & business & all that   sort of thing you know. a real interesting sensible sort of   a letter. but – the girls –

with much   regard.
yours’ &c
Charles Taber
F. R. Cope
H & A. Cope & Co
Philada.

Title: 1853 April 4, to Clemmie

April 29,1853

Will thee dear Clemmie accept this   little book as a token that I appreciated thy patient   endeavors to gratify my request; & also as a companion of   thy sorrowful thoughts, who would fain, with the blessing of   God, lead thee to peaceful meditations.--
Especially note   the introduction. Thee will find some passages marked; these   struck me as applicable to thy feelings--But do not feel   compelled to read
because I give; rather seek its counsels, as thee is drawn   by a sense of need; and perhaps thee may find a fountain of   joy which thee has never know yet. But it will only be as a   guide to the everlasting spring of peace which is in Jesus   our Saviour.
I opened my Bible to find a promise for thee   & this was the verse which met my eye. Isa xxxv 4 "Say to   them that are of a fearful heart, be strong, fear not:   behold your God will come with vengeance, even God 
with a recompense; he will come and save you." 
Will thee   not bend a listening ear, and a believing heart to such a   gracious message?
I have added a few thoughts on the last   leaf of the book; and with them wld. give the warm affection   of

Thy Cousin
Wills



----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Henry W. (Henry Waln) Drinker:  1787-1866

Title: 1817 June 13, Stoddartsville, to Thomas P. Cope Esq., Philadelphia

Stoddartsville June the 13th. 1817–
Dear Uncle.
By   William Drinker who pass’d Here on the 9th  I receivd thy   remembrance of the 3d inst–  What Charles Miner has done or   is now about I cannot precisely say not hav[ing] seen Him or   any of his friends since [my] Last
I question the   Establishment of the proposed Bank at Wilkes barre & beleive   also that if it ever does go into Operation it will be by   compromise and by a [di----] of the few offices of [---]   attatched to it–  Humble merit will I presume stand but a   poor chance–
Mr Arndt on whom I depended for [the]   Hemlock Bark Has not yet ground it but I hope He will attend   to it shortly–  if it in any degree succeeds [in] England it   will be Highly important to this Count[r]y as well as   convenient to ship overseas–  I beleive that the mak[ing]   pot & pearl Ash might prove an advantageous thing to us more   than to any other persons [We] owning the nearest Large Body   of suitable timber for the purpose – if it will pay for its   mak[ing] & a reasonable sum for outlay & superintendance it   will answer us as a means of clear[ing] Land –
I am glad   that thy mind is made up for a peep at this quarter of the   world – I think it will be likely to be beneficial to thy   Health as also to Aunts – Some Rough travell[ing] there will   no doubt be – but generaly speak[ing] the Roads are   tolerable to the mouth of Tunkhannock–  Thereare no excelent Taverns on the Route so far as I am   acquainted–  I think the one Here is the Best & likely to be   the most pleasant for the Residence of aunt–  Gentlemen can   be well accomodated at Easton & at Wilkes barre at Mr Whites   in the first nammed place & at Mr Arndts in the second in   Both Houses there is Rather too much noise and Drink[ing] to   be entirely agreeable to Ladies –  Here also we have more   noise than is pleasant–  There be from 15 to 20 of Stoddarts   work[ing] hands quart[ere]d in the House –  
The Road by   Easton is Rather worse than that by Bethlehem & Nazareth & I   think generaly the accommodations are better on this last   Route–  from Nazareth to Hellers at the Wind gap at which   House I have generaly procured tolerable Eating & pretty   clean–  from thence about 17 miles to William Sox’s upon the   top of Pokono – where th[e]y make prety good coffee & give   you what ever they may Have in the House in a tolerably   cleanly stile–  from thence to this place say 12 miles   –
The present is about as pleasant a Time to Travel in   this county as any other Dur[ing] the summer – ere the grain   is cut which will not be Done before the Last of next monthHowever the Weather is now variable and we may expect   occasional Rains, until after Harvest – 
in the Last of   August & to the middle of September is generaly more settled   weather – as to the [Gnats] they Have already come & in the   woods Bite sharply–  This [they] will continue to Do until   September – But out of the woods we do not find them   Troublesome– There are not any curiosities worthy a name   from Philada to this place–  The Habits & manners of the   people on the Route may perhaps afford Something novel – The   scenery also & general Aspect of the County will be new –   [marbly] nature in Her Roughest garb will surround you – you   will have pure Air & pure water & I doubt not to good   [appetites] as to enable you to Encounter much coarser fare   than usual – in the neighbourhood of Easton-Bethlehem &   Nazareth is a lime stone county – & I would have you beware   of the water – it is no doubt wholesome but to persons   [unaccustomed] to it it is often unpleasant in its effects–   if I know when you intend com[ing] up I will endeavor to   join you at Hellers – I have been constantly interupted   since I began writing which must excuse this   scrawl–
affectionaly thy nephew. H.W.Drinker –Stoddartsville 
 12 1/2 
June 14th
Thomas P. Cope   Esq.
Merchant
Philada.

Title: [1865 May ?], 190 Calvert st, to Mother and sisters

2nd day eve
190 Calvert st

Dear Mother & sisters,   Tired as I am I must write you a few words to night, as I   shall probably be at the sch, in the morn & the mail closes   at 1 P.M. & I thought you’d like to know that we arrived   safely about 5 this aft. & I am installed in my new boarding   house wh. promises to be very nice.  They ladies were   exceedingly kind & welcomed me as if I had been an old   friend  They are so free & easy.  One of them Miss Talbot   came right up in my room & talked to me while I was getting   dressed – & was as kind as possible  They used to know uncle   Jasper & quantities of our friends, so that I begin to feel   quite at home already  It is a large 4story house with a very nice pleasant parlor, & a   comfortable dining room, where we had tea on a little   refreshment table—the 4 school “marms”—as cozy as possible.    They say “thee” & call me by name wh. makes me feel much   less strange
Jesse called a few minutes after we arrived   in his elegant carriage, having been to one of the dipots to   meet us, but we unfortunately had got out at the wrong one;   & very much out of our way.  The ladies seem in very   moderate circumstances only keeping one servant, & a sch. of   near 40 day scholars.   consequently they have not much time   to attend to housekeeping nor much talent in that way I shd.   think.  Their kindness however makes amends.The house is on a very high situation & there is a fine view   of the city fr[m]. my room, wh is in the 2nd story & very   airy & pleasant.  But there is no closet unfortunatley wh.   is remarkably home like & seems to be my fate.  Not a place   to hang a dress, but I have 5 beaureau drawers & can make   out.  So much for the house.  3rd day morn.  We went last   evening to see the sch. & I was most agreeably disappointed   in it in every respect..  The rooms are well ventilated &   airy & no disagreeable odour.  & their state of advancement   is surprising.  There were a few to be sure who reminded me   of Busy—in his attempt to spell girl—but mostly they were   astonishingly quick--& cld. add & subtract like quite   accomplished arithmeticaians.  Quite as fast as I cld.   myself.  They were mostly adults.  In the morningThey are children.
I am to have a class of 30 & am very   glad to find that I shall be in the school with Miss Field,   who is a very pleasant young lady about my own age I shd.   judge, & we can go backwards & forward to gether, & shall be   companionable I hope.  The morning session is frm. 9 till 1   1/2 not 3.  The evening teaching you can take part in or not   as you choose.  So it will not be very laborous & in every   respect, it is going to be I think, much pleasanter than I   had anticipated.  & if you are only satisfied I think I can   be very comfortable & enjoy the work & the change.Love to Cousin Sarah.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Taber:  1822-1887
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1848
Title: 1848 to Francis R. Cope, Philada.

Oh Poesy! what wight of Wretched State
Een at the lowest   bottom of his woe
When griefs surround him or sad toils   await
When cold misfortunes hand doth round him   blow
But calls on thee to aid against the foe?
Come   gentle soother of wan misery’s train
Before the scowling   can away doth go
Come shower thy spirit down on me   again
*For Frank Cope wants a letter – shall he want in   vain!!!!
*Here the Poet alludes to Danae & Jupiter   olympus an ancient buck

So Henricus is dead! dead ere   his prime!
Alas! that he should share the doom of   man!
Who now is left to build the lofty   rhyme?
Although his altitude was but a span
It   [overtopped] his years. = But no man can
Add cubits to   his stature or his days –
Vain task to stop the fateful   cruel hand
That wields the gory scissons. -- Worldy   praise 
High thought – nor noble deed its destined course   delays. –

(Now all that second Paragraph is   gammon
But if you really think it worth the trouble
If   twill not seem like too great love of mammon
I think you   can get quite as much or double
Prime cost – besides –   perhaps – who knows the bubble
Called Fame / which you’ll   keep for commissions
I want the rhino – all besides is   stubble)
By handing it about without omission
‘Mong'st   those who loudest wail that he's gone to Perdition)
I want you to hand it particularly to Miss B. --------.    Send on the amount collected for the benefit of the author   as soon after the funeral as possible.---

But as in   olden time, when-freshly sprung
From the great Maker’s   hand – all Earth was fair
Excelling in its beauty – fresh   & young
When strength & health perfumed with the balmy   air 
And all Earth’s Gifts were far beyond compare   
With what now ‘neath Heaven’s weary blessing   grows
What time the grove Hesperia apples bare
From   out the salt salt wave fair Venus rose
Graceful her   dripping locks she round her did dispose

So from the   Sorrow tearful deep & sad
Which mourns thy memory   departed Shade
While oer the dust which erst thy spirit   clad
And the loved link which bound thee to us made
We   grieve thou coulds’t not Death’s cold hand evade
Who   plucks the brightest flowers – hard to please
[While]   tears fall fast from all that thou shouldst fade
Love   ever radiant though steeped in tears
Love-rosy tints the   clouds – Love sooths the foamy seas
or Love heavenly love   appears
Just as you please

all the while alluding   in an inexpressibly delicate manner to the very peculiar   situation in which Miss B. ----- and I find ourselves since   Harry’s departure  You may show them to the lady.  Present   them as the first fruits. ----
But enough of this nonsense -  If you are heartily tired of   it remember you began it. --  and when my Muse gets well   under weigh – like Addisons there’s no stopping her. -------   Father has been unwell for some time and so much so that a   good part of the business devolves on me – in connection   with some other domestic affairs – putting a very unlooked   for and regrettable veto on my proposed trip to Philada   –
Perhaps another year may bring around the same   expectations which I hope will not be disappointed
Before   that time however I trust to see you on [here] for although   it is not to be presumed that New Bedford alone should   possess sufficient attractions – to be the terminus of your   visit it may serve as a [stepping] stone to some place that   has more ---
Remember me to [Tom] [&] your   friend
Charles Taber
Francis R. Cope
care of H. & A. Cope
Philada.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William Newbold
Recipient:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Date: 1853-12-05
Title: 1853 December 5, Philadelphia, to Clemmie

Phila. Decr. 5/1853

Does thee not dear Clemmie, open   my letter, with at least a cold, if not a repulsive   feeling?, thinking to thyself--again the unwelcome   subject,--would it had not come so soon--&c &c? I have but   one or two ideas to present at present, yet am thankful to   be permitted to do this.--Thy occupation about many things,   I do appreciate, and would never chide thee for--delay   or--naught else in answering me;--on the contrary can truly   say I have rarely received letters more truly satisfactory   than thine;--but one thing they lack, the joyful news that   thee has accepted the offer of salvation, and the effect of   this change in all thy words and feelings. I will hope for   this also;--for nothing is impossible with   God.

over
One thought is this; thee says thee has an unwilling   heart;--that the only reason thee can give for not resolving   is, thee is unwilling to resign the world;--did thee ever   think of this text "He will make them willing in the day of   his power"? God can give a willing heart;--Thy will is   corrupted, as well as all thy powers,--ask of him.--But thee   wld know if it is not better to omit prayer than to ask   "when I do not in reality desire these blessings, when my   mind is not in a fit state for prayer".--But if this is one   of thy necessities why not pray for it; pray, that thee may   pray aright; that thee may receive, first the desire, then   the blessing. Would thee neglect the only source from whence   salvation can come?--Satan will tempt thee to, and if he   succeed in this, needs no other temptation to insure his   end.--
Let me tell thee of a fact; a friend of mine (the   person who told me the circumstance/accompanied a young lady   when she visited a minister to speak of her soul's   salvation;--he urged that she shld. accept the offer of   redemption thru Christ, that
she should resolve whom she wld serve; she replied she cld.   not give up the world, but that she wanted to be a   christian;--"but you must choose, between the world &   death,--or--Jesus & his salvation.--I will leave you;"--he   did so for--some moments &retd.,--"have you resolved",--she   cld. not,--"You must determine whether you will be saved, or   lost," he waited a few moments, and with the deepest   emphasis she said "I will resolve".--from that day she was a   new creature, & for years past has, &now has, adorn her   profession.--Dear Clemmie, for a long while thee has been   halting; the Holy Spirit has not yet deserted thee; but he   may; and that is the second that I wld offer;--if thee   rejects him now he may not return, thee will succeed in   stifling his voice in thy heart--he will be grieved away,   and thy soul will be lost; can thee take this   responsibility?--Would it not be thy "soul's suicide"? Other   than wldst hearken even then in this thy day."--Sinner turn why will thee die?
God the Spirit asked thee   why:
He who all thy life has strove,
Wou'd thee to   embrace his love.
Will thou not his grace   receive?
Will thou still refuse to live?
O, thou dying   sinner why,
Why will thou for-ever die? A little tract   enclosed speaks in the same strain.--But thee fears to   possess a Christian's portion, because of trials &c, the   word of God says "Godliness is profitable with all things,   having the promise of the life that now is, & of that wh. is   to come."--And from my heart I can say that it is a most   delightful portion; I cannot tell thee all I think of it,   thee would weary, & time is not;--but I wld not exchange the   joys I have had for all the world can give; & that which we   hope for is "a far more exceeding, and eternal insight of   glory."--and this is freely offered to thee.--Now my dear   Cousin I leave thee for the present,--will thee not   resolve?--
Let me give thee some news; we are only pretty   well all having colds; Nellie walks down stairs & round the   yard & is pretty bright; Father not retd yet, are hoping for   a letter to say when; Maggie & [-oll] are with us Catter has   been sick but is better. Carrie spent an aft. & eve at our   house & is as lovely as ever, comes soon to stay several   days.--Have not seen our fds at Bristol or recd aught fm   them since I saw thee. Love to Aunt Susan & Uncle   Wm.--Hoping--yet fearing for thee; As ever

Willie


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna S. Biddle
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1862-09-17
Title: 1862 September 17, to Chellie

Sept. 17th. 1862.

Dear Chellie, 
I have been      waiting for news, before answering your last letter and am      now not much better off, but you write such very short      letters that I am not at all conscientious about making mine      short also.  I wish my dear, that you would make your      letters a little longer, & if you do not you will see mine      gradually decreasing in length, till there is hardly any      letter at all.  Uncle James went off to Harrisburg on Monday      as did Uncle Clem George Emlen John Thayre (my cousins) and      Cousin George Biddle.  Uncle Clem never told a soul that he      was going and on Sunday night when John went to the      Baltimore depot to see Gerge Emlen and John Thayre off to      his surprise he saw Uncle Clem.He was going off without bidding us good-bye when perhaps we      may never see him again.  He always was very queer but this      beats every thing.  Is not the war news splendid?  I have      not been so glad since the battle of Drainsville,      particularly about Howell Cobb the old traitor.  There is      now not the slightest fear of our having Stonewall Jackson      in Philadelphia but I pity the poor citizens of Cincinnati.       Cousin Sam Cox was called to a churchthere (St. Paul’s) and he accepted.  He left town two weeks      from yesterday and when he arrived at Cincinnati he was not      allowed to enter the city but was sent to a boarding house      about two miles from the city.  There he is now with his      wife children and father.  Of their furniture they know      nothing and are not allowed to go to the city to see about      it.  Every morning at five o’clock all the bells in the town      ring and every man who is able to carry a gun assembles in      some perminent place and from thence they go out into the      country to wait for the enemy.  Even clergymen are forced to      fight & Cousin Sam is in almost hourly fear of being made to      serve.  I received a letter from Martha Henderson just now.They are at present in Wiesbaden and Martha says that if her      relations were with her she would never again wish to leave      there, not even for America.  That I cannot understand for      no place can or will ever be the same to me as dear      Philadelphia.  But I am forgetting my determination to make      my letter short and although I am burning to go on I deny      myself for your good as I think a little correction will be      very beneficial to you so I will sign myself y
your ever      loving and for long letters begging friend
Anna

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1864-10-09
Title: 1864 October 9, Newport, to Elizabeth S. Cope, Awbury

Newport Oct 9th  1864, 1st day morn

Dear Sister–
I   recieved thy note (for I cannot call it a letter because it   contained so much nonsense) yester-day morning; but I did   not say poo! because I had an idea it was from Rachel or at   least hoped it did not contain nonsense.  I was glad to   recieve such information as thy note contained, & thought it   was a great compliment to be called handsome by sombody,   although I do not think father was much complimented by   having his hair called an iron gray color; unfortunatly I   did not lose my heart with her, although I think I must have   seen her & was very sorry I could not go to meting but my   knee was not equal to it.  I could have found some time to   write to you or thee butI have been very lazy since I have been here.  I delivered   thy message to Father (about Dr Thomas) but fear he has   forgotten about it, so I will remind him of it & now I must   close for I am getting lazy & will tell thee what we are   doing when there is some thing to tell about of more   consequence.  I believe Mother intends writing a   P.S.
Affec thy brother
TP. Cope Jr
P.S.  when I   said you on the first page near the bottom I meat Rachel &   thyself.  TP Cope Jr.

I am sorry there should be any   mistake about Dr. Thomas  I thought I told you, you would   have to send him word when you were ready to begin  You had   better tell him of myabsence from home so that he may understand why he was not   called on before.  So much for that - the burden of my   [----] is “painting.”  It is the burden on my mind & must of   course show itself in words.  Uncle Tom sent me word that he   had expressed a sample of color which Craig has prepared for   our inspection.  I suppose we may get the package tomorrow –   but what troubles me is the delay – Craig said he would have   it all done so we could come back the 20th.  If he has got   to put on two coats after he hears from us I fear he will   not be ready for us.  We are getting tired of this plan &   anxious to know whether there will be any difficulty about   getting intoour house on the 22nd.  Seventh day week - We have to engage   Staterooms two weeks before to get good ones & I intend   tomorrow to engage them for 6th day the 21st & if you find   the house cannot be got ready by that time you will please   send us word at once so that we can disengage the rooms.    Perhaps if Craig can not get all done & dry he can have the   kitchen & back passages finished & if the last coat is on   the parlors &c we might come in before it is dry–  I feel   sorry to have filled up Toms sheet with nothing but such a   message – try to do better next time.  It has been blowing   strong from the N.W. all day & is cold as charity Alf &   Hazen went to meeting with me in the morning & your   [br]other in the afternoon but its dull work here either   at the larger or smaller body Yankee self conceit shows   nowhere more. 


Elizabeth S. Cope
