----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Annette Cope:  1843-1916
Date: 1865-03-27
Title: 1865 March 27 to My dearest children

Second day morn  3. 27.

My dearest children
I have   just come home from school & found yr. letter on the card   plate in the entry, wh. is where they always put them, so we   can be refreshed by the sight the moment we get in, & I was   refreshed I assure you.  Miss Field gets a great many & I   began to feel as if it was quite time for me to be having my   turn too.  You must remember that I never was befor so   entirely among strangers. & that your letters now will be my   best substitutes for home, as I shall depend on them greatly   I tried to write yesterday but did not make out much.  It   was my first 1st day in Baltimore.  Do you remember last 1st   day, when [were] were walking on the piazza & wondering   whether I shd. be here?  I did not much think I shd. then   but it seems I am.  Went to meeting yesterday morn. wh. I   quite enjoyed.  The only faces that I had ever seen before   were Deborah Thomas, Margy Coale & Tammie Miller.  I was   introduced to lots of others who were all very kind, & said   they were coming to see me.  There was a frd. named Elicott   & her two sisters who I think said they knew Mother.  We had   a sermon [fmr.] Deba  Thomas, the Dr, & one or two others.    After meeting in the aftnoon I set out to take a walk & was   joined by a young lady named Mary Elicott & & Jesse, who   took me a beautiful walk out to whats called theReservoir, where there is a fountain and a splendid view of   green hills & also of the distant waters of the bay, as well   as of parts of the city.  & yet it was not a walk of more   than a mile I shd. think
Baltimore is certainly a   beautiful place & I never realized before so fully what an   advantage what an advantage a hilly city possesses over a   flat one.  It quite throws Philada into the shade as far as   beauty is concerned.  There is such a refreshing variety in   the style of the houses, & other [buildings] & the hills   show them off to great advantage.  Charles St. seems to be   one of the most aristocratic in wh. the monument is   situated, a very beautiful column of white marble, 170 ft   high wh. as it stands upon a hill serves as a land mark for   a long distance round.  as you ascend the street with the   monument towering high above you the stars & stripes   floating over it & the city as you catch glimpses of it at   certain points apparently beneath you, the effect is very   imposing.  I think Phila. wld. strike one as flat after   this.  It has its advantages tho’.
Jesse has not come to   take us any rides yet.  tho he has promised to.  They say he   is very attentive to a certain – young lady here so we shall   not be so likely to derive as much benefit.  [---]. He has   been very polite so far.  & the ladies of the house are   continually laying plans for our entertainment wh. is   exceedingly kind in them.  I really feel more at home here   than I wd with some relations!Miss Talbot who is the housekeeper is one of the easy   talkative kind & makes me think a little of Mary Sayne.    Only far Superior.  they are exceedingly informal & get up &   wait on table & clear the things away in what thee, Nat,   wld. call a very shocking manner, but they are perfect   ladies for all – hospitable & fond of society, & they seem   to have a great many pleasant frds.  Their one girl is not   the most efficient cook in the world but I have such a good   appetite that I get along very well, – I feel most as hungry   as when I get home frm. school as I remember I used to when   I was a scholar.  We have breakfast about 7 1/2 go to sch.   about 8 1/4.  it is only 10 min. walk — get home about 1.   pretty tired with the 4 hrs. standing & ready to lie down   till dinner time at 2 1/2.  After dinner we get dressed & go   out or see company.  We most always have one or two callers.   at 7 again we have tea & then get our work and sit in the   parlor, & wonder who is coming when the bell rings.  Miss   Field I like exceedingly.  She is a Presbyterian & a very   superior girl I shd. think so that in the matter of   companionship I need to have had fewer fears and   trepidations than I had
The school duties are not long   but pretty arduous while they last.  We have to stand nearly   all the time.  At least the model teachers do, but we   inferiors take the liberty of popping downoccasionally, but it is at the risk of [good] order for   there are so many in the room that unless you stand up to   it, & keep your eye on all 30 or 40 at once they are very   apt to get wrong in the back seats.  One of the first points   is to get [them] disciplined.  Mr Waterman the principal –   drills his class just as you wld. soldiers makes them fold   their arms put out one foot & finally stand up just as a   general wld. his troops, & when school is dismissed they   file out in quite an imposing manner.  That is to teach them   obedience I suppose, wh. is a great point gained.  They also   teach them a kind of gymnastic exercises by way of   recreation. as they have no place to play & consequently no   regular recess or almost none.  Mine is the next to the   smallest class. & only studys reading & spelling in words of   4 or 5 letters wh. is not very interesting.  I have’nt   discovered that there are any specially smart or Topsy like   ones among them.  We dont stop to talk or get acquainted   much but just keep them doing something or other the whole   time.  Upon the whole I enjoy the effect of the work very   much. & outside of that it is all very pleasant.
Jesse   has just called in a splendid barouche to ask for Miss F or   I to ride.  As I had’nt finished my letter & she had’nt been   out for sev. days I persuaded her to go.  Yesterday was the   first pleasant one we have had. since I have been here.  I   was so sorry I took my purple dress out.  It is just what I   want this cool weather for afternoons.  I want twice as many   clothes here as at home.  Caroline dont thee want to be   benevolent and cut me out a pair of those round cuffs like   thee made me for undersleeves.  Thee can work the button   holes, & have them starched & ironed.  I have a pair of   sleevesthat I can sew them on.  I wish if you shd. have any   opportunity you wld. send me my old blk silk body wh. hangs   in the back room closet.  Tammy Miller is going to P   tomorrow & out to Mary Morris’ so I told her to tell you   that she saw the school “mam”  Give my love to Cousin Frank   & Mary  Tell Cousin Mary I had the pleasure of seeing her   mother & I think her father yesterday.  Give my love to   Cous. Sarah & to Tom & Harry & to all Aunt Carolines & any   other enquiring frds.
I have written you a lengthy   epistle I hope there’ll be an exception in favor of mistakes   & bad writing as I have written lying on my back  I was so   very tired this morning that I was too lazy to sit up.  I do   not get much time to [sun] as my room is too cold to sit in   & they do not seem to bring their sewing into the parlor   much.  With much love

Your affec
Sister C

I   am going to send you a drawing of my house when I get time   so you can imagine how things are a little better.  I hope   Edgar will get the drafting business all settled,   satisfactorily

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Taber:  1822-1887
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1841-02-28
Title: 1841 February 28, New Bedford, to Frank, Philada.

New Bedford 2 mo 28 1841

Dear Frank

Among the   many sins of omission & commission with which my Conscience   has been burdened of late – none has laid harder on my   stomach to speak in a physiological metap[h]or than my not   having answered [thine] epistle of – mo. – 1840.  This sheet   then intended as a peace offering and mediator for past   offences “by-gones” comes to thee by the hands of Geo. H.   Dunbar – (a young man of our religious denomination-   somewhat diligent attender of meeting – (where He in company   with the majority of our young men occupies the seat   fronting the women friends – pardon the digression but the   fact is worth recording that as the Mahometan prays with his   face towards Mecca – thou canst draw the parallel) not so   much distinguished as would be best for plainness of speech.   [behavi] and apparel – and inheriting with the rest of us   some failings I fear from Father Adam - ) who is to pass   thro Philada. on his way to Haverford and then to France in   a New Lock Haven packet next week. – A poet moreover and   somewhat unique personage. & can either roar like a lion or   a sucking dove at his pleasure – rhyme to the moon or swear   like a pirate. – I don’t know how long he stays in Philada.   but if you fall in with him you’ll know him.

The   greatest attraction in these parts this winter - & which   must take its share of the blame of having kept me from   attending to my Philada correspondence is a new periodical   entitled “L’Entreprise” which has originated among us and   has claimed a goodly portion of my leisure
The great   charm about you must know is that we have Lady contributors   – Gertrude Hussey “Murray” quondam –
with sundry & divers others – too tedious to mention as the   advertisements would say – with a respectable lot of   Quak[er] lady make considerable of a coterie. – 
Dr Hardy   undertook to join but whether he did not succeed [to] his   mind or whether his practice is too extensive & laborious to   admit of his wasting his time so idly I know not – but he   has not yet contributed – This much however must be said of   him whether through his intrinsic merits or accidental   circumstances he has in fact succeeded in getting into an   extraordinary practice and seems likely to settle down here   and live easy. – Ah!  Francis if I were only as goodlooking   a young man as thou art I should then think that Destiny had   cut me (too) out for a Doctor
Ben Hardy’s whiskers were   always irresistible – but a new bobwig which I find I had   the honor of bringing home from Philada. in one of those   boxes you remember – that new bobwig with the [portage] of   which I was so unconsciously honored – that new bobwig is   worth a thousand dollars a year to him – 

The old   gentleman that was at our house a little while since from   Salem – gave us a few particulars in Ben’s history that will   be useful to any one who shall hearafter have the honor of   compiling his biography – It seems that such was his   enterprise and such too his earnest zeal in the laudable   task of pleasing the women even in early life that after   having studied the art of Crispin in his nativevillage of Kennebunk he was at the pains of a journey and   long residence at Lyme to be initiated into the art &   mystery of making woman’s shoes

How instructive the   lesson that such heroism and model-gallantry teaches –   Frank! that mans life is a lesson to all posterity – Raised   very probably on a [shingle] in that bleak [-egion]   described so emphatically by the poet – 
“Away down East   dere
[Clow] [by] de moon”

Title: 1847, August 10, to My dear Mary

Newport 8 mo 10th / 47
      
      My dear Mary
      
      Frank has been writing to William this morning, and has most likely advised you on all points of interest.- you probably know by this time, that we are all in a good state of health, and we hope that our sister Susan is improving, tho' she still has some head-ache.  Frank & cousin Wistar are very kind and devote themselves almost exclusively to contributing to her comfort & pleasure in every way.  F is devoted to Susan and does evey thing in his power to promote the improvement of her health, his kindness is unparalleled: everything is done for us, and we have nothing to do, but join in the pleasant plans laid out for us.- Elizy H & Susan were concluding before dinner, that they accomplished very little of any thing on account of the time occupied in changing their dresses for the different labors of the day.- About ten in the morning they prepare for bathing or rather we do when Susan does not go-
      /
      not arrive on 7th day tho' we intend to do so if possible.  the Boat did not leave until 5 o'clock this morning.  I expect the irregular lately.- with much love
      aff thy sister Anne
      Susan will accompany us to Hazard's this afternoon
      she is resting since her bath.then return about 12 o'clock.  rest, until time to away for dinner, then about 5 o'clock, a different costume must necessarily be adapted for Sailing especially when the boats, are slightly fishy & a little dirty.- then we come home about ten-time or little past, and another change must be made to appear at [---] which [---] will suffice for the evening.- but all this is done in a good hurry and I cannot say it consumes much time.- I believe I have nothing new to tell thee, and indeed, I expect it would be very puzzling to think of any such thing when Cousin Wistar is of the party, for he writes home to frequently, and describes every thing that seems with so much minuteness, that if you are favored with the perusal of his epistles, ours must seem quite commonplace; this is my conjecture, as we joke Wistar & Sue both, about writing so often.- Only to think- Sixth day evening we leave, if a storm or fog does not prevent us, and Tom has concluded to remain, and return with us last evening tho' fog was so dense that the Bay-State" did not go out, and now we have every prospect, of the same thick state of the atmosphere for this evening consequently.  it seemed hardly worth while for Tom to leave before we did.- The Massachusetts arrived here with Mr. Williams on board, about 11 o'clock thismorning having been lying off Point Judith, even since four o'clock.  Susan & Lizzie went to bathe this morning with F & Wistar leaving me at home to pass the time as I could.  Tom & Moses had gone fishing, and I was quiet enough.  Susan though it best notwithstanding your message, to try the [---] three times faithfully as the Dr directed, and I hope she will not be any worse for it, and perhaps it may strengthen her afterwards.  She says she likes it very much while in the water, but she feels pretty weak for sometime afterwards.  we think she is the best judge for what is best for her, and she does exactly what she wished in the Bathing line; Frank takes her in, giving her three waves as directed, he said the water was very warm & pleasant this morning.  I quite long to go in again but fear I shall not have an opportunity of going more than once or twice more before I leave.- It suits Elizy Hacker exactly, she feels a little tired after coming out, but it seems to brance & strenghthen her, and shee looks better I think in this little time of our [---] here.  I do hope her father will telegraph her to remain with Sue, if the letter does not arrive in time to answer it before our leave.- yester afternoon we were out Sailing in the bay, landed on one of the [dumpling?] rocks gathered some sprigs of green to press, and enjoyedthe novelty of it highly, it was really very pleasant, altho' by the time we returned, our blanket shawls were almost white with the fog.  Sailing seems to suit Susan, very well, but I think clear weather as a general thing is preferable to her.- This afternoon we think of calling at fr'd Hazard’s, we spent a pleasant evening there last Sixth day.  they are certainly a delightful family. Ann[a/e?] Hazard called here this morning with S & A Jenkins who are still staying with them – we intend riding out to see fr'd Jenkins before we go.- 4th day morn.  I was obliged to leave this shut hastily yesterday afternoon, as Thomas Hazard & his wife called upon us inviting us to spend this afternoon with them which we intend doing.  Elizy & Frank are much disappointed I believe in Fanny H’s beauty, but they must see her at [---] before they fully decide.  She is perfect at home.- my love to all- Susan and Lizzie are taking a nap before dinner, and I cannot disturb them now.- there is a thick fog over they bay now 12 at noon, and it will [---] increase- Tom could not have gone last night in consequence of the bay as the boat did not leave, and perhaps it is as well for him to wait for us.  Frank & myself do not think it proper to leave here in a fog or storm and Tom must not think it strange if we do

Title: 1859 August 14, Awbury, to mother

Awbury 8 mo 14th 1859
   
   Dear mother
   
   I wrote a few hasty lines to Frank this afternoon which brother Thomas did not succeed in sending to you, as the Germantown post-office he found was not open on First-day, giving you the good news that sister E. has another boy, a very fine-looking child, and the tenth grandson, but as yet without a name, which is not decided upon, indeed, I have not heard one suggestion, only it is to be a fancy name, and Lizzie leaves it to bro' Thomas select.  Sister E. desires her love, and wishes me to say to thee, that she is very comfortable, this evening; and the Doctor says she is doing as well as is possible.  The child was born at 1/2 past 7 o'clock this morning, and the nurse came about 9.  Thomas sent to town for her early, and she came as soon as shecould, but it did not make any difference as the Doctor thought Mary Sixsmith was entirely competent to attent to all that was needed, and she proved so.
   Bro’ Thomas took Harry, Tom & Willy to meeting, and afternoon left our two boys at father’s to dine, and went for them to return home towards evening.  The house seems quite lonely and deserted now, and company at the tea-table was very slim this evening, only three, Thomas, Harry & myself.
   Ellie Stokes with little Ellie left for Riverton yesterday afternoon.  Ellie ad been staying with us since 6th day morning.
   Sister Susan and Virginia also went home yesterday afternoon, they enjoyed their visit with us very much, and it was very pleasant to us to have them, as we miss you all so much.   The children have kept pretty well, tho' yesterday was an oppressively warm day here, so damp & close, but to day it is lovely, tho' quite warm.-
   I hope you are all enjoying the sea-breezes notwithstanding the hard beds, which must be quite a draw-back to thecomfort of some of you.  How is Anne?  Sister Lizzie wished me to mention, that she hopes Anne will drink plenty of [---] wine as it was particularly recommended to Clemmie by Dr. [Meigs?], at one time as being very beneficial, as it has the peculiar quality of enriching the blood, and he ordered her to take a tumbler full a day.  Lizzie thinks Frank had better take some more of it to Atlantic City for her on 4th day, when he comes up.  Please give my love to her, also to father, Emma, and sister Lizzie Brown.  Dr Rhoads mentioned this morning that Margaret Eliz expected to go to the sea-shore tomorrow in company with Augustus Wilson, and some one else whose name I did not quite understand.  I hope you may meet with her.-   
   affectionately thy daughter
   
   Anna S. Cope

Title: 1880 February 8, Cannes, to Alexis

Cannes Feb. 8. 1880.
   
   Dear Alexis,
   
   We recd thy letter of Jan. 16th a few days since, & have been thinking over thy proposition.  It wd. be nice to be able to spend part of our summers in Susquehanna Co particularly if you make it your home, but we have not been looking forwarrd to keeping house in our return.  I do not want to live at Connymead again, (indeed I do not think any of us want to; unless we cd. find some one to live with us)  It was too lonely, particularly for me.  & if we did not keep house there in winter, we cd. not keep very well keep house in summer.  How or where we shall live when we go home, I do not know.  Indeed the uncertainties of the future, & what it will be best to do, often weighs upon my mind.  Connymead is no placefor any body to live who wants to be a Friend, or who has any preference for their ways.  Life there was a continual struggle wh. I have no desire to renew, & perhaps we shall never know again [ever/even?] that semblance of a home.  I hope if thee and Lily picked to bring your children up as Friends, you may be able to keep them in a community where Friends live.  For it is pretty hard for a young person who has been uninstructed in what are considered the accomplishments of life to have to live where these are considered all important, & are the chief recupations of those by whom you are surrounded.  It requires a good deal of strength of character to be able to live alone, I [---], & Friends must always do it more or less when they go out from among their own people.  When one has not been brought to play on the piano or sing or draw, or paint, or evento play cards- a not very valuable accomplishment certainly- & yet one in wh. English people who are both intelligent & sensible, seem to while away at least a fourth part of their waking hours; & never to tire of- When I say, one has never been instructed in any of these things, one feels as if one ought to be at least where they are not the chief employment of life.  Of course when living in a delightful pension on the Riviera- one is not supposed to be exactly fulfilling the normal conditions of existence- Existence here (the physical part of it) seems too delightful to be long continued, & I have wonder since we have been here how long 14 human beings could live together, without apparently a shadow of sorrow or anxiety to disturb the delightful days, which seem, to glide away without a cloud either inward or outward, to mar their peacefulness such skies, & such weather , & such walks as we have- only one littleshower in all the two months we have been here- It is the most perfect thing in weather certainly, that we have ever experienced.  If we had come last winter we shd  not have had the same experience of it, for it rained very much even here.  But I have digressed widely from the subject upon wh. I intended to write, [---] the old house of Woodbourne.  Whatever may be my inclincation with regard to it, (& I certainly shd. like very much the idea of being able to live somewhere near you).  I do not thonk C & A have any desire to undertake housekeeping there.  The life of a travelling artist- or even of the traveller, minus the artist- in these delightful regions & pensions where have all the comforts of home without its cares, does not intend to inspire you with a desire to renew the contest with the [biddy?]- in art less America. If only some plan cd. be devised by wh. Woodbourne cd. be converted into a pension.  I have no doubt we shd. spend a good deal of our time there, & shd. think the old house wd. need an immense amount of repairing, & as to the old chairs of the Conklin family, I feel as if I had lost my interest in them & I shd. not think they wd. be worth the sum they mentioned.  It is provoking to have to buy what is your own.  (see 4th page of A's letter)Can thee tell us who paid the drivers on our Naples [---] wh. were packed in the same box with P.C.G.'s- we asked thee to do it & I suppose thee must have- but we have never heard.If not paid
   
   Please pay to the order of Francis C. Haines (who may be too modest to speak of it) 9 francs 15 centimes, as near as you can come at it.
   
   Clementine CopeAlexis T Cope
   
   (Haines St Germantown)
   
   Philadelphia
   Etats-Unis d'Ameriq

Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1880-03-21
Title: 1880 March 21, Hotel de la Paix, Rome, to Lily

March. 21. 1880.
   
   My dear Lily, Behold us in Rome once more!- dear delightful bewitching Rome- The city of cities- I cannot tell with what delight I find myself again threading its labyrinths & wandering amidst its ruins.  We reached here the 6th of March, having left Mentone 2 days before, passing one night in Genoa & thence by the midnight train to Rome.  This being the only train (owing to their very insane & uncomfortable arrangements) wh. gets you here at a respectable hour.  It was a very uncomfortable journey- but then we were coming to- Rome!!  We made a sojourn of two weeks only, at Dr. Müllers- Mentone we thought lovely- Dr M’s house not altogether so.  It is not happily [---] being at the end of one of thos dried up rivers, down wh. torrents of cold airrushed from the mountains.  We thought it much colder & damper than either Cannes or Nice.  & then there was a slight suggestion of boarding school about the household arrangements- & most for much open warfare between the Dr & his spouse to be altogether agreeable.  It is a great pity they have not learned to control their tempers a little in the presence of their guests at least- for at times it was rather to peppery to be pleasant.  Fortunately the storms seemed to be not very lasting.  & they were generally jolly enough- & in fact much more jolly then most people would be who were at their wits ends to make two ends meet.  A lady who was staying there with her family (pretty much as a matter of charity I fancy) told me they were over head & ears in debt & that she had come to the conclusion there was no use in trying to help them, as they never cd. keep any money- altho' they ask a very high price for their accomodations.  The excursions at Mentone were truly lovely, & the Dr. was alwaysready to take us.  In fact we thought he quite preferred the ladies to the boys for he seemed quite put out once or twice at our declining to go.  but they were too hard for me, & I did none of the very long ones.  I shd. think however for those who were up to that sort of thing, Mentone would be one of the most delightful of the Riviera towns, tho' each one of them seems to have its own peculiar charms.  The weather was very warm when we got to Rome, & took the back bone out of me terribly- It however soon changed from mild, to cool, clear & bracing & the last 10 days have been delicious- I never was able to do so much walking in Rome before, & on spring afternoons such as these what luxury cd. be greater than to drive or to wander at will among the ruins all golden in the light of the declining sun- or to watch the funny old models in their gay rags & tatters- (wh. seem to [---] the spirit of the twins-) hanging themselves out on the Spanish Steps to be admiredwith all the rest.  Surely there is no place on earth like Rome.  Last first day was the kings birthday & there was a grand review- & the king & queen & the [---] kindly [---] themselves , to our admiring gaze in the Borghese. It was quite too gay & disappointing to be proper for 1st day.  The usual ceremonies of holy week begin to day, wh. is Palm Sunday.  We did not attend at S. Peters, thinking last year it was rather a sell.  I went to the little Italian [Waldensian] Church, a great contrast indeed to the pomp & [---] of the great Cathedral.  We had got back to our old Hotel della Pace, where we were twice last winter.  We went first to another but did not like it, & so came here, where we found some friends of last summer (the Müllers).  It is a good central situation.  We look down upon the Piazza Barberinni & the old Tritan who is always blowing his stream of water into the air, & then catching it again all over his head & back wh. must be pretty well washed in all the years that it has been trickling over him.  Then on the other side of the street2
   
   is the Barberrini Pal.  & sad eyed Beatrice.  By way of variety the other day we went to one of Miss Brewsters receptions.  It was a kind of afternoon tea fight, of [---] & other distinguished persons like ourselves.  Tea, wine, & talk & many beautiful things to look at.   

   Next, we want to go with her.  Forbes the archaeologist to hear tge Forum explained on the latest authorities.  His explanations one said to be intensely interesting.  In fact Rome is so dissipating- there is such an infinity to see & to read & to learn that it is most distracting.  I hope we shall be here three or four weeks longer at least.  In fact it spoils you so for every thing else that it does’nt seem worth while to go any where afterwards.
   
   I ought to have told thee before, how glad I was to get thine & Agnes' letter at Mentone.  I was greatly struck with the advance of the latter's ideas since her first epistle wh. I have carried ever since, in the pocket of my satchel& wh. was composed mostly of kisses.  I see she is now advancing to the doll & the baby house interests of the little girl-hood.  The way the ideas were put together was very amusing- & the circumstantial acct. of the flight of the nurses & the changing reigns of the lady’s of the nursery very graphic.  Give her a kiss, & tell her Auntie has very much obliged for her letter & thought it very interesting.  Also that she must’not cut any more holes in her apron with her little scissors, but must make some nice little paper dresses for the paper dollys that Aunty sent in the letter.   

   22nd.  Just returned from our excursion to the Forum with Mr Forbes- two hours rummage amoung the ruins- intensely interesting- back nearly broken- head ditto.  General conglomeration of podiums, Tabulariums, demolished temples & roman emperors- but quite worth the 4 francs wh. is the price per head at wh. Mr F. deals out his information.  He has been on the spot for some years & actually seen & superintended the excavations- so of course knows a great deal about it, & sees it in a very interesting way- much more so than [Hare?], who is a dreadfully guide booky old fellow I think- Am too tired to write more   

   Please tell Alexis that the letters of credit came a few days since, & we are much obliged for his attention to them.  Love to all.  Tell Cousin Anna I am going yo ans. her letter as soon as I can find time.  Thy affectionate Sister   

   C.C.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas) Cope:  1850-1883
Date: 1880-07-11
Title: 1880 July 11, Geneva, to Alexis

Geneva, July 11, 1880
   
   Dear Alexis,
   
   I want to ask thee a question.  Is it necessary in order to effect a division of our property (I mean such a division as shall give thee thy portion at Connymead) is it necessary that I return to America in the Autumn with C & A, as it has been our intention to do, (or at least theirs)?  For myself I have not entirely decided, tho' we have partly paid our passages for the 6th Nov. in the steamer "Illinois", on condition that we can change if it seems best to another vessel of the line.  It is late to sail, but there seemed to be no good steamer between the first week of October& the last, & as there will be no moonlight the last of October we thought it wd. be best to wait until the next moon.   

   There are many reasons why I shd. like to return in the Autumn, but the prospect of boarding in Phila is not very attractive, & of keeping house at Connymead still less so- indeed I shd. never be willing to undertake the latter again unless circumstances were very much changed.  C & A prefer the former.  If they were willing to keep house or even to board near Germantown, where we could have the enjoyment of the children, I shd. come home with the greatest pleasure.   

   But this I expect they will never wish to do.  So that until I can think of some way for me to live in that part of the world.  It seems as if I might almost as well stay here- for boardingin Phila wd. not be much better as far as you are concerned.   

   The thought of staying by myself seems a little dismal, but I cd. stay very well in the family where we now are & be as well cared for as I cd. expect or wish to by, by strangers.  Then there is an elderly lady (whom we have met several times (& I think have spoken of) Miss Wetherill, Jno. Price Wetherills dhr, of Phila) who has asked me to join her party, consisting of her niece & [Pebers?] of Phila.  We were with them 8 weeks in Rome & found them very pleasant.  So I could stay very well if I wanted to- Tell me how the idea strikes you, with regard to the business- as, if my presence is necessary to the accomplishment of it, that wd. decide the question.   

   We still continue in Geneva & still continue to like exceedingly our french family.  We intended in coming, to stay a month & then go to the Mts.  But the weather has been almost too cool for anygreat heights, & this, so far (I dont know how it may be in August) seems a happy medium.  We have had a few warmish days, but for the most part it has been a delightful summer climate.  Then too we have had so much gadding about, that we enjoy the quiet & the thought that we are learning something.   

   How often I wish I cd. have Agnes here for a few months.  It would do for her, what years of study at home cannot do for any body.  I never knew before how badly, or rather how little we had been taught at home, how to pronounce french.  Then too this is such a nice family where it wd. be so safe to place a child.  Their ideas about education are good- & they have so much simplicity in their ways & manners- they seem almost like those of friends.  The children have never been allowed to go to the opera or the theater- tho' they have one, within a few doors of them.  Every evening before going to bed, we have a little "culbe"- Madam Duproix reads out of a big bible- & then makes a little extemporaneous prayer- so very simple, that one cannot help but feel as if it came from the heart; After this, we separate for the night with much hand-shaking and many "[---]" & "[---]" & "[---]" &c- The great objection to the french is that they have to say so much about every little thing & are really too polite for comfort.  I think each person at the table says "par-r-r-don"- about 50 times at each meal (with a very great trill to the r- & a very great accent on the last syllable) if all this wasn't accompanied with real kindness of heart (as in this case) one wd. become "very fatigued" of it.   

   We suppose that you are now at Montrose tho' we dont know it.  It has been a perfect age since anyone has written from Awbury.  I sent cous. FRC a letter containing a cheque about5 weeks since & having rec'd no acknowledgement fear it has been confiscated, or that he is not well.  We are anxious to hear how you perform'd the journey & how Montrose goes.  Netty is writing to Lilly as I will not write now 
   
   with much love to her & the children
   
   they aff. sister C :

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  E. D. (Edward Drinker) Cope:  1840-1897
Recipient:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903

Title: 1865 April 20, Haverford, to Clemmy

Haverford 4 mo 20 1865
   
   My dear Cousin Clemmy
   
   My thoughts have been with thee at various times since thy departure from our neighborhood, and I have been inclined to reproach myself for not having written;- but perhaps it is well enough, for there is no telling what effect in one way, things said out of season, may have, more than what may result in the other direction from things said in season.  Much conversation on religious matters thee will agree with me, is under some circumstances disadvantagious; as when deeds, acts, and strivings are the more needful thing.   

   The great purpose and Love of Christ have been much in my mind in remembering a former time of bitterness and grief, and how he wiped away such tears frommy eyes though he opened their fountains again for gratitude and joy: and how new roles and a new strength were granted me.  And to attain this what is not worthy to be passed through? and what suffered and endured?  Truly "men ought always to pray and not to faint" "Be thou fruitful and I will give thee a crown of life."  and how little worthy we are of it ever then.  We know how that "this brief suffering which [---] but for a moment, worked for us a far more eternal might of glory."  How the business of life tends to wear off the strong gratitude and love which a little view of the glory and goodness of our Maker causes to swell and burn in their heart; and how as it grows dimmer, and we further from the shadow of his wing [---]  words and hard judgements creepin.  But can any forget that "with what judgement ye judge ye shall be judged".  But we must continually return to the fountain head, if perhaps He will again bless us, and "cause our heart to burn within us", how low do we then sink, in the light of glory [---], and immesurable greatness.  In such a state of mind are we fit to do out duty with pleasure, and find ourselves still unprofitable servants, with rejoicing, for "Grant what thou wilt, without thee I am poor, but with thee I am rich, take what thou wilt away."  What this duty is, is the real difficulty, this is the fight to test the shield of faith, and the preparation of the Gospel of Peace.May we both bear it well, doing the work- or some work, well & not beating the air.  But this and many other weak things/5/22 Lilly was married last 5th day.  I was second groomsman with Martha Garrett.  All passed off very pleasantly.  The meeting was uncommonly favored: I have not often when in so undeserving a state (but we are that at all times) had such a heart-opening granted, and the ministers were favored with true fervency and spoke very encouragingly and usefully to the pair just married, and to the others.  Samuel Emlen made a prayer which I have seldom heard excelled in strength of feeling.   

   Thy letter thro' Alexis was very acceptable.  I hope thee may feel thy reward either in connection with or independent of results.  If thee feels dull about it sometimes- thee will remember that all men do that.  I certainly do when I look at results (which I needn't do if I do mybest).
   
   The committee of managers are putting a house in order for me here.  Perhaps thee remembers a small establishment by the Rail Road where Joseph Harlan formerly lived.  With a few alterations it will be a very nice home.  The breast of the pond where the front lane passes will probably be strengthened, and the water backed nearer the Rail R. so as to make a very pretty sheet.  I will not forget to send thee an invitation in time.  Does thee want anything in the book line,- or other kind of assistance?  I would like to hear more of thy school and its working.
   
   Believe me thy
   affectionate cousin
   
   Edw. D. Cope
   
   Annie sends her love with mine.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872

Title: 1833 July [June] 25, Bloomsdale, to William D. Cope

Bloomsdale July [June] 25th. 1833.
   
   Thee will probably be somewhat surprised in receiving a communication from me, in reply to thine- but I have determined notwithstanding my extreme diffidence to employ pen & paper- in order- if possible to dispel some unpleasant and I may ass unhappy associations connected with thy last visit.  That I did feel and evince some repugnance to having a private conversation with thee- I freely acknowledge.  Why I did so- it is impossible for me to explain- unless it was because I supposed the one- we had previously had- was sufficient to elucidate all difficulties- and therefore a second one useless.- I regret now such a thought should have entered my mind- and why I felt it painful- to have a further explanation- when I saw it wd. afford thee a satisfaction- is a mystery I do not yet understand; but as all regrets are unavailing- I will not strengthen them by indulging in, or dwelling upon them.-  That my manners may have appeared in some instances- as they says, cold and repulsive, I am sensible- without my intending them to have that effect, at any rate- let me assure thee, it was very far from my intention, to wound or hurt thy feelings for even as I wd. like my own respected- have I endeavoured to consider thine.------ I certainly meant to imply from what I said- I considered thee in fault, in not having sent me any intimation of thy feelings with resepct to me, throughout the whole seven months of thy absense; most assuredly- absense & silence were never calculated to cherish and increase a preference, which under different- and more auspicious circumstances might have arisen; & as thee gave me no intimation I was not forgotten- I had no alternative left, but to believe as I did- thee had abandoned all idea of further intercourse- well then- considering myself slighted, and neglected, how could reserve and coldness of manner be entirely avoided?  In extending my forgiveness, I really thought I had something to forgive- but it seems- according to the light in which thee views it- there was no fault committed- and consequenlty no "need of forgiveness."  However different thy views of human nature- and the ways of the world, are from my own- I must still see those actions- in the light of errors- but will consider them as unintentional- and arising from inexperience.  With respect to our correspondence motives of delicacy alone- prevented me from consenting to it- If thee had thought correctly about it- theewd. have supposed, as our friendship & intimacy advanced those feelings- wd. have been overcome- and however great an effort I still think it wd. be- to maintain a correspondence with a gentleman even after an engagement, I should consider it a duty- an obligation, not to be dispensed with.-  I do not remember thy suggesting any other mode of intercourse between us- than the one just spoken of- at all events neither of those mentioned by thee- wd. have been very suitable, or meet with my concurrence.  I acquit myself- if thee will not do it- of all design at "flirtation & coquetry," however some of my sex may indulge in it at the expense of yours- I am very sure- I do not belong to that class of cruel coquettes- who make a boast of their conquests- & offer encouragement where none is meant.  In writing this letter- I trust I am not guilt of an improper act- I thought considering all things- it was nothing more than thy due- & in doing it- my mind which was before ill at ease- is put comparatively at rest.-  I beg thee will destroy this letter- and forget anything but friendship ever passed between us.-  I have now only to add an assurance of respect & esteem & how earnestly I wish thy happiness, thee can never know, unless thee can read the heart of thy sincere friend
   S.....
   
   No eye but thy own must rest upon the contents of this sheet.6.

   William D. Cope.
   Care T.P. Cope Esq.
   Fourth St.
   Philadelphia
   
   From S.
   dated July 25. 1833.- should be June 25.

Title: 1833 November 7, Philadelphia, to William Forster

Philada. 11 mo 7.  1833
   
   William Forster
   
   Esteemed friend
   
   It is probable that my son Alfred, who is about embarking for Madeira for the benefit of his health, may visit your country on his return homewards.  Should he do so, I have a desire that he should call on thee.  He would like to be made known to some friends in England, among whom he would prefer to spend his time while among you.  He is an exemplary member of the religious Society of Friends, & I shall feel greatly obliged by any act of kindness & attention which may be shown to him.
   
   thy friend
   
   Thos. P. CopeWilliam Forster
   
   Alfred Cope
   
   [Introductn to W. Forster]

Title: 1833 November 7, Philadelphia, to James Cropper

Philada. 11 mo 7.  1833
   
   James Cropper
   
   Dear friend
   
   My son Alfred is about to proceed to Madeira, where he designs to spend the winter, for the benefit of his health.  & as he will probably visit England before returning to America, I feel desirous of making thee acquainted with him.  He will of course incline to be principally among friends, while in your Country, & I shall feel much gratified by thy making him known to some of them.  He is an exemplary member of the religious Society of Friends, & will be found worthy of their regard.  I need scarcely add how much I shall be obliged by thy kind attentions to him-
    
   thine
   
   Thos. P. Cope[Introductn. to Ja's Cropper]
   
   James Cropper
   
   Alfred Cope   Liverpoolobtaining a wife- Henry will doubtless inform thee of thy having another niece.  Rebecca Harrison is very ill & her recovery doubtfull- poor [---], she has been sadly afflicted since last autumn- one disease succeeding to another- until she has been suddenly attacked with inflamatory rheumatism- first in all her limbs, then in the region of the heart.  Thy dear mother takes constant interest in thy welfare & has been anxiously looking for advices from thee- She is much rejoiced to hear of thy safety.  Jane Bettle still lingers-
   
   Other calls compel me to come to a close.
   
   Recommending thee to the protection of that Power, which alone can preserve us from evil- & insure peace & comfort
    
   I am affectionately
   
   Thos. P. Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Caroline R. (Caroline Rachel) Cope Yarnall:  1802-1881
Date: 1826-09-12
Title: 1826 September 12, Montrose, to Sisters, Philadelphia

Montrose 9mo 1826
   
   My Dear Sisters,
   
   Your acceptable communication of 29th [---] has reached me.  it was truly grateful to my soul to enter into fellow feeling with you, in traveling in th't to ye Heavenly Mansion to which it has pleased the Father of Spirits to call the purified spirit of our deceased Mother.  tho' in general, I wd. be ye last to discourage an affable, benevolent, & christian cheerfulness, yet I believe we will find that it is sometimes, "better to go to ye house of mourning than go to ye house of feasting": that sorrow is better than [---].  Pa[-]ly ye sadness of ye countenance ye heart is made better."  I trust that we shall often be refreshed when thus dwelling together in unity & sympathy.-  when I reflect upon ye great affection which our departed Mother manifested to us, upon ye moment when she has prest me to her bosom, when, she has evinced her maternal care by instilling into my mind, new & useful ideas, my feelings are affected with a sensability, which language is inadequate to convey to another.
   
   "Thy constant flow of love, that knew no fall,   Ne'er roughened by those cataracts & breaks,   That humour interposed, too often makes;-   This, still is legible in mem'ry's page,   And still will be so to my latest age."
   
   When my tho'ts are thus led, there seems to be a sacredness in them, which it wd. be sacrilige to interrupt by words or ye common occurances of ye world around us.  I experience a degree of that feeling which is produced in approaching ye Sanctuary of the Most High & calling to mind ye injunction, "The Lord is in his Holy Temple, let all the Earth, keep silence before him."
   
   I[---][Montrose P
   Sept 8th]
   
   9mo 12. 1826,
   
   Caroline R Cope
   care of Thomas P Cope
   Philadelphia

Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865

Title: 1828 December 12, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 12mo. 12-1828
   Dear Brother:
   
   Having an opp'y of writing, I will embrace it if it be only to thank thee for thy kind attention to the subjects mentioned in thine of 22 ult.-  ye mildness of ye season so far, will probably favor the operations of the Ches. & Del. Canal Co.-  I hope the Algonquin may do well at Savannah, as I observe by late a/cts, that no vessels were up there, & freights were brisk, tho' ye rates were low.  if it be not improper, nor too much trouble, please mention in writing to me, ye names of ye authors of any of the essays in "the Friend," that may come to thy knowledge.-  we have lately had a visit in these parts, from two hetorodox friends, Jno. Foulke of Quakertown, Bucks Co., & Salathiel Cleaver, of Montgomery Co.-  they had meetings at Friendsville, & in the neighborhood.  the Presbyterians expressedtheir satisfaction with the communications of J. Foulke.  I did not hear him speak in public, but understand that he did not speak on doctrinal points.  he is a man of venerable appearance, & his plain, communicative, unostentatious habits & manners, are calculated to preposess a stranger in his favour.  amongst other places, that he has visited, is ye settlement of the German Separatists in the Western country.  he speaks of their condition as very comfortable & flourishing.  the canal which is to connect the Lakes with the Ohio, passes thro' their land.
   
   I have just rec'd a letter from Caroline.  please give my love to her & tell her, that I will thank her to use my authority in contradicting any rumours of the kind to which she alludes.-  we are obliged to submit to the mortification of being ye subjects of them, but I think it is no more improper to contradict such, than any other incorrect reports.
   
   I have a paymt. to make before long, & expect to draw on the firm in a few days, to meet it, for about $200.-
   
   With love to all, I remain thy affectionate brother,
   Wm D Cope[Wm D Cope Woodbourne 12mo 12 1828
   
   Mtg at Friendsville
   Jno. Foulke &c
   
   12mo 20 1828-]
   Henry Cope
   Care of Thomas P Cope,
   no.36, North 4th St., or Walnut St. Wharf,
   Philadelphia.-
   
   p. Charles Chandler Esqe.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1829-07-13
Title: 1829 July 13, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 7 month 13th 1829
   Dear Brother:
   
   Thine of 29th ult. has been rece'd. I was pleased to learn that our parents were well, and hope that Edward & Alfred may be benefited by their proposed excursion and that thou may’st also find time to enjoy ye benefits of ye same kind of recreation. Ye country is now enlivened by visitors from ye City and Susquehanna Co. is favoured with a share of them. James Holly Biddle bro't back with them from Phila. their sisters Sarah Biddle and Mary Drinker, and E. Walker's family have ye company of ye widow Morris, and her daughters, Susan & Elizabeth. We have lately been favoured also with a visit from Joel Woolman and Alvin Keyser, appointed by Abington Quarterly Meeting to visit Friendsville Preparative Meeting. they appeared to be man of plain, unassuming humble manners, and were well received by both Hicksites & Orthodox. Cha's Shoemaker accompanied them as far as a Stroudsburg, where he became so ill, as to present his proceeding further. We have subsequently had a visit from Ja's Bell, another orthodox friend and an elder, appointed by Stroudsburg Monthly Meeting.
    
    Dan'l Stroud has been indisposed, or he also wd. probably have visited this part of his flock.  he occasionally writes excellent letters of advice to afford thee an idea of his decisive and at the same time affectionate letters of language & manner, I will give thee an extract from one of them, recently addressed to E. Walker: "distressing as is ye fact, yet it certainly is the case, that the Hicksites are a distinct Society from Friends, and ye separation proceeded from ye leaders of that seccession having become corrupted with anti-christian doctrines, mostly Socinian, but compounded with some other speculative notions, made up into bills to suit ye subjects to whom they were to be administered, and gilt with specious professions of great spirituality, to captivate members and professors with Friends. this with various practices, such as are too commonly used in electioneering, have beguiled & seduced many, who have not or had not previously embraced those awfully dreadful notions, not fitting to be styled doctrines, when we are speaking of religion, and whether these will become leavened into the mass of infidelity with their leaders, or separate from them remains among the things which futurity must disclose. that thou & I, and ye dear children Providentially entrusted to our care, may be preserved from this direful contagion, I have earnestly craved, feeling some hope, that we may resist every temptation that may beset us, to unsettle us and loss about with every wind of doctrine.
    
   If we ever knew anything, "as we ought to know", le us "walk by ye same rule and mind the same thing." Let us be satisfied with and established in "the faith once delivered to ye saints",and say with ye apostle, "thanks be to God for his unspeakable gift", in uniting Deity & virility so as to provide salvation for our fallen race, consistently with divine justine & mercy, though the august plan & means were such as Angels desired to look into.  and tho' this wonderful union is beyond their conception & ours also, we shd. be grateful for it, for surely it is exactly adapted to the condition & need of us poor frail beings, inasmuch as it is complete, or affords complete salvation, both indemnity & cure. Redemption from the penalty & power of sin; remdemption from the penalty by the atonement made by Jesus Christ, our Lord, being God & man;- and redemption from ye power or government of sin by the Holy Spirit, so received into & operating upon our hearts, as to change them, producing a birth of ye spirit & furnishing divine ability in faithful humility & obedience, to resist temptation & be preserved in divine acceptance."++++- Present my very warm & cordial love to thy very dear children, who I feel expressibly near to me. I remember ye kindness of R. T. also; and entertain sentiments of regard for our dear yound friend W. D. Cope, your near neighbour. under sensations which I am thankful for, I bid you all affectionately fare well." (signed) Daniel Stroud.-
   
   Thy observations with regard to ye precarious tenure of our hold on life, are worthy of being often recalled, & deeply impressed upon ye memory & ye heart.- with thyself, I hope & trust that ye deep concern & unbounded affection of our dear deceased Mother for us, will not have been uttered & felt in vain;- that ye expression of her hopes & fears, her sighs & sorrows, have not been for naught.-  I sincerely desire that ye change in ye management of your business, may be advantageous in a pecuniary point of view to thyself & Alfred, but ye annunciation of it, caused a shade of sorrow to pass over my heart. ye expunging of a name, upon which we have been in ye habit of looking so long, that we look upon it with a degree of veneration, seems somewhat like ye disappearance of an old friend or favourite.
   
   I have had workmen pretty constantly employed at my building since my last return from ye City, sometimes to ye number of 6 or 8, sometimes more. ye attention which these, my farm & Father's estate, occupies my time, pretty fully. ye last mentioned concern requires in its present stage & condition much attention for but little profit. but it is absolutely necessary that something shd. be done to guard against ye effects to which it is liable from an accumulation of taxes & interest. I still look forward however, to a change, decidedly for ye better, but we are so apt to be too fast in our calculations, that it becomes us to be cautious.-  I think it likely from present appearances, that my investment in ye stock of ye Leigh Coal and Navigation Co, will be a good one. I am not displeased to find myself becoming more & more interested in my farm. I form an attachment for every tree & every field, which has called forth my care & attention,- for every hill and every valley, that have afforded me gratification by their smiles & beauties.  ye lover of ye country can often realize ye enthusiasm of [Hervey], & exclaim, "when the little hills rejoice & the vallies laugh & sing, who can forbear joining ye general joy". I have at all events reason for self gratulation, inasmuch as I am more pleased with my present mode of life, than I at one time ever expected to be.- I early perceived that with my limited means, I mustbe contented with advancing slowly, in any improvements that I might wish to make, but it has been very difficult to reconcile myself to making so little progress as yet been able to make, owing to ye circumstance last mentioned as well as others.-  I expect that ye capital & influence that Caleb Carmalt is employing in favour of this County, will be of advantage to it, though we we may not feel their effects immediately in this neighbourhood.  some of E. Walker's Family, who have recently been at Friendsville, mention, that he has 30 men & 9 yoke of oxen at work on his farm.  two of his brothers, & one of his sisters have also pitched their tents at Friendsville.-  his brother James, fm Philada., has purchased a farm of 1000 acres & is employed in improving it.-
   
   With particular love to all, I remain thy affectionate brother,
    Wm D Cope
   
   Since writing ye foregoing, I have received thine of 6 ins’t. I will attend to doing what is necessary, to further ye collection of ye divd on ye Canal loan. I hardly expect that there will be any divd. this year, on ye Lehigh Canal stock, but if there should be, I will be obliged by thy informing me of it.-  in addition to the drafts referred to by thee, I passed one to C. Avery & Co, on ye 10 ins't, numbd. 10, for $50.00.-  I regret that I can get no tidings of my missing papers.-  I am obliged by ye information communicated by thee respecting the C & D Canal.  that great work, seems still to baffle calculation.Woodbourne
   7mo. 13.
   
   [7mo 15 1829]
   Henry Cope
   Care of Thomas P Cope
   Philadelphia.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1830-05-15
Title: 1830 May 15, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne, 5 month 15th 1830
   Dear Brother:
   
   Thy acceptable letter of 7th inst.  has been rec'd.  thy observations with regard to retirement & the Christian's duty, are certainly correct in the abstract, but I think it will be readily admitted by thee on reflection, that remotely placed as thou art from ye scene in which I move, a correct opinion of ye course most proper for me to pursue, cannot easily be formulated, either by thyself, or any one similarly situated.  to be candid; I may mention, that I think myself pretty fortunate in being able by some excersize or display of management, to make a live,- to use a significant term of the Yankees here,- to possess or enjoy ye common comforts of life.  I have therefore, not much time or inducement to propound to myself sentimental or metaphysical queries in regard to duties, problematical, or supposed to be omitted.  I may be compared in some measure to an honest & benevolent day labourer. (not insinuating that I have a claim to ye character of benevolence.)-  if a distressed fellow creature cross his path or approach his cabin, no one is more willing to dispense ye comforts with which he may be blessed.  but he cannot, like his more wealthy & independent fellow-citizens, go in quest of objects of charity.-  ye call of benevolence, shd. be heard & obeyed, and I freely acknowledge that it ought to be our aim, so to arrange our temporal concerns, as to be in the way of receiving benefit & advantage from our fellow men, or of administering ye same to them, as opportunities present.  this view & reflection, I wish to bring home to myself.  but I have undertaken a business & entered upon a course of life which I had but little previous knowledge, for which I had but little previous education & of which I had formed erroneous expectations.  it wd. certainly have been better on some accounts, if I had taken up my abode in a town or village, upon my first making this county my residence.  if I had excluded farming & building from my views, my business wd. have been much simplified.  but I wished to select ye most adventageous situation for promoting the interest & settlement of Father's est'e: and I think by showing that I consider ye land and ye country good enough for myself, a favorable effect has been & will continueto be produced.  ye difficulty of obtaining assistance here, is a great drawback to ye comfort & satisfaction of ye farmer.  yet as I have put ye machine in motion, I must keep it moving, & as I am harnessed in, I must move with it, unless I have some one to supply my place.  I still indulge ye hope that I shall be able to pull things into proper train, but I begin to think that it will require about as many years to accomplish ye object, as I supposed it would of weeks, before commencing ye undertaking.  I am often however enabled, gratefully to call to mind ye advantage of my present situation, to that of remaining in the City, a victim to disease.  tho' I am thankful that my circumstances are what they are, I trust I shall have sense enough to keep in view that I am not a man of fortune, in ye sense that ye term is generally understood; and when I see how easily my income & more than my income, is fittered away, and how little is to be seen of its effects, I am induced to pause, before launching out into expensesm without calculation.  when & how, ye returns are to come, is uncertain.  a farm in a new county is indeed a quicksand, so great are its absorbing qualities; & we have to deal here with a shewd set of sharpers.  a man who is considered to be in tolerably good circumstances, & is supposed to have money, must expect to be asked two prices for everything, & they will be Jewed or Yankeed out of him, if he does not look about him with eagle eyes.-  Dr. Rose, to be sure, in ye course of upwards of twenty years has done much: but ye course pursued by one man, does not form a rule for another, differently circumstanced.  he has had a numerous class of settlers, of diversified trades & occupations to assist him, to whom he has sold land for good prices, & from many of whom he wd. probably have obtained nothing, had he not have taken pay in such kind of assistance.-  Caleb Carmalt is similarly situated.-  speaking of Caleb, reminds me of a circumstance which occurred at the last Friendsville Preparative Meeting.  he was present, and John Kite, the clerk, objected to proceeding with ye business, whilst one who was not a member of the Society, was in ye house.  Caleb said that he supposed he was ye person alluded to, but that he had proof of his being a member of the Society of Friends, which he cd. produce if necessary.  one of the Hicksites remarked, that ye meeting itself had no information, or at least no official information of C. Carmalt's disownment.  a number of remarks were made in bothsides, but there seemed to be a general sentimentin favour of proceeding with what was before the meeting, without further discussion or excitement, and the clerk accordingly complied with what seemed to be the wish of the meeting.-  this is about ye substance of an account given by a Hicksite to E. Walker.-  what I mentioned in ye preceding part of my letter with regard to charity & benevolence, also recalls to recollection ye case of Uniah Estes, one of Father's settlers, who for ye last 6 weeks or 2 months, has been afflicted with mental alienation.  Jno. Mann kept him at his house several weeks.  by judicious management there, he has been so far resolved, that it was considered safe to suffer him to return to his family.  if he shd. have a relapse which is feared, it is tho't that it wd. be advisable to send him to Friends' Assylum.  if ye information is in thy possession or can be conveniently obtained by thee, I will thank thee to mention in thy next, ye lowest term on which poor patients are rec'd into that institution.  he is a member of the Society of Friends & belongs to a monthly meeting in ye State of New York.-  Elias Bennet, an old & respectable settler on ye Susqa. Co. Tract, who, Father will probably recollect was grievously afflicted with a cancer, died in ye early part of this Spring.  he has bequeathed his farm, or his right in it, to two of his sons.-  my annual subscription in advance, to "the Friend," became due in ye early part of this month.  I will be obliged by thy having it paid when convenient, & having a rec't taken.-  please not to forget my subscription to the Athenaeum.  I wish I were well rid of my share of stock.  I did not intend to have omitted to mention, that there was no charge in my a/c with the old firm of Thomas P Cope & Sons, for my proportion of ye amo't of subscription to the "Morning Journal."  it would I think be no more than right that I shd. pay part of it.-  I shall be anxious relative to Sister Caroline, & will be obliged by thy giving me information relative to her state of health, as soon as convenient.
   
   With love to all, I remain affectionately thy Brother,
   Wm D Cope
   
   I drew on 5 ult. in fav. C. Avery & Co., at 3 d/s, draft no 24 for $100.  and no 25 on ye 3d ins't at samesight fav. C. Avery for $50.0-Woodbourne
   5mo.15.
   
   [5 mo 19]
   
   Henry Cope
   care of Henry & Alfred Cope,
   Philadelphia.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1830-07-29
Title: 1830 July 29, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 7mo. 29th 1830
   Dear Brother:
   
   The idea presented in thine of ye 20 inst. of finding me out in the woods, I may truly say, excited in me very pleasant feelings; tho' at ye same time, I feel as if I can scarcely dare to invite you, for reasons that I think it wd. not be proper to mention in a letter. I will give thee a remote exception of what amongst other things, I allude to, by refering to a frequent remark, that in every flock, there is a black sheep, & a Judas in every community. more than this, I ought not to say. I believe I have never hesitated to answer any query put to me by relatives & friends respecting my situation, nor have I any objections to doing so, unless I may have a very particular reason for secrecy. but Marmaduke will perhaps from having been an impartial spectator, be more likely to give thee a satisfactory description of Woodbourne than myself.- E. Walker bro't me thy letter whilst I was spending ye evening as usual, with his family. I mentioned what was said by thee about visiting me. George desired me to tell thee that they shd. be very glad to see thee: and Priscilla said, tell him to bring Rachel &Martha. they all seemed to be as glad to see Marmaduke & our other cousins, as if they had been their own relations. it seemed to me to be quite like an era in ye history of Woodbourne, when my City relations had actually paid me a visit.- I think you had better come on, and take us by surprise as they did, and thus give us no time to think about any obstructions, objections, or difficulties. with regard to any pecuniary considerations, I think I cd. fully satisfy my neighbours, tho' they will not listen to any direct proposition relative to consideration money.- in expressing what precedes, I have used ye freedom, which ought to exist in ye intercourse between brothers. to one, who does not stand in ye same relationship to me as thyself, I wd. have felt some hesitation in saying what I have said to thee.- I was much interested in reading thy description of ye proposed institution for imparting instruction in ye higher branches of learning to the children of Friends, and had no idea that so great an advance had been made towards affecting ye object in view. it is a noble undertaking, & if accomplished, will tend to increase ye reputation of the Society. the sup-position or opinion, that our profession, principles or religion acquires ye discouragement of literary knowledge & intelligence, appears to me pretty evidently to be a mistake.-  I was fearful that there wd. be an appearance of ambiguity in my observations with regard to the Union Canal stock.  In my last communication on ye subject, I expressed a willingness to invest, if I cd. obtain five per cent on the am't invested.  this I shd. receive, were I to give $240 per share, or 120 per cent.  consequently, if I am right in my estimate, ye price is still below my limits.  but of course, there would be no advantage in offering a high price, if there is none of the stock for sale.-  I am much obliged to thy attention to the subject.  supposing that the Bank of Penna has declared ye dame divd. for ye last as for ye previous half year, I inclose a Power of Att'y for its collection, & one also for the interest on the C & D Canal loan.  if the Lehigh Co. shd. have disclosed a divd. please inform me.  I see by the news-papers, that 3 1/2% has been declared by the U.S. B'k.
   
   With best love to family & friends, I remain thy affectionate brother,
   Wm D Cope
   
   I have drawn, under date of 5mo. 3-'30, draft no. 25, fav. C. Avery for $50.+  and no 26, under date of 7mo. 1-'30, fav. Avery & Drinker, for same am't, & both at 3 d/s.  also no. 27, at 3 d/s, fav. Avery & Drinker, dated 7mo.13-'30, for $50.00
   I lately spoke to G. Mallery about ye P. Thomson tract & he promised me that he will again lay ye subject before ye Com's & when their decision is ascertained, will write to me.
   
   + before advised ofKnow all men by these presents, that I, William D Cope of the Township of Springville, County of Susquehanna and State of Pennsylvania, have authorized and appointed, and do authorize and appoint, Henry Cope, of the firm of Henry & Alfred Cope, Philadelphia, my true and lawful attorney, to demand and receive from the Chesapeak & Delaware Canal Company, the interest due me on Nine thousand five hundred dollars ($9500.) Loan of said Company.
   
   In witness whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seal rgw twenty-ninth day of the 7mo. (August) 1830
   Signed and sealed in the presence of
   Jonathan Nichols
   Lyman BaldwinWoodbourne
   7mo.30.
   
   [8mo 1 1830-]
   Henry Cope,
   care of Henry & Alfred Cope,
   Philadelphia.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1832-11-27
Title: 1832 November 27, Philadelphia, to S.

Philada. 11mo. 27. 1832
   
   I may say the worst that I have for years   I have had a dreadfully bad cold, and though I think it would have done me good to see thee, I must now bid all hail! to Susquehanna County, and did not feel much inclined to go into company nor was I in a very suitable condition for so doing.  I hasten to the country of cloud-capped eminences, invigorating breezes, placid lakes, ever-varying surface and romantic scenery.-  there to feel myself reinstated in the occupation which is the height of my ambition, that of an independent farmer.-  an occupation for which I do not think my partiality as yet has diminished.  "Ye generous yeomen, [---] the plough"!  before taking my flight, I wish to let thee know that I did not forget the subject of "Friendship’s Offering" relative to which we had some conversation during our last rural walk.  the reason for my not sending the said work, I will give when I again see thee.  this seems to be a small matter to [---] to, but I think it best thus to do it, as I have never yet forfeited my word or violated an engagement, and I do not wish to give any cause for so however slight for supposing that I wd. do so.  if thee gets married to any one, while I am gone, be sure that it is to a clever fellow.  I am still somewhat inclined I should like to have had one sweet kiss of thy pretty mouth, before, peradventure, I should forever be [---] the opportunity (5); however thee knows we ought to learn to submitto submit with fortitude to our fate.  I am still somewhat inclinded to the opinion, which I have before hinted to thee, that I am not well qualified to undergo the ordeal of a systematic courtship, such as is frequently, perhaps generally expected & practiced in this part of the world.  if I ever succeed in making a capture of that fair citadel, or seat of love,- a lady’s heart; it must, I apprehend be by storm, rather than by gradual approaches, long trains, dexterous manouvers, or a regular siege.
   
   I have now only to say,
   "Adieu! a heartfelt warm adieu"! from thy still affectionate friend,
   
   if thou wilt only be persuaded, dear Susan, a drab bonnet, I will on my part agree to shade my face with a broad-brim.  if we do not then attract universal admiration, who will be so bold as to say that we will not at least command general respect.
   
   I have received a notice requiring my immediate departure from the City, if possible, in order to attend the next Court to be held at Montrose.  excuse haste and all the nonsense contained in these lines.-I expect to have the agreeable company of my Cousin Rebecca Drinker as far as [Stoddartsville].  being of a cheerful disposition, I expect she will prevent my spirits from flagging.To S,
   dated Philada. 11mo. 27. 1832.
   
   (3) "Though I to" distant "lands must [---],   Pursuing fortune's [sliddery] [---],   With melting heart & [brimful] eye,   I'll mind thee when I’m far away."
   
   (5) by some spruce, fashionable [---].  plague on such I say.
   
   Ph

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Reed Cary
Recipient:  Francis Algernon Evans:  1878-1946
Date: 1911-06-29
Title: 1911 June 29, to Alg

6/29/11
   
   Dear Alg-
   
   Words are so hopelessly futile and especially are they so when cold on the paper that I hesitate to make the attempt to express the very deep feelings that the recent news inspired in me.  Our meetings together during the past year had had the effect of developing in me desires for development and usefulness as thosewhich most manifestly animated him and especially during the past few months I had looked forward to a future where we might work for the common object of developing in ourselves and thence to our meeting and Society a deeper truer life.  And so it comes that I feel as though I might to at least make the attempt to tell you all how deep is my sense ofof personal loss and there fore how sincerely I sympathize with thee and the rest of his family in the loss of him from your circle.
   
   I know of no one person who, of recent years, has had more influence for good when upon me than did Ernest and it seemed to me that the bottom had dropped out of every thing when I learned that he wastaken but tho it does still seem that way there is the perfectly sure knowledge that the very little knowledge I have of his life will stay with me as an inspiration.  Tho it was seldom we got together I feel as tho I, too, had lost a brother.
   
   With sympathy which I really cannot express
   sincerely
   Charles Reed Cary

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Davis H. (Davis Hoopes) Forsythe:  1858-1934
Recipient:  Francis Algernon Evans:  1878-1946
Date: 1911-03-27
Title: 1911 March 27, Westtown, to Boys

Westtown Pa.
   3 mo 27th 1911
   
   Dear Boys
   
   This morning's mail brings to me a sad  letter from your cousin Elizabeth Goodhue. It is my last wish to intrude upon your sorrow but I must make just a few words for my sake if not for yours.
   
   The greatesttrial of my life & even yet in retrospect it seems very great, your father was the very embodiment of kindness to me, the sort of kindness that allows your weakness to grow a little stronger from his strength & this and more than thisif possible he was to me. I remember, it was many years ago, the summer before Algernon went to College, your dear father said to me in the school house office "I did not sleep last night, for the thought of the responsibility of the rear-ing of these children of mine got so on my nerve that it banished sleep." I could ask for no better legacy for you dear fellows than that a father would wrestle in prayer the night through that God's blessing might rest on you & on his effort. He answered that prayer & long ago gave your father the assurance that he sought. I could write on and on for Icannot help mingling my tears with yours. With a messageof love to you mother & to Anna.
   Your Friend
    
   Davis H. Forsythe
