----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Hannah Rhoads Haines Garrett:  1846-1901
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1899-04-26
Title: 1899 April 26, Rosemont, to Lily

4 mo 26. 1899
   
   Dear Lily,
   
   There has been a lack of vocal or written sympathy with thee this winter, and this brief message is only to assure thee of my love and frequent thought being freshly flowing.That mere words would only weary thee I know and I only sent messages to thee by notes to Rachel. It was my hope that long before this my own strength would have retuned and enabled me to go to thee. But that is not the case as only a very little exertion ispossible yet - writing, almost is a lost art. Excuse this detail, because I could not otherwise explain my absence. Now we have heard of Edward's illness, and I wish to send by thee my love to Jonathan and Rachel, when it is convient to thee.
   
   We Also understand Edward is much beter, I hope convalescent.Dear, believe me, thy loss is shared in some degree by me, for thy lovely Agnes was especially near to me, her gentle pure spirit now a lasting place in my heart.
   
    She always seemed as one apart from our every-day routine, and now she is in full & glourious development of all her Savoir has prepared her to be for Him. Always lovingly thy
    Hannah R. Garrett.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Phebe E.H. Haines
Recipient:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Date: 1909-11-08
Title: 1909 November 8, to Thomas

My dear Thomas:-
   
   As my thoughts have gone out in sympathy for thee in the great loss of thy dear father, I have recalled an acrostic which he wrote for my mother after my father's death, just twenty years ago; and which we valued very much. I think it is most touchingly beautiful, especially so, that it now seems almost prophetic of his own entranceinto the heavenly city.
   "Joined to the loved ones who, expectant long,
    On yonder shore his coming did await,
    Singing their jubilant, thanksgiving song,
    Early & late, before the pearly gate,
    Palms in their hands; And robed in spotless
 white,
   Happy to praise their Savior day and night!
   How must his soul have thrilled with rapture,
 when
    On quicken ear, burst the ecstatic song!
    With what transporting joy, behold again
    Earths lost ones gathered in that Heavnely
 throng! 
   Loving, as only ransomed spirits love,
   Love centered in Him who is Eternal love."
   
   Please give my love & sympathy to thy mother and sisters andBelieve me, with sincere sympathy.
   
   Thy Friend,
   Phebe E. H. Haines
   
   5433 Wayne Ave.
   11 mo. 8th. 1909.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna C. (Anna Cope) Hartshorne:  1860-1957
Recipient:  Annette Cope:  1843-1916
Date: 1895-09-01
Title: 1895 September 1, Woodbourne, to Annette

Woodbourne
   Sept. 1st 1895
   
   My dear Annette,
   
   When I reached Holmhurst last week Nanna immediately presented me with thy package, and I opened and found the irresistable little gentleman from Dai Nippon. Where did thee pick him up, I wonder! He will be a most pleasant memento of thee, though I shall hesitate to insult his diginity by inkinghis fine skirts! I have thought of thee, and of you all so much this summer, and greatly wished I could have seen thee and Carrie before we leave. I hoped Mrs. Cope would return while I was at Holmhurst, but she is I supppose still with you. If so please give her my dear love. Thee will forgive me I know for this tardy work, I spent a whole week nominally at Holmhurst, actually between the city, Germantown, and all the [---]. Thee knows onlytoo well what such packing is. Now I am enjoying a few day's rest at Woodbourne before going back to Awbury for a square start westward. Virginia here and sends her love, also says to tell thee that I will meet thee in Italy winter after next. I tell her I give the message as hers, not mine! Much as I should like such a prospect; she is much more liekly to turn up there in the next year or two, than I! Lillie and the girls & Thos. & Elizabeth Cope are entertaining Dr. Norris and a Germandoctor friend in the parlor, else they would doubtless send messages. Please give my love to Carrie and Clementine, I understand you are all together, and are glad to know you have that comfort. With dear love for thy own self, and thanks for thinking of me amid so much sorrow, I am as always,
   
   Affectionally thine
   Anne C. Hartshorne

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Hartshorne:  1829-1908
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1860-05-08
Title: 1860 May 8

Six years ago, when ever joyous Spring 
   scattered rich gifts upon this earth of our's 
   Far sweeter than the sweetest of her flowers, 
   One flower did God to our own garden bring. 
   
   He planted it a noble plant, and gave 
   The charge of it into our loving care, 
   To train it tenderly, so it might bear 
   Fruit to His praise who for such fruit I did crave. 
   
   Ah! how kept we our trust? Was ours the love, 
   Which while it prized the gift loved more the given, 
    And sought with tears, how is might best deliver 
   The entrusted talent back to him above? 
   
   Oh! earthly love, oh! selfish human heart, 
   Weak and mistrustful of God's providence 
   Troubled for many things of time and sense, 
   Yet careless of the one thing needful, the good path! 
   
   Therefore when God our ill kept graden saw, 
   And marked how weeds were climbing o’er the flowers
    So that the refreshing Heavenly showers 
   Might hardly reach them; gently did he draw 
   
   One flower from our keeping, it may be
    Not only to preserve that one from harm, 
But that our careless souls be might alarm, 
   And waken from their false security. 
   Ah me! How little had we dreamed of this
!    Listless, beside our cherished flowers we lay. 
   And as we breathed their fragrance day by day. 
   Looked for no pride awakening from own bliss. 
   
   In distant meadows could we often hear
    The stern old mower what his fatal sythe; 
   But yet our hearts beat ever free & blythe, 
   Since to our garden still he drew not near. 
   
   Angel of Death! Ah! who may ever tell 
   The bitter anguish of our souls, but now 
   No doubt can e'er disturb our faith that thou 
   Wast sent by Him who doeth all things well. 
   
   He called our flower Willie; twas a name 
   Borne by one dearly loved, whose gentle heart
    Waited e'en then the summons to depart; 
   And joyfully received it when it came. 
   
   And we had hoped, that in our brother's stead
    Our darling might be found by name & all 
   His guiltless actions, ever to recall 
   The cherised memories of the loved & dead. 
   
   Such was wour hope; yet may we not repine; 
    Twas matchless wisdom and unbounded love 
   Drew both our precious ones to him above; 
   To make them in His Heavenly courts to shine. 
  Now other names we trust to them are given, 
   In that blest land where our loved flower is growing. 
    The stream of life beside him ever ever flowing, 
   Which maketh glad the heritage of Heaven. 
   
   And now on this his Natal Day, 
   We humbly bend the knee, and pray 
   To Thee, who wast his God always, 
    God of all Consolation, 
   
   That thou our hearts may so incline, 
   So bend our stubborn wills to thine, 
   That we no longer may repine
   In our deep tribulation
   
   We thank Thee God, that Thou hast taken 
   Our Willie from this world of pain, 
   Before upon his robes the stain 
   Of deadly sin did cling. 
   
   And in his sweet simplicity, 
   That thou, most precious thoughts of Thee
    And of Thy Heaven, continually, 
   Before his mind did bring. 
   
   overSo, when thy summons to him came, 
   While suffering racked his tender frame, 
   The call was welcome, as the claim 
   Of friend long dearly known. 
   
   An doubting naught, his willing feet 
   Hastened the messenger to meet, 
   As one he trustingly could greet, 
   Who came to take him home. 
   
   Oh Lord! Thou gainest the victory! 
   Not unto him, but unto Thee 
   Let all the praise and honor be 
   Oh, Lord! our God most glorius! 
   
   Oh! In the darkness of our night 
   When we too wage the fearful fight, 
   May we be made through thy blessed light, 
    Like him o'er death victorious. 
   
   5th  month 8th 1860.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Hartshorne:  1829-1908

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Samuel Morris:  1827-1905
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1897-01-19
Title: 1897 January 19, Olney, to Francis & Anna Cope

Olney 1 mo. 19. 97.
   
   My dear friends
    Francis & Anna Cope,
   
   Those only who have passed thr'o a similar trial, can justly measure the affliction which is now your portion. So I find my heart going out in tender sympathy with yours and our earnest desire that he among whose gracious offices it still is to "heal the broken hearted", and "to comfort them that mourn", may be near to sustain & comfort you.
   
   To a loving parent, the right time never comes, as viewed from our standpoint, to part with a dear child. The infancy, its very tenderness & helplessness beget the care it is there so continually needing. As childhood comes with all its winsome ways, it is surely hard to give the little one up. And when mandhood or womanhood have been reached, and ourhopes brighten for their future, or we fondly look for ripenning fruit from all our care & anxiety & effort for their temporal & spiritual good, a feeling akin to bitter disappointment is mingled with the sorrow, as we bear them to the silent tomb.
   
    But the Christian believer has learned, not only thr'o observing the lots of others, but by his own happy experience, that a Heavenly Father, who "tender mercies are over all His works", and whose "compassions fail rest", knows best how to deal with us and our loved ones, and that "he doeth all things well".  Whether we understand the meaning of the dispenesation or not, we can thr'o our tears exclaim, "The Lord gave and the Lord hath taken away, but blessed be the name of the Lord." This filial submission to the Will of God, we well know comes to us only thr'o the humbling, sweetening, calming influences of his grace. But I rejoice to believe you have known & felt its efficacious power, and I long that it may in this time of need, rest largely upon the spirits of you both.Some sweet lines by Charlotte Elliot, you may be already familiar with, but they seem so fitted for those who are passing this heavy trials, that I will add a few stanzas, th'o feeling sure you will appreciate them all.
   
    If those shouldst call me to resign
   What most I prize, it ne'er was mine:
   I only yield thee what was there;
   "Thy will be done".
   
   If but my fainting heart be blest
   With thy sweet spirit for its guest,
   My God! To thee I leave the rest,
   "Thy will be done"
   
   Renew my will from day to day;
   Blend it with thine, and take away
   All that now makes it hard to say,
   "Thy will be done."
   
   Then, when on earth I breathe no more
   The prayer half mixed with tears before,
   We sing, upon a happier shore,
   "Thy will be done"
   
   My lameness still keeps me a cripple,and almost house-bound, or I should gladly have been with you ere this, but the above may express, better perhaps than I could in person, the loving sympathy and desires of
   
   your attached friend,
   Saml Morris.

Whether we understand the meaning of the dispenesation or not, we can thr'o our tears exclaim, "The Lord gave and the Lord hath taken away, but blessed be the name of the Lord." This filial submission to the Will of God, we well know comes to us only thr'o the humbling, sweetening, calming influences of his grace. But I rejoice to believe you have known & felt its efficacious power, and I long that it may in this time of need, rest largely upon the spirits of you both.Some sweet lines by Charlotte Elliot, you may be already familiar with, but they seem so fitted for those who are passing this heavy trials, that I will add a few stanzas, th'o feeling sure you will appreciate them all.
   
    If those shouldst call me to resign
   What most I prize, it ne'er was mine:
   I only yield thee what was there;
   "Thy will be done".
   
   If but my fainting heart be blest
   With thy sweet spirit for its guest,
   My God! To thee I leave the rest,
   "Thy will be done"
   
   Renew my will from day to day;
   Blend it with thine, and take away
   All that now makes it hard to say,
   "Thy will be done."
   
   Then, when on earth I breathe no more
   The prayer half mixed with tears before,
   We sing, upon a happier shore,
   "Thy will be done"
   
   My lameness still keeps me a cripple,and almost house-bound, or I should gladly have been with you ere this, but the above may express, better perhaps than I could in person, the loving sympathy and desires of
   
   your attached friend,
   Saml Morris.

Title: 1861 April 22, to Anna S. Cope

Thanks dear Anna, for thy many  kind remembrances; the basket of flowers was exquisitely beautiful, how they remind us of the skill and benevolence of the great Creator, cheer the path of life and touch the heart with gratitude to Him who has so bountifully provided for one enjoyment ever in his visible works.
   
   With love,
   H. Rhoads
   
   4th day 22nd.Anna S. Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Hannah Sansom Vaux
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1840-07-31
Title: 1840 July 31, Philadelphia, to Anna, near Germantown

Philadelphia 7th mo 31st 1840.
   
   My dearest Anna,
    
   When we last parted I had intended to fulfill my promise of writing to thee at a much earlier period than I have done, but my time has been so much occupied that I have found it impossible to do so, and trust thee will not attribute it to forgetfulness, as I can assure thee that although absent, thee is not forgotten. Several of the family have been very much indisposed, grandfather has indeed had quite a severe attack, we scarcely thought he would recover for a day or two, but he is now very much improved and able to be about his room. The weather has been so very warm, I expect you enjoy the country exceedingly there  are but a few persons now remaining in the city, the streets are quite deserted, great numbers have gone to Cape May and other watering places. I understood from a gentleman who had just returned from Saratoga Springs, that the Hotels there were very much crowded, about four hundred visitors at one house.
    
   I regretted exceedingly you were unable to hear Friend Gurney once more before his departure, I can scarcely realise that he has indeed left our native land forever, as he now supposes; there was a little girl inquired of him if he would never return here, and was almost broken hearted, when he placed his hand upon his head and replied, that "his docks were too grey ever to expect to revisit this country". I had several op-portunities of being in company with him and they were much more delightful on account of being unexpected.
   
   The First day morning before he left he attended the North Meeting, and gave us a very interesting and beautiful sermon, taking his text from the sixty third chapter of Isaiah, ninth Verse. After meeting Sister Mary and myself were returning home, when Friend Paul joined us and said, that she had fully expected we would have called to see Friend Gurney the evening before, that there was a number of friends and young people assembled at their house, between sixty and seventy she thought, to bid him Farewell, and insisted upon our going home with her; as she said that it would be our last oppurtunity, we accordingly accepted her invitation, highly grateful as thee may suppose. Our particular facourite E. P. Kirkbride was there when we arrived, and seveal other friends. Friend Gurney was very much pleased to see us, he said that he had been expecting us, and was very glad we had come, he seated himself close by us and conversed awhile very sweetly, after which we bade him adieu, wishing him a prosperous voyage and safe return, he sent his Love to all the family a kiss to the younger ones. He had an appointed meeting at the Arch Street house in the evening. (I was very much surprised a few days after to hear that you had not attended it). It was very large, he addressed us in a very interesting manner and furnished with a most touching prayer, in which he commended all his Endeared Friends, to the protection of that Saviour, who had so long sheltered him under his parent wing, and had been with him, in joy and in sorrow in this land."
   
   When the meeting had concluded, every one rushed to shake hands with him, I think he must have stood twenty minutesbidding all farewell, until I thought his hand really must ache however all were finally satisfied, and we had just returned home, when to our utter amazement who should arrive directly after, but Joseph John he said he must see us all once more, he sat a short time with us, and we then bade him adieu, although I trust it will not be forever. He sailed in "The Roseius" on the 25th, I shall be truly glad when I hear of his safe arrival at home, for surely his children and relations must ardently desire to behold him again, if he makes such an impression upon strangers what must their feelings be? I shall leave the remainder to thy imagination; I have written a long narrative about him my Dear Anna, supposing it would interest thee, if it does not thee must excuse the length of it, and not waste thy time in perusing it. I suppose thee has most probably heard of the death of Harry Collins, and Maria’s loss of her dear little babe, his namesake, so near the same time, poor girl she must feel it very deeply. Sister Susan and family have gone into the country expecting to remain three weeks. Cousin S. Cresson is no anxiously awaiting the arrival of her son Charles &c they intended sailing on the 25th in the "Great Western" for New York, I suppose they will arrive here in a week or ten days.
   
   Brother Wm is very anxious that some of us should take a trip through Pennslyvania, we had thought of going to Cape May for the benefit of the bathing the Dr. having recommended it for George, but Mama was so unwilling that he should be near the sea, we have concluded that a mountain ride, will perhaps be equally beneficial, I do not think it likely we shall be absent longer than a week. My letter has become so very lengthy, that I have only room to add do write me a very long letter and very soon, give my love to all inquiring friends of course reserving a lrage portion for thyself and hoping this will find you all in a perfect state of salubrity believe mestill thy sincerely attached friend and cousin
   
   Hannah S Vaux
   
   P.S. Please excuse all blunders and do not allow any one to read this but thyself. (A speedy answer Dear Anna).

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Date: 1901-01
Title: 1901 January, to Family

Wednesday
   
   [Jan ? 1901] 
   
   Dearest Family, 
   
   Well!  I have had two visits since I last wrote, & mighty nice ones they were.  Aunt L & Ellie came the first time (I told you I wondered  which 2 it would be, didnt I?) & after theyhad been here about an hour & we had a good talk Dr. Stedman came up and said they would have time for a cup of tea at the [---] House (his house you know) & that Miss Stedman was there-  Mrs. Stedman was away unfortunately.  He asked me to come down, too, so we all went& I enjoyed it ever so much, as it was the first time I had been inside their house.  I was sorry Aunt Lilly didn't see Mrs. Stedman, but I believe they have asked her & Miss Stedman to lunch with them at Brunswick so they will meet after all.  I was in hopes the Doctor would let me go into lunch with them some day this week but he thinks I am not quite ready for that, so they are coming out again.  Mary & Frank came on Monday & we had a jolly time, & Polly is coming out with Aunt Lilly & Ellie when they come, I think.  Frank will come again, toosometime, I guess & I have found out that I can call him up on the telephone if I want to.  I had a nice little talk with Polly last evening on that instrument, & a few words with Aunt Lilly.  The latter is not very fond of talking on it& they have had some rather funny times I guess, as they have telephones in their rooms to the office instead of bells.  To-day they are Cambridge.  I believe, lunching with Mr. Foote at the Colonial Club, & are at present looking at the glass flowers, I expect.  Of course youknow [---] or "tea" for them, & they met lots of people there.  I told Dr. Stedman I was crazy to go to it, & he said he would love to let me, but he didnt think I was up to it.  Perhaps I shall get to Class Day, however. 
   
   To change the subject, I dont think I ever acknowledged the little bookthee mailed me, Mother dear, from Aunt Lizzie Cope.  I [---] it all night, & sometime will you give her my love & thank her very much for me?  Then the photos & the card-case Aunt L brought.  The card case is all right & so are the photos, but I'm going to bother you to send mesome more things.  Thanks very much for these first, however.  The other things are- 1. the little lace tie to go around your neck, which Cousin Hannah sent me last summer- 2. my two lace collars- one of [---] edged with lace, & one of illusion with wide lace onthe edge- 3 my little gold pin (not a strap pin but a clasp) one of a pair I used to have, & my little white wreath pin (that is if it is all right to send them by mail), 4 & some more photos.  It is so nice to have those you sent, & I want more.  I'd like my group of the GoldenWedding for one thing, & if there is a copy of that picture of Mother & me I want that & there is a picture of Esther in a little frame & one of Mary Emlen- & any others you can find.  I cant have too many-  If the frames are bulky dont send them, though I'd like to have the ones Esther & Mary are in,if you can manage it.  If there are any old kodak pictures of Awbury or Conanicut send them, too, but dont bother too much.  You see it is so nice to have them to show to Miss Webb & other people to whom I talk about things, besides the phasum of having them to look at myself.  I do wish therewas a good one of Father-  You might send me the family group.  He is pretty good in that.  The one of the house you sent is great & I have it on my bureau, next to the boys. 
   
   Now I'm going to stop this scrawl.  I hope you dont think I'veasked for a great many things.  Miss Richardson thinks my bloomers are in my trunk.  I'm awfully sorry.  Miss R. wants to be remembered to Mother. 
   
   With lots of love I am in great haste. 
   Your very loving
   
   Anna.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Edward W. (Edward Wyatt) Evans:  1882-1976
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1911-06-16
Title: 1911 July 16, Woodbourne, to Aunt Lilly

Woodbourne
   Sunday, July 16, 1911
   
   Dear Aunt Lilly, 
   
   I want to thank thee very, very much for thy letter to me, so full of love and sympathy and helpful thought for Jack and me and for us all. Thee knows, I am sure, how glad we all are of the assurance that the miles which separate us cannot prevent the, being with us in spirit, nor us with thee. I am sure this experience of sudden and great sorrow has given us all, (and many, also, I think, outside our family circles), a new vision of the sacredness and beauty of these lives of ours however commonplace their daily rounds may seem and to me, I think, the greatest inspiration of all comes from the thought of how dear Ern's spirit by the dark, faithfulness of his unselfishness, which all who knew him felt, was unconsciouslygrowing to that wonderful capacity for selflessness which he so beautifully displayed in those last hours. I know he would be the last one to wish praise that was not due or ever praise at all but he would rejoice for us all together from this experience and to go forward with more and more steadfast faithfulness to the light that is given us. 
   
   It is lovely being up here all together in the quiet peace  of the woods and hills with Frank and Ev and I wish we had thee, too. Woodbourne is almost like another home to me. 
   
   Harold, I am sorry to say, had to leave us today, but he went I am sure much the better for his eight days here and enjoyed it all very much. You are all very good to take us in so generously. 
   
   I have read Jack's note and see that she has mentioned that this is Ernest's Birthday. I think we all feel much as she says about his appreciation of Woodbourne and  love of nature. 
   
    Mother and Anna seem wonderfully well, I think, and it has been very good for Alg, too. The weather is very pleasant, a delightful breeze keeping the hilltop cool and fresh today. 
   
    Alg is the only other member of the family about us now and he sends a great deal of love to thee and to you all. I join warmly in his message with a special one of love to Ell. And please tell her how much her letter meant to us all. How I wish she were here with us now! 
   
    We were very sorry to hear of Uncle Tom's loss on the way up. We did, indeed appreciate having him with us at Awbury and all he did for us. 
   
   Thy very affectionate nephew
   Edward. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Hannah Bacon Evans:  1839-1939
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1882-09-03
Title: 1882 September 3, Meadowfield, to sister

Meadowfield 9.3.
   
   My beloved sister
   I feel as tho' I wanted to send thee another greeting before you leave Newport, thy last letter was very welcome with its good report of your welfare, I trust you have all continued in good case & will return home strengthened for the cares & duties of the winter.  As to dear little Edward, I do not suppose we shall know him, nor doubt he has changed much, I hope he will make up his mind to take food when he really needs it, perhaps he may take to a cup & spurn if a bottle is too insulting to his dignity.  Rebekah Smith's little boy is growing nicely & is a cute baby with the large dark eyes, your children ought to our ideas, & tho' his fractures are rather too large now for baby beauty he promises to develope that trait after awhile; at present his great charm is his good behavior, which is a real comfort to his mamma as her nurse left her sooner than she wished & she has only a young girl to assist her in taking care of him.  I suppose it will not be very long now before you are turning your faces homeward & it will be pleasant to think of your bring near us.  tho' we shall not see one another for awhile.  I am glad to hear from a letter to Katharine from Jthat you will not move into your own house until the 11th month, as I would like to be on hand at that season, having a fancy for such dissipations.  I have seen allusions in the papers to the burning of The Cliff House, but have not seen any account of the event, what a favor you were not there! & how about the boarders, did they lose their things was anyone hurt, poor Mrs Emmons I hope she was not there, (or thy Aunt Lizzie).  By the way what do you hear of the latter.  I trust her trip to England has been of use to her, when do you expect her back.  I am sorry to hear that Hazen is not very strong, perhaps he did too much, it seemed a very short time to be absent.  Since our last letter to thee we have had a visit from Susan Kito & Amy Roberts, they are bothundemonstrative people, especially Susan, but they enjoyed being here I think, SK was not well & did not like to ride so we had a quiet time, reading, talking, examining flowers & looking at objects in the compound microscope, one of Frank's late investments; they took tea at sister Eleanor's & also at Joshua's.  Sister Eleanor's summer home was vacated on 3rd day, she, Tom, Ellie, & Walter drove home with the two horses & carriage she spent one night at Arondale & one at HM Stokes at Chester & reached Germantown on 5th day evening.  Hetty & Wistar have gone to "Uncle Gideon's" & Betty is staying with us; the stay down here has been a real succes, the children have been very well & happy, have found much to interest & occupy them.Wistar & Franky have spent many hours in "bug hunts" & do manifest much zeal in the collection of beetles, butterflys & moths, & really have quite a large number; we labor under great difficulty as far as the study of the subject is concerned, as we have no books on Entomology except one by [Wood?] which treats of British insects, I quite want to get some good work & be able to learn the names of some of the creatures the boys have.  I have wandered away from my starting point, sister Eleanorfound the quiet of the country life & the absense of the many demands on her time & thoughts that she has to meet in Germantown a great rest, & altho' the house has not much to attract as regards situation it did not make the same difference to her it would to us, as she is so fond of riding she was out almost daily & enjoyed taking others drives.  Thee may remember Katharine & I find great comfort in sitting under the trees or lying in the hammocks when not busy sewing.  I suppose Hetty will stay down some weeks yet, her trip to Mt [Desert?] brokeinto her summer & I think she dont feel at all ready to leave Maryland.  John & Walter came down yesterday with Frank but dont expect to make much of a visit as they talk of going back tomorrow.  We heard a report that Sophy Kimber was to be married at Newport this summer, does thee know if it is so, her certificate has been sent on from 12th st, we shall miss her from Germantown she is so efficient & willing.  Now my dear sister when thee writes, which I hope may be [---] long, please tell us how thee is, Katharine wishes to know if thee has picked up any fat in the cool air, how does thy nurse geton, I hope she has proved an efficient help.  It is raining quite heavily now, which is not as acceptable as at some seasons, but when I think how we have longed for it in former days I dont like complaining.  The season of canning has arrived & folks in this part of the country are busy enough putting up corn, tomatoes & peaches &c, I should feel dubious about eating the products of some of the factories, as they employ Bohemians whose cleanliness is more than doubtful.  We were quite startled to see the death of Mary Morton yesterday, she spent a few days with Rebekah some 2 weeks ago, but was not well then & wished to get to Phila, it is such a favor she went up when she did or she might have died here.  Please give my love to thy mother & Lilly, kiss the dear children for me & accept for thyself a message of warmaffection from thy attached sister K sends love Hannah B. Evanscan thee tell us anything of the Newhalls.  Ive not heard from A for some time & fear her mother is more poorly.

Date: 1902-08-03
Title: 1902 August 3, Locust Avenue, to sister

[Tear this up when you have read it.  I have answered it.] 
   
   Locust Avenue
   8 Mo 3rd
   
   My dear sister
   
   I am once more at home and quite miss hearing of thy welfare and dear Anna's from Jonathan's letters.  I hope you still continue to gain and enjoy the mountain air.  When I got home last 2nd day, I felt very much used up with the heat & the change in air, but now have become accustomed to it and feel quite well, tho' the amount of moisture in the air makes things damp & sticky.  No doubt thee has heard particulars of E.W. Copes last hours, the close must have been very peaceful, both Ellie & Madgie express their feelings of thankfulness that their mother did not have to endure long confinement and great suffering.  The funeral was small, so many are away, S. Morris and E Allen bore testimony to her character, there was nothing said at the grave but there was such a sweet, quiet feeling as we stood silently there in the evening lights, everything looking so beautiful & peaceful, words did not seem to be needed.  E. Allen said after meeting today to Eleanor & me, that after sheheard of E.W. Copes death she went into her room and such a sweet feeling came over her, she felt it was a forecast of the rest & peace into which Elizabeth Cope had entered.  I rode to the ground with cousin Rebecca Evans, she spoke of cousin Elizabeth, said the letter thee wrote her had been such a particular comfort and help to her, that Rebecca had felt she must write & tell thee but has been rather burdened with calls, so I said I would let thee know about it, I think R sent her love to thee.  Will & Grace have both had mumps, and little Mary, (Alice'sdaughter) has been very sick, she is now gaining down at the Dennis and Grace has been there with them.  Cousin Wm & John Rhoads have gone to T. Brown's camp for their vacation.  I send thee one of Esthers letters as thee may be interested to hear something of the Conference.  It seems to have been a time of spiritual refreshment & uplifting & I hope may prove of use to the building up of the Church.  Eleanor says the spirit of love & unity was very marked, Alfred urged that all [---] and feelings of antagonism between old & young, conservative & progressive should be laidaside, which seemed to be the case.  Alfred seems to feel his mind relieved of the concern, he went back to Bupshire yesterday & is going on to Northfield.  Frank Goodhue also went to Bupshire will spend today there & go on to Brattleboro taking little Mary with him.  Edith Silver came up on 5th day eve, it was very pleasant to see her, she went home yesterday, Betty & little Elizabeth & Sam Mason all went with her.  Betty intends spending a couple of weeks at Swallowfield where she hopes to have a good rest.  Francis Jr is at Bupshire so all the children are cared for.  Sister Eleanor & Tom I believe are going to Bupshire soon & Wistar to the South on business so the house will be deserted  for awhile.  Katy & the childrenpropose coming home on 3rd day.  Frank came on to the funeral but went back last night, I am glad for him to have a visit there.  Emma Edwards fell in her house and broke her hip, she is now very ill not expected to live & her life is not to be [---] under the circumstances.  I had an active time last week attending meetings but got on better than I expected to, tomorrow is Phila Quarterly Mg & 5th day ours, after that I shall take a rest and do a little here at home, as I see many things that need looking after.  I dont know when Esther will come home probably in about a week.  A great deal of love to dear Anna & also for thyself from thy attached sister
   
   Hannah B. Evans

Title: 1911 September 16, Awbury, to Grandma

Awbury, 
   September 16th
   
   Dearest Grandma, 
   
   It was dear of thee to write to me & I certainly appreciate thy doing so & thank thee very much.  Mother, Aunt Lilly Alg & I have already enjoyed thy letter & I will give it to Harold when I get a chance.  He is over near the polls this afternoon trying to get people to register, as this is the last day.  This evening he is going3
   down to Mrs. [Brabury's].  Thee knows he is to be an usher for Paul Brown next fourth day. 
   
   I am sorry not to have written before this to thank thee for the lovely visit I had at4
   Northeast.  I did so enjoy it, & you have done so much for us all,- this summer.  Thank thee very much, dear Grandma, & I want to thank Uncle Tom, too.  I am so sorry to have given so5
   much trouble with my ticket & hot-water bag! 
   
   Well!  the wedding came off yesterday, & in spite of the rain it was lovely.  Jac made such a lovely little bride, & Edward was beaming.6
   They had the ceremony in the large parlor right in front of the Mantel-piece this way-
   [illustration] 
   The mantel piece was decorated with maiden-hair & white7
   [---] & there were jars of white daisy-like flowers on each side.  Little Theodore & Brewster in white sailor suits & with little baskets of tiny white chrysanthemums stood on one side.  They did not8
   walk in.  Joe & Alg walked in just as we started the first hymn-  Dick is bringing thee a leaflet with the hymns on it-  Then Theodora & Eleanor came walking in with little Mary be-9
   tween them- all with baskets like the little boys- then came Jac & her father.  They all stood in front of the fire place.  The ceremony was lovely- Joe was fine & Ed & Jac were "dear"10
   & it was all so solemn & full of feeling.  After the benediction they all sat down-  I tried to mark where on the plan- & there was a few minutes of silent worship.  Then the last hymn & they11
   walked out.  They came back soon, however, & stood in front of the mantel to speak to people.  We all sat down to the breakfast.  There were 24 at the brides table- I will put in a plan to show12
   how we sat.  There was an enormous bride's cake in the center & this with white [---] & white china [---] as decoration made the table pretty.  The cake had a ring, thimble & piece of money in it & Jac cut13
   it.  They had no wedding cake.  They got off very nicely in Henry Scattergoods auto, after running down stairs & through the crowd & getting sprinkled with rice! 14
   I expect Dick will be with thee by the time this arrives & will tell thee about the wedding.  Please give her my best love & tell her I will write to her soon.  Please give my love to Aunt Anna & Uncle Theo. & Uncle Tom & keep much, dear Grandma, for thyself,
   from
   Thy loving
   Anna

Title: 1873 July 26, London, to brother

London 7 mo 26th 73
   
   Dear brother
   
   I have been intending for some time to write thee a letter but since our arrival in London there has been so much to do and so little time for writing that I have dont next to nothing in that line-  And now what shall I tell thee about for between Chellie and Tom both of whom have written I feel as if there was nothing left for me to say-  On fifth day last we went to the Zoological Garden and I do wish thee could have been along, we were very much amused as well as interested-
   
   The first thing that struck us in particular was the storks.  With their long legs (only one of which they stand upon at a time) their necks which they draw well down between their hunched up shoulders, their grave or rather I may say melancholy expression gives them a ridiculous appearance and when they gyrate or give a great jump as they sometimes do with no apparent object it was perfectly [inesistable]-  The monkey house also proved a place of no small amusement-  as we visited it about 11 o'clock I suppose it was the hour for the old monkies to be taking their morning naps however that may be a number of them were asleep-  One old ape amused us very much he was taking a nap upon one of the bars and apparently the last idea that had entered his head beforefalling asleep was that it would be desirable to scratch his head so he would raise his arm until his hand nearly reached his head and then down it would drop, this he repeated over and over again-  In another cage there were three asleep upon one of the roosts with their arms around each other0  In other cages there were the usual pranks and absurdities going on which monkies indulge in. 
   
   The keeper of the laughing hyenas was very obliging and gave us the opportunity of hearing "the very remarkable noise" which the song informs us the animal makes every fifteen minutes"- 
   
   In the snake house every thing seemed to be in a very quiet state most of the snakes being coiled up  under their blankets-  One or two of the Boa Constrictors were tied up in sundry knots and laid out on the tree to sun-  We saw quite as much of them as we care to snakes not being our favorites-  We next visited the Hippopotomi and Rhinoceros.  The former are the most ungainly looking animals I ever saw.  There is a little one only eight months old and altho' so young its body so much longer than an ox.  The keeper brought some grass to feed them and made them open their mouths-  But I will stop for I am afraid I have said too much already about animals-  I think thee would be very amused at some of the servants we see here the absurd way they are dressed-  Not unfrequently5
   we see footmen with drab coats with brass buttons, crimson breeches, white stockings, low shoes and with either white wigs or powdered hair-
     
   The other day I saw an old fashioned coach by an old fashioned coach I mean one driven in the style of olden time four horses with a guard who had a long horn which he was blowing as they drove through the streets.  I believe it is owned and driven by a young lord who having plenty of money and a fancy for that sort of thing amuses himself in this way-  He has men to attend to all the money matters and to the passengers while he just drives-  Yesterdat we went out to the Crystal Palace and spent most of the day there-  It is a wonderful place so much to see-  It is something like our Sanitary Fair was, if thee remembers that, only on a larger scale.  We went around until we were very tired and then we dined.  After dinner we continued out investigations visiting amongst other things the "[---] animals"- These are large creatures made to represent what they suppose some of the extinct species were like-  They are placed about among the trees and on the edge of one of the lakes in natural positions but it struck us there was a good deal of humbling about it-  One sixth day evening last Tom, Rueben, & I went to Parliament-  We couldnot get seats for Chellie and H as they told us they were often engaged a week ahead in the ladies gallery-  We had rather an amusing experience-  We reached the hall about five minutes of nine and were told we would have to wait for a few minutes as the  House was just being made up.  We were seated with a number of others upon benches in the Hall and after waiting for sometime the first was told it might go in and then the second-  We passed up a long flight of stairs and went into a little toom where our tickets (which Tom had purchased from a man in the afternoon) were examined we were in a bitter trepidation while this was going on as we did not know whether they were good for anything or not, however they passed us- As soon as weentered the gallery the janitor came to us and pointed us to seats into which we sank he then told us we must park our hats under the seats, then he turned to another man and told him he must not raise up to see, then he made another man put his umbrella upon the seat behind him not allowing him to hold it in his hand so if he had ordered us to pull off our shoes I should not have been surprised- We heard three or four speeches upon the Army bill and were very much amused-  Every once in a while the speakers would get rather muddled and there would come a succession of aws and grunts and hesitations which was absurd-  And then there were occasional mysterious sounds which at9
   last we discovered was applause in the shape of hear! hear!-  How they made such sounds I dont know it was a kind of mingled mumble and rattle it put me in mind of the child that swallowed the bead necklace-  We stayed until nearly half past eleven and then concluded we had got nearly two shillings worth and would go. 
   
   This morning we went to Westminster meeting and were not a little surprised upon going into see Chas & Anna Sharples and their daughter-  After meeting we had quite a talk with them and learn that they are going to sail on the second of next mo:-  They have visited Vienna Switzerland France &c [---] trip ideed-  We also met Wm Bradford (the Artist) who is spending the summer in London) he was very kind and invited us to come to his studio-  Bevan Braithwaite was at meeting and pressed us to come and see him when we return a very warm hearted Friend.  We expect to leave tomorrow for the north-  Tell mother we are all pretty well-  Please give a great deal of love to father and mother and each one of brothers & sisters.  Tell them none must feel slighted when letters are not addressed to them individually for all our letters are intended for all.  Please give love to them at Uncle Johns & Toms also at School Lane.  Chellie joins me in message of love.  Please excuse this writing as I am using a quill pen which writes better on this paper than a steel one-  With much love I am thy affectionate brother
   JEvans  First Steamer

Frances R Cope
No1 Walnut St
Philadelphia
Pennsylvania
U.S.A.

Francis Hazen Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1857-1897
Date: 1875-11-28
Title: 1875 November 28, Church Lane, to brother

Church Lane 11 mo 28. 75
   
   My dear brother
   
   Having received a message from thee through a letter to Tom, and not being able to plead sickness as a reason for not writing, I am going to send thee a greeting-  Well we are not going to see thee until next spring, it seems a long time, and we were all of us not a little disappointed when the news came.  We were counting the days until the time when thee was to sail and beginning to speculate upon the probable length of the passage, when suddenly all our hopes were dashed-  I was going to say I would not flatter thee by telling thee what lamentations there were on the part of some of us, but I think it does no one harm to know how much they are loved and missed at home, on the contrary I think  to a young man it does good, tending perhaps to keep him out of some things by which he might otherwise be tempted-  Now for the scrape of news I can glean up-  Last fourth day Tom and I drove over to Haverford to bring away thy [chattels?]-  We arranged to go on third day, but on that day we had a regular old fashioned Nor'easter and it poured most of the day-  The next morning about nine oclock Tommy appeared at our house in the [---] with Lady and Eric (Harry having been laid up some time with sore feet) after getting some more warm wraps for it had cleared off quite cold when we started-  The roads were in a pretty miserable state of muddiness and as we undertook to go by the Lancaster road we almost stuck so to speak-  However we reached the College about half past eleven, and finding the students in recitation we went up stairs and explored-  We found all thy things had been moved out of thy room and were locked up in another closet of which the matron hadkey so she had to be hunted up-  We packed most of the books and some other things in a drawer which Tommy and I carried down to the front door Tommy saying it was "like carrying down a little coffin"-  We donated to Frank Haines a bottle of eye wash, a little bottle of carbolic acid and a few other valuables?-  Thus were the last rites performed-  We packed the books in the bottom of the wagon, and put the precious articles, around with we supposed tender associations ( clung , (a broken fan with names thereon &c) between folds of the down cover-  We drove home to dinner reaching Awbury about quarter of four-  We had a good laugh at Tom - one of the objects over was to bring home the hanging book shelf and we forgot all about it, and came home without it - which rankled in Tommy's breast-  By the way talking of Haverford does thee know they have raised a sufficient amount of money to enable them to build, and Samuel Alsop Jr told me it was decided to go ahead-  The day we werethere was the day before Thanksgiving day, and as I waited upstairs in the entry while Tom was hunting up the Matron I was amused at two of the students, one was in the hall down stairs and as the other came out I suppose from recitation - he announced the fact that they were going to have Turkey for dinner, whereupon there went up such a howl of rejoicing as almost upset me-  We hoped while at Haverford to have had time to have called upon Margaret Yarnall, but we spent to much time at Any Marys that we had not time.  I suppose you have heard that Ellis and M Yarnall are boarding at [---] during the Winter.  I am glad to hear they are vert comfortably fixed-  It seems an out of the way kind of place for them, a good deal away from most of the latter's friends, I should think she would long to have her daughter with her.  I do feel for them very much-  First day 12/5.  A week, my dear Afred, has passed since I commenced this letter yet it is not finished.5
   During the week we have been pained from day to day to hear of Uncle Alfred's increasing illness.  As early as the beginning of the week Dr Wister said he seemed to be failing, and on second day they telegraphed for James, they received an answer the next morning only saying "will come" and that is all they have heard.  Up to second day Uncle Alfred has been able to get over into the library, this he has accomplished with the aid of a man who has been staying with him at night for a number of weeks- assisting him to dress and undress.  One second day he was so much weaker that he had to remain in bed- and since then he has been gradually growing weaker and weaker, until yesterday afternoon about three o'clock he quietly passed away-  He does not seem to have had any acute disease-  His appetite almost entirely gave out, and he gradually weakened - with the exception of a pain in one of his lungs I do not think he has suffered any-  Since last first day Uncle Tom and John E Carter have been sitting up with him half of alternate nights, the nurse sitting up the other half.  Lilly and Edward have been staying over at Fairfield for the last day or two-  Yesterday morning having heard how he was the evening before Father, Uncle Tom and Aunt Lizzie went over there, the Doctor came soon after they arrived and said he did not think he could live but a few minutes.  They went up into his room (except Father who had gone on to town) and sat there for two hours awaiting the close- he seemed entirely conscious but lay perfectly still excepting once when he passed his hand through his hair as his custom was and once he put his hand under his head-  They went to dinner and a few minutes after dinner was over he passed away, no one but Aunt Rebecca, Lily and Edward being present.  Just at the close, there was a short spasm and then to him all was joy and peace and rest-  What a wonderful and glorious change it must be for him after a long life of ill health and suffering during which I suppose he could never have said he really felt well, to awake inthat Holy City none of whose inhabitants can say I sick and where "there shall be no more death, neither sorrow nor crying, neither shall there be ay more pain: for the former things are passed away"-  Aunt Caroline seems to feel it very much, not having seen for some time except a few days ago, when hearing how sick he was she went out to see him, but ut was thought best for her not to go in the room or let him see her so she looked at him through the door-  The only remarks I have heard that Uncle Alfred made (though he probably said more which I have not heard) were that some days ago he told J.E.C. "that it made very little difference which way it ended" meaning his sickness-  To E. Allen who visited home within a few days, and as she was leaving said she supposed she should never see him on earth again and that she did not doubt but that the change would be a glorious one to him he replied "I have been forced to feel very quiet and peaceful"  I think those were the words he used-  The funeral is to be next third day at two oclock.  It will be a great trial I doubt not to James to find all over when hearrives - 
   
   Last sixth day Uncle Tom commenced his winter readings and it was said to have been a very interesting occasion-  Neither Chellie nor I was able to get there-  There is a good deal of stir in our City now over the meetings of Moody & Sankey-  They have fitted up the old freight depot of the Pennsylvania RR so that it will seat about eleven thousand and meetings are being held I think twice on week days and three times on first days - they are largely attended and from accounts some of them must be impressive.  I hope they may do good-
   
   I suppose Mother in her weekly letter told you that Hazen had sprained his ancle, turned it under him as he was rushing out of the side door to catch the train-  Tommy seems to think it was a mercy he sprained it as it will probably save him from something worse if he will only take warning.  He had to hold it up for nearly a week.  However he is about again now tho he says it feels weak.  Aunt Lizzie Brown is still down at Atlantic City where she has been for some 9
   weeks and from accounts does not seem much better.  Aunt Fanny went down last third day taking with her a maid to stay with aunt Lizzie-  I am afraid her sickness is a pretty serious one and not to be gotten over in a hurry.  The rest of them at Grandfathers are pretty well now-  Grandfather has had a cold but is better-  Aunt Martha Leeds I suppose you have heard is at the Frankford Asylum, and from last accounts was not much better in her mind and was also very sick with [---] in her head-  I dont know whether thee has heard or not that the new building at Haverford is to go up next year they having got enough subscribed to warrant them in commencing so Samuel Alsop Jr told me.
   
   Lillies letter from [---] arrived on sixth day last and we were very glad to hear of your being so comfortably and pleasantly fixed-  Please give a great deal of love to both Lilly and Alexis and tell them I often think of them both with much affection and truly it does seem a long long time since we parted with them.  I do hope the stay will do you all a great deal of good-  I am afraid you have missed some of our letters Chell and I both misunderstood and have been directing our letters to Brown-Shipley & Co Liverpool - and I am afraid they have not forwarded them-  I wrote not long ago a letter to thee and one to Lilly and Alexis enclosing a photograph of the baby to each-  If they have never come to hand I will send you another-  Harry has at last made up his mind to return to Minneapolis - he expects to start next fourth day.  I hope he will have a more prosperous time the coming year than he has had the last-  Upon looking over the forepart of this letter which I wrote a week ago I find I have mentioned about the building at Haverford in that so thee will please excuse my telling it again-  I dont feel like rewriting the letter-  Chell sends her love to you all in which I join and wish you "a merry Christmas" and "a happy New Year"-  I remain thy
   loving brother
   J Evans    

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1883-07-12
Title: 1883 July 12, Philadelphia, to wife

Philadelphia, 7 mo. 12 1883
   
   My Darling wife, I stayed out to meeting this morning and on my arrival at this office at noon found thy telegram and Algie's letter awaiting me. Dear little boy I am very glad to hear he is better and it was very thoughtful and kind of thee dearest to telegraph. We are going along very nicely at home. Tom and Alf and I had dinner at 7 o'clock last night and it was very nice. We had fricasseed chicken, potato peas and [beets?] and then raspberries for dessert and tea was on the side board and we each took a cup at the close of the meal. We then adjourned to the piazza at about 8:15. 
   
   [We?] weather is very pleasant the thermo. at my side as I write marking 86° at this hour 3 PM. I was very much surprised to hear of the death of Hannah Newhall. She is to be burried to morrow at 2 o'clock from our house.  I was tired last evening and so did not go over to call until this morning I found Abby and Mary in a very resigned? and very cheerful state. They said they did not regret at all having moved out and were glad of it. They said they were afraid we would not like to have the funeral from our house and hoped there mothers death then would not cast a gloom over the house for us-  I assure them that it would not in the least and that I was very glad they were going to have the funeral from there-  Abby said the great heat of last week seemed to prostrate their mother and she gradually sank away until third day morning she quietly ceased to breathe without struggle-  Ally said she was leaning over her at the time doing something and her bother had her hand closed upon a handkerchief and she said she noticed her hand gently relaxed and ther handkerchief dropped this was all that markedthe change.  William Newhall was there and he told me he was so glad his sisters had such a place to stay in and Abby and Mary both seems so glad they were when they were and not at a boarding house or hotel.  They said it had seemed like home to them from the very first day they move out.  I sent them some flowers on my way to meeting.  They want me to be on hand at the time of the funeral to do some things for them so I shall go out in the 12 M train.
   
   We had a good meeting this morning Cousin James and Samuel Morris spoke-  Cousin James came to me after meeting and said they were so much obliged for our kindness to Anna &c-  I am better dearest the pain in my back is almost entirely gone and my [---] is less.  Tell Mother we concluded it would be more polite for me to call on Lena so I drove over there before meeting and invited her to come over and stay sixth day night with us and she accepted-  Nancy left last evening going into town at 7 o clock.  Everything is moving along very serenely so far as I know.  It is fun to see Tommy studying [---] and Paramous book at the breakfast table getting up a menu winding up by saying "Well!  I hate this business"  My dearest my thoughts are with you a great great deal and I do hope thee will take care of thyself and that you all may be better.  Give my love to Father Mother and all the rest and wish a heartful for thy own dear self I am thine
   J Evans.
   Dont tire thyself with writing much altho it is delightful to hear from thee.  

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1883-07-15
Title: 1883 July 15, Awbury, to wife

Awbury 7/15-83
   
   My own dear wife
   
   Anna and Hazen arrived home yesterday in good condition and as Anna wrote to mother yesterday I will not go into details of the journey or arrival.  They were however the [---] of various testimonials of love to me so that I feel quite rich.  Dear little children how sweet it was of them, however I am going to write each of them a letter either today or tomorrow.  I am ever so much obliged dearest for thy letter-  I am so glad to hear that Algie seems so much better and hope he will continue to improve-  I am glad thee is not pressing the Cod Liver oil as I am afraid it will upset his stomach and thus do more harm than good.  When thee writes tell me what the Dr thinks of his condition.  I am more and more inclined to think he caught the disease from Edward.
   
   We have been to meeting this morning and had sermons from E. Allen and W Kite and a prayer from Sarah Johnson.  The meeting was small.  We brought Cousin Anna Rhoads home with us as she was all alone-  Cousin James having gone to New Hope to spend First day.  Hazen and Anna expect to go over to Cousin C Hartshorne to tea this evening.  We are getting along very nicely dearest and thee need not feel the least concerned about.  I am really very comfortable and as to health am much better I have a good appetite in fact I expect I eat too much for my dyspepsia - which however is better - And now dearest I want to tell thee that I am sorry I said what I did at Newport-  I know my natural tendency is when everything goes along smoothly to settle down build castles in thr air and enjoy this world and I have no doubt that I need to be [---] more and more from this world and that our loving and merciful Heavenly Father breaks up my rest and [---] this world's pleasures that I may look beyond and have my heart fixed on Heaven and Heavenly things -  Our Heavenly Father does not willingly affect and if it only has the effect intended it will be but one of the light affliction which last but for a moment-  Therefore my dearest pray that I may grow better and better - I reallylong that such may be the case but the flesh is very weak.  I feel as our dear children are growing up I should be a better example to them -  So dearest do not worry about me but try and get well and strong-  I think of thee very very often with the tenderest love and pray that we may grow together in best things which I know will make us happen and happen in each other and in out Children.  Farewell dearest.  Give my love to Mother and Aunt Mary and the [---] abd with lots for thy own dear self 
      I am thy loving husband
      JE.  

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1864-08-21
Title: 1864 August 21, Newport, to Mother

Newport Aug 21 1864
  1st day
  
  Dear Mother
  
  Aunt Mary received thy letter this morning or rather we did as we all read it first & then gave it to aunt Mary.  Cousin Charles & Carry & cousin Ellie Yarnall arrived last night or rather this morning, as the boat didnt get in till after 5 o'clock, consequently they were so tired that they are not going to get up till dinner time.  they could not get any state rooms & had to take berths so were very sick.  We took cousin Becky Howell & Annie out riding yesterday afternoon over to the three beaches & had a splendid time & got a good many shells, then in the evening we went out rowing on the bay with Eddie Howell & uncle H (the former makes a pretty good [bean?]) in the moonlight & sought the waves of the steam boats coming in, it was splendid, Lilly tried to row a little, but did not succeed very well.  Tell Aunt Annie I am going to get the story of the Haunted House fresh from Hannah Williams & Lilly or I will write it to her if she wants to know it very badly.  We were very glad to hear that you have cooler weather at home it must have been very hot - (pardonme, mamma) but it is only a slip of the tongue, I have in vain looked for hot in thy letters it's only "excessively warm."  Tell Hazen, Anna says she is going to bring home some shells to him & she wants him to answer her letter to him as soon as possible.  Aunt Mary sends her love & says she thinks she feels a little stronger though she don't attempt to walk far.  Anna wants me to tell Franky that some of the shells she is going to bring him are called boats & if he will put them in water they will float.  Love to papa, Alfred, Nannie & all at home & believe me thy loving daughter
  Chellie 2nd day
  
  Dear Sister-
  Chellie received thy letter at the dinner table to day, but feels rather disinclined to write in the few minutes we have to spare before going to ride.  We had a fine South West wind yesterday and again to day so that the surf at the bathing beach was first rate this morning.  Charles and Carry, Elly and our party with two ladies from this house made a [load?] for the omnibus and we all enjoyed the sight and sound of the beaches very much, but Henry, Jimmie, Elly, and Lilly, were the only ones to go in.  they had a splendid bath they said.  H. unfortunately is deaf in one ear since and does not feel quite well so I doubt their going in tomorrow unless C. escorts them - and he has the rheumatism - Charly thinks Newport air is all sufficient without bathing.-  H. says I have no time to write as the carriage will be here.  Chelly is quite well, and all the rest.  aff thy sister Mary
  Love to Frank and the children. P.S. Dear Frank - In writing my review which is on hand, I want to make sure of a word I think wrongly used in the book review, and have no dictionary here.  Will thee please look in your Imperial Dictionary, - or the Text of the Iconographic (Anatomical part) & send me word, if found, in your next letter, whether there are not two words, ilium and ileum,
  and the definition of the latter, if,
  as I am almost certain, there are the two,
  affly - [---] Newport Aug 21 1864
  1st day

  Aunt Mary received thy letter this morning or rather we did as we all read it first & then gave it to aunt Mary. Title: 1864 August 21, Newport, to Mother

Newport Aug 21 1864
  1st day
  
  Dear Mother
  
  Aunt Mary received thy letter this morning or rather we did as we all read it first & then gave it to aunt Mary.  Cousin Charles & Carry & cousin Ellie Yarnall arrived last night or rather this morning, as the boat didnt get in till after 5 o'clock, consequently they were so tired that they are not going to get up till dinner time.  they could not get any state rooms & had to take berths so were very sick. Anna wants me to tell Franky that some of the shells she is going to bring him are called boats & if he will put them in water they will float.  Love to papa, Alfred, Nannie & all at home & believe me thy loving daughter
  Chellie 2nd day

  and the definition of the latter, if,
  as I am almost certain, there are the two,
  affly - [---] Newport Aug 21 1864
  1st day
  
  Dear Mother
  
  Aunt Mary received thy letter this morning or rather we did as we all read it first & then gave it to aunt Mary.  Cousin Charles & Carry & cousin Ellie Yarnall arrived last night or rather this morning, as the boat didnt get in till after 5 o'clock, consequently they were so tired that they are not going to get up till dinner time.  they could not get any state rooms & had to take berths so were very sick.  We took cousin Becky Howell & Annie out riding yesterday afternoon over to the three beaches & had a splendid time & got a good many shells, then in the evening we went out rowing on the bay with Eddie Howell & uncle H (the former makes a pretty good [bean?]) in the moonlight & sought the waves of the steam boats coming in, it was splendid, Lilly tried to row a little, but did not succeed very well.  Tell Aunt Annie I am going to get the story of the Haunted House fresh from Hannah Williams & Lilly or I will write it to her if she wants to know it very badly.  We were very glad to hear that you have cooler weather at home it must have been very hot - (pardonme, mamma) but it is only a slip of the tongue, I have in vain looked for hot in thy letters it's only "excessively warm."  Tell Hazen, Anna says she is going to bring home some shells to him & she wants him to answer her letter to him as soon as possible.  Aunt Mary sends her love & says she thinks she feels a little stronger though she don't attempt to walk far.  Anna wants me to tell Franky that some of the shells she is going to bring him are called boats & if he will put them in water they will float.  Love to papa, Alfred, Nannie & all at home & believe me thy loving daughter
  Chellie 2nd day
  
  Dear Sister-
  Chellie received thy letter at the dinner table to day, but feels rather disinclined to write in the few minutes we have to spare before going to ride.  We had a fine South West wind yesterday and again to day so that the surf at the bathing beach was first rate this morning.  Charles and Carry, Elly and our party with two ladies from this house made a [load?] for the omnibus and we all enjoyed the sight and sound of the beaches very much, but Henry, Jimmie, Elly, and Lilly, were the only ones to go in.  they had a splendid bath they said.  H. unfortunately is deaf in one ear since and does not feel quite well so I doubt their going in tomorrow unless C. escorts them - and he has the rheumatism - Charly thinks Newport air is all sufficient without bathing.-  H. says I have no time to write as the carriage will be here.  Chelly is quite well, and all the rest.  aff thy sister Mary
  Love to Frank and the children. P.S. Dear Frank - In writing my review which is on hand, I want to make sure of a word I think wrongly used in the book review, and have no dictionary here.  Will thee please look in your Imperial Dictionary, - or the Text of the Iconographic (Anatomical part) & send me word, if found, in your next letter, whether there are not two words, ilium and ileum,
  and the definition of the latter, if,
  as I am almost certain, there are the two,
  affly - [---]

Title: 1864 August 21, Newport, to Mother

Newport Aug 21 1864
  1st day
  
  Dear Mother
  
  Aunt Mary received thy letter this morning or rather we did as we all read it first & then gave it to aunt Mary.  Cousin Charles & Carry & cousin Ellie Yarnall arrived last night or rather this morning, as the boat didnt get in till after 5 o'clock, consequently they were so tired that they are not going to get up till dinner time.  they could not get any state rooms & had to take berths so were very sick.  We took cousin Becky Howell & Annie out riding yesterday afternoon over to the three beaches & had a splendid time & got a good many shells, then in the evening we went out rowing on the bay with Eddie Howell & uncle H (the former makes a pretty good [bean?]) in the moonlight & sought the waves of the steam boats coming in, it was splendid, Lilly tried to row a little, but did not succeed very well.  Tell Aunt Annie I am going to get the story of the Haunted House fresh from Hannah Williams & Lilly or I will write it to her if she wants to know it very badly.  We were very glad to hear that you have cooler weather at home it must have been very hot - (pardonme, mamma) but it is only a slip of the tongue, I have in vain looked for hot in thy letters it's only "excessively warm."  Tell Hazen, Anna says she is going to bring home some shells to him & she wants him to answer her letter to him as soon as possible.  Aunt Mary sends her love & says she thinks she feels a little stronger though she don't attempt to walk far.  Anna wants me to tell Franky that some of the shells she is going to bring him are called boats & if he will put them in water they will float.  Love to papa, Alfred, Nannie & all at home & believe me thy loving daughter
  Chellie 2nd day
  
  Dear Sister-
  Chellie received thy letter at the dinner table to day, but feels rather disinclined to write in the few minutes we have to spare before going to ride.  We had a fine South West wind yesterday and again to day so that the surf at the bathing beach was first rate this morning.  Charles and Carry, Elly and our party with two ladies from this house made a [load?] for the omnibus and we all enjoyed the sight and sound of the beaches very much, but Henry, Jimmie, Elly, and Lilly, were the only ones to go in.  they had a splendid bath they said.  H. unfortunately is deaf in one ear since and does not feel quite well so I doubt their going in tomorrow unless C. escorts them - and he has the rheumatism - Charly thinks Newport air is all sufficient without bathing.-  H. says I have no time to write as the carriage will be here.  Chelly is quite well, and all the rest.  aff thy sister Mary
  Love to Frank and the children. P.S. Dear Frank - In writing my review which is on hand, I want to make sure of a word I think wrongly used in the book review, and have no dictionary here.  Will thee please look in your Imperial Dictionary, - or the Text of the Iconographic (Anatomical part) & send me word, if found, in your next letter, whether there are not two words, ilium and ileum,
  and the definition of the latter, if,
  as I am almost certain, there are the two,

--------------------------------------------------------POLITICAL

--------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1865-04-11
Title: 1865 April 11, B, to Mother and sisters

B – 4/11

Dear Mother & sisters,
I think I shall            take to writing to you in a journal form, as I often have            little times when I can sit down for a few minutes & no            longer.  I recd thy letter Carry of the 9th wh. was very            nice & also the cuffs, wh. were also very nice, & I am very            much obliged to whoever did ‘em & that person was mother I            reckon & it was very good of her & they were just what I            wanted. & now if you can only send me a white skirt, I shall            be so [g---] for I can hardly get along without, as I find            the one I brot will hardly bear another washing.
On 4th            day eve. I took tea at Mart. Chestons & had such a nice            time.  Altho’ she is so feeble that she washardly able to sit up all the even, she insisted upon      inviting a few others to make it pleasant for me – & I thot      it was so kind in her. The party consisted of H Lytle (who      is such a nice & good person) Julia Valentine Dr Thomas H.      King & Jesse – & we had such a nice home-like time, & such      an elegant tea & Ice cream & all.  I thought it the nicest      visit I have paid, & then in the evening as it was rainy she      wd. insist upon sending us home in the carriage & she asked      me so kindly to come there any time when I felt like it,      that I felt quite gratified.  It rained so much the      afternoon I was to go out to Careys – that it was deferred      so I have not been yet, & I believe I have’nt done anything      in particular else, since [---] wrote last.  While I think      of it Caroline Ill ans. thy questions. There are 200 chil’n      in our sch. & 4 teachers wh. makes 1 to every 50.  Mine is      the least advanced class & consequently the least      interesting.  Ages, frm. abt, 7 yrs. to 15 or 16. & strange      to say the smallest chil’n in my sch are generally the best      scholars. The greater proportion are boys, about a third      girls. They are children of this place who have not hitherto      had the advantage of free schools.
End of first sitting.3rd day – 18th
I have laid aside my letter for two or      three days, – for we have all felt so sad since hearing the      dreadful news that I cld. not feel like writing abt.      ordinary things & there seemed little to say on the one      great subject – the presidents dreadful death, wh. seemed      dreadful enough to strike every one dumb with horror &      astonishment.  It seemed so near to us, & the more so      because the very day after wh. it occurred we had planned to      make a little excursion to Washington for the day having      been invited by one of Miss M’s frds. who often goes down.       So you can judge of our horror when a few min. before      setting out, this dreadful intelligence was brot. to us. The      feeling here against the seccessionists has been intense as      they have been heard to rejoice in the sts. at thedreadful news, & to have prophesied a few days since that   our rejoicings wld. be turned to sorrow.  The city was under   martial law for a day or two – but by the strict vigilance   of the authorities was kept quiet.  but they compelled every   secessionist as well as union on the principal business sts   to drape their stores in mourning & [if] the appearance it   presents is very solemn & sad.  I suppose it is the same in   Phila. – & everywhere.  It seems really a more horrible   thing than some we have shrunk frm. reading in books of   history.  People here seem to be sanguine about the new   administration – & the prospects of peace, but that does not   take away frm. the horrible fact that there can exist in our   midst such a wicked & fiendish spirit.
4th day morn — our   school has been dismissed to day on account of the   solemnities wh. are to be observed in the churches &   elsewhere
We also had a holliday on 2nd day & Jesse Tyson   very kindly took advantage of it to take us a very beautiful   ride to a lake abt. 7 miles frm. here wh. is situated among   hills & woods as beautiful as any Iever saw.  I had no idea there was anything of the kind so   near to the city.  It was delightful to get a sight of the   beautiful spring in the country.  The trees are just putting   out their first leaves, & look so lovely, & we cld. not but   enjoy it in spite of the mournful circumstances wh. have   been so much in our minds,  Jesse took us past his place,   where he wishes to erect his model house.  It is a very   beautiful situation indeed with views of the city & the bay   &c.
I suppose you (that is some of you) are in the midst   of yearly meeting now. but the sad newsmust have thrown a great damp over every thing.
We have   been spending two or three afternoons this week at the   meeting house sewing for the refugees.  The friends have a   sewing machine there, & meet every day this week to sew.  &   they will get a good deal accomplished no doubt.  Julia   Valentine seems to be very active & is a very nice frd.  I   [am] [you] [will] try to call on [Tamy] Miller when she is   in P again as she — Aunt has been so kind in asking me to   come out there &c.
Clementine Cope.
If you can find   out when [Tamy] will be in P I have no doubt she wld. bring   any package.  I want to go out this morning to get one or   two thins so I will bring my letter to a close.  Hope I   shall get one frm. you today but suppose you have felt   unlike writing as I have.  But for this, I shd. have written   to Tom this week, tell him.  Give my love to Cous. T. & all   enquiring frds. am glad to hear you miss me a little some   times.  Yours affec Clemmy
I miss you very much

Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911

Title: 1905 July 17, Philadelphia, to Mr. Jonothan Evans, Jamestown, R.I.

WILLIAM DRAPER LEWIS.

Philadelphia, July   17, 1905

Mr. Jonothan Evans,
Jamestown,   R.I.
