----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William Draper Lewis:  1867-1949
Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Date: 1905-08-27
Title: 1905 August 27, Northeast Harbor, Me, to Jonnie

WD. Lewis
8 mo 27. 05

North East Harbor, Me
Aug   27- ‘05

My dear Jonnie,

We have not heard from   the crime paper. Edward, however, I happen to know has a   [--] in it, as Mikell used his paper as a model for the   person he secured to read the other papers. This is not   publicinformation, though there is no reason why Edward should not   know. You ought to be proud of that boy. He has not only   done well -- he has done splendidly, and I understand that   either he or his friend Kratz leads the class with higher   marks than we have given in the first year for several   years. Good brains have helped, - but hard steady work has   been the realfactor. Two things gave me special satisfaction; one that I   did not know his handwriting, and the other that I had   marked him higher than anyone else in my subject, writing   across the face of his paper just after reading it: “a Jim   dum dandy man”. 

Father is a great deal better – up   and about. I have just returned from Narragansett. Weather   perfect here.uppose it is also with you. All send   love.

Affectionately

Wm. Draper Lewis

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Annette Cope:  1843-1916
Date: 1865-04-25
Title: 1865 April 25, Baltimore, to Net

Baltimore 4.25.

Dear Net,
I have just got thy   letter of the 1st to the 19th inclusive, (where has it been   so long?)  Its very well I did’nt go on with the great scold   I began yesterday — I thot, I wld defer it one day longer &   see – Why I dont believe you know how long you’ve been   neglecting me, & thee must remember while thee’s   journalizing that thy writing every day is’nt my getting   it,.  However it was very interesting if not very late news.   Thee does’nt say a word about having got either of my last   letters,  I hope the one containing my elaborate sketch of   the Environs of the city & my room as a centre, did not get   lost, as it wld. have been a waste of artistic   effort.
The presidents death has indeed made mourning in   our land.  The ways of Providence are very inscrutable.  I   told you in my last letter of the feeling produced here, so   I will notrevert to it..  The day of the funeral procession here was   very solemn.  We dismissed our school, & went by particular   invitation to where we cld. have an excellent view of the   whole as it passed, at the store of an old gentleman in   market st, where we had a room to ourselves & refreshments   provided wh. seemed rather singular but is his custom.  It   was the most touching & mournful procession I ever saw    Perhaps you saw it in Phila.  It will take a long time to   forget the grief & horror of this sad event,– but work has   to be done & yesterday our sch. began [afresh] after the   interruptions of the week before, & while sch. lasts we are   forced to forget every thing but the work before us.  It is   what you might call intense work. & wld. be wearing [--]   [----] [----] if incessant.  Thy description of getting   home, & the nice clean room & all most made me home-sick.  I   miss great many of the little home luxuries and cleannesses   here,– but cannot expect to have them in boarding.  We dont   get any good Mrs [Mcaff--] [----] [butter] &c — excepting   when we get invited out to our rich frds.
I was perfectly   charmed with my visit at Carey’s last 6th day night.  Their   place is perfectly magnificent & the house keeping   altogether princely compared to this.  I went out in the   afternoon & returned next morning.  Their house situated on   the tip top of a [very] hill seems like something up in the   air, & the view splendidSusan Carey has gone to Phil. & expects to return next 7 or   2 day.  She very kindly offered to bring anything for me —   said she wld. have room for any sized bundle, so that I   might get my silk skt.  But it is so late in the season that   I think I can do without it, & I shd. not like to ask her to   bring so large a thing.  I wld. like tho’ to have my old   blk. silk body & I wish thee wld send me a little brown   grenadine bag of horse hair in the right hand corner of my   upper beaureau drawer.  These things however are not very   important, & you need not send them if inconvenient.+    [+Perhaps you can send them by T Miller instead.]  S Carey   stays at Anthony Kimbers cor. 13. & Arch.  I yesterday recd   the skt. sent by Alford Coale for wh. I am much obliged.    Mary Pennyman called yesterday & was very pleasantLizzie Hopkins of the house where Lizzie Edge, Jenny Harris   &c staid, called to see me also, & some Matthews wh. lives   in the country said Lizzie E had written to her that I was   here & that she intended to invite me out to her place in   the country, a very pleasant one I understand.  A gentleman   called here night before last — Miller M Kim whom you have   perhaps heard of — one of the Freedmens board in Phila. &   [----] me a message frm. Cous. Frank whom he had seen the   day before.  Tho’ a stranger he seemed quite like somebody   from home.  To night I am going with H Lytle to the frds.   bible class, meeting at Dr. Thomas’ — it is attended by   frds. mostly, altho’ Ellen Carey who is an episcopalean &   one or two others attend.  They say it is very interesting,   tho’ I have’nt been before.  A few days ago I went to hear   Thomas Beecher a (brother of H Wards) speak, but was   disappointed, as it was nothing very interesting.     I cld.   not make out by thy journal exactly when your visit to Aunt   C’s began or ended, but am glad you had a nice time.  Give   my love to them & tell them I hope they’ll ans. my note.    Love also to Cous. F & M.  You were quite enterprising to   walk up to Athensville.  I am going to try & write to Tom

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan S. Reeve:  1833-1866
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1865-05-27
Title: 1865 May 27, Locust Shade, to Annie

Locust Shade. 5. 27. [18]65

My dear Annie, 

It   seems to me that a very improper time has elapsed since the   receipt of they welcome letter, without my having answered   it - but as we are both well hosted in excuses I will not   add to the list.- Just as I began my letter, thy kind note   was handed me - & I truly thank thee for it and should love   to comply with they request - but [dont] see that it would    be possible. Besides dearie I want thee to come here - and   hope to persuade thee to do so.- Your place must indeed   looklovely & I have thought several times how I should like   to look uponits beauty and enjoy your society - which is always so   pleasant, but I must deny myself this time- I want too, to   hear about the wedding & Clemmy & diverse other things. Our   “Strawberry Company” as thee calls it, is not here- tho we   have had several of our friends the past week, - and shall   probably have more [next]. - - Our cook had gone away for a   fortnights visit, half of the time is gone - at which I   rejoice, and this is another reason why I cannot leave home-   the next week father and mother will be away for a Sundays-   and after that I do hope thee will come to see me. Any day   that suits thee we shall gladly welcome thee. - 

I   heard from Deborah Thomas that Clemmy was pleasantly   situated and like her occupation.- Thee must miss her visits   very much & she thine. - Lily seemsquite absented in her work and is turning out a very      managing young lady - it will probably be of great use to      her in calling out her latent energies.- 

How many      remarkable & [steming]  events have transpired since we were      together.- It seems to me we have, every day, reason to      mourn death of our own dear good President -  Johnson is so      different - & if he should get us into a Mexican war it      would be so sad. But we can but hope for the best. Was it      not wonderful how suddenly & completely the Rebellion cam to      an end. Like the “One hoss slay”- it all broke down at      once.- Poor Jeff makes a sorry figure in his humiliation he      is showing very plainly what a poor miserable specimen  of a      man he was.- Niether true courage or honor in the slightest      appreciative of his great crimes. -- We have justhad our Bettie at home for ten days and busy enough we were   with her spring clothing - she comes back again the last of   next month for vacation.- She is growing so companionable   that I miss her when she is gone very much.-
I am glad to   hear Uncle D B Smith sometimes gets to your house. no doubt   it does him good. Wish I could see him. Will thee give him   my love when thee see him.- Suppose Uncle John & Aunt R   Smith & cos Lizzie are out in the broad Ocean. we hear our   cousin Richard Howland was to go with them, but do not know   if its true. If aunt R’s health is improved - it will be   delightful for them all to be together. Would thee not like   to go if thee could do so properly? - I should exceedingly,   but probably never shall, my life seems destined to be very   unadventurous and matter of fact, - all for the best no   doubt.- Do Lilly & her Philip’slive in Germantown? What a favored place you live in all the  nice people do mostly congregate there. R wishes to be  remembered to thee & hopes sometime to accept the very kind  invitation. Just now I [----] [------] are all engrossing. -  I hope thy father is pretty well this spring please remember  me to him.- With much love I am very truly thee thee  at[----] 
S. S. Reeve

I hope thee has not got any  of those little salt sellars yet, as I have has a pair  waiting for thee ever so long, Will send them down next week  if I can. - 


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles M. Drinker
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1806-1875
Date: 1862-08-07
Title: 1862 August 7, Scranton Pa, to Alfred Cope Esq

Scranton Pa Aug 7th. 1862
Alfred Cope Esq
Dear   Sir
I write to you to request you to procure for me a   Situation in the Navy as Captains Clerk if Possible  I   should enlist in the Army but I am the only one at home to   care for my Mother & Sisters & they object to my so doing, I   may be drafted under the new call & for this reason they   will feel satisfied if I can get an opportunity in the Navy   as the service is not so hard
very respectfully your   friend
Charles M Drinker


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas) Cope:  1850-1883

Title: 1865 May 10, Baltimore, to Tom

Baltimore 5. 10th. 65

Dear Tom,
Thee must excuse   me for having been so long answering thy letter, & not think   that I did not care about it, for I was right pleased that   thee wrote to me, & I have said to myself ever so many times   [said] that I must write to that “Little “Toms”—  but thee   sees now I have got to be a school mistress, I have so many   cares that I cant always do[o] what I’d like & then I have   had a good many letters to write to different people &   knowing that thee saw the home ones & knew all about me, I   took it the easier.
I have now been “school”mom=’en” long   enough to get a prety good idea of the business – & my idea   of it is, thatits a good deal easier to be a scholar than I teacher, – so   thee can remember that for thy comfort when thee has a hard   lesson to learn.  To teach a school of troublesome boys I   shd. say was one of the hardest businesses’s that cld. well   be got up..  The girls are bad enough, but when it comes to   boys – – they’re the [---] of man.  I have in my school   about 35 boys & a dozen girls between the ages of 6 & 15 —   The girls I have but little trouble with, but the little   boys are regular monkeys.  No sooner is my back turned than   they begin their discussions of wh. they have a variety —    Its the hardest thing in the world to keep them still, & if   they get a good chance there’s not one of them that is too   good to get up & takea dance or a fight or any other such little amusement that   they think will set the school in an uproar.+  [+ Throwing   spit balls is a very bad habit they have – also dancing “Ham   fat”]  My punishments are various.  Sometimes I shake the   culprit & if that wont do, tie em up hand & foot & put em in   the corner — wh. is a very troublesome operation to me.  But   it seems as if nothing wld. beat it into their heads that   school is any thing but a place to play in.  
Most of   them can read a little some not at all, & like “Busy” – they   must always spell girl gril and dirt – drit –.  It seems as   if it came natural —  One of their best accomplishments is   singing wh. we sometimes let them do in school.  My children   know “my”native country thee” & the colored “Wolunteer”— wh.   they shout out with great effect. But I guess I’ve told thee   enough about the darkies  We’ll talk a little abt.the whites.  How comes on work at Haverford?  By the way thy   hand writing is coming on so well, that when I got thy   letter I thot. it was Busy’s himself, it was so good.    Have’nt you a boy named Allen Thomas,?  I expect he’s a nice   fellow & has two very nice brothers whom I met last eveng.    There are [---] pleasant frieds here & I do not often have a   chance to feel lonely or home sick.  How does Prof. Cope &   his botany lectures?  I am going to try to write him a note   to send in this & consequently must say farewell or shall   not have time.  Thee can take this down home with thee next   7th day & tell ‘em it’s all they’ll get this week.— as they   dont deserve any for some time.  Give my love to all, & if   thee gets time write again to thy affec sister C

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Martha Leeds:  1810?-1888
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1864-06-04
Title: 1864 June 4, Rockview Cottage, to Anne

Rockview Cottage
6 mo 4th 1864 –

My dear   Anne,

From cloud land do I now address thee it has   been raining, raining for days – but we cannot wish it   otherwise as it will raise the mountain springs which were   beginning to fail rapidly it has been rather an anxious care   with us to watch the springs for fear they would give out   before the cisterns were prepared to save the water and the   steam pumps were fixed so that the pure water might be   available for the sick in the Hospitals there are but about   500 patients now but it is hoped that the large field   Hospital at Chattanooga may soon be moved up here and   probably two thirds of the patients that would otherwise die   might recover I think there had been but four deaths since   the Hospital was established here  The air is so fine and   the water runningthrough sand stone rocks the sweetest that could be and I   sometimes think the patients would recover without medicine   –  Several patients extremely ill with pneumonia have lived   although Dr H said they must die –
When it does clear I   expect we shall have one of these magnificent cloud scenes –   Sunshine and blue sky above whilst below us a billowy sea of   clouds looking as if they were frozen as they formed –  I   imagine it must look precisely like an Artic sea –  We have   witnessed two such scenes when it had been raining heavily –   the whole valley completely hid except about half way up the   Mountain –  Anna Harlow is describing some of the cloud   scenes we have had beautifully alluded to the psalm where   they are so grandly described and which we can appreciate   from having witnessed the clouds in their grandeurabove and below us as well as like the present time we have   been for days enveloped in the thick clouds –  "The waters   stood above the mountains At Thy rebuke they fled – at the   voice of thy thunder they hasted away –  They go up by the   Mountains they go down by the valleys unto the place which   thou hast founded for them –  He watereth the hills from his   chambers" &c–  There are many beautiful scenes so much so   that I could not picture them to thee –  I know thee would   enjoy many of the views that are on every hand, not only   from their beauty but from the historic interest that even   now induces people by hundreds to come up the Mountain to   see the celebrated "Lookout" and the scenes in the valley   below us –  I never was at a more charming place I think –    The other day some ladies from Philada. Ellen Parrish sister   to Robert A Parrish and Dr Janney’s daughter spent two days   at our house (and rather inconveniently,two nights as we were obliged to give up our room and our   husbands had to sleep on the floor –  they had come on a   mission of relief to E Tennessee refugees and had become   acquainted with the Commander of the post Col Culver who   offerred them facilities to go to the Lake and Falls about   six miles distant –  Lewis & myself accompanied the party –    It was a scene of rare beauty –  The Falls are not large but   very high and fall in shimmering spray down the most   beautiful rocks –  It seemed to me as though every thing had   been brought to bear to make the place charming  The rocks   of various hues and shaded seemed cut into the most   picturesque forms whilst the clear mountain stream came over   its clean and clear rocky bed & went down the precipice to   the height of 125 feet –  Another face below us which we   could discover by the Mist we did not get to visit –The slopes were covered with Rhodedendron of very large   flower and Laurels and the [Fringe] tree growing wild –  We   came away reluctantly and all of us thought I have no doubt   that we either would visit it again or would more than ever   desire to do so –  The next day being First day our   neighbours Dr Ridgleys who had been up but a few days   started to go there on horseback there were six of them one   of the party told me that she went feeling rather afraid   that it was not right – they had got quite a distance beyond   the pickets and they must have been very near the Falls I   judge when as they were a little off the roadside resting   off their horses they saw a man dressed in Rebel uniform,   grey cloth and brass buttons passed right by them [leading]   his horse and did not take notice of them – one of the   gentlemen called after him after he passed – "My kind sir   where do you belong?" he repliedat General Thomas’ Headquarters.  They all believed him to   be a rebel officer and as he had a large revolver and they   were unarmed he could have captured the whole of them – they   were pretty much frightened and concluded to turn their   horses heads homeward and did not see the Falls – so much   for their pleasure party on First day –  In speaking of it   it was remarked that sometimes our scouts go dressed in   Rebel uniform – it might have been one of them –  There is   another very beautiful place called "Rock City"–  The brow   of this Mountain is crowned with soft kind of Rocks which   look as if some day had been washed and rounded by water   covering them –  Geologists would say they had –  At Rock   City these rocks cover the ground, at one place like a town   and at another we walked over them and gathered the most   beautifullichens and mosses x_, red green & drab, [x  with most   remarkable fissures & clefts all through them] I only wish   we could send you some specimens –  I think we might by   "Adams Express" sometime before we go away when the   facilities [of] transportation are more available than they   are here at present there have been some moms gathered and   sent to the different Fairs for the benefit of the Sanitary   Com. as well as lots of Canes–  The roots of the Laurel are   very hard and beautifully grained large quantities are dug   and articles made of them as mementoes of the place –  Our   Ben has quite a lot which the soldiers gave him when they   went to the Front – which he sells as well as canes to   increase his fortune –
Thee may be very sure that I was   much gratified upon receiving thy kind little note –  I had   not forgotten my promise to write to thee but supposing thee   often heard from us through my Children I did not know   whetherthee cared particularly about my writing added to which I   rather feel averse to tell the same thing over again –   although there is not any lack of incident here –  We have   been living very quietly here the past three months –  We   have had some acquisitions to the place lately but need not   feel alarmed at their being very extensive, without people   build for themselves or live in tents –  As I raise my eyes   I see the tents of Major Mc’Michael and one or two others in   the woods at one side of us – they look very pretty – he is   Adjat to Gen Thomas – is the son of Morton McMichael of   Philada. on the other side is the cottage of Dr Ridgley   Medical Purveyor with two ladies boarding with them and Capt   Edwards from Penn Wife & daughter who board with one of the   old residents are all the Society here except ourselves A   part of an Engineer Brigade about600 men the Officers Hospital of 100 men and convalescents   of the number of 400 are all that live here except three or   four families who have remained through all and are entirely   dependent for provision for what they can purchase through   exchange –  They sell their milk at from 50 cts to $1.00 per   gal eggs 75 cts per doz butter 75 cts per lb and have been   getting in exchange from us flour at 3 1/2 cts per lb sugar   14 cts per lb –  They charge for butter milk 75 & 80 cts per   gal and can get it readily as it is so desirable for the   sick –
I have often recurred to the time I spent at your   house last Spring when I was with you in sympathy by the   Suffering bed of thy dear Mother –  I never witnessed such   suffering and I never recur to it perhaps but with Something   of the tender feelingsthat then pervaded my heart –  I dare say thee often feels   lonely without her dear Anne – but no doubt thee thinks that   thy loss is her gain and that she would not wish to exchange   her bliss in Heaven for any earthly thing – there was a   great deal that was pleasant and sweet that she left below –   Many that have the tastes to enjoy the beautiful could not   have them gratified like the inmates of such a home as you   have but with it all I often felt sorrowful that dear sister   was deprived of the use of her eyes which to me would have   been terrible – but all things have been ordered aright we   cannot doubt –  I would be very glad to hear from thee as   often as thee feels like writing to thy absent but not the   less interested and affectionate 
Aunt Martha –
Please   give my love to Father and all the inmates of your home –

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Elizabeth Sandwith Drinker:  1734-1807
Recipient:  Mary Sandwith
Date: 1771-07-13
Title: 1771 July 13, Bristol, to Mary Sandwith

Bristol July 13. 1771 – 7th day 1 oClock
My dear   Sister

My Henry came here last evening in seeming   good spirits but indifferent Health; he eat a very light   supper, and sett off this morning (after a poor breakfast)   about 8 oClock.  He has a fine day, and I hope riding and   relaxation from business will restore him; he talked of   returning to Bristol on 5th day or perhaps not untill 7th   day next.  Thy continued Confinement and constant care give   me many an anxious minute; but I trust the time will come   when it may please kind Providence to make things easier to   thee.  I was not quite so well yesterday as usual & my dear   Henrys coming to me so unwell gave me pain.  I am quite   bravely to day after coming out of the water but full of   thought about my dear little crowing Henry.  Doct. D.*   [*Denormandie] came here last evening, and, after the usual   salutation, said to me, he was come to have some serious   talk with me; I smiled; nay said he I am in earnest; about   what Doctor? – weaning your little son; such a hearty   growing boy, who seems to live upon you, is enough to draw a   pain in a weakly person, where there had never been one   before; besides he keeps you waking at nights, and prevents   your using means that might restore you; if it was not on   his account you might now go with Mr. Drinker to the sea   shore, and so forth.  There are several women here who I   beleive have put it into the Doctors head that I ought not   to suckle the Child.  My Henry seconded him, and said he   would write this morning to thee, but as he was poorly, I   undertook to do it.–  Do not think my dear, from what I have   written, that I am worse; Indeed I am not through mercy, but   have had the pain in my breast oftener than I had sometime   ago, which I told the Doctor.  I beleive that if I had a   Girl with me that was worth a fig, it would be different,   for the one I have has no knack of making the Child fond of   her.  Doctr. D. says as Doctr. Evans knows my Constitution,   he would have him spoken to. –  I would have thee see the   Doctor and talk with him.  Patty would do a great deal   better than the Girl I have, and should she offer again, I   would not have thee entirely discourage her, but tell her   thee beleives the girl I have does not suit me, and if she   thinks she can behave so as to please me, thee would have   her call again.  It will be time enough (after theehas spoken to Doct. Evans) to come to any conclusion when my   Henry returns.  I had a room full of visitors yesterday   afternoon; two Chariotts full besides others; T. Ringold &   Wife from Maryland; Sally Hoffman, Sukey Pintard, her sister   Boudinott from New York; Serlis’ wife, Betsy Tilghman from   Philada. and Billy Coxe’s daughter, and Sally Tredwell the   Doctors sister.  We all went in the evening to Bath.  I go   but little a visiting, and they all think that my little   dear keeps me at home, and every ones cry is wean him, wean   him; thee would be charmed to see the dear little fellow,   how he daily improves in cunning antick tricks.  I long to   see thee and my dear Children, but dont know how to bring it   about.  My Henry was saying that he was well pleased that I   did not get his letter by Billy Hodge (as he had mentioned   thy being unwell) as thee is now better. – I would have thee   my dear take half a spoonful of the Elixir every day to   strengthen thee.  I have not had occasion to take any since   I came up as yet, but thee knows it was of great use to me   taken in small quantity.  I have been but a little while   writing thus far, but as I have not stopped since I began, I   grow tired, and my dear little one is crying for me; My dear   love is to thee & to my sweet Children, to whom I intend to   write when I can conveniently; they must not be impatient,   but good and kind to each other, & very dutiful & mindful of   their Aunty’s will, which will give great pleasure to their   very affectionate mammy
I am, my dear Sister, thine &c   –
E. Drinker

My dear, dear, kind Henry looked so   unwell as he slept this morning as made my heart ache; he   was last night more than commonly chearful, which I have   observed often to be the case when he is unwell.  how unlike   the generality of Mankind is he in his natural disposition   many ways.  he was last night at supper affectionately   acknowledging thy tender care of him, & saying how clever it   was to have two Wives.  We were likewise wishing that it was   convenient to thee to spend one month here, free from care   of us & ours. –  I hope it may please God to spare me and   restore me to health for my Henrys sake, & that I may be   enabled to make up in some measure to my dear Husband and   Sister their many, many kindnesses to me; but shouldshould it happen otherwise, may I be enabled to say, the   Lords will be done. –

5 oClock – Billy Parr has been   here; he says he saw thee, & that you are all well.  he has   gone to Trenton, where Peggy, Nancy and Caleb are to go   tomorrow; they want me to go, but I shall not.  Molly Foulke   is expected here this evening or in the morning.  Mag.   Divine next second day, so that we shall have the house   full.  Peggy gives her love to thee.  Henry’s asleep, & I am   going to Bath.  farewell my dear Sister for the   present.
E.D.
I wrote yesterday by S. Le Gay, which   letter I suppose thee has received.  I make no doubt but my   dear Henry will return bravely.  tomorrow will be a lonesome   day to me.  my love to neighbour James – 
E.D.Bristol July 13. 1771
Elizabeth Drinker to Mary Sandwith

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1865-06-07
Title: 1865 June 7, B, to Mother and sister Annte

B 6/7—65—

Dear Mother & sister Annte.

I think   I’ll address you collectively this time, as I suppose   Caroline’s head’ll be turned with weddings & unable to   appreciate common topics. I recd. yr. very interesting &   spirited epistles this morn.g & reply at once, in order that   you may not have cause to complain of remissness this time,   & upon what ground you did it last, I must say I cld. not   discover, as I think I have been up to the mark quite as   much as you have. Thy remarks [a] on properness &c were   quite edifying. I expect thee wd. be charmed with the   Baltimore people. They are certainly most social & charming   in their manners, tho’ I dont believe afterall, when you come to the foundation of things that there is   any more good substantial material among them than among   some of that despised class denominated "the proper." As to   the gentlemen I cant say that I have met any whom I consider   very deeply interesting As far as gallantry & politeness go   they are certainly very attractive Bt if we cld. only   introduce a little more of these elements with some of our   [imperturbables] I incline to think these wld. be found   quite as deep in the long run. I must say it is refreshing   to get hold of some thing that is more [impressible] than a   stone & I intend to [---] up Baltimore ways loudly when I   get home. Tell Cousin Mary she must hurry & come down as   fast as she can, or I fearI shall not get to have my sprees with her. This morn the   new teacher who is going to take my sch. arrived & I was   promoted or depressed I dont know wh. to the rank of   assistant to Mr Waterman, the principal of the sch. It is a   splendid change for me, as his room is much pleasanter & I   have none of the discipline to do but only the hearing of   the lessons—intellectually, it seems a most magnificent   advance frm. a-b only to geography and arithmetic & I shd.   be quite willing to teach there for weeks if it was’nt for   the hot weather, as it is, however, considering the [--] &c   I think I had better not stay much after the three months   are up wh. will be abt. the mid of June--& very soon—as you   will perceive, so you may make preparations for me, soon   after that time—I hope you’ll havepleasant little surprise prepared for me in the way of a   closet—wh. wont be the linen closet—I have to keep up such   an everlasting foolding and unfolding here that I shall be   perfectly delighted to get a place to "hang up" in.

I   expect I am indebted to my frd. Jesse for this release frm.   the infants—I said to him in joke some time ago that I thot,   I shd. give "notice" soon for them to get another teacher &   he took it in earnest but I am very glad, on some accts, as   I shd like to get some ideas about older teaching frm Mr.   W.

I expect you’ll enjoy [Mr. N’s] wedding most as   much as Lilly’s—There was a young gentleman here the other   day who told somebody that he thot L’s wedding was   dreadfully stupid, & that he thot’ one or two of the   bridesmaids (he did’nt say all) were the ugliest girls he   had ever seen—not a very complimentary speech I think.
As I shall probably come home so soon it will not be worth   while to send the things by express—tho’ if I cld only have   had them now they wld. have been exceedingly useful -- I   think maybe I’ll try & get myself a beige skt. here & we   shall not be likely to have many more tea parties now the   warm weather has come -- We’ve never heard any more abt.   Jessies strawberry party & we’re afraid he’s forgotten it.   He took us to a small one out at his bro. James’ night   before last. We went in a buggy & pair & came home by   moonlight—quite romantically -- The buggy is only used on   very romantic occasions, I believe. Its so nice here   moonlight nights—the ladies all dress up in their whites &   sit out on the front door steps, & go round [seeing?] one   another with beaux or beau less just as it happens.Has Fanny Drinker gone home? I reckon she has & where is   Cous. Sarah? Give my love to her if she is about still. I   ought to have written to her. Give my love also to all the   Wynndowners also please give my love & congratulations to   all the bride cousins & tell them I’m very sorry not to be   giving them anything-- Maybe if I aint so lazy I’ll make em   something after I get home. But dont tell em that. I believe   this is all I have to say at present—will write and fix the   day of course before I come. If Cous. M. comes soon please   send the shawl and the [b----] skt. as I [---] much love to   all—yrs. affec

ClemmyI shd. be pleased to have some [---] my return & also before   my return

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Henry W. (Henry Waln) Drinker:  1787-1866
Recipient:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Date: 1817-06-13
Title: 1817 June 13, Stoddartsville, to Thomas P. Cope Esq., Philadelphia

Stoddartsville June the 13th. 1817–
Dear Uncle.
By   William Drinker who pass’d Here on the 9th  I receivd thy   remembrance of the 3d inst–  What Charles Miner has done or   is now about I cannot precisely say not hav[ing] seen Him or   any of his friends since [my] Last
I question the   Establishment of the proposed Bank at Wilkes barre & beleive   also that if it ever does go into Operation it will be by   compromise and by a [di----] of the few offices of [---]   attatched to it–  Humble merit will I presume stand but a   poor chance–
Mr Arndt on whom I depended for [the]   Hemlock Bark Has not yet ground it but I hope He will attend   to it shortly–  if it in any degree succeeds [in] England it   will be Highly important to this Count[r]y as well as   convenient to ship overseas–  I beleive that the mak[ing]   pot & pearl Ash might prove an advantageous thing to us more   than to any other persons [We] owning the nearest Large Body   of suitable timber for the purpose – if it will pay for its   mak[ing] & a reasonable sum for outlay & superintendance it   will answer us as a means of clear[ing] Land –
I am glad   that thy mind is made up for a peep at this quarter of the   world – I think it will be likely to be beneficial to thy   Health as also to Aunts – Some Rough travell[ing] there will   no doubt be – but generaly speak[ing] the Roads are   tolerable to the mouth of Tunkhannock–  Thereare no excelent Taverns on the Route so far as I am   acquainted–  I think the one Here is the Best & likely to be   the most pleasant for the Residence of aunt–  Gentlemen can   be well accomodated at Easton & at Wilkes barre at Mr Whites   in the first nammed place & at Mr Arndts in the second in   Both Houses there is Rather too much noise and Drink[ing] to   be entirely agreeable to Ladies –  Here also we have more   noise than is pleasant–  There be from 15 to 20 of Stoddarts   work[ing] hands quart[ere]d in the House –  
The Road by   Easton is Rather worse than that by Bethlehem & Nazareth & I   think generaly the accommodations are better on this last   Route–  from Nazareth to Hellers at the Wind gap at which   House I have generaly procured tolerable Eating & pretty   clean–  from thence about 17 miles to William Sox’s upon the   top of Pokono – where th[e]y make prety good coffee & give   you what ever they may Have in the House in a tolerably   cleanly stile–  from thence to this place say 12 miles   –
The present is about as pleasant a Time to Travel in   this county as any other Dur[ing] the summer – ere the grain   is cut which will not be Done before the Last of next monthHowever the Weather is now variable and we may expect   occasional Rains, until after Harvest – 
in the Last of   August & to the middle of September is generaly more settled   weather – as to the [Gnats] they Have already come & in the   woods Bite sharply–  This [they] will continue to Do until   September – But out of the woods we do not find them   Troublesome– There are not any curiosities worthy a name   from Philada to this place–  The Habits & manners of the   people on the Route may perhaps afford Something novel – The   scenery also & general Aspect of the County will be new –   [marbly] nature in Her Roughest garb will surround you – you   will have pure Air & pure water & I doubt not to good   [appetites] as to enable you to Encounter much coarser fare   than usual – in the neighbourhood of Easton-Bethlehem &   Nazareth is a lime stone county – & I would have you beware   of the water – it is no doubt wholesome but to persons   [unaccustomed] to it it is often unpleasant in its effects–   if I know when you intend com[ing] up I will endeavor to   join you at Hellers – I have been constantly interupted   since I began writing which must excuse this   scrawl–
affectionaly thy nephew. H.W.Drinker –Stoddartsville 
 12 1/2 
June 14th
Thomas P. Cope   Esq.
Merchant
Philada.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Joseph Simpson:  1835-1901
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1894-11-16
Title: 1894 November 16, Sunnyside, Mayfield, Ashbourne, to My dear Friend

Sunnyside
Mayfield
Ashbourne

Nov.16.1894
<br   My dear Friend,
When I received thy very welcome letter,   & the handsome volumes which accompanied it, I felt once   more that strong desire, which often stirs me, to visit   America, & to see again those dear friends who, nearly   thirty years ago, received me there with such unbounded   kindness.  Some of these have passed away, but a few are   left, and of these thou, my dear friend, with thy good   Brotherand your dear Wives, are kept in very cherished remembrance.   So it was delightful to get thy letter, & since its receipt   I have spent several hours in reading, with great interest,   this excellent Life of your great President.  How it has   recalled the old days!  I have gone over so much that had   lain dormant so long, & am more than ever impressed with   Lincoln’s marvellous development from his miserable early   surroundings. How could any man so outlive his environment?    And who could have believed that any man with such aparentage, & such debasing influences around him in early   life, could, by any innate power, or any outward   circumstance, become the great man Lincoln proved himself   later on.  We are slow to learn God’s lesson that He chooses   his instruments very differently to ourselves.
So far as   I can test Mr. Morse’s accuracy, he is very just; neither   hiding Lincoln’s shortcomings nor wishful to make out “a   case,” pro or con, but to act judicially.  I hope to give   our Workpeople an hour’s talk this Winter, based largely   upon this interesting Biography.Thanks for thy kind message to Agnes & the [baines].  All   are well.  How I wish they could see thee in the flesh, for   they often hear thee quoted, and are familiar with thy face,   through the Portrait which is hung, with Uncle Smith   Harrison’s, in our Library – the much valued gift of thy   good son, Hazen – to whom please give my love.
I trust   you are all well: it would be a real pleasure to see you all   again, but, at present, I see no chance of getting away.    With our united love to all our friends at Awbury, I   am,
Thine, very sincerely
J. Simpson.


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1865-05-00
Title: [1865 May ?], 190 Calvert st, to Mother and sisters

2nd day eve
190 Calvert st

Dear Mother & sisters,   Tired as I am I must write you a few words to night, as I   shall probably be at the sch, in the morn & the mail closes   at 1 P.M. & I thought you’d like to know that we arrived   safely about 5 this aft. & I am installed in my new boarding   house wh. promises to be very nice.  They ladies were   exceedingly kind & welcomed me as if I had been an old   friend  They are so free & easy.  One of them Miss Talbot   came right up in my room & talked to me while I was getting   dressed – & was as kind as possible  They used to know uncle   Jasper & quantities of our friends, so that I begin to feel   quite at home already  It is a large 4story house with a very nice pleasant parlor, & a   comfortable dining room, where we had tea on a little   refreshment table—the 4 school “marms”—as cozy as possible.    They say “thee” & call me by name wh. makes me feel much   less strange
Jesse called a few minutes after we arrived   in his elegant carriage, having been to one of the dipots to   meet us, but we unfortunately had got out at the wrong one;   & very much out of our way.  The ladies seem in very   moderate circumstances only keeping one servant, & a sch. of   near 40 day scholars.   consequently they have not much time   to attend to housekeeping nor much talent in that way I shd.   think.  Their kindness however makes amends.The house is on a very high situation & there is a fine view   of the city fr[m]. my room, wh is in the 2nd story & very   airy & pleasant.  But there is no closet unfortunatley wh.   is remarkably home like & seems to be my fate.  Not a place   to hang a dress, but I have 5 beaureau drawers & can make   out.  So much for the house.  3rd day morn.  We went last   evening to see the sch. & I was most agreeably disappointed   in it in every respect..  The rooms are well ventilated &   airy & no disagreeable odour.  & their state of advancement   is surprising.  There were a few to be sure who reminded me   of Busy—in his attempt to spell girl—but mostly they were   astonishingly quick--& cld. add & subtract like quite   accomplished arithmeticaians.  Quite as fast as I cld.   myself.  They were mostly adults.  In the morningThey are children.
I am to have a class of 30 & am very   glad to find that I shall be in the school with Miss Field,   who is a very pleasant young lady about my own age I shd.   judge, & we can go backwards & forward to gether, & shall be   companionable I hope.  The morning session is frm. 9 till 1   1/2 not 3.  The evening teaching you can take part in or not   as you choose.  So it will not be very laborous & in every   respect, it is going to be I think, much pleasanter than I   had anticipated.  & if you are only satisfied I think I can   be very comfortable & enjoy the work & the change.Love to Cousin Sarah.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna S. Biddle
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1862-09-17
Title: 1862 September 17, to Chellie

Sept. 17th. 1862.

Dear Chellie, 
I have been      waiting for news, before answering your last letter and am      now not much better off, but you write such very short      letters that I am not at all conscientious about making mine      short also.  I wish my dear, that you would make your      letters a little longer, & if you do not you will see mine      gradually decreasing in length, till there is hardly any      letter at all.  Uncle James went off to Harrisburg on Monday      as did Uncle Clem George Emlen John Thayre (my cousins) and      Cousin George Biddle.  Uncle Clem never told a soul that he      was going and on Sunday night when John went to the      Baltimore depot to see Gerge Emlen and John Thayre off to      his surprise he saw Uncle Clem.He was going off without bidding us good-bye when perhaps we      may never see him again.  He always was very queer but this      beats every thing.  Is not the war news splendid?  I have      not been so glad since the battle of Drainsville,      particularly about Howell Cobb the old traitor.  There is      now not the slightest fear of our having Stonewall Jackson      in Philadelphia but I pity the poor citizens of Cincinnati.       Cousin Sam Cox was called to a churchthere (St. Paul’s) and he accepted.  He left town two weeks      from yesterday and when he arrived at Cincinnati he was not      allowed to enter the city but was sent to a boarding house      about two miles from the city.  There he is now with his      wife children and father.  Of their furniture they know      nothing and are not allowed to go to the city to see about      it.  Every morning at five o’clock all the bells in the town      ring and every man who is able to carry a gun assembles in      some perminent place and from thence they go out into the      country to wait for the enemy.  Even clergymen are forced to      fight & Cousin Sam is in almost hourly fear of being made to      serve.  I received a letter from Martha Henderson just now.They are at present in Wiesbaden and Martha says that if her      relations were with her she would never again wish to leave      there, not even for America.  That I cannot understand for      no place can or will ever be the same to me as dear      Philadelphia.  But I am forgetting my determination to make      my letter short and although I am burning to go on I deny      myself for your good as I think a little correction will be      very beneficial to you so I will sign myself y
your ever      loving and for long letters begging friend
Anna

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Henry W. (Henry Waln) Drinker:  1787-1866
Recipient:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Date: 1818-11-20
Title: 1818 November 20, Stoddartsville, to Thomas P. Cope Esq., Philadelphia

Thomas P. Cope
Stoddartsville November 20th   1818.
Respected Uncle,
From Father from Wm Drinker &   from B.[T]. Case I have understood that Susquehanna County   Has recd from thee a recent visit & also that our   Philadelphia & Great Bend Turnpike was not without interest   in thy sight–
That this Road Should be deemed of   importance By thee & yet not through my representations of   its incalculable Value affords me much pleasure–  Directly   Interested in it myself & anxious by every Honest means to   ensure its success  Still there were insurmountable   objections to my endeavoring to influence Thee in its   promotion–  I hope I need not explain from whence these   objections proceeded – they are inseparable from the History   of my life & my powers of Memory–
On the 14th I proceeded   to Wilkes barre in order to See Mr Henry Clymer- Thomas   Meredith & others and to definitively establish the Route of   our Turnpike – also to nominate Commissioners & to Petition   the Legislature–  without Know[ing] who would or would not   Serve in Philada we nominated the following subject to   alterations if necessary–
Thomas Stewardson – Thomas P   Cope – John Reed – Condy Raquet, Benjamin R Morgan & John   Gibson – for Philada–
Henry Clymer – Henry W Drinker & Wm   Clark – for Luzerne–
Isaac Ryneerson – Thomas Meredith –   Wm Ward & B[T] Case – for Susquehan[a]
A New Route Had   been Explored By Mr B[T] Case to the Westward several miles   of the one contemplated & Explored for Thomas Stewardson –   shorter in distance & less Hilly than the [first] & far more   interesting to thy Estate on the Meshoppen–
after   minutely examining the apparent advantages of the two   Routes. I gave my assent to adopting the one last explored &   Our Petition was Drawn in conformity thereto–
For want of   a Better map of Common Reference I must make use of Reading   Howells map of Pennsylvania to carry to thee an Idea of the   Route though from the incorrectness of it our Road will   appear more crooked than it will be eventualy found–
Our   Road begins at One Matts Tavern on the Coskectune and Great   Bend Turnpike Towards the Head of Salt [Lick] Creek – where   the Road from Tyoga Point crosses the said Turnpike –    Thence across the Milford & Owego Turnpike – & thence   between Martins Creek & the North Branch of the Tunkhannock   Creek–Thence across the South Branch of the same – & Thence   through Leggets Notch (or Gap) in the Lackawannock Range of   mountains [Formed by Leggets creek a small stream pretty   into the Lackawannock about 15 miles from the Susquehannah   according to Reading Howells map & scale] then across the   East & West Road at one Swartz Tavern – & then across   Roaring Brook or Deep Hollow Creek – Thence nearly Parralel   with the Same to the main Branch of the Lehigh River–    Thence S. 10 E across Tobyhanna Creek & its Branches to the   Sullivans Road & thence by the East End of the Large Pond to   the Turnpike Road on the top of the Pokono mountain at or   near the 30 mile stone from Wilkesbarre–  The whole Distance   Being from Point to point as Explored & measured about Fifty   Three miles – & the Estimated Expence $1000 per mile–  Our   Petition asks the Legislature to incorporate a company with   a capital of $75,000 – but entre nous this is but a [Ruse de   Guerre]–
I do not pretend (from my imperfect knowledge of   the precise situation of thy lands upon the Meshoppen) to be   able to say How far thy interest may be advanced by the   completion of this Road But that it will be more or less   appears evident and plain –  That the Whole of Susquehanna   County – a Part of Luzerne Co. & a part of Pike will feel   its Blessings is not to be denied–  Neither I think will it   be doubted that the Road is interesting to parts of   Northampton – Bucks & Montgomery counties & as will be shown   Peculiarly Interesting to the City & county of   Philadelphia–
We have called it The Philadelphia & Great   Bend Turnpike & with good reason.- it forming the most   Important Link in the chain of communication & the only one   wanting to secure to Philadelphia incalculable advantages–    From the Pokono a good Turnpike Road now Exists (not Log   Turnpike) to the Wind Gap & from thence [are] two good   county Roads to Easton – on to Bethlehem by the way of   Nazareth – or to Janets Bridge in Lower Saucon where a   Turnpike Road is laid out – then by good Roads to either the   Willow Grove or Germantown Turnpikes  to the City of   Philada–.  We might Have called our Turnpike The   Counteracting Turnpike – it being the Only one Ever   projectedcalculated (By Intersecting the Turnpikes Leading to the   City of New York in important points) to counteract the   Influence that City by Her Liberallity Her Geographical   Wisdom and foresight in despight of natural obstructions –   Has obtained–
There is One advantage which will result to   Philada from this Road which (amongst many others) I select   Because it will reach the comprehension of Every man & is   capable of undeniable proof & is indeed Known to very many   persons in Bussiness in Philadelphia–  I speak now of the   Cattle Trade or the Driving of Horned Cattle Sheep & Horses   to the Philadelphia market–  I shall speak of such Facts as   are Known to me – some of which are Known to our Dry good   merchants – some to our Graziers and all to the Drovers   themselves–
The persons Engaged in this Trade are nearly   to a man Store Keepers from the state of New York–  They   receive cattle sheep & Horses in payment for various   merchandize sold by them to farmers in their vicinity.  Or   purchase them with the monies they Receive for their goods–    Their Best market for these cattle is found at Philadelphia   & notwithstanding the circuitous Route they are obliged to   take & the most miserable & wretched Roads which alone Exist   to this market they Drive Annualy cattle sheep & Horses to   the amount of One million of Dollars– (I [think] this season   of Horned cattle alone that near if not quite 1/2 a million   of Dollars in value Has passed By this place & through the N   & South Road  at least I am persuaded that I may rely on the   account I have Received of the number) – if then it be a   fact that near one million of Dollars in cattle sheep &   Horses reaches Philadelphia Every year from the State of New   York and that for want of a Road from Philada- to the   Western part of that state – the whole Sum is Drawn in cash   from Philada and goes to the City of New York & there is   Expended in the purchase of Merchandize Because of good   waggon Roads Connecting that City with the Said western part   of the State – will it not be apparent thatOur Road in Truth is a Philadelphia Turnpike & well Worthy   the Patronage & Support of every liberal minded Citizen–    But that this is the fact Every Drover will admit & I   beleive that they will very generaly declare that they would   much rather purchase their merchandize in Philadelphia than   in New York if it were possible to waggon [their] goods   through Pennsylvania to their Homes–  at least this is the   Sentiment expressed to me as far as I have conversed with   them – in addition Then to these facts – I may state That   Though Cattle forms perhaps a principal Remittance from   Store Keepers in the Western pt of N York–  Yet it is not   the only One – a good deal of Cash also is brought Down by   these persons & this cash also goes to the City of New York   which would if our Road was made Remain in Philada–
I may   State too without fear of contradiction that this Cattle   Trade in despight of Obstacles Has constantly & rapidly   increased that in spight of them it will increase & that if   nothing is done to Counteract the Evil we shall still   continue to pay to the City of New York for the Beef we Eat   – or in other words that the Philadelphia merchant. shall   continue to pay the New York merchant for the whole amount   of cattle Driven from this quarter to Philadelphia–  an   Enormous Annual Ballance Indeed for this one article of our   Consumption – again – This Highly Interesting Section of the   State of New York – [is] Hourly increasing in Wealth &   Importance – in wants of Foreign articles & Resources of   Domestic Wealth – And let me ask where can the merchants of   Philadelphia Find a Body of such customers as exist Here –   where Such a certain& constant Trade–  Where such an increase of Trade where   such certain remittances–  Presenting also at Least one   Million of Dollars per annum Being Drawn out of the City at   this Time & How much Hereafter it is not possible to   predict–  This However may Be reasonably [assumed] as a fact   – that if such now is the amount of this Trade with all the   difficulties which want of Roads present – a good Road will   very materially increase it – in [----] to Enumerate the   advantages to be reaped by Establishing a Free communication   with this Most Fertile Section of New York would more   properly form a Volume than suit the limits of a Letter– Yet   I may add that This Cattle Trade – though in itself of no   mean Importance to Philadelphia is only One amongst many   Valuable Blessings which New York has taken from   Philadelphia By the Superior Foresight of Her Citizens –   There it Has been Esteemed Honorable & not unworthy the   attention of Her first merchants to Examine in to The   Internal Resources of Her State as well as of Her Sister   States – whilst the [reins] of Philadelphians Seems to Have   Been almost altogether Turned Towards the Sea – to Maritime   ports & Latterly to the Great Western Waters–  Yet what   assisted to raise Philadelphia to Her present prosperity &   Rank more than all other Things was the Internal resources   of Her own State & those Sections of other States within   marketable Reach – and it is only as these Blessings   multiply & Have facilities given them to Extend to & Support   Her that She can on any Just grounds expect to advance – If   this possition is True & if I Have notfailed in making good my ground of the Vast advantage of communication with a Section of the State of New York to Philadelphia is not our Road in Truth a Philadelphia Road & entitled to the Best wishes & aid of that City–   in the Magnitude of the Advantages to Be reaped from the State of New York through the Medium of this Road ??? I must not loose sight of the Trade of our own Counties which also at present for want of Roads lead[ing] to Philadelphia likewise goes to the City of New York ??? The amt of this I Have not the present means of ascertain[ing] But it must be considerable & is rapidly increasing??? The Coskectune and Great Bend Turnpike & the Milford & Owego Turnpike are striking at the Best Interests of Philadelphia??? New York City is By these Roads Establishing to Herself a Course of Trade which Though Now Easily Diverted from Her to Philadelphia is growing every day more & more difficult ??? a Timely Exertion an application of one mite of the Vast money Resources of Philada at this time in aid of this apparently insignificant Road will do more than the Expenditure of much Greater sums on Seemingly much Greater undertakings   Our Road will cut the Milford & Owego Road & the Coskectune & Great Bend Turnpike in so delicate a part that the whole Eastern Section of Each will be benumned & rendered lifeless ??? Their object (the secur[ing] the Trade to the City of New York)will be effectualy Counteracted & Defeated – & The Proverb   Be good to Philada – “One man Sows & another reaps the fruit   of His Labour”–
I have gone into a length of detail &   [-----] reasoning that I had not contemplated & I fear Have   tired Thee as well as myself.–  I crave forgiveness for my   fault–  I nevertheless would be much pleased if Thee Should   Think a Publication of Any of these Views – Couched in   different Language and Respectfuly dressed would in any way   be of advantage to us in gett[ing] through with our   important Road – for though I have made it appear that there   is abundant Riches to the West & North West of us & more   wealth than foresight in Philadelphia  Yet the fact must be   told that We are miserably poor – & that unless the City   aids our Road it may Be as long as Troys Seige before it is   Travelld–
Now if Thee would undertake the Herculean Task   of Picking the marrow (if there be any to be found) out of   this Long [map] of writing – Dress it & Suit it to the   palate of our Philadelphians & Serve it up to them in a News   paper I should Hope that it might in time of need possibly   aid us in Subscriptions to our Turnpike Stock –  This   However I leave to thy Better Judgement–
My Best Respects   to Aunt Grandmother & my cousins Generaly remain[ing] as   Ever affectionaly
thy Nephew HWDrinkerStoddartsVille
Novembr. 21st
Paid 25
Thomas P. Cope Esq.
Merchant
Philada

Title: 1865 March 15, Locust Shade, to Annie

Locust Shade. 3. 15. 1865

My dear Annie

Does   thee think I have quite forgotten thee and all thy kindness,   & my delightful visit to you? That I have been such a long   while without writing to thee. Indeed I have not, & never   shall I hope- but my wonderings [early] terminated last 7th   day & since then I have had a very bad cold, which thee   knows makes one lazy. - I have wanted to know how thee   faired after our parting on the hill. My walk was brisk & I   did not keep Maggie’s [---] waiting long, and did not feel   tired. I fear thee did not fare so well. Our visit to our   Wilmington friends was very pleasant.
Richie, thee knows, joined me in that. Tho he was not well   enough to enjoy it thoroughly. Lizzie seems very happy & we   hope is learning something, - at least she gets very good   numbers. - The roads were so bad it was not easy to get   about & my journey to Faulkland was a [arduous] one. but the   pleasure of cheering cousin Mary a little & hearing Dr   [Fell]  talk,- a great deal more than repaid me for it.-   

When I returned to Phila John & Sallie Hilles & I   went over to see Charles Rhoads. It was very touching to see   those five little motherless children. Charles looks tens   years older and much broken down.- His sister was very   pleasant- I never knew her before. They are certainly much   favored in having such kind caretakers & hardly feel their   loss as they will after awhile. - I often think of   what

thee said to me in the car after our visit to Clemmy. dear   Annie, with loving sympathy. Deserving too that I may fully   appreciate the blessing of a mothers love while mine is   still spared to me. - I hear Clemmy is going, or has gone to   Baltimore, to teach the Freedmen. What do you think of it?   It seems to me that anything that would give interesting   employment to both mind and body, would be good for her. Tho   I’m right sorry to have her go so far away. - Thee will miss   her too. - Do write some & tell me all about her plans. -   Lilly Collins seems to like her situation very well. I found   a letter from her awaiting me on my return.- She gives an   amusing account of a colored meeting which she attended, - a   real happy [----------] affair.- Lilly enjoys the variety I   should think & it keeps her from being homesick.- Cousin   Elizalooked & seemed more cheerful when I called - but she   certainly is very weak.-

I suppose the preparations   for the wedding are proceeding briskly- Does the go? I quite   want to hear about it. - Lizzie Brown’s sister is to be   married tomorrow & I hope the threatened storm will not come   to spoil all their nice dresses.- Lizzie’s friend Edward   Balderson stayed with us last night. He is to wait on a   young lady from Jersey -  so I fear the love affair between   him & Lizzie is all over - but time will make manifest. Has   thee seen anything more of the interesting students- Till   thy brother Thomas his opinion of the [-----] position of   Carpenters is very family impressed upon my mind.- It makes   me smile now to think how frightened I was, I deserved   rebuke too.- Do please write to me soon dear Annie.- My love   please to thy father & sister E & with a large share of the   same for thyself I am thy sincerely attached & grateful   friend
 
S. S. Reeve

Title: 1862 May 8, Clifton, to Henry Cope

Clifton May 8th 1862

Dear Cousin., 
 
 It has occurred to me since writing my last letter that it might be best to inform thee how my father acquired the title to the lands Ive inherit from him. They were purchase by him, by Uncle John Tomas of the State of Penna. The Legislatures Land office being about that time / 1772 in Philadelphia. The Legislature at that early period - had made a rule that the public lands should be sold in tracts not exceeding 480 acres each- and that no individual should be permitted to purchase more- but finding this plan did not answer- they concluded to allow purchaser to buy more largely. On condition that they would find a number of nominal purchasers of 400 acre tracts- each receiving a deed poll for every tract- and then transferring them to the purchaser. Accordingly Father and Uncle John found a number of their friends & acquaintances to do this - and in this way bought of the state about 2500 acres of land under different Warranter homes. Uncle J Thomas becoming embarrassed and owing a debt to the firm of Adams and Loughey - his interest was free wh to sale- and bought by my father - who became sole owner of these lands. this transaction- is mentioned in the [land] deed now in my possession- which I am persuaded gives a clear title to the land. The deed polls for these traitswere in Brother Henry's possession but were consumed with other important papers by the bank fire. --- The record of these deed polls must have been in the Land office in Philadelphia - and taken to Harrisburg when the office & Legislature removed there. 

10th [may]
 Dear Cousin--- I rec'd thy letter of the 8th ins yesterday & I am very sorry thee has had so much trouble on my account. We had hoped our statements would have satisfied thee as to the clearness of the title to the lands. It is thought by some that if I had gone to the city - a personal interview with thee might have resulted differently- but I could not see that this was a right course-- I should be glad to sell our lands as thee suggests and it seems probable we may; but dear cousin, I fear we could not do in it time to save ourselves-- but I believe if I could sell my own land which is clear of all encumbrances - it might be a benefit to me as well as others- By offering to sell and pay part of the purchase money to be applied in reducing the mortgage on Henry's property- Wm L Gildersleac might be induced to free me from the lien he holds on my own. though a money makings he is said to be a religious man- and a friend to the poor- and if in addition to dealing his "bread to the hungry" he will also "let the oppressed go free" by releasing me "from this bond" he may be a gainer in the best sense without losing any of his earthly gains -- By selling some & gettingthe rest of my property clear it would reliever me from much embarrassment & trouble- there is not mortgage on them the taxes all paid by brother Richard with his [mon] - except for this year I believe and I can pay them with a small sum reserved in [Levanton] for such purchases- the lands are well timbered and in a good location, where they can easily be seen after. Those I propose to sell (as most advantageous to a purchaser are in a black - except one a valuable timbered lot No 81 - which is not far from the railroad it corners on No 82* containing 200 acres a lot for which I am offered $1218 = but I would rather be intently clear of any interference before I make a sale- The lands I want to sell are all mentioned and described in the large Deed I have in my possession which was drawn up by brother John who was considered a very good [--------] as well as a Lawyer. The lots are No 30.. Nos 42 52 53 54 & part of No 41 in all with lot No81 about 650 acres--- no 42 contains about 82 acres 26 of this lot being sold and a small clearing made- I suppose there is a drawing of there lots in the [m---] drawn by my nephew Charles which will show how they are situated. My cousins Cope Brothers in their last letter to me asked at what price it would be desirable to sell my property. Expecting to sell the whole property. I had to consult others about the price- but in regard to the lots I have mentioned I will say just what my friends may think it right to give- If I can by selling there lands pay W Gildersleac what he may require and leave enough to settle some debts and pay the arrears of taxes on some lands now in the hands of the [common coiners] in Wilkes Barres. I shall be glad to do so. the sale of our lumber will then I think carry as through

*this lot was under construct - previous to the lien on my other property. Which makes some doubt as to whether W L Gildersleac would claim it.and if in time- we can succeed in paying off the mortgage or sell our lands. I can then be repaid for the money. I may advance now to help others as well as myself. If times become more favorable - I have hopes with prudence & care- we may yet be extricated from our difficulties & be enabled to pay all our own liabilities. I am much in need of good council- I have suggested the sale of part of my lands as a means of relief but I am not certain even if I could effort it- that I could obtain a release from Wm. L Gildersleac-- 
 
 do as thee thinks but dear cousin- in regard to returning the papers- but if thee can help me in any way by advice it will be a great favor to thy
 affectionate cousin
Rebecca Drinker

Recipient:  Annette Cope:  1843-1916
