Title: 1865 March 27 to My dearest children

Second day morn  3. 27.

My dearest children
I have   just come home from school & found yr. letter on the card   plate in the entry, wh. is where they always put them, so we   can be refreshed by the sight the moment we get in, & I was   refreshed I assure you.  Miss Field gets a great many & I   began to feel as if it was quite time for me to be having my   turn too.  You must remember that I never was befor so   entirely among strangers. & that your letters now will be my   best substitutes for home, as I shall depend on them greatly   I tried to write yesterday but did not make out much.  It   was my first 1st day in Baltimore.  Do you remember last 1st   day, when [were] were walking on the piazza & wondering   whether I shd. be here?  I did not much think I shd. then   but it seems I am.  Went to meeting yesterday morn. wh. I   quite enjoyed.  The only faces that I had ever seen before   were Deborah Thomas, Margy Coale & Tammie Miller.  I was   introduced to lots of others who were all very kind, & said   they were coming to see me.  There was a frd. named Elicott   & her two sisters who I think said they knew Mother.  We had   a sermon [fmr.] Deba  Thomas, the Dr, & one or two others.    After meeting in the aftnoon I set out to take a walk & was   joined by a young lady named Mary Elicott & & Jesse, who   took me a beautiful walk out to whats called theReservoir, where there is a fountain and a splendid view of   green hills & also of the distant waters of the bay, as well   as of parts of the city.  & yet it was not a walk of more   than a mile I shd. think
Baltimore is certainly a   beautiful place & I never realized before so fully what an   advantage what an advantage a hilly city possesses over a   flat one.  It quite throws Philada into the shade as far as   beauty is concerned.  There is such a refreshing variety in   the style of the houses, & other [buildings] & the hills   show them off to great advantage.  Charles St. seems to be   one of the most aristocratic in wh. the monument is   situated, a very beautiful column of white marble, 170 ft   high wh. as it stands upon a hill serves as a land mark for   a long distance round.  as you ascend the street with the   monument towering high above you the stars & stripes   floating over it & the city as you catch glimpses of it at   certain points apparently beneath you, the effect is very   imposing.  I think Phila. wld. strike one as flat after   this.  It has its advantages tho’.
Jesse has not come to   take us any rides yet.  tho he has promised to.  They say he   is very attentive to a certain – young lady here so we shall   not be so likely to derive as much benefit.  [---]. He has   been very polite so far.  & the ladies of the house are   continually laying plans for our entertainment wh. is   exceedingly kind in them.  I really feel more at home here   than I wd with some relations!Miss Talbot who is the housekeeper is one of the easy   talkative kind & makes me think a little of Mary Sayne.    Only far Superior.  they are exceedingly informal & get up &   wait on table & clear the things away in what thee, Nat,   wld. call a very shocking manner, but they are perfect   ladies for all – hospitable & fond of society, & they seem   to have a great many pleasant frds.  Their one girl is not   the most efficient cook in the world but I have such a good   appetite that I get along very well, – I feel most as hungry   as when I get home frm. school as I remember I used to when   I was a scholar.  We have breakfast about 7 1/2 go to sch.   about 8 1/4.  it is only 10 min. walk — get home about 1.   pretty tired with the 4 hrs. standing & ready to lie down   till dinner time at 2 1/2.  After dinner we get dressed & go   out or see company.  We most always have one or two callers.   at 7 again we have tea & then get our work and sit in the   parlor, & wonder who is coming when the bell rings.  Miss   Field I like exceedingly.  She is a Presbyterian & a very   superior girl I shd. think so that in the matter of   companionship I need to have had fewer fears and   trepidations than I had
The school duties are not long   but pretty arduous while they last.  We have to stand nearly   all the time.  At least the model teachers do, but we   inferiors take the liberty of popping downoccasionally, but it is at the risk of [good] order for   there are so many in the room that unless you stand up to   it, & keep your eye on all 30 or 40 at once they are very   apt to get wrong in the back seats.  One of the first points   is to get [them] disciplined.  Mr Waterman the principal –   drills his class just as you wld. soldiers makes them fold   their arms put out one foot & finally stand up just as a   general wld. his troops, & when school is dismissed they   file out in quite an imposing manner.  That is to teach them   obedience I suppose, wh. is a great point gained.  They also   teach them a kind of gymnastic exercises by way of   recreation. as they have no place to play & consequently no   regular recess or almost none.  Mine is the next to the   smallest class. & only studys reading & spelling in words of   4 or 5 letters wh. is not very interesting.  I have’nt   discovered that there are any specially smart or Topsy like   ones among them.  We dont stop to talk or get acquainted   much but just keep them doing something or other the whole   time.  Upon the whole I enjoy the effect of the work very   much. & outside of that it is all very pleasant.
Jesse   has just called in a splendid barouche to ask for Miss F or   I to ride.  As I had’nt finished my letter & she had’nt been   out for sev. days I persuaded her to go.  Yesterday was the   first pleasant one we have had. since I have been here.  I   was so sorry I took my purple dress out.  It is just what I   want this cool weather for afternoons.  I want twice as many   clothes here as at home.  Caroline dont thee want to be   benevolent and cut me out a pair of those round cuffs like   thee made me for undersleeves.  Thee can work the button   holes, & have them starched & ironed.  I have a pair of   sleevesthat I can sew them on.  I wish if you shd. have any   opportunity you wld. send me my old blk silk body wh. hangs   in the back room closet.  Tammy Miller is going to P   tomorrow & out to Mary Morris’ so I told her to tell you   that she saw the school “mam”  Give my love to Cousin Frank   & Mary  Tell Cousin Mary I had the pleasure of seeing her   mother & I think her father yesterday.  Give my love to   Cous. Sarah & to Tom & Harry & to all Aunt Carolines & any   other enquiring frds.
I have written you a lengthy   epistle I hope there’ll be an exception in favor of mistakes   & bad writing as I have written lying on my back  I was so   very tired this morning that I was too lazy to sit up.  I do   not get much time to [sun] as my room is too cold to sit in   & they do not seem to bring their sewing into the parlor   much.  With much love

Your affec
Sister C

I   am going to send you a drawing of my house when I get time   so you can imagine how things are a little better.  I hope   Edgar will get the drafting business all settled,   satisfactorily

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan S. Reeve:  1833-1866
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1866-04-15
Title: 1866 April 15, Locust Shade, to Ruthanna Cope

Locust Shade. 4.15.1866

My Dear Annie

I have   been very sorry to see day after day passing away without   any acknowledgment sent of thy very interesting &  welcome   lettter, which was a real treat to me. I wish there was some   hope of thy getting as good a one in reply but what with   colds & headache the little wit I ever had seems to have   departed, for which loss I console with my corespondents   every time one of my stupid effusions goes to the Post   Office.- I think a visit from thee & Clemmy would have an   enlivening effect & when summer comes so must you.- It was   very kind to send me that excellent Photo of Uncle Daniel,   after my negligence in the
matter of which I have been duly ashamed- and I am very much   obliged for it.- We had a nice visit to him had we not? If I   had not gone then, I fear I should not have seen him at all-   except that we did meet in the cars the other day- as being   sick in Wilmington entirely spoiled my Germantown visit. so   that I could make none of the calls I hoped to.-
How thee   must have enjoyed having Clemmy so long with thee. You had   splendid times I know. Indeed no one can be at your house   without enjoying themselves- At least that is my   experience.-
Thee knows perhaps that I have been a good   deal with my friend Lizzie Howell this winter.- Her mothers   death was so very sudden- only sickda little more that half   & hour- that the shock was fearful & Lizzie

was a long time recovering from it.- She is yet very sad-   and her brother being in poor health adds to the feeling.-   She was so sick for some weeks as rarely to get down stairs.   nervous & weak- but is now stronger & brighter & very busy   she writes me.- It is often a great blessing I think to   those in sorrow to have duties pressing upon them with must   be attended to & so the mind is diverted from its greif and   made to realize that life has yet much in store for them.   –
Did thee know our Georgie has been sent adrift from his   home into the city? We do miss him sadly- but he likes his   situation in a wholesale store in Market St, very well &    perhaps it is the right thing for him.- We hope that he may   be preserved from the temptations that summoned him.- Lizzie   has come home
for yearly meeting week.- We have been looking for aunt   Rachel Howland & her family every day but hear now they are   not coming till next week.-
Has thee been after “Trailing   Arbutus” this spring? [-] and I went the other day &  found   some pale blossoms. but very sweet.- Isnt it delightful to   hunt under the dead leaves for the delicate things- it seems   to make one feel young again fot the time.- Thee asks have I   read “Snow Bound”—Only a little of it &  have not happened   even to see it in a volume. But intend to get it soon if I   can.- The part I read was pleasant, simple &  [s-----] , -   as thee says more understandable than much of the latter day   poetry.- We have been reading “Across the Continent” and I   have indulged dreams of someday seeing the “Yosemite Valley”   if my finances get into sufficiently prosperous conditions   for such a journey.- Don’t thee 
want to go to Europe with the party that starts next month?-   It must be bery pleasant to look forward to & finer still to   experience if all things are fair & no anxieties to follow   you.- Wonder if John Wood &  Lily will go.- John says he   wants to & I guess Lily would not object.- I liked John   better than I expected to- but he is certainly neither   handsome nor dignified- but [-------] & kind hearted. I   should think.- Is’nt it a comfort Mary Ann Morris is so much   better? I cannot help hoping she will be entirely herself   again before very long.- Their house is very bright &   pleasant & I should think they might be very happy there-   This to be sure happiness is not a thing of outward   circumstances [----]Did thee remember that yesterday was the anniversary of our   dear Presidents death? Wonder where another year will find   us.- What do thy brothers think of our prospects with such a   man as Johnson at the helm.- It is a comfort that the crew   of out ship of State are so staunch & true.-
Suppose   Marry Emma Stokes passed meeting last third day- I do like   Alexander Wood very much. He seems so open & honest.- Will   they have a wedding  I wonder- or just be married & go   travelling.- I hear friends at Arch Street did not accept   Sue Farnum’s resignation. Had she violated discipline before   presenting it? The usual yearly mtg storms seems to be   brewing this evening- but I hope it wont come this.- Does   thee go in and out every day?.- Please excuse this [prosy]   sheet dear Annie & write very soon.- My love please to thy   sister E. – Very loving by thine
S S Reeve



----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  John Inskeep:  1757-1834
Date: 1800-08-18
Title: 1800 August 18, to Mayor & Committee for introducing water into the City of Philadelphia

Gentlemen
   
   In compliance with a resolve of your body, & at the pressing solicitation of your members, I paid a visit to Soho-
   
   You had good reason to believe that a fair representation of the progress of the works had not been made to you- & you wished for your own satisfaction, & to appease the popular clamour, to obtain correct information- You deputed me to visit Soho, & I cheerfully obeyed,- tho I expected that the expedition would not be relished by the Engineer- what has been the result?  I accomplished my mission- & reported to you an honest state of facts- but in the discharge of this duty, at your last meeting, I found myself insulted by your Engineer in a manner at once indecorous, approbrious, & unmerited- and, let me tell you gentlemen, in a stile which, considering the occasion, I think you ought not to have permitted.
   
   I do not pretend to say what degree of respect is due to you, from your Engineer, but I presume it to be a novelty in the annals of deliberative bodies- for an Agent, not only to take an active part in their discussions- but to brow beat a member while in the very act of reporting the issue of a duty imposed on him by that body- The patient sufferance of such conduct appears to me to be a direct dereliction of your dignity-
   
   So long as a faithful discharge of muy duty to the public rendered my services availing, I feltbound by my solemn affirmation, & the interest I took in your proceedings , punctually to attend your meetings- Finding however that I can no longer be useful, where I have not been protected in the common right of membership, I beg you accept my resignation-
   
   Thos P. Cope
   Augt. 18. 1800.
   
   The Mayor & Come. for introducing water into the City of Philada.-

Title: 1811 February 3, Washington, to son

Washington   Feb.y 3d. 1811
   
   Dear Son
   
   I will consent to the sale of the Brig Eliza to Captn Veacock for $5000- the price offered- on a credit of 3 [?] 6 months- & this is the ultimatum- consult Isrl. & Jasp. on the security, & it would also be well to have the approbation of Thos. Coffin- altho the joint letter from Trickerman & Hussey might justify on in acting without him- But as I am to guarantee or procure a guarantee of the paper, that which Capn Veacock gives must be unexceptionable- Keep it until I return-
   
   I have seenthe President, Gallatin & many other of the great folks of the nation- Have been introduced to Randolph- & heard him harangue Congress yesterday- He is in my opinion the greatest Parliamentary debater of this Country- & I would not have missed the opportunity of hearing him on any [a/c?]  I shall say more about it when I return- We are in such a perpetual round & the parts we visit are so distant from each other, that there is scarce time to write- wh I do with such pen, such ink, such paper & in such place as I can catch- We have examined before a Come. of[---] Senate- they treated us handsomely but I do not believe the Bk will have [---] charter- Love to Mother & all the rest
   
   Affectionately
   
   Thos. P. Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1806-1875
Date: 1834-02-28
Title: 1834 February 28, Philadelphia, to Alfred Cope

Philada. 2mo 28. 1834
   
   We have at last my dear son been favoured to hear from thee- thy Letters of the 21st 1mo having reached us 2 days ago- that is one to Henry & one to William.  These are all which have as yet been recd-  Much as all of us have been gratified to learn thy safe arrival at Madeira our pleasure would have been greatly increased to have some assurance of thy health having been improved.  We hope for the best & are thankful to find thou art spending thy time so agreeably- far away from the troubles which surround us on all hands- Our country is indeed in a very portentious condition.  Genl Jackson seems to be determined let the consequences be what they may, to crush the Bank of the United States.  & such is the foolish nay mad devotion of his immediate partizans, that they are as determined to support him, reckless as to the future.  To day we have a message from our Governor, to the Legislature, announcing the failure of his attempts to borrow money.  & labouring to throw the blame on the Bank- besides the injustice of this charge, he appears to be but little aware of the effect this will produce on money lenders at home & abroad.  Who are [---] thy set, & will be alarmed with fears that the state may not be able to pay the interest of its vast debt- Had he posessed the manliness to recommend the recharter of the Bk public confidence would at once have been restored, & with it the facility of borrowing.  He contemplated the stopage of the public works- Who will then be able to calculate the public loss?  There can of course be little or no income, & the works themselves must be injured if not ruined.
   
   Our family concerns are going on much as usual.  Thy brother Wm is in a fair way ofAlfred Cope
   
   Madeira
   
   [T.P Cope 2/28- recd 4/25 1834   [---] Spark]

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1837-10-28
Title: 1837 October 28, Harrisburg, to Henry

Harrisburg 10mo 28.  1837-
   
   Dear Henry
   
   From thy letter of yesterday I perceive that doubts still exist as to the apprehended piracy- & the papers which reach us are full of contradictions & vain conjectures- at one time we were assured that the informtation had reached Norfolk about the same time it reached N Castle- & after that statement had passed current for some days we find by a Balte. paper that the first knowledge they had of it in Norfolk was the 25th in the afternoon.  The pilots if I recollect first reported the capturing schooner to be full of men & black sided- it now seems they kept so far away that they could not see whether the ship was bright sided- still they alledge to have distinctly seen the cross in her foretop sail- This circumstance is the most striking, & yet it is possible that at their distance they might be mistaken even in that.  I observe a story has been circulate in NYork of an oyster boat having supplied the ship at Sea- & that is believed, contradicted & reiterated- If that were true it wd. indeed be some comfort, as it might accot. for the whole affair, making some allowances for discrepancies.  It is altogether a painful subject, & has caused me much perhaps useless anxiety.  but no benefit can arise from despondency.  & it is our duty to submit to the Divine Will- & our best interest too- Let us then hope while hope we may-29th
   
   The letter from Capn. Miller which I read in the papers that reached us last evening, stating that information had been recd. from the Break Water by a Schr. just arrived, that she has passed the Susqa. of Chincoteague, a shr. along side of her- if true, wd. seem to put an end to doubt- But why did not Miller mention the name of the Schr. at the Break Water.  & how did that Schr. know what he saw was the Susqa.  If the ship was in the situation mentioned, & at the time mentioned, it argues a most extraordinary degree of hardy hood in the Pirate.
   
   Yesterday commenced the battle on the Judiciary.  Judge Hopkinson opened the debate- in a masterly manner- he spoke for 3 hours, & then gave way to a motion for adjournment- of course he will proceed with his argument 2d. day morning.  I hear it will prove unavailing- so many of the Convention being resolved on a change.  The discussion will no doubt be protracted thoughout all this week, perhaps even another- so many will try to distinguish themselves on this fruitful subject.  Feeling so much disappointed by the issue of the militia question I can no longer hope for much good from this Convention.  Indeed I care very little now how bad they may make a constitution- the worse perhaps the better-as the people will be the more likely to, reject it.  Earl made his appearance yesterday and forthwith commenced taking notes of Hopkinsons speech- He will attempt a reply- so will I suspect Ingersoll- but the most powerful antagonist will be Woodward- from Luzerne.  He is plausible, argumentative & fluent, but with all a thorough radical & in my judgement a most mischevous politician.  Doran & others are still absent- When I shall be relieved from my unpleasant imprisonment I cannot say.
   
   The morng the Thermometer at sunrise was 35.
   
   With love to Rachel & the children
   I am
    affectionately
   
   Thos. P. Cope
   
   Please say to Wm Evans that I have just recd. his Note with the Pamphlets, of wh. I shall endeavor to make a proper use- but as that subject has been dismissed for the present, & the mind of the members are filled with the Judiciary question I fear were I now to distribute them- they wd. just be glanced at- thrown aside & forgotten- The subject will come up again on 2d. reading & then may be a suitable time for their distribution.  My own fears are however that Friends have little more to hope for from this Convention.Thos. P. Cope
   
   Henry Cope
   Philadelphia
   
   [TP Cope Harrisburg
   10mo 28 1837]

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1806-1875
Date: 1837-10-30
Title: 1837 October 30, Harrisburg, to Alfred

Harrisburg 10mo 30th.  1837
   
   Dear Alfred
    
   I wrote to Henry yesterday & in the evening recd. thine of the 28th-
   
   The still absorbing topic is the ship & those on board- it is difficult to discharge the subject from the mind however useless it may be to indulge in speculation & conjecture.  Time will bring all things to light, & we must patiently wait the event trusting in Providence that whatever that result may be, whether according to our conceptions for good or for ill, it will nevertheless be right.
   
   Henry mentioned in one of his Letters the subject of the railing that Caleb wd. write to me abt. it- In my reply I sd. I wd. give it my attention when I heard from C.
   
   As to Barton I wish H.y to give him a ck for the $50 he needs- Thou hast not yet said whether mother recd. one, or two, Letters from me- I shd. like to know- I am glad to learn that EW intends coming to the City- The air of the country [?] I think be too sharp for her during winter, & in the City she will be nearer to medical aid-
   
   The discussion on the Judiciary is proceeding- Judge H. has just closed a very lucid & argumentative & powerful address- Woodward has risen in reply- He will be wiley, but he will not respite his antagonist.  The issue isuncertain.  So much will be sacrificed to ambition, party views & popular prejudice.  Should the radicals succees in prostrating the Judiciary by rendering them subservient to the Legislature, farewell to liberty & security.  Indeed under the garb of democracy & feeling for the people this republic seems fast travelling towards a despotism & it is of little importance to our security whether it be the despotism of the rabble or the despotism of a single tyrant.  The latter would probably be the least exceptionable- but if the first happen, the latter will not be slow to follow- Ingersoll will soon follow Woodward.  I wish our friends, that is the Conservatives, wd. permit the disorganizers to vent themselves fully- before they reply.  This will probably not happen, & I cannot say when the debate will terminate- certainly not this week- at least I fear not.
   
   I have just been informed that Caleb passed through Harrisburg yesterday.  I recd a bundle of pamphlets, wh no doubt came by him.  I suppose he could not delay long enough to call on me.
   
   I have become accustomed to listen & to write at the sametime- still I may & do often commit errors of commission & omission which wd. have been avoided under a more abstracted condition- but if at anytime I omitnoting matters to wh my attention should be given, I hope to be reminded of my deficiency.
   
   I wished mother to inform me whether the Garden plot was completed- Whether the Carpenters had finished their work, Whether C H Canby was done.  This I think was in my last letter to her.  I want her to me reminded of my wish to hear from her.
   
   The mail hour is at hand & I must close.
   
   Farewell
   Thos. P. Cope
   
   I have just been shown a L[etter?] from the City stating that the Susqa. was seen on first day 12 leagues from the Capes of the Delaware by the Steam Boat from NYk to Charleston-[TPC 10/31 '37]
   
   T.P. Cope [10/31]
   
   Alfred Cope
   Philada.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1806-1875
Date: 1837-06-09
Title: 1837 June 9, Harrisburg, to Alfred

Harrisburg 6mo 9.  1837
   
   Dear Alfred
   
   Yesterday after I had sealed my Letter to thy dear mother the mail brt. me thine of the 7th-
   
   The time of our adjournment is as uncertain as ever- To day I expect we shall close the debate on the last sec of the 1st article.  The veto power caused some discussion- but the majority for returning the provisions of the Constitution on that subject, has been expectedly great- The next great effort of the reformers will be on the Judiciary- but I shall not be at all surprised if they succeed little better in that than in other things- Indeed I cannot help hoping that our Constitution will not undergo any very great change- We have however the most exciting subjects yet to come up- & no man can predict the time they may occupy.
   
   Having heard since coming here the speech made by Judge Hallowell much landed, I felt anxious to see it- but if it cannot be had we myst try to do without it- We have today some skirmishing on a resolution to prohibit colored persons from coming into the State- a motion was made to postpone it indefinitely, but I regret to say it did not prevail-  It was however postponed for the present-
   
   I shall indeed rejoice when I can be permitted to join you once more in Race Street- but am truly rejoiced to hear of all being well-
   
   I had a fall to day from wh. I recd. some slight injury & my principal object in writing now has been to mention it lest some other person shd. do so to make you uneasy- I hurt my side & head a little- perhaps it w.d be as well to say little about it- lest mother sh.d be uneasy I made a mistep on the stair way
   
   Farewell
   Thos. P CopeTPC-6/9-'37]
   
   TP Cope [6/10]
   
   Alfred Cope
   Philada.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1806-1875
Date: 1840-08-25
Title: 1840 August 25, Newport, to Alfred

Newport 8mo 25. 1840
   
   Dear Alfred,
   
   It is growing towards being after sunset, but while Job is making arrangements for our departure tomorrow morning in the Massacheusetts Steamer for Providence, it falls to my lot to drop a line by Wm who is intended send with the Carriage & Horses next day, by return of the same Steamer to NYk thence to proceed on his way to Philada.-  You will all be gratified to hear of thy dear mothers improved health, & also of Eleanors- altho we have experienced hot weather for some days, & have qualms as to the propriety of throwing ourselves into a more heated atmosphere-  Stephen P. Morris arrived here yesterday from Providence, & reports the thermometer to have been up to 95 the day before.  The air since dinner to day has become cooler, & we may reasonably hope will improve a pace shortlty-  Other things change as well as the weather- & now after writing so far, a bell man announces that a Balloon Steamer is to be here tomorrow from P. & return again at 3 AM-  We wished originally to go by her- but she has undergone repairs, & there was this morning no certainty when she wd. be here-  We therefore had made up our minds to go by the Massachusetts between 6 & 7 AM-  We intend to visit N. Bedford, Boston, Wooster &c &c.  & stop at Hartford Ct where letters may meet us on our way home, not later than 10 days from today-
   
   We have visited most of the Lions- & among them the Library, where rest the remains of divers elderly volumes-  The discoveries of the Icelanders are there deposited-  We met in the St a certain antiquarian, named Bull, with whom we held learned converse on those discoveries-  On asking him if he had heard of the learned northener who had found a stone with Runic Characters- a temple, & an image representing the Scandanavian God Thor, in Brazil- He said he had not- & then added, "so long as they confined themselves to N. Am, I was willing to concede that point to them- but now that they are going to claim S. Am too, I wont believe any of it"-  The old man may have read our couplet- "They lose the whole who claim too much
    
   As Simon Snyder said in Dutch- And the Danes may now hang up their fiddle, & content themselves with their own Icy shores-The drives abt. Newport are fine- but we have too much dust- the grass is nevertheless very fresh- & the fields are beautiful- We visited a tract at Brenins Point, I side of the Island, & skirted by the Ocean- & a more fertile splendid farm, I do not remember ever to have seen-  They use the seaweed abundantly, as a manure- & also a fish called Manhayden- dragged from the Ocean by nets, & sold at 14 Cts a Bbl- They are very oily- but I do not admire the filthy practice of strewing them over the fields to contaminiate the air-  The bathing here is very good & Job & I use it freely- while mother & E continue their purifications in the warm salt bath-  Among our numerous lodgers we have had Abraham Knickerboker & wife- He the lineal descendant of the true Dietrich- & has his residence at the very spot described by Irving, whose description he says is very correct-  He is an intelligent and well informed man, speaking the English fluently- & his wife interested us very much, by her smiley face, he goodly appearance & good sense-  The good man himself is out of health, & his loving spouse seems very uneasy abt. him-  On leaving us they each gave us a cordial invitation to visit them at their home in the romantic poetical village of Schaghticoke-
     
   While writing Elenor bids me say- you have among you, used her [---] badly, in not even noticing a Letter- wh he took trouble- pains taking man- to endite to some of you- but as she has stepped out- I do not know when manufactured, nor to whom directed- Cara’s epistle of odds & ends- like this of mine- has been received, & was, for her comfort, very satisfactory-
   
   Having in council duly convened decided to go by the Baloon to morrow.  I have come to the conclusion to rest for the present from my labours- to resume if needs be, in the morning but not until I say that we this afternoon paid another visit to the afflicted family mentioned before- none of them are better- the mother indeed much worse- she seems destined we think to take her departure to a better world very soon-
   
   26th
   
   A bright cool air promising a pleasant [---] to Providence- A boarding House forms a pretty good epitomy of life on a larger scale- One generation passeth away & is succeeded by another- so old faces depart [---] & new ones present themselves- In all things said the great Apostle I am instructed- & so we may be even in this day- did not time hurry us with such Rail Road speed as scarcely to permit us more than a glance- Among our imates is a certain Judge Balch of Florida, a thorough going Loco- & reviler of sacred things- He attempted to show that the creation was the result of natural causes, combining & operating on each other- Moses' account he calls a fiction,the mere offspring of a fervid imagination.  He abounds in anecdote- mostly I suspect the product of his own fancy- His atheism offended Knickerbocker much- it shd. be Knickerbacker- marble baker-  I joked & talked politics with the Judge for a while- but finding when hard pressed he became rude, I quit it- yet shd. be amused with his profundity of discourse could I have faith in his word-  He stated for instance that he had furnished the Bk. US. with the first list of Directors for the branch at Nashville- all of whom "Me. Biddle appointed"- He did not however know that while making this statement to me & others he was addressing a man, who had been not only a Director of the Parent Bank at the time, but chairman of the Cme. of elections, who alone reported all nominations of branch directors, to the Board, & who knew the statement to be untrue-  I did not undeceive him, but left him to the enjoyment of his own fiction.  We had a short visit from a mercht. of Havanna- Cpa!  Clapp of the House of Drake, & Co an intelligent man, who, inter alia, gave me a piece of information entirely new, at least to myself- He says that a company of individuals, Spaniards & others, residents in Cuba have purchased a large tract of sand from a native Prince, in Africa, 150 miles square- wh. is to be cultivated with Coffe Sugar &c for commerce- the natives being the Labourers- should the designs of the Comp.y be honest, & fairly carried out- it will carry out Buxtons Scheme, & prove a great blessing to Africa- but considering of whom the Co. is composed, I cannot avoid fears.  C says the Coffee Plantations in Cuba yield but 6 or 7 Pct. while their Sugar Plantations give them 10- the slaves working 14 hours of the 24- The labour is so severe that when suspended, to take food, he has known the slave to fall asleep while on his feet, & prefer rest, even to eating- the waste of life is consequently great.
   
   The change in the weather has produced its usual effect- my E has a headache but will doubtless be better when the sun advances- by the way we have had but one or two foggy mornings since our arrival-  Job & I mean to experiment on a warm bath this morning deeming the sea air is too fresh for our skins-  Love to all- & sympathy in the bargain for any that have tooth ache or the like-
   Thos. P. Cope
   
   As there are so many at Lincolns who have nothing to do, we have half a mind & almost tother half tooto get our dander up for their wicked neglect open in not writing-
   
   I had just sealed this letter when Henry's of the 22d arrived- & have accordingly reopened it to make the acknowledgment- It is gratifying to learn of your continued good condition & of his having parted with his tooth ache- a most troublesome compassion-  I had not heard of any defaltations in the Kent.y Bank- nothing short of making such crimes felony can prevent them-  We have indeed arrived at a such state of morals-  Finding that the next mail goes via Providnce, I shall carry this letter there- & if anything worth penning occur
   
   will make proper not thereof-  We rece.d Franks letter of the 22d recording his & Toms marvellous escape from Hicksite contamination- tho I think they might have broken bread with J.B without fatal consequences-
   
   26th
   
   Here we are at Providence, after a run of abt. 2 hours from Newport-  We lodge at the City Hotel, a large & apparently well regulated House- we have formed no acquaintences but shall probably see some of our friends during the day- Our run up the Narragansett was not very interesting- the shores presenting little variety-  Bristol, Warren & a few neat villages were in view, but trees, those grand ornaments of nature, & wh. impart so much beauty to rural scenery & to City & Town comfort are sadly wanting-  This morn is bright & cool-  As yet we have formed no plans for the day-  When all are up we will hold a councilThe Town meeting to control the Courts is of bad omen- especially as the Judges are by our new Constitution subject for their offices to the popular will- These doings tend to anarchy and despotism, the fruit of Jacksonism- Fanny Wrightism &c[T.P.C. 8/26- Prove- -]
   
   [8/28]
   
   Henry & Alfred Cope
   Philada

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Henry  Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1840-08-25
Title: 1840 August 25, Newport, to Alfred

Newport 8mo 25. 1840
   
   Dear Alfred,
   
   It is growing towards being after sunset, but while Job is making arrangements for our departure tomorrow morning in the Massacheusetts Steamer for Providence, it falls to my lot to drop a line by Wm who is intended send with the Carriage & Horses next day, by return of the same Steamer to NYk thence to proceed on his way to Philada.-  You will all be gratified to hear of thy dear mothers improved health, & also of Eleanors- altho we have experienced hot weather for some days, & have qualms as to the propriety of throwing ourselves into a more heated atmosphere-  Stephen P. Morris arrived here yesterday from Providence, & reports the thermometer to have been up to 95 the day before.  The air since dinner to day has become cooler, & we may reasonably hope will improve a pace shortlty-  Other things change as well as the weather- & now after writing so far, a bell man announces that a Balloon Steamer is to be here tomorrow from P. & return again at 3 AM-  We wished originally to go by her- but she has undergone repairs, & there was this morning no certainty when she wd. be here-  We therefore had made up our minds to go by the Massachusetts between 6 & 7 AM-  We intend to visit N. Bedford, Boston, Wooster &c &c.  & stop at Hartford Ct where letters may meet us on our way home, not later than 10 days from today-
   
   We have visited most of the Lions- & among them the Library, where rest the remains of divers elderly volumes-  The discoveries of the Icelanders are there deposited-  We met in the St a certain antiquarian, named Bull, with whom we held learned converse on those discoveries-  On asking him if he had heard of the learned northener who had found a stone with Runic Characters- a temple, & an image representing the Scandanavian God Thor, in Brazil- He said he had not- & then added, "so long as they confined themselves to N. Am, I was willing to concede that point to them- but now that they are going to claim S. Am too, I wont believe any of it"-  The old man may have read our couplet- "They lose the whole who claim too much
    
   As Simon Snyder said in Dutch- And the Danes may now hang up their fiddle, & content themselves with their own Icy shores-The drives abt. Newport are fine- but we have too much dust- the grass is nevertheless very fresh- & the fields are beautiful- We visited a tract at Brenins Point, I side of the Island, & skirted by the Ocean- & a more fertile splendid farm, I do not remember ever to have seen-  They use the seaweed abundantly, as a manure- & also a fish called Manhayden- dragged from the Ocean by nets, & sold at 14 Cts a Bbl- They are very oily- but I do not admire the filthy practice of strewing them over the fields to contaminiate the air-  The bathing here is very good & Job & I use it freely- while mother & E continue their purifications in the warm salt bath-  Among our numerous lodgers we have had Abraham Knickerboker & wife- He the lineal descendant of the true Dietrich- & has his residence at the very spot described by Irving, whose description he says is very correct-  He is an intelligent and well informed man, speaking the English fluently- & his wife interested us very much, by her smiley face, he goodly appearance & good sense-  The good man himself is out of health, & his loving spouse seems very uneasy abt. him-  On leaving us they each gave us a cordial invitation to visit them at their home in the romantic poetical village of Schaghticoke-
     
   While writing Elenor bids me say- you have among you, used her [---] badly, in not even noticing a Letter- wh he took trouble- pains taking man- to endite to some of you- but as she has stepped out- I do not know when manufactured, nor to whom directed- Cara’s epistle of odds & ends- like this of mine- has been received, & was, for her comfort, very satisfactory-
   
   Having in council duly convened decided to go by the Baloon to morrow.  I have come to the conclusion to rest for the present from my labours- to resume if needs be, in the morning but not until I say that we this afternoon paid another visit to the afflicted family mentioned before- none of them are better- the mother indeed much worse- she seems destined we think to take her departure to a better world very soon-
   
   26th
   
   A bright cool air promising a pleasant [---] to Providence- A boarding House forms a pretty good epitomy of life on a larger scale- One generation passeth away & is succeeded by another- so old faces depart [---] & new ones present themselves- In all things said the great Apostle I am instructed- & so we may be even in this day- did not time hurry us with such Rail Road speed as scarcely to permit us more than a glance- Among our imates is a certain Judge Balch of Florida, a thorough going Loco- & reviler of sacred things- He attempted to show that the creation was the result of natural causes, combining & operating on each other- Moses' account he calls a fiction,the mere offspring of a fervid imagination.  He abounds in anecdote- mostly I suspect the product of his own fancy- His atheism offended Knickerbocker much- it shd. be Knickerbacker- marble baker-  I joked & talked politics with the Judge for a while- but finding when hard pressed he became rude, I quit it- yet shd. be amused with his profundity of discourse could I have faith in his word-  He stated for instance that he had furnished the Bk. US. with the first list of Directors for the branch at Nashville- all of whom "Me. Biddle appointed"- He did not however know that while making this statement to me & others he was addressing a man, who had been not only a Director of the Parent Bank at the time, but chairman of the Cme. of elections, who alone reported all nominations of branch directors, to the Board, & who knew the statement to be untrue-  I did not undeceive him, but left him to the enjoyment of his own fiction.  We had a short visit from a mercht. of Havanna- Cpa!  Clapp of the House of Drake, & Co an intelligent man, who, inter alia, gave me a piece of information entirely new, at least to myself- He says that a company of individuals, Spaniards & others, residents in Cuba have purchased a large tract of sand from a native Prince, in Africa, 150 miles square- wh. is to be cultivated with Coffe Sugar &c for commerce- the natives being the Labourers- should the designs of the Comp.y be honest, & fairly carried out- it will carry out Buxtons Scheme, & prove a great blessing to Africa- but considering of whom the Co. is composed, I cannot avoid fears.  C says the Coffee Plantations in Cuba yield but 6 or 7 Pct. while their Sugar Plantations give them 10- the slaves working 14 hours of the 24- The labour is so severe that when suspended, to take food, he has known the slave to fall asleep while on his feet, & prefer rest, even to eating- the waste of life is consequently great.
   
   The change in the weather has produced its usual effect- my E has a headache but will doubtless be better when the sun advances- by the way we have had but one or two foggy mornings since our arrival-  Job & I mean to experiment on a warm bath this morning deeming the sea air is too fresh for our skins-  Love to all- & sympathy in the bargain for any that have tooth ache or the like-
   Thos. P. Cope
   
   As there are so many at Lincolns who have nothing to do, we have half a mind & almost tother half tooto get our dander up for their wicked neglect open in not writing-
   
   I had just sealed this letter when Henry's of the 22d arrived- & have accordingly reopened it to make the acknowledgment- It is gratifying to learn of your continued good condition & of his having parted with his tooth ache- a most troublesome compassion-  I had not heard of any defaltations in the Kent.y Bank- nothing short of making such crimes felony can prevent them-  We have indeed arrived at a such state of morals-  Finding that the next mail goes via Providnce, I shall carry this letter there- & if anything worth penning occur
   
   will make proper not thereof-  We rece.d Franks letter of the 22d recording his & Toms marvellous escape from Hicksite contamination- tho I think they might have broken bread with J.B without fatal consequences-
   
   26th
   
   Here we are at Providence, after a run of abt. 2 hours from Newport-  We lodge at the City Hotel, a large & apparently well regulated House- we have formed no acquaintences but shall probably see some of our friends during the day- Our run up the Narragansett was not very interesting- the shores presenting little variety-  Bristol, Warren & a few neat villages were in view, but trees, those grand ornaments of nature, & wh. impart so much beauty to rural scenery & to City & Town comfort are sadly wanting-  This morn is bright & cool-  As yet we have formed no plans for the day-  When all are up we will hold a councilThe Town meeting to control the Courts is of bad omen- especially as the Judges are by our new Constitution subject for their offices to the popular will- These doings tend to anarchy and despotism, the fruit of Jacksonism- Fanny Wrightism &c[T.P.C. 8/26- Prove- -]
   
   [8/28]
   
   Henry & Alfred Cope
   Philada

Date: 1835-06-08
Title: 1835 June 8, Haverford, to Uncle

Haverford 6th month 8th 1835
   
   Dear Uncle,
   
   As I suppose that thee has by this time returned from Sykens' Valley, I will endeavour this morning, to fulfil my promise.  I wish that I could find something to say that would interest thee but I am afraid that in a place like this a person is much better able to hear than to relate news.  Had thee a pleasant time at Sykens' Valley?  It is now rather later in the season than it was when we visited it several years ago.  I recollect that the country was very pleasant then, and I suppose that it is still more so now unless the lateness of the season has retarded the growth of the plants in such a degree as that they should not be any more in bloom than they were then.  I expect that in thy promised letter thee will give a very interesting account of the journey.  I must not forget to mention that we expect to have a French teacher here next week.  He is a Frenchman and has lately come from Ireland where he had been living since his banishment and where his wife now is.  He was a captain under Buonaparte and showed us a number of wounds which he received in the battle ofLeipsic with lances, and several places where bullets had gone entirely through his arms.  When the Pope was taken prisoner by Buonaparte he was guard over him and he treated the Pope so kindly that when he was liberated he made him captain of the Guards of Honor.  He appears to be a very pleasing and goodn-natured man and like all the French, extremely polite.  We expect that he will tell us many very interesting accounts of the battles that he has been present at.  He appears to be a very intelligent man and speaks Arabic, Spanish, Italian and English very fluently.  He accompanied his father who was minister to the Count of Persia and while there acquired a knowledge of the Arabic language.  His name his D'Mouillon.  I do not know whether I have spelt it right or not, but that is the way that it is pronounced.  As it is nearly time for this letter to go to the Post office and, as I wish to write a few lines to father on the same sheet I must conclude with 
   
   Thy affectionate nephew
   
   Thomas P Cope jrHaverford 6th mo 8th 1835
   
   Dear Father,
   
   As there is plenty of room on this sheet for a few lines more, I may as well fill it up with some of our wants.  Please send us out our Jacobs Greek Readings and a new supply of money as that which we had before is nearly exhausted.  Thy affect son
   
   Thomas P Cope jr
   
   We are very well[Buck Tavern-
   June 8th,]
   
   Alfred Cope
   Care of H&A Cope
   Philadelphia
   
   [TPCope jr-6/8-'35
   ansd-15-]

Date: 1852-07-17
Title: 1852 July 17, to Clemmie, Woodbourne

Philadelphia, 7mo 17, 1852
   
   Dear Clemmie,
   Grandfather desired me to acknowledge the receipt of thy acceptable letter of last seventh day. I am sorry for thy sake that it has not fallen into better hand, but if thee will believe that I have the will to send thee such a letter as would give thee a great deal of pleasure, I will rely upon the interest it will have for thee as coming from among and giving thee a great deal of pleasure. I will rely upon the interest it will have for thee as coming from among and giving thee perhaps, the latest news of some of those who think so much of thee. Anne and I entirely agree with thee in considering that the pleasantest part of the days journey was when we were all traveling together. We ran off the track about half an hour after we parted and were four hours in a pretty hot place before we were on our way again. If we had foreseen that we were to pass nearly the whole day on the road might have he fellow travelers a greater distance and lightened me and others burdens. Thee must have had a very tiresome journey all the way home Henry Drinker tells us thee had to ride from Wilkes-Barre in the hot sun in an open wagon: he thinks they did much better. When thee comes down next winder, take thou Scranton unto. We are glad to hear that thee friend Uncle William so much better and the rest all well. Grandfather seems stronger and generally better than when he fist came out in the country- He sends his love to thee and all the family. Aunt Caroline, Frank and Ellie are at Cape May. I forget whetherthey went before thee left: they wrote several days ago that Ellie’s general health was improved We have heard indirectly that Mary was unwell- Julia has gone to Reading for a few weeks. Aunt Mary returned to Jersey yesterday I believe- She was kept in turn an account of Elizabeth’s mother having an attack very much like if not really cholera. She was very ill one night: they have gone to Cape May since with Henry and Ellie. The three families that live in that unnamed corner of this country that is so hard to find am pretty much as the left them they all send their love. Elizabeth says she would be very glad if thee would write to her if thee fells so inclined. Please tell Uncle William that a package for Grandfather by Henry Drinker came safe to hand the morning- Uncle Alfred has taken the letter out to him. He comes in and spends every "third-day" in town.   
   I hope we shall hear from thee often; if thee should write to me it would give me much pleasure.
   
   Affectionately thy cousin,
   Thomas P Cope Jr.
    
   Germantown, 7mo 18, 1852
   
   Dear Clemmie,
   
   Not having a woman's privilege as to postscripts I begin afresh.  I have no objections however to having reason to call the by name again – it seems more natural and sociable and I see thee look up from thy work or from study or quiet wordto hear what I have to say- I finished in a hurry yesterday afternoon intending to mail this before leaving town, but time failing I have an opportunity to say that Anne secured a letter from Eddy last evening in which he says nothing about his bodily conditions, but that his discontent which she had inquired about are improving" Your visit no doubt did him good. Visits from home to a boy at school are a pleasant recollections for the rest of his life.
   
   Thee did not grieve much about they blanket shawl when thee was riding in the stage at night; it will be cooler when thee comes down next fall and we will take care to sent it up to thee in time. Grandfather will be glad to hear from thee and I hope if thee is not afraid of a repetition of what thy first letter has brought upon thee, that thee will write to [.]
   
   With many desire for thy happiness.
 Affectionately, thy Cousin,
   Thomas Cope Jr.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1828-09-10
Title: 1828 September 10, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 9mo. 10. 1828
   
   Dear Brother,   
   If thou should not have invested for me the sum relative to which I wrote to thee on the 2d. ult., having confidence in the success of the C&D Canal, I will be obliged by thy adding to the amt. $1000 or $1500., & charging it to my a/c.  if it had occurred to me at the time, I wd. have made ye same request when I last wrote to thee, and it may be difficult to invest in the canal loan so small an am't as I then mentioned.* - having lately purchased some cattle & implements for my farm, I shall have occasion to draw on ye firm for ab't $100 or $120.  I drew on ye 5 inst., at 3 d/s fav. Porter & Keene for $50.-   
   with particular love to ye members of thy family individually, I remain thy affectionate brother,
   
   Wm D Cope
   
   *I need scarcely add, that I do not wish this to be done, unless entirely convenient to you.Henry Cope
   Care of Thos. P. Cope & Sons
   Philadelphia.
   
   attention of Caleb Carmalt.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1828-11-17
Title: 1828 November 17, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 11mo. 17. 1828
   Dear Brother,
   
   Thy letter of 28 ult. has been rec'd.  Wm Drinker has transferred his claim on Father to Martin Curtis, store-keeper of Montrose.  ye latter mentioned to me, when I was last in Montrose, that Wm has spoken to him on the subject of stopping any legal proceedings that may have been commenced.  this he said he was willing to do, tho' he wd. not relinquish a cent of ye claim, wh he was sure must be all paid: that unless a legal tender had been made, interest cd. be obtained on ye respective sums for ye time of their becoming due: that he knew W. Drinker had pd. a considerable portion of them in cash, because they had been pd.thro' him.  I told him that I tho't he had only heard one side of the case & advised him not to be to confident of success.-  W.D. also says that he subjected himself to considerable inconvenience in order to pay the taxes, but considered that ye debt was in safe hands & wd. ne accumulating by ye addition of interest.
   
   I observe that the Ches. & Dele. Canal loan has not yet risen, if ye public quotations are to be relied on, & shall be glad if thou hast succeeded in making a further investment for me.-  besides the drafts mentione[d] in thy last, I drew on the 6th inst. draft no. 5 for $50.00.- how [---] does ye agitation in ye corn market affect ye shipping interest?  and what freights have ye packets lately had?-  I was sorry to learn that Alfred was again lame.  please mention in thy next ye cause of his lameness.-  with particular love to ye members of thy family individually, I remain thy affectionate brother,   Wm D Cope
   
   I will be obliged by thy collecting the annexed drafts for me.Woodbourne
   11 mo, 17 1828
   
   [11mo 19 1828]
   
   Henry Cope,
   Care of Thomas P Cope & Sons
   Philadelphia.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1829-05-11
Title: 1829 May 11, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 5mo. 11. 1829
   Dear Brother:
   
   I reached this place after a pleasant journey, which occupied, as usual, 2 days.  I had pleasant company, & never before endured so little fatigue in crossing the Pokono.  the road over it is considerably improved.  I had the company of Jos'h [S?]inton  from Nazareth to Wilkes-barre.  he was on his return from attending the Orthodox Yearly Meeting.-  I was much pleased with the verdant appearance of the fields in this part of ye country.  ye season is much less advanced than usual at this time of year, but the grass looks well.-  there has not been so much done at my buildings during my absense as I expected wd. have been done, but ye workmen are now busily employed.  my Scotch farmer, I think it likely, will maintain the character of his countrymen for industry & fidelity, but I have not hired him long enough, fairly to test his qualifications.  ye female part of his family, however, it too numerous to suit me, as I have but little employment for women.-  tho' I have but little to communicate, I tho't I wd. not let a private opp'y pass without informing you of my safe arrival here & present health.  I shall feel anxious to hear from the invalids of thy family, tho' I hope they are not now invalids.-  I hope also that our new Mother may, by this time have regained her usual health.-  please give my love to all my kind friends & relatives, with whom I have so recently passed so many pleasant hours, that ye chain of communication between us, though separated, seems unbroken & strong.-  if thee shd. see Uncle Jasper please tell him, that I delivered his letter to Henry Colt, but that John N Conyngham had left Montrose before I arrived.  I therefore immediately forwarded the letter for him, to Wilkesbarre, & have little doubt but that he received it before leaving there for Bradford County.   I remain thy affectionate brother,
   Wm D CopePlease say to Eleanor, that I hope she will not mention to Cousins Abby Ann & Emma, any remarks that I made with regard to the evening company invited by them a short time before I left the City & of which I was one.  such observations are sometimes repeated under circumstances that give them an air of more seriousness than was intended by the one who makes them.[Note in second hand: W.D. Cope Woodbourne 5mo 11 1829]
   
   [Note in third hand: Journey home & personal allusions-"Our new Mother," etc., Scotch farmer- too many females in his family!]
   
   Henry Cope
   Care of Thomas P Cope & Sons,
   Philadelphia.
   
   attention of Jas C Biddle

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1828-12-12
Title: 1828 December 12, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 12mo. 12-1828
   Dear Brother:
   
   Having an opp'y of writing, I will embrace it if it be only to thank thee for thy kind attention to the subjects mentioned in thine of 22 ult.-  ye mildness of ye season so far, will probably favor the operations of the Ches. & Del. Canal Co.-  I hope the Algonquin may do well at Savannah, as I observe by late a/cts, that no vessels were up there, & freights were brisk, tho' ye rates were low.  if it be not improper, nor too much trouble, please mention in writing to me, ye names of ye authors of any of the essays in "the Friend," that may come to thy knowledge.-  we have lately had a visit in these parts, from two hetorodox friends, Jno. Foulke of Quakertown, Bucks Co., & Salathiel Cleaver, of Montgomery Co.-  they had meetings at Friendsville, & in the neighborhood.  the Presbyterians expressedtheir satisfaction with the communications of J. Foulke.  I did not hear him speak in public, but understand that he did not speak on doctrinal points.  he is a man of venerable appearance, & his plain, communicative, unostentatious habits & manners, are calculated to preposess a stranger in his favour.  amongst other places, that he has visited, is ye settlement of the German Separatists in the Western country.  he speaks of their condition as very comfortable & flourishing.  the canal which is to connect the Lakes with the Ohio, passes thro' their land.
   
   I have just rec'd a letter from Caroline.  please give my love to her & tell her, that I will thank her to use my authority in contradicting any rumours of the kind to which she alludes.-  we are obliged to submit to the mortification of being ye subjects of them, but I think it is no more improper to contradict such, than any other incorrect reports.
   
   I have a paymt. to make before long, & expect to draw on the firm in a few days, to meet it, for about $200.-
   
   With love to all, I remain thy affectionate brother,
   Wm D Cope[Wm D Cope Woodbourne 12mo 12 1828
   
   Mtg at Friendsville
   Jno. Foulke &c
   
   12mo 20 1828-]
   Henry Cope
   Care of Thomas P Cope,
   no.36, North 4th St., or Walnut St. Wharf,
   Philadelphia.-
   
   p. Charles Chandler Esqe.

Date: 1830-05-15
Title: 1830 May 15, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne, 5 month 15th 1830
   Dear Brother:
   
   Thy acceptable letter of 7th inst.  has been rec'd.  thy observations with regard to retirement & the Christian's duty, are certainly correct in the abstract, but I think it will be readily admitted by thee on reflection, that remotely placed as thou art from ye scene in which I move, a correct opinion of ye course most proper for me to pursue, cannot easily be formulated, either by thyself, or any one similarly situated.  to be candid; I may mention, that I think myself pretty fortunate in being able by some excersize or display of management, to make a live,- to use a significant term of the Yankees here,- to possess or enjoy ye common comforts of life.  I have therefore, not much time or inducement to propound to myself sentimental or metaphysical queries in regard to duties, problematical, or supposed to be omitted.  I may be compared in some measure to an honest & benevolent day labourer. (not insinuating that I have a claim to ye character of benevolence.)-  if a distressed fellow creature cross his path or approach his cabin, no one is more willing to dispense ye comforts with which he may be blessed.  but he cannot, like his more wealthy & independent fellow-citizens, go in quest of objects of charity.-  ye call of benevolence, shd. be heard & obeyed, and I freely acknowledge that it ought to be our aim, so to arrange our temporal concerns, as to be in the way of receiving benefit & advantage from our fellow men, or of administering ye same to them, as opportunities present.  this view & reflection, I wish to bring home to myself.  but I have undertaken a business & entered upon a course of life which I had but little previous knowledge, for which I had but little previous education & of which I had formed erroneous expectations.  it wd. certainly have been better on some accounts, if I had taken up my abode in a town or village, upon my first making this county my residence.  if I had excluded farming & building from my views, my business wd. have been much simplified.  but I wished to select ye most adventageous situation for promoting the interest & settlement of Father's est'e: and I think by showing that I consider ye land and ye country good enough for myself, a favorable effect has been & will continueto be produced.  ye difficulty of obtaining assistance here, is a great drawback to ye comfort & satisfaction of ye farmer.  yet as I have put ye machine in motion, I must keep it moving, & as I am harnessed in, I must move with it, unless I have some one to supply my place.  I still indulge ye hope that I shall be able to pull things into proper train, but I begin to think that it will require about as many years to accomplish ye object, as I supposed it would of weeks, before commencing ye undertaking.  I am often however enabled, gratefully to call to mind ye advantage of my present situation, to that of remaining in the City, a victim to disease.  tho' I am thankful that my circumstances are what they are, I trust I shall have sense enough to keep in view that I am not a man of fortune, in ye sense that ye term is generally understood; and when I see how easily my income & more than my income, is fittered away, and how little is to be seen of its effects, I am induced to pause, before launching out into expensesm without calculation.  when & how, ye returns are to come, is uncertain.  a farm in a new county is indeed a quicksand, so great are its absorbing qualities; & we have to deal here with a shewd set of sharpers.  a man who is considered to be in tolerably good circumstances, & is supposed to have money, must expect to be asked two prices for everything, & they will be Jewed or Yankeed out of him, if he does not look about him with eagle eyes.-  Dr. Rose, to be sure, in ye course of upwards of twenty years has done much: but ye course pursued by one man, does not form a rule for another, differently circumstanced.  he has had a numerous class of settlers, of diversified trades & occupations to assist him, to whom he has sold land for good prices, & from many of whom he wd. probably have obtained nothing, had he not have taken pay in such kind of assistance.-  Caleb Carmalt is similarly situated.-  speaking of Caleb, reminds me of a circumstance which occurred at the last Friendsville Preparative Meeting.  he was present, and John Kite, the clerk, objected to proceeding with ye business, whilst one who was not a member of the Society, was in ye house.  Caleb said that he supposed he was ye person alluded to, but that he had proof of his being a member of the Society of Friends, which he cd. produce if necessary.  one of the Hicksites remarked, that ye meeting itself had no information, or at least no official information of C. Carmalt's disownment.  a number of remarks were made in bothsides, but there seemed to be a general sentimentin favour of proceeding with what was before the meeting, without further discussion or excitement, and the clerk accordingly complied with what seemed to be the wish of the meeting.-  this is about ye substance of an account given by a Hicksite to E. Walker.-  what I mentioned in ye preceding part of my letter with regard to charity & benevolence, also recalls to recollection ye case of Uniah Estes, one of Father's settlers, who for ye last 6 weeks or 2 months, has been afflicted with mental alienation.  Jno. Mann kept him at his house several weeks.  by judicious management there, he has been so far resolved, that it was considered safe to suffer him to return to his family.  if he shd. have a relapse which is feared, it is tho't that it wd. be advisable to send him to Friends' Assylum.  if ye information is in thy possession or can be conveniently obtained by thee, I will thank thee to mention in thy next, ye lowest term on which poor patients are rec'd into that institution.  he is a member of the Society of Friends & belongs to a monthly meeting in ye State of New York.-  Elias Bennet, an old & respectable settler on ye Susqa. Co. Tract, who, Father will probably recollect was grievously afflicted with a cancer, died in ye early part of this Spring.  he has bequeathed his farm, or his right in it, to two of his sons.-  my annual subscription in advance, to "the Friend," became due in ye early part of this month.  I will be obliged by thy having it paid when convenient, & having a rec't taken.-  please not to forget my subscription to the Athenaeum.  I wish I were well rid of my share of stock.  I did not intend to have omitted to mention, that there was no charge in my a/c with the old firm of Thomas P Cope & Sons, for my proportion of ye amo't of subscription to the "Morning Journal."  it would I think be no more than right that I shd. pay part of it.-  I shall be anxious relative to Sister Caroline, & will be obliged by thy giving me information relative to her state of health, as soon as convenient.
   
   With love to all, I remain affectionately thy Brother,
   Wm D Cope
   
   I drew on 5 ult. in fav. C. Avery & Co., at 3 d/s, draft no 24 for $100.  and no 25 on ye 3d ins't at samesight fav. C. Avery for $50.0-Woodbourne
   5mo.15.
   
   [5 mo 19]
   
   Henry Cope
   care of Henry & Alfred Cope,
   Philadelphia.

Title: 1830 July 29, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 7mo. 29th 1830
   Dear Brother:
   
   The idea presented in thine of ye 20 inst. of finding me out in the woods, I may truly say, excited in me very pleasant feelings; tho' at ye same time, I feel as if I can scarcely dare to invite you, for reasons that I think it wd. not be proper to mention in a letter. I will give thee a remote exception of what amongst other things, I allude to, by refering to a frequent remark, that in every flock, there is a black sheep, & a Judas in every community. more than this, I ought not to say. I believe I have never hesitated to answer any query put to me by relatives & friends respecting my situation, nor have I any objections to doing so, unless I may have a very particular reason for secrecy. but Marmaduke will perhaps from having been an impartial spectator, be more likely to give thee a satisfactory description of Woodbourne than myself.- E. Walker bro't me thy letter whilst I was spending ye evening as usual, with his family. I mentioned what was said by thee about visiting me. George desired me to tell thee that they shd. be very glad to see thee: and Priscilla said, tell him to bring Rachel &Martha. they all seemed to be as glad to see Marmaduke & our other cousins, as if they had been their own relations. it seemed to me to be quite like an era in ye history of Woodbourne, when my City relations had actually paid me a visit.- I think you had better come on, and take us by surprise as they did, and thus give us no time to think about any obstructions, objections, or difficulties. with regard to any pecuniary considerations, I think I cd. fully satisfy my neighbours, tho' they will not listen to any direct proposition relative to consideration money.- in expressing what precedes, I have used ye freedom, which ought to exist in ye intercourse between brothers. to one, who does not stand in ye same relationship to me as thyself, I wd. have felt some hesitation in saying what I have said to thee.- I was much interested in reading thy description of ye proposed institution for imparting instruction in ye higher branches of learning to the children of Friends, and had no idea that so great an advance had been made towards affecting ye object in view. it is a noble undertaking, & if accomplished, will tend to increase ye reputation of the Society. the sup-position or opinion, that our profession, principles or religion acquires ye discouragement of literary knowledge & intelligence, appears to me pretty evidently to be a mistake.-  I was fearful that there wd. be an appearance of ambiguity in my observations with regard to the Union Canal stock.  In my last communication on ye subject, I expressed a willingness to invest, if I cd. obtain five per cent on the am't invested.  this I shd. receive, were I to give $240 per share, or 120 per cent.  consequently, if I am right in my estimate, ye price is still below my limits.  but of course, there would be no advantage in offering a high price, if there is none of the stock for sale.-  I am much obliged to thy attention to the subject.  supposing that the Bank of Penna has declared ye dame divd. for ye last as for ye previous half year, I inclose a Power of Att'y for its collection, & one also for the interest on the C & D Canal loan.  if the Lehigh Co. shd. have disclosed a divd. please inform me.  I see by the news-papers, that 3 1/2% has been declared by the U.S. B'k.
   
   With best love to family & friends, I remain thy affectionate brother,
   Wm D Cope
   
   I have drawn, under date of 5mo. 3-'30, draft no. 25, fav. C. Avery for $50.+  and no 26, under date of 7mo. 1-'30, fav. Avery & Drinker, for same am't, & both at 3 d/s.  also no. 27, at 3 d/s, fav. Avery & Drinker, dated 7mo.13-'30, for $50.00
   I lately spoke to G. Mallery about ye P. Thomson tract & he promised me that he will again lay ye subject before ye Com's & when their decision is ascertained, will write to me.
   
   + before advised ofKnow all men by these presents, that I, William D Cope of the Township of Springville, County of Susquehanna and State of Pennsylvania, have authorized and appointed, and do authorize and appoint, Henry Cope, of the firm of Henry & Alfred Cope, Philadelphia, my true and lawful attorney, to demand and receive from the Chesapeak & Delaware Canal Company, the interest due me on Nine thousand five hundred dollars ($9500.) Loan of said Company.
   
   In witness whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seal rgw twenty-ninth day of the 7mo. (August) 1830
   Signed and sealed in the presence of
   Jonathan Nichols
   Lyman BaldwinWoodbourne
   7mo.30.
   
   [8mo 1 1830-]
   Henry Cope,
   care of Henry & Alfred Cope,
   Philadelphia.

Date: 1830-08-23
Title: 1830 August 23, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 8 month 23d. 1830.
   My Dear Brother:
   
   I now write to thee, under the pressure of misfortune.-  my dwelling house, & nearly all its contents have been reduced to ashes.  the result of two years' toil, anxiety, & incessant thought & attention have gone, as it were in an instant, beyond recall.  I had advanced so far in my improvements, that I began to indulge the hope that their completion might be effected, & I enabled to enjoy some advantage from them, & some degree of repose from the troublesome kind of occupation which they gave me.-  the exterior was handsomely painted, the windows hung with green [verition] shutters & I had made an agreement with a person to plaister the rooms.-  this, my dear brother, is a misfortune that I find hard to bear.  it has come upon me so suddenly & unexpectedly!-  it seems doubly so, when I reflect upon ye time and thought that is has required to plan ye various conveniences that had been constructed, and the labour that had been spent in collecting & preparing what I had, in & about my house.  I had formed an attachment to almost everything that I had obtained ye possession of in this way, & enjoyed a degree of satisfaction in reflecting upon ye difficulties that I had overcome.  I feel at present, as if I had scarcely spirit & fortitude enough to continue a method of getting along with my concerns & business.  to be without a house on a farm, is truly embarrassing.  thou hast sympathized with me, my dear brother, in temporal afflictions, with which both of us have been equally affected & concerned, & I have no doubt but that thou wilt in this.  I feel a wish to fly to thee for consolation, as well as to avoid ye sight of ye ruins of my dwelling, which stare me constantly in ye face.  but I seem to be tied here, as there is no one to attend to my concerns in my absense, & I am also aware that no human power can heal the wounds inflicted by misfortune.-  I have rece'd, dear brother, another deeply instructive lesson on ye uncertainty & instability of earthly possessions.  to be sure, a calamity of ye kind that has befallen me, seems light, when we reflect upon ye comparatively short period of existence here, and of the primary & unspeakably greater importance of securing an interest & inheritance in the world to come.  but we are so constituted, that ye feelings of our nature, appear as if they wd. at times obtain ye mastery over us.  mine seem as if they would sometimes overcome me.-  I will be obliged by thy not showing this letter to others, as it contains some of ye outpourings of my feelings, whilst smarting under misfortune, and which I shall perhaps be ashamed of, after I shall have had time to stay my mind on ye foundationwhere alone, enduring & unfailing consolation is to be found.-  I had indulged in many pleasing anticipations of ye reward that wd. await me, upon the result of my labours.-  they are all blasted!  the ways of Providence are mysterious.  may I be resigned to its will.-  no insurance had been effected on my property.  the Philada. offices that I applied to, declined insuring, & there is a difficulty in effecting insurance at the N. York offices, owing to the law lately passed by the Legislature of Penna.  before ye passage of that law, one or more of the N. York offices had an agent at Montrose.  he cannot now act for them.-  I had intended, after ye completion of my buildings, to have made another effort to have insurance made.-  ye fire is supposed to have been communicated to some wood-work about & near to, the oven.  it burst out of ye roof & sides of ye house just as we were sitting down to dinner, about 1, O’clock on 6th day last, & so rapidly did ye flames spread, that I had only time to rescue my manuscript papers, part of my personal clothing, & a few articles of furniture, before ye heat & smoke had enveloped everything, so that no one could enter or approach near to the building.  I cd. not have thought before experiencing it, that a loss of this kind wd. have been so hard to bear.-  I am now left more dependant than I have ever before been since residing here, upon ye kindness of my neighbours.-  E. Walker's family have offered me shelter & lodging, and have done all in their power to make me comfortable.  I deire that I may be sufficiently grateful for their kind assistance & sympathy.   Please convey assurances of love & regard to relatives & friends, from thy affectionate brother,   Wm D Cope
   
   I wrote to thee on ye 18 inst. by Andw. Hodge.  ye letter was marked on ye outside, attention of Dr. P. Price.Woodbourne
    8mo. 25
   
   Henry Cope
   Care of Henry & Alfred Cope
   Philadelphia.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Joel Baily
