Title: 1897 January 9, Philadelphia, to Frank

[Letterhead: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia   -- Logan Square.]

Philadelphia Jan. 9.   1897

Dear Frank

I have been looking over the   membership of the Audubon Society & find your sisters are   not on the list. 

Cannot you induce them to sign the   card & sign one yourself. We want all the names possible &   every one helps If we can get a membership of 1000 we will   exert a much greater influence than if we have only   100.

We want gentlemen as well as ladies, for we are   going to try toobtain better game laws & support all matters relative to   the protection of birds.

I enclose a card for your   signature.

Sorry you did not get in Thursday we had a   gathering of 23 & elected DeHaven Pres. & Shylock Secty for   the coming year

I want to see you & Justice in the   Active Membership & am working to that end

Sincerely   yours

Witmer Stone


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Pemberton Pleasants
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1856-04-27
Title: 1856 April 27, Iowa Falls, to Cousin Annie

Iowa Falls 4 mo 27. 1856
My Dear Cousin Annie

A   great flood has washed away mills and houses along the Iowa   River carrying every thing before it but what a puny flood   it was compaired to the flood of tears I shed on hearing of   the marriage of Susan (how my hand trembles as I write the   name) thy letter of consolation came as a balm to my wounded   heart and I will try and take thy advice not to cry after   spilled milk.
Affairs are going on in the old way in this   section of the globe nothing of much interest is stirring   except the wind which to day is particularly severe I never   had an idea that the wind blew, as it does across the   praries it realy exceeds the blowing at "Our old House at   Home" otherwise called "Bleak House."
Thy letter of   information was replete with accounts of marriages and I can   do no better than return the complement by telling thee of   an intended one between Benjamin K Wetherell & Miriam   Thompkins both of them are young and friends they will be   married in about 4 weeksat our meeting house (ie the residence of Benj Talbott.) it   will no doubt be conducted in a novel style.  I am not at   present able to give any information respecting bridesmaids   but will at a future time give a complicated description of   dress and cerimony.  The groom, or intended groom rather is   from Chester, Pa I was at Westtown B School, with him.  His   is the only face I have ever seen before, since I came into   Iowa.
Thee would smile to see the inconsistency in dress   of the females of the society in this part of the country I   observed one in meeting this morning who wore a plain bonnet   and shawl a red calico dress made surplus, and to crown all   a cheap plated silver breastpin not small in sise with a   large red stone, or glass rather set in it,!!!  I had to   smile.  An other peculiarity in meeting is the presence of   numerous "babies" and small children who enliven the meeting   with their sonorous (?) music.  I might enlarge much on the   peculiarities of the west but time and space will not permit   But one expression I will tell thee when tellinga story to any fair dame.  if it proves to be rather a   remarkable one she replyes "I want to know"! with an   emphasis on the word to also repeating it with a slight   nasal twang.
One word about western life in some of its   stages a few weeks ago having occasion to go about 20 miles   north of this place into the "wilds of Iowa" I had to stop   all night at the house of a "Hoosier" his cabin was about 18   by 16 without a window 7 small children stood around the   fire with their mouths and eyes open as I entered the room   was also without a floor unless a hard surface of earth   might be called a floor in one corner stood a bedstead a   calf was tied in an other corner whilst a "pig" had the   entire range of the house.  in such quarters I was compelled   to eat and lodge for one night, and only one thank fortune,   as there was no other house within 8 or 9 miles.  After   "tea" (what’s in a name?) I amused myself with looking into   the fire and listening.  to the oldest daughter (aged about   16) who stood by the fireplace chewing her bonnet string whorelaited the hair breadth escapes the pig had from being   hooked by the "old brindle cow" and how Jonny (the next to   youngest) got lost in the "bresh" when looking after the   cows.  a bed was at last made on the floor for my companion   and myself where we soon forgot all the world and the rest   of mankind in sleep.
But this is not all Iowa I am as   comfortably fixed as can be expected.
While I write some   inteligence just comes which has cast a gloom over the whole   town it is the inteligence that a steam mill which was   intended to be erected in place of the water mill removed by   the water during the freshet, will not be erected excuse   more at present, the town will be evacuated by a great part   of the inhabitants their indignation is so great.  I dont   know what my next move will be 
Love to Uncle Henry Aunt   Rachel Julia and all thy affectionate cos
Chas P.   Pleasants

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872

Title: 1865 June 7, B, to Mother and sister Annte

B 6/7—65—

Dear Mother & sister Annte.

I think   I’ll address you collectively this time, as I suppose   Caroline’s head’ll be turned with weddings & unable to   appreciate common topics. I recd. yr. very interesting &   spirited epistles this morn.g & reply at once, in order that   you may not have cause to complain of remissness this time,   & upon what ground you did it last, I must say I cld. not   discover, as I think I have been up to the mark quite as   much as you have. Thy remarks [a] on properness &c were   quite edifying. I expect thee wd. be charmed with the   Baltimore people. They are certainly most social & charming   in their manners, tho’ I dont believe afterall, when you come to the foundation of things that there is   any more good substantial material among them than among   some of that despised class denominated "the proper." As to   the gentlemen I cant say that I have met any whom I consider   very deeply interesting As far as gallantry & politeness go   they are certainly very attractive Bt if we cld. only   introduce a little more of these elements with some of our   [imperturbables] I incline to think these wld. be found   quite as deep in the long run. I must say it is refreshing   to get hold of some thing that is more [impressible] than a   stone & I intend to [---] up Baltimore ways loudly when I   get home. Tell Cousin Mary she must hurry & come down as   fast as she can, or I fearI shall not get to have my sprees with her. This morn the   new teacher who is going to take my sch. arrived & I was   promoted or depressed I dont know wh. to the rank of   assistant to Mr Waterman, the principal of the sch. It is a   splendid change for me, as his room is much pleasanter & I   have none of the discipline to do but only the hearing of   the lessons—intellectually, it seems a most magnificent   advance frm. a-b only to geography and arithmetic & I shd.   be quite willing to teach there for weeks if it was’nt for   the hot weather, as it is, however, considering the [--] &c   I think I had better not stay much after the three months   are up wh. will be abt. the mid of June--& very soon—as you   will perceive, so you may make preparations for me, soon   after that time—I hope you’ll havepleasant little surprise prepared for me in the way of a   closet—wh. wont be the linen closet—I have to keep up such   an everlasting foolding and unfolding here that I shall be   perfectly delighted to get a place to "hang up" in.

I   expect I am indebted to my frd. Jesse for this release frm.   the infants—I said to him in joke some time ago that I thot,   I shd. give "notice" soon for them to get another teacher &   he took it in earnest but I am very glad, on some accts, as   I shd like to get some ideas about older teaching frm Mr.   W.

I expect you’ll enjoy [Mr. N’s] wedding most as   much as Lilly’s—There was a young gentleman here the other   day who told somebody that he thot L’s wedding was   dreadfully stupid, & that he thot’ one or two of the   bridesmaids (he did’nt say all) were the ugliest girls he   had ever seen—not a very complimentary speech I think.
As I shall probably come home so soon it will not be worth   while to send the things by express—tho’ if I cld only have   had them now they wld. have been exceedingly useful -- I   think maybe I’ll try & get myself a beige skt. here & we   shall not be likely to have many more tea parties now the   warm weather has come -- We’ve never heard any more abt.   Jessies strawberry party & we’re afraid he’s forgotten it.   He took us to a small one out at his bro. James’ night   before last. We went in a buggy & pair & came home by   moonlight—quite romantically -- The buggy is only used on   very romantic occasions, I believe. Its so nice here   moonlight nights—the ladies all dress up in their whites &   sit out on the front door steps, & go round [seeing?] one   another with beaux or beau less just as it happens.Has Fanny Drinker gone home? I reckon she has & where is   Cous. Sarah? Give my love to her if she is about still. I   ought to have written to her. Give my love also to all the   Wynndowners also please give my love & congratulations to   all the bride cousins & tell them I’m very sorry not to be   giving them anything-- Maybe if I aint so lazy I’ll make em   something after I get home. But dont tell em that. I believe   this is all I have to say at present—will write and fix the   day of course before I come. If Cous. M. comes soon please   send the shawl and the [b----] skt. as I [---] much love to   all—yrs. affec

ClemmyI shd. be pleased to have some [---] my return & also before   my return

Title: 1846 January 21, New Bedford, to F.R. Cope, Philada.

Dear Friend 
New Bedfor[d] 1 mo 21 1846 –

Your   letters were as duly received as unduly attended to.  Not   however that I did not make search for the subscription   paper. actual[--] mon ami by two reasons one to comply with   your request & another to trump up certain delinquents whose   names were therein appended to certain generous figures   which have not as yet been Transferred to my Pocket Book. --   Troubles in the family have since then as you surmised   interfered with all other matters and hence. -- -- --.  But   if I cant find it. put us down viz. W.H. Hussey Jack do. Ed   Rudman Tom do. S.R. Morgan Ben Barker Job A.T. Eddy. Rob’ B   Howland. Ch. Osborne. Aug. & myself for the whole amot.   –

Warned – I am armed.  But Frank you need a rib.    When I consider the imminent danger – you are in Every   Sunday. of blowing away walking home from Meeting alone. I   wonder at your remaining single.  Let her be somewhat solid.   – an anchor to windward – then no matter how the storm may   rage. mignon you may under [bare] [poles] you know ride out   the gale, rocked in the cradle of the Deep –

But a   fig for your predictions – What satisfies me of thine   felicity is in the 1st place & chiefly. I. am dreadful   pertikler myself. & 2dly (see over the leaf.)some others are so likewise – "man & consequently   woman"

Every creature likes his ease
English   French & Roman
I’ve seen men were hard to please
&   consequently Woman –

Womenkind will have their   way
Even tell you go! man!
I like to hear men say   their say
& consequently woman –

But marriage is a   happy lot
He who doubts is no man
Men in plenty may be   got
& consequently woman

You’re a good boy never   fib
Gamble [----] & so, man!
Go and get yourself a   rib
& consequently woman –

As for me you never   fear
Sure I shant be slow, man!
Get some money – then   – oh dear!
& consequently woman
Write me a systematic letter. --  I abominate this way you   have got into of diplomatic correspondence. Every word of   which you might publish in the newspapers.  Hows   [Con—cervis] my next leisure moment, shall be tak[en] up   with a letter to him.  Give New B. my best respects. whither   I [go] on to Balt or not shortly. is doubtful. as every   thing else is in this “wale”. but if “i” do I shall pop in   to your counting room some fine morning –

Write me   first. about the crops & the weather & business & all that   sort of thing you know. a real interesting sensible sort of   a letter. but – the girls –

with much   regard.
yours’ &c
Charles Taber
F. R. Cope
H & A. Cope & Co
Philada.

Title: N.D., to Henry and Francis

My Dear Henry and Frances

I am now Set down to talk a   little with you, in the first place, Frances how came thee   Poisond I hope it is not bad, I wish the would be more   Carefull & not go where the poisen vines are I was much   pleasd with thy letter, and hope it wont be the last, and   now my dear Henry I address myself to the, I was grattyfy’d   with thy kind rememberance of me in thy Las[s]t letter, with   Desires to see me, be assur’d you can’t Desire more to se me   than I do to see you, but my way seems block’d up at   present, I thank thee for the Picture the sent me, I wish I   could send thee something more than bare thanks, we all   enjoy the blessing of health Except your aunt she continues   in a very poor way, our Cousen Sarah Perot is likewise in a   very poor way your father intends writeing to you, Caroline   will will hardly let me write she wants me to be done she   say’s give my love to Henry and Frances & except a great   deal from your Loving grandmother - Rachel Drinker

Title: 1853 April 4, to Clemmie

April 29,1853

Will thee dear Clemmie accept this   little book as a token that I appreciated thy patient   endeavors to gratify my request; & also as a companion of   thy sorrowful thoughts, who would fain, with the blessing of   God, lead thee to peaceful meditations.--
Especially note   the introduction. Thee will find some passages marked; these   struck me as applicable to thy feelings--But do not feel   compelled to read
because I give; rather seek its counsels, as thee is drawn   by a sense of need; and perhaps thee may find a fountain of   joy which thee has never know yet. But it will only be as a   guide to the everlasting spring of peace which is in Jesus   our Saviour.
I opened my Bible to find a promise for thee   & this was the verse which met my eye. Isa xxxv 4 "Say to   them that are of a fearful heart, be strong, fear not:   behold your God will come with vengeance, even God 
with a recompense; he will come and save you." 
Will thee   not bend a listening ear, and a believing heart to such a   gracious message?
I have added a few thoughts on the last   leaf of the book; and with them wld. give the warm affection   of

Thy Cousin
Wills



----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1867-07-21
Title: 1867 July 21, Laurel House, to Father

Laurel House July 21st/67

My dear Father,
Tom has   written to thee so very lately, that I fear I can hardly   find enough of interest to fill a second letter, & besides I   am almost afraid to write one to go so far, & cost so much;   but perhaps a little Cattskill news would not be unwelcome.    We have been here for several days but owing to the   unkindness of the weather have not been able to accomplish   as much as we could wish – we made one very successful   expedition to Haines’ falls on 6th day morning, we took a   carriage or rather an express-wagon & rode over there, & had   a fine scramble, we went down the stream to the lower falls,   & scrambleddown to the foot, Tom concluded not to go all the way as it   was so rough & hard, & one after another gave out until when   we arrived at the foot there was no one but Harry, Ellie,   Madge & I left, but we were very glad we persevered &   thought ourselves well repaid, you never told us last fall   how beautiful it was.  We did not get home till after they   had gone to dinner so were obliged to go in just as we were   in our mountain dresses, & as we were all prepared concluded   to go under Tom’s guidence to visit Bastion falls   afterwards.  So about 4 we set off prepared to have a very   jolly time, Tom went ahead and cleared the way, & we   followed jumping over the logs & stones which Thomas   declare[d] were not there last fall, & must be the result of   last winters slide;Just as we arrived at the head of the fall, & were   congratulating ourselves on the prospect before us, what   should it do but begin to rain!  At first we thought it   would only be a little shower, & took shelter under the   trees as there were unfortunately no overhanging rocks –   this did very well for a little while, but instead of   stopping the rain got harder & harder, & at last began to   find its way through the trees & onto us – we soon found   ourselves getting very moist, & began to confer on measures   of relief, it was at length concluded as we were already   quite wet, & there was no sign of stopping to start for   home.  At first it seemed to slacked a little & we pushed   bravely on, but it got faster & faster & by the time we   reached the foot of Cauterskillwe were thoroughly drenched & in despair at having to ascend   all those dreadful steps – I wish thee could have seen us as   we came up to the house too tired to run any more dragging   along all dripping & hot, looking as much as possible like   drowned rats.  The gentlemen on the piazza were so polite as   not even to smile, but I’m sure I could not have helped. it.   I don’t think we any of us suffered for it though, & I did   not even feel tired in the evening, this mountain air is so   invigorating.  Yesterday it rained perseveringly & we had to   amuse ourselves as best we could reading, & walking on the   piazza.  The company here is not as congeneal as we could   wish, & we often envy Aunt Annie & Cous. Clem in their   Adirondack society.  One young gentleman regaledus last night with some Scotch songs, but it was very   inferior to Carry Rowland’s performance.  I think Tom told   thee that we have the same room you had last year, & enjoy   it very much, it is so nice having that beautiful view   always before us, I think I enjoy it much more than the map   in front of the Mountain House; it is so constantly   changing, sometimes that distant mountain will be entirely   hid by the clouds, & it is so beautiful to see them coming &   going; we have had no perfectly clear weather since we   arrived, & have become almost discouraged, & the   chamber-maid told me by way of comfort yesterday, that it   sometimes rained strait aheadfor a week, however it really does look like clearing now,   the clouds are drifting away, & there are great patches of   blue-sky.  If it is clear tomorrow we have planned an   expedition to the Plauterkill which I hope will be a   success.  Tom Stokes & Harry had intended starting on a   fishing excursion yesterday but after routing out of their   beds about 4, & eating sandwitches preparatory to starting,   were obliged to give up on account of the rain, & go back to   bed in disgust.  We have only received one letter from home   which reported all well, but by the time this reaches thee   thee will have received more recent news.  All send their   love & wishes for thy welfare wh. means I suppose that they   hope thee is not awfully sick, in which I heartily join,   Thee must notimagin from my description that we are not having a good   time for we are only the rain was a little dampening but   since the sun has come out we feel very lively & up to any   amount of of scrambling.  Write by every steamer & tell us   every thing.
Thy very affectionate
Lily


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Witmer Stone:  1866-1939
Recipient:  Francis R. (Francis Reeve) Cope:  1878-1962
Date: 1896-07-30
Title: 1896 June 30, Philadelphia, to Frank

[Letterhead: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia   -- Logan Square.]

Philadelphia June 30th   1896

Dear Frank

I am greatly pleased to hear   of your success in adding some more birds to your list, and   especially that you keep up your enthusiasm sufficiently to   keep up active search for birds. I know from personal   experience that there is a tendency in summer vacations to   become lazy, but I hope the mountain air is gong to keep you   active. Water-thrushes always, so far as I have heard, breed   among the rootsof upturned stumps. If there are any such in the swamp it   would pay you to examine them carefully. I hope you   preserved the bird to make sure which species it was. I   suppose it was the small billed one though the Louisiana   species does go as far north as the Water Gap. The Snow   birds you need not regret so seriously, the loss of two will   not materially affect them & they will be very interesting   as indicating more clearly the possible relationship of the   Penna bird to the Carolina [Junes]. I should like to see   them, if you can bring them with you in the fall.

And   now I wish to ask a favor If you should go over to theElk Mt. region I wish you could get me a young Snow Bird –   they have speckled breasts – I am very anxious to secure the   first plumages of all our birds & have nearly all now except   those which breed in the mountains.

If you come   across any young Warblers (except Chest-sided & Black &   White) or any young Thrushes or Savanna Sparrows I should be   just as thankful to get one of them.

I don’t think it   is as bad to kill a young bird as an old one during the   breeding seasonShould you get one you could remove the entrails, put in a   little cotton with some carbolic acid (or plaster) & send it   by mail it will carry all right. Don’t put yourself to   trouble however.

I saw Stew & he greatly regrets his   inability to accept your invitation as you have doubtless   heard from him by this time. He is organizing quite an   expedition of Phila & N.Y. botanists to convene at Pocono   Mts on the 4th

I am always glad to hear from you and   will try to keep the bird interests stirred up by writing to   you

With regards to your family I remain sincerely   yours

Witmer Stone

P.S. How does the Guitar   progress? (?)


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Henry W. (Henry Waln) Drinker:  1787-1866
Recipient:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Date: 1817-06-13
Title: 1817 June 13, Stoddartsville, to Thomas P. Cope Esq., Philadelphia

Stoddartsville June the 13th. 1817–
Dear Uncle.
By   William Drinker who pass’d Here on the 9th  I receivd thy   remembrance of the 3d inst–  What Charles Miner has done or   is now about I cannot precisely say not hav[ing] seen Him or   any of his friends since [my] Last
I question the   Establishment of the proposed Bank at Wilkes barre & beleive   also that if it ever does go into Operation it will be by   compromise and by a [di----] of the few offices of [---]   attatched to it–  Humble merit will I presume stand but a   poor chance–
Mr Arndt on whom I depended for [the]   Hemlock Bark Has not yet ground it but I hope He will attend   to it shortly–  if it in any degree succeeds [in] England it   will be Highly important to this Count[r]y as well as   convenient to ship overseas–  I beleive that the mak[ing]   pot & pearl Ash might prove an advantageous thing to us more   than to any other persons [We] owning the nearest Large Body   of suitable timber for the purpose – if it will pay for its   mak[ing] & a reasonable sum for outlay & superintendance it   will answer us as a means of clear[ing] Land –
I am glad   that thy mind is made up for a peep at this quarter of the   world – I think it will be likely to be beneficial to thy   Health as also to Aunts – Some Rough travell[ing] there will   no doubt be – but generaly speak[ing] the Roads are   tolerable to the mouth of Tunkhannock–  Thereare no excelent Taverns on the Route so far as I am   acquainted–  I think the one Here is the Best & likely to be   the most pleasant for the Residence of aunt–  Gentlemen can   be well accomodated at Easton & at Wilkes barre at Mr Whites   in the first nammed place & at Mr Arndts in the second in   Both Houses there is Rather too much noise and Drink[ing] to   be entirely agreeable to Ladies –  Here also we have more   noise than is pleasant–  There be from 15 to 20 of Stoddarts   work[ing] hands quart[ere]d in the House –  
The Road by   Easton is Rather worse than that by Bethlehem & Nazareth & I   think generaly the accommodations are better on this last   Route–  from Nazareth to Hellers at the Wind gap at which   House I have generaly procured tolerable Eating & pretty   clean–  from thence about 17 miles to William Sox’s upon the   top of Pokono – where th[e]y make prety good coffee & give   you what ever they may Have in the House in a tolerably   cleanly stile–  from thence to this place say 12 miles   –
The present is about as pleasant a Time to Travel in   this county as any other Dur[ing] the summer – ere the grain   is cut which will not be Done before the Last of next monthHowever the Weather is now variable and we may expect   occasional Rains, until after Harvest – 
in the Last of   August & to the middle of September is generaly more settled   weather – as to the [Gnats] they Have already come & in the   woods Bite sharply–  This [they] will continue to Do until   September – But out of the woods we do not find them   Troublesome– There are not any curiosities worthy a name   from Philada to this place–  The Habits & manners of the   people on the Route may perhaps afford Something novel – The   scenery also & general Aspect of the County will be new –   [marbly] nature in Her Roughest garb will surround you – you   will have pure Air & pure water & I doubt not to good   [appetites] as to enable you to Encounter much coarser fare   than usual – in the neighbourhood of Easton-Bethlehem &   Nazareth is a lime stone county – & I would have you beware   of the water – it is no doubt wholesome but to persons   [unaccustomed] to it it is often unpleasant in its effects–   if I know when you intend com[ing] up I will endeavor to   join you at Hellers – I have been constantly interupted   since I began writing which must excuse this   scrawl–
affectionaly thy nephew. H.W.Drinker –Stoddartsville 
 12 1/2 
June 14th
Thomas P. Cope   Esq.
Merchant
Philada.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1865-05-00
Title: [1865 May ?], 190 Calvert st, to Mother and sisters

2nd day eve
190 Calvert st

Dear Mother & sisters,   Tired as I am I must write you a few words to night, as I   shall probably be at the sch, in the morn & the mail closes   at 1 P.M. & I thought you’d like to know that we arrived   safely about 5 this aft. & I am installed in my new boarding   house wh. promises to be very nice.  They ladies were   exceedingly kind & welcomed me as if I had been an old   friend  They are so free & easy.  One of them Miss Talbot   came right up in my room & talked to me while I was getting   dressed – & was as kind as possible  They used to know uncle   Jasper & quantities of our friends, so that I begin to feel   quite at home already  It is a large 4story house with a very nice pleasant parlor, & a   comfortable dining room, where we had tea on a little   refreshment table—the 4 school “marms”—as cozy as possible.    They say “thee” & call me by name wh. makes me feel much   less strange
Jesse called a few minutes after we arrived   in his elegant carriage, having been to one of the dipots to   meet us, but we unfortunately had got out at the wrong one;   & very much out of our way.  The ladies seem in very   moderate circumstances only keeping one servant, & a sch. of   near 40 day scholars.   consequently they have not much time   to attend to housekeeping nor much talent in that way I shd.   think.  Their kindness however makes amends.The house is on a very high situation & there is a fine view   of the city fr[m]. my room, wh is in the 2nd story & very   airy & pleasant.  But there is no closet unfortunatley wh.   is remarkably home like & seems to be my fate.  Not a place   to hang a dress, but I have 5 beaureau drawers & can make   out.  So much for the house.  3rd day morn.  We went last   evening to see the sch. & I was most agreeably disappointed   in it in every respect..  The rooms are well ventilated &   airy & no disagreeable odour.  & their state of advancement   is surprising.  There were a few to be sure who reminded me   of Busy—in his attempt to spell girl—but mostly they were   astonishingly quick--& cld. add & subtract like quite   accomplished arithmeticaians.  Quite as fast as I cld.   myself.  They were mostly adults.  In the morningThey are children.
I am to have a class of 30 & am very   glad to find that I shall be in the school with Miss Field,   who is a very pleasant young lady about my own age I shd.   judge, & we can go backwards & forward to gether, & shall be   companionable I hope.  The morning session is frm. 9 till 1   1/2 not 3.  The evening teaching you can take part in or not   as you choose.  So it will not be very laborous & in every   respect, it is going to be I think, much pleasanter than I   had anticipated.  & if you are only satisfied I think I can   be very comfortable & enjoy the work & the change.Love to Cousin Sarah.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Charles Taber:  1822-1887
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1848
Title: 1848 to Francis R. Cope, Philada.

Oh Poesy! what wight of Wretched State
Een at the lowest   bottom of his woe
When griefs surround him or sad toils   await
When cold misfortunes hand doth round him   blow
But calls on thee to aid against the foe?
Come   gentle soother of wan misery’s train
Before the scowling   can away doth go
Come shower thy spirit down on me   again
*For Frank Cope wants a letter – shall he want in   vain!!!!
*Here the Poet alludes to Danae & Jupiter   olympus an ancient buck

So Henricus is dead! dead ere   his prime!
Alas! that he should share the doom of   man!
Who now is left to build the lofty   rhyme?
Although his altitude was but a span
It   [overtopped] his years. = But no man can
Add cubits to   his stature or his days –
Vain task to stop the fateful   cruel hand
That wields the gory scissons. -- Worldy   praise 
High thought – nor noble deed its destined course   delays. –

(Now all that second Paragraph is   gammon
But if you really think it worth the trouble
If   twill not seem like too great love of mammon
I think you   can get quite as much or double
Prime cost – besides –   perhaps – who knows the bubble
Called Fame / which you’ll   keep for commissions
I want the rhino – all besides is   stubble)
By handing it about without omission
‘Mong'st   those who loudest wail that he's gone to Perdition)
I want you to hand it particularly to Miss B. --------.    Send on the amount collected for the benefit of the author   as soon after the funeral as possible.---

But as in   olden time, when-freshly sprung
From the great Maker’s   hand – all Earth was fair
Excelling in its beauty – fresh   & young
When strength & health perfumed with the balmy   air 
And all Earth’s Gifts were far beyond compare   
With what now ‘neath Heaven’s weary blessing   grows
What time the grove Hesperia apples bare
From   out the salt salt wave fair Venus rose
Graceful her   dripping locks she round her did dispose

So from the   Sorrow tearful deep & sad
Which mourns thy memory   departed Shade
While oer the dust which erst thy spirit   clad
And the loved link which bound thee to us made
We   grieve thou coulds’t not Death’s cold hand evade
Who   plucks the brightest flowers – hard to please
[While]   tears fall fast from all that thou shouldst fade
Love   ever radiant though steeped in tears
Love-rosy tints the   clouds – Love sooths the foamy seas
or Love heavenly love   appears
Just as you please

all the while alluding   in an inexpressibly delicate manner to the very peculiar   situation in which Miss B. ----- and I find ourselves since   Harry’s departure  You may show them to the lady.  Present   them as the first fruits. ----
But enough of this nonsense -  If you are heartily tired of   it remember you began it. --  and when my Muse gets well   under weigh – like Addisons there’s no stopping her. -------   Father has been unwell for some time and so much so that a   good part of the business devolves on me – in connection   with some other domestic affairs – putting a very unlooked   for and regrettable veto on my proposed trip to Philada   –
Perhaps another year may bring around the same   expectations which I hope will not be disappointed
Before   that time however I trust to see you on [here] for although   it is not to be presumed that New Bedford alone should   possess sufficient attractions – to be the terminus of your   visit it may serve as a [stepping] stone to some place that   has more ---
Remember me to [Tom] [&] your   friend
Charles Taber
Francis R. Cope
care of H. & A. Cope
Philada.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Witmer Stone:  1866-1939
Recipient:  Francis R. (Francis Reeve) Cope:  1878-1962
Date: 1896-08-03
Title: 1896 August 3, Philadelphia, to Frank

Letterhead: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia   -- Logan Square.]

Philadelphia Aug 3rd.   1896

Dear Frank 

I saw a history of   Susquehanna Co Pa. the other day and in it were a few notes   on birds & mammals contributed I think by a man named   Jennings The notes were sufficient to show that whatever   else Mr. Jennings may be he is not much of an   ornithologist.

He says however that Dr.L. A. Smith of New Milford has a nearly complete collection   of the birds of Susquehanna Co. mounted.

How accurate   this statement may be I cannot say but as I see that New   Milford is not very far from Montrose I thought you might be   able to drive over there and hunt up the Dr. and perhaps he   could give you some valuable notes. At any rate I thought I   had better let you know about him.

I expect to leave   next week for the Catskills

With kind regards to your   family I am sincerely yours

Witmer Stone

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1864-10-09
Title: 1864 October 9, Newport, to Elizabeth S. Cope, Awbury

Newport Oct 9th  1864, 1st day morn

Dear Sister–
I   recieved thy note (for I cannot call it a letter because it   contained so much nonsense) yester-day morning; but I did   not say poo! because I had an idea it was from Rachel or at   least hoped it did not contain nonsense.  I was glad to   recieve such information as thy note contained, & thought it   was a great compliment to be called handsome by sombody,   although I do not think father was much complimented by   having his hair called an iron gray color; unfortunatly I   did not lose my heart with her, although I think I must have   seen her & was very sorry I could not go to meting but my   knee was not equal to it.  I could have found some time to   write to you or thee butI have been very lazy since I have been here.  I delivered   thy message to Father (about Dr Thomas) but fear he has   forgotten about it, so I will remind him of it & now I must   close for I am getting lazy & will tell thee what we are   doing when there is some thing to tell about of more   consequence.  I believe Mother intends writing a   P.S.
Affec thy brother
TP. Cope Jr
P.S.  when I   said you on the first page near the bottom I meat Rachel &   thyself.  TP Cope Jr.

I am sorry there should be any   mistake about Dr. Thomas  I thought I told you, you would   have to send him word when you were ready to begin  You had   better tell him of myabsence from home so that he may understand why he was not   called on before.  So much for that - the burden of my   [----] is “painting.”  It is the burden on my mind & must of   course show itself in words.  Uncle Tom sent me word that he   had expressed a sample of color which Craig has prepared for   our inspection.  I suppose we may get the package tomorrow –   but what troubles me is the delay – Craig said he would have   it all done so we could come back the 20th.  If he has got   to put on two coats after he hears from us I fear he will   not be ready for us.  We are getting tired of this plan &   anxious to know whether there will be any difficulty about   getting intoour house on the 22nd.  Seventh day week - We have to engage   Staterooms two weeks before to get good ones & I intend   tomorrow to engage them for 6th day the 21st & if you find   the house cannot be got ready by that time you will please   send us word at once so that we can disengage the rooms.    Perhaps if Craig can not get all done & dry he can have the   kitchen & back passages finished & if the last coat is on   the parlors &c we might come in before it is dry–  I feel   sorry to have filled up Toms sheet with nothing but such a   message – try to do better next time.  It has been blowing   strong from the N.W. all day & is cold as charity Alf &   Hazen went to meeting with me in the morning & your   [br]other in the afternoon but its dull work here either   at the larger or smaller body Yankee self conceit shows   nowhere more. 


Elizabeth S. Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan S. Reeve:  1833-1866
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1865-03-15
Title: 1865 March 15, Locust Shade, to Annie

Locust Shade. 3. 15. 1865

My dear Annie

Does   thee think I have quite forgotten thee and all thy kindness,   & my delightful visit to you? That I have been such a long   while without writing to thee. Indeed I have not, & never   shall I hope- but my wonderings [early] terminated last 7th   day & since then I have had a very bad cold, which thee   knows makes one lazy. - I have wanted to know how thee   faired after our parting on the hill. My walk was brisk & I   did not keep Maggie’s [---] waiting long, and did not feel   tired. I fear thee did not fare so well. Our visit to our   Wilmington friends was very pleasant.
Richie, thee knows, joined me in that. Tho he was not well   enough to enjoy it thoroughly. Lizzie seems very happy & we   hope is learning something, - at least she gets very good   numbers. - The roads were so bad it was not easy to get   about & my journey to Faulkland was a [arduous] one. but the   pleasure of cheering cousin Mary a little & hearing Dr   [Fell]  talk,- a great deal more than repaid me for it.-   

When I returned to Phila John & Sallie Hilles & I   went over to see Charles Rhoads. It was very touching to see   those five little motherless children. Charles looks tens   years older and much broken down.- His sister was very   pleasant- I never knew her before. They are certainly much   favored in having such kind caretakers & hardly feel their   loss as they will after awhile. - I often think of   what

thee said to me in the car after our visit to Clemmy. dear   Annie, with loving sympathy. Deserving too that I may fully   appreciate the blessing of a mothers love while mine is   still spared to me. - I hear Clemmy is going, or has gone to   Baltimore, to teach the Freedmen. What do you think of it?   It seems to me that anything that would give interesting   employment to both mind and body, would be good for her. Tho   I’m right sorry to have her go so far away. - Thee will miss   her too. - Do write some & tell me all about her plans. -   Lilly Collins seems to like her situation very well. I found   a letter from her awaiting me on my return.- She gives an   amusing account of a colored meeting which she attended, - a   real happy [----------] affair.- Lilly enjoys the variety I   should think & it keeps her from being homesick.- Cousin   Elizalooked & seemed more cheerful when I called - but she   certainly is very weak.-

I suppose the preparations   for the wedding are proceeding briskly- Does the go? I quite   want to hear about it. - Lizzie Brown’s sister is to be   married tomorrow & I hope the threatened storm will not come   to spoil all their nice dresses.- Lizzie’s friend Edward   Balderson stayed with us last night. He is to wait on a   young lady from Jersey -  so I fear the love affair between   him & Lizzie is all over - but time will make manifest. Has   thee seen anything more of the interesting students- Till   thy brother Thomas his opinion of the [-----] position of   Carpenters is very family impressed upon my mind.- It makes   me smile now to think how frightened I was, I deserved   rebuke too.- Do please write to me soon dear Annie.- My love   please to thy father & sister E & with a large share of the   same for thyself I am thy sincerely attached & grateful   friend
 
S. S. Reeve

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Rachel Drinker
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1805-09-18
Title: 1805 September 18 to Henry Cope, Wesston

9 mo 18 1805

Dear Henry

I am Still in town,   and was present when thy letter and [---] came, It gave me   great pleasure to see thy improvement in writing, and to   find that you ar so well Contented, and I must note the   acceptance of thy acepable letter, and present; I am   desireous of Comeing to See my Dear Boys if I can, If I Cant   I must wait with patience your coming; I have been a   thinking what a favour it is to have the Company of T-S with   you so long; as I beleive he has the good of the Youth much   at Heart I hope you will proffet by it, I am going to   farehill and cant’ tell when I shall be in town again, I   should be glad to see the [---] fill’d, but, I shan’t have   time, I expect to be Call’d for Every minute 

I   Continue to be your Affectinate Grandmother Rachel Drinker9 mo 18th 1805
 Henry Cope 
 Wesston

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Eleanor Cope Tyson:  1807-1847
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1821-02-22
Title: 1821, February 22, Trenton, to Brother

Thee will reccollect my dear Brother that when I last saw thee I promised to write to thee in a short time.  Thee will conclude that my short time is a pretty long one but I have been pretty constantly employed since I returned and have not felt in a very letter-writing humour.  I wrote to Caroline about 3 weeks ago and have not yet received an answer I hope thee will prove a better correspondent than she or I shall have but little encouragement to write.  I have begun tolearn french and I like it very much as far as I have gone.  Sister Rachel told me when I was at [Home] that Hannah Bolton had returned from Weston I should be obliged if thee would give my love to her when thee sees her.  Thee desired to know what I was studying.  I am studying, Geography, Grammar, history and spelling and at present how to write a letter worth reading.  Tell sister Rachel I should be pleased to receive a letter from her though I am not willing to risk writing just again but if she will write to me I will endeavour to be more punctual in the answering of her's than I have been of thine.
When thee writes please to tell me how mother is for I believe all ourfamily have forgotten me and therefore I need not look for a letter from any of them.  Tell Alfred I will answer his letter as soon as I possibly can.  mean-while he must wait patiently.  I must now stop for the present as school is just going to close.
Thee desires to know how the swelling is behind my ear I believe it is much the same as it was when I left home.
Please to give my love to Father, Mother, Grandmother, Rachel, William, Caroline & Alfred and accept a large share for thyself & little Mary From thy affectate sister 
Elenor

Trenton 2nd mo: 22nd 1821.Henry Cope
No 36 north 4th st
Philada

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Eleanor Cope Tyson:  1807-1847
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope:  1794-1863
Date: 1842-08-17
Title: 1842 August 17, Schooley's Mountain, to Rachel Reeve Cope

Schooley's Mountain Aug 17. '42 

Dear Sister Rachel

We had so uneventful a journey, I have been so quiet since our arrival here, that I have scarcely material for a letter. Travellers are expected, I believe, to be particularly entertaining. Now, there is no time when I feel less so. Fatigue, change of air & diet, always for a time, affect my health unfavorably; and then, the turmoil & bustle scatter the little wits I possess. So that, from home, I am an especially stupid correspondent. Still, as you were kind enough to wish to hear from us, and as we exchanged promises about writing, I will not wait for any thing worth saying, --as I may not have it at all, thee knows; -- and my delay may occasion me the disappointment of not receiving here, the speedy return letter from Fourth St, which is to be my reward.-- 

We had quite a pleasant time so far as Trenton, for our first day's exploit. We arrived there about half past five o'clock; and George with our baggage, via. steam-boat and rail-road, very shortly after. In the evening, we made a little visit to Elizabeth Gummere, who lives near the Hotel. They have a fine, large house, in a pleasant part of town, & express themselves, the young folks, most emphatically, pleased with their change of residence. As we were in the immediate neighborhood, we went with Eliza..th, to spend a few minutes with our old friend, Judge Gordon's wife. She looks and seems just the same asI recollect her in the days of my childhood. So it appears that in this bustling life, there are some not easily jostled out of their way. We found the Judge, some years ago, busy with his attempts to sell his map of New Jersey. It still seems a most interesting theme to him; & if we come this way six years hence, I dare say he will even then be ready to speak of its merits & to state that his stock is not yet exhausted.-- Fifth day night brought us within twelve miles of the mountain, and the next day at noon, we reached the end of our journey--and over such roads! I was thinking, perpetually, of the children's song "Here we go up, up, up, & here we go down, down" &c &c. To adopt little Cary's favourite style, the rain had washed such gulleys in the roads, & the stones were so bare, & there were so many of them!-- 
The first two days after we got here, we had three or four showers per day. By way of consolation, we were told, this was a favorable specimen of their weather this season. For the previous ten days, it had rained all the time. "Recorder [Vaux?]" who is here, calls it temperance weather. I wonder if [Espy] is a tee-totaller.--We were beguiled , when we first came, into taking a room in "the cottage" Its superior dimensions, privacy &c were warmly insisted upon. And as we like plenty of room, and don't like much noise, we thought it quite a prize. The sun shone so flatteringly upon the [compact?], that we never thought of the inconvenience of being drenched in going to our meals, or having them drenched  in being brought to us. As we have now had ample opportunity of trying it both ways, and don't relisheither, we begin to murmer. Coming in search of Health, we fancy too, that a sleeping apartment on the ground floor is not exactly the place to meet with her ladyship, this damp summer. We have some of the inconvenient "[Fine-ear]" family, moreover, next us, who have been very near getting us into a scrape. A grand-daughter of John Jacob Astor has been stoping with a Mr Kane, from Albany, and, under what her friends consider, very aggravated circumstances. They came here to spend the Honey moon, & unfortunately, were placed in the room adjoining ours. Job related to me, one day, in a confidential tone of voice, the history of their flight, as just detailed to him by Governor Coles. This they contrived to over-hear, & being displeased thereat, they imagined a series of questions and answers,-- Job & I being the speakers,-- about the pedigree, personal consequence &c of many of the boarders, which they carried directly to the individuals about whom we were said to be so curious, & from there, they came immediately back to us. Happily, they fixed upon people whom we knew perfectly well, & thus the absurdity of our asking who they were whom we had known all our lives, was sufficiently apparent, & created only a little merriment. But we were somewhat annoyed until we discovered the full extent of this eaves-dropping. Thus, the storms without, & the treachery within doors, have given us a thorough distaste to this part of the premises. Besides, there is more of a crowd than we wished to get into, & if the company does not diminish, we shall want to try some quieter region. Direct, here, however, as we shall leave instructions for letters tobe sent to us. -- We have had it very warm & almost clear now for a couple of days, & have been enjoying it by driving about. The country is sufficiently beautiful to render the slow climbing of hills by no means a tedious affair. The roads are kept in quite tolerable order, & occasionally, we come to a level piece of ground where we trot away quite merrily. People tell us wonders about the flush gained and the disease lost among these hills. I hope our cases may add to a reputation, so richly earned, according to all accounts. -- I should write to Caroline, but I am not a very disinterested letter writer; sowing only where I may hope to reap, --& I fear she is scarcely yet at home.--I should like much, to know how you all are, where you now are, & where you are to be for he next few weeks.--Does thee know where Father & Mother are & when Cara returns? When do you go to Susquehanna [---] & how are Anne's eyes? Tell her I have not seen a single cat since I left home; but we have plenty of little ducks & chickens, the feeding of which is a daily source of amusement to the children. I heard them complaining this morning, that the older ladies were interfering with this, their peculiar privilege. Indeed the belles and beaux seem to find it quite as entertaining as they--remember, my dear R, that thee is bound to procure me a letter, in some way. Either from under thy own hand, (how is it?) or from one of those to whom thee can say "do this & he doeth it." If thee is not well enough, I shall calculate a little, too, on the affection & kindness of my nephews & niece. I do not know whether it will be any thing of a bribe-but I always make it a point to answer letters addressed to me--some time or other. If I should not


Henry Cope Esq.
For R. R. Cope.
N. 4th St.
Philadaget time during the excursion, I shall recollect my indebtedness on a future occasion.--Our love to brother H, to your segment of our family circle, & to all othermembers of it who are in the city. The carriage is waiting for me. Fare thee well! in haste, but very affectionately, sayeth thy sister 
E. C. Tyson:----We have determined to leave here on Second day. Will you not so arrange it as that a letter may reach us before then? It will gratify us very much.---

Title: 1806 March, to Henry

[3. 1806]
Dear Henry
I receiv'd thy letter & was glad to here that you were well, I still enjoy that Blessing.
Your cousin J D T is in a poor state of helth, we red thy letter to him, he is very willing the should have the Book, a man of the name of Willcox Drank Tea with as last evening liv's about 2 miles from Weston, he gave thy Uncle & my self [pressing] invitation to come and spend a few days at his house, thy Uncle say'd hed try if he could make it convenient to take me to Weston as I was desirous of going there, and then we would go and se him. your cousin H D sent a very sattisfactory Letter from the Capes, in which he sends his love to you with desir's for your happiness here and hereafter I conclude your loving Grand Mother.
Rachel Drinker

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Brown Cope Stork:  b. 1862
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1874-08-10
Title: 1874 August 10, Awbury, to Lilly

Awbury
Aug 9th 1874

Dear Lily
I got thy very nice note day before yesterday and was very glad to get it. Yesterday was very rain and about 7 o-clock  it just poured. Haines and High Street & Locust Avenue bridges were all washed away and a man and a and a boy were going along Locust avenue after darkand the lamps were not lit because of the rain I suppose and the both of them were drowned. Uncle Harry & Aunt Mary and Anna are staying over here and we are having a splendid time. Brother Jonnie & Chellie & Hazen came home yesterday to dinner and we think they look better except Hazen but we are going to sent him down to Atlantic City tomorrow to get fat. Cousin Clemmie came over to meeting today and went to Uncle Tom's to dinner. I am going to wait till Alexis is smart enough to writeto me before I write to him. As I have nothing more to say I will close. Hoping thee will excuse this very great scribble I remain they very affectionate sister
Anna B. Cope
P.S. Please give my love to the rest of the party remaining.My dear [Lulu] - As A.B.C. has left a blank page I concluded to fill it, having had it on my mind to send you a word of greeting all day & not having accomplished it. J. & I are at father's this evening ['leaving"], & are now sitting in the library with quite a party. Uncle H & aunt Mary (who with Anna are staying here) cousin Clem, aunt Lizzie, Mary, Henry, & "the family". Father's [----] have yielded to- I don't know what- but he seems to have recovered pretty much & goes to meeting, town[--] as usual. Tom is not quite up to par, but seems in excellent spirits. J& I are about as when we left you I was somewhat tired with the journey but feel pretty much rested now. Last night we had a regular pelting rain, so that the country was flooded in parts, and the bridgesswept away our Armalt St. & High a man & a boy were drowned crossing at Armalt St. Tom has recovered his clothes from the Custom House & is now wearing one of the suits. Father says before he goes to [-] S. Springs, he's rather go to sea & be sick so there is not much hope of his joining you. J says to give you his love & tell you he's sorry for you. Love to all. 
R. C. E.Elizabeth S. Cope
Old Sweet Springs 
Monroe Co.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Francis Cope:  1794-1816
Recipient:  Rachel Drinker
Date: 1806-08-05
Title: 1806 August 5, to Grandmother, Philadelphia

Weston 8th mo. 5th 1806


Dear Grandmother
I have taken this opportunity to inform thee that we are well and have had a pleasant time of it since we left you. I should like to hear from you for we have not had a letter since we have been back.  I would wish to know if anything is the matter as Henry has written several times I beleive. We have had apples handed out several times and once we had 5 a-piece and I expect we shall have the liberty of the peach orchard when the peaches are ripe. I would like to know if Arthur and Henry intend to go out to sea again and if they do where they will go to. Thou must write to us as soon as thou canst either third fifth or seventh days will do. Please to remember me to all your an our families.

From thy loveing grandson.
Francis Cope.8 mo. 5th 1806
Rachel Drinker
Care of John Thomas
No. 19 North Second Street
Philadelphia

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Rachel Drinker

Title: 1808 January 8, to Henry

1 mo. 8 1808

Dear Henry

 I was yesterday at your house where thy Mother handed me a letter from thee.  I find thee expects me to write to thee in answer to thy question about Williams writeing to you.  I answer yes Cousin Lydea stays with thy Mother, and Susquehannah is arrived, the Marchants seems pretty quiet about the Embargo.  They don't expect it will continue long.  I often think of thee with strong desire for thy wellfare.  I hope thy study about Learning & wanting to know a great Deal about Causes and Effects won't occupy so much of thy mind as to have no leasure to make ready, & be prepared for a better inheratence that will be lasting and perminent, as all things here are uncertain.  I have been thinking about my Son Henry when about thy age he was very anxious about Learning & knowing the cause of this or that.  He Thursted after Knowledge.  I was setting where he was at work brushing Hats.  He put down his work and took up the pen and wrote down his thoughts as they [----] in his mind.  I got the paper from him with reluctance on his part.I was much pleas'd to find his mind was so well occupied.  I remember the lines & thought it would not hurt thee at least the poetry is not elegant but the desire was commendable.
Let not vain Learning lead my steps aside
 Be not my mind be puff't up with empty pride
 The Worm that seems by night with fire to glow
 In vain to light his torch a man may blow
 But O thou source of wisdom by my guide
In vertues paths direct me to Abide 
Teach me to know thee that I Bless may be
And with thy Saints share Immortality.
Perhaps this may be the last letter thee will have from me.  My love is to Frances. I could not write to him as I expect we shall have him with us befor long, and in the Spring I hope if I should live so long I shall see thee.  With much love and affection I remain thy grandmother>br>Rachel DrinkerJames Sherwood was the candidate.  We are all in health.  I hope this will find you in the same.  Did thee know that Ellinor was out at [-----] She grows finely.1 mo 8th 1808
Henry Cope at Weston

[ Extract from "An act prescribing the mode of assessments for special improvements and providing for the collection thereof," approved August 10, 1871]
"SEC 3. And be it further enacted, That if any person or persons notified as aforesaid, shall neglect or refuse to pay the amount assessed against his or their property, as aforesaid, after the expiration of thirty days, the said Board of Public Works shall immediately thereafter issue certificates of indebtedness against the property assessed, as aforesaid, which certificates shall bear interest until paid at the rate of ten per centum per annum; and until paid the assessment and certificate shall remain, and be a lien upon the property on, or against which they shall have been issued; and if the said assessment shall not be paid within one year the said Board shall, upon the application of the holder of the certificate of indebtedness, proceed to sell the property against which the assessment and the certificate exists, or so  much thereof as may be necessary to pay said assessment, such sales to be first duly advertised daily, for three successive weeks, in the regular issue of some newspaper published in the District of Columbia, and to be made by said Board, at public auction to the highest bidder; and a deed shall be given, by the Governor, countersigned by the Secretary of the District of Columbia, which deed shall be deemed and held to be a good and perfect title to any property bought as any such sale hereby authorized: Provided, That the owner of such real estate shall have the right to redeem the property so sold, by paying the amount of the purchase money, and twenty per centum (per annum) thereon, within two years from the date of sale."
The provisions of the law will be carried out unless complied with

George W. Beall,
Supt. of Assessments

N.S. - If this property no longer belongs to you, please direct this circular to the present owner, or return it to this office with the name of the present owner.
Payments to be made at this office.   Office hours from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m.
Persons having claims for old material will file them with the Board, who will value the same, and pay the valuation as other bills for material are paid.

Jan 19th

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope) Haines:  1819-1890
Recipient:  Eleanor Cope Tyson:  1807-1847
Date: 1819-10-09
Title: 1819 October 9, Philadelphia, to Ellen

I have just recieved my dear Ellens Letter of 5th addess'd to me; and am much more pleased with the stile in which it is written, than I was with the one that preceded it, address'd to thy Sister.  The latter done no credit either to thy heart or judgement.  Thy Father condemned it in to-to, as the sauciest little girls Letter he thought he had ever seen; & thou knowest he is not very rigid; or as some would say, not at all particular or precise; so when he is offended thou mayest conclude thy improprieties must be very striking indeed.  My Daughter should ever recollect that when she asks a favor, it should not be in the high tone of a demand: it should not be claimed as a Right, which if not immediately complied with is to be forthwith resented as an injury; but when she wishes for attentions, her wishes should be modestly insinuated, not as tho' she believed them due to her merit, on account of her great worth & services for which she expected extraordinary returns; but as tho her Affection prompted her to desire them, at the same time that she was conscious she could do & had done but little, for her friends; while their time & thought, & industry was often exerted in providing for her Wants, & promoting her Welfare.  This would lead her to be content with such portions as they could conveniently bestow, & grateful when she recieved them: she would dwell upon every instance of their kindness & cherish the remembrance of it, as an evidence of love for which she had never, as yet, had the power to render an equivalent, & she would hasten to qualify herself to become useful to them, in her turn, especially to her Mother, who, if she lives, must shortly be overtaken by Age & its attendant infirmities.  Then the kind offices, the endearments & domestic services of a dutiful affectionate Daughter, are an invaluable treasure.  These considerations, when once embraced, cannot fail to sink deep in the heart of sensibility" & will, if cherished, bring forth those substantial [-------] of Virtue in my beloved daughter, which my heartincessantly longs for.  After all my dear Ellen, I still flatter myself, that in regard to the said saucy letter the fault lays more in the manner & language, than the heart that dictated it:  I am by no means displeased that thou should'st prize our love & cover the marks of it; & am in hopes that the fear, the dread, & horror of being hated (so earnestly express'd & often repeated) will operate to induce thee to be best calculated to win back affection, even if it has fled.  But on this subject I need not enlarge.  Thou knowest well what my desires for thee are.  Thou hast only to look back & reflect on my frequent labors of love, & painful anxieties on thy account (lest thou should not be what my heart craves,) and it will be enough: - yet there is one still remains untouch'd, on which I feel in duty bound to refresh thy memory.  I mean the observance of respect to thy Teachers & superintendants; absolute & complete perfection is seldom found among Mortals; as least it takes (in most of us) nearly a whole Life to attain it: do not therefore indulge a disposition in thyself, neither take part with any who do so, to make exceptions or look out for faults in those who have so great a weight of Care & responsibility upon them; but rather turn thy attention to thy own deficiencies & need of improvement.  If their patience & sweetness is not uniform, recollect that thy own, if in their situation, would probably come far short of what is expected , remember that it is for the sake of order, & for thy own, or the general good.  By forgetfulness or ignorance of these truths, Children often display the weakness of their understandings, their excess of selfish feeling, & total want of feeling for others.  It is never too early to begin to do good, & few little girls, who were resolved to make a firm stand against these errors: but it must begin at one, & how proud should I be, would but my Ellen resolve to be that one what a happiness would it be to know that she had been the instrument of giving a new tone of feeling & action to the whole of the little community of which she is a Member - a tone so correct & beautiful too, as to excite general approbation!on the contrary, what a pain to find her banded with a company not only so childish, but so vulgar, so void of all true taste ; so void of all gentility, refinement & delicacy - so completely low, as to speak of "throwing old shoes &c" - Indeed I am almost ashamed to write it, or think of it.  Those who desire respect or attention for themselves - who expect ever to be esteemed as gentlewomen, should have more regard to propriety & true dignity of character.

Thy copy of Verses is very pretty, & if they express thy own thoughts & feelings, very acceptable ; except the last stanza, which represents a forlorn destitute state, not at all applicable to thy situation.  As to thy request about a jingling Letter, I must inform thee that such music is not always at my finger ends - & for thyself I would much rather thou would'st improve in good prose-writing , before any attempt at poetry is made - unless indeed it should come of itself without such "hard striving".
It was singular I think that thou should'st dream of thy Grandmother Cope never having seen her - but I have no doubt the inscription on white, which thou could'st not read is indeed of thy admirable Brother.  For him was exemplified all that gentleness & delicacy of character, which I so warmly recommend to my Ellen.  In whatever School or family he was placed his behaviour, & his memory now, that he has left the World & all us, [--] less pure inhabitants to mingle in the Society of angelic Spirits; & his watery Urn has been plentifully bedew'd with those tears of sadness which mingled, as it were with the waves that overwhelmed him; now, henceforth & forever, will the remembrance of him be precious; yea, sweeter than a garden of Roses after the Summer.

I expect thy Grandmother D-r every minute from Burlington-- Thy various messages have mostly been delivered, & all desire their love in return - (Mariam in particular) - thy  Brother Henry cannot recollect about M.G.'s Letter: but if he had the charge of it I dare answer for his punctuality.  If he does not often send his love in form, he loves thee none the less.  I believe he has hope of thee, for he sometimes comforts me by saying he thinks thy faults are much like his own were at thy age; only, his were in thought, for he was affraid to shew them because he knew they were not allowed: indeed he did not dare to let them be seen, lest he should give offence: for he loved his parents tenderly, & could not bear to give them pain; & I have heard him say when a Boy, on seeing others misbehave - get into disgrace - & excite disgust, - I am glad my parents never suffered me to get into such habits.  Now there is this difference between you, supposing you both to have been under the same temptations to evil in your childhood - that all thy virtue will be voluntary, & therefore more meritorious - that is, it will originate in a love of goodness, & desire to attain it, in thy own breast, & for its own sake - whereas he was assisted in his endeavours by the Authority of his parents, & the divine blessing superadded to both; and thou hast beenleft more to thyself: at least in thy education, persuasion has been used more than compulsion.  Let me entreat thee therefore my Daughter, not to dissapoint thy Father; when belief has been so sanguine that his Daughters could be won to Virtue thro' the medium of the Understanding, by the force of Reason & good counsel; yet tho I entreat thee, I know - & I am in duty bound to tell thee so - I know, that without earnest & frequent intercession, with thy Saviour, in true humility of heart, accompanied by love of his divine perfections, & fear of offending him - in short, without his aid & blessing, thou can'st do nothing:  As he said himself - "Without me of yourselves, ye can do nothing": - So, tho' it is possible to conform to outward rules of good behaviour, at times, & for a time, (which is better than being always bad) yet to become establish'd to be immovable in virtuous intention, to be steadfast in resisting every temptation to evil, is impossible without him:  for this cause is he stiled a Saviour, a Redeemer from the bondage of Sin; and we are assured by a revelation from God "that there is no name given under Heaven or amongst men, whereby they can be saved, but by the name of Jesus" - How great then is his goodness & how much do we owe him who tho' he needs nothing from us, has given his Life for us in the body of flesh be assumed; & ever stands, as it were knocking at our hearts by his gentle checks & intimations wooing us to good - meeting & strengthening our feeble desires after it - & all for the sake of our eternal happiness!

Well my dears, thou wilt perhaps think, if I have not written thee many Letters, I am making up for it in the length of this: and not to tire thee quite out I will now conclude
Thy truly loving mother
Mary Cope
P.S. Mother is not come; but we hear is coming the last of next Week.  Thy Capes are done, I was pleased with thy proposition to make them thyself, as a mark of industry; but would rather thee would make the shirt to learn to darn neatly.  We have had so much company (not many at a time, but almost constantly somebody) - & have had so much to do since we opened the house, that we have been pinched for time to do all.  Louisa, too, having a gathering on her hand could not work, & did not come home when we expected her.  She is not come yet.  Does thee know her?  She is Uncle Israels - Jem's sister, & our Joseph's Cousin, & my Cook.
Philada. 10 mo 9. 1819.

Recipient:  Annette Cope:  1843-1916
Date: 1865-03-27
Title: 1865 March 27 to My dearest children

Second day morn  3. 27.

My dearest children
I have   just come home from school & found yr. letter on the card   plate in the entry, wh. is where they always put them, so we   can be refreshed by the sight the moment we get in, & I was   refreshed I assure you.  Miss Field gets a great many & I   began to feel as if it was quite time for me to be having my   turn too.  You must remember that I never was befor so   entirely among strangers. & that your letters now will be my   best substitutes for home, as I shall depend on them greatly   I tried to write yesterday but did not make out much.  It   was my first 1st day in Baltimore.  Do you remember last 1st   day, when [were] were walking on the piazza & wondering   whether I shd. be here?  I did not much think I shd. then   but it seems I am.  Went to meeting yesterday morn. wh. I   quite enjoyed.  The only faces that I had ever seen before   were Deborah Thomas, Margy Coale & Tammie Miller.  I was   introduced to lots of others who were all very kind, & said   they were coming to see me.  There was a frd. named Elicott   & her two sisters who I think said they knew Mother.  We had   a sermon [fmr.] Deba  Thomas, the Dr, & one or two others.    After meeting in the aftnoon I set out to take a walk & was   joined by a young lady named Mary Elicott & & Jesse, who   took me a beautiful walk out to whats called theReservoir, where there is a fountain and a splendid view of   green hills & also of the distant waters of the bay, as well   as of parts of the city.  & yet it was not a walk of more   than a mile I shd. think
Baltimore is certainly a   beautiful place & I never realized before so fully what an   advantage what an advantage a hilly city possesses over a   flat one.  It quite throws Philada into the shade as far as   beauty is concerned.  There is such a refreshing variety in   the style of the houses, & other [buildings] & the hills   show them off to great advantage.  Charles St. seems to be   one of the most aristocratic in wh. the monument is   situated, a very beautiful column of white marble, 170 ft   high wh. as it stands upon a hill serves as a land mark for   a long distance round.  as you ascend the street with the   monument towering high above you the stars & stripes   floating over it & the city as you catch glimpses of it at   certain points apparently beneath you, the effect is very   imposing.  I think Phila. wld. strike one as flat after   this.  It has its advantages tho’.
Jesse has not come to   take us any rides yet.  tho he has promised to.  They say he   is very attentive to a certain – young lady here so we shall   not be so likely to derive as much benefit.  [---]. He has   been very polite so far.  & the ladies of the house are   continually laying plans for our entertainment wh. is   exceedingly kind in them.  I really feel more at home here   than I wd with some relations!Miss Talbot who is the housekeeper is one of the easy   talkative kind & makes me think a little of Mary Sayne.    Only far Superior.  they are exceedingly informal & get up &   wait on table & clear the things away in what thee, Nat,   wld. call a very shocking manner, but they are perfect   ladies for all – hospitable & fond of society, & they seem   to have a great many pleasant frds.  Their one girl is not   the most efficient cook in the world but I have such a good   appetite that I get along very well, – I feel most as hungry   as when I get home frm. school as I remember I used to when   I was a scholar.  We have breakfast about 7 1/2 go to sch.   about 8 1/4.  it is only 10 min. walk — get home about 1.   pretty tired with the 4 hrs. standing & ready to lie down   till dinner time at 2 1/2.  After dinner we get dressed & go   out or see company.  We most always have one or two callers.   at 7 again we have tea & then get our work and sit in the   parlor, & wonder who is coming when the bell rings.  Miss   Field I like exceedingly.  She is a Presbyterian & a very   superior girl I shd. think so that in the matter of   companionship I need to have had fewer fears and   trepidations than I had
The school duties are not long   but pretty arduous while they last.  We have to stand nearly   all the time.  At least the model teachers do, but we   inferiors take the liberty of popping downoccasionally, but it is at the risk of [good] order for   there are so many in the room that unless you stand up to   it, & keep your eye on all 30 or 40 at once they are very   apt to get wrong in the back seats.  One of the first points   is to get [them] disciplined.  Mr Waterman the principal –   drills his class just as you wld. soldiers makes them fold   their arms put out one foot & finally stand up just as a   general wld. his troops, & when school is dismissed they   file out in quite an imposing manner.  That is to teach them   obedience I suppose, wh. is a great point gained.  They also   teach them a kind of gymnastic exercises by way of   recreation. as they have no place to play & consequently no   regular recess or almost none.  Mine is the next to the   smallest class. & only studys reading & spelling in words of   4 or 5 letters wh. is not very interesting.  I have’nt   discovered that there are any specially smart or Topsy like   ones among them.  We dont stop to talk or get acquainted   much but just keep them doing something or other the whole   time.  Upon the whole I enjoy the effect of the work very   much. & outside of that it is all very pleasant.
Jesse   has just called in a splendid barouche to ask for Miss F or   I to ride.  As I had’nt finished my letter & she had’nt been   out for sev. days I persuaded her to go.  Yesterday was the   first pleasant one we have had. since I have been here.  I   was so sorry I took my purple dress out.  It is just what I   want this cool weather for afternoons.  I want twice as many   clothes here as at home.  Caroline dont thee want to be   benevolent and cut me out a pair of those round cuffs like   thee made me for undersleeves.  Thee can work the button   holes, & have them starched & ironed.  I have a pair of   sleevesthat I can sew them on.  I wish if you shd. have any   opportunity you wld. send me my old blk silk body wh. hangs   in the back room closet.  Tammy Miller is going to P   tomorrow & out to Mary Morris’ so I told her to tell you   that she saw the school “mam”  Give my love to Cousin Frank   & Mary  Tell Cousin Mary I had the pleasure of seeing her   mother & I think her father yesterday.  Give my love to   Cous. Sarah & to Tom & Harry & to all Aunt Carolines & any   other enquiring frds.
I have written you a lengthy   epistle I hope there’ll be an exception in favor of mistakes   & bad writing as I have written lying on my back  I was so   very tired this morning that I was too lazy to sit up.  I do   not get much time to [sun] as my room is too cold to sit in   & they do not seem to bring their sewing into the parlor   much.  With much love

Your affec
Sister C

I   am going to send you a drawing of my house when I get time   so you can imagine how things are a little better.  I hope   Edgar will get the drafting business all settled,   satisfactorily
