Title: 1865 May 7, to Mother &c.

[1865]

First day eve 5/7

Dear Mother   &c

Altho’ it is after 10 o’ck I want to just drop you   a line to tell you to look out for a call from a young   gentleman this week.  Jesse sent me word to day that he was   going [on] himself to P & out to Mary Yarnalls & that he wd.   give you a call & bring or take anything I wanted so here is   a chance again for the silk skt. only I wld nt like to ask   him to bring it, as I think he only offered out of   politeness & will probably take nothing with him but a   valise & as mine is a plain silk & wd. not bear rumpling, I   guess it had better not be sent altho’ I told him I shd. be   obliged to him to bring a small package.  If thee Mother cd.   sendme thy old light silk skt. (wh. I believe thee offered) it   wld. do as well to wear with white bodies, & cld be put in   smaller space.  But I really wd not like to ask Jesse to   bring it, for he is so polite that he wd. say it was   convenient whether it was or not.  If however you cd. manage   to get up a sack or shawl that wd. do for sch. (wh. subject   I mentioned in my last letter) I shd. be very glad to have   it.  Jesse returns on 5th day,--so his call will be sometime   between this & then, He proposed that I shd. go with him &   pay a short visit, wh. I declined of course.  His dinner   party did’nt come off last week as we expected, but probably   will next.  Tell C & A that at a tea party a few eve since   at frd. Janney I met their old sch. mate Josy Hoag  She   asked after them & quite amused me by saying that she had   often heard of [---] “Sister Clemmy.”  She’s a sort of bride   having married a person by the name of Hopkins.  She seemed   to be more interested in her husband than anything..  Tell   Edgar I was escorted home by a youth named Joe Hopkins who   asked me if I was any relation to Edgar Cope an old school   mate of his--I said yes & asked what kind of a young man he   was--”a very clever fellow he said but very lazy”, in wh.   lattercharacteristic he said they greatly resembled each other    Mister H. is what you’d call a rather fast young man I shd.   think, a variety wh. I think a good many of the young men   here belong to.

On 6th day eve took tea at Thos.   Matthews about 5 m. in the country.  We met there E. Smith   of West Chester.  An Aunt of the Rileys & sister of Rhoda’s.   She is making a visit to these frds. & is a very pleasant   person  A great many Phila’s seem to [stray] down this way.    Emma Parry & some of the Perots are here now I believe.  The   Coales told me to day that Cous. Mary was talking of coming.   Margy amuses me very much by saying she does hope she’ll see   a good deal of me when she is in P this summer she does not   seem to think that in B it is [deemed] as I have never been   invited there.

Date: 1852-07-12
Title: 1852 July 12, Woodbourne, to Ruthanna Cope

Woodbourne 7th mo 12th 1852

Dear Annie,

This is the first sheet of that ream of paper, but for fear thee should be appalled with the anticipation of having the whole of it filled up to thy account, I am going to tell thee in the first place that I ai'nt going to be quite so unconscionable tho' I wont promise how I far I shall short of it.  I thought maybe you would like to know something about my gettings along on my journey, so I will begin at Pottstown up to which place you are informed of what transpired.  Well after taking the last look at you, I turned round & felt a little forlorn at finding nothing but my carpetbag to keep me company, so as I had nobody to talk to (I was very glad I had'nt) I thought I would occupy myself with thinking about you & wondering how you were getting along.  Directly after we started we came whizzing past a train of cars, which I supposed were the ones wh. were to convey you back to Philada.  I was very glad to see them because I knew you would be & I was afraid you might have had to wait there a good while, but it was'nt very pleasant to think that we were speeding away from each other as fast as we could go.  I hope you did'nt feel as [worn] & dusty when you got to Phila as I did when I reached Port Clinton I had'nt much time to think about it however for I had to go quite in traveller like style & superintend as well as I could amid the bustle & din the transportation of our baggage from one car to another, that seen to, I joined my companions & weput ourselves on board the cars for Tamaqua, a ride of two hours brought us to that place about 1 o'clock, there we staid about half an hour most of wh. time I spent in trying to restore my face to a decent shade of color, for I found it in the funniest looking condition thee can imagine, the dust, & the tears occasioned by the cinders, (& something else) had covered [skin] spots with a sort of black paste wh. very much resembled mud & wh. I had some difficulty in removing.  I thought it expedient to [see first] watering place to get out & wash so I performed my ablutions quite comfortably under the spout where the horses were drinking, it reminded me of Aunt Fortunes style of face washing.  The ride over the mountains was just about as usual, except that it was a little bit hotter & dustier & disagreeabler than ever.  We had 9 passengers in the stage not counting carpetbags & blanket shawls wh are an important item in hot weather I hope I have left mine for the enjoyment of somebody who will take a cooler time for it.  We lived all the afternoon in the anticipation of a cooler ride after sunset, but it seemed to grow hotter instead of colder, most of the passengers seemed to forget their discomforts in a nap so I was left to my own entertainment & sat very quietly in one corner thinking about different things among others I amused myself with imagining what you were about at, Oakland, & wishing I was there with you instead of where I was, about 11 1/2 P.M. we were wheeled up before the Phoenix Hotel in Wilkesbarre where as soon as possible (tho' not until morning) we made our way to our sleeping apartments mine did not prove to be much of a sleeping apartment however tho' as much as could have been expected of a roomwithout windows & with featherbeds, they were very full at the Hotel & we were obliged to be content with the kind of accomodations we could get.  Thinking to better my condition I got up the next morning at half past three & found it a decided improvement upon lying in bed We left [W] about 7 o'clock & had a pleasant ride thro' the valley of Wyoming, it is by far the pleasantest part of the journey I think, the country is looking beautifully now, only it was too hot to enjoy it.  We reached Tunkhannock about 12 1/2 PM, & now comes the very dismalest part of all, at this place the two lades with whom I had travelled from Phila & whom I knew very well left me unexpectedly, & I was packed without any ceremony into a kind of open arrangement upon wheels (for it hardly deserved the name of a wagon) & after considerable crowding & pushing, & groaning I managed to squeze in between two fat women & an indiscriminate collection of trunks, & handboxes, & men.  Under these auspicious circumstances we started, the sun basking down upon us in one direction, & some ominous looking black clouds in another, so [hot] I scarcely knew whether to wish most for a drenching or a coo[k]ing I an addition to this the driver was entertaining us with all sorts of awful predictions, he said the roads were terrible, that the bridge had been washed away & he expected we would all be drowned in crossing the creek, & as to his horses he was perfectly certain they never could stand it, & so I thought I shd never get home in the world, that something awful certainly could'nt fail to happen among so many dismal predictions, & they were such a queer set of people, & altogether I felt such an utter sense of forlornness that I eddified them by beginning to cry.  I was provoked at myself for being so foolish but I really could'nthelp it, it did'nt last very long however, for directly one man who seemed to quite pity me turned round & said in the most compassionate tone, "you feel kind'er used up do'nt you."  I was so struck with the applicability of the expression (for in truth I did feel a sort of sense of "goneness") that I began to laugh, & seeming quite pleased that his efforts were so successful, the man set himself to work to entertain me during the rest of the way, he said he always kind, o' hated to see people discouraged, that he never got discouraged in his life & he thought it was'nt a good plan, & so he got me into quite a composed state of mind & I was enabled to bear the rest of the journey with a tolerable degree of calmness, it is well disagreeable things come to an end as well as agreeable ones, thee may imagine how delighted it was to be safely landed at home after all this, without being either drowned or drenched, they were quite surprised to see me arriving in such a forlorn condition.  If Father & mother had known they wd have met me at Tunkhannock.  I believe the reason of our having such a miserable affair was that the stage had broken down the day before, & this was all they had to send.  They are all very well here excepting father who is somewhat stiff yet with the effects of the rheumatism, the children have grown very much.  And now that I have almost filled my letter with an acct of my own doings, let me ask thee about yours.  I want to know how you are getting along, it seems ages since I have heard anything about you.  I do hope thee'll write very soon & tell me about everything.  I feel somehow as if I was farther away than I ever was before, do come up this summer if you possibly can, any of you, we shd be so delighted Mother requested me to give her love & tell you so.  I suppose whether you remember'd our agreement for last night.  I did & thought about it too.  I suppose Julia is in Reading.  Please give a great deal of love to Uncle Henry & Aunt Rachel, Cos Frank & Cos Anna, Cos Thos & Cos Elizabeth & all the rest of the cousins, to Grfather of course & every body else to whom thee sees fit.  Of course thee will write to me [very] soon.  I am at the end of my paper & must conclude, thy affectionate Cos Clementine CopePS. I gave such a dismal acct of our proceedings up here that I am afraid it will not be any encouragement to come, but let me tell thee that things ai'nt always at such a forlorn pass, it only happened to be so at that particular time.
The children send their love & desire me to thank Cos Frank for the books with wh. they were very much pleased.

Title: 1896 July 13, Philadelphia, to Frank

[Letterhead: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia   -- Logan Square.]

Philadelphia July 13.   1896.

Dear Frank

I enclose the statement of   your fitness for holding a license. You have also I believe   to file a bond signed by two residents of the county (your   mother I suppose would do for one) which is only forfeited   in case you shoot for miliners or something of that kind   which of course you won’t do. The blank bond form can be   obtained at the [Bothonotary’s?] office I think. The only   cost is $1 per year for your license. The bond & certificate   need not be renewed every year

We are just getting   overhe worst of that museum “moving” that I spoke of & I am glad   of it, for it has been hard work for this time of   year.

I am delighted to hear of your additions to the   list. The Prairie Horned Lark I always thought would turn up   in your vicinity.

Stew Brown found the Wilson’s   Thrush at Tannersville Pocono Mts. & was as much taken aback   by the notes as I was, but as he had Mr Eugene P. Bicknell   of N.Y. in the party, he had no trouble in ascertaining who   the songster was

With kind regards to your family I   remain sincerely yours

Witmer Stone

Title: 1841 February 28, New Bedford, to Frank, Philada.

New Bedford 2 mo 28 1841

Dear Frank

Among the   many sins of omission & commission with which my Conscience   has been burdened of late – none has laid harder on my   stomach to speak in a physiological metap[h]or than my not   having answered [thine] epistle of – mo. – 1840.  This sheet   then intended as a peace offering and mediator for past   offences “by-gones” comes to thee by the hands of Geo. H.   Dunbar – (a young man of our religious denomination-   somewhat diligent attender of meeting – (where He in company   with the majority of our young men occupies the seat   fronting the women friends – pardon the digression but the   fact is worth recording that as the Mahometan prays with his   face towards Mecca – thou canst draw the parallel) not so   much distinguished as would be best for plainness of speech.   [behavi] and apparel – and inheriting with the rest of us   some failings I fear from Father Adam - ) who is to pass   thro Philada. on his way to Haverford and then to France in   a New Lock Haven packet next week. – A poet moreover and   somewhat unique personage. & can either roar like a lion or   a sucking dove at his pleasure – rhyme to the moon or swear   like a pirate. – I don’t know how long he stays in Philada.   but if you fall in with him you’ll know him.

The   greatest attraction in these parts this winter - & which   must take its share of the blame of having kept me from   attending to my Philada correspondence is a new periodical   entitled “L’Entreprise” which has originated among us and   has claimed a goodly portion of my leisure
The great   charm about you must know is that we have Lady contributors   – Gertrude Hussey “Murray” quondam –
with sundry & divers others – too tedious to mention as the   advertisements would say – with a respectable lot of   Quak[er] lady make considerable of a coterie. – 
Dr Hardy   undertook to join but whether he did not succeed [to] his   mind or whether his practice is too extensive & laborious to   admit of his wasting his time so idly I know not – but he   has not yet contributed – This much however must be said of   him whether through his intrinsic merits or accidental   circumstances he has in fact succeeded in getting into an   extraordinary practice and seems likely to settle down here   and live easy. – Ah!  Francis if I were only as goodlooking   a young man as thou art I should then think that Destiny had   cut me (too) out for a Doctor
Ben Hardy’s whiskers were   always irresistible – but a new bobwig which I find I had   the honor of bringing home from Philada. in one of those   boxes you remember – that new bobwig with the [portage] of   which I was so unconsciously honored – that new bobwig is   worth a thousand dollars a year to him – 

The old   gentleman that was at our house a little while since from   Salem – gave us a few particulars in Ben’s history that will   be useful to any one who shall hearafter have the honor of   compiling his biography – It seems that such was his   enterprise and such too his earnest zeal in the laudable   task of pleasing the women even in early life that after   having studied the art of Crispin in his nativevillage of Kennebunk he was at the pains of a journey and   long residence at Lyme to be initiated into the art &   mystery of making woman’s shoes

How instructive the   lesson that such heroism and model-gallantry teaches –   Frank! that mans life is a lesson to all posterity – Raised   very probably on a [shingle] in that bleak [-egion]   described so emphatically by the poet – 
“Away down East   dere
[Clow] [by] de moon”
then as he grew up from   [clouts] to petticoats from petticoats to breeches to trace   the ardent aspirations of a full soul. – panting after   greatness and distinction. – from the time he first drove a   peg to the time when he last [drove] a peg – still his   potentialities are visible [from] germ to perfection and   full maturity of cobblerhood. – Ah!  if I were only   good=looking enough!
One sin of commission too I must   confess & be shrived of – As I was turning over some old   papers of mine the other day – I accidentally opened an old   letter of thine containing “a Serenade” [which] being   forthwith tempted by the Devil I inserted in a forthcoming   no. of my periodical – Now I am of opinion that the   temptation proceeds from that source because unintentionally   I find I have eclipsed myself altogether I having “done the   poetry” in that [line] till now finding that I shall not be   able to write anything as good myself why “Othello’s   occupation gone”. – 
and I shall be obliged to cultivate a little taste & genius   which I flatter myself I possess [as] “dea[t]h is [shocking]   accident – and suicide Songster.” – By the way I have begun   a pastoral

“Jocund lambkins softly warble” which when   finished shall be forwarded for your criticism and another –   
[Thus] fair brow thoughts richest mine
When thy   bright as diamonds shine
Rivalled only by the glow
of   the bright orbs below – there’s a [touch] for you –   

Remember you dont pay any postage for this letter   
So it is no matter if it is not worth anything
very   sincerely yours
Charles Taber


Francis R. Cope
care of Henry & Alfred Cope<Br>Walnut St.   
Philada.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan S. Reeve:  1833-1866
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1866-04-15
Title: 1866 April 15, Locust Shade, to Ruthanna Cope

Locust Shade. 4.15.1866

My Dear Annie

I have   been very sorry to see day after day passing away without   any acknowledgment sent of thy very interesting &  welcome   lettter, which was a real treat to me. I wish there was some   hope of thy getting as good a one in reply but what with   colds & headache the little wit I ever had seems to have   departed, for which loss I console with my corespondents   every time one of my stupid effusions goes to the Post   Office.- I think a visit from thee & Clemmy would have an   enlivening effect & when summer comes so must you.- It was   very kind to send me that excellent Photo of Uncle Daniel,   after my negligence in the
matter of which I have been duly ashamed- and I am very much   obliged for it.- We had a nice visit to him had we not? If I   had not gone then, I fear I should not have seen him at all-   except that we did meet in the cars the other day- as being   sick in Wilmington entirely spoiled my Germantown visit. so   that I could make none of the calls I hoped to.-
How thee   must have enjoyed having Clemmy so long with thee. You had   splendid times I know. Indeed no one can be at your house   without enjoying themselves- At least that is my   experience.-
Thee knows perhaps that I have been a good   deal with my friend Lizzie Howell this winter.- Her mothers   death was so very sudden- only sickda little more that half   & hour- that the shock was fearful & Lizzie

was a long time recovering from it.- She is yet very sad-   and her brother being in poor health adds to the feeling.-   She was so sick for some weeks as rarely to get down stairs.   nervous & weak- but is now stronger & brighter & very busy   she writes me.- It is often a great blessing I think to   those in sorrow to have duties pressing upon them with must   be attended to & so the mind is diverted from its greif and   made to realize that life has yet much in store for them.   –
Did thee know our Georgie has been sent adrift from his   home into the city? We do miss him sadly- but he likes his   situation in a wholesale store in Market St, very well &    perhaps it is the right thing for him.- We hope that he may   be preserved from the temptations that summoned him.- Lizzie   has come home
for yearly meeting week.- We have been looking for aunt   Rachel Howland & her family every day but hear now they are   not coming till next week.-
Has thee been after “Trailing   Arbutus” this spring? [-] and I went the other day &  found   some pale blossoms. but very sweet.- Isnt it delightful to   hunt under the dead leaves for the delicate things- it seems   to make one feel young again fot the time.- Thee asks have I   read “Snow Bound”—Only a little of it &  have not happened   even to see it in a volume. But intend to get it soon if I   can.- The part I read was pleasant, simple &  [s-----] , -   as thee says more understandable than much of the latter day   poetry.- We have been reading “Across the Continent” and I   have indulged dreams of someday seeing the “Yosemite Valley”   if my finances get into sufficiently prosperous conditions   for such a journey.- Don’t thee 
want to go to Europe with the party that starts next month?-   It must be bery pleasant to look forward to & finer still to   experience if all things are fair & no anxieties to follow   you.- Wonder if John Wood &  Lily will go.- John says he   wants to & I guess Lily would not object.- I liked John   better than I expected to- but he is certainly neither   handsome nor dignified- but [-------] & kind hearted. I   should think.- Is’nt it a comfort Mary Ann Morris is so much   better? I cannot help hoping she will be entirely herself   again before very long.- Their house is very bright &   pleasant & I should think they might be very happy there-   This to be sure happiness is not a thing of outward   circumstances [----]Did thee remember that yesterday was the anniversary of our   dear Presidents death? Wonder where another year will find   us.- What do thy brothers think of our prospects with such a   man as Johnson at the helm.- It is a comfort that the crew   of out ship of State are so staunch & true.-
Suppose   Marry Emma Stokes passed meeting last third day- I do like   Alexander Wood very much. He seems so open & honest.- Will   they have a wedding  I wonder- or just be married & go   travelling.- I hear friends at Arch Street did not accept   Sue Farnum’s resignation. Had she violated discipline before   presenting it? The usual yearly mtg storms seems to be   brewing this evening- but I hope it wont come this.- Does   thee go in and out every day?.- Please excuse this [prosy]   sheet dear Annie & write very soon.- My love please to thy   sister E. – Very loving by thine
S S Reeve



----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Recipient:  Francis Reeve Cope:  1821-1909
Date: 1870-08-16
Title: 1870 August 16, Awbury, to My dear Frank

Awbury 8 mo. 16th 1870      

      My dear Frank,      

      I rec'd thine & Chellie’s letters to day, when Tho's came out from town.  They also had one from Mary, and we are glad to hear of your safe arrival at Snow Shoe and very thankful I am, that you had a doctor so near at hand to extract the bone from thy throat.  I read thy letter first, and was much alarmed. before knowing what the accident thee alluded to was, but Thomas fortunately knew about it from Mary's letter & told me at once.  What a providential thing it was, that there was a Dr. so near at hand.  the children must have been very much frightened, before thee was relieved.--I hope thee will be careful of thyself, and not jump, and injure thy arch again.—
      -
      attached wife Anna S. Cope.  I hope Tom is provided with warm under-clothing.  Mary sends her love & hopes you will have a good time.I hope thee has enough warm clothing, with thee, for I sh'd not be surprised of thr warmest weather is past.  We are having it delightful here at home, the thermometer 68 this morning at 8 o'clock and under 80 at noon.  This afternoon Thomas & Elizabeth Mary & I called at father's, and afterwards at Ellis Yarnall's leaving Mary at father's.  We found them all at home, and had a very pleasant visit.  Lucy Harrison is very bright & agreeable & Anne is lovely.  She told me she had written a note to Lillie, which I would send to her when it comes to hand.  She also told me she was sorry not to go to Snow Shoe with you, but they could not go to Chicago, & as their time is so limited they of course felt anxious to see as much as possible before going home.  they expect to go to Detroit from Chicagoand then on to Niagara.  They expect to leave sometime next week, and take the journey alone.  We all disapprove of them taking such a long journey by themselves, but I suppose Ellis Yarnall will find out some one to look after them.  When they go on, they expect to spend the first night at Altoona, and then travel day & night until they reach Chicago.  I have sent Lillie & Chellie some under-clothing.  2 flannel skirts, 2 under vests, 1 cloth body, 2 pairs thick stockings, 1 pair drawers, 1 [Alpaca?] skirt.  Anna & Carrie are quite well, & the former is invitee to spend tomorrow with cousin Mary [W.?] Brown's little Mary.  I did not [?] like [?]-ing her just now, but could not well decline.  I was at father's this afternoon, and they were all pretty well.  father seems stronger from the change in weather.  I saw bro. John and his boys go off this morning, and hope they had apleasant trip to Altoona.  I am glad you met with such a polite reception at Bellefonte.  I had no idea before, that there was any such spring of water, there as mentions.  63000 gallons a minute is immense.  I think you must have enjoyed the ride up the mountain very much, if the views are so beautiful.  Give my love to Lillie & Chellie, and tell them I hope they will not be put out at my sending them some warm clothing, as I am only sorry they did not send for warm dresses too, as they have nothing warm with them.  It is now bed-time and I must put by my writing; the children are enjoying Anna Hartshorne's company very much.  I hope some of you will write tho' I do not want you to tax yourselves.  I have already been much favored.  Bro Thomas intended sending sister Anne's letter, but it was not returned from Aunt Ruth's in time.  with much love to you all, ever thy

Title: 1861 November 25, Newport, to Chellie

Newport 11 mo. 25th 1861
      2nd day      

      Dear Chellie      I have been writing a long letter to grandma Brown this morning as we were kept indoors on account of a snow-storm, and I fully intended writing to cousin Amelia too, but the dinner hour came too soon, and now the carriage is at the door to take us to ride, and we must be off.  I hope we shall get off as we expect on 4th day evening, as I am anxious to get home-we are all pretty well-with much love, and kisses to the little ones, affectionately      thy mother AS Cope      

      Mama [Haines?] and I add our [?] while she gets ready which I do with pleasure      aftly thy father      F.R.CTom sends a picture of a policeman trying to catch a man for [---]1861 with drawing by T.P.C

Recipient:  Mary Elizabeth Brown Hartshorne:  b. 1823
Date: 1847-08-11
Title: 1847, August 10, to My dear Mary

Newport 8 mo 10th / 47
      
      My dear Mary
      
      Frank has been writing to William this morning, and has most likely advised you on all points of interest.- you probably know by this time, that we are all in a good state of health, and we hope that our sister Susan is improving, tho' she still has some head-ache.  Frank & cousin Wistar are very kind and devote themselves almost exclusively to contributing to her comfort & pleasure in every way.  F is devoted to Susan and does evey thing in his power to promote the improvement of her health, his kindness is unparalleled: everything is done for us, and we have nothing to do, but join in the pleasant plans laid out for us.- Elizy H & Susan were concluding before dinner, that they accomplished very little of any thing on account of the time occupied in changing their dresses for the different labors of the day.- About ten in the morning they prepare for bathing or rather we do when Susan does not go-
      /
      not arrive on 7th day tho' we intend to do so if possible.  the Boat did not leave until 5 o'clock this morning.  I expect the irregular lately.- with much love
      aff thy sister Anne
      Susan will accompany us to Hazard's this afternoon
      she is resting since her bath.then return about 12 o'clock.  rest, until time to away for dinner, then about 5 o'clock, a different costume must necessarily be adapted for Sailing especially when the boats, are slightly fishy & a little dirty.- then we come home about ten-time or little past, and another change must be made to appear at [---] which [---] will suffice for the evening.- but all this is done in a good hurry and I cannot say it consumes much time.- I believe I have nothing new to tell thee, and indeed, I expect it would be very puzzling to think of any such thing when Cousin Wistar is of the party, for he writes home to frequently, and describes every thing that seems with so much minuteness, that if you are favored with the perusal of his epistles, ours must seem quite commonplace; this is my conjecture, as we joke Wistar & Sue both, about writing so often.- Only to think- Sixth day evening we leave, if a storm or fog does not prevent us, and Tom has concluded to remain, and return with us last evening tho' fog was so dense that the Bay-State" did not go out, and now we have every prospect, of the same thick state of the atmosphere for this evening consequently.  it seemed hardly worth while for Tom to leave before we did.- The Massachusetts arrived here with Mr. Williams on board, about 11 o'clock thismorning having been lying off Point Judith, even since four o'clock.  Susan & Lizzie went to bathe this morning with F & Wistar leaving me at home to pass the time as I could.  Tom & Moses had gone fishing, and I was quiet enough.  Susan though it best notwithstanding your message, to try the [---] three times faithfully as the Dr directed, and I hope she will not be any worse for it, and perhaps it may strengthen her afterwards.  She says she likes it very much while in the water, but she feels pretty weak for sometime afterwards.  we think she is the best judge for what is best for her, and she does exactly what she wished in the Bathing line; Frank takes her in, giving her three waves as directed, he said the water was very warm & pleasant this morning.  I quite long to go in again but fear I shall not have an opportunity of going more than once or twice more before I leave.- It suits Elizy Hacker exactly, she feels a little tired after coming out, but it seems to brance & strenghthen her, and shee looks better I think in this little time of our [---] here.  I do hope her father will telegraph her to remain with Sue, if the letter does not arrive in time to answer it before our leave.- yester afternoon we were out Sailing in the bay, landed on one of the [dumpling?] rocks gathered some sprigs of green to press, and enjoyedthe novelty of it highly, it was really very pleasant, altho' by the time we returned, our blanket shawls were almost white with the fog.  Sailing seems to suit Susan, very well, but I think clear weather as a general thing is preferable to her.- This afternoon we think of calling at fr'd Hazard’s, we spent a pleasant evening there last Sixth day.  they are certainly a delightful family. Ann[a/e?] Hazard called here this morning with S & A Jenkins who are still staying with them – we intend riding out to see fr'd Jenkins before we go.- 4th day morn.  I was obliged to leave this shut hastily yesterday afternoon, as Thomas Hazard & his wife called upon us inviting us to spend this afternoon with them which we intend doing.  Elizy & Frank are much disappointed I believe in Fanny H’s beauty, but they must see her at [---] before they fully decide.  She is perfect at home.- my love to all- Susan and Lizzie are taking a nap before dinner, and I cannot disturb them now.- there is a thick fog over they bay now 12 at noon, and it will [---] increase- Tom could not have gone last night in consequence of the bay as the boat did not leave, and perhaps it is as well for him to wait for us.  Frank & myself do not think it proper to leave here in a fog or storm and Tom must not think it strange if we do

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1858-07-09
Title: 1858 July 9, Awbury, to sister Anna

[Letter from Anna S. Cope to her sister in law R.Anna Cope]
   
   Awbury 7 mo. 9th / 58
   
   Dear sister Anna
   
   Thee will think I am very remiss in performing my promises but it is useless for me to make excuses, as thee knows how time goes with me, generally, amongst the childrenm during the day, and by evening thee may imagine how it is that I feel too indolent to write a letter.  We are much obliged to father for his kind & sympathetic letter at this time and I hope we may be enabled to take the right view of our troubles, in this matter.  Much love to father and mother, and tell them that Francis keeps up his spirits very well, considering all things, he has received a letter from bro' Thomas to day, with Geo. M. Dallas reply to his (Tho's) epistle, which he hasprobably sent to Atlantic City for father's perusal.- it is short, very politely worded, and caps the climax for coolness, on the subject, as he had evidently not troubled himself about the affair in the slightest degree.- I must confess, I was completely taken aback at such cool indifference on the subject, especially as Thomas had consulted him before, when in England.  But I suppose there is nothing more to be done about it, and we must try to hear it with a Christian spirit as father does.-
   Elizy sends her love to you all & is in better spirits, than lately, as she has received several letters from Thomas, he is still in Brussels, and appears to have no very definite idea when he may return home.-
   We are glad father has sent for Julia to join you, as she needs a change, I fear she confines too lately to the attic, and a little of your refreshing sea-breezes will revive her.  I think she has been concerned about George, as he hasbeen quite indisposed.  He is now much better and spent this afternoon here for the first time, as the Dr. thought the ride might do him good, but unfortunately he did not see much of Julia, she having been in town, and did not reach home until near seven o'clock when he was obliged to go home to tea.  He says the Dr. pronounced his lungs quite clear now, and I hope he will be able to accompany Julia to the shore.- Hannah Stokes has been here to day, and intends staying over-night, it is quite cheering to have a little company as we miss you all so much.  Thy letter this afternoon was very acceptable, and tell Clemmy I thought perhaps she would have favored us again.  I am glad to hear of the Doctor having slept better and hope he may be benefitted, my love to sister Mary, and mention to her if thee pleases, that I have not received any reply to my letter to her, but suppose I am to get a bonnet for her at Jones' according to my best judgment.  but they think it is very doubtful if they can procure any other quality of [---].  it is not as fine as thatof which our sun-bonnets are made.  Elizy Hacker expected to have gone down to Atlantic City this week, but was not well enough.-
   Brother John has been here a few minutes this evening, Rueben is not entirely well of the poison yet, and they think he has the whooping-cough.  Our Willy has it now, also little Johnny & little Mary has it quite badly.-
   Our Tom is getting better of it, and Alfred does not cough now at all; Henry still coughs a good deal at night, as well as little Johnny.-
   Mary Mayer has arrived in the city of P- and will come down here tomorrow afternoon.  How does sister Mary enjoy herself, and has she returned to bathe?  Tell Clemmy I was not surprised to hear her opinion that it is not equal to Newport.  Sarah Biddle mentioned to us on first day last, of their having received letters from uncle Alfred and aunt Rebecca- and uncle Alfred is much better, thinks the hydropathic system suits him.  Bishop Potter’s family are still with them.  Thee does not know, how much I wished she had offered to show usthe letters, as she said they were long, and very interesting.
   It is past ten o'clock, and F- is shutting up the house affectionately thy sister
   Anna 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1858-08-12
Title: 1858 August 12, Awbury, to My dear sister

Awbury 8 mo 12th / 58
   
   My dear sister
   
   When I last wrote, it seemed so doubtful whether thee would be at uncle William's or on the way home with Edward Biddle, that I concluded to direct the letter to Clemmy in case thee had left there.- Brother Thomas returned home very unexpectedly on second day evening, the very time we were looking for thee, he was much overcome by the voyage, and the anxiety of getting off in a steamer, but I hope is better now,and likely to improve; his strength has been much prostrated, and he has had some fever but the Doctor considers him better this evening, and he does really seem better, tho’ he is still quite weak.  They had a very cold voyage, and he could not keep warm enough & consequently took a severe cold, but thee must not be anxious or uneasy about him, as Dr Rhoads thinks him much better; &he is entirely free of fever this evening.  Alfred is also much better to day for the first time, but he has changed so frequently from better to worse in the course of twenty four hours, that we hardly know how to calculate about him.  But I think the Doctor is more encouraged about him this evening, and I have great hopes that he will soon be on the well list, as he has one tooth through, and he has not coughed quite so hard to day; the rest of the family are all pretty well, father, and mother desire their love to thee, and say thee had better take the first good opportunity to return home, and not to think of coming home alone, without hearing further from us; and Francis also adds that in case Alfred continues better, perhaps he can come up for the next week.-
   With regard to thy medicine, and salve, we will endeavor to send it to thee in some way, as well as the material for aunt Susan’s duster.- Bro' Thomas has bough various little articles for the children, with which they are much pleased; he bought Lilly & Chelly eacha suit of doll’s clothes made in Paris, according to the present style, hats shoes, and even night-gown and cap.  velvet [---] watch & chain, little [---] all furnished in the most minute style, [---], &c little beauties,- the children are so overjoyed, that they show them to everyone that comes, and do not get tired of examining them, at all times in the day, and I do not wonder for they are so elegantly made that you cannot help admiring them.  Sister Elizy and Julia sed their love to Clemmy and thyself, in which I wish to join, also love to Aunt Susan, Annette & Carry- I am sorry I have no news to tell thee, such as thee would like to hear, but as I have not been any where for the last three or four weeks thee must not wonder at it.-
   with much love affectionately
   sister Anna S. Cope
   PS.
   I am obliged to close this in haste, as it is late, and the family have mostly retired
   mother is about as well as usual now.-Tom continues to get better- whether I get up for thee or not will depend on how Alfred is.  He is a good deal better this morning.  I have Aunt Susans cloth which if I do not bring up I will send by envelope.  There seems to be no use of sending thy medicine as thee will hardly have a chance to use it, but I will bring it with me if I come. Dr Evans is not in town now
   afftly thy bro
   F.R.C.Awbury 8 mo 12th / 58

   mother is about as well as usual now.-Tom continues to get better- whether I get up for thee or not will depend on how Alfred is.  He is a good deal better this morning.  I have Aunt Susans cloth which if I do not bring up I will send by envelope.  There seems to be no use of sending thy medicine as thee will hardly have a chance to use it, but I will bring it with me if I come. Dr Evans is not in town now
   afftly thy bro
   F.R.C.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Francis Reeve  Cope:  1821-1909
Recipient:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Date: 1858-08-12
Title: 1858 August 12, Awbury, to My dear sister

Awbury 8 mo 12th / 58
   
   My dear sister
   
   When I last wrote, it seemed so doubtful whether thee would be at uncle William's or on the way home with Edward Biddle, that I concluded to direct the letter to Clemmy in case thee had left there.- Brother Thomas returned home very unexpectedly on second day evening, the very time we were looking for thee, he was much overcome by the voyage, and the anxiety of getting off in a steamer, but I hope is better now,and likely to improve; his strength has been much prostrated, and he has had some fever but the Doctor considers him better this evening, and he does really seem better, tho’ he is still quite weak.  They had a very cold voyage, and he could not keep warm enough & consequently took a severe cold, but thee must not be anxious or uneasy about him, as Dr Rhoads thinks him much better; &he is entirely free of fever this evening.  Alfred is also much better to day for the first time, but he has changed so frequently from better to worse in the course of twenty four hours, that we hardly know how to calculate about him.  But I think the Doctor is more encouraged about him this evening, and I have great hopes that he will soon be on the well list, as he has one tooth through, and he has not coughed quite so hard to day; the rest of the family are all pretty well, father, and mother desire their love to thee, and say thee had better take the first good opportunity to return home, and not to think of coming home alone, without hearing further from us; and Francis also adds that in case Alfred continues better, perhaps he can come up for the next week.-
   With regard to thy medicine, and salve, we will endeavor to send it to thee in some way, as well as the material for aunt Susan’s duster.- Bro' Thomas has bough various little articles for the children, with which they are much pleased; he bought Lilly & Chelly eacha suit of doll’s clothes made in Paris, according to the present style, hats shoes, and even night-gown and cap.  velvet [---] watch & chain, little [---] all furnished in the most minute style, [---], &c little beauties,- the children are so overjoyed, that they show them to everyone that comes, and do not get tired of examining them, at all times in the day, and I do not wonder for they are so elegantly made that you cannot help admiring them.  Sister Elizy and Julia sed their love to Clemmy and thyself, in which I wish to join, also love to Aunt Susan, Annette & Carry- I am sorry I have no news to tell thee, such as thee would like to hear, but as I have not been any where for the last three or four weeks thee must not wonder at it.-
   with much love affectionately
   sister Anna S. Cope
   PS.
   I am obliged to close this in haste, as it is late, and the family have mostly retired
   mother is about as well as usual now.-Tom continues to get better- whether I get up for thee or not will depend on how Alfred is.  He is a good deal better this morning.  I have Aunt Susans cloth which if I do not bring up I will send by envelope.  There seems to be no use of sending thy medicine as thee will hardly have a chance to use it, but I will bring it with me if I come. Dr Evans is not in town now
   afftly thy bro
   F.R.C.Awbury 8 mo 12th / 58

Title: 1859 August 14, Awbury, to mother

Awbury 8 mo 14th 1859
   
   Dear mother
   
   I wrote a few hasty lines to Frank this afternoon which brother Thomas did not succeed in sending to you, as the Germantown post-office he found was not open on First-day, giving you the good news that sister E. has another boy, a very fine-looking child, and the tenth grandson, but as yet without a name, which is not decided upon, indeed, I have not heard one suggestion, only it is to be a fancy name, and Lizzie leaves it to bro' Thomas select.  Sister E. desires her love, and wishes me to say to thee, that she is very comfortable, this evening; and the Doctor says she is doing as well as is possible.  The child was born at 1/2 past 7 o'clock this morning, and the nurse came about 9.  Thomas sent to town for her early, and she came as soon as shecould, but it did not make any difference as the Doctor thought Mary Sixsmith was entirely competent to attent to all that was needed, and she proved so.
   Bro’ Thomas took Harry, Tom & Willy to meeting, and afternoon left our two boys at father’s to dine, and went for them to return home towards evening.  The house seems quite lonely and deserted now, and company at the tea-table was very slim this evening, only three, Thomas, Harry & myself.
   Ellie Stokes with little Ellie left for Riverton yesterday afternoon.  Ellie ad been staying with us since 6th day morning.
   Sister Susan and Virginia also went home yesterday afternoon, they enjoyed their visit with us very much, and it was very pleasant to us to have them, as we miss you all so much.   The children have kept pretty well, tho' yesterday was an oppressively warm day here, so damp & close, but to day it is lovely, tho' quite warm.-
   I hope you are all enjoying the sea-breezes notwithstanding the hard beds, which must be quite a draw-back to thecomfort of some of you.  How is Anne?  Sister Lizzie wished me to mention, that she hopes Anne will drink plenty of [---] wine as it was particularly recommended to Clemmie by Dr. [Meigs?], at one time as being very beneficial, as it has the peculiar quality of enriching the blood, and he ordered her to take a tumbler full a day.  Lizzie thinks Frank had better take some more of it to Atlantic City for her on 4th day, when he comes up.  Please give my love to her, also to father, Emma, and sister Lizzie Brown.  Dr Rhoads mentioned this morning that Margaret Eliz expected to go to the sea-shore tomorrow in company with Augustus Wilson, and some one else whose name I did not quite understand.  I hope you may meet with her.-   
   affectionately thy daughter
   
   Anna S. Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1859-08-18
Title: 1859 August 18, Awbury, to My dear Chellie

Awbury 8 mo 18th 1859

My dear Chellie

As Dr Rhoads very kindly offered to take this note to thee, I thought perhaps thee would like to hear how thy little brothers are getting along at home and therefore take the opportunity to send a few hasty lines.  Alfred was very happy in a few minutes after papa and Willy & Tom left us; I went to ride with uncle Thomas the latter part of the afternoon, and took him along, we had a few errands to do in Germantown.-
Uncle Alfred & Aunt Rebecca Cope with Annie, called to see us yesterday afternoon and we had a very pleasant visit from them.  Uncle Alfred's knee is still rather troublesome, but his foot is better.  Cousin Edward is going to the WhiteMountains with uncle Edward Yarnall & Aunt Caroline, very soon.  Tell Aunt Lizzie that I saw grandma Brown at meeting this morning, she told me they were all pretty well except Ridgely and he was threatened with [cramp?] last night, but was much better to day, indeed quite relieved; they sent for Dr Rhoads who saw him again this morning before grandma came to meeting.  Tell papa that wonders will never cease, Aunt Mary Haines & mamma are going to spend this evening with Ann Haines to meet B Yarnall's family.-

in great haste
affly thy mother

A S Cope

Title: 1875 July 4, Lake Windermere, to Tom & Scrubby

Lockwood Hotel   Lake Windermere
   July 4. 1875
   
   Dear Tom & Scrubby.
   
   I did write a few lones to thee Scrubby from Kendal but I rec'd such a nice letter from thee last Fifth day that I concluded to send thee a longer one; & as I have already rec'd two letters from Tom I thought it would be well to kill two birds with one stone-so here goes-We saw the first of this lake last Fourth day afternoonand will continue to see it till sometime tomorrow.  I haven't the slightest idea where the picture, at the head of this sheet, is taken from;- but I know one thing & that is that I have not as yet seen anything like it nor do I think that there is such a view.  At any rate it gives you no idea of the place.  Now for the narrative- We took a row on the lake soon after arriving here & on Fifth day took the steamer down to [Bowness?] where we expected to get on a carriage & drive over to Coniston.  When we arrived there, however, the sky looked so threatening & Alexis not feeling very well we concluded to leave it till next day, & returned to Louwood.  Arriving in a heavy shower we were at a loss to know what to do, till I decided to go over to Keswick & get our letters that were probably awaiting our arrival there.  So as the stage did not go till 3 o'clock I drove over to Ambleside, bought a full rubbersuit (coat leggings & cap) hired a horse & started off, about 1 o'clock.  You can imagine me clothed in these things sitting on an awfully rough trotter nothing of my usual self being visible except my eyes, nose & mouth, and my shoes.  The suit answered admirably, keeping me perfectly dry in the hardest thunder-storm I was ever out in- Except my shoes wh. in a few minutes were rather soggy.  However it was soon over & I arrived at [Derwentwater?] Hotel, [Portinscale?] at 4 P.M. having ridden on horseback 19 miles.  Here I obtained, first a lunch then the letters, one from each of you.  While waiting here another gust came up & when it had gone over the sky looked brighter & more settled.  So having engaged rooms for 2nd day, at 6 P.M. I set off & had a most beautiful ride past [Thirlmue?] & Helvellyn, Grasmere & Rydal Water back to Ambleside wh. I reached at half past eight.  Drove downto our hotel, took some red-hot tea & then went out to hunt for Lilly & Alexis, whom I found spooning in a bench & who told me that there were three other pairs in the hotel worse off than we were.  Sixth-day we set off for Coniston Water, driving alongside of Windermere & crossing below Bowness, through Hawkshead where Wordsworth went to school & finally reached Coniston where Lillie & I made the tour of the lake in the steam Gondolee as they call it while Alexis ascended the "Old Man."  We had the best of it for, although he immortalized himself by leaving his name & address in full on top of pole of stones which has been placed there, yet he was caught in such a dense fogthat he couldn't see anything & in turn caught a species of chill & fever, from which he is slowly recovering.  Yetserday we went through Grasmere & Rydal & got Lillie pretty well played out.  We rowed down Grasmere Lake & walked to Rydal Mount, (wh we did not see, exceptone window & the chimney's) Lillie & Alexis "preferring rather" to keep on a level while I crossed over the hill from wh. I got an elegant view of Windermere, Rydal Water, Grasmere & [Tharlmere?] besides some small 'towns' and the mountains on all sides.  On coming down I overtook Lou & Alexis spooning by the roadside, On my coming up they had began to talkpleasantly about the weather, Lillie suggesting that it was much cooler than the 3rd of July 2 years ago, at wh. both looked remarkably pleased & mysterious.  I looked very innocent but on making "comparative mathematical calculations" have concluded that it must have been that day they drove over from Connymeade together & took two hours & a half (2 ½ hrs) by the watch to get up to the house from the stable-   

   It’s fearfully hard to get Lillie up in the mornings.  She grumbles incessently because Alexis & myself will order breakfast at half past eight & uses as anargument to the statement, (I wont say in fact) that Father when he was over here did not breakfast till nine.  Another instance, Tom of the force of example.  However we dont give in & in revenge she gener-ally keeps us waiting 15 or 20 minutes.  Alexis thinks it is a good thing that we travel from place to place, as they must think wherever we go that it is a mere accident that we are late.  This miserable climate dont seem to suit me very well.  In the first place the voyage knocked me, clean; for I caught cold some how wh. increased my sore-throat & I haven’t got rid of it yet.  It steadily increased till I got to Warwick wh place seemed to agree with it; for it has been improving since.  Then I had a boil on my skin which troubled me not a little when I ran against anything or Alexis hit me with his umbrella.  I have got it down to a pretty fine point now however & one is coming on my backjust between my shoulders so as to afford me an opportunity of displaying my skill in twisting my arms around.  Beer dont seem to be the thing for me at present, & I have hardly tasted it since leaving Liverpool.  As to the roast-beef, it tastes very much like the same article at home, and they put so much mint with the peas to make them green I suppose that you cant taste any thing else.  But the great charm is that every thing is so nice & clean- no greasy knives &c  You must excuse this writing; but Lillie brought us out here on a most uncomfortable hill-side & insists on sticking it out.  We saw some very pretty little ponies when we were in Wales Srubby; but as we are carrying very small valises & they are pretty full we thought best to defer our purchasefor a season.  I commenced writing on this sheet as you may see but Lou thought it was so important to write on pictured paper that I gave in- Consequently the above marks- I hope that Hazen may succeed in getting up his party & also that he will not ruin the horses driving too much in the park.  I have just thought of a little map wh. I have in my packet wh. I shall enclose in this letter with 5th and 6th sdays excursions marked on them.  Although it may not interest either of you I think mother will like to see it.  I will now cook as it is time for me to be poking Lillie up to go down to dinner,   

   affectly your bro
   Alfred Cope Jr.[Derwentwater] Hotel.
   Portsinscale- Keswick
   7.7.75.
   
   P.S.
   
   2 1/2 P.M.
   
   Have just arrived here & rec'd a letter from T.P.C. Jr. giving a fair "a/c" of the baby, water-works & crops.  Also a bill from Holliday & Storrs I [---] amounting to the enormous sum of [Pound] 5.16.6.  I have come to the conclusion that he is not the man for me.  Lou gaps as much as ever.  This morning just as we were finishing breakfast she commenced raising her elbows to the same level as her shoulders (You probably remember that little habit) but I saw it in time & proposed to up to our rooms to stretch.  Please remember me to the baby- and Chellie.  Also to any other member of the family wh. happens to be at home.  I dont wonder John dont know know where you all are-   

   A.C.Jr.[Alfred's letters from Europe 1875-76   

letter

   Thos. P. Cope Jr.
   Cope Brothers
   Philadelphia
   U.S.A.
