Recipient:  Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas) Cope:  1850-1883
Date: 1880-02-08
Title: 1880 February 8, Cannes, to Alexis

Cannes Feb. 8. 1880.
   
   Dear Alexis,
   
   We recd thy letter of Jan. 16th a few days since, & have been thinking over thy proposition.  It wd. be nice to be able to spend part of our summers in Susquehanna Co particularly if you make it your home, but we have not been looking forwarrd to keeping house in our return.  I do not want to live at Connymead again, (indeed I do not think any of us want to; unless we cd. find some one to live with us)  It was too lonely, particularly for me.  & if we did not keep house there in winter, we cd. not keep very well keep house in summer.  How or where we shall live when we go home, I do not know.  Indeed the uncertainties of the future, & what it will be best to do, often weighs upon my mind.  Connymead is no placefor any body to live who wants to be a Friend, or who has any preference for their ways.  Life there was a continual struggle wh. I have no desire to renew, & perhaps we shall never know again [ever/even?] that semblance of a home.  I hope if thee and Lily picked to bring your children up as Friends, you may be able to keep them in a community where Friends live.  For it is pretty hard for a young person who has been uninstructed in what are considered the accomplishments of life to have to live where these are considered all important, & are the chief recupations of those by whom you are surrounded.  It requires a good deal of strength of character to be able to live alone, I [---], & Friends must always do it more or less when they go out from among their own people.  When one has not been brought to play on the piano or sing or draw, or paint, or evento play cards- a not very valuable accomplishment certainly- & yet one in wh. English people who are both intelligent & sensible, seem to while away at least a fourth part of their waking hours; & never to tire of- When I say, one has never been instructed in any of these things, one feels as if one ought to be at least where they are not the chief employment of life.  Of course when living in a delightful pension on the Riviera- one is not supposed to be exactly fulfilling the normal conditions of existence- Existence here (the physical part of it) seems too delightful to be long continued, & I have wonder since we have been here how long 14 human beings could live together, without apparently a shadow of sorrow or anxiety to disturb the delightful days, which seem, to glide away without a cloud either inward or outward, to mar their peacefulness such skies, & such weather , & such walks as we have- only one littleshower in all the two months we have been here- It is the most perfect thing in weather certainly, that we have ever experienced.  If we had come last winter we shd  not have had the same experience of it, for it rained very much even here.  But I have digressed widely from the subject upon wh. I intended to write, [---] the old house of Woodbourne.  Whatever may be my inclincation with regard to it, (& I certainly shd. like very much the idea of being able to live somewhere near you).  I do not thonk C & A have any desire to undertake housekeeping there.  The life of a travelling artist- or even of the traveller, minus the artist- in these delightful regions & pensions where have all the comforts of home without its cares, does not intend to inspire you with a desire to renew the contest with the [biddy?]- in art less America. If only some plan cd. be devised by wh. Woodbourne cd. be converted into a pension.  I have no doubt we shd. spend a good deal of our time there, & shd. think the old house wd. need an immense amount of repairing, & as to the old chairs of the Conklin family, I feel as if I had lost my interest in them & I shd. not think they wd. be worth the sum they mentioned.  It is provoking to have to buy what is your own.  (see 4th page of A's letter)Can thee tell us who paid the drivers on our Naples [---] wh. were packed in the same box with P.C.G.'s- we asked thee to do it & I suppose thee must have- but we have never heard.If not paid
   
   Please pay to the order of Francis C. Haines (who may be too modest to speak of it) 9 francs 15 centimes, as near as you can come at it.
   
   Clementine CopeAlexis T Cope
   
   (Haines St Germantown)
   
   Philadelphia
   Etats-Unis d'Ameriq

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1880-03-21
Title: 1880 March 21, Hotel de la Paix, Rome, to Lily

March. 21. 1880.
   
   My dear Lily, Behold us in Rome once more!- dear delightful bewitching Rome- The city of cities- I cannot tell with what delight I find myself again threading its labyrinths & wandering amidst its ruins.  We reached here the 6th of March, having left Mentone 2 days before, passing one night in Genoa & thence by the midnight train to Rome.  This being the only train (owing to their very insane & uncomfortable arrangements) wh. gets you here at a respectable hour.  It was a very uncomfortable journey- but then we were coming to- Rome!!  We made a sojourn of two weeks only, at Dr. Müllers- Mentone we thought lovely- Dr M’s house not altogether so.  It is not happily [---] being at the end of one of thos dried up rivers, down wh. torrents of cold airrushed from the mountains.  We thought it much colder & damper than either Cannes or Nice.  & then there was a slight suggestion of boarding school about the household arrangements- & most for much open warfare between the Dr & his spouse to be altogether agreeable.  It is a great pity they have not learned to control their tempers a little in the presence of their guests at least- for at times it was rather to peppery to be pleasant.  Fortunately the storms seemed to be not very lasting.  & they were generally jolly enough- & in fact much more jolly then most people would be who were at their wits ends to make two ends meet.  A lady who was staying there with her family (pretty much as a matter of charity I fancy) told me they were over head & ears in debt & that she had come to the conclusion there was no use in trying to help them, as they never cd. keep any money- altho' they ask a very high price for their accomodations.  The excursions at Mentone were truly lovely, & the Dr. was alwaysready to take us.  In fact we thought he quite preferred the ladies to the boys for he seemed quite put out once or twice at our declining to go.  but they were too hard for me, & I did none of the very long ones.  I shd. think however for those who were up to that sort of thing, Mentone would be one of the most delightful of the Riviera towns, tho' each one of them seems to have its own peculiar charms.  The weather was very warm when we got to Rome, & took the back bone out of me terribly- It however soon changed from mild, to cool, clear & bracing & the last 10 days have been delicious- I never was able to do so much walking in Rome before, & on spring afternoons such as these what luxury cd. be greater than to drive or to wander at will among the ruins all golden in the light of the declining sun- or to watch the funny old models in their gay rags & tatters- (wh. seem to [---] the spirit of the twins-) hanging themselves out on the Spanish Steps to be admiredwith all the rest.  Surely there is no place on earth like Rome.  Last first day was the kings birthday & there was a grand review- & the king & queen & the [---] kindly [---] themselves , to our admiring gaze in the Borghese. It was quite too gay & disappointing to be proper for 1st day.  The usual ceremonies of holy week begin to day, wh. is Palm Sunday.  We did not attend at S. Peters, thinking last year it was rather a sell.  I went to the little Italian [Waldensian] Church, a great contrast indeed to the pomp & [---] of the great Cathedral.  We had got back to our old Hotel della Pace, where we were twice last winter.  We went first to another but did not like it, & so came here, where we found some friends of last summer (the Müllers).  It is a good central situation.  We look down upon the Piazza Barberinni & the old Tritan who is always blowing his stream of water into the air, & then catching it again all over his head & back wh. must be pretty well washed in all the years that it has been trickling over him.  Then on the other side of the street2
   
   is the Barberrini Pal.  & sad eyed Beatrice.  By way of variety the other day we went to one of Miss Brewsters receptions.  It was a kind of afternoon tea fight, of [---] & other distinguished persons like ourselves.  Tea, wine, & talk & many beautiful things to look at.   

   Next, we want to go with her.  Forbes the archaeologist to hear tge Forum explained on the latest authorities.  His explanations one said to be intensely interesting.  In fact Rome is so dissipating- there is such an infinity to see & to read & to learn that it is most distracting.  I hope we shall be here three or four weeks longer at least.  In fact it spoils you so for every thing else that it does’nt seem worth while to go any where afterwards.
   
   I ought to have told thee before, how glad I was to get thine & Agnes' letter at Mentone.  I was greatly struck with the advance of the latter's ideas since her first epistle wh. I have carried ever since, in the pocket of my satchel& wh. was composed mostly of kisses.  I see she is now advancing to the doll & the baby house interests of the little girl-hood.  The way the ideas were put together was very amusing- & the circumstantial acct. of the flight of the nurses & the changing reigns of the lady’s of the nursery very graphic.  Give her a kiss, & tell her Auntie has very much obliged for her letter & thought it very interesting.  Also that she must’not cut any more holes in her apron with her little scissors, but must make some nice little paper dresses for the paper dollys that Aunty sent in the letter.   

   22nd.  Just returned from our excursion to the Forum with Mr Forbes- two hours rummage amoung the ruins- intensely interesting- back nearly broken- head ditto.  General conglomeration of podiums, Tabulariums, demolished temples & roman emperors- but quite worth the 4 francs wh. is the price per head at wh. Mr F. deals out his information.  He has been on the spot for some years & actually seen & superintended the excavations- so of course knows a great deal about it, & sees it in a very interesting way- much more so than [Hare?], who is a dreadfully guide booky old fellow I think- Am too tired to write more   

   Please tell Alexis that the letters of credit came a few days since, & we are much obliged for his attention to them.  Love to all.  Tell Cousin Anna I am going yo ans. her letter as soon as I can find time.  Thy affectionate Sister   

   C.C.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1880-06-14
Title: 1880 June 14, Geneva, to Lily

Geneve No 5 Chemin de la Tour. 6.14.1880
   
   My dear Lily,
   
   I expect Caroline will give me "Jesse" as the saying is, if I presume to enter on the stage with her.  Nevertheless as she has occupied the floor for some weeks past in thy favor, I think I shall dare to add a note, tho' she tells me it must be short & upon no account much upon Revenna.  Wherefore conclude she has been expending herself on that ancient & delightful city- & forbear.  Thy letter of-- containing the childrens photographs came tohand two days since, & gave much pleasure.  We think thine, with little Eleanor, is the best of thee we have ever seen, & as to the little E I shd. say she was her Mama in miniature just as little F is his Papa over again only with a few shades more of jollity in his face.  What a sweet little good natur’d  happy kissable face it is & tho' I believe we have understood that he was'nt particularly fond of the latter operation, I doubtnot he has to undergo a good deal of it, & he does'nt look as if he wd. be very refractory under any circumstances, Indeed such a nice little jolly face must be a great comfort to look at, &, I need not suggest for Mamas to be proud of.  I suppose when we get home thee & Alexis will be a grand old couple, sitting up in the middle of your flock, looking very wise & experienced, as you contemplate with "majestic pride" the youthful scions growing & flourishing about you.
   
   I don’t see that thee has a very care worn air however in thy photo-graph.  but on the contrary one might suppose that they cares & worries of domestic life were quite [---] & pleasant.  by what you say I shd. think the heat must have been of that nature wh. wd. have a tendancy to drive you to seek for a cooler clime.  For my part I dont see the use of undertaking to live in such a climate at all, as the chief object of life seems to be with most people to get away from it.  Why not try to live, as I said to the Awbury people yesterday, where such fearful agonies wd. not have contin-ually to be gone thro' with in order to try to effect an escape.
   
   I am very sorry for Madjy's disappointment as her letter to us showed that he hopes were very much set on Europe, & she seems to need some change so much.  It is a great pity they have to undergo such alternations of hope & despair, because they have got [---] on the living side of the Atlantic.  At least it seems to be the side wh. is very much below par with most persons who inhabit it judging from the frantic manner in wh.they rush for the other shore.  The papers say that pretty much Ole America is now on the way to [---].  We concluded that the pleasure to be derived from seeing the play, wh. I think wd. be but doubtful at best, wd. be very much spoiled by the crowd of cooks & other tourists who will infest the country. We therefore have chosen to spend some time insteadin Geneva in French family No 2.  Not that we were disappointed with our experiences in No 1, but that we fell very much in love with this family last fall, when we took some lessons of them.  They are more cultivated people than the others- consequently moreinteresting, & tho' less well off- they are still friench, wh. means that they are practical & know how to be comfortable on a little.  We only pay about half as much as we do at the large Hotels, with more real comfort, beside the very good advantage of hearing the best of french spoken.  The lady has two sons, one a professor in the University & one a clergyman, & two dhrs. all highly educated.  The advantages of the education here for those in moderate circumastances are so very great.  We shall stay probably a month or more until the weather gets to hot wh. does'nt seem very likely- as we are on pretty high ground just outside the city with plenty of green trees & alps in profusion in the distance.
     
   My advice to you is to come & build a cottage on one of the hill sides of Geneva, instead of Woodbourne & get a Savoyard maid as we have, who with her mistresses aid does the work for a household of 9 persons.  We have two dinners daily, of several courses & very well cooked, & how in the world they do it all I cannot conceive.  I suspect that Madam is at the bottom of a good deal, but she does it all with such apparent grace & ease, that one cannot suspect her of cooking.  There are beautiful building lots to be bought here, by the way, on the high ground along the town with the Lake on one side & Mt. Blanc on the other, & there are many beautiful gardens & suburban residences- wh. are quite unseen & [---] by the mere passing traveller.  If it was’nt for those children of yours whom we want to see!- I shd. be quite tempted to invest in one of these little spots & settle down for the rest of my days.  Will thee please ask Alexis to inquire of cousin FRC if he rec'd a letter fm. me posted June 8. containing a cheque for $200.  I also posted one on the 13 June to M.S.C. containing cheque for $100.  As there is some risk of these things being lost shd. be very much obliged if A or some body wd. advertise Provident Life & Trust Company of [---] and [---]. of these two cheques payable to the order of the above mention’d persons.  Hoping soon to have news of you in a cooler clime & under Mrs. Hotchkiss' hospitable roof.  Ever thy affec- sister C.  Ever so many kisses to dear little Agnes & to theothers as for as appreciated by them.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Recipient:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Date: 1833-06-25
Title: 1833 July [June] 25, Bloomsdale, to William D. Cope

Bloomsdale July [June] 25th. 1833.
   
   Thee will probably be somewhat surprised in receiving a communication from me, in reply to thine- but I have determined notwithstanding my extreme diffidence to employ pen & paper- in order- if possible to dispel some unpleasant and I may ass unhappy associations connected with thy last visit.  That I did feel and evince some repugnance to having a private conversation with thee- I freely acknowledge.  Why I did so- it is impossible for me to explain- unless it was because I supposed the one- we had previously had- was sufficient to elucidate all difficulties- and therefore a second one useless.- I regret now such a thought should have entered my mind- and why I felt it painful- to have a further explanation- when I saw it wd. afford thee a satisfaction- is a mystery I do not yet understand; but as all regrets are unavailing- I will not strengthen them by indulging in, or dwelling upon them.-  That my manners may have appeared in some instances- as they says, cold and repulsive, I am sensible- without my intending them to have that effect, at any rate- let me assure thee, it was very far from my intention, to wound or hurt thy feelings for even as I wd. like my own respected- have I endeavoured to consider thine.------ I certainly meant to imply from what I said- I considered thee in fault, in not having sent me any intimation of thy feelings with resepct to me, throughout the whole seven months of thy absense; most assuredly- absense & silence were never calculated to cherish and increase a preference, which under different- and more auspicious circumstances might have arisen; & as thee gave me no intimation I was not forgotten- I had no alternative left, but to believe as I did- thee had abandoned all idea of further intercourse- well then- considering myself slighted, and neglected, how could reserve and coldness of manner be entirely avoided?  In extending my forgiveness, I really thought I had something to forgive- but it seems- according to the light in which thee views it- there was no fault committed- and consequenlty no "need of forgiveness."  However different thy views of human nature- and the ways of the world, are from my own- I must still see those actions- in the light of errors- but will consider them as unintentional- and arising from inexperience.  With respect to our correspondence motives of delicacy alone- prevented me from consenting to it- If thee had thought correctly about it- theewd. have supposed, as our friendship & intimacy advanced those feelings- wd. have been overcome- and however great an effort I still think it wd. be- to maintain a correspondence with a gentleman even after an engagement, I should consider it a duty- an obligation, not to be dispensed with.-  I do not remember thy suggesting any other mode of intercourse between us- than the one just spoken of- at all events neither of those mentioned by thee- wd. have been very suitable, or meet with my concurrence.  I acquit myself- if thee will not do it- of all design at "flirtation & coquetry," however some of my sex may indulge in it at the expense of yours- I am very sure- I do not belong to that class of cruel coquettes- who make a boast of their conquests- & offer encouragement where none is meant.  In writing this letter- I trust I am not guilt of an improper act- I thought considering all things- it was nothing more than thy due- & in doing it- my mind which was before ill at ease- is put comparatively at rest.-  I beg thee will destroy this letter- and forget anything but friendship ever passed between us.-  I have now only to add an assurance of respect & esteem & how earnestly I wish thy happiness, thee can never know, unless thee can read the heart of thy sincere friend
   S.....
   
   No eye but thy own must rest upon the contents of this sheet.6.

   William D. Cope.
   Care T.P. Cope Esq.
   Fourth St.
   Philadelphia
   
   From S.
   dated July 25. 1833.- should be June 25.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Recipient:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Date: 1833-10-17
Title: 1833 October 17, Bloomsdale, to William D. Cope

Bloomsdale Oct. 17th 1833.
   
   "I long have thought my absent friends, a something to have sent you,
   Tho' it should serve nae other ends, than just a kind memento."
   
   Thy letter bearing date of twenty seventh of last month- came to hand after some detention- and has determined me to set about writing immediately- as I owe it, both to my duty, and my feelings, to send a speedy reply to thy communication- containing intelligence of a nature- which astonished & vexed me not a little.  I was astonished, thee should suppose me to be the author of that document, styled by thee, the "witty letter;" and vexed, that any one should descend to such meanness- as thus to endeavour to practice upon thy credulity.  As for me, I must disclaim all knowledge or connection with it in any way- and I do not envy the person who could be guilty of such an action- any of the wit it displayed- or grammatical learning- which if I understood thee rightly it is woefully deficient in.
   
   By the bye, I am much indebted for the compliment, of having so fine a piece of wit and learning, attributed as the production of my hand and pen- at the same time I will frankly own- from some expressions in thy letter- I think the shadow of a doubt more than [---] crossed thy mind as to my being in reality, the author.
   
   And now the question is- who can have been the offenders and against whom are we to direct our honest indignation? for I assure thee I feel no small share- I have not the slightest idea who it can be and yet some one it wd. seem, who had some knowledge of the circumstances- must have had a hand in it.  I think the want of learning displayed- could only have been a part of their plan to avoid detection- and not from real ignorance of the rules of grammar.  I've a womans curiosity to see the letter, and know all about it.
whether the writing resembles mine- if 'twas dated B........ with my name appended to it; all of which enquired I hope to have answered.
   
   The says in thy letter- ro please the ladies- thee must not broach serious subjects- if thee wishes to please my ladyship- and thee has professed as much- thee may make choice of any subject- whether "sober prose, or prose run mad"- I shall not object to anything and 'tis quite a mistaken idea- that ladies are never pleased with serious subjects- notwithstanding the author of the witty letter to the contrary.- Although thee may think there is very little like sobriety, or a disposition to moralize, in my character- I think my heart can duly appreciate and respond to good sentiments, whenever it is my good fortune to meet with them.
   
   Have we not had a very delightful Autumn?  such beautiful weather for riding or walking- and yet we have not availed ourselves of the bright sunshineand pleasant air- to make any rambling excursions in the woods or along by the banks of the river- the scattered foliage is already strewn upon the pathway- and in a few short days- we shall have the bare and leafless branches- telling us of the desolation of natures beauties.  Spring has always been my favorite season- but in all its gaiety and animation- it could not spread a scene more showy or more varied than the one now before us- such a happy blending of colours- but we have no beautiful hills or fertile [---]- where nature at this season appears so prominently beautiful.  In the "far off country" which thee inhabits- there must be every variety and beauty of scene- but then the distance is such a barrier- so many hundred miles from all ones friends-  I almost wonder thee has not been tempted to move within the reach of those thee holds most dear---
   
   I am sorry thee has experienced any uneasiness onaccount of having read to me those New York letters;- since it is so- I regret thee favourd me with a sight- at the same time I feel very certain of not having betrayed the confidence reposed in me- and have not the most distant idea who the lady can be.  I think the young lady- with so many [trunks?] – must have played the coquette very skillfuly- to have secured so many offers in so short a time- she knew her power I suppose- and was determined to excersize it- at the expense of her numerous admirers- Before I close my letter I must not forget to acknowledge the receipt of two newspapers- sometime in the month of August- for which accept my thanks the tale which they contained (the title of it I forget just now) I quite admired.--  The other day I met with something which pleased me exceedingly, in one of [Lardners?] papers.- It was an essay on lovers- and described the different kinds of lovers, most admirably- I recognized more than one or two, or three of my acquaintance in the descriptions.  I wd. like them to see it.-  I must now conclude my letter- as I have already written more- than I expected to- or that can afford thee much interest in the perusal.  with [---] of    rememberance-
   I remain sincerely thy friend,
   S.....
   
   Thy letters have all been duly received- Pray admire the beautiful direction- especially the D.10 Mo. 24 at Montrose
   
   William D. Cope.
   Woodbourne
   Susquehanna Coty.
   
   From S.
   date Oct. 17. 1833.- ans'd 10 mo. 18. '33  

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Recipient:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Date: 1834-03-10
Title: 1834 March 10, Bloomsdale, to Wm D Cope

I am giving thee dear William- a proof of my sincere and unabated affection- in this early replying to thy most welcome letter of the 8th which only came to hand this morning- thee may be sure its arrival was awaited by me, with more than usual impatience- I could not believe another week wd. be suffered to elapse- without the accustomed message of love, and rememberence,- and every day I wd. say to myself well- I certainly will hear to day- but very many times have I been doomed to suffer disappointment- how however- I am relieved by the actual presence of the well known hand writing- and will thus evince my greatful feelings- in its early acknowledgement.-  Let me tell thee dear William- I think thee greatly undervalues thy epistolary talents, thy letters cannot be any thing but interesting to me- and if I acknowledge them to be so- why that,- must be as much as thee can desire- as for my own I have long since despaired of arriving at any thing like excellence in the art,- and the only and slight merit- if merit it may called- which they posess- is the spirit of affection which they [---], & which prompts me to the undertaking I have not the least partiality for the employment thee knows- and often with merely for the purpose of receiving in return.-  To day I was [---] gratified & delighted- for independent of the pleasure thine afforded me- there was one from my dear sister Caroline.  I will not tell thee what she says, now- but when thee comes- thee shall see it.- I do not know that I recollect to observation thee alludes to- as having been made by me- when last here- at least I am not certain what it was.- The will find in me as usual- a very ready and willing listener to all thee may have to communicate- I hope my presence will not prove talismanic and cause thee to forget what thee had to say- I did not find it necessary to apply to Father for information respecting the time of holding our monthly meeting- it has just passed, last week- and the next oneoccurs- on the ninth of April- The [---] is- the first fourth day after the first second day in the month.- I had a sweet little note from cousin Edith the other day- it contained an invitiation for us to come, or rather go out to make them a visit- I knew it wd. not be very pleasant just now and in my answer, declined the invitation for myself- and promised to deliver the one to thee when next we met- Edith styles thee, her "cousin elect" already.-  What an appalling spectacle the burning of the Wm Penn must have been- It will have an effect I think, to increase the fears of [---] travellers-.  How sorrowful I felt, upon learning of the death- of R.B. [Thornson?], during her life we had each of us, made attempts to become better acquainted- but were never very successful- and now in her death, I feel as if I had almost lost a dear friend- her family will feel her loss to be irreparable- I should like to have some particulars of her death- I trust it was a happy one- holding out consolation to her afflicted and berieved family-.  Dearest Wm. I must now say farewell! as it is fast-approaching [---] 6 o'clock- and I am encroaching not a little [---] the time usually devoted to the indifference of my friends [---]- with a thousand assurances of undiminished affection
   remain as ever thy own
   S.
   
   March 10. 1834.
   
   P.S. If thee wd. like to avoid the observation of a certain person in B. who is always upon the look out- thee can do it by going up the street where the market is and round by the [?-nch]*- I hear of our engagement from all quarters- will thee excuse the brevity of this letter- I write this evening because time will not permit to morrow.  again
   Adieu!
   *tis very little further
   
   I cannot make the direction come in the right place.from S. [1834]
   dated 3 mo. 10. 1834.
   
   [---]no 6
   
   Wm D Cope
   36 N. 4th
   Philadelphia

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Recipient:  Sarah Miller Walker:  1799-1874
Date: 1873-01-27
Title: 1873 January 27, Connymede, to Sarah Walker

Connymede 1 mo 27
   2d day
   
   My dear friend
   Sarah Walker
   
   I little while ago Carry handed me thy letter to read- which was received today, and dated 1 mo 22d and 24th and asked if I would write to thee.  From the tenor of thy letter thee seems to think there has been an improvement is Uncle Wm's condition.  But though for a little while, since being in bed- he was able to take cream again, to some little amount, he is now very low indeed, and taking only a very little wine, about a teaspoonful at a time.  TheDr told them he might not live through last night.  I came over yesterday afternoon.  About 7 O'clk  the girls and Edgar were around his bed.  He was asking about one or two of them; and who it was at the foot of the bed?  when told it was Nettie, said he could’nt see- still I think there was but little light in the room- The remark was made that he had a good many kind children round him, I think he tried hard to say yes- but seemed unable, something like a slight spasm coming on, from that time for a while, it seemed as if he might be dying.  but he again revived, and was able to speak out quite loud during the night.  calling outhis wishes he does not seem able to modulate his voice.  He is very childlike and dependant upon those around him.  How frail we are truly!  Human nature seems to be utter weakness at such times.  He  has been generally & uncomplaining during his sickness, although within a day or two there has been some moaning, apparently from weakness he dont speak as if he suffers much.  He seems very appreciative of the attention of his friends.  I do not think any of them now look for his recovery.  And from present appearances, it does not seem likely the end is very far off and yet I feel as if it was hard to know how long it may be.  He is very very sick looking now.  By dear aunt Susans removal, pooruncle Wm seems of course more thrown upon his children, And it is indeed pleasant to see their kindness & attention.  dear Clemmie especially, [*] but perhaps I should not draw any comparison, but she is the oldest and has felt perhaps more responsibility, especially before her father was confined to bed, and others had stepped in to assist.  The girls seem pretty well and much composed.  Nettie is suffering with headache to day.  and Clemmie was a day or two ago.  Edgar does not look very well to me but he was up a good deal last night.  Alexis seems very well.  Of course thee knows the girls have been passing through a great deal.  but I hope the Lord has been near may an eternal inheritance be granted uncle Wm if he is taken
   
   *more striking with Clemmie than Carry & Nettie, because of her former shrinkingClemmie seemed much distressed and unnerved last evening, when her father seemed to be reviving again, and she had been in hopes it was almost over.  His groaning was distressing  to her.  but I do not know that he was suffering so much.  If it was suffering, I should suppose it was from weakness and distress.  Cousin Frank and Mary Yarnall have been very kind and attentive.  We are expecting brother Thos out to night.  I will now close this biding thee farewell.  I fear this is a very different letter from what it might have been had one of the girls written it.*  Affectionately thy friend
   
   R Anna Cope
   
   *they perhaps would have been netter able to tell of their ownsorrow.  I fear I am dificient in entering into the feelings of others, as some do
   
   Dear R.A. Cope
   with [---] of her
   dear Uncle passing
   away-
   1.31.73-

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Recipient:  Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas) Cope:  1850-1883
Date: 1876-04-14
Title: 1876 April 14, Delaware Water Gap, to Alexis & Lillie

Del Water Gap 4 mo 14th
   1876
   
   My dear Alexis & Lillie
   
   Shall your tardy Aunt Anne try to write you a bit of a letter from this substantial land perhaps to meet you in the land of antiquity, art, and beauty.  I cannot describe Pompeii, I cannot say I have been where Paul landed so long, long ago.  Yet give me the land of protestant vigorous American for my home, before stale Itily [sic]!  do you think that very unappreciative?  Do not suppose I think there is nothing of interest there.  There seems to me much of the spirit of this world which you may see when abroad, more than in our more practical land.
   
   Let me tell you I have thought of you and have been looking towards writing sometime.  I [---] say how gratifying it was toreceive  the little card remembrance sent from Mentone long since to me, I have been long in acknowledging it, but it was truly acceptable to Aunty  I have an idea I sent a message about it lately in some one elses letter.  As my own writing had been and seemed to be a poor dependance I had a short attack of sickness lately,- though I have not been very mighty for some time- and Dr Darrah suggested my going to the shore, but I prefered coming here.  I have Mary Creeth with me, she is pleasant company.  And I am glad to have the opportunity of hearing about dear uncle Alfred.  She seems to have thought very much of him.  The old home as it was with its inmates will be forever gone when you return- if so permitted- We know all is so uncertain.  What a wipingout!  James and Louise left for Oxford last 7th day week.  Mary Creeth thinks James much improved.  And we may hope his good traits will appear to his advantage.  He took articles of clothing with him belonging to his parents and one or two articles which he took of his fathers I was glad to hear of; it seemed to show an affectionate feeling connected with the old association.  Perhaps you heard that Philip and Lillie Garrett expect to take Fairfield this summer.  And John Biddle take Philip's house in Germantown this summer after it is vacated.I find it does not well answer to write on both sides of my paper so take another sheet.
   
   The streams are so beautiful this time we have been here, so much water & charmingly clear.  We have driven several times.  And I hope we are both gaining.  Has mother told you of the prospect of my keeping house at Atlantic City this summer?  With Jane Taylor for housekeeper.  If I get there I hope some of the family may feel it attractive enough to accept hopsitality under my roof.  The house is a private one, on the Avenue next above the beacth & between the Surf House and Denis' Cottage.  It has three rooms on each floor, and backs towards the ocean, with not as open a view of the rolling deep as I could desire.  What will be the result remains to be known.  Whether we get establishedand if so, how things will turn out?  I may not be there all the time even though I should be the back bone of The Rest by the sea.  Now my foreign relations dont feel too saucy about this sandy place.  I know it is not Mentone or the Bay of Naples.  But indeed I wish it had some rocks for the waves to dash over, and some greenness to add its beauty.
   
   St. Cloud Hotel Phila [---] I came direct to this place from the Water Gap and my own dear Lillie thy own nice letter to me came to my hand here.   I was glad I already commenced a letter to thee before thine arrived that I might be credited for my intention or wish to write whether there was any letter or not for me.  The Yearly Meeting opened yesterday, but I did not leave the Water Gap in time to attend the first sitting.  I arrived last evening & Madgiemet me here and stayed with me that night.  It is less exertion to remain in the city if you attend the meeting.
   
   19th The date of my letter will be rather old but perhaps it will make little difference to you.  Ellie came to stay with me tonight and George took tea with us, they have gone to call at George's uncle's.  Brother T. and sister E. Madgie and Clemmie dined with me to day also.  Mary expects to come tomorrow.  Poor Madgie is again troubled with her eye.  it looks very badly and it seems to be a serious affection which she is subject to.  Dr Norris allows her to go out though.  Anthony K. created an excitement in meeting to day, in persevering in reading a chapter in the Bible, suffering no indifference of friends to stop him said he had got the book 3 years ago with the intention of reading the chapter in meeting.  saying hethought he now had the strength to read it and expected to read it through, which I understood he did  I forget the chapter, but understood it was a prophecy against the unfaithful shepherds.  No one seconded him in this thing, at any rate not in meeting and I heard they afterwards had one of the best meetings they had had at all.  It is time for me to prepare for bed, I will bid you an affectionate farewell.  Give my love to Alfred.  And with love to you your affectionately interested
    
   Aunt Anne

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Ruthanna Cope:  1834-1879
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)  Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1876-04-14

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Henry Cope:  1793-1865
Date: 1837-10-28
Title: 1837 October 28, Harrisburg, to Henry

Harrisburg 10mo 28.  1837-
   
   Dear Henry
   
   From thy letter of yesterday I perceive that doubts still exist as to the apprehended piracy- & the papers which reach us are full of contradictions & vain conjectures- at one time we were assured that the informtation had reached Norfolk about the same time it reached N Castle- & after that statement had passed current for some days we find by a Balte. paper that the first knowledge they had of it in Norfolk was the 25th in the afternoon.  The pilots if I recollect first reported the capturing schooner to be full of men & black sided- it now seems they kept so far away that they could not see whether the ship was bright sided- still they alledge to have distinctly seen the cross in her foretop sail- This circumstance is the most striking, & yet it is possible that at their distance they might be mistaken even in that.  I observe a story has been circulate in NYork of an oyster boat having supplied the ship at Sea- & that is believed, contradicted & reiterated- If that were true it wd. indeed be some comfort, as it might accot. for the whole affair, making some allowances for discrepancies.  It is altogether a painful subject, & has caused me much perhaps useless anxiety.  but no benefit can arise from despondency.  & it is our duty to submit to the Divine Will- & our best interest too- Let us then hope while hope we may-29th
   
   The letter from Capn. Miller which I read in the papers that reached us last evening, stating that information had been recd. from the Break Water by a Schr. just arrived, that she has passed the Susqa. of Chincoteague, a shr. along side of her- if true, wd. seem to put an end to doubt- But why did not Miller mention the name of the Schr. at the Break Water.  & how did that Schr. know what he saw was the Susqa.  If the ship was in the situation mentioned, & at the time mentioned, it argues a most extraordinary degree of hardy hood in the Pirate.
   
   Yesterday commenced the battle on the Judiciary.  Judge Hopkinson opened the debate- in a masterly manner- he spoke for 3 hours, & then gave way to a motion for adjournment- of course he will proceed with his argument 2d. day morning.  I hear it will prove unavailing- so many of the Convention being resolved on a change.  The discussion will no doubt be protracted thoughout all this week, perhaps even another- so many will try to distinguish themselves on this fruitful subject.  Feeling so much disappointed by the issue of the militia question I can no longer hope for much good from this Convention.  Indeed I care very little now how bad they may make a constitution- the worse perhaps the better-as the people will be the more likely to, reject it.  Earl made his appearance yesterday and forthwith commenced taking notes of Hopkinsons speech- He will attempt a reply- so will I suspect Ingersoll- but the most powerful antagonist will be Woodward- from Luzerne.  He is plausible, argumentative & fluent, but with all a thorough radical & in my judgement a most mischevous politician.  Doran & others are still absent- When I shall be relieved from my unpleasant imprisonment I cannot say.
   
   The morng the Thermometer at sunrise was 35.
   
   With love to Rachel & the children
   I am
    affectionately
   
   Thos. P. Cope
   
   Please say to Wm Evans that I have just recd. his Note with the Pamphlets, of wh. I shall endeavor to make a proper use- but as that subject has been dismissed for the present, & the mind of the members are filled with the Judiciary question I fear were I now to distribute them- they wd. just be glanced at- thrown aside & forgotten- The subject will come up again on 2d. reading & then may be a suitable time for their distribution.  My own fears are however that Friends have little more to hope for from this Convention.Thos. P. Cope
   
   Henry Cope
   Philadelphia
   
   [TP Cope Harrisburg
   10mo 28 1837]

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Recipient:  Alfred Cope:  1806-1875
Date: 1840-08-25
Title: 1840 August 25, Newport, to Alfred

Newport 8mo 25. 1840
   
   Dear Alfred,
   
   It is growing towards being after sunset, but while Job is making arrangements for our departure tomorrow morning in the Massacheusetts Steamer for Providence, it falls to my lot to drop a line by Wm who is intended send with the Carriage & Horses next day, by return of the same Steamer to NYk thence to proceed on his way to Philada.-  You will all be gratified to hear of thy dear mothers improved health, & also of Eleanors- altho we have experienced hot weather for some days, & have qualms as to the propriety of throwing ourselves into a more heated atmosphere-  Stephen P. Morris arrived here yesterday from Providence, & reports the thermometer to have been up to 95 the day before.  The air since dinner to day has become cooler, & we may reasonably hope will improve a pace shortlty-  Other things change as well as the weather- & now after writing so far, a bell man announces that a Balloon Steamer is to be here tomorrow from P. & return again at 3 AM-  We wished originally to go by her- but she has undergone repairs, & there was this morning no certainty when she wd. be here-  We therefore had made up our minds to go by the Massachusetts between 6 & 7 AM-  We intend to visit N. Bedford, Boston, Wooster &c &c.  & stop at Hartford Ct where letters may meet us on our way home, not later than 10 days from today-
   
   We have visited most of the Lions- & among them the Library, where rest the remains of divers elderly volumes-  The discoveries of the Icelanders are there deposited-  We met in the St a certain antiquarian, named Bull, with whom we held learned converse on those discoveries-  On asking him if he had heard of the learned northener who had found a stone with Runic Characters- a temple, & an image representing the Scandanavian God Thor, in Brazil- He said he had not- & then added, "so long as they confined themselves to N. Am, I was willing to concede that point to them- but now that they are going to claim S. Am too, I wont believe any of it"-  The old man may have read our couplet- "They lose the whole who claim too much
    
   As Simon Snyder said in Dutch- And the Danes may now hang up their fiddle, & content themselves with their own Icy shores-The drives abt. Newport are fine- but we have too much dust- the grass is nevertheless very fresh- & the fields are beautiful- We visited a tract at Brenins Point, I side of the Island, & skirted by the Ocean- & a more fertile splendid farm, I do not remember ever to have seen-  They use the seaweed abundantly, as a manure- & also a fish called Manhayden- dragged from the Ocean by nets, & sold at 14 Cts a Bbl- They are very oily- but I do not admire the filthy practice of strewing them over the fields to contaminiate the air-  The bathing here is very good & Job & I use it freely- while mother & E continue their purifications in the warm salt bath-  Among our numerous lodgers we have had Abraham Knickerboker & wife- He the lineal descendant of the true Dietrich- & has his residence at the very spot described by Irving, whose description he says is very correct-  He is an intelligent and well informed man, speaking the English fluently- & his wife interested us very much, by her smiley face, he goodly appearance & good sense-  The good man himself is out of health, & his loving spouse seems very uneasy abt. him-  On leaving us they each gave us a cordial invitation to visit them at their home in the romantic poetical village of Schaghticoke-
     
   While writing Elenor bids me say- you have among you, used her [---] badly, in not even noticing a Letter- wh he took trouble- pains taking man- to endite to some of you- but as she has stepped out- I do not know when manufactured, nor to whom directed- Cara’s epistle of odds & ends- like this of mine- has been received, & was, for her comfort, very satisfactory-
   
   Having in council duly convened decided to go by the Baloon to morrow.  I have come to the conclusion to rest for the present from my labours- to resume if needs be, in the morning but not until I say that we this afternoon paid another visit to the afflicted family mentioned before- none of them are better- the mother indeed much worse- she seems destined we think to take her departure to a better world very soon-
   
   26th
   
   A bright cool air promising a pleasant [---] to Providence- A boarding House forms a pretty good epitomy of life on a larger scale- One generation passeth away & is succeeded by another- so old faces depart [---] & new ones present themselves- In all things said the great Apostle I am instructed- & so we may be even in this day- did not time hurry us with such Rail Road speed as scarcely to permit us more than a glance- Among our imates is a certain Judge Balch of Florida, a thorough going Loco- & reviler of sacred things- He attempted to show that the creation was the result of natural causes, combining & operating on each other- Moses' account he calls a fiction,the mere offspring of a fervid imagination.  He abounds in anecdote- mostly I suspect the product of his own fancy- His atheism offended Knickerbocker much- it shd. be Knickerbacker- marble baker-  I joked & talked politics with the Judge for a while- but finding when hard pressed he became rude, I quit it- yet shd. be amused with his profundity of discourse could I have faith in his word-  He stated for instance that he had furnished the Bk. US. with the first list of Directors for the branch at Nashville- all of whom "Me. Biddle appointed"- He did not however know that while making this statement to me & others he was addressing a man, who had been not only a Director of the Parent Bank at the time, but chairman of the Cme. of elections, who alone reported all nominations of branch directors, to the Board, & who knew the statement to be untrue-  I did not undeceive him, but left him to the enjoyment of his own fiction.  We had a short visit from a mercht. of Havanna- Cpa!  Clapp of the House of Drake, & Co an intelligent man, who, inter alia, gave me a piece of information entirely new, at least to myself- He says that a company of individuals, Spaniards & others, residents in Cuba have purchased a large tract of sand from a native Prince, in Africa, 150 miles square- wh. is to be cultivated with Coffe Sugar &c for commerce- the natives being the Labourers- should the designs of the Comp.y be honest, & fairly carried out- it will carry out Buxtons Scheme, & prove a great blessing to Africa- but considering of whom the Co. is composed, I cannot avoid fears.  C says the Coffee Plantations in Cuba yield but 6 or 7 Pct. while their Sugar Plantations give them 10- the slaves working 14 hours of the 24- The labour is so severe that when suspended, to take food, he has known the slave to fall asleep while on his feet, & prefer rest, even to eating- the waste of life is consequently great.
   
   The change in the weather has produced its usual effect- my E has a headache but will doubtless be better when the sun advances- by the way we have had but one or two foggy mornings since our arrival-  Job & I mean to experiment on a warm bath this morning deeming the sea air is too fresh for our skins-  Love to all- & sympathy in the bargain for any that have tooth ache or the like-
   Thos. P. Cope
   
   As there are so many at Lincolns who have nothing to do, we have half a mind & almost tother half tooto get our dander up for their wicked neglect open in not writing-
   
   I had just sealed this letter when Henry's of the 22d arrived- & have accordingly reopened it to make the acknowledgment- It is gratifying to learn of your continued good condition & of his having parted with his tooth ache- a most troublesome compassion-  I had not heard of any defaltations in the Kent.y Bank- nothing short of making such crimes felony can prevent them-  We have indeed arrived at a such state of morals-  Finding that the next mail goes via Providnce, I shall carry this letter there- & if anything worth penning occur
   
   will make proper not thereof-  We rece.d Franks letter of the 22d recording his & Toms marvellous escape from Hicksite contamination- tho I think they might have broken bread with J.B without fatal consequences-
   
   26th
   
   Here we are at Providence, after a run of abt. 2 hours from Newport-  We lodge at the City Hotel, a large & apparently well regulated House- we have formed no acquaintences but shall probably see some of our friends during the day- Our run up the Narragansett was not very interesting- the shores presenting little variety-  Bristol, Warren & a few neat villages were in view, but trees, those grand ornaments of nature, & wh. impart so much beauty to rural scenery & to City & Town comfort are sadly wanting-  This morn is bright & cool-  As yet we have formed no plans for the day-  When all are up we will hold a councilThe Town meeting to control the Courts is of bad omen- especially as the Judges are by our new Constitution subject for their offices to the popular will- These doings tend to anarchy and despotism, the fruit of Jacksonism- Fanny Wrightism &c[T.P.C. 8/26- Prove- -]
   
   [8/28]
   
   Henry & Alfred Cope
   Philada

Date: 1840-08-25
Title: 1840 August 25, Newport, to Alfred

Newport 8mo 25. 1840
   
   Dear Alfred,
   
   It is growing towards being after sunset, but while Job is making arrangements for our departure tomorrow morning in the Massacheusetts Steamer for Providence, it falls to my lot to drop a line by Wm who is intended send with the Carriage & Horses next day, by return of the same Steamer to NYk thence to proceed on his way to Philada.-  You will all be gratified to hear of thy dear mothers improved health, & also of Eleanors- altho we have experienced hot weather for some days, & have qualms as to the propriety of throwing ourselves into a more heated atmosphere-  Stephen P. Morris arrived here yesterday from Providence, & reports the thermometer to have been up to 95 the day before.  The air since dinner to day has become cooler, & we may reasonably hope will improve a pace shortlty-  Other things change as well as the weather- & now after writing so far, a bell man announces that a Balloon Steamer is to be here tomorrow from P. & return again at 3 AM-  We wished originally to go by her- but she has undergone repairs, & there was this morning no certainty when she wd. be here-  We therefore had made up our minds to go by the Massachusetts between 6 & 7 AM-  We intend to visit N. Bedford, Boston, Wooster &c &c.  & stop at Hartford Ct where letters may meet us on our way home, not later than 10 days from today-
   
   We have visited most of the Lions- & among them the Library, where rest the remains of divers elderly volumes-  The discoveries of the Icelanders are there deposited-  We met in the St a certain antiquarian, named Bull, with whom we held learned converse on those discoveries-  On asking him if he had heard of the learned northener who had found a stone with Runic Characters- a temple, & an image representing the Scandanavian God Thor, in Brazil- He said he had not- & then added, "so long as they confined themselves to N. Am, I was willing to concede that point to them- but now that they are going to claim S. Am too, I wont believe any of it"-  The old man may have read our couplet- "They lose the whole who claim too much
    
   As Simon Snyder said in Dutch- And the Danes may now hang up their fiddle, & content themselves with their own Icy shores-The drives abt. Newport are fine- but we have too much dust- the grass is nevertheless very fresh- & the fields are beautiful- We visited a tract at Brenins Point, I side of the Island, & skirted by the Ocean- & a more fertile splendid farm, I do not remember ever to have seen-  They use the seaweed abundantly, as a manure- & also a fish called Manhayden- dragged from the Ocean by nets, & sold at 14 Cts a Bbl- They are very oily- but I do not admire the filthy practice of strewing them over the fields to contaminiate the air-  The bathing here is very good & Job & I use it freely- while mother & E continue their purifications in the warm salt bath-  Among our numerous lodgers we have had Abraham Knickerboker & wife- He the lineal descendant of the true Dietrich- & has his residence at the very spot described by Irving, whose description he says is very correct-  He is an intelligent and well informed man, speaking the English fluently- & his wife interested us very much, by her smiley face, he goodly appearance & good sense-  The good man himself is out of health, & his loving spouse seems very uneasy abt. him-  On leaving us they each gave us a cordial invitation to visit them at their home in the romantic poetical village of Schaghticoke-
     
   While writing Elenor bids me say- you have among you, used her [---] badly, in not even noticing a Letter- wh he took trouble- pains taking man- to endite to some of you- but as she has stepped out- I do not know when manufactured, nor to whom directed- Cara’s epistle of odds & ends- like this of mine- has been received, & was, for her comfort, very satisfactory-
   
   Having in council duly convened decided to go by the Baloon to morrow.  I have come to the conclusion to rest for the present from my labours- to resume if needs be, in the morning but not until I say that we this afternoon paid another visit to the afflicted family mentioned before- none of them are better- the mother indeed much worse- she seems destined we think to take her departure to a better world very soon-
   
   26th
   
   A bright cool air promising a pleasant [---] to Providence- A boarding House forms a pretty good epitomy of life on a larger scale- One generation passeth away & is succeeded by another- so old faces depart [---] & new ones present themselves- In all things said the great Apostle I am instructed- & so we may be even in this day- did not time hurry us with such Rail Road speed as scarcely to permit us more than a glance- Among our imates is a certain Judge Balch of Florida, a thorough going Loco- & reviler of sacred things- He attempted to show that the creation was the result of natural causes, combining & operating on each other- Moses' account he calls a fiction,the mere offspring of a fervid imagination.  He abounds in anecdote- mostly I suspect the product of his own fancy- His atheism offended Knickerbocker much- it shd. be Knickerbacker- marble baker-  I joked & talked politics with the Judge for a while- but finding when hard pressed he became rude, I quit it- yet shd. be amused with his profundity of discourse could I have faith in his word-  He stated for instance that he had furnished the Bk. US. with the first list of Directors for the branch at Nashville- all of whom "Me. Biddle appointed"- He did not however know that while making this statement to me & others he was addressing a man, who had been not only a Director of the Parent Bank at the time, but chairman of the Cme. of elections, who alone reported all nominations of branch directors, to the Board, & who knew the statement to be untrue-  I did not undeceive him, but left him to the enjoyment of his own fiction.  We had a short visit from a mercht. of Havanna- Cpa!  Clapp of the House of Drake, & Co an intelligent man, who, inter alia, gave me a piece of information entirely new, at least to myself- He says that a company of individuals, Spaniards & others, residents in Cuba have purchased a large tract of sand from a native Prince, in Africa, 150 miles square- wh. is to be cultivated with Coffe Sugar &c for commerce- the natives being the Labourers- should the designs of the Comp.y be honest, & fairly carried out- it will carry out Buxtons Scheme, & prove a great blessing to Africa- but considering of whom the Co. is composed, I cannot avoid fears.    Thos. P. Cope
   
   As there are so many at Lincolns who have nothing to do, we have half a mind & almost tother half tooto get our dander up for their wicked neglect open in not writing-

   will make proper not thereof-  We rece.d Franks letter of the 22d recording his & Toms marvellous escape from Hicksite contamination- tho I think they might have broken bread with J.B without fatal consequences-
   
   26th
   
   Here we are at Providence, after a run of abt. 2 hours from Newport-  We lodge at the City Hotel, a large & apparently well regulated House- we have formed no acquaintences but shall probably see some of our friends during the day- Our run up the Narragansett was not very interesting- the shores presenting little variety-  Bristol, Warren & a few neat villages were in view, but trees, those grand ornaments of nature, & wh. impart so much beauty to rural scenery & to City & Town comfort are sadly wanting-  This morn is bright & cool-  As yet we have formed no plans for the day-  When all are up we will hold a councilThe Town meeting to control the Courts is of bad omen- especially as the Judges are by our new Constitution subject for their offices to the popular will- These doings tend to anarchy and despotism, the fruit of Jacksonism- Fanny Wrightism &c[T.P.C. 8/26- Prove- -]
   
   [8/28]
   
   Henry & Alfred Cope
   Philada

Title: 1852 July 17, to Clemmie, Woodbourne

Philadelphia, 7mo 17, 1852
   
   Dear Clemmie,
   Grandfather desired me to acknowledge the receipt of thy acceptable letter of last seventh day. I am sorry for thy sake that it has not fallen into better hand, but if thee will believe that I have the will to send thee such a letter as would give thee a great deal of pleasure, I will rely upon the interest it will have for thee as coming from among and giving thee a great deal of pleasure. I will rely upon the interest it will have for thee as coming from among and giving thee perhaps, the latest news of some of those who think so much of thee. Anne and I entirely agree with thee in considering that the pleasantest part of the days journey was when we were all traveling together. We ran off the track about half an hour after we parted and were four hours in a pretty hot place before we were on our way again. If we had foreseen that we were to pass nearly the whole day on the road might have he fellow travelers a greater distance and lightened me and others burdens. Thee must have had a very tiresome journey all the way home Henry Drinker tells us thee had to ride from Wilkes-Barre in the hot sun in an open wagon: he thinks they did much better. When thee comes down next winder, take thou Scranton unto. We are glad to hear that thee friend Uncle William so much better and the rest all well. Grandfather seems stronger and generally better than when he fist came out in the country- He sends his love to thee and all the family. Aunt Caroline, Frank and Ellie are at Cape May. I forget whetherthey went before thee left: they wrote several days ago that Ellie’s general health was improved We have heard indirectly that Mary was unwell- Julia has gone to Reading for a few weeks. Aunt Mary returned to Jersey yesterday I believe- She was kept in turn an account of Elizabeth’s mother having an attack very much like if not really cholera. She was very ill one night: they have gone to Cape May since with Henry and Ellie. The three families that live in that unnamed corner of this country that is so hard to find am pretty much as the left them they all send their love. Elizabeth says she would be very glad if thee would write to her if thee fells so inclined. Please tell Uncle William that a package for Grandfather by Henry Drinker came safe to hand the morning- Uncle Alfred has taken the letter out to him. He comes in and spends every "third-day" in town.   
   I hope we shall hear from thee often; if thee should write to me it would give me much pleasure.
   
   Affectionately thy cousin,
   Thomas P Cope Jr.
    
   Germantown, 7mo 18, 1852
   
   Dear Clemmie,
   
   Not having a woman's privilege as to postscripts I begin afresh.  I have no objections however to having reason to call the by name again – it seems more natural and sociable and I see thee look up from thy work or from study or quiet wordto hear what I have to say- I finished in a hurry yesterday afternoon intending to mail this before leaving town, but time failing I have an opportunity to say that Anne secured a letter from Eddy last evening in which he says nothing about his bodily conditions, but that his discontent which she had inquired about are improving" Your visit no doubt did him good. Visits from home to a boy at school are a pleasant recollections for the rest of his life.
   
   Thee did not grieve much about they blanket shawl when thee was riding in the stage at night; it will be cooler when thee comes down next fall and we will take care to sent it up to thee in time. Grandfather will be glad to hear from thee and I hope if thee is not afraid of a repetition of what thy first letter has brought upon thee, that thee will write to [.]
   
   With many desire for thy happiness.
 Affectionately, thy Cousin,
   Thomas Cope Jr.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas Pim Cope:  1823-1900

Date: 1835-08-05
Title: 1835 August 5, Haverford, to Uncle, Philadelphia

Haverford 8mo 5th, 1835
   
   Dear Uncle,
   
   As I have but little to do to day why should I not be punctual in answering thy very interesting letter? Perhaps my desire to answer thy letter is not a little increased by what thee says in the latter past of it, that I am indebted to a white-wash woman for it. I have puzzled myself a great deal about how that could  be and at last have come to the conclusion that the said wash-woman is white-washing Grandfathers house, and thee had on that account been obliged to go down to the store, where having nothing to do in the business may, has very kindly taken it into they head to answer my last, especially as the seems to have anticipated a something from the letter that was lying on the desk. However I hope they next will solve the mystery.
    
   As to Monsieur, I told thee all that I knew about what had happened to give us a bad opinion of him, I merely heard that he had moved to be something of an imposter. If he is an Imposter for I can hardly believe that he is, he must be capable of acting the part of the hypocrite extremely well.Thee says that thee cannot accept my excuse for not writing a long letter and that I did not squeeze the right way; whether I squeezed the right way or not, I cannot tell, but when there is nothing to come, nothing will come. As thee had been please to liken the case to milking a cow, suppose I do the same. If the cow has had nothing to eat (in other words if nothing has happened for one to tell about) squeeze might [mong] or stand still as the woman Grandmother Drinker told about did nothing can come: such is my case. Perhaps thee will say "why did not tell thee about those things that thee mentioned last: With respect to the first I have already told thee all I knew about. Monsieur which to be sure is precious little, and with respect to Wm Dennis Address it cost but a trifle, not worth mentioning. Look there! Haven't I argufied  my case right well; at any rate, if I haven't made out any good reasons, I have made it help fill my sheet. Don't thee think that I have made out as good an excuse as thee did for not answering mine sooner.
   
   Thee will please excuse my using the offensive phrase "do not understand": I would not wish thee to understand by that, that they letters are unintelligible to me; they are not by any means. The personages I alluded to thee says are a distinguished inhabitant of the renowned city of Moodle doosie and his faithful and only friend Tom, who by the way thee says is apig. Quite a Compliment! The boys of the 3rd Class (of which there are about a dozen) have just returned from an excursion they have been making this afternoon to the Inclined Plane with Daniel B Smith to obtain minerals. According to their account of the matter they had a delightful time after having obtained the objects for which they went, they went in swimming in the Schuylkill , and found the water very warm, notwithstanding it has been such a cold morning. They were at one time within a mile of the city, and I think had I been with them, that the temptation to run in to the city and say "how-dye-do" to all the folks at home would have been almost sufficient to have induced me to do so, if I could have stayed but a half an hour. Now won't thee acknowledge that I have written a pretty long letter, considering what a poor hand I am? I shall expect a sheet well filled with interesting matter (a thine usually are) to arrive very shortly folded up and dissected to me. I hope top thee mill acknowledge that I have been very punctual in answering thy last. Time slips away very fast and very pleasantly with me. Why does thee not come out and pay us a visit some day.   
   They affectionate Nephew,
   Thomas P Cope Jr.Alfred Cope
   No 36 Nth 4th St
   Philadelphia
   
   Politness of
    [---] Morgan

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Thomas Pim Cope:  1823-1900
Recipient:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Date: 1852-08-30
Title: 1852 August 30, Philadelphia, to Clemmy, Dimock

Philadelphia 8mo 31, 1852
   
   Dear Clemmy,
    
    Thy very welcome letter came safe in to enclosure. I should have been quite disappointed if thee had not written to me and would like to think that there was not much debate in thy mind about it or at least that inclination took some part in it. Thee would give me a great deal of pleasure if thee would write often good long letters and thee may be very sure that I shall be interested in every thing thee chooses to tell me of thy doings and thinkings. I looked often for a sign that thee had not forgotten us, to appear on opening the letters we received from home while we were at Cape May and when we returned and still received no such sign, nothing but the belief from day today that we should certainly hear from thee before the next, save this from a letter about  it in which I expect I should have let fall some little misgivings which I should have reported of as soon as I got thy note. We had a pleasant and restful visit to the seashore and would  have been very glad if thee could have had thee with us. I should be almost sorry however that thy first acquaintance with the sea should be made when there is such a throng of visitors, it take away very much from your real enjoyment. I am glad that my first recollections of thesea at Cape May of other places here no such associations so that it seems to me in looking back on if it was always First Day it was so quite and pleasant. There were a number of new friends with us this summer, part of the time, all of Elizabeth's family except the little boys and several of Uncle Nathaniel's Mother has quite benefited by his visit and the swelling of his feet has almost disappeared.
     
   If thee had told me that thee took a walk every morning before breakfast I should answer that I doubted whether it would be good for thee, but I do not suppose once in a month or two will hurt thee. But to be up and about before breakfast and before sunrise I think is very useful and very pleasant. I am excellent habit, not very easy to get into. I used often when I was at Haverford at school to get up some time before sunrise and watch the coming in of day and I have not forgotten the freshness of the morning and the pleasant sight, and sounds there are at that quiet time. I As people are said to require less sleep as they grow old I hope to enjoy it all again and if I lived now, in such a pleasant country as Susquehanna Co. I don’t know what it might do for me. And it is very good to have a little time to yourself before the day begins, not very hard to get into the practice, very easy to help in it and easy to fall out of it, as I know. Do not think I am making light of thy "improving." I used for a long timeNot very long ago to be up some time before breakfast and desire very much to get back into the habit and intend to when I begin to practice my preaching's to thee on this and other matters.
    
   I will not believe that thee is not fond of rambling about the woods until I have a chance of cross-questioning thee about it. I dare say it would turn out that it was being overtired that thee does not enjoy.
   
   I believe I have not much family or other news to send thee. Aunt Caroline has been kept to her bed for some time, but is getting better. Mary I suppose thee knows was at the sea shore with us. Aunt Rebecca and son James B. are pretty much well. Grandfather continues very well for him and seems contented and comfortable at Uncle Alfred's.  Our [] families both great and small members are almost as usual. Is Mary Anne Morris a sort of cousin to thine? If she is, thee will have to make a little room in the place when thee keeps thy cousins, for Sandy Martin.
    
   Now Clemmy thee will agree with me that this is not an interesting letter. That is what I never did and never expect to write and thee must not take it as any measure of my good will toward thee. If I had followed my inclination it would have been written very soon after I got thine, and I hope thee will find time amid thy household cares, if this finds thee still at the head of affairs to answer it very soon. I send Elizabeth love on my own responsibility and if I was at Germantown should have various such messages for thee. If I have not replied to every thing in thyletter it is not because I do not find a great deal of interest on whatever thee tells me about thyself. I am much obliged to thee for taking my lectures so kindly and remember them so well.
   
   Affectionately thy Cousin,
   Thomas P Cope Jr.Clementine Cope
   Care of William D. Cope
   Dimock
   Susquehanna Co.
   Pa

Recipient:  Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope) Haines:  1819-1890
Date: 1811-06-12
Title: 1811 June 12, Newgarden College, to Mary Cope, Philadelphia

[Newgarden College 5
   Master Lewis- Enoch Lewis]
   
   June 12th 1811
   
   I suppose Father has told you that I arrived here safe and therefore it is needless for me to say anything in that respect.  I found it was harder to part with Father than I expected:  I felt the difference between being with my connections and Master Lewis' family; however I have got pretty well used to their noise and have got once more settled down to my studies pretty much in the old way.  I am sorry to have it to tell you that the cloth I got while I was at home is damaged.  there is a very ugly place goes round the sleeve of the coat and there are a few spots in other parts of the cloth.  I dare say this will be very disagreeable news, and I am sorry for it but can not help it.
   
   I did not find Alice as I hoped to find her, down stairs, nor is she able to come down now.
    
   I would tell thee nothing to tell Grandmother but I shall give her the pleasure or I hope I shallof informing her myself.  perhaps thee may wonder what I mean by saying, I hope I shall; I dont mean that I hope I shall write to her but I hope it will give her pleasure if I do write.
   
   I have read Think-I-to-myself since I cam back and I think it is a very interesting tale; but I suppose thee would much rather hear that I had read the Bible and so I have read some of it.  perhaps thee will say to thyself, I wonder how much; why I can tell thee 3 verses at least.  perhaps thee may now say to thyself, very little indeed; but hower if used rightly it might be better than none.  I have not heard from Caroline since I left her at West-town but she seemed to leave us quite contentedly, an indication I think (though I dont pretend to know much about it) of a strong mind.  I can easily see a difference between me and her in that respect, (but it is best to be sensible of our faults Jacob Lindley tells us) for I am pretty sure that I felt more dejected when Father left me than Caroline did when Father left her.I would like to hear how Father & Alfred got home but I suppose if any of their legs or arms or any of their bones at all had been broken I should have heard of it.
   
   The preceeding lines have been written several days ago and I was waiting for a favorable opportunity to send them which I now have by Charles Allen.  one of my hands is again affected by poison.
   
   The spots on my coat have in a great measure disappeared.
   
   With love to you all I remain
   Thy affectionate Son
   
   Wm. D. CopeMary Cope
   No36 North Fourth St
   Philada.

Title: 1829 May 11, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 5mo. 11. 1829
   Dear Brother:
   
   I reached this place after a pleasant journey, which occupied, as usual, 2 days.  I had pleasant company, & never before endured so little fatigue in crossing the Pokono.  the road over it is considerably improved.  I had the company of Jos'h [S?]inton  from Nazareth to Wilkes-barre.  he was on his return from attending the Orthodox Yearly Meeting.-  I was much pleased with the verdant appearance of the fields in this part of ye country.  ye season is much less advanced than usual at this time of year, but the grass looks well.-  there has not been so much done at my buildings during my absense as I expected wd. have been done, but ye workmen are now busily employed.  my Scotch farmer, I think it likely, will maintain the character of his countrymen for industry & fidelity, but I have not hired him long enough, fairly to test his qualifications.  ye female part of his family, however, it too numerous to suit me, as I have but little employment for women.-  tho' I have but little to communicate, I tho't I wd. not let a private opp'y pass without informing you of my safe arrival here & present health.  I shall feel anxious to hear from the invalids of thy family, tho' I hope they are not now invalids.-  I hope also that our new Mother may, by this time have regained her usual health.-  please give my love to all my kind friends & relatives, with whom I have so recently passed so many pleasant hours, that ye chain of communication between us, though separated, seems unbroken & strong.-  if thee shd. see Uncle Jasper please tell him, that I delivered his letter to Henry Colt, but that John N Conyngham had left Montrose before I arrived.  I therefore immediately forwarded the letter for him, to Wilkesbarre, & have little doubt but that he received it before leaving there for Bradford County.   I remain thy affectionate brother,
   Wm D CopePlease say to Eleanor, that I hope she will not mention to Cousins Abby Ann & Emma, any remarks that I made with regard to the evening company invited by them a short time before I left the City & of which I was one.  such observations are sometimes repeated under circumstances that give them an air of more seriousness than was intended by the one who makes them.[Note in second hand: W.D. Cope Woodbourne 5mo 11 1829]
   
   [Note in third hand: Journey home & personal allusions-"Our new Mother," etc., Scotch farmer- too many females in his family!]
   
   Henry Cope
   Care of Thomas P Cope & Sons,
   Philadelphia.
   
   attention of Jas C Biddle
