Title: 1829 February 16, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 2 mo 16 1829
   
   Dear Brother:
   
   I tho't it ye less necessary to take a formal leave of thee before my departure from ye City, as I had a prospect of revisiting you, before ye lapse of a very long period of time. I therefore was not satisfied with bidding thee farewell, thro’ ye medium of thy "better half". No material incident occurred during my journey hither. We were amused by ye remarks and minute observations of one of our fellow passengers, a young man of respectable appearance, probably 25 years of age, who, as I understood him to say, had never before been 14 miles from Philadelphia and had never seen a mountain. As we approached the Blue Ridge, his curiosity seemed on tip toe. The most novel circumstance that I have heard of having taken place during my absence from Woodbourne, in a hunt after wild boars. G. Walker shot one during ye day which was occupied in the chase. I will give thee an idea of other enjoyment that we may have in ye country, in Winter, by transcribing an extract of a letter from an accomplished young lady of the City of N. York to her friend at Woodbourne, who has permitted me to enter it, in my diary: "I have just returned from a visit to ye country, and have been indulging my taste for Winter scenery, checked vegetation and leafless tress to perfection. I had not indeed ye warmth of a good Schuylkill coal fire, to counterbalance ye want of which, I adopted ye beautiful sentiment of ye late Dr. Drake, "to make our climate in ye heart, & I feel 'tis Summer there."  what delightful privileges we have in ye country.  in ye gay Metropolis, we cannot as there, throw round our shoulders, ye old cloak, pitch on ye slouched hat, & slip on ye leather shoes-, then, race off, with ye freedom of untamed savages.  no, my dear, ye glass must be consulted with percision, ye dress arranged for observation,- ye hop, skip & jump, exchanged for ye measured step, or mincing gait, & a certain air of nonchalance, thrown over ye whole exterior."-  a few days after my return hither, E. Walker reached home.  ye joy of ye family was extreme, on again seeing him, after an absense of 7 mos.-  his seemed equally keen.  whatever may be his deficiencies, he is certainly a most affectionate father, & ye attachment between ye different members of his family, seems to be mutual.  this feeling extends even to the servants.-  a pleasing instance occurred on my arrival.  a nice little Germantown girl, was ye first to see me.  she ran eagerly to inform the family, but so excited were her feelings, that she cd. only say, Mr. Cope, Mrs. Cope, unaccompanied with any explanation of ye cause of her agitation.  they inform me that she shed tears on my leaving them for Philada.-  in my intercourse with ye head of the family, herementioned, as well as with others, I have been lead into this train of reflection: if we associate with those only that are perfect, who are to be our companions?  is it not wise to accept thankfully of kindness from ye hands of a fellow-being, whatever extended, to return like with like & good for evil, (a hard thing for poor human nature to do,) to condemn in a mild, frank & friendly manner, his faults, & try to show him by our own conduct, a good example for imitation.-  it is probably a fortunate circumstance, that, in a new country, we are almost obliged to hold more free inercourse with one another, than people in other situations.-  many prejudices are thus removed, & we are taught to know that tho' thro' selfishness of men, we may be injured, we can also be benefitted by them.  but I acknowledge it is a nice point, to avoid shipwreck, upon the rocks of misanthropy on the one hand, & the quicksands of good natured credulity, on the other.-  E.W’s mind seems much beclouded on ye subject of religious & society concerns, tho' he seems to harbour no asperity towards any party, but evinces kind & good natured feelings towards all.
   
   I found thy letter of 8 ult. safe in the P.Office here, & return thee thanks for ye names it furnishes, of the authors of communications for "the Friend".  several of them, I had not ascertained during my stay in the City.  "the Voyage to India," I was informed, is ye production of Dr. Reynell Coates.
   
   Please give best love to all, from thy
 affectionate brother,
   Wm D CopeWoodbourne
   2mo.16.
   
   [2mo 20 1829]
   Henry Cope
   Care of Thomas P Cope & Sons,
   Philadelphia.

Title: 1829 July 13, Woodbourne, to Brother, Philadelphia

Woodbourne 7 month 13th 1829
   Dear Brother:
   
   Thine of 29th ult. has been rece'd. I was pleased to learn that our parents were well, and hope that Edward & Alfred may be benefited by their proposed excursion and that thou may’st also find time to enjoy ye benefits of ye same kind of recreation. Ye country is now enlivened by visitors from ye City and Susquehanna Co. is favoured with a share of them. James Holly Biddle bro't back with them from Phila. their sisters Sarah Biddle and Mary Drinker, and E. Walker's family have ye company of ye widow Morris, and her daughters, Susan & Elizabeth. We have lately been favoured also with a visit from Joel Woolman and Alvin Keyser, appointed by Abington Quarterly Meeting to visit Friendsville Preparative Meeting. they appeared to be man of plain, unassuming humble manners, and were well received by both Hicksites & Orthodox. Cha's Shoemaker accompanied them as far as a Stroudsburg, where he became so ill, as to present his proceeding further. We have subsequently had a visit from Ja's Bell, another orthodox friend and an elder, appointed by Stroudsburg Monthly Meeting.
    
    Dan'l Stroud has been indisposed, or he also wd. probably have visited this part of his flock.  he occasionally writes excellent letters of advice to afford thee an idea of his decisive and at the same time affectionate letters of language & manner, I will give thee an extract from one of them, recently addressed to E. Walker: "distressing as is ye fact, yet it certainly is the case, that the Hicksites are a distinct Society from Friends, and ye separation proceeded from ye leaders of that seccession having become corrupted with anti-christian doctrines, mostly Socinian, but compounded with some other speculative notions, made up into bills to suit ye subjects to whom they were to be administered, and gilt with specious professions of great spirituality, to captivate members and professors with Friends. this with various practices, such as are too commonly used in electioneering, have beguiled & seduced many, who have not or had not previously embraced those awfully dreadful notions, not fitting to be styled doctrines, when we are speaking of religion, and whether these will become leavened into the mass of infidelity with their leaders, or separate from them remains among the things which futurity must disclose. that thou & I, and ye dear children Providentially entrusted to our care, may be preserved from this direful contagion, I have earnestly craved, feeling some hope, that we may resist every temptation that may beset us, to unsettle us and loss about with every wind of doctrine.
    
   If we ever knew anything, "as we ought to know", le us "walk by ye same rule and mind the same thing." Let us be satisfied with and established in "the faith once delivered to ye saints",and say with ye apostle, "thanks be to God for his unspeakable gift", in uniting Deity & virility so as to provide salvation for our fallen race, consistently with divine justine & mercy, though the august plan & means were such as Angels desired to look into.  and tho' this wonderful union is beyond their conception & ours also, we shd. be grateful for it, for surely it is exactly adapted to the condition & need of us poor frail beings, inasmuch as it is complete, or affords complete salvation, both indemnity & cure. Redemption from the penalty & power of sin; remdemption from the penalty by the atonement made by Jesus Christ, our Lord, being God & man;- and redemption from ye power or government of sin by the Holy Spirit, so received into & operating upon our hearts, as to change them, producing a birth of ye spirit & furnishing divine ability in faithful humility & obedience, to resist temptation & be preserved in divine acceptance."++++- Present my very warm & cordial love to thy very dear children, who I feel expressibly near to me. I remember ye kindness of R. T. also; and entertain sentiments of regard for our dear yound friend W. D. Cope, your near neighbour. under sensations which I am thankful for, I bid you all affectionately fare well." (signed) Daniel Stroud.-
   
   Thy observations with regard to ye precarious tenure of our hold on life, are worthy of being often recalled, & deeply impressed upon ye memory & ye heart.- with thyself, I hope & trust that ye deep concern & unbounded affection of our dear deceased Mother for us, will not have been uttered & felt in vain;- that ye expression of her hopes & fears, her sighs & sorrows, have not been for naught.-  I sincerely desire that ye change in ye management of your business, may be advantageous in a pecuniary point of view to thyself & Alfred, but ye annunciation of it, caused a shade of sorrow to pass over my heart. ye expunging of a name, upon which we have been in ye habit of looking so long, that we look upon it with a degree of veneration, seems somewhat like ye disappearance of an old friend or favourite.
   
   I have had workmen pretty constantly employed at my building since my last return from ye City, sometimes to ye number of 6 or 8, sometimes more. ye attention which these, my farm & Father's estate, occupies my time, pretty fully. ye last mentioned concern requires in its present stage & condition much attention for but little profit. but it is absolutely necessary that something shd. be done to guard against ye effects to which it is liable from an accumulation of taxes & interest. I still look forward however, to a change, decidedly for ye better, but we are so apt to be too fast in our calculations, that it becomes us to be cautious.-  I think it likely from present appearances, that my investment in ye stock of ye Leigh Coal and Navigation Co, will be a good one. I am not displeased to find myself becoming more & more interested in my farm. I form an attachment for every tree & every field, which has called forth my care & attention,- for every hill and every valley, that have afforded me gratification by their smiles & beauties.  ye lover of ye country can often realize ye enthusiasm of [Hervey], & exclaim, "when the little hills rejoice & the vallies laugh & sing, who can forbear joining ye general joy". I have at all events reason for self gratulation, inasmuch as I am more pleased with my present mode of life, than I at one time ever expected to be.- I early perceived that with my limited means, I mustbe contented with advancing slowly, in any improvements that I might wish to make, but it has been very difficult to reconcile myself to making so little progress as yet been able to make, owing to ye circumstance last mentioned as well as others.-  I expect that ye capital & influence that Caleb Carmalt is employing in favour of this County, will be of advantage to it, though we we may not feel their effects immediately in this neighbourhood.  some of E. Walker's Family, who have recently been at Friendsville, mention, that he has 30 men & 9 yoke of oxen at work on his farm.  two of his brothers, & one of his sisters have also pitched their tents at Friendsville.-  his brother James, fm Philada., has purchased a farm of 1000 acres & is employed in improving it.-
   
   With particular love to all, I remain thy affectionate brother,
    Wm D Cope
   
   Since writing ye foregoing, I have received thine of 6 ins’t. I will attend to doing what is necessary, to further ye collection of ye divd on ye Canal loan. I hardly expect that there will be any divd. this year, on ye Lehigh Canal stock, but if there should be, I will be obliged by thy informing me of it.-  in addition to the drafts referred to by thee, I passed one to C. Avery & Co, on ye 10 ins't, numbd. 10, for $50.00.-  I regret that I can get no tidings of my missing papers.-  I am obliged by ye information communicated by thee respecting the C & D Canal.  that great work, seems still to baffle calculation.Woodbourne
   7mo. 13.
   
   [7mo 15 1829]
   Henry Cope
   Care of Thomas P Cope
   Philadelphia.

Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1832-10-24
Title: 1832 October 24, Philadelphia, to S.

Philadelphia 10 mo 24. 1832
   
   I have often thought of thee since leaving Bloomsdale, and feel quite desirous to have a little conversation with thee upon paper. there is something animating in placing ourselves in imagination by the side of a fair lady, and holding sweet converse with.
    
   "Woman, lovely woman, whom Heaven designed to temper man."
   "We had been brutes without thee."
   
    I hope I shall have the pleasure ere long of paying my respects to thee in person, but as I wish to do my best to please thee, I must not tire thee by too early repetition of my last visit. I hope also that I shall be less and less stiff and formal in my manners, as our acquaintance & friendship advances and increases it happily, such should be the tendency of things. A young lady possessing the recommendations of youth, beauty and accomplishments, told a mutual friend at Woodbourne, not a great while since, that the greatest objects on she had to make against me, was that of being to reserved. Alas! I could not say the same with regard to herself, much as I appreciated many traits of her character, she wished she said, that she could take the liberty of telling me what she thought of me. As amongst our best friends, are those who tell us of our faults, I could not but feel grateful for the reproof, though indirectly made, and hope to be improved by it. I shall also feel grateful to my dear friend Susan, if she will point out with frankness and freedom any faults that I may possess. But I pray thee not to do it, so as to give the appearance of its being done with the intention of wounding my feelings. I am keenly sensitive to a blow struck with such a view. It is a great mistake entertained by some ladies, thatmen have no feelings, because they restrain or suppress them. a sensitive mind, will I think readily perceive the difference between reproves made in a proper manner, and form a proper motive, and thos made with different intentions. I am credulous enough to believe, with confidence, that none wo be made by them of the improper kind.- besides many things that I think I shall have to say to thee when we meet again, I have some also to show thee. but I have been hoping that before the suitable time for visiting thee again, shall I arrive, I will feel something like being really well. This [---] air that we breathe here is so different from the elastic atmosphere that I have latterly been accustomed to, that I have not felt right well during any part of my last two visits to the City.-  nothing like a Susquehanna County glow! Thee don't know how much better I look when I acquire the ruddy hue that the mountain air inparts. thee knows however, that it will be good policy in me to try to persuade thee that my appearance in general, is somewhat more captivating than at present.- the idea has several times occured to me, that it would perhaps have been well for me to have offered my services as gallant on any excursion that thee & thy sisters might wish to make, either to the City, or elsewhere. if thee should not should not be procided with one more suitable than myself, will thee use the freedom to drop me a line informing whether it would be agreeable or desirable in such case to have my servie? The number of our house is 36. please excuse as well as thee canthe vanity that I have displayed in alluding to myself in the foregoing lines.  it is a vice that is very apt to show itself, however slight may be our reason or excuse, for displaying it. I wish, thee sees, to forestall thy condemnation of it, by condemning it myself. I bide thee adieu and wish thee health, happiness, prosperity and an increase of regard for thy affectionate friend.
    
   Will thee do me the favour to refer to & read the 24th chapter of Genesis. I am so great a lover of artlessness and patriachal simplicy of manners, that I should be glad if thee would agree with me in admiring the picture of them therein presented.
   
   P.S. Be sure to look very pleasant the next time we meet; thee knows for ladies smiles they say are sunbeams and have a bland & genial influence on thou upon whom they are cast.Philadelphia 11 mo. 7 1832
   
   I have to apologize for not paying thee a visit this week, in conformity to the intention made by me at the time of my taking leave on 7th day last, circumstance not then thought of having occurred to prevent. however, as there is no necessity that I am yet apprised of, for my immediate departure for Woodbourne,  I hope that another week will not elapse, with my having the opportunity and pleasure of taking thee by the hand. in the mean time, wishing thee a continuance of good health & spirits, I remain as ever thy affectionate friend.
   
   P.S. Be sure to look very pleasant the next time we meet; for thee knows ladies smiles they say. are sunbeams and have a bland and genial influence on those upon whom they are cast.    N.B. my last visit was rather too much prolonged; but allowance must be made in certain cases, for some slight indiscretions. I will try to have better for the future.
   
   To
   
   There is some business to be attended to relative to my Father's coal lands in Dauphin Co & whether it will be necessary either for my Brother Alfred or myself to go forthwith. I mention the circumstance to account for my absence, should I go myself & should it be prolonged beyond what I expect will be the fact.

Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1834-01-06
Title: 1834 January 6, Philadelphia, to Susan

(by mail)
   Philada. 1 mo. 6. 1833
   Dear Susan:
   
   As I had hoped and expected I received the thrice welcome communication of which we had been speaking, the evening of the same day I left thee. it was handed to me by my Father, who said that he had taken charge of it in the morning, upon finding it at the Counting House. so thou had'st been thinking of me during the three weeks' interval of non-intercourse. thee is a a dear creature,  (pardon the familiarity of the expression) and I thank thee much, for it. how delightful to be though of and remembered, by those that we love! "Tho' my pen has been idle this long, my thoughts have not". I recalled these expressions of thy "talking letter", again and again, and tho' the construction admits of doubt with regard to its correctness, yet the influence that thee was thinking of me was so agreeable that I concluded to assume it as the right and proper interpretation. at all events thy thoughts must have been indirectly, if not directly turned towards me. I am unable to answer satisfactorily thy quiery with regard to the authorship of the poetical effusion that I sent thee from Woodbourne. I have frequently recurred to it during moments of calm and quiet meditation, and have derived soathing satisfaction from the consoling and pious spirit that it breathes. I suppose that I shall in due time be informed by thee who the "intruder" is, who has had the presumption to invade thy tranquil haunts, whilst occupied with thoughts of me. If he shall molest or disturb any more, he will incur my high displeasure. restingsatisfied for the present with the expectation or supposition just expressed, I bid thee affectionaly adieu. I wishing thee, "Health of body, peace of mind, quiet by day; sound sleep by night".
    Thine,
   [Philimus]
   
   I hope to have the pleasure of seeing thee in a few days.
   
   Philada. 1mo. 13. 1834
   
   I reached the City, about dusk in the evening of the day that I left Bloomsdale, after a tolerably pleasant passage. the coach was not crowded, and I did not make any very interesting acquaintances, nor any with whom I felt much disposed to enter into conversation, or to enlarge upon the topics of the day. and if I had felt such disposition, it would have been an unpleasant exertion to have attempted to make my voice heard or to elevate it above the noise & rattling of the stage coach, owing to my cold, and the condition of my throat. But tho' my voice was "idle my thoughts were not". And I suspect that thou cannot give a pretty good guess as to who and what were the subjects of them. ipon glancing over the pages of Father's copy of the "Sentimental Journey", I espied the article recommended for my perusal by my friend Adeline. It is contained under the heading, "The Remise. Calais". Vol. 1 I am highly pleased with the delicate manner used by thee in adverting to the postage subject. It has reminded me of the following stanza by Pope:
   "Men should be taught as tho’ you taught them not;
     And things unknown rehearsed as thing forgot.Tis not enough your counsels still be true:   Blunt truth more mischief than nice falsehoods do.
   
   the sentiment is open to criticism, but think that there is sufficient truth in it to make it worth of a consideration. I am fearful that I may have been considered by thee remotely or in some measure, changeable with bluntness in my manner of suggesting to thee, that it would perhaps be best not to advert to any circumstances that might be of disagreeable or unpleasant nature. the suffered suitable time and opportunity to pass for alluding to the circumstance in the course of conversation with embracing it. As I am now "an engaged man", I shall be desirous of complying with all the duties and requisitions thereof, and shall therefore take care not to forget to profit by thy kind hint relative both aforesaid item of those duties. I want thee as to admired applied to another, the following line of the Poet Burns, whilst I will admire them as applied to thyself:
   
   "A gaudy dress and gentle air may slightly touch the heart,
   But its innocence and modesty that polishes the dart."
   'Tis this in Susan pleases me, 'tis this enchants my soul,
    For absolutely in my heart the reigns without control."
   
   if it were not however that the metre and force of the third line would be destroyed by so doing I am say, this is one thing in Susan, or this is part of what pleases me. I am not certain that I am literally correct in the quotations that I have made, as I depend for their correctness upon my memory, but I believe I have nearly the substance. I have made my arrangements to as to be at B. about the usual time this week, having concluded to procrastinate,fare-thee-wells. a thousand good wishes I send thee and more love than I can mention of which last may.
    
   "Thine but the impression stronger make,   Is stream their channels deeper wear."
   
   Thine unchangeably,
   [Philimus]
   
   procrastinate the two weeks interval till another time. I thought it would be so. How readily we form plans & [exences] for doing what is agreeable.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1832-11-27
Title: 1832 November 27, Philadelphia, to S.

Philada. 11mo. 27. 1832
   
   I may say the worst that I have for years   I have had a dreadfully bad cold, and though I think it would have done me good to see thee, I must now bid all hail! to Susquehanna County, and did not feel much inclined to go into company nor was I in a very suitable condition for so doing.  I hasten to the country of cloud-capped eminences, invigorating breezes, placid lakes, ever-varying surface and romantic scenery.-  there to feel myself reinstated in the occupation which is the height of my ambition, that of an independent farmer.-  an occupation for which I do not think my partiality as yet has diminished.  "Ye generous yeomen, [---] the plough"!  before taking my flight, I wish to let thee know that I did not forget the subject of "Friendship’s Offering" relative to which we had some conversation during our last rural walk.  the reason for my not sending the said work, I will give when I again see thee.  this seems to be a small matter to [---] to, but I think it best thus to do it, as I have never yet forfeited my word or violated an engagement, and I do not wish to give any cause for so however slight for supposing that I wd. do so.  if thee gets married to any one, while I am gone, be sure that it is to a clever fellow.  I am still somewhat inclined I should like to have had one sweet kiss of thy pretty mouth, before, peradventure, I should forever be [---] the opportunity (5); however thee knows we ought to learn to submitto submit with fortitude to our fate.  I am still somewhat inclinded to the opinion, which I have before hinted to thee, that I am not well qualified to undergo the ordeal of a systematic courtship, such as is frequently, perhaps generally expected & practiced in this part of the world.  if I ever succeed in making a capture of that fair citadel, or seat of love,- a lady’s heart; it must, I apprehend be by storm, rather than by gradual approaches, long trains, dexterous manouvers, or a regular siege.
   
   I have now only to say,
   "Adieu! a heartfelt warm adieu"! from thy still affectionate friend,
   
   if thou wilt only be persuaded, dear Susan, a drab bonnet, I will on my part agree to shade my face with a broad-brim.  if we do not then attract universal admiration, who will be so bold as to say that we will not at least command general respect.
   
   I have received a notice requiring my immediate departure from the City, if possible, in order to attend the next Court to be held at Montrose.  excuse haste and all the nonsense contained in these lines.-I expect to have the agreeable company of my Cousin Rebecca Drinker as far as [Stoddartsville].  being of a cheerful disposition, I expect she will prevent my spirits from flagging.To S,
   dated Philada. 11mo. 27. 1832.
   
   (3) "Though I to" distant "lands must [---],   Pursuing fortune's [sliddery] [---],   With melting heart & [brimful] eye,   I'll mind thee when I’m far away."
   
   (5) by some spruce, fashionable [---].  plague on such I say.
   
   Ph

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1833-06-22
Title: 1833 June 22, Philadelphia, to S.

Philada. 6mo. 22. 1833.
   
   I wished very much to have had some conversation with thee during my last visit to Bloomsdale, relative to the subject of our recent & former intercourse with each other, but I thought that an approach to it, seemed disagreeable to thee (2).  why did thee, my dear friend, deam it necessary, in several instances during my two last visits to you, to display cold and repulsive manners?  I do think that the might have spared my feelings, considering that I had assured thee that I would not obtrude, or press any claim to favour from thee, beyond what might be agreeable to thee.-  ladies are sometimes incomprehensible beings, but I understood thee, to say, or it might be implied from what thee said, that thee thought I was in fault in not having written to thee after my return to Woodbourne last Winter.  do, I beg of thee, consider the circumstances of the case.  I supposed that thy objections to continuing correspondence, arose from delicacy of feelings.  I therefore suggested two modes of maintaining an intercourse between us.  one through thy Father, and another through my Sister Elenor.  but thee seemed to think that it would be a severe trial & effort, to correspond with a gentleman even if engaged to him.  thee asked me if I could not conceive it to be so [---] could not make allowance for thee, or something I think to that effect.  the motive which I have mentioned was not that which induced thee to object to correspondence, I supposed that the objection arose from want of inclination.  if the letter were the fact, would it not have been disagreeable to thee if I had been strenuous in urging the thing?  thee asked me during the courseof conversation which we had in the garden last week, whether I thought if thee had formed any new attachment or engagement during my absense, that thee would not have informed me of it.  I did not understand how I was to be informed, if thee did not write to me.  thee knows, I might have made myself appear rather ridiculous, if I should have been writing letters couched in terms of affection & admiration etc., if the circumstance alluded to should have actually existed, which was quite within the verge of possibility.  thee said that thee would forgive me if thee believes that I have been in fault, it is praise worthy and admirable to do so, but where there has been no fault there is no need of forgiveness.  I would rather that thee would say that thee tho't I should be exempted from blame yet acknowledge that we are apt not see our faults as plainly as others see them.  the more I have reflected upon the subject, since our conversation, the more clearly it has appeared to me that I am not indictable for the commission of offence (3).  thou hast had thy own way, and I have been governed by thy wishes, so far as have been expressed, from the first.  I have slighted no pledge, I have violated no engagement, I have receded from no advance that I have made, and I have blamed thee for anything unless what I have mentioned in the forepart of this letter.  I believe almost all ladies practice more or less in love affairs, at flirtation & coquetry.  but it seems as if we could hardly blame the dear creatures for what appears to be so natural to them.  the desire of making conquests by displaying the power of their charms may perhaps be said to be inherent in their nature for practicing the art.  I do not mean to say, that the passion is not kept underunder restraint when virtuous & religious principles are allowed to have their due weight in the mind.
   
   I tender thee my thanks for the politeness with which I have been treated during the progress of our intercourse.  courtship is generally a stiff, awkward business on the part of the one who is expected to make the advances, & places a gentleman in an embarrassing situation, demanding the consideration & sympathy of the object of his addresses.-  I again beseech thee not to blame me for unintentional errors if such have been committed.  at all events, I am determined, sweet, amiable lassie, to continue to like & admire thee, whether thou art displeased with me or not.  I had wished to have shown thee a correspondence between myself and a fair lady of the great City of New York, which thee would have acknowledged partakes eminently of the romantic.  there was no suitable opportunity however, of doing it.  it would also have afforded thee an opportunity (4) of seeing, that all ladies to not object to corresponding with gentlemen.  I can assure thee, I was not in love with her!-  Wishing thee health , happiness & prosperity, I remain, truly & sincerely, thy friend,
   
   + thee will of course understand that I should have considered myself under a sacred obligation not to have disclosed names.  (4) amongst many others,
   
   T.O.I confidently trust and believe that I am not mistaken in the opinion that thy sense of honour & propriety will induce thee to withhold from others, what I once said to thee with regard to thy Cousin E.D. [?], what I did say, I said with reluctance, and only because I thought a full explanation due to thee.  I never spoke on the subject in the same way to any other person unless perhaps to my Father.(2) I think however, that I cannot do much amiss by writing thee a few lines.  I would not do it if I thought they would cause thee any unpleasant feelings.(3) I offered to try to make thee as comfortable & happy as circumstances would admit.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Recipient:  Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Date: 1833-10-28
Title: 1833 October 28, Woodbourne, to S.

(1)
   Woodbourne 10mo. 28. 1833.
   
   I was much gratified, Dear Susan, by the rece't of thine of 17th inst tho' it did not reach me as soon at it ought to have, if it traveled hitherward by the usual course. perhaps owing to the circumstance of this state not having been mentioned upon the endorsement it may have strayed for a time into another. we usually receive letters in two days after date from New York and three from Philada.  it met with a welcome reception however at its journey's end and I was pleased to receive through it, a confirmation of my misgivings with regard to the authorship of the "witty letter". I am more than ever bewildered and puzzled. circumstance are alluded to in it, which I had supposed were known to mortal being besides ourselves. I therefore concluded before the rece't of thy letter, that it must have been written in some measure with thy privity, thro' an amanuensis, or else that it presented an instance & example of some very singular coincidences in answer to they queries, I may say, that th' document was dated Philada, Sep. 1., post marked at the same place on the 3d. of the same month, and was subscribed with the attractive name & surname of Dorothy Dolittle. yet notwithstanding the feminine & harmonious form and fashion and sound of said name, I think, judging from the stiff & set stile of the hand-writing to which it is signed, that the writer and signer one and the same person, is of the masculine gender. "An enemy hath done this." I said to myself as I perused thy remarks in relation to it. But we have the power and I trust the disposition to defeat his insidious attack. Let us be on our guard, & not be taken by surprise lest he succeed in his assault. In coming over the various errors and blundersthat I might have been guilty of, and which might have been the cause of the reprobatory authourings of this mysterious letter writer, the aforesaid Dorothy, the subject of the New York Letters, came up in course, and I did not know, but that my having read them to thee might have been construed into a breach of confidence. hence the reason for my having mentioned them in mine of 27th. how I wish that I could enjoy with thee some of the pleasant walks of which thee gives such an interesting idea. but do not I beseech thee magnify distances so much, or thee will alarm me. thee speaks of the "far off country", that is of this delightful region which I inhabit as if it were "the far West.", whereas it is so in no other respect, than as regards climate. to be sure, a spur of the Allegany intervenes between us and the Atlantic, and intercepts the damp & chilly winds from old Ocean, but as regards distance, faculties of communication, and geographical position, we are essentially Atlantic and indeed is almost the Easternmost County of the State. Even the obstruction to communication presented by the barrier to which I allude, has been greatly lessened, and almost overcome, by the perseverance, industry, and enterprise of the inhabitants; and railroad cars, now pass & repass over it, as it were on the wings of the wind, & with the rapidity of the eagle in its flight. I feel some attachment to the country, but after the affairs of may Father's estate here, shall have been adjusted and settled, I expect that I shall not be indissolubly bound to it, or to remain in it, if things do not suit "all round," to borrow an expression from the shrewd Yankee. Eliza G Drinker who thee was bro't up in your neighborhood, says that she should never have wished to have left it (this County) if she had not have been overtaken by misfortunes of a kind to which we are all liable in the course of our earthly pilgrimage. I think I must have seen the essay on lovers mentioned by thee. I was copied into a Philadelphia paper taken by Des. Walker, entitled "The Sun", and credited to the ColumbianColumbian (Ct.) Regn. I enjoyed a hearty laugh whilst reading it. Pray tell me who was that one of thy acquaintance whom thee recognized in the description, and in which part of the essay is he described? I should like to know whether I have applied the right part to the right person when I next enjoy the pleasure of seeing thee, I must beg thee to give me a lesson upon the best mode & manner & means of sealing letters. I admire thy productions in the act exceedingly. how have thy Father’s English potatoes succeeded? Tell him that the product of some of those that I planted, are I think, without exception, the best that I have ever tasted. We have had love, a very abundant first year, more apples and peaches & raspberries than we knew what to do with. I selected 120 bushels of sweet apples from my orchard, and made of them some of the most delicious cider that I ever drank. Part of it I made into wine. The process of making wine from cider, is the most simple and least laborious mode of making it that I have anywhere seen adopted. the red Antwerp  raspberries grow here spontaneously and were so abundant this year, that I used a considerable proportion of them in my mixture for currant wine.
   
   If I cannot pay thee a visit soon, I think I must certainly furnish thee with a copy of mother's letter. in the mean time accept of the kindly remembrances and best wish of thy friend.
   
   Gulielmus.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William Brown
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937

Title: N.D. April 21, St. Augustine, to Lilly

St Augustine April 21st
   
   My dear Lilly-
   
   A very kind niece, Uncle Will think he has, to reply to his letter so soon. He is delighted to hear that she can say so much for herself. About her learning to read and cypher fast, but what does Miss Amelia say-Does she think that Lilly is as forward, as the March Chicks she saw at Grandma' - dont grow too fast, for perhaps Uncle Will may not know her, [---] he must ask Papa, who that little girl is? When he sees her- [---] large tho, Aunt Lissy says I am fine boy, what a big family of brothers & sisters you will be if far still grow so fast. You will be [---]big people, & every body cant take you up to kiss them- Chelly will like that, for she always wipes them off-
   
   In your next letter, tell me if you liked the music at the B[---] Asylum-
   
   The flower I sent, was a rose leaf & now I put in two Honeysuckle flowers- Chelly can have one, or whoever Lilly wants to give it to. & now I shall write to momma- for I have not written to her for a long time- & Lilly will not forget to write to her
   
   Uncle Will

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  William Brown
Recipient:  Susanna Sansom Brown:  1826-1909
Date: 1843-08-24
Title: 1843 August 24, Roxborough, to Sisters, Boston

Roxborough 8st Mo 24st 1843.
   4th day eve
   
   Dear Sisters,
   
    I presume you started as you expected at 7 o'clock this morning and if I may judge by the coolness of the atmosphere here at that hour,  I should think that you needed your blanket shawls on the river, and now perhaps you have them on again pacing the deck of the steamer on the Sound.
   
   But I write now more particularly at Father's request. He wished me to record the uncommon softness and mellow tints of the sky. For the Sun after a cloudy day is setting perfectly clear & the evening is certainly one of the pleasantest we have had this season. Though probably more so to him, having just returned from his business in the city. We miss your company very much, but I have no doubt but that you will enjoy yourselves exceedingly and return refreshed as you expect in body and mind.
    
   I wil now close for this evening and making a short addition tomorrow I will leave the remainder of the sheet to Mary.5th day 24st
   
   Wistar informed Mother last evening that Mamaduke Cope went to New York yesterday in the early line. You must have seen him. He goes to see the English Minister Pease previous to his tour to Canada.
   
   I expect that you have by this time nearly or quite recovered from the fatigue attending your journey. Sue would perhaps feel it the most as she is so unaccustomed to travelling. We intend to send Harry to the city tomorrow and our family will then be very small.
    
   You must write soon as father and all of us would wish to hear. Perhaps you will trouble yourselves to note down some of the most interesting things you see and then you will retain them more fresh in you memory for our benefit, as will as your own. Please remember me to Cousin William. We are all quite well & hoping that you are the same & wishing you every enjoyment
    I bid you adieu-
   
   Your aff Bro William.Dear Sisters,
   
   William & I concluded it would be a good place to set you all example by penning a few lines immediately; accordingly I have seated myself in our old apartment at 12 past 9 o'clock, whilst the rest of the family are quietly giving themselves up to repose, for since your departure we have retired ever earlier if possible than usual, in order to give you an idea how matters work on School house lane. We feel quite impatient to hear how Sue bore the journey. I hope you experienced no detention in consequence of the [---]; we saw by the paper this eve that the passenger cars from New York were notable to come on [---] day as so large an amount of rain had fallen as completely to deluge the road. Our meeting at Arch st was so as very large this morning as it was expected the English friends would be there but owing to the lat[---] storm they could not arrive till this evening I supposed they are now in the city. Francis B was at Uncle Moses' this afternoon perhaps if Anna had been at home he would have done her the favour to have called but as he has now received information that she is not at home he will take precious care that he does not show his face in these parts for several weeks; he had a letter a few days since from Cape May.  the family are all very well and intend coming home in a few days. Frank says if they do not return by second day, which is the last day the boat runs, they will have either to swim or return by land so that it is most probable they will arrive by the the end of this week. Wistar spent this evening with us very pleasantly he says every thing is going on in the city as usual very few persons have as yet returned. Mother wishes that you should buy her a [--] de [---] dress in Boston. If you see any thing that would be suitable; she wishes you to consult your own taste in the matter. If you see one with a small figure that you admire get it or if you see a handsome plain one, not too light a color, something that would be suitable for autumn.  A plain one she would rather prefer if youmet with what suited you. Give my love to Cousins R & Maria and tell the former I regretted exedingly not having an opportunity to bid adieu farewell Mother and I fully expected to have seen him in the city and were quite disappointed in not doing so. I hope you will write soon and let us know how you are coming on as it is the only thing you can do to cheer us during your absence as the evening draws to a close I believe I must now bid you an aff good night. excuse haste.  if you either of choose to favour me with an epistle I will promise to answer it immediately and to some length.  your aff sister Mary.I suppose the Cousins R. & Maria to whom Aunt Mary refers in this letter where Cousins Robert & Maria Earle.  The former was very fond of kissing & Aunt Mary ysed to say that she always kept a pin ready to stick him if he came too near!  Mother must have been 21 at this time, Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue younger- Uncle Will came between Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue.  They were visiting Cousins in New England, where all Grandpa's relations lived.  At the time everybody travelled from New York to Boston by boat.
   letters dated.
   Aug. 1843

Title: 1843 August 24, Roxborough, to Sisters, Boston

Roxborough 8st Mo 24st 1843.
   4th day eve
   
   Dear Sisters,

Our meeting at Arch st was so as very large this morning as it was expected the English friends would be there but owing to the lat[---] storm they could not arrive till this evening I supposed they are now in the city. Francis B was at Uncle Moses' this afternoon perhaps if Anna had been at home he would have done her the favour to have called but as he has now received information that she is not at home he will take precious care that he does not show his face in these parts for several weeks; he had a letter a few days since from Cape May.  the family are all very well and intend coming home in a few days. Frank says if they do not return by second day, which is the last day the boat runs, they will have either to swim or return by land so that it is most probable they will arrive by the the end of this week. Wistar spent this evening with us very pleasantly he says every thing is going on in the city as usual very few persons have as yet returned. Mother wishes that you should buy her a [--] de [---] dress in Boston. If you see any thing that would be suitable; she wishes you to consult your own taste in the matter. If you see one with a small figure that you admire get it or if you see a handsome plain one, not too light a color, something that would be suitable for autumn.  A plain one she would rather prefer if youmet with what suited you. Give my love to Cousins R & Maria and tell the former I regretted exedingly not having an opportunity to bid adieu farewell Mother and I fully expected to have seen him in the city and were quite disappointed in not doing so. I hope you will write soon and let us know how you are coming on as it is the only thing you can do to cheer us during your absence as the evening draws to a close I believe I must now bid you an aff good night. excuse haste.  if you either of choose to favour me with an epistle I will promise to answer it immediately and to some length.  your aff sister Mary.I suppose the Cousins R. & Maria to whom Aunt Mary refers in this letter where Cousins Robert & Maria Earle.  The former was very fond of kissing & Aunt Mary ysed to say that she always kept a pin ready to stick him if he came too near!  Mother must have been 21 at this time, Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue younger- Uncle Will came between Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue.  They were visiting Cousins in New England, where all Grandpa's relations lived.  At the time everybody travelled from New York to Boston by boat.
   letters dated.
   Aug. 1843

Title: 1843 August 24, Roxborough, to Sisters, Boston

Roxborough 8st Mo 24st 1843.
   4th day eve
   
   Dear Sisters,
   
    I presume you started as you expected at 7 o'clock this morning and if I may judge by the coolness of the atmosphere here at that hour,  I should think that you needed your blanket shawls on the river, and now perhaps you have them on again pacing the deck of the steamer on the Sound.
   
   But I write now more particularly at Father's request. He wished me to record the uncommon softness and mellow tints of the sky. For the Sun after a cloudy day is setting perfectly clear & the evening is certainly one of the pleasantest we have had this season. Though probably more so to him, having just returned from his business in the city. We miss your company very much, but I have no doubt but that you will enjoy yourselves exceedingly and return refreshed as you expect in body and mind.
    
   I wil now close for this evening and making a short addition tomorrow I will leave the remainder of the sheet to Mary.5th day 24st
   
   Wistar informed Mother last evening that Mamaduke Cope went to New York yesterday in the early line. You must have seen him. He goes to see the English Minister Pease previous to his tour to Canada.
   
   I expect that you have by this time nearly or quite recovered from the fatigue attending your journey. Sue would perhaps feel it the most as she is so unaccustomed to travelling. We intend to send Harry to the city tomorrow and our family will then be very small.
    
   You must write soon as father and all of us would wish to hear. Perhaps you will trouble yourselves to note down some of the most interesting things you see and then you will retain them more fresh in you memory for our benefit, as will as your own. Please remember me to Cousin William. We are all quite well & hoping that you are the same & wishing you every enjoyment
    I bid you adieu-
   
   Your aff Bro William.Dear Sisters,
   
   William & I concluded it would be a good place to set you all example by penning a few lines immediately; accordingly I have seated myself in our old apartment at 12 past 9 o'clock, whilst the rest of the family are quietly giving themselves up to repose, for since your departure we have retired ever earlier if possible than usual, in order to give you an idea how matters work on School house lane. We feel quite impatient to hear how Sue bore the journey. I hope you experienced no detention in consequence of the [---]; we saw by the paper this eve that the passenger cars from New York were notable to come on [---] day as so large an amount of rain had fallen as completely to deluge the road. Our meeting at Arch st was so as very large this morning as it was expected the English friends would be there but owing to the lat[---] storm they could not arrive till this evening I supposed they are now in the city. Francis B was at Uncle Moses' this afternoon perhaps if Anna had been at home he would have done her the favour to have called but as he has now received information that she is not at home he will take precious care that he does not show his face in these parts for several weeks; he had a letter a few days since from Cape May.  the family are all very well and intend coming home in a few days. Frank says if they do not return by second day, which is the last day the boat runs, they will have either to swim or return by land so that it is most probable they will arrive by the the end of this week. Wistar spent this evening with us very pleasantly he says every thing is going on in the city as usual very few persons have as yet returned. Mother wishes that you should buy her a [--] de [---] dress in Boston. If you see any thing that would be suitable; she wishes you to consult your own taste in the matter. If you see one with a small figure that you admire get it or if you see a handsome plain one, not too light a color, something that would be suitable for autumn.  A plain one she would rather prefer if youmet with what suited you. Give my love to Cousins R & Maria and tell the former I regretted exedingly not having an opportunity to bid adieu farewell Mother and I fully expected to have seen him in the city and were quite disappointed in not doing so. I hope you will write soon and let us know how you are coming on as it is the only thing you can do to cheer us during your absence as the evening draws to a close I believe I must now bid you an aff good night. excuse haste.  if you either of choose to favour me with an epistle I will promise to answer it immediately and to some length.  your aff sister Mary.I suppose the Cousins R. & Maria to whom Aunt Mary refers in this letter where Cousins Robert & Maria Earle.  The former was very fond of kissing & Aunt Mary ysed to say that she always kept a pin ready to stick him if he came too near!  Mother must have been 21 at this time, Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue younger- Uncle Will came between Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue.  They were visiting Cousins in New England, where all Grandpa's relations lived.  At the time everybody travelled from New York to Boston by boat.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Nathan Cope:  1733-1820

Title: 1810 February 14, East Bradford, to Esteemed Cousin, Philadelphia

East Bradford 14th of 2nd mo 1810-
   
   Esteemed cousin-
   
   I request the favour of thee to purchase me four yds of broad Cloth, it is intended for my own wearing, I should not chuse a very dark Coulor, nor yet on the Yellow cast. But of a pretty good Quality tho not the foremost late. Thy judgement herin I prefer so much before my own is the cause of this application, form a hope thou will not think too much trouble of complying with the requests, and if [---] thou may embrace the present opportunity of sen[---] David Hoopes, if not by the west-Chester stages, [---] I am writing I have in prospect of Sending the money, but be that as it may the settling of the matter may be left as I entertain a hope of seeing thee at thy own dwelling before long.
    
   To Thomes P Cope
   Philadelphia
   
   Thy [---] relation
   Nathan Cope

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  George Drinker:  b. 1766
Recipient:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Date: 1793-05-26
Title: 1793 May 26, Alexandria, to Esteemed Cousin, Philadelphia

Alexandria 5mo 26th 1793
   
   Esteemed Cousin, I am sorry I had to leave the City without biding thee fairwell, and yet I found the task verry difficult, in taking leave of the few Friends I did; I am at the time safely arrived in a fruitful Country, and have a prospect of continuing here. Business appears to me to be carryed on to a very good Amount.  Hats I find a very good article, if thee has a mind to send me the Children's Hats, thee got of me, I think I could find sail for them much sooner than thee will be likely to put them off in Philada. I would take them at the wholesail price, and if thee has a mind to send them: apply to my Father and he will pack them up in a suiteable Caske, I wish thee would put up three Quire of large Hat paper in the Caske, thee will get it of Joseph Shoemak[er]. I have taken a Small Store in King Street. I have not been long enough here to positively assert that I can do Business to advantage, but I have scarely a doubt of it in my mind; I wish thee to send me, 2 doz of Sellerses Wool and Cotton Cards, 1 doz of each, if thee has any steel [---] Chains I should wish to have one doz of them . I likewise wish to have 2 Cards of steel keyes if thee has them not thy self thee may get themof Benjam Horner. he has them of 2 qualities thee has already been verry kind to me. I hope my conduct shall be such as to justify the Confidence thee has put in me and that I may act so as to be though worthy of thy Esteem, if thee could lern the Cash price for hemp and send it me by Elwood I would thank thee, I am in good health and Spirits and remain
 Affectionalely thine.
   
   George Drinker
   
   Remember me to Cos Poley
   if I have time I shall write to Peter Thomson but give my love to himThomas P. Cope Mercht
   North Second Street
   Philadelphia

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  George Drinker:  b. 1766
Recipient:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Date: 1805-07-18
Title: 1805 July 18, Alexandria, to Thos. P. Cope, Philadelphia

Alexandria July 18th 1805
   
   Thos. P. Cope
   Respected Kinsman
   
   I did not get thy letter of the 10th Inst. until yesterday; we had not quite completed our collections of Money subscried for the Engene: on fourth day next we shall procure a Check at the City Bank fro $405 and forward it to thee by Post, if thee has not engaged a Vessel to bring it round: we would prefer Capt. Elwood or Hand who will be at your port in a short time: they are careful and will only charge half freight.
   I observed in thy last letter an appology for the publication of my letter to our friend Joseph Bringhurst: altho I feele no kind of Ambition to appear in print. nevertheless if the insirtion of that communication can answer any useful purpose. I shall rest satisfyed. I must have appeard obvious to the convention that it was intened only for the eye of a discriminating friend: I am glad you published it in the form you did. More especially in omiting the conluding observation respecting the Richmond society. Not withstanding, they are sound facts which can be subtantially attested; shuch opinions may have a tendancy to extinguish the little spark of life yet remaing among them: & that I would cautiously avoid, please to excuse my detaining thee, the addresses, with a number of Copyes of the minutes of the Convention, were recd by Cap Hand. I have taken care to put them in the hands of a number of friends, & have distributed the addresses to the free blacks among the thoughtful & sober part of them they appear thankful for the attention, Indeed I consdier your labour towards these people, often profitably bestowed we have some among them who are sober orderly good member of society.-  last week I had the pleasure of spending a day at thy Brother Jasper, in Baltimore. am sorry to infrom thee I left him indisposed, tho I believe not seriously ill.  please remember me to thy family & friends. respectfully,
   
   George Drinker
Thomas P. Cope
   Mercht
   Philadelphia

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Joseph D. Drinker:  1796-1881
Recipient:  Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1768-1854
Date: 1814-11-06
Title: 1814 November 6, Newcastle, to Uncle, Philadelphia

Newcastle 6th Nov. 1814.
   
   Dear Uncle,
   
   You will be surprised to receive a letter from me, particularly dated as it is. I have not time to relate to you all the accidents, & delays which have occasioned our remmaing yet in the river, Wm Adams no doubt can inform you, I have scarsely time to write to you at all.- -
    To day Captian Banks asked me what clothes I had. I answered that I had but one round about, one thick waiscot, & one pair of trousers.  Upon which he ordered the boat ready, & took me ashore to Taylor's, & got me one round about, one waiscoat, one pair of pantaloons & one red flannel shirt with sleeves. The whole ammounted to $17.25 cts. which he said Mr Adams would pay, & I must write a letter to my father to inform him of it, & tell him to refund Mr. Adams.Now you Know my Dear Uncle that it was out of the question to tell the captian of the terms on which my father & me were. What could I do? I could think of no other expedient but to write to you & request you to refund Mr Adams. The Keg of tobacco which you was so kind as to give me, after it is turned into money, will enable me to pay you the $ 17.25 when I come back, & by trading, I hope to be able to pay you all the money that I owe you. As for the kindness which you have shown me, I feel all the gratitude & affection of a son towards you, & never while I breath will I forget your fatherly goodness to me. Please to tell Grandmother Drinker that I would be glad if she would let my father know that I entreat his forgiveness for what I was wrong in, & that I hopeTo be reconviled to him when I come back, & that I repent very much of all my bad conduct to him & am becoming quite changed in consequence of the hardships I endured & from reflection. I have no time to write anything more, please to give my love ot all your family & accept the same from you Affect [---]
   
   Jos. D Drinker jrMr Thomas P. Cope
   Fourth St. between market
   & Arch
   Philadelphia.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Davis H. (Davis Hoopes) Forsythe:  1858-1934
Recipient:  Francis Algernon Evans:  1878-1946
Date: 1911-03-27
Title: 1911 March 27, Westtown, to Boys

Westtown Pa.
   3 mo 27th 1911
   
   Dear Boys
   
   This morning's mail brings to me a sad  letter from your cousin Elizabeth Goodhue. It is my last wish to intrude upon your sorrow but I must make just a few words for my sake if not for yours.
   
   The greatesttrial of my life & even yet in retrospect it seems very great, your father was the very embodiment of kindness to me, the sort of kindness that allows your weakness to grow a little stronger from his strength & this and more than thisif possible he was to me. I remember, it was many years ago, the summer before Algernon went to College, your dear father said to me in the school house office "I did not sleep last night, for the thought of the responsibility of the rear-ing of these children of mine got so on my nerve that it banished sleep." I could ask for no better legacy for you dear fellows than that a father would wrestle in prayer the night through that God's blessing might rest on you & on his effort. He answered that prayer & long ago gave your father the assurance that he sought. I could write on and on for Icannot help mingling my tears with yours. With a messageof love to you mother & to Anna.
   Your Friend
    
   Davis H. Forsythe

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Davis H. (Davis Hoopes) Forsythe:  1858-1934
Recipient:  Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)  Evans:  1882-1976

Title: 1911 March 27, Westtown, to Boys

Westtown Pa.
   3 mo 27th 1911
   
   Dear Boys
   
   This morning's mail brings to me a sad  letter from your cousin Elizabeth Goodhue. It is my last wish to intrude upon your sorrow but I must make just a few words for my sake if not for yours.
   
   The greatesttrial of my life & even yet in retrospect it seems very great, your father was the very embodiment of kindness to me, the sort of kindness that allows your weakness to grow a little stronger from his strength & this and more than thisif possible he was to me. I remember, it was many years ago, the summer before Algernon went to College, your dear father said to me in the school house office "I did not sleep last night, for the thought of the responsibility of the rear-ing of these children of mine got so on my nerve that it banished sleep." I could ask for no better legacy for you dear fellows than that a father would wrestle in prayer the night through that God's blessing might rest on you & on his effort. He answered that prayer & long ago gave your father the assurance that he sought. I could write on and on for Icannot help mingling my tears with yours. With a messageof love to you mother & to Anna.
   Your Friend
    
   Davis H. Forsythe
