----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Hannah Rhoads Haines Garrett:  1846-1901
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1899-04-26
Title: 1899 April 26, Rosemont, to Lily

4 mo 26. 1899
   
   Dear Lily,
   
   There has been a lack of vocal or written sympathy with thee this winter, and this brief message is only to assure thee of my love and frequent thought being freshly flowing.That mere words would only weary thee I know and I only sent messages to thee by notes to Rachel. It was my hope that long before this my own strength would have retuned and enabled me to go to thee. But that is not the case as only a very little exertion ispossible yet - writing, almost is a lost art. Excuse this detail, because I could not otherwise explain my absence. Now we have heard of Edward's illness, and I wish to send by thee my love to Jonathan and Rachel, when it is convient to thee.
   
   We Also understand Edward is much beter, I hope convalescent.Dear, believe me, thy loss is shared in some degree by me, for thy lovely Agnes was especially near to me, her gentle pure spirit now a lasting place in my heart.
   
    She always seemed as one apart from our every-day routine, and now she is in full & glourious development of all her Savoir has prepared her to be for Him. Always lovingly thy
    Hannah R. Garrett.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Hannah Rhoads Haines Garrett:  1846-1901
Recipient:  Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Date: 1873-08-15
Title: 1873 August 15, Wolfrun Farm, to Lilly, Bar Harbour

Wolfrun Farm 8 mo 15. 1873
   
   My very dear Lilly,
   
   How many times lately has thee been in my thoughts and very pleasantly too. But owing to my peregrinations with the children, I have been unable to send thee a single greeting of love and good wishes. When John came out to Marple, and told me that one of my friends was announced as inelligible, I turned to thee at once, and said not to, with immense disapprobation and disbelief, and then revived mydrooping spirits with Oh! Alexis Cope! No, my dear, though I gave thee a sight of good advice in good faith, on Chellie's wedding day, about the opportune moment when house and grounds were in perfection, I was too modest to suppose it would sink so deep into thy heart, and show such good fruit so soon. Many thanks my dear, for they acceptance of my wishes as well as those of some one's else; and hope indeed thee will continue to follow my wishes when they again happen to coincide with thy own. This is destined to be a memorable year among my nearest friends, andone full of happines in its future consequences to Harry, Johnny, Chellie and thyself. How I wish to have a look at thee, and see with my eyes the happiness I feel sure must be thine. Am I to have no single friends left, my mind turns to H.B.E. and S.E. Marshall. I hope they will do nothing rash, and bring home some German counts or English baronets  with them. How much better we think it is not to risk our future to a stranger, but with those whom we can trust, & know all about their home life.
   
   As I look at Mary and Francis I begin to feel asympathy for thy mother, thus "bereaved of her children", as "I look in the future far as human eye can see" and think of the possibility that some pair of boys now fond of candy and fire-crackers may one summer turn their attention to destorying my house-hold harmony and peace-alas!
    
   Now I've written a deal of nonsense and a fear of Alexis comes before me, lest he has already imbued thee with dignifed scorn for such silliness. Do not betray me then, or I will whisper some of thy lightmindness in times past when I've a chance not that he would believe if I did I do long for some news from the European party,are they having a prosperous summer? With love to thy mother and thy self I am as ever thy warmly attached.
   
   H.R. GarrettElizabeth S. Cope
   Bar Harbour
   East Eden
   Maine

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  M.H. Garrett
Recipient:  Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth) Cope:  1840-1944
Date: 1883-09-30
Title: 1883 September 30, Germantown, to Carrie

Germantown, 9.30.83.
   
   My Dear Carrie-
   I hope the expression of sympathy & affection may be acceptable, even though there may be no new thoughts of comfort to suggest.
   
   I was so sorry to hear from Sister Lillie today that Edgar's health had been poor. I though of him as a strong man. It will be a pleasure, no doubt, though mingled with sadness, to Nettie & thee, to minister to the comfort of your remaining brother.
   
   The memory of Alexis is one of calmness & sweetness. I did not know him well, yet recall with pleasure the queit cordiality of his greeting. Samuel Morris, who rode in the same carriagewith me at the funeral, said he had learned to love him much. I think it is grateful to look back on his life here as a happy one, & his life there as is fit & glorious consummation. And he left a dear legacy in his children. I am glad you have them. I count myself so rich in my dear nephews & nieces, my young brothers & sisters, as I sometimes call them. Does thee know I am a great-aunt? My oldest nephew, Joseph Rhoads, has a wee Edgar, away out in Plainfield Indiana, where he has gone to teach. Hetty  is out there, helping. Has been away nearly 7 weeks & we don't know when we shall get her back. She went to help furnish & arrange the new little home.
   
   Fanny & Alfred Garret were here last evening a while. We do think Fannya very lively have character, & Alfred seems to be coming out a fine manly boy, & doing well at college. 
    
   How the time does fleet away! Think of it being 50 years since we were at West-town together! And what can those fleeting years show? For me, a life made up of many little things, & with too many idle hours. I enjoy my work of various kinds though; simple household cares, an extensive correspondence, partly for pleasant sympathies, partly for teaching, & on the rest days, a restful work in the care of my first-day class. Dr. Rhoads holds a school at our house and I have as my class nearly 20 boys & girls from 9 to 14 years old who troop up to my room with me. I will not claim to do them much good. I don't believe in direct religious teaching exceptwhere there is an opening for it, but I think the hour passes not unprofitably, & they learn to find the study of the Bible pleasant.    
   I hope Ellie Alderson may continue to improve. I should be glad to hear from thee if thee can feel like writing, & to be told what your prospects are.
   With Love to Nettie & Thyself,
   ever thy affectionate friend
   
   M. H. Garrett

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna C. (Anna Cope) Hartshorne:  1860-1957
Recipient:  Annette Cope:  1843-1916
Date: 1895-09-01
Title: 1895 September 1, Woodbourne, to Annette

Woodbourne
   Sept. 1st 1895
   
   My dear Annette,
   
   When I reached Holmhurst last week Nanna immediately presented me with thy package, and I opened and found the irresistable little gentleman from Dai Nippon. Where did thee pick him up, I wonder! He will be a most pleasant memento of thee, though I shall hesitate to insult his diginity by inkinghis fine skirts! I have thought of thee, and of you all so much this summer, and greatly wished I could have seen thee and Carrie before we leave. I hoped Mrs. Cope would return while I was at Holmhurst, but she is I supppose still with you. If so please give her my dear love. Thee will forgive me I know for this tardy work, I spent a whole week nominally at Holmhurst, actually between the city, Germantown, and all the [---]. Thee knows onlytoo well what such packing is. Now I am enjoying a few day's rest at Woodbourne before going back to Awbury for a square start westward. Virginia here and sends her love, also says to tell thee that I will meet thee in Italy winter after next. I tell her I give the message as hers, not mine! Much as I should like such a prospect; she is much more liekly to turn up there in the next year or two, than I! Lillie and the girls & Thos. & Elizabeth Cope are entertaining Dr. Norris and a Germandoctor friend in the parlor, else they would doubtless send messages. Please give my love to Carrie and Clementine, I understand you are all together, and are glad to know you have that comfort. With dear love for thy own self, and thanks for thinking of me amid so much sorrow, I am as always,
   
   Affectionally thine
   Anne C. Hartshorne

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna C. (Anna Cope) Hartshorne:  1860-1957
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1909-11-10
Title: 1909 November 10, to Aunt Anna

16 [---]
   Nov-10-1909
   
   Dearest Aunt Anna,
   
    There is nothing to say to thee but that I think of thee all the time, and long to be near thee instead of on the other side of the earth. The letters with any definite news will be very slow in coming, as these of mine must seem late and longin reaching you. But thee knows, and you all know, how my heart is with you. I have been thinking of Father’s last message to his "more than brother", and of what both he and thee have been to me all my life. From my babyhood thee has made me feel almost as much thy child as mother’s and to me it seems those tiesare not broken but made strong for eternity, where our beloved cross to the Beyond. My desire is to be worthy of such an inheritance of affliction as mine. My love can never repay it, but that thee has always.
   
   Ask some to write me a line when they can. My Love to them all.
   
   Thy always loving niece,
   Anna C. Hartshorne

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  John Stokes:  1800-1868
Recipient:  Thomas Pim Cope:  1823-1900
Date: 1860-03-27
Title: 1860 March 27, Astor House, New York, to Thomas P. Cope, Philadelphia

Thomas P. Cope Philada
   
   My dear Son, I thought I could no longer forbear expressing in this way my feeble acknowledgements for thy many tokens of unparalleled kindness and generosity towards me and mine, the number and magnitude of which have frequently overwhelmed me with feelings that I cannot ever attempt to express, and that simple gratitude is but a feeble term to represent. For since the departure of my beloved and sainted consort, whose loss I more and more deplore and which seems more and more irreparable, and almost constantly weighs upon my feelings, there seems but few ties remaining to attach me to this world, except my children, who seem to me (pardon a fathers weakness), so worthily to rifle at their mother’s virtues and graces, that I hold myself excusable for wearing them in my hearts care, as constituting the principal charm of my declining years. So that amid all my trials, and I have had my share, I feel thankful that I am blessed with such a family, and have been so favored in sundry ways, not the least of which is that of having in incorporated with us, one, who seems to have been as a guardian angel to us all. And I am humbly sensible that I cannot be too thankful to a kind providence for such a blessing, and regard it as a special dispensation of divine mercy and goodness towards us, that thee has beenso cordially united to my family, and that so much affectionate unity and sympathy should prevail amongst us, binding us together in bonds, which I trust nothing will ever be able to weaken or to sever. My dear departed consort and myself did frequently dwell upon these considerations, and united in the belief that a blessing would attend thy influence and example on our children, particularly our sons; and I think this has indeed been already realized in good measure; and my sincere desire and prayer for them is, that they may continue to walk circumspectly and depend themselves wisely and consistently in all things, so as to render themselves in a degree worthy of thy almost paternal concern and kindness: which none of us can ever hope to compensate in any other way than by the most respectful deference, and affectionate regard; under a warm sense of which, I conclude, and subscribe myself thy deeply obliged and grateful father in law.
   
   John Stokes
   
   Astor House, New York
   3 Month 27th, 1860.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  George O. Walker:  b. 1838
Recipient:  Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Date: 1888-12-23
Title: 1888 December 23, Woodbourne, to Clementine Cope

Woodbourne 12/23- 88
   
   My very Dear Friend Clementine Cope,   Many thanks for your lovely Christmas Greeting & for  Christmas Box ccontaining a superior Down Comfortable Superior Oranges grapes &c for which I am much obliged very grateful & much oblidged yesterday I tested the quality of the Down for keeping warm  It was certainly very thoughtful & kind in sending a covering. So useful to protect from severe cold from the severity soften think of Elizabeth the exile of Siberia undertakiing a journey two thousand miles to obtain a pardon from the Emperor of Russia for her Father. When the weather is more congenial than at present, I hope that you three lovely Sisters may not hesitate to perform a visit to yournative land where you will be certain to obtain a kind welcome we miss your agreeable manners & refined good sense more than words can tell. May we not anticipate the pleasure of a good long visit next summer three lovely sister.  I sincerely wish you one & all a very Happy Christmas & New Year & Many happy returns of the Same. Thanks to a kind Providence I am still favored to enjoy good health with the exception of Rheumatism. I enjoy a good appetite & sleep will at nights for which I am very thankful. Please write soon to your deserted lonely friend & with that love which neither nor distance can efface for Dear thee Clementine I remain very truly & sincerely thy affectionate loving friend G Walker

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Date: 1901-01-19
Title: 1901 January 19, to Father & Mother

[January 19th]
   [1901]
   
   Dearest Father & Mother,
   
   First of all thank thee ever so much, dear Father, for the lovely flowers which came last evening.  They are beautiful and the vase of carnations and asparagus fern, which Miss Richardson put on my center table this morning, was truly good to look at!  I am glad youaccomplished the journey home comfortably, and I hope Mother was not much the worse for all the exertion.  I have been tobogganing since I saw you.  Only once however, as the next time we tried it we found it was no good.  We had a good ride, however, down to the hill hitched on behind the sleigh.  I stay down in the evenings now till halfpast eight, and last night I laughed till my sides ached to see Dr. Shine and Mr Wells drilling Miss Barnard (one of the patients)- teaching her to salute etc.  They were killing!  They play a game here called Louisa, which is something like Parcheesee, and we have fun on that too.  I have progressedquite a little with the Autoharp, and find it quite absorbing-
   
   [Jan. 25th]
   
   Almost a week you see since this letter was started, and I have a lot more things to acknowledge now.  Two letters from Mother, I think (one of which I have just read.  I don’t mean I haven't read both) besides one from Esther, and Frannie Strawbridge's weddinginvitation.  The latter was indeed a surprise.  I hope the man is nice.  The silk dress also arrived safely & in good condition I think.  Please give Esther my love and thank her for her letter which I was very glad to get.  I dont think I thanked Alg or Ted for their last letters either, though they camea good while ago-  Ted's especially.  I certainly do get nice letters.  I have been skating a good deal since I started this letter and having great fun playing hockey with Mr. Wells and Mr. Chipman and once with Miss Chapman (one of the nurses) & once with Miss Richardson.  It soundsvery fine to say I played hockey, but Miss Richardson and I could at least get our feet and skirts not to mention our sticks in front of the goal & so do some good.  I shrieked so in the excitement I could be heard way up at the house!
   
   I have finished the little hood I was knitting(which alas did not turn out to be a little one owing to my loose handling) & I have nearly finished another which is much more of a success.  I guess I wont take another sheet but will begin to say good-by.  Please give my dear love to each of the boys, & to them all at Grandpa's & Aunt Lilly's & [---] if you think of it.  Tell Aunt Hannah I am using & enjoying her hunting bag.  And with a lot of love for your own dear selves I am your loving little Daughter.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967

Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Date: 1901-01
Title: 1901 January, to Family

Wednesday
   
   [Jan ? 1901] 
   
   Dearest Family, 
   
   Well!  I have had two visits since I last wrote, & mighty nice ones they were.  Aunt L & Ellie came the first time (I told you I wondered  which 2 it would be, didnt I?) & after theyhad been here about an hour & we had a good talk Dr. Stedman came up and said they would have time for a cup of tea at the [---] House (his house you know) & that Miss Stedman was there-  Mrs. Stedman was away unfortunately.  He asked me to come down, too, so we all went& I enjoyed it ever so much, as it was the first time I had been inside their house.  I was sorry Aunt Lilly didn't see Mrs. Stedman, but I believe they have asked her & Miss Stedman to lunch with them at Brunswick so they will meet after all.  I was in hopes the Doctor would let me go into lunch with them some day this week but he thinks I am not quite ready for that, so they are coming out again.  Mary & Frank came on Monday & we had a jolly time, & Polly is coming out with Aunt Lilly & Ellie when they come, I think.  Frank will come again, toosometime, I guess & I have found out that I can call him up on the telephone if I want to.  I had a nice little talk with Polly last evening on that instrument, & a few words with Aunt Lilly.  The latter is not very fond of talking on it& they have had some rather funny times I guess, as they have telephones in their rooms to the office instead of bells.  To-day they are Cambridge.  I believe, lunching with Mr. Foote at the Colonial Club, & are at present looking at the glass flowers, I expect.  Of course youknow [---] or "tea" for them, & they met lots of people there.  I told Dr. Stedman I was crazy to go to it, & he said he would love to let me, but he didnt think I was up to it.  Perhaps I shall get to Class Day, however. 
   
   To change the subject, I dont think I ever acknowledged the little bookthee mailed me, Mother dear, from Aunt Lizzie Cope.  I [---] it all night, & sometime will you give her my love & thank her very much for me?  Then the photos & the card-case Aunt L brought.  The card case is all right & so are the photos, but I'm going to bother you to send mesome more things.  Thanks very much for these first, however.  The other things are- 1. the little lace tie to go around your neck, which Cousin Hannah sent me last summer- 2. my two lace collars- one of [---] edged with lace, & one of illusion with wide lace onthe edge- 3 my little gold pin (not a strap pin but a clasp) one of a pair I used to have, & my little white wreath pin (that is if it is all right to send them by mail), 4 & some more photos.  It is so nice to have those you sent, & I want more.  I'd like my group of the GoldenWedding for one thing, & if there is a copy of that picture of Mother & me I want that & there is a picture of Esther in a little frame & one of Mary Emlen- & any others you can find.  I cant have too many-  If the frames are bulky dont send them, though I'd like to have the ones Esther & Mary are in,if you can manage it.  If there are any old kodak pictures of Awbury or Conanicut send them, too, but dont bother too much.  You see it is so nice to have them to show to Miss Webb & other people to whom I talk about things, besides the phasum of having them to look at myself.  I do wish therewas a good one of Father-  You might send me the family group.  He is pretty good in that.  The one of the house you sent is great & I have it on my bureau, next to the boys. 
   
   Now I'm going to stop this scrawl.  I hope you dont think I'veasked for a great many things.  Miss Richardson thinks my bloomers are in my trunk.  I'm awfully sorry.  Miss R. wants to be remembered to Mother. 
   
   With lots of love I am in great haste. 
   Your very loving
   
   Anna.

You see it is so nice to have them to show to Miss Webb & other people to whom I talk about things, besides the phasum of having them to look at myself.  I do wish therewas a good one of Father-  You might send me the family group.  He is pretty good in that.  The one of the house you sent is great & I have it on my bureau, next to the boys. 
   
   Now I'm going to stop this scrawl.  I hope you dont think I'veasked for a great many things.  Miss Richardson thinks my bloomers are in my trunk.  I'm awfully sorry.  Miss R. wants to be remembered to Mother. 
   
   With lots of love I am in great haste. 
   Your very loving
   
   Anna.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Francis Algernon Evans:  1878-1946
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1901-07-08
Title: 1901 July 8, Awbury, to Mother

Awbury 7/8/01
   
   Dearest Mother
   It seems rather absurd to start to write to you so soon after you started but by my calculations it will have to be written tonight in order to catch you on your arrival as I will not be able to [---] tomorrow night and this must go by 4th days boat.  I suppose that as you will have fully recovered from any bad effects of the voyage when this reaches you it will be ok for my to express my present wonderings about your present condition.  I hope that you are not wishing like Ellie Garrett did that you were like a woman in Boston who hadnt any stomach.  I dont believe you are tho it is not so very long since you started and I am afraid that there is a chance that in spite of all opinion plaster;s etc the sea may still have its effects on certain ones, I wont mention names!  Well we are having not delightfully cool weather now.  It is simply great here at home but I can just hear those at Woodbourne and at Jamestown comment on their blessings in having it so cool and sigh for those of us who have to stay ay [---] in "that awful heat."  Well poor things it makes them feel a sight happier and it dont hurt us.  We have just had a circus of a time with a couple of fox terrier pups wich uncle Hazen invited in.  He has been keeping them down at the stable during his absense and Uncle Thomas' household have had a perfectly charming time with their midnight serenades.  Tonight he came home & brought them down here and they didnt do a thing but get themselves and every body else tied up and during supper time they raised perfect cane barking.  UncleHazen had to rush out a couple times to see the cause of the rumpus and now he has put them down in the cellar and because they are quiet now thinks he has solved the problem of keeping them quiet!  I have my doubts but am not saying anything just yet a while.  Grandpa and Uncle T. did not come down today after all.  Uncle Hazen received a telegram today saying that they would be down on 4th day.  I rather expect that Uncle Hazens stage party which comes off tomorrow night has rather discouraged them tho I dont know anything about it.  I did nothing during thr 4th except go over to Ros[---] in the evening and see them send off a lot of fireworks which were very good considering they were private.  The Goodhue kids were great sports.  Little [---] nearly turned inside out when a rocket or bomb went off.  On 7th day I took a Sabbath day journey out to Moorestown and played cricket which turned out desasterously to us as we were beaten 162 to 50 of which I made 10.  I stayed out at Moorestown with Stodgell Stokes to supper and had a very pleasant visit with them.  I had never been there before and enjoyed seeing them much.  Dr & Mrs Stokes inquired after you all.  I had intended to get out to Joes Morris' to stay over 1st day but I could not get in town in time to get out to Villa Nova before very late so I came home.  On 1st day I went to Frank Goodhues to dinner and in the evening went to Emlens to supper.  On 6th day Evening I went down to Shoemakers to see Anna & Frank Fortunately they were at home and I had a very nice visit.  Tomorrow Anna Hacker, Mary Jones, Annie Williams, Frank Stokes, Frank Strawbridge & myself are going up to Willow Grove.  I guess we will have pretty good time.  Tell Ed that I tried to getsomething for ASM but all the stores were closed before I got there at the Girard namely [---].  I will try & do it tomorrow.  I have not heard anything definite about my vacation yet but I guess I can have it sometime in Aug.  I am fine & well so dont be [---] of those who bother about the heat.  Give my love to Anna Ed Es. and with a great deal for thyself I am as ever thy loving son Alg.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Ernest Mervyn Evans:  1884-1911
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1906-07-22
Title: 1906 July 22, Awbury, to Mother

Awbury
   July 22
   
   Dear Mother, 
   I believe that to-morrow is thy birthday, and having no more useful or ornamental token to offer I will dedicate this epistle to the celebration of the happy occasion. Think of that! Well, dear, please take much love from thy son, at  any rate, and thanks for thy letter. 
    
   We are having some most welcome rain here this evening which I hope will continue for sometime but am a little afraid is only the edge of a gust. We had a little rain last night too so I hope that the dry spell is broken. Things are pretty well dried up, and Milton has had to start feeding the cows.  Ralph is still staying with us which I certainly find very satisfactory, though I am afraid that his being here prevents the boys from having some of their friends, as four is about our number, for comfort. 
   
    Tom Evans came over and played some tennis this afternoon and Alg has been taking supper with him this evening. He is certainly an amusing person. 
   
    Last evening Ed and Alg went over to Stokes' for supper. 
    
    Next seventh day we will probably be away as Ed and Alg are invited to the Wright's at [Bayhrad] and Alg and I are bidden to Suis. I don't know how Alg will fix it up. Please give Father, Anna and Harold & Miss R. my love and Esther too if she is with you. 
    
   Maggie seems to bear up nobly, though Jennie has not been able to start to work yet. With much love from thy son. 
    
   Ernest Awbury

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Hannah Bacon Evans:  1839-1939
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1882-09-03
Title: 1882 September 3, Meadowfield, to sister

Meadowfield 9.3.
   
   My beloved sister
   I feel as tho' I wanted to send thee another greeting before you leave Newport, thy last letter was very welcome with its good report of your welfare, I trust you have all continued in good case & will return home strengthened for the cares & duties of the winter.  As to dear little Edward, I do not suppose we shall know him, nor doubt he has changed much, I hope he will make up his mind to take food when he really needs it, perhaps he may take to a cup & spurn if a bottle is too insulting to his dignity.  Rebekah Smith's little boy is growing nicely & is a cute baby with the large dark eyes, your children ought to our ideas, & tho' his fractures are rather too large now for baby beauty he promises to develope that trait after awhile; at present his great charm is his good behavior, which is a real comfort to his mamma as her nurse left her sooner than she wished & she has only a young girl to assist her in taking care of him.  I suppose it will not be very long now before you are turning your faces homeward & it will be pleasant to think of your bring near us.  tho' we shall not see one another for awhile.  I am glad to hear from a letter to Katharine from Jthat you will not move into your own house until the 11th month, as I would like to be on hand at that season, having a fancy for such dissipations.  I have seen allusions in the papers to the burning of The Cliff House, but have not seen any account of the event, what a favor you were not there! & how about the boarders, did they lose their things was anyone hurt, poor Mrs Emmons I hope she was not there, (or thy Aunt Lizzie).  By the way what do you hear of the latter.  I trust her trip to England has been of use to her, when do you expect her back.  I am sorry to hear that Hazen is not very strong, perhaps he did too much, it seemed a very short time to be absent.  Since our last letter to thee we have had a visit from Susan Kito & Amy Roberts, they are bothundemonstrative people, especially Susan, but they enjoyed being here I think, SK was not well & did not like to ride so we had a quiet time, reading, talking, examining flowers & looking at objects in the compound microscope, one of Frank's late investments; they took tea at sister Eleanor's & also at Joshua's.  Sister Eleanor's summer home was vacated on 3rd day, she, Tom, Ellie, & Walter drove home with the two horses & carriage she spent one night at Arondale & one at HM Stokes at Chester & reached Germantown on 5th day evening.  Hetty & Wistar have gone to "Uncle Gideon's" & Betty is staying with us; the stay down here has been a real succes, the children have been very well & happy, have found much to interest & occupy them.Wistar & Franky have spent many hours in "bug hunts" & do manifest much zeal in the collection of beetles, butterflys & moths, & really have quite a large number; we labor under great difficulty as far as the study of the subject is concerned, as we have no books on Entomology except one by [Wood?] which treats of British insects, I quite want to get some good work & be able to learn the names of some of the creatures the boys have.  I have wandered away from my starting point, sister Eleanorfound the quiet of the country life & the absense of the many demands on her time & thoughts that she has to meet in Germantown a great rest, & altho' the house has not much to attract as regards situation it did not make the same difference to her it would to us, as she is so fond of riding she was out almost daily & enjoyed taking others drives.  Thee may remember Katharine & I find great comfort in sitting under the trees or lying in the hammocks when not busy sewing.  I suppose Hetty will stay down some weeks yet, her trip to Mt [Desert?] brokeinto her summer & I think she dont feel at all ready to leave Maryland.  John & Walter came down yesterday with Frank but dont expect to make much of a visit as they talk of going back tomorrow.  We heard a report that Sophy Kimber was to be married at Newport this summer, does thee know if it is so, her certificate has been sent on from 12th st, we shall miss her from Germantown she is so efficient & willing.  Now my dear sister when thee writes, which I hope may be [---] long, please tell us how thee is, Katharine wishes to know if thee has picked up any fat in the cool air, how does thy nurse geton, I hope she has proved an efficient help.  It is raining quite heavily now, which is not as acceptable as at some seasons, but when I think how we have longed for it in former days I dont like complaining.  The season of canning has arrived & folks in this part of the country are busy enough putting up corn, tomatoes & peaches &c, I should feel dubious about eating the products of some of the factories, as they employ Bohemians whose cleanliness is more than doubtful.  We were quite startled to see the death of Mary Morton yesterday, she spent a few days with Rebekah some 2 weeks ago, but was not well then & wished to get to Phila, it is such a favor she went up when she did or she might have died here.  Please give my love to thy mother & Lilly, kiss the dear children for me & accept for thyself a message of warmaffection from thy attached sister K sends love Hannah B. Evanscan thee tell us anything of the Newhalls.  Ive not heard from A for some time & fear her mother is more poorly.

Title: 1884 August 8, Meadow Farm, to Anna

Meadow Farm
   8 Mo 8th/84
   
   My dear little Anna
    
   I have thought of thee very often since thee left us on 4th day morning and shall be glad to hear how thee and Ethel made out on your journey, did she behave well? and was thee very tired when thee got to Montrose? I expect you have had a great many nice plays together, I mean thee, Agnes, Franky and Ellie, not Ethel and thee! I left Germantown the day after thee did and came down  to Maryland with cousins George Emlen and Katy Stokes, Edith came over to Conowingo to meet us, with Robert, and they put the trunk in the front of the carriage and sat on it instead of a seat, cousin George rode up with Horace Stokes, so we all got home nicely, only the roads are very rough and we were well shaken up. Just after dinner today we had a very hard rain and Wistar, Edith and Franky put on thin bathing clothes and ran about out doors until it was nearly over and then they went down to the streamthat crosses our lane and here they found the water so deep they took another bath in that, which they thought was great fun. They have a kitten a little larger than yours but she is nearly all white except her tail which is grey with a white tip; aunt Kate says her name is Pennyroyal but Edith don't like that at all, and Wistar says she ought to be called Tip. We expect Henry home tomorrow and shall be very glad to see him. Cousin George, Ellie and the children are not staying with us now, theyare at Gideon Smiths but the children, all except Sam, are to go home tomorrow. I hope Franky's trumpet did not get bent going up, and that he liked it and the game. I am afraid Aunt Lilly won't care to have him blow the trumpet very near the house, perhaps you take it when you go out rowing on the lake or walking in the woods. I hope thee will get quite strong and fat and have a very good time. Give my love to aunt Lilly and Anna and a great deal to thy self with a kiss from thy aunt Hannah.The Children have all gone to bed or they would send love to thee.Anna Cope Evans
Dimock PO
Susquehanna Co
Penna.

Date: 1885-08-16
Title: 1885 August 16, Meadow Farm, to brother

Meadow Farms
   8 Mo 16.85.
   
   My beloved brother
    
   Thy letter of love and sympathy was very acceptable for tho' our friends cannot do much for us just now we do appreciate their sympathy. I am sorry I cannot tell thee that dear Katy is better, her fever still continues tho her temperature is one degree down this morning. I believe I told thee the typhoid symptoms had disappeared, which conclusion I jumped at from hearing the Dr. say the trouble about the abdomen was gone, and tongue clearing off, but on saying something like it to the Dr., he replied he thought they seemed to be developing much more then in the first weeks of the sickness.  Dr. Newlin Stokes came down to G. Smith's funeral yesterday, saw Katy and had a consultation with Dr. Sapington. Yesterday for the 1st time a few spots appeared in the abdomen and the Dr.s both said that was the 9th day of the typhoid fever, so dear child she has a long siege before her yet. It was a great satisfaction that Dr. Stokes said the case had been treated just as he should have done and he had no change to suggest except giving valerian instead of bromide to quiet her at night. They both unite in giving little medicine, only quinen to keep up her strength and all the nourishment she can take. Dr. [Lapingson?] thought perhaps Valentines extract did not suit her so we now squeeze the bloodOut of raw beef and give her that every four hours. Sam will send us down a druggists press, which will be a help in getting the juice out. Both Dr.'s said we ought to have a nurse, Dr. Stokes said he know of one he thought we could get, Frank telegraphed for her and I think Thomas Cope will probably see her for us tomorrow and if suitable send her down. It will be a comfort to have some one who is skilful and can move and change Katy with less fatigue than we do. Frank stays with Katy part of every night and helps much with the nursing, but Katherine is so anxious and nervous I fear she will be quite laid up unless we have some help. Katy's fever is not high, 102 2/10 the highest her temperature has reached and todayit is a degree less. She has little disturbance of the bowels and no head ache, her mouth and throat are very uncomfortable, feel gummy and sore and she feels very weak and weary. Slept but little last night and the hours were long and tedious for her, she is very patient but at times is nervous. Edith seems to be gaining, is taken down stairs everyday and takes tea with us, Dr. took her temperature today and found it a little below normal, says she must have a little brandy. It is rather depressing for her and [Esther?] and frankly, we are so taken up with Katy and the house has to be kept so quiet, so it is proposed for them to go to Uncle's for a few days and when Edith is stronger they may go to Awbury. If sister Eleanor takes Ellie away perhaps the girls could accompany her. I am glad to know you are better for Newport air, we had a very nice letter from dear Rachel please thank her for it and let her see this as I shall not have time to write to her now. I rejoice to think thee spent some days at Batemans and do hope thee feels stronger for it, thee will be lonely at Awbury with so many of both families away. With much love from usAll I am thy attached sister Hannah. I remember this is thy birthday.

Title: 1902 August 3, Locust Avenue, to sister

[Tear this up when you have read it.  I have answered it.] 
   
   Locust Avenue
   8 Mo 3rd
   
   My dear sister
   
   I am once more at home and quite miss hearing of thy welfare and dear Anna's from Jonathan's letters.  I hope you still continue to gain and enjoy the mountain air.  When I got home last 2nd day, I felt very much used up with the heat & the change in air, but now have become accustomed to it and feel quite well, tho' the amount of moisture in the air makes things damp & sticky.  No doubt thee has heard particulars of E.W. Copes last hours, the close must have been very peaceful, both Ellie & Madgie express their feelings of thankfulness that their mother did not have to endure long confinement and great suffering.  The funeral was small, so many are away, S. Morris and E Allen bore testimony to her character, there was nothing said at the grave but there was such a sweet, quiet feeling as we stood silently there in the evening lights, everything looking so beautiful & peaceful, words did not seem to be needed.  E. Allen said after meeting today to Eleanor & me, that after sheheard of E.W. Copes death she went into her room and such a sweet feeling came over her, she felt it was a forecast of the rest & peace into which Elizabeth Cope had entered.  I rode to the ground with cousin Rebecca Evans, she spoke of cousin Elizabeth, said the letter thee wrote her had been such a particular comfort and help to her, that Rebecca had felt she must write & tell thee but has been rather burdened with calls, so I said I would let thee know about it, I think R sent her love to thee.  Will & Grace have both had mumps, and little Mary, (Alice'sdaughter) has been very sick, she is now gaining down at the Dennis and Grace has been there with them.  Cousin Wm & John Rhoads have gone to T. Brown's camp for their vacation.  I send thee one of Esthers letters as thee may be interested to hear something of the Conference.  It seems to have been a time of spiritual refreshment & uplifting & I hope may prove of use to the building up of the Church.  Eleanor says the spirit of love & unity was very marked, Alfred urged that all [---] and feelings of antagonism between old & young, conservative & progressive should be laidaside, which seemed to be the case.  Alfred seems to feel his mind relieved of the concern, he went back to Bupshire yesterday & is going on to Northfield.  Frank Goodhue also went to Bupshire will spend today there & go on to Brattleboro taking little Mary with him.  Edith Silver came up on 5th day eve, it was very pleasant to see her, she went home yesterday, Betty & little Elizabeth & Sam Mason all went with her.  Betty intends spending a couple of weeks at Swallowfield where she hopes to have a good rest.  Francis Jr is at Bupshire so all the children are cared for.  Sister Eleanor & Tom I believe are going to Bupshire soon & Wistar to the South on business so the house will be deserted  for awhile.  Katy & the childrenpropose coming home on 3rd day.  Frank came on to the funeral but went back last night, I am glad for him to have a visit there.  Emma Edwards fell in her house and broke her hip, she is now very ill not expected to live & her life is not to be [---] under the circumstances.  I had an active time last week attending meetings but got on better than I expected to, tomorrow is Phila Quarterly Mg & 5th day ours, after that I shall take a rest and do a little here at home, as I see many things that need looking after.  I dont know when Esther will come home probably in about a week.  A great deal of love to dear Anna & also for thyself from thy attached sister
   
   Hannah B. Evans   

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Harold Evans:  1886-1977
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1905-03-11
Title: 1905 March 11, Haverford College, to Mother

Dear Mother
   It certainly does not seem over two weeks ago that I saw you at Aldine, and I can scarcely tell what I have been doing with myself.  The Sophomore-Freshman debate caame off the Third-day of the week after I saw you, and so I was pretty busy preparing for that.  Unfortunately we lost.  It was the first thing the Freshmen had beaten us in, so we were rather sour.  Then the next night came the Entertainment for the Preston Boys' Club.  I had no idea of staying till the dance but go to talking and didn't get back till after twelve!  It was very good fun and I enjoyed it very much.  It is rather good fun to watch other people dance even though you don't dance yourself.  It was a success financially too, and we cleared $156.25 all of which, I am glad to say was given to the Boys' Club through Dr. Babbitt.  For a wonder the newspaper report about Emily Fox and the Biddles was true except that I think it was greatly exaggerated.  Detectives have been put on the case, I believe and they hope to recover at least some of the things.  I don't know whether they think they lost it or that it was stolen.  It certainly was mighty hard luck as I believe some of Emily's things were valuable on account of being heir looms. 
   
   Ernest's knee, I think is just about all right.  He can walk around on it all right but I imagine it is still weak. 
   
   The weather here has been quite warm and the snow has been melting pretty fast, but there is a good deal of ice over things and it takes a good while to melt that off.  To-day however is quite cool again, though I imagine it will warm up toward the middle of the day as the sun has so much power.  It sounds fine to hear of May days and violets and daffodils but it will not be so very long before we too shall be getting spring, for here it is about a third of  the way through March.  It certainly seems funny to think that there are only three more weeks of the third quarter left; for the fourth quarter goes by like grease-lightening.  I am glad I am not in Ernest's shoes. 
   
   To-night the gymnasium competition with Lehigh University comes off and I certainly hope we win.  Last week our team went up to Rutgers, and when the last event began we were several points behind, but we won the event and the meet by one point!  I hope it will be as exciting to-night. 
   
   It is fine to hear of all that Anna can do.  Please give her a great deal of love from me and tell her that this letter is for her too.  I suppose thee has heard of President Sharpless' illness.  He has not been at college for nearly three weeks, I think.  They took him into the Pennsylvania Hospital where Fred Sharpless  is one of the physicians, but he is better now. 
   
   Last Fourth day afternoon we had another festivity in the way of a Faculty tea for the Sophomores.  It was rather good fun, though I don't think much of teas.  They are too stiff and formal. 
   
   I think I shall have to cry a halt as my slender stock of news is about exhausted.  With lots of love for you both and thanking thee very much for thy letter, 
   
   Thy very affectionate son   Harold.   

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Harold Evans:  1886-1977
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1905-09-05
Title: 1905 September 5, Jamestown R.I., to Mother

Jamestown R.I.
   Sept 5th 1905
   
   Dear Mother
   
   I was just about to write to thee, in fact I started a letter last night, getting as far as the date,- when I received thine this morning.  I wrote to Mr. Wood on Sixth day and I suppose he has received it by this time.  It is rather a new experience writing to elderly gentlemen, so I hope I didn't say anything queer. 
   
   Art Brown arrived a week ago last First-day and he and Paul and I had a very good time.  Art is very different from the rest of mankind- he is so very anxious to please and writes letters at such an awful rate.  In one mail he sent eight or nine letters including postals.  Isn't that awful? We jollied him a great deal, Paul and I, too much I am afraid, but he was so good-natured about it that it was hard to know when to stop.  On Third-day, after we had been to tennis, Margaret Mellor asked us all to go out sailing.  I could not go as I had to play in the tennis tournament, but Paul and Art went and had a rather amusing time.  Then she asked us down to a marshmallow roast on Fifth-day night.  We were not very keen about going but nevertheless went and had a very crazy time.  In the first place the crowd did not know each other at all,- some of them were very gay and sporty while others were sedate and sober like myself.  Paul and Art spent most of the time having a marshmallow fight.  Eleanor Haydock was there (this was the one saving feature of the evening) and so I managed to survive.  The consequence of these two invitations wasthat we decided we ought to try to do some thing in return.  Sixth-day was Arts last day so we tried to find out what he wanted to do and finally decided to take a sail in the morning and the Ocean Drive in the afternoon.  Paul decided he would rather play tennis so Art and I went down to the Bay Voyage and asked Margaret Mellor and Eleanor Haydock to go.  I am not especially keen about Margaret Mellorm so she, of course, went, while Eleanor, who was staying at [---] Wharton's, decided she had better return and see whether they had anything for her to do.  We took three large fat magazines and managed to have a pretty good time.  In the afternoon we took the Ocean Drive and nearly died laughing.  The swells were out in force with their footmen and coachmen, and, as
Paul and Art were not much used to them, some of their remarks were very amusing.  They kept speaking to the different ones they passed and then went off in fits of laughter.  We drove back over the hills back of the golf-course, and it certainly was mighty pretty.  Art left that night and went down to Elsie Smith's house-party the next day.  Paul left on Seventh day morning on the nine o'clock train for Boston and went up to the White Mts (as far as Plymouth by the same train as we took).  He is at present at the Flume House, and I should not be so very much surprised if he came over your way some of these days.  His father and mother, Ellis and he are going to stay there for a couple of weeks and Paul told me that his father had been going up there for the last fifty years and had only missed about
ten.  I don't know whether this is true or not but Paul said so!  Alg and the rest of the crowd arrived about an hour after Paul departed this island (You say "departed this life" so I don't see why you should not say "departed this island").  Things began to move [instanter?] and the first thing done was a game of roof-ball in which Art and I defeated Joe and Alg most ignominiously after which we inquired if they could play marbles or any such game!  A little baby-in-the-hat was the result but unfortunately was interrupted by swimming.  On Seventh-day afternoon Jim asked me to race with him in his new half-rater (15 footer).  I accepted with great pleasure and went down to Whitall's to lunch.  Six of the little boats, all exactly alike, started.  There were two of E.D. Morgan's (one sailed by his daughter and the other byhis son) one of the Lippitt's, on of the Wetherill's and one sailed by Miss Grosvenor.  Miss Morgan did not understand the course and started off wrong, but instead of giving up the race she kept her nerve and came chasing after us.  When we rounded the last buoy we were third but were soon passed by another boat.  From that time on Miss Morgan and we did not follow the rest but showed our independence, and we won while she came in second.  I was pretty nearly as glad to see her beat the rest of them as I was that we won.  It was Jim's first victory so I think I must have been his mascot!  When we awoke on First-day morning a good old southeaster was snoring outside but we braved the elements and went to meeting.  Comong home it rained so hard that it went right through my rain coat,and rendered thy little Willie boy quite damp.  Second-day was still fine and wet so we fooled round the house most of the day.  In the morning we read a couple of Kenneth Grahame's "Dream Days" stories, and they certainly are pretty good.  We also read a crazy story by Paul [---] entitled "Love Will Find a Way" and "The Maltese Cat" by Rudyard Kipling.  In the afternoon we tried to take a sail but failed as Father had told the captain he could have a holiday.  However we went up to Whitall's and Greta and Alg and I went out  in a row-boat with a sail in it.  The little craft went sideways pretty nearly as fast as it did forwards so we did not get very far.  The rest of them went out in the rowboat and took a row.  This morning was cloudywhen we got up, but we had decided to go on a picnic over to Gilbert Stuart's so we did and before we had fairly started the sun shone forth in all his grandeur and we had a fine day.  I took Colin along and he behaved very well and seemed to enjoy it though he was pretty tired before we got home.  Altogether we walked about thirteen miles so thee sees we had plenty of exercise.  After lunch we walked back toward Kingston and got a good view of the country.  We had to hustle back to catch the five-thirty boat, but when we got to Saunders town we found we had time enough to eat some ice cream at a fair that was going on behind the hotel.  We walked over from the West Ferry and then Joe, Art, Alg and I took a short swim at Whitall's.  It is getting pretty late, the news and this sheet are rapidly coming to a close and I am tired so good night.With lots of love for both thee and Anna
   I am as ever
   Harold
   
   Please give my love to Miss Richardson.  Katherine and Jacquee say to thank thee very much for thy letter.  If any of you think of it you can remember me to the Leeds and the Hodges.  Tell me about the tournament and give my congratulations to the young Miss Hodge if she won. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Harold Evans:  1886-1977
Recipient:  Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Date: 1907-07-11
Title: 1907 July 11, Chester, to Grandparents

Chester
   July 11th, 1907
   
   My Dearest Grandparents, 
   
     I have been meaning to write to you for some time, but somehow have not got it done so far, with the exception of one poor postal. 
    
   Well, we have been having the best kind of a time. The voyage was most enjoyable for there were some very jolly people on board and there was lots of deck-room for games. 
   
    Since landing we have had a good deal of rainy weather but we don't seem to mind rain at all, and it has not interfered with our plans except once or twice when we have taken the coach instead of walking in the rain. The cold too, for it has been pretty chilly at times, has been rather a blessing than otherwise for it has made our walks and sightseeing tours all the more enjoyable, and the soft coal fires have been very nice and cheerful. 
    
   Our trip through Devonshire was a great success, though we can scarcely call it a walking trip as we walked only two days instead of four. From London we went straight to Tintagel, arriving there Seventh day evening. The cliffs are perfectly magnificent and we spent most of First day morning admiring them from King Arthur's Castle which is on a beautiful promontory. Finding it was impossible to get our bags to Bude on the Sabbath we took the only course open and drove there,  taking them with us. It was disappointing to miss the walk, but we had the more time at Tintagel of which we were very glad. Bude was rather uninteresting, but the walk from there to Clovelly is certainly charmingly quaint, though the tourists have, I suppose, come in such swarms that it seems as though the place were artificially natural (if you can guess what I mean by that). From Clovelly we went to Ilfracombe by boat and thence we coached to Lynton. Here again we had expected to walk but were again prevented, this time by rain. Lynton and Lynmouth took my fancy very much, and Paul Brown and I had a delightful walk up the Valley of the Lyn to Watermeet (where the East and West Lyn come together)The next day we walked to Porlock in spite of the rain.  We were very fortunate, however, and each time a shower overtook us we were able to reach shelter.  The dark, low-flying clouds with here and there a burst of sunshine rather added to the wildness of Exmoor and it was not hard to imagine that the Doones might almost still be living in some of the wild valleys.  We saw a herd of the wild Exmoor ponies but were not fortunate enough to see any of the red-deer which we were told at Porlock are not at all uncommon.  From Porlock we went to Tintern by train.  It was a rather tedious journey with a good deal of waiting.  The two place are only about thirty miles apart in a straight line, but it took us six hours toreach our destination.
   
   Tintern Abbey is a fine old ruin and takes you back to the Middle Ages, giving the whole town an air of antiquity.  The little chapel on the hill, which they say is older than the abbey was also very interesting and we spent last Seventh-day morning (till train time) wandering around them and taking pictures of them.
   
   We came straight to Chester from Tintern, and I must say I was rather disappointed in it.  The Cathedral is fine but the Walls do not amount to very much it seems to one.  We left here First-day evening and went to Carnarvon where we were very much interested in the Castle which dates I believe from 1256.  At Carnarvon the rain again interfered with our walking, and this time it rained so hard that the coach did not run and we were obliged to go to Bedd-gelert by train.  In some ways Bedd-gelert appeals to me more than most of the places we have seen.  It is such a quiet little town, "far from the madd'ning crowd's ignoble strife," nestled in the heart of the Welsh Mts, that I felt I should like to have more time there.  In the afternoon it stopped raining and we walked down the Pass of Aberglaslyn where they say the cliffs rise eight hundred feet from the road.  It is especially fine now as the recent rains have filled the streams very full and the little brooks tumbling over themselves down the mountainsides are very beautiful.
   
   When we awoke the next morning we were again greeted by the pleasant patter of rain, but we decided to walk to Beltus-y-coed at any rate.  I am very glad we did as it soon stopped raining and it was a very pretty walk.  At Capel-Curig we again saw the king (we had seen him twice in London) this time in plain every-day clothes in an automobile, on his way to Carnarvon.  The people had gathered from far and near and greeted him enthusiastically.  I was interested to her them sing the Welsh national anthem in their native language, which is certainly most unintelligible.  This morning we returned here and this afternoon visited the Cathedral after which Arthur and I went to see Eaton Hall, the Duke of Westminster's place.  As he is now in London we were allowed to go over his house, of course for a shilling, (everything is for a shilling) and were very much interestedto see how he lives.  It is a most magnificent place, "rich but not gaudy" and somehow seems much more "fit" than some of the summer cottages at Newport, though I imagine, as far as money goes that Newport's "cozy little cottages" are quite as grand.  Eaton Park is a beautiful stretch of land about three miles (or more) long and the deer grazing in the open fields were very pretty.
   
   I have now come to the end of my letter, and as it is growing late I must close.  Please give a great deal of love to Uncle Tom and to Aunt C. and Uncle W and their family and keep a great great deal for yourselves
   from your loving grandson
   Harold. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Harold Evans:  1886-1977
Recipient:  Francis Reeve  Cope:  1821-1909

Date: 1901-02-15
Title: 1901 February 15, to Family

Friday the 15th
   2/16/01
   
   Dearest Family, 
    
   I have just been reading a very nice letter from Polly, which I was rightly glad to get. If you think of it tell her so with a great deal of love and many thanks from me. Then I have some more beautiful flowers to thank thee for,  Father dear. They were truly beautiful, and are still lovely though some of them, the roses especially, show their age! Miss Richardson thought they were packed better and seemed fresher if anything than the ones from [Waltemates?]. I suppose my attack of Grippe was the excuse for my having these, but I am afraid it sounded more than it was.  I dont think the doctor was atallsure it was Grippe, & if it was I dont think Ive heard of such a light case!  Thank thee [---] so much , dearie, for the lovely flowers and the letter that came with them.  I'd like some more of the last mentioned article whenever thee has time & feels like it but thee really mustnt send me any more of the former.  While we are on the flower subject, just pay thyself $5.00 from me, will thee?  I have moneyin bank I think, & my flower bill this month or lately will about amount to that I think.  I have been indulging myself by sending some to different people.  Some violets to Miss Stedman (who has had a cold) etc.  People have been so kind to me here.
   
   I havent got to the boys photo. yet, there are so many things to say.  I think it is mighty nice, & I am so glad to have it.  It is a little like seeing them.  It stands on my bureau & this morning I burst out laughing just looking at it.  I could just imagine from seeing their expressions the kind of time they had getting it taken.  Edwards expression especially makes me laugh.  Thank you all for it ever so much.  You must feel somewhat repaid for all your trouble, for it is so nice to have it.  If AuntLilly or Ellie have room I think I'd like some of my other photos.  Any that you can find.  Also my other belt buckle, if you can find it easily.  I think I had it at Conanicut.  It is a clasp & looks something like silver.  It isnt important at all.  If you have a copy of "She Stoops to Conquer" that isnt too nice perhaps you would send that too by them, ormail it to me later if you havent finished reading it by the time they come.  I just thought maybe I'd like to read it as you all are.  Oh & if you know where my visiting cards are I think it would just as well for me to have some & a card case if you can find one.  I dont suppose I need them, but I might want one for something later on.  I'd rather also like to have my black bloomers (sort ofsilk they are made of) sometime, but there is no hurry.
   
   I am sending thee, dearest Mother, something I started for thee last Fall, but have only finished lately.  I thought thy old one was pretty well worn.  I dont think I showed thee when thee was here the hound glass I got Miss Webb to get me as a birthday present from thee.  Does thee remember thee told me to get one & never did? It is a very nice one I think.  The usual shape & white celluloid I think.  Now I am talking to thee.  I'll just say one or two things I want to.  First Miss Richardson asked me to thank thee for thy message & to remember her to thee.  She is so nice.  Sweet & jolly- I think I am very fortunate.  Thee ought to hear us laughing over things sometimes.  Sheis young & ready for fun.  Then if thee thinks of it when thee writes to Cousin Hannah wont thee give her my dear love and thanks for the little book & the letter she sent me at Christmas.  And please give my love to Cousin Sallie too and thank them both for the very nice message they sent me when I was first taken sick.  I have on the table in front of me a nice fat looking letter from thee, Mother dear, but I'm afraidI wont have time to read it before I finish this, as I am going sleighing in a few minutes & the postman may come before I get back.  Thank thee for it though ever so much.  And thank thee, dear Ern, for thy nice one which came the early part  of the week.  It was nice to hear from thee once again.  If there are any loose pictures ofour house & Awbury floatinh around send those with the other photos.
   
   Now good-by.  With a great deal of love for each one of you, dear ones, I am
   Your loving
   Anna
   
   PS.  Please give my love to the girls & remember me to Simon if he is still with us. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope  Evans:  1850-1939

Date: 1901-03-21
Title: 1901 March 21, to Mother

Thursday-
   March 21st
   
   Darling little Mother, 
   
   I am going to begin my letter to thee to-day, though I dont think I will send it at once, as I sent one home yesterday, which I imagine thee will receive the end of this week, that is if they send it on at once.  But as  I am expecting to be taken sick to-morrow or next day & may not feel like writing.  I dont think I will do any [---] to begin my letter now.  I think I have told most of the news in my letter home.  Wasn’t it fine about my going in to see the pictures?  I think I will mail thee the catalogueas thee might be interested, & it is very prettily gotten up.  I am sorry that the pictures in the catalogue are not the ones I especially enjoyed, for I should like to have had copies of some of them, & the pictures in the catalogue are pretty enough to frame-  I mean the finish & all.  The coloring of the Blue Boy & his pose Iliked, also the coloring of the “Little Girl with Doll” was lovely, but I didn’t care much for them.  The Blue Boys [---] was an unusual shade of blue, bordering on green but soft & not starey & there were lovely shades of old rose in the Little Girl etc.  The ones I marked were the ones I liked, especially “The Elder Sister,” & the Romney ones,a dear little head by Bougereau & perhaps some others I dont just think of.  The little childs head by Gilbert Stuart I was interested in & rather liked.  I hardly saw the modern ones at all, as we had only about 20 minutes there. 
   
   Wednesday morn. 
   I am almost sorry I didnt finish this letter up some days ago & send it  even if I could say all I wanted to- for I shant be able to do that now, as I want it to go by this morning’s mail-  I have been unwell since I started this- taken just on the day, isnt it fine?- I’ve been as regular as can be lately- in fact ever since last Fall sometime.  But I must hurry up &say some at least of the things I want to.  I sent the catalogue of the pictures to thee last Monday, but dont know whether thee will ever receive it, as I directed it to Berkley- Thee put Berkley, Md, at the head of thy letter so I thought I’d try it & I put my address on it, so it will come back to me, I guess,if it never reaches thee.  I also sent thee the little [sagne?] & hoods & socks I have been making, thinking thee might like to see them.  I hope thy trunk isnt very crowded or they may not be as welcome as I should like.  I directed them to Darlington, I dont believe the little sagne would bebig enough for Edith’s baby, so dont bother about it.  Thee will probably be a baby some of these days I shall want it for, & the little hoods may be useful, too.  I’m glad to have learned how to make them at any rate. 
   
   It is nearly time for  the post man, so I’m going to say good-by & write the rest again.  If any one of the boys should want to know something to give me on my birthday, I’m very fond of Burne-Jones “Hope” & should like a photo of it, but remember only if they want to knowsomething.  I must finish in a rush & with a great great deal of love, darling from
   
   Thy little Daughter.     

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Date: 1901-04-06
Title: 1901 April 6, to Daddy

Tuesday
   
   Dearest Daddy, 
   
   I amgoing to write a little note just to thee, thyself, to thank thee again for some more lovely flowers and for such a beautiful pair of scissors which came directed in thy handwriting.  I dont know whether they are a birthday present or not, but they are a mighty nice one, if they are, and I am ever so much obliged for them.  They are perfect daisies & I have cut out a shirt with them already, for, my dear, I am making a dress!  A little [---] & I say, "making it," but Miss Richardson sews most of it on the machine for me.  It is great fun & I hope it is going to be a great success!  I shall have to show it to you when you come.Now about the flowers.  They havent carried as well the last two times, especially the last, & Miss Richardson and I both think it is quite likely because the weather is warmer.  So, dearest, please dont send any more, for I really think it is a waste to send them so far, especially when I am so well now.
   
   Daddy dear, I wonder if thee would order me a  picture at Staton's for a wedding present for Margaret Kim.  I should like to send her a photo of Burne-Jones' [---] of "Hope" in about the $2.00 size framed in a wide dark frame without a mat, like the one Staton framed for me to give Edith & Ben when they were married.  Very likely he wont remember, but it is not very important that just havent is done.  I'm going to enclose a card & if thee can conveniently will thee order one for me?  Her address is
   Miss Margaret Kim
   1735 Chestnut St
   At least I think that's the no. at any rate I think it is near enough-  Please give my dear love to Alg & Ted & thankthem both for their last letters.  I am finishing this in rather a hurry so please excuse everything and take a good hug & kiss from
   Thy little Daughter 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Recipient:  Rachel Reeve Cope  Evans:  1850-1939
Date: 1901-04-06

   Daddy dear, I wonder if thee would order me a  picture at Staton's for a wedding present for Margaret Kim.  I should like to send her a photo of Burne-Jones' [---] of "Hope" in about the $2.00 size framed in a wide dark frame without a mat, like the one Staton framed for me to give Edith & Ben when they were married.  Very likely he wont remember, but it is not very important that just havent is done.  I'm going to enclose a card & if thee can conveniently will thee order one for me?  Her address is
   Miss Margaret Kim
   1735 Chestnut St
   At least I think that's the no. at any rate I think it is near enough-  Please give my dear love to Alg & Ted & thankthem both for their last letters.  I am finishing this in rather a hurry so please excuse everything and take a good hug & kiss from
   Thy little Daughter 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Creator:  Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Recipient:  Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Date: 1901-04-12
Title: 1901 April 12, to Family

Thursday
   
   Dearest Family, 
   
    This is a poor way to thank you for all the lovely things I have had from you since I last wrote, but I can't possibly get 5 letters written at once! So I am going to take this way for the present and maybe later I shall get round to you each separately, I wonder if you have been wondering why my thanks have been so long in coming, but dearies, I have been doing so many nice things that letter writing got left. Please don't think I am unappreciative, but I know you would be glad for me to do these other things,for they seem sort of steps toward getting well. But I must tell you about my birthday first of all. It was such a nice one. I started it by reading thy letter, deares mother, which came the night before. I suspected what it was and [---] it and think was the first birthday greeting I got.Then in the morning's mail came thy lovely nightgown case thee made me and dearest. I am so much obliged for it. I have begun to use it at once and think it a much nicer place for my nighty than the closet where used to hang. It came in perfect condition in spite of thy fears! A book from Frank also came in the mail and I had a letter from him, too, later. People have been lovely to me and all the people have been so kind.Miss Richardson gave me a dear little stamp box, Miss Barnard (one of the patients) sent me a lovely bunch of violets and another beautiful bunch came for me in the afternoon from Miss Stedman . When I came up from dinner I found a beautiful Easter Lily with Dr. Stedman's card!, & the afternoon mail brought me a book, a lovely letter and Easter card from Aunt Anna in the shape of a little book of pressedCalifornia wild flowers. Then just before supper a hugh package was carried up by one of the men and caused a great excitement. It was from Boston and that made it all the more mysterious! On openning it we found a beautiful engraving of Faith Hope & Charity & a letter & an accrostic from Grandpa discolosed the giver- Then in the evening Dr. Stedmancame into the parlor lugging what he pretended was a very heavy box & I recognized Father's handwriting.  He & Dr. Shine opened it for me right there regardless of the dirt the [---] made which was pretty nice of them I thought, & didn't I enjoy getting all your dear things!  The picture is a beauty, Father dear, & I am so much obliged for it.  Then the books.  First of all "The Rivals"- it is such a jolly little edition& I am so glad to have it, with the list of the parts you each took.  Thanks dear Alg ever so much. Then The Cardinals Snuff Box- you've heard of it but havent read it & I'm ever so much obliged to thee dear Ern for it- the Boston Experiences- Miss Webb & I looked at the pictures at once & I think we may read it out loud.  The pictures are awfully cute &I imagine it's amusing.  Thank thee, dear old Squid, a great many times.
   
   But even this was not the end, for Dr. Shine informed me that two boxes had gone up to my room & when I went up to bed I found some beautiful flowers from Father & a box of violets from Aunt Carrie-  I dont hardly know how to thank Father for besides the lovely flowers on my birthday, when I came home from church on Easter I found a lovely lily waiting for me in my room from him, so that my fireplace now has an Easter lily on each side of it.  Thank thee, dear Daddy, so much.  Thee gives thy little daughter much too much.  The rosesthis time carried better for a wonder- Now before I leave the subject of my birthday- please if you see Grandpa will you thank him so very much from me for the beautiful picture & the lovely acrostic.  I hope to write to him myself, but dont know just how soon I shall accomplish it & I'd likehim to know at once how much I appreciated both the picture & the poem.  Then dear Grandma too.  I had a letter from her & I think maybe a book I received without any card is from her.  It is a daisy & is called the Oxford Book of English Verse- If you can find out whether she send it please thank her ever so much & tell her I am delightedwith it.  Please give them both my love.  And will you give Aunt Carrie my love & thank her so much for the lovely violets.  I think it was so dear of her to send them.  I may get a letter written to her myself some of these days.  I'd like to send my love to Aunt Anna too & thank her for her dear letter &lovely Easter card & oh will you thank Aunt Lizzie Brown for the dear little book she sent me as an Easter card & please give her a great deal of love.
   
   I'm afraid this letter may be too full of messages to be very satisfactory, & I cant go on & tell you about anything else-  about my going to church or Anne & Evelyn's visit or anything, for it is nearly mail time & I want you to get this before Sunday.  I am finishing it on Friday afternoon you see.  Give my love to them at Church Lane if you think of it & thank dear Aunt H for her birthday letter.Thank thee, dearest Mother for thine, which came this morning, also Ern for a very nice one written on Sunday& Alg for one written the Sunday before.  With much much love to you all, dear ones, I am
   Your very loving
   Anna.
   
   P.S. I'm so excited over something.  You may  be able to guess in a few days what!!!
